column7: I sayde that foure sortes of people were the occasion of the trouble of hys Magisties shyppe thys Realme of Englande, but I sayd not that euerye man of these foure sorts was giltye of the tempest, therfore there muste be lottes, and examinacion of euerye deorce and of eche person in hys degree that the innocente be not punyshed, neither the transgressoure fauored.
column8: I said that foure sorts of people were the occasion of the trouble of his Majesties ship this Realm of England, but I said not that every man of these foure sorts was guilty of the tempest, Therefore there must be lots, and examination of every deorce and of eke person in his degree that the innocent be not punished, neither the transgressoure favoured.

column7: WE neuer rede in anye wryters whether they be holy or prophae of anye kyngedome or comune wealth that continually endured without tumultes, sedicion or warre, eyther by foreyn and outwarde enemies, eyther amonge it selfe by conspiracye, treason,

column8: & disobedience of Subjects of the same realm, and the same evil not being in time taken heed of, and Redressed, brought always the Kingdom or commune wealth from trouble and sedition unto utter PAGExxxiiii PAGExxxiiii PAGExxxiiii PAGExxxiiii ruin, and confusion.

column8: We shall never bring it to pass until such time as we agree and confess that Jonah is the occasion why the realm is thus unquieted, that is to say, as many as be in this realm, that neglect, or pervert their appointed vocation.

column8: But lest any man should think I condemned every man within the ship of your commune wealth, we will follow the Wisdom and commendable doings of these shippemen which were not only content to have found out Jonah (the cause of their trouble) by Lots, but also diligetly they examine him.

column8: & into the Citizens. All & every country or housbad ma that lives not of his labour, and Giveth him self to Idleness, and so moves Seditio and treason against their lawful King and Magistrate, or privily PAGExlii PAGExlii PAGExlii PAGExlii in their conventicles, and assemblies speak evil, curse, or provoke any thing against their Magistrates, they can nor will Learn, neither to know god, neither to obey their Prince:

column8: Yet is not this enough to confess our Faults, but therewythall we must make a Confessi of our Faith, but not such a Confessi as most men use, but such as may most be like unto Jonah.

column7: P A G Exlvii That these gentilyshe Mariners rebuke Ionas of dysobedience, it declareth the faute to be so greate when anye man leueth his vocacion and specially the vocacion of preching, that it meriteth and is worthy to be rebuked of all men.
column8: PAGExlvii PAGExlvii PAGExlvii PAGExlvii That these gentilyshe Mariners rebuke Jonah of dysobedience, it Declareth the fault to be so great when any man leveth his vocation and specially the vocation of preaching, that it merits and is worthy to be rebuked of all men.

column7: But suche is nowe the proude mindes of Byshops and pastours that it wyl suffer no rebuke, or Christian admonicion, but wil be lauded and praised yea in euel doyng and omissio of their vocacion, as it is to be seene in that horrible and wycked decre:
column8: But such is now the proud minds of Bishops and Pastors that it will suffer no rebuke, or Christian admonition, but will be lauded and praised yea in evil doing and omissio of their vocation, as it is to be seen in that horrible and wicked Decree:

column8: The word of God Come the seconde time to Jonah After this sort:

column8: Rise, go to Nineveh that great City and preach in it the preaching that I have spoken unto the of.

column7: That Ionas goeth not to the citie to preache of his own heade, but tarieth to be called vnto it by God, we learne no man shuld wysh, or desyre for any office or vocacion to a priuate commoditie, and his own lucre, but to tarye tyl God cal hym to it, chiefely the offyce of a byshop or preacher.
column8: That Jonah Goes not to the City to preach of his own head, but tarrieth to be called unto it by God, we Learn no man should wish, or desire for any office or vocation to a private commodity, and his own lucre, but to tarry till God call him to it, chiefly the office of a bishop or preacher.

column7: For that office hath so many difficulties, labours,
column8: For that office hath so many difficulties, labours,

column7: & daugers, that incase the man that is in it, be not wel perswaded ye he cam to it by ye calling of god, he shal neuer be able to endure the troubles anexed to the vocacio:
column8: & daugers, that incase the man that is in it, be not well persuaded you he cam to it by you calling of god, he shall never be able to endure the Troubles adnexed to the vocacio:

column7: as the perfit mans tidyousnes and werines therin declareth.
column8: as the perfect men tidyousnes and weariness therein Declareth.

column7: Iere. xx. who decreed wt hym selfe to haue preached no more, because of the malice of the people, and for the contempt that folowed him in doyng of hys vocacion.
column8: Jeremiah xx. who decreed with him self to have preached no more, Because of the malice of the people, and for the contempt that followed him in doing of his vocation.

column7: Euen so is the office of a good counceler & good magistrate that incase he loke not to come to hys dignitie and honour for ambicion, pride, and priuate lucre, but commeth whe he is called of God, he shal fynd so manye labours & vnquietnes in hys vocacion, that doubtles wer it P A G Eciiii not for God, he could be glad to leaue it to an other ma.
column8: Eve so is the office of a good counceler & good magistrate that incase he look not to come to his dignity and honour for ambition, pride, and private lucre, but comes when he is called of God, he shall find so many labours & unquietness in his vocation, that doubtless were it PAGEciiii PAGEciiii PAGEciiii PAGEciiii not for God, he could be glad to leave it to an other ma.

column7: For incase the magistrate doo any thyng cotrary vnto God, doutles he shal fal into two yuels, fyrst into Gods displeasure,
column8: For incase the magistrate do any thing contrary unto God, doubtless he shall fall into two yuels, fyrst into God's displeasure,

column7: & then the thing he doth shal neuer prosper, as it is to be scene by the Israelites that warred before they were commauded by God. Num. xiiii.
column8: & then the thing he does shall never prosper, as it is to be scene by the Israelites that warred before they were commanded by God. Num. xiiii.

column7: Let noma therfore run into an offyce before the tyme god cal him, neither bye hym selfe into y office as is now adaies comonly vsed:
column8: Let noma Therefore run into an office before the time god call him, neither buy him self into y office as is now adais commonly used:

column7: for I know surelye he that byeth wil sel,
column8: for I know surely he that buyeth will sell,

column8: & never do God, the King, neither the Subjects good service, but dishonour the First, and rob the other.

column7: that of al thinges in euery vocacion, idlenes & sloth must be chieflye auoyded, and labours exercysed:
column8: that of all things in every vocation, idleness & sloth must be chiefly avoided, and labours exercised:

column7: the whyche if we leaue vndone (being workes annexed wyth our vocacion) we declare oure selues vnmete for the roume and vocacio we be appointed vnto.
column8: the which if we leave undone (being works annexed with our vocation) we declare our selves unmeet for the room and vocacio we be appointed unto.

column8: Incase any man had a servant appointed to dreasse his meat in the kytchen, or to keep his horse in the stable,

column7: & yet wold neglect the labours & paynes that the offices ordinarily and of deuty requyred, who gladly would be contented wyth such a seruaunt, or desyre he shulde be preferred to anye offyce in his house?
column8: & yet would neglect the labours & pains that the Offices ordinarily and of duty required, who gladly would be contented with such a servant, or desire he should be preferred to any office in his house?

column8: Therefore commaudeth S. Paul that he that will not labour, should not eat. i. tes. iiii.

column8: PAGEcv PAGEcv PAGEcv PAGEcv The Third Doctrine of this fyrst part declared for asmuch as it behooves every man, to avoid idleness in his vocation,

column8: It is not the office of the Bishop to play the King and Lord, nor the Kings part to play the Bishop.

column7: For the kynges offyce is inoughe for a kynge, and the Bishoppes office inoughe for a Byshop, let them do the best they can, and studye eche of them in their office.
column8: For the Kings office is enough for a King, and the Bishops office enough for a Bishop, let them do the best they can, and study eke of them in their office.

column7: But let the kynge take hede he be able to iudge whether the Byshop do true seruice to God in his vocacion bi the worde of God, and let the Byshop do the same, take hede whether the kynge or councell wolde commaunde hym to do anye thynge contrarye to the workes of his vocacion, which is to preache gods worde:
column8: But let the King take heed he be able to judge whither the Bishop do true service to God in his vocation by the word of God, and let the Bishop do the same, take heed whither the King or council would command him to do any thing contrary to the works of his vocation, which is to preach God's word:

column7: incase he do, wyth knowledge and sobernes to admonyshe hym, and to brynge hym to a better mynde.
column8: incase he do, with knowledge and soberness to admonish him, and to bring him to a better mind.

column7: If yu be a iudge, remember thi name, and do the workes of ryght iudgemente.
column8: If thou be a judge, Remember thy name, and do the works of right judgement.

column8: If a Justice, do according to thy name:

column7: if a marchaunt, bye P A G Ecvi and sell truelye:
column8: if a merchant, buy PAGEcvi PAGEcvi PAGEcvi PAGEcvi and fell truly:

column8: In supplex ora, tu regna, tuque labora There be Three Images, the one of the Pope, the other of the Emperor, the Third of a plough man, and the verse Teaches all Three their duties.

column8: This I say, God to record, of no hatred but of love, for I am afraid of God's threteninges & vegeaunce towards them, if they amend not.

column8: I know my fault, and would gladly amend it if I could, but I am so old I can not preach, nor never used myself PAGEcvii PAGEcvii PAGEcvii PAGEcvii there unto.

column7: I wold aduise hym then to folow the doinges of Ualerius the Byshoppe of Hipponensis, that in hys olde and latter dayes perceiuinge hys age coulde not satysfye the laboures dewe vnto hys vocation, associated to hymself a coumpanion and coadiutor Saint Augustine, as he testifieth Epist. cxlviii.
column8: I would advise him then to follow the doings of Valerius the Bishop of Augustine, that in his old and latter days perceiving his age could not satisfy the labours dew unto his vocation, associated to himself a coumpanion and coadjutor Saint Augustine, as he Testifieth Epistle cxlviii.

column7: In the begynninge of that Epistle thus he wryteth.
column8: In the beginning of that Epistle thus he writes.

column7: Before al thynges I wold your godlye prudence shulde thinke in this our tyme nothing to be more acceptable, facile, or more desired of me the the office of a Bishop, priest, or deco, if their office be slightly & slederly vsed, but with God no thynge is more dampnable, miserable, or sorowful.
column8: Before all things I would your godly prudence should think in this our time nothing to be more acceptable, facile, or more desired of me the the office of a Bishop, priest, or deco, if their office be slightly & slederly used, but with God no thing is more damnable, miserable, or sorrowful.

column7: The same knewe Samuel: for in his age he instituted his sones to help and ease the intollerancye and importaunce of hys offyce^ so I woulde euerye Byshop and personne that for age or lacke of learnyng cannot do hys offyce, should institute and take vnto hym some wyse and learned preacher to helpe him, and not a synger as nowe is vsed.
column8: The same knew Samuel: for in his age he instituted his Sons to help and ease the intollerancye and importance of his offyce^ so I would every Bishop and person that for age or lack of learning cannot do his office, should institute and take unto him Some wise and learned preacher to help him, and not a synger as now is used.

column7: If this counsel and doinges of the godlye men rehersed before lyke the not, let the deuise some other lyke, and all is one to me, so they exchue the Ire of God.
column8: If this counsel and doings of the godly men rehearsed before like the not, let the devise Some other like, and all is one to me, so they Eschew the Ire of God.

column7: For doutles it is horrible to fall in this parte, into the handes of God.

column8: For if they bestow their Benefices for lucre or affection, to such as can not or will not fede with the word of God, the people of his cure, the patron shall die eternally for it as well as his blind and naughty curate, person, or vicar.

column7: Ionas now being an obediente seruaunt, loketh no more for a shyppe to flie, but goeth the nexte waye whether he is commaunded, though the iournye was paynefull and daungerous to the fleshe.
column8: Jonah now being an obedient servant, looketh no more for a ship to fly, but Goes the Next Way whither he is commanded, though the journey was painful and dangerous to the Flesh.

column8: But the Cross of trouble is not unprofitable to the Christians, it mortyfyeth the Flesh, so that in the afflicted dwells the Spirit of God, it excersiseth the faith and Proves Obedience.

column8: & such as have no living to Set it forth, or of malice whister, and secretly hindereth the setting forth of it, for doubtless At length, they shall not only drink of the wine of adversity, but be compelled to drink drags and all.

column8: so shall the auaricyous judge, the Covetous Marchat, and the traitorous and seditious Subject.

column7: P A G Ecxi The obedience of Ionas is set forth and comended with manye circumstaunces, and shulde therefore the better be noted.
column8: PAGEcxi PAGEcxi PAGEcxi PAGEcxi The Obedience of Jonah is Set forth and commended with many Circumstances, and should Therefore the better be noted.

column7: Fyrste, because he went the next waye to Niniue, and hyred none other, nor substituted hys suffragane, nor wente not into Samaria to aske coucell at hys fryndes what was beste to do, but went streighte way hym selfe.
column8: First, Because he went the next Way to Nineveh, and hired none other, nor substituted his suffragan, nor went not into Samaria to ask council At his Friends what was best to do, but went straight Way him self.

column7: The second circustance is worthy annotacio, that he dyd all thynges as the Lorde bad hym.
column8: The second circumstance is worthy annotacio, that he did all things as the Lord bade him.

column7: Wherein we are taughte to be diligente, we see all our doinges, actes, and obedience to be according, and as the worde of God biddeth.
column8: Wherein we Are taught to be diligent, we see all our doings, acts, and Obedience to be according, and as the word of God bids.

column7: And Niniue was a great citie to the Lord of three dayes iourney.
column8: And Nineveh was a great City to the Lord of three days journey.

column7: Thys dyscryption settethe forth the obedyence of Ionas, that diligentelye preached the roughe the hole cytye the pleasure of God, that it shoulde be destroyed wythin.xl. dayes.
column8: This dyscryption setteth forth the Obedience of Jonah, that diligently preached the rough the hold City the pleasure of God, that it should be destroyed within xl days.

column7: The cytye is called greate vnto God, that is to saye euerye greate cytye, as the Cedre of God, the mounte of God.
column8: The City is called great unto God, that is to say every great City, as the Cedre of God, the mount of God.

column7: &c. Or else it is called the cytye of God, for the wonderfull respecte and pitye that the Lorde had in the sauinge of it.
column8: etc. Or Else it is called the City of God, for the wonderful respect and pity that the Lord had in the Saving of it.

column7: Whether the cytye were thre dayes Iournye aboute, or else thre dayes space to vysytte all the P A G Ecxii streates thereof, it is not agreed yet vpon amog al wryters:

column7: F Astynge is a moderat vse and takynge of meate and drynke, lest the fleshe shoulde by aboundaunce and to muche of it, rebel and ouercome the spirite.
column8: Fasting Fasting is a moderate use and taking of meat and drink, lest the Flesh should by abundance and to much of it, rebel and overcome the Spirit.

column7: And thys fast eyther it is continually, or at certayne tymes vsed.
column8: And this fast either it is continually, or At certain times used.

column7: Priuate when any man consideryng and waiynge P A G Ecl hys owne infyrmyties, bindeth hym selfe fro meates, and drynkes, to tame and ouercome the vehemente, and lasciuious inclinacions thereof, to the obedyence and rule of the spirite.i. Corin. vii.
column8: Private when any man considering and waiynge PAGEcl PAGEcl PAGEcl PAGEcl his own infyrmyties, binds him self from Meats, and drinks, to tame and overcome the vehement, and lascivious inclinations thereof, to the Obedience and Rule of the Spirit i Corin. vii.

column8: All these things must you do, most Gracious King and you my honourable lords of his high and wysecouncel, if you will live in peace, and quietness.

column7: I do not exhorte your Maiestye nor your most honorable Counsell lyghtlye, but vpon greate, and wayghtye consideracion to remoue al these thynges, that be eyther the Deuyl^, ether mannes inuincion.
column8: I do not exhort your Majesty nor your most honourable Counsel lightly, but upon great, and weighty consideration to remove all these things, that be either the Devil, either Man's inuincion.

column7: P A G Elxxxii For in the scripture I fynde that God manye tymes is offended when we giue ^ym but halfe honour.
column8: PAGElxxxii PAGElxxxii PAGElxxxii PAGElxxxii For in the scripture I find that God many times is offended when we give them but half honour.

column7: Howe well began Hiiu the kynge of Israell.iiii.
column8: How well began Hihu the King of Israel iiii

column7: Regum. x. But because he remayned in the synnes of Hieroboam, hys kyngdome was not onelye afflycted, but at length distroied also.
column8: Regum. x. But Because he remained in the Sins of Jeroboam, his Kingdom was not only afflicted, but At length destroyed also.

column7: Abolyshe therfore godlye kynge all iniquytye, and permit not Masse nor such abhominacion to any man wyth in youre hyghnes realme:
column8: Abolah Therefore godly King all iniquity, and permit not Mass nor such abomination to any man with in your highness realm:

column7: no not to the straungers, whyche doubtles shoulde be an occacyon of slaunder to youre realme, and subiectes.
column8: no not to the Strangers, which doubtless should be an occasion of slander to your realm, and Subjects.

column7: For Asa the kyng of Iuda.iii.
column8: For Asa the King of Juda iii

column7: Regum. xv. remouyd hys mother from the rule, and gouernaunce of of the realme, because she had an Idole in a groue, the which her sonne the kyng brent.
column8: Regum. xv. removed his mother from the Rule, and governance of of the realm, Because she had an Idol in a grove, the which her son the King brent.

column7: The your magestie muste institute true, faythfull, and iudges of good conscyence.
column8: The your Majesty must institute true, faithful, and judges of good conscience.

column7: Then sende suche priestes throughe youre realme, that haue these twoo condycions.
column8: Then send such Priests through your realm, that have these twoo conditions.

column7: Fyrste that they teach, the yt thie teach the word of God.
column8: First that they teach, the that Thief teach the word of God.

column7: If your magestye doo these thynges, then shall God sed peace and quietnes to hys pleasure.
column8: If your Majesty do these things, then shall God sed peace and quietness to his pleasure.

column7: Farther, God shall make you a feare and terrour to fo^en and straunge nacions that know not the liuing god.
column8: Farther, God shall make you a Fear and terror to fo^en and strange Nations that know not the living god.

column7: And this your magesty shal auoeyde the better, if ye beware of flaterers, and thynk as Ioada in hys youth fauored the truthe of God, and in hys age P A G Eclxxxiii by flattery departed from it iiii. Reg. xii. so the same yuell and daunger maye corrupte your hyghnes.
column8: And this your Majesty shall auoeyde the better, if you beware of Flatterers, and think as Ioada in his youth favoured the truth of God, and in his age PAGEclxxxiii PAGEclxxxiii PAGEclxxxiii PAGEclxxxiii by flattery departed from it iiii. Reg. xii. so the same evil and danger may corrupt your highness.

column7: Then if it may please you to commaund more sondry tymes to haue sermos before your magestie, it wyll not be a lytle healpe to you yf they be wel made, wel borne awaye, and wel practised.
column8: Then if it may please you to command more sundry times to have Sermons before your Majesty, it will not be a little help to you if they be well made, well born away, and well practised.

column7: And seyng ther is in the yeare.viii. M.vii. C.lx. houres, it shall not be much for your highnes no nor for al your housholde, to bestow of the.lii. in the yere to heare the Sermon of God.
column8: And sing there is in the year viii M.vii. C.lx. hours, it shall not be much for your highness no nor for all your household, to bestow of the lii in the year to hear the Sermon of God.

column7: If your magesty do these thinges, the blud of youre people shal not be requyred at youre hands.
column8: If your Majesty do these things, the blood of your people shall not be required At your hands.

column7: But I rede both kyng and counsel to be admonished, and to amend thynges amysse.
column8: But I rede both King and counsel to be admonished, and to amend things amiss.

column7: Yf not, the kynge of Niniue wyth hys people, shall ryse a^ the later daye, and condempne bothe kynge and counsell to deathe.
column8: If not, the King of Nineveh with his people, shall rise a the later day, and condemn both King and counsel to death.

column7: For they conuerted at the preaching of one man:
column8: For they converted At the preaching of one man:

column7: yea at the preachyng of a straunger, we haue not only heard yt same by the mouth of straungers, but also by the mouth of our owne country men,
column8: yea At the preaching of a stranger, we have not only herd that same by the Mouth of Strangers, but also by the Mouth of our own country men,

column7: & that many tymes. Let vs therfore beleue and amende, or els we must peryshe.
column8: & that many times. Let us Therefore believe and amend, or Else we must perish.

column7: God preserue for ye death of Christ, the Kyngs magestie, al hys honorable councell wyth the hole realme.
column8: God preserve for you death of christ, the Kings Majesty, all his honourable council with the hold realm.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: Faultes eskaped in the pryntyng.
column8: Faults escaped in the pryntyng.

column7: The. iiii. Sermon
column8: The. iiii. Sermon

column7: Q Uecuque scripta sunt ad nostram doctrinam scripta sunt.
column8: Whosoever Whosoever Scripta sunt ad nostram Doctrinam Scripta sunt.

column7: All thinges which are writte ar writen for our eruottion & knowledge.
column8: All things which Are written Are written for our eruottion & knowledge.

column7: All thinges that are writte in Goddes boke, in the Byble boke, in the booke of the holy scripture, are written to be oure doctrine.
column8: All things that Are written in Goddess book, in the bible book, in the book of the holy scripture, Are written to be our Doctrine.

column7: I told you in my first sermon, honorable audience, that I purposed to declare vnto you. ii. thinges. The one what sede shuld be sowen in Gods field, in Goddes plough land.
column8: I told you in my First sermon, honourable audience, that I purposed to declare unto you. ii. things. The one what seed should be sown in God's field, in Goddess plough land.

column7: And the other who should be the sowers.
column8: And the other who should be the sower's.

column7: That is to say, what doctrin is to be taught in Christes church & congregacion, and what men shoulde be the teachers and preachers of it.
column8: That is to say, what Doctrine is to be taught in Christ's Church & congregation, and what men should be the Teachers and Preachers of it.

column7: The fyrst part I haue told you in the thre sermos past, in which I haue assaied to sette furth my plough, to proue what I coulde do.
column8: The fyrst part I have told you in the Three Sermons past, in which I have assayed to Set forth my plough, to prove what I could do.

column7: And now I shal tel you, who be the plowers, for Gods worde is a seede to be sowen in Goddes fielde, that is the faythful cogregacion,
column8: And now I shall tell you, who be the plowers, for God's word is a seed to be sown in Goddess field, that is the faithful cogregacion,

column7: & the preacher is the sower.
column8: & the preacher is the sour.

column7: And it is in the gospell.
column8: And it is in the gospel.

column7: Exiuit qui seminat seminare semen suum.
column8: Exiuit qui seminat seminare semen suum.

column7: He that soweth, the husbanman, the plowghman wente furth to sowe his seede, so that a preacher is resebled to a ploughma, as it is in a nother place.
column8: He that Soweth, the husbanman, the plowghman went forth to sow his seed, so that a preacher is resebled to a ploughma, as it is in a neither place.

column7: Nemo admota aratro manu, et a tergo respiciens aptus est regno.
column8: Nemo admota aratro manu, et a tergo respiciens Apt est regno.

column7: Dei. No man that putteth his hand to the plough and loketh backe, is apte for the kingdo of god?
column8: Dei. No man that putteth his hand to the plough and looketh back, is apt for the Kingdom of god?

column7: That is to say, let no preacher be negligente in doinge his office.
column8: That is to say, let no preacher be negligent in doing his office.

column7: Al be it this is <NOTE> one of the places yt hath ben racked,
column8: All be it this is one of the places that hath been racked,

column7: as I toulde you of rackyng scriptures.
column8: as I told you of racking Scriptures.

column7: And I haue bene one of the my selfe yt hathe racked it,
column8: And I have be one of the my self that hath racked it,

column7: I crye God mercye for it,
column8: I cry God mercy for it,

column7: & haue bene one of them that haue beleued and haue expounded it, agaynste relygious persons that would forsake theyr ordre which they had professed, and woulde go out of theyr cloyster, whereas in deed it toucheth not monkerye, nor maketh any thing at all for any such matter.
column8: & have be one of them that have believed and have expounded it, against religious Persons that would forsake their ordre which they had professed, and would go out of their cloister, whereas in deed it touches not monkery, nor makes any thing At all for any such matter.

column7: But it is directlye <NOTE> spoken of diligente preachyng of the worde of God.
column8: But it is directly spoken of diligent preaching of the word of God.

column7: For preachyng of the Gospel is one of Goddes plough workes, and the preacher is one of Goddes plough men.
column8: For preaching of the Gospel is one of Goddess plough works, and the preacher is one of Goddess plough men.

column7: Ye may not be offended wyth my similitude:
column8: You may not be offended with my similitude:

column7: in that I compare preachynge to the laboure & worke of ploughinge,
column8: in that I compare preaching to the labour & work of ploughing,

column7: & the preacher to a ploughman.
column8: & the preacher to a ploughman.

column7: Ye maye not be offended wyth thys my similitude, for I haue ben selaundred of some personnes for suche thynges.
column8: You may not be offended with this my similitude, for I have been selaundred of Some personnes for such things.

column7: It hath bene saied of me.
column8: It hath be said of me.

column7: Oh Latimer, nay, as for him I wil neuer beleue hym whyle I lyue, nor neuer trust him, for he lykened our blessed Ladye to a saffrone bagge, where in deede I neuer vsed that similitude,
column8: O Latimer, nay, as for him I will never believe him while I live, nor never trust him, for he likened our blessed Lady to a saffrone bag, where in deed I never used that similitude,

column7: But it was as I haue sayd vnto you before nowe, accordinge to that whiche Peter sawe before in the spirite of prophesy and sayed that there shoulde come afterwarde men:
column8: But it was as I have said unto you before now, according to that which Peter saw before in the Spirit of prophesy and said that there should come afterward men:

column7: Per quos via veritatis maledictis afficeretur, there shoulde come felowes by who the waye of truth should be yll spoke of and sclandred.
column8: Per quos via veritatis maledictis afficeretur, there should come Fellows by who the Way of truth should be ill spoke of and slandered.

column7: But i case I had vsed this similitude, it had not bene to be reproued, but myght haue bene wythout reproche.
column8: But i case I had used this similitude, it had not be to be reproved, but might have be without reproach.

column7: For I might <NOTE> haue sayed thus, as the saffrone bagge that hath bene full of saffron, or hath had saffron in it, doth euer after sauoure and smel of the swete saffron that it conteyned:
column8: For I might have said thus, as the saffrone bag that hath be full of saffron, or hath had saffron in it, does ever After savour and Smell of the sweet saffron that it contained:

column7: so oure blessed Ladye which conceyued & bare Chryste in her wombe, dyd euer after resemble the maners and vertues of that precious babe which she bare.
column8: so our blessed Lady which conceived & bore Christ in her womb, did ever After resemble the manners and Virtues of that precious babe which she bore.

column7: And what had oure blessed Ladie bene the worse for thys?
column8: And what had our blessed Lady be the Worse for this?

column7: or what dishonour was thys to our blessed Ladye.
column8: or what dishonour was this to our blessed Lady.

column7: But as preachers must be ware and circumspect yt ther geue not any iust occasion to be sclaundered and yll spoke of by the hearers, so must not the auditours be offended without cause.
column8: But as Preachers must be aware and circumspect that there give not any just occasion to be slandered and ill spoke of by the hearers, so must not the Auditors be offended without cause.

column7: For heauen is in <NOTE> the gospel likened to a musterde seede.
column8: For heaven is in the gospel likened to a musterde seed.

column7: It is compared also to a piece of leauen, as Chryst saith, that at the last day, he wyll come lyke a thiefe,
column8: It is compared also to a piece of leaven, as Christ Says, that At the last day, he will come like a thief,

column7: & what dishonoure is this to God?
column8: & what dishonour is this to God?

column7: or what derogation is thys to heauen?
column8: or what derogation is this to heaven?

column7: Ye maye not then, I say, be offended wyth my similitude, for because I lyken preaching to a ploughmans laboure & a prelate to a ploughman.
column8: You may not then, I say, be offended with my similitude, for Because I liken preaching to a ploughman's labour & a prelate to a ploughman.

column7: But now you wyll aske me whom I cal a prelate.
column8: But now you will ask me whom I call a prelate.

column7: A prelate <NOTE> is that man, what soeuer he be, yt hath a flocke to be taughte of hym, who soeuer hath any spirytuall charge in the fayethfull congregacion, and who so euer he be that hath cure of soule.
column8: A prelate is that man, what soever he be, that hath a flock to be taught of him, who soever hath any spiritual charge in the faithful congregation, and who so ever he be that hath cure of soul.

column7: And wel may the preacher and <NOTE> the ploughman be lykened together.
column8: And well may the preacher and the ploughman be likened together.

column7: Fyrst for theyr labour of all ceasons of the yere.
column8: Fyrst for their labour of all ceasons of the year.

column7: For there is no tyme of the yere, in whiche the ploughman hath not some speciall worke to do, as in my countrey in Lecester Shire, the ploughe man hath a tyme to set furth and to assaye his plough, and other tymes for other necessary workes to be done.
column8: For there is no time of the year, in which the ploughman hath not Some special work to do, as in my country in Leicester Shire, the plough man hath a time to Set forth and to assay his plough, and other times for other necessary works to be done.

column7: And the they also maye be likened to gether for the diuersitie of workes & varietie of offices yt they haue to do.
column8: And the they also may be likened to gether for the diversity of works & variety of Offices that they have to do.

column7: For as the ploughma first setteth futth his plough, and the tilleth hys lande, and breaketh it in furroughes, and sometyme ridgeth it vp agayne.
column8: For as the ploughma First sets futth his plough, and the Tilleth his land, and breaks it in furroughes, and sometime ridgeth it up again.

column7: And at an other tyme harroweth it,
column8: And At an other time harroweth it,

column7: & clotteth it, & somtyme doungeth it,
column8: & clotteth it, & sometime doungeth it,

column7: & hedgeth it, diggeth it, and weedeth it, pourgeth and maketh it cleane:
column8: & hedgeth it, diggeth it, and weedeth it, Purgeth and makes it clean:

column7: So the prelate, the preacher hath many diuers offices to <NOTE> do.
column8: So the prelate, the preacher hath many diverse Offices to do.

column7: He hath fyrst a busie worke, to bringe his parishioners to a tyght fayth, as Paule calleth it.
column8: He hath fyrst a busy work, to bring his parishioners to a tyght faith, as Paul calls it.

column7: And not to a swaruinge fayth, but to a fayeth that enbraceth Christ, and trusteth to hys merytes,
column8: And not to a swerving faith, but to a Faith that enbraceth christ, and Trusteth to his merits,

column7: <NOTE> a lyuely faith, a iustifiyng fayth, a faith that maketh a man righteous wythout respecte of workes.
column8: a lively faith, a justifying faith, a faith that makes a man righteous without respect of works.

column7: As ye haue it, werie wel declared and set furth in the Homily.
column8: As you have it, weary well declared and Set forth in the Homily.

column7: <NOTE> He hath the a busie worke I say, to bringe his flocke to a ryght fayth and then to cofirme them in the same fayth,
column8: He hath the a busy work I say, to bring his flock to a right faith and then to cofirme them in the same faith,

column7: Nowe castynge them downe wyth the lawe, and with threateninges of <NOTE> God for synne. Nowe rydginge them vp a gaine, with the gospel and wyth the promyses of Gods fauoure.
column8: Now casting them down with the law, and with threatenings of God for sin. Now rydginge them up a gain, with the gospel and with the promises of God's favour.

column7: Nowe wreding them, <NOTE> by tellyng them their faultes,
column8: Now wreding them, by telling them their Faults,

column7: & makynge them forsake synne.
column8: & making them forsake sin.

column7: Nowe clottinge them, by breakyng theyr stony hartes, and by making them supple herted, and makynge them to haue hertes of fleshe, that is soft hertes, and apt for doctryne to enter in.
column8: Now clottinge them, by breaking their stony hearts, and by making them supple herted, and making them to have herts of Flesh, that is soft herts, and apt for Doctrine to enter in.

column7: Nowe teachyng to knowe God ryghtely, and to knowe theyr duetie to God and to theyr neyghboures.
column8: Now teaching to know God ryghtely, and to know their duty to God and to their neighbours.

column7: Nowe exhorting them whe they knowe theyr duetye, that thei do it and be dilygente in it:
column8: Now exhorting them when they know their duty, that they do it and be dilygente in it:

column7: so that they haue a continuall worke to do,
column8: so that they have a continual work to do,

column7: Great is theyr busynes, and therefore greate shoulde be their <NOTE> hyre.
column8: Great is their business, and Therefore great should be their hire.

column7: They haue great laboures and therfore they ought to haue good liuynges, that they maye comodiously feade theyr flocke, for the preachyng of the woorde of God vnto the people is called meat.
column8: They have great labours and Therefore they ought to have good livings, that they may commodiously feade their flock, for the preaching of the word of God unto the people is called meat.

column7: Scripture calleth it meat. Not strawberies, that come but once a yeare and tarye not longe, but are sone gone:
column8: Scripture calls it meat. Not Strawberries, that come but once a year and tarry not long, but Are soon gone:

column7: but it is meat. It is no deynties.
column8: but it is meat. It is no dainties.

column7: The people muste haue meate that muste be familier and cotinuall, and dayly <NOTE> geue vnto them to fede vpon.
column8: The people must have meat that must be familiar and cotinuall, and daily give unto them to fede upon.

column7: Manye make a strauberye of it, ministrynge it but once a yeare, but suche do not thoffice of good prelates. For Christ sayeth.
column8: Many make a strauberye of it, ministering it but once a year, but such do not intent of good Prelates. For christ Saith.

column7: Quis putas est ser^^s prudens et fidelis?
column8: Quis putas est ser^^s Prudens et Fidelis?

column7: qui dat ^ibum in tempore.
column8: qui that ^ibum in tempore.

column7: Who thynke you is a wyse and a faythfull seruaunt?
column8: Who think you is a wise and a faithful servant?

column7: He that geueth meate in due tyme.
column8: He that Giveth meat in due time.

column7: So that he must at all tymes conuenyent preache dyligentyle.
column8: So that he must At all times convenient preach dyligentyle.

column7: Therefore sayeth he? Who trowe you is a faythefull seruaunte?
column8: Therefore Saith he? Who trow you is a faithful servant?

column7: He speaketh it as thoughe it were a rare thynge to fynde suche a one, and as thoughe he should saye, there be but fewe of theym to fynde in the world.
column8: He speaks it as though it were a rare thing to find such a one, and as though he should say, there be but few of them to find in the world.

column7: And how few of theim there be throughout this realme that geue meate to theirr flocke as they should do:
column8: And how few of them there be throughout this realm that give meat to theirr flock as they should do:

column7: the visitoures can best tell.
column8: the visitoures can best tell.

column7: To fewe, to fewe, the more is the pitie, and neuer so fewe as nowe.
column8: To few, to few, the more is the pity, and never so few as now.

column7: By this then it appeareth that a prelate or anye that hath cure of soule, must diligently and substancially worke and laboure.
column8: By this then it appears that a prelate or any that hath cure of soul, must diligently and substantially work and labour.

column7: Therfore sayeth Paul to Timothe.
column8: Therefore Saith Paul to Timothy.

column8: & it was of shedding blood and of destroiyng the cities of Moab.

column8: For (Saith he) cursed be he that Keepeth back his sword from shedding of blood.

column7: As Saule when he kepte backe the sworde from shedding of bloude, at what tyme he was sent agaynst Amalech, was refused of God for being disobedient to Goddes commaundementes, in that he spared Agag ye kynge.
column8: As Saule when he kept back the sword from shedding of blood, At what time he was sent against Amalek, was refused of God for being disobedient to Goddess Commandments, in that he spared Agag the King.

column7: So that, that place of ye prophet was spoken of them that wente to the distruction of the cityes of Moab, among the whiche there was one called Nebo, whiche was muche reproued for idolatrie, supersticion, pryde, auaiyce, crueltie, tiranny, and for hardenes of herte, and for these sinnes was plaged of God and destroied.
column8: So that, that place of you Prophet was spoken of them that went to the destruction of the cities of Moab, among the which there was one called Nebo, which was much reproved for idolatry, Superstition, pride, auaiyce, cruelty, tyranny, and for hardens of heart, and for these Sins was plagued of God and destroyed.

column8: Yet must I speak. For is there not reigning in London, as much pride, as much covetousness, as much cruelty, as much oppression, as much supersticio, as was in Nebo?

column8: they would have converted. And you Rulers and Officers be wise and circuspecte, look to your charge & see you do your duties, and rather be glad to amend your ill living, then to be angry when you Are warned or told of your fault.

column7: And yet wold god they were no worse then butterflyes.
column8: And yet would god they were no Worse then butterflies.

column7: Butterflyes do but their nature, the butterfly is not couetouse, is not gredy of other mens goodes, is not ful of enuy & hate red, is not malicious, is not cruel is not merciles.
column8: Butterflies do but their nature, the butterfly is not covetous, is not greedy of other men's goods, is not full of envy & hate read, is not malicious, is not cruel is not merciless.

column7: The butterflye glorieth not in her owne dedes, nor preferreth the tradicions of men before gods word, it comitteth not idolatri, nor worshippeth false gods.
column8: The butterfly Glorieth not in her own Deeds, nor preferreth the traditions of men before God's word, it Committeth not idolatri, nor Worshippeth false God's.

column7: But London can not abide to be rebuked, suche is the nature of man.
column8: But London can not abide to be rebuked, such is the nature of man.

column8: If they be rubbed on the gale:

column8: But how shall I speak well of them.

column8: If you could be content to receive and follow the word of God and favour good Preachers, if you could bear to be told of your Faults, if you could amend when you hear of them:

column8: if you would be glad to reform that is amiss:

column7: But London was neuer so yll as it is now.
column8: But London was never so ill as it is now.

column7: In tymes past, men <NOTE> were full of pitie and compassyon, but nowe there is no pitie, for in London their brother shal dye in the streetes for colde, he shal lye sycke at their doore betwene stocke & stock.
column8: In times past, men were full of pity and compassion, but now there is no pity, for in London their brother shall die in the streets for cold, he shall lie sick At their door between stock & stock.

column7: I cannot tel what to cal it, and perishe there for huger, was there any more vnmercifulnes in Nebo?

column7: I thinke not. In tymes paste when any ryche <NOTE> man dyed in London, they were wont to healpe the pore scholars of the vniuersityes with exhiby^ion.

column8: When any man died, they would Bequeath great sums of money toward the relief of the poor,

column7: When I was a scholer in Cambrydge my selfe,
column8: When I was a scholar in Cambridge my self,

column7: I harde very good report of London and knewe many that had reliefe of the ryche menne of London, but nowe I can heare no suche good reporte, and yet I enquire of it, and herken for it, but now charitie <NOTE> is waxed cold, none healpeth the scholer, nor yet the poore.
column8: I harden very good report of London and knew many that had relief of the rich men of London, but now I can hear no such good report, and yet I inquire of it, and harken for it, but now charity is waxed cold, none Helpeth the scholar, nor yet the poor.

column7: And in those dayes what dyd, they whan they helped the scholers?

column8: Mary they maintained & gave them livings that were very Papists and professed you Popes Doctrine,

column7: & nowe that the knoweledge of Gods word is brought to lyghte, and many earnestly study and labour to sette it forth now almost no man healpeth to maintayne them.
column8: & now that the knowledge of God's word is brought to Light, and many earnestly study and labour to Set it forth now almost no man Helpeth to maintain them.

column7: Oh London <NOTE> London, repente repente, for I thynke God is more dyspleased with London, then euer he was with the citie of Nebo.
column8: O London London, Repent Repent, for I think God is more displeased with London, then ever he was with the City of Nebo.

column7: Repent therfore repent London, and remembre that the same god liueth now that punished Nebo, euen ye same god & none other,
column8: repent Therefore Repent London, and Remember that the same god lives now that punished Nebo, even you same god & none other,

column7: & he wyll punyshe synne as well nowe as he dyd then, and he wyll punish the iniquitie of London as well as he did them of Nebo.
column8: & he will Punish sin as well now as he did then, and he will Punish the iniquity of London as well as he did them of Nebo.

column7: Amend therfore. And ye that be prelates <NOTE> loke well to your offyce, for right prelatynge is buisye labouryng & not lordyng.
column8: Amend Therefore. And you that be Prelates look well to your office, for right prelatynge is busy labouring & not lording.

column7: Therfore preache and teache, and let your ploughe be doyng, ye lordes I saye that lyue lyke loyterers, loke well to your offyce, the plough is your office & charge.
column8: Therefore preach and teach, and let your plough be doing, you Lords I say that live like loiterers, look well to your office, the plough is your office & charge.

column7: If you liue idle & loyter, you do not your duetye, you folowe not youre vocacion, let your ploughe therfore be going and not cease, that the groud maye brynge foorth fruite.
column8: If you live idle & loiter, you do not your duty, you follow not your vocation, let your plough Therefore be going and not cease, that the Ground may bring forth fruit.

column7: But nowe me thynketh I heare one <NOTE> saye vnto me, wotte you what you say?
column8: But now me Thinketh I hear one say unto me, wot you what you say?

column7: It is a worcke? It is a labour?
column8: It is a work? It is a labour?

column7: how then hath it happened, that we haue had so manye hundred yeres, so many vnpreachynge prelates, lordyng loyterers and idle ministers?
column8: how then hath it happened, that we have had so many hundred Years, so many vnpreachynge Prelates, lording loiterers and idle Ministers?

column7: ye would haue me here to make aunswere and to shewe the cause thereof.
column8: you would have me Here to make answer and to show the cause thereof.

column7: Nay, this lande is not for me to ploughe, it is to stonye, to thornye, to harde for me to plough.
column8: Nay, this land is not for me to plough, it is to stony, to thorny, to harden for me to plough.

column8: They have so many things that make for them, so many things to say for them selves, that it is not for my weak term to plough them.

column8: They have to say for them selves long customs ceremonies, and authorytie, placing in parliament, and many things more.

column7: And I feare me thys lande is not yet rype to be ploughed.
column8: And I Fear me this land is not yet ripe to be ploughed.

column8: For as the saying is,

column8: It lacketh weathering: This get lacketh weathering, At jest Way it is not for me to plough.

column8: For what shall I look for among thorns but pricking and scratching?

column7: what among stones but stumbling?
column8: what among stones but stumbling?

column8: What (I had almost said) among Serpents but stinging?

column7: But this muche I dare saye, that sence lordyng and loiteryng <NOTE> hath come vp, preaching hathe come downe contrary to the Apostelles tymes.
column8: But this much I Dare say, that sense lording and loitering hath come up, preaching hath come down contrary to the Apostles times.

column7: For they preached and lorded not.
column8: For they preached and lorded not.

column8: And now they lord and preach not.

column8: For they that be Lords will ill go to plough.

column7: It is no mete office for theym.
column8: It is no meet office for them.

column7: It is not seming for their estate.
column8: It is not seeming for their estate.

column7: Thus came vp lordyng loyterers,
column8: Thus Come up lording loiterers,

column7: Thus crept in vnpreachynge prelates, and so haue they longe continewed.
column8: Thus crept in vnpreachynge Prelates, and so have they long continued.

column7: For howe many vnlearned prelates haue we now at this daye?
column8: For how many unlearned Prelates have we now At this day?

column7: And no meruel. For if ye plough me that now be, were made lords they woulde cleane geue ouer ploughynge, they woulde leaue of their laboure and fall to lordyng outright, and let ye plough stande.
column8: And no Marvel. For if you plough me that now be, were made Lords they would clean give over ploughing, they would leave of their labour and fallen to lording outright, and let you plough stand.

column7: And then both ploughes not walkyng, nothyng should be in the common weale but hounger.
column8: And then both ploughs not walking, nothing should be in the Common weal but hunger.

column8: For ever sense the Prelates were made lords and Nobles, the plough Stands, there is no work done;

column7: ye people sterue. Thei hauke, they hunt, thei card, they dyce, they pastyme in their prelacies with galaunte gentlemen, with theyr daunsyng minyons, and with their freshe copanions, so that ploughyng is sette a syde.
column8: you people starve. They hawk, they hunt, they carded, they dice, they pastime in their prelacies with galaunte gentlemen, with their dancing minyons, and with their fresh copanions, so that ploughing is Set a side.

column7: And by the lordyng and loytryng, preachyng and plough yng is cleane gone.
column8: And by the lording and loitering, preaching and plough yng is clean gone.

column7: And thus yf the ploughmenne of the countrey,
column8: And thus if the ploughmenne of the country,

column7: were as negligente in theyr office, as prelates be, we shoulde not longe lyue for lacke of sustynaunce.
column8: were as negligent in their office, as Prelates be, we should not long live for lack of sustynaunce.

column7: And as it is necessary for to haue this ploughyng for the sustentacion of the bodye:
column8: And as it is necessary for to have this ploughing for the sustentation of the body:

column7: so muste we haue also the other for the satisfaction of the sowle, or elles wee canne not lyue longe gostly.
column8: so must we have also the other for the satisfaction of the soul, or Else we can not live long ghostly.

column7: For as the bodie wasteth <NOTE> and consumeth away for lacke of bodilye meate:
column8: For as the body wastes and consumeth away for lack of bodily meat:

column7: so doeth the soule pyne awaye for default of gostly meate.
column8: so doth the soul pine away for default of ghostly meat.

column7: But there be two kyndes of inclosynge to lette or hynder <NOTE> bothe these kyndes of ploughyng.
column8: But there be two Kinds of enclosing to let or hinder both these Kinds of ploughing.

column7: The one is an inclosyng to let or hynder the bodily ploughynge, and the other to let or hinder the holy daye ploughyng, the churche ploughing.
column8: The one is an enclosing to let or hinder the bodily ploughing, and the other to let or hinder the holy day ploughing, the Church ploughing.

column7: The bodylye ploughynge, is taken in and enclosed thorowe syngular commoditie.
column8: The bodily ploughing, is taken in and enclosed thorough singular commodity.

column7: For what man will lette goe or dimynyshe his priuate commoditie for a commune welthe?
column8: For what man will let go or dimynyshe his private commodity for a commune wealth?

column7: and who wyll susteyne any damage for the respecte of a publique commoditie?
column8: and who will sustain any damage for the respect of a public commodity?

column7: The other plough also no manne is diligent to sette forewarde, nor no manne wyll herken to it. but to hynder and lette it, al mennes eares are open, yea and a greate manye of this kynde of ploughmen whiche are very busye and woulde seeme to be verye good workemenne.
column8: The other plough also no man is diligent to Set forward, nor no man will harken to it. but to hinder and let it, all men's ears Are open, yea and a great many of this kind of ploughman which Are very busy and would seem to be very good workemenne.

column7: I feare me some be rather mocke gospellers then faithefull ploughmen.
column8: I Fear me Some be rather mock Evangelists then faithful ploughman.

column7: I knowe many my selfe that professe the gospel, and lyue nothyng there after.
column8: I know many my self that profess the gospel, and live nothing there After.

column7: I knowe them, and haue been conuersaunte with some of theym.
column8: I know them, and have been conversant with Some of them.

column7: I knowe theym, and I speake it with an heauye hearte,
column8: I know them, and I speak it with an heavy heart,

column7: there is as little charitie & good liuynge in them, as in any other, accordyng to that whiche Christ sayed in the Gospell to the great numbre of people that folowed hym, as thoughe they had had an earnest zeale to his doctryne, where as in dede they had it not.
column8: there is as little charity & good living in them, as in any other, according to that which christ said in the Gospel to the great numbered of people that followed him, as though they had had an earnest zeal to his Doctrine, where as in deed they had it not.

column7: Non quia vidistis signa, sed quia comedistis de panibus.
column8: Non quia Vidistis Signs, sed quia comedistis de panibus.

column7: Ye folowe me (saieth he) not because ye hau seene the sygnes and myracles that I haue dooen, but because ye haue eaten the breade and refreshed your bodies.
column8: You follow me (Saith he) not Because you hau seen the Signs and Miracles that I have done, but Because you have eaten the bread and refreshed your bodies.

column7: Therfore you folowe me, so that I thinke manye one nowe a dayes professeth the Gospell for the liuynge sake, not for the loue they beare to gods word.
column8: Therefore you follow me, so that I think many one now a days Professes the Gospel for the living sake, not for the love they bear to God's word.

column7: But they that wil be true ploughmen muste worke faythfully for Goddes sake, for the edifiyng of theyr brethren.
column8: But they that will be true ploughman must work faithfully for Goddess sake, for the edifying of their brothers.

column7: And as dilygentlye as the husbande man plougheth for the sustentacion of the bodie:
column8: And as diligently as the husband man plougheth for the sustentation of the body:

column7: so dilygentlye muste the prelates and ministers labour for the fedynge of the soule:
column8: so diligently must the Prelates and Ministers labour for the feeding of the soul:

column7: bothe the ploughes muste styll be doynge, as moost necessarye for man.
column8: both the ploughs must still be doing, as most necessary for man.

column7: And wherefore are magistrates ordayned, but that the tranquillitye of the commune weale maye bee confirmed limiting both ploughes.
column8: And Wherefore Are Magistrates ordained, but that the tranquillity of the commune weal may be confirmed limiting both ploughs.

column7: But nowe for defaulte of vnpreachynge Prelates me thynke I coulde gesse what myghte be sayed for excusyng of theym.
column8: But now for default of vnpreachynge Prelates me think I could guess what might be said for excusing of them.

column7: They are soo troubeled wyth lordlye liuyng, they be so placed in palacies, couched in courtes, ruffelyng in their rentes, dauncyng in their dominions, burdened with ambassages, paperyng of their paunches lyke a Monke that maketh his Jubilie, mounchynge in their maungers, and moilyng in their gay manoures and mansyons, and so troubeled wyth loyterynge in theyr Lordeshyppes:
column8: They Are so troubled with lordly living, they be so placed in palaces, couched in Courts, ruffling in their rents, dancing in their Dominions, burdened with ambassages, paperyng of their paunches like a Monk that makes his Jubilee, mounchynge in their mangers, and moiling in their gay manoures and mansyons, and so troubled with loitering in their Lordships:

column7: that they canne not attende it.
column8: that they can not attend it.

column7: They are otherwyse occupyed, somme in the Kynges matters, some are ambassadoures, some of the priuy councell, some to furnyshe the courte, some are Lordes of the Parlyamente, some are Presydentes, and some comptrollers of myntes. Well, well.
column8: They Are otherwise ocupied, sum in the Kings matters, Some Are Ambassadors, Some of the privy council, Some to furnish the court, Some Are lords of the Parliament, Some Are Presidents, and Some comptrollers of mints. Well, well.

column7: Is this their duetie? Is this theyr offyce?
column8: Is this their duty? Is this their office?

column7: Is this their callyng? should we haue ministers of the church to be comptrollers of the myntes?
column8: Is this their calling? should we have Ministers of the Church to be comptrollers of the mints?

column7: Is this a meete office for a prieste that hath cure of soules?
column8: Is this a meet office for a priest that hath cure of Souls?

column7: Is this his charge? I woulde here aske one question:
column8: Is this his charge? I would Here ask one question:

column7: I would fayne knowe who comptrolleth the deuyll at home at his paryshe, whyle he comptrolleth the mynte?
column8: I would fain know who comptrolleth the Devil At home At his parish, while he comptrolleth the Mynte?

column7: If the Apostles myghte not leaue the offyce of preachynge to be deacons, shal one leaue it for mintyng?
column8: If the Apostles might not leave the office of preaching to be Deacons, shall one leave it for mintyng?

column7: I can not tell you, but the saying is;
column8: I can not tell you, but the saying is;

column7: that synce priestes haue been mynters, money hath been wurse then it was before.
column8: that since Priests have been Minters, money hath been Worse then it was before.

column7: And they saye that the euylnesse of moneye hath made all thynges dearer.
column8: And they say that the euylnesse of money hath made all things Dearer.

column7: And in this behalfe I must speake to England.
column8: And in this behalf I must speak to England.

column7: Heare my coutrey Englande, as Paule sayed in his firste epystle to the Cor. vi.
column8: Hear my country England, as Paul said in his First epistle to the Cor. vi.

column7: Chap. For Paule was no sittynge byshoppe, but a walkynge and a preachynge byshoppe.
column8: Chap. For Paul was no sitting bishop, but a walking and a preaching bishop.

column7: But when he wente from them, he lefte there behynde hym the ploughe goynge styll, for he wrote vnto theym and rebuked theym for goynge to lawe and pleadynge theyr causes before Heathen Judges.
column8: But when he went from them, he left there behind him the plough going still, for he wrote unto them and rebuked them for going to law and pleading their Causes before Heathen Judges.

column7: Is there (saye th he) vtterlye among you no wyse manne, to be an arbitratoure in matters of iudgemente?
column8: Is there (say that he) utterly among you no wise man, to be an arbitratoure in matters of judgement?

column7: What? not one of all that canne iudge betwene brother and brother?
column8: What? not one of all that can judge between brother and brother?

column7: But one brother go to lawe with an other, and that vnder heathen Judges?
column8: But one brother go to law with an other, and that under heathen Judges?

column7: Constitu^te contempt^s qui sunt in ecclesia?
column8: Constitu^te contempt^s qui sunt in Church?

column7: et cere. Appointe them Judges that are most abiect, and vyle in the congregacion, whiche he speaketh in rebukyng them, for (saieth he) Ad exscenciam vestram dico.
column8: et cere. Appoint them Judges that Are most abject, and vile in the congregation, which he speaks in rebuking them, for (Saith he) Ad exscenciam vestram dico.

column7: I speke it to your shame.
column8: I speak it to your shame.

column7: So Englande I speke it to thy shame.
column8: So England I speak it to thy shame.

column7: Is there neuer a noble ma to be a lord presybente,
column8: Is there never a noble ma to be a lord presybente,

column7: but it muste be a prelate?
column8: but it must be a prelate?

column7: Is there neuer a wyse manne in the realme to be a Comptroller of the minte?
column8: Is there never a wise man in the realm to be a Comptroller of the Mint?

column7: I speake it to your shame,
column8: I speak it to your shame,

column7: I speake it to youre shame.
column8: I speak it to your shame.

column7: If there be neuer a wyse man, make a water bearer, a tinker, acobler, a slaue, a page, comptroller of the Mynte.
column8: If there be never a wise man, make a water bearer, a tinker, acobler, a slave, a page, comptroller of the Mynte.

column7: Make a meane gentileman, a groome, a yeoman, make a poore beggar Lorde president.
column8: Make a mean gentleman, a groom, a yeoman, make a poor beggar Lord president.

column7: Thus I speake not that I would haue it so, but to your shame.
column8: Thus I speak not that I would have it so, but to your shame.

column7: If there be neuer a gentleman meete nor able to be Lorde presydente.
column8: If there be never a gentleman meet nor able to be Lord presydente.

column7: For why are not the noble men and yonge gentleme of Englad, so brought vp in knowledge of God and in learnynge, that they maye be able to execute offyces in the commune weale?
column8: For why Are not the noble men and young Gentlemen of Englad, so brought up in knowledge of God and in learning, that they may be able to execute Offices in the commune weal?

column7: The Kynge hath a greate many of wardes and I trowe there is a courte of wardes, why is there not a schole for the wardes, as well as there is a courte for their landes?
column8: The King hath a great many of wards and I trow there is a court of wards, why is there not a school for the wards, as well as there is a court for their Lands?

column7: Why are they not set in scholes, where they maye learne?
column8: Why Are they not Set in Schools, where they may Learn?

column7: Or why are they not sent to the vniuersities, that they maye be able to scrue the kyng when they come to age?
column8: Or why Are they not sent to the universities, that they may be able to scrue the King when they come to age?

column7: Yf the wardes and young gentlemen were well brought vp in learnyng and in the knowledge of God, they would not when they come to age, so muche geue theym selues to other vanities.
column8: If the wards and young gentlemen were well brought up in learning and in the knowledge of God, they would not when they come to age, so much give them selves to other vanities.

column7: And if the nobilitie be well trayned in godlye learnyng, the people would folow the same traine.
column8: And if the Nobilt be well trained in godly learning, the people would follow the same train.

column7: For truly, such as the noble men be, suche wyll the people be.
column8: For truly, such as the noble men be, such will the people be.

column7: And nowe the onely cause, why noble <NOTE> menne be not made Lorde presidentes, is because they haue not been broughte vp in learnyng.
column8: And now the only cause, why noble men be not made Lord Presidents, is Because they have not been brought up in learning.

column7: Therfore for the loue of GOD, appoint teachers and scholemaisters, you that haue charge of youth, and geue the teachers stipendes worthy their paines, that they maye brynge theym vp in Grammer, in Logike, in Rethorike, in Philosophie, in the ciuyle lawe, and in that whiche I can not leaue vnspoken of, the worde of God.
column8: Therefore for the love of GOD, appoint Teachers and Schoolmasters, you that have charge of youth, and give the Teachers Stipends worthy their pains, that they may bring them up in Grammar, in Logic, in Rhetoric, in Philosophy, in the ciuyle law, and in that which I can not leave unspoken of, the word of God.

column7: Thankes be vnto god the nobilitie, otherwyse is very well broughte vp in learnynge and godlines, to the great ioye and comfort of England, so that there is nowe good hope in the youth, that we shal an other day haue a florishyng comon wealth, consideryng theyr godlye educacion.
column8: Thanks be unto god the Nobilt, otherwise is very well brought up in learning and godliness, to the great joy and Comfort of England, so that there is now good hope in the youth, that we shall an other day have a flourishing Common wealth, considering their godly education.

column7: Yea, & there be al ready noble men ynoughe though not so many as I woulde wyshe able to be Lorde presidentes, and wise menne inough, for the mynt.
column8: Yea, & there be all ready noble men enough though not so many as I would wish able to be Lord Presidents, and wise men enough, for the mint.

column7: And as vnmeete a thynge it is for bishoppes to be Lorde presidentes or priestes to be mynters, as it was for the Corthinthyans to pleade matters of variaunce before heathen Judges.
column8: And as unmeet a thing it is for Bishops to be Lord Presidents or Priests to be Minters, as it was for the Corinthians to plead matters of variance before heathen Judges.

column7: It is also a sclaunder to the noble men, as thoughe they lacked wisedome, and learnyng to be able for suche offyces, or elles were no men of conscience, or els were not meete to be trusted, and able for suche offyces.
column8: It is also a slander to the noble men, as though they lacked Wisdom, and learning to be able for such Offices, or Else were no men of conscience, or Else were not meet to be trusted, and able for such Offices.

column7: And a prelate hath a charge & cure otherwyse, and therfore he cannot discharge his duetie, and be a Lorde presydent to.
column8: And a prelate hath a charge & cure otherwise, and Therefore he cannot discharge his duty, and be a Lord president to.

column7: For a presidentshippe requireth a whole man, and a byshoppe can not be two menne.
column8: For a presidentship requires a Whole man, and a bishop can not be two men.

column7: A bishoppe hath his offyce, a flock to teache, to loke vnto, and there for he can not meddle wyth an other offece, whiche alone requyreth a whole man.
column8: A bishop hath his office, a flock to teach, to look unto, and there for he can not meddle with an other offence, which alone requireth a Whole man.

column7: He should therfore geue it ouer to whome it is meete, and laboure in his owne busynesse, as Paule wryteth to the Thessalonians.
column8: He should Therefore give it over to whom it is meet, and labour in his own business, as Paul writes to the Thessalonians.

column7: Lette euery man do his owne busynes, and folow his callyng.
column8: Let every man do his own business, and follow his calling.

column7: Let the priest preache, and the noble men handle the temporal matters.
column8: Let the priest preach, and the noble men handle the temporal matters.

column7: Moyses was a meruailous manne, a good man.
column8: Moses was a marvelous man, a good man.

column7: Moyses was a wonderful felowe, and did his duetye being a maryed man.
column8: Moses was a wondered fellow, and did his duty being a married man.

column7: We lacke suche as Moyses was.
column8: We lack such as Moses was.

column7: Well, I woulde all menne would loke to their dutie, as God hath called them, and then we shoulde haue a florishyng christyan commune weale.
column8: Well, I would all men would look to their duty, as God hath called them, and then we should have a flourishing christian commune weal.

column7: And nowe I woulde aske a straunge question.
column8: And now I would ask a strange question.

column7: Who is the most diligente bishoppe and prelate in all England, that passeth all the reste in doynge his office I can tell, for I knowe him who it is,
column8: Who is the most diligent bishop and prelate in all England, that passes all the rest in doing his office I can tell, for I know him who it is,

column7: I knowe hym well. But nowe I thynke I se you listyng and harkening, that I shoulde name hym.
column8: I know him well. But now I think I see you listing and Harkening, that I should name him.

column7: There is one that passeth all the other, and is the moste diligent prelate & preacher in al England.
column8: There is one that passes all the other, and is the most diligent prelate & preacher in all England.

column7: And wil ye know who it is?
column8: And will you know who it is?

column7: I wyll tell you. It is the Deuyll.
column8: I will tell you. It is the devil.

column7: He is the moste dilygent preacher of all other, he is neuer out of his dioces, he is neuer from his cure, ye shall neuer fynde hym vnoccupyed, he is euer in his patishe, he keepeth resydence at all tymes, ye shal neuer fynde hym oute of the way, call for hym when you will, he is euer at home, the dilygenteste preacher in all the realme, he is euer at his ploughe, no lordynge nor loyteryng canne hynder hym, he is euer appliynge his busynes, ye shal neuer fynde hym idle I warraunte you.
column8: He is the most diligent preacher of all other, he is never out of his diocese, he is never from his cure, you shall never find him unoccupied, he is ever in his patishe, he Keepeth resydence At all times, you shall never find him out of the Way, call for him when you will, he is ever At home, the dilygenteste preacher in all the realm, he is ever At his plough, no lordynge nor loitering can hinder him, he is ever appliynge his business, you shall never find him idle I warrant you.

column7: And his office is to hynder religyon, to mayntayne supersticion, to set vp Idolatrie, to teache al kynd of poperye.
column8: And his office is to hinder Religion, to maintain Superstition, to Set up Idolatry, to teach all kind of popery.

column7: He is readye as can be wyshed, for to sette forth his ploughe, to deuyse as manye wayes as can be, to deface and obscure Goddes glorye.
column8: He is ready as can be wished, for to Set forth his plough, to devise as many ways as can be, to deface and Obscure Goddess glory.

column7: Where the Deuyl is resydente and hath his ploughe goyng:
column8: Where the devil is resydente and hath his plough going:

column7: there away with bookes, and vp with candelles, awaye with Bybles and vp with beades, awaye with the lyghte of the gospel, and vp with the lyghte of candelles, yea at noone dayes.
column8: there away with books, and up with Candles, away with Bibles and up with beads, away with the Light of the gospel, and up with the Light of Candles, yea At noon days.

column7: Where the Deuyll is residente, that he maye preuayle, vp with all supersticion and Idolatrie, sensing, pain tynge of ymages, candels, palmes, asshes, holie water, and new seruice of mennes inuentyng, as though man could inuente a better waye to honoure God with, then god hymselfe hath apoynted.
column8: Where the devil is resident, that he may prevail, up with all Superstition and Idolatry, sensing, pain ting of Images, Candles, palms, Ashes, holy water, and new service of men's inventing, as though man could invent a better Way to honour God with, then god himself hath appointed.

column7: Doune with Christes crosse, vp with purgatory picke pursse, vp with hym, the popishe pourgatorie I meane.
column8: Down with Christ's cross, up with purgatory pick purse, up with him, the popish pourgatorie I mean.

column7: Awaye with clothing the naked, the pore and impotent, vp with deckynge of ymages and gaye garnyshynge of stockes and stones Up with mannes tradicious and his lawes, downe with Gods tradycions and his most holye worde.
column8: Away with clothing the naked, the poor and impotent, up with decking of Images and gay garnishing of stocks and stones Up with Man's tradicious and his laws, down with God's traditions and his most holy word.

column7: Downe with the olde honoure dewe to God, and vp with the new gods honour, let al thynges be done in Latine. there muste be nothynge but Latine, not as muche as,
column8: Down with the old honour dew to God, and up with the new God's honour, let all things be done in Latin. there must be nothing but Latin, not as much as,

column7: Memento homo quod cinis es, et in cinerem reuerteris.
column8: Memento homo quod Cinis es, et in cinerem reuerteris.

column7: Remembre manne that thou arte asshes, and into asshes thou shalt returne.
column8: remember man that thou art Ashes, and into Ashes thou shalt return.

column7: Whiche be the wordes that the minister speaketh to the ignoraunte people, when he geueth them asshes vpo asshe wens daye, but it muste be spoken in latine.
column8: Which be the words that the minister speaks to the ignorant people, when he Giveth them Ashes upon ash wens day, but it must be spoken in latin.

column7: Goddes worde may in no wyse be translated into Englishe Oh that our prelates would bee as dilygente to sowe the corne of good doctrine as Sathan is, to sowe cockel and darnel.
column8: Goddess word may in no wise be translated into English O that our Prelates would be as dilygente to sow the corn of good Doctrine as Sathan is, to sow cockel and darnel.

column7: And this is the deuelyshe ploughyng, the whiche worketh to haue thinges in latine, and letteth the fruteful edificacion.
column8: And this is the deuelyshe ploughing, the which works to have things in latin, and lets the fruitful edification.

column7: But here some mane will saye to me, what sir, are ye so priuie of the deuils councel, that ye know al this to be true?
column8: But Here Some mane will say to me, what sir, Are you so privy of the Devils council, that you know all this to be true?

column7: Truli I knowe him to wel, and haue obeyed him a little to much in con discenting to some folies.
column8: Truli I know him to well, and have obeyed him a little to much in con dissenting to Some follies.

column7: And I knowe him as other men do, yea, that he is euer occupied & euer busy in folowing his plow.
column8: And I know him as other men do, yea, that he is ever occupied & ever busy in following his blow.

column7: I know by S. Peter which saith of him.
column8: I know by S. Peter which Says of him.

column7: Sicut leo rugiens circuit querens quem deuoret.
column8: Sicut leo rugiens circuit Queries Whom devoret.

column7: He goeth about like a roaryng lyon sekyng whom he may deuoure.
column8: He Goes about like a roaring Lion seeking whom he may devour.

column7: I would haue this text well vewed and examyned euerye worde of it.
column8: I would have this text well viewed and examined every word of it.

column7: Circuit, he goeth <NOTE> about in euery corner of his dioces.
column8: Circuit, he Goes about in every corner of his diocese.

column7: He goeth on visitacion dailye.
column8: He Goes on Visitation daily.

column7: He leaueth no place of his cure vnuisited.
column8: He Leaveth no place of his cure unvisited.

column7: He walketh roud aboute from place to place, and ceaseth not,
column8: He walks roved about from place to place, and ceases not,

column7: Sicut leo, as a Lion that is strongly, boldly,
column8: Sicut leo, as a lion that is strongly, boldly,

column7: & proudlye, straytely, and fiercelye with haute lookes, with ^is prowde countenaunces, with his stately braggynges.
column8: & proudly, straytely, and fiercely with haute looks, with is proved countenances, with his stately braggings.

column7: Rugiens, roaryng, for he letteth not slyppe any occasyon to speake or to roare out when he seeth his tyme.
column8: Rugiens, roaring, for he lets not slip any occasion to speak or to roar out when he sees his time.

column7: Querens. he goeth about sekyng and not sleepyng, as our Byshoppes do, but he seketh diligently, he searcheth diligetly al corners, wheras he may haue his pray.
column8: Queries. he Goes about seeking and not sleeping, as our Bishops do, but he seeketh diligently, he Searches diligetly all corners, whereas he may have his prey.

column7: He roueth abrode in euery place of his dioces, he standeth not styll, he is neuer at reste, but euer in hande with his ploughe that it may go foreward.
column8: He roveth abroad in every place of his diocese, he Stands not still, he is never At rest, but ever in hand with his plough that it may go forward.

column7: But there was neuer suche a preacher in England as he is.
column8: But there was never such a preacher in England as he is.

column7: Who is able to tell his dyligente preachynge?
column8: Who is able to tell his dyligente preaching?

column7: whiche euery daye and euerye howre, laboreth to sowe cockel and darnell, that he may bryng oute of forme and out of estimacio and roume, thinstitucion of the Lordes supper and Christes crosse, for there he loste his ryghte, for Christ fayed.
column8: which every day and every hour, Laboureth to sow cockel and darnel, that he may bring out of Form and out of estimacio and room, thinstitucion of the lords supper and Christ's cross, for there he lost his right, for christ fayed.

column7: Nunc iudicium est mundi, princepes seculi huius eiicietur foras, et sicut exaltauit Moises serpentem in deserto, ita exaltari oportet filium hominis, et cum ex altatus fuero, a terra, omnia tradam ad meipsum.
column8: Nunc iudicium est mundi, princepes Seculi Huius eiicietur foras, et sicut exaltauit Moses serpentem in Deserto, ita exaltari oportet Son hominis, et cum ex altatus fuero, a terra, omnia Tradam ad meipsum.

column7: Nowe is the iudgemente of thys worlde and the Prynce of thys worlde shall be caste out.
column8: Now is the judgement of this world and the Prince of this world shall be cast out.

column7: And as Moyses dyd lyfte vp the serpente in the wyldernesse, so muste the sonne of manne be lyfte vp.
column8: And as Moses did lift up the serpent in the Wilderness, so must the son of man be lift up.

column7: And when I shall be lyfte vp frome the earthe.
column8: And when I shall be lift up from the earth.

column7: I wyll drawe al thynges vnto my selfe.
column8: I will draw all things unto my self.

column7: For the Deuyll was dysapoynted of hys purpose, for he thoughte all to be hys owne.
column8: For the devil was disappointed of his purpose, for he Thought all to be his own.

column7: And when he had once broughte Christe to the crosse, he thoughte all cocke sure.
