column8: And when he had once brought Christ to the cross, he Thought all cock sure.

column7: But there loste he all his reygning, for Christ sayed Omnia traham ad meipsum.
column8: But there lost he all his reigning, for christ said Omnia traham ad meipsum.

column7: I wyll drawe all thynges to my selfe. ^e meaneth drawyng of mannes soule to saluacion.
column8: I will draw all things to my self. e means drawing of Man's soul to salvation.

column7: And that he sayd he would do,
column8: And that he said he would do,

column7: Per semet ipsum. by hys owne selfe, not by any other bodyes sacrifice.
column8: Per semet ipsum. by his own self, not by any other bodies sacrifice.

column7: He mente by hys owne sacryfyce on the crosse, wheare he offered him self for the redempcion of mankynd, and not the sacrifice of the masse to be offered by an other.
column8: He mente by his own sacrifice on the cross, where he offered him self for the redemption of mankind, and not the sacrifice of the mass to be offered by an other.

column7: For who can offer him, but him selfe?
column8: For who can offer him, but him self?

column7: He was bothe the offerer and the offeryng.
column8: He was both the offerer and the offering.

column7: And this is the prycke, thys is the marke at the whyche the Deuyll shooteth, to euacuate the crosse of Chryste, and to mingle the instytucion of the Lordes supper, the whiche although he canne not brynge to passe:
column8: And this is the prick, this is the mark At the which the devil shoots, to evacuate the cross of Christ, and to mingle the instytucion of the lords supper, the which although he can not bring to pass:

column7: yet he goeth aboute by his sleightes and subtyle meanes, to frustrate the same, and these fyftene hundreth yeres he hath been a dooer, onelye purposynge to euacuate Christes death, and to make it of smal efficacitie and vertue.
column8: yet he Goes about by his sleights and subtle means, to frustrate the same, and these fyftene Hundredth Years he hath been a doer, only purposing to evacuate Christ's death, and to make it of small efficacity and virtue.

column7: For where as Christe accordyng as the serpente was lyfte vp in wyldernesse:
column8: For where as Christ according as the serpent was lift up in Wilderness:

column7: so woulde he hym selfe to be exalted, that thereby as manye as trusted in hym, shoulde haue saluacion.
column8: so would he him self to be exalted, that thereby as many as trusted in him, should have salvation.

column7: But the deuyl would none of that.
column8: But the Devil would none of that.

column7: They would haue vs saued by a daily oblacion propiciatorie, by a sacrifyce expiatorie, or remissorie.
column8: They would have us saved by a daily oblation propitiatory, by a sacrifice expiatory, or remissorie.

column7: Nowe yf I shoulde preache in the countrey amonge the vnlearned,
column8: Now if I should preach in the country among the unlearned,

column7: I woulde tell what propiciatorie, expiatorie and remissorie is:
column8: I would tell what propitiatory, expiatory and remissorie is:

column7: but here is a learned auditorie.
column8: but Here is a learned auditory.

column7: Yet for them that be vnlearned I wil expound it.
column8: Yet for them that be unlearned I will expound it.

column7: Propiciatorie, expiatorie, remissorie, or satisfactorie, for they signifie al one thynge in effecte, and is no thynge elles but a thynge wherby to obteyne remissyon of synnes, and to haue saluacion.
column8: Propitiatory, expiatory, remissorie, or satisfactory, for they signify all one thing in Effect, and is no thing Else but a thing whereby to obtain remission of Sins, and to have salvation.

column7: And thys waye the Deuyll vsed to euacuate the deathe of Chryste, that we myghte haue affyaunce in other thynges, as in the daylye sacrifice of the pryeste, where as Chryste woulde haue vs to truste in his onelye sacrifice.
column8: And this Way the devil used to evacuate the death of Christ, that we might have affyaunce in other things, as in the daily sacrifice of the Priest, where as Christ would have us to trust in his only sacrifice.

column7: So he was Agnus occisus ab origine mundi, the lambe that hathe be slaine frome the beginnyng of the worlde, and therfore he is called,
column8: So he was Agnus Occisus ab origine mundi, the lamb that hath be slain from the beginning of the world, and Therefore he is called,

column7: Juge sacrificium. A continuall sacrifyce, and not for the continuaunce of the Masse as the blauchers haue blaunched it, and wrested it.
column8: Juge Sacrificium. A continual sacrifice, and not for the Continuance of the Mass as the blanchers have blanched it, and wrested it.

column7: And as I my selfe dyd once mystake it.
column8: And as I my self did once mystake it.

column7: But Paule sayeth. Per semetip sum purgatio facta, by him selfe & by none other,
column8: But Paul Saith. Per semetip sum purgatio facta, by him self & by none other,

column7: Christ made pourgacion and satysfaction for the whole worlde.
column8: christ made pourgacion and satysfaction for the Whole world.

column7: Woulde Christ this woorde (by hym selfe) hadde been better weyghed and loked vpon, and,
column8: Would christ this word (by him self) had been better weighed and looked upon, and,

column7: In sanctificacionem, to make theym holye, for he is,
column8: In sanctificacionem, to make them holy, for he is,

column7: Juge sacrificium, a continuall sacryfice, in effecte, fruite and operacion, that lyke as they whiche seeyng the serpente hange vp in the deserte were put in remembraunce of Christes death, in whome as many as beleued were saued:
column8: Juge Sacrificium, a continual sacrifice, in Effect, fruit and operation, that like as they which seeing the serpent hang up in the desert were put in remembrance of Christ's death, in whom as many as believed were saved:

column7: so all men that trusted in the deathe of Christ shall be saued, as wel they that were before, as they that came after.
column8: so all men that trusted in the death of christ shall be saved, as well they that were before, as they that Come After.

column7: For he was a contynuall Sacrifyce, as I sayed in effecte, fruite, operacion and vertue.
column8: For he was a continual Sacrifice, as I said in Effect, fruit, operation and virtue.

column7: As thoughe he had frome the beginnyng of the world and continually should to the worldes ende hange still on the crosse, and he is as freshe hangyng on the crosse nowe to them that beleue and truste in hym, as he was fiftene hundreth yeares a go when he was crucyfyed.
column8: As though he had from the beginning of the world and continually should to the world's end hang still on the cross, and he is as fresh hanging on the cross now to them that believe and trust in him, as he was fiftene Hundredth Years a go when he was Crucified.

column7: Then lette vs truste vpon hys onely deathe, and looke for none other sacrifyce propiciatorie, then the same bloudye sacrifice, the liuelye sacrifice, and not a drie sacrifice, but a blouddy sacrifice.
column8: Then let us trust upon his only death, and look for none other sacrifice propitiatory, then the same bloody sacrifice, the lively sacrifice, and not a dry sacrifice, but a bloody sacrifice.

column7: For Chryste hymselfe sayed, Consummatum est.
column8: For Christ himself said, Consummatum est.

column7: It is perfectlye finyshed. I haue taken at my fathers hande the dispensation of redemyng mankynd.
column8: It is perfectly finished. I have taken At my Father's hand the Dispensation of redeeming mankind.

column7: I haue wroughte mannes redempcion, and haue dyspatched the matter.
column8: I have wrought Man's redemption, and have dyspatched the matter.

column7: Why then myngle ye hym?
column8: Why then mingle you him?

column7: why do ye deuide hym?
column8: why do you divide him?

column7: why make you of hym mo sacryfyces then one?
column8: why make you of him more Sacrifices then one?

column7: Paule sayeth. Pascha nostrum immolatus est Christus Christe our passeouer is offered vp, so that the thing is done, and Christ hath done it, and he hath done it, semel. Once for all.
column8: Paul Saith. Pascha nostrum Immolatus est Christus Christ our passover is offered up, so that the thing is done, and christ hath done it, and he hath done it, semel. Once for all.

column7: And it was a bloudy sacrifice, not a drie sacrifice.
column8: And it was a bloody sacrifice, not a dry sacrifice.

column7: Why then, it is not the Masse that auaileth or profiteth for the quicke and the dead?
column8: Why then, it is not the Mass that avails or profiteth for the quick and the dead?

column7: Wo worth thee, O Deuyll, wo worth thee, that haste preuayled so farre and so longe, that thou haste made Englande to worshyppe false Goddes, forsaking Christe their Lorde.
column8: Woe worth thee, Oh devil, woe worth thee, that haste prevailed so Far and so long, that thou haste made England to worship false God's, forsaking Christ their Lord.

column7: Wo worthe the Deuil. Wo worth thee Deuyll and all thyne Aungels:
column8: Woe worth the devil. Woe worth thee devil and all thine Angels:

column7: yf Christ by his deathe draweth all thynges to him selfe, and draweth al men to saluacion, and to heauenly blysse that trust in him.
column8: if christ by his death draws all things to him self, and draws all men to salvation, and to heavenly bliss that trust in him.

column7: Then the priestes at the Masse, at the popyshe Masse I say) what ca they draw when Christe draweth all, but landes and gooddes frome the right heyres?
column8: Then the Priests At the Mass, At the popish Mass I say) what circa they draw when Christ draws all, but Lands and God's from the right Heirs?

column7: The priestes draw gooddes and rychesse, benefyces and promocions to theym selues and suche as beleued in theyr sacrifyce they drawe to the Deuyll.
column8: The Priests draw God's and richesse, Benefices and promotions to them selves and such as believed in their sacrifice they draw to the devil.

column7: But Christe it is that draweth sowles vnto hym by hys bloudy sacrifice.
column8: But Christ it is that draws Souls unto him by his bloody sacrifice.

column7: What haue we to do then, but Epulari in domiuo, to eate in the Lorde at hys Supper.
column8: What have we to do then, but Epulari in domiuo, to eat in the Lord At his Supper.

column7: What other seruyce haue we to do to hym?
column8: What other service have we to do to him?

column7: and what other sacrifyce haue we to offer:
column8: and what other sacrifice have we to offer:

column7: but the mortificacio of our flesh?
column8: but the mortificacio of our Flesh?

column7: What other oblacion haue we to make, but of obedyence, of good liuynge, of good woorkes, and of healpynge oure neyghbours?
column8: What other oblation have we to make, but of Obedience, of good living, of good works, and of helping our neighbours?

column7: But as for oure redempcion, it is done already, it can not be better.
column8: But as for our redemption, it is done already, it can not be better.

column7: Christe hath done that thynge so well, that it can not be amended.
column8: Christ hath done that thing so well, that it can not be amended.

column7: It cannot be deuised howe to make that, any better then he hathe done it.
column8: It cannot be devised how to make that, any better then he hath done it.

column7: But the Deuyll by the healpe of that Jtalian Bishop yonder, his chaplayne:
column8: But the devil by the help of that Italian Bishop yonder, his chaplain:

column7: hath laboured by all meanes, that he myght, to frustrate the death of Christe, and the merytes of hys passyon.
column8: hath laboured by all means, that he might, to frustrate the death of Christ, and the merits of his passion.

column7: And they haue deuised for that purpose to make vs beleue in other vayne thynges by his pardonnes, as to haue remission of sinnes for praiynge on hallowed beades, for drinkyng of the bakehouse bole, as a Channon of Waltam Abbey, once tolde me, that when soeuer they putte theyr loaues of breade into the ouen, as manye as drancke of the pardon bolle shoulde haue pardon for drinckynge of it.
column8: And they have devised for that purpose to make us believe in other vain things by his pardonnes, as to have remission of Sins for praying on hallowed beads, for drinking of the bakehouse bole, as a Cannon of Waltham Abbatiae, once told me, that when soever they put their loaves of bread into the oven, as many as drank of the pardon bowl should have pardon for drinking of it.

column7: A madde thyng to geue pardon to a bolle.
column8: A mad thing to give pardon to a bowl.

column7: Then to Pope Alexanders holye water, to halowed belles, palmes, candelles, asshes, and what not?
column8: Then to Pope Alexanders holy water, to hallowed Bells, palms, Candles, Ashes, and what not?

column7: And of these thynges euerye one hath taken awaye some parte of Christes sanctificacion.
column8: And of these things every one hath taken away Some part of Christ's sanctification.

column7: Euery one hathe tobbed some parte of Christes passion and crosse, and hathe myngled Christes death, and hath been made to be propiciatorie and satisfactorie, and to put awaye sinne.
column8: Every one hath tobbed Some part of Christ's passion and cross, and hath mingled Christ's death, and hath been made to be propitiatory and satisfactory, and to put away sin.

column7: Yea and Alexanders holye water yet at thys daye remaynethe in Englande, and is vsed for a remedy against spirytes, and to chase awaye deuylles, yea and I woulde thys had been the worste.
column8: Yea and Alexanders holy water yet At this day remaineth in England, and is used for a remedy against spirits, and to chase away Devils, yea and I would this had been the worst.

column7: I would thys were the worste.
column8: I would this were the worst.

column7: But wo worth thee, O deuyll that haste preuayled to euacuate,
column8: But woe worth thee, Oh Devil that haste prevailed to evacuate,

column7: Chrystes crosse and to myngle the lordes supper.
column8: Christ's cross and to mingle the Lords supper.

column7: These be the Italian byshoppes deuyces, and the deuyll hathe prycked at thys marke to frustrate the crosse of Christe.
column8: These be the Italian Bishops deuyces, and the Devil hath pricked At this mark to frustrate the cross of Christ.

column7: He shotte at thys marke longe before Christe came, he shotte at this pricke fowre thousande yeares before Christ hanged on the crosse, or suffered his passion.
column8: He shot At this mark long before Christ Come, he shot At this prick fowre thousande Years before christ hanged on the cross, or suffered his passion.

column7: For the brasen serpente, was sette vp in the wyldernes to put men in remembrance of Christes commyng, that lyke as they whiche behelde the brasen serpente were healed of their bodilye diseases:
column8: For the brazen serpent, was Set up in the Wilderness to put men in remembrance of Christ's coming, that like as they which beheld the brazen serpent were healed of their bodily diseases:

column7: so they that loked spirituallye vpon Christe that was to come, in hym shoulde be saued spiritually from the Deuyll,
column8: so they that looked spiritually upon Christ that was to come, in him should be saved spiritually from the devil,

column7: The serpent was set vp in memorie of Christe to come, but the Deuyll founde meanes to steale awaye the memorie of Christes commyng and brought the people to worshippe the Serpenre selfe, and to sence hym, to honoure hym, and to offer to hym, to worshyppe hym, and to make an Idoll of hym.
column8: The serpent was Set up in memory of Christ to come, but the devil found means to steal away the memory of Christ's coming and brought the people to worship the Serpent self, and to sense him, to honour him, and to offer to him, to worship him, and to make an Idol of him.

column7: And thys was done by the markette menne that I tolde you of And the clarke of the markette dyd it for the lucre and aduauntage of his maister, that thereby his honour myghte encrease, for by Christes death, he could haue but small worldlye aduauntage.
column8: And this was done by the market men that I told you of And the Clerk of the market did it for the lucre and advantage of his master, that thereby his honour might increase, for by Christ's death, he could have but small worldly advantage.

column7: And euen nowe so hath he certayne blaunchers longyng to the markette, to lette and stoppe the lyghte of the Gospel, and to hinder the kynges procedynges in settyng forth the word and glorye of God.
column8: And even now so hath he certain blanchers longing to the market, to let and stop the Light of the Gospel, and to hinder the Kings proceedings in setting forth the word and glory of God.

column7: And when the kinges maiestie with the aduyse of his honourable counsayle goeth about to promote Goddes word and to sette an order in matters of religyon there shall not lacke blaunchers that wyl saye.
column8: And when the Kings majesty with the advise of his honourable counsel Goes about to promote Goddess word and to Set an order in matters of Religion there shall not lack blanchers that will say.

column7: As for Images wheras they haue been vsed to be senced, and to haue candels offred vnto theim:
column8: As for Images whereas they have been used to be sensed, and to have Candles offered unto them:

column7: none be so folishe to do it to the stocke or stone, or to the Image selfe, but it is done to GOD and his honour before the Image.
column8: none be so foolish to do it to the stock or stone, or to the Image self, but it is done to GOD and his honour before the Image.

column7: And thoughe they shoulde abuse it, these blaunchers will be ready to whysper the Kynge in the eare, and to tell hym that this abuse is but a small matter.
column8: And though they should abuse it, these blanchers will be ready to whysper the King in the ear, and to tell him that this abuse is but a small matter.

column7: And that the same wyth all other lyke abuses in the churche maye be refourmed easilye.
column8: And that the same with all other like Abuses in the Church may be reformed Easily.

column7: It is but a litle abuse (say they) and it maye bee easily amended.
column8: It is but a little abuse (say they) and it may be Easily amended.

column7: But it shoulde not be taken in hande at the first for feare of trouble, or further inconueniences.
column8: But it should not be taken in hand At the First for Fear of trouble, or further inconveniences.

column7: The people wil not beare sod ayne alteracions an insurreccyon maye be made after sodayne mutacion, whiche maye be to the greate harme and loste of the realme.
column8: The people will not bear sod ayne alterations an insurrection may be made After sudden mutation, which may be to the great harm and lost of the realm.

column7: Therefore all thynges shal be wel, but not out of hand, for feare of further busynes.
column8: Therefore all things shall be well, but not out of hand, for Fear of further business.

column7: These be ye blanchers that hitherto haue stopped the worde of god, and hindered the true settyng forth of the same.
column8: These be you blanchers that hitherto have stopped the word of god, and hindered the true setting forth of the same.

column7: There be so many put offes, so manye put byes, so many respectes, and consideracios of worldly wisdo.
column8: There be so many put offes, so many put bies, so many respects, and consideracios of worldly Wisdom.

column7: And I dout not but there were blanchers in the olde time, to whysper in the eare of good kynge Ezechyas, for the mayntenaunce of Idolatrie done to the brasen serpet, aswel as there hath ben now of late,
column8: And I doubt not but there were blanchers in the old time, to whysper in the ear of good King Hezekiah, for the maintenance of Idolatry done to the brazen serpet, aswell as there hath been now of late,

column7: & be now that can blanche the abuse of Images and other lyke thynges.
column8: & be now that can blanch the abuse of Images and other like things.

column7: But good kynge Ezechias woulde not be so blynded, he was lyke to Apollos, feruent in spiryte.
column8: But good King Hezekiah would not be so blinded, he was like to Apollos, fervent in Spirit.

column7: He woulde geue no eare to the blanchers, he was not moued wyth these worldlye respectes, wyth these prudente consyderacions, with these policies, he feared not insurreccions of the people.
column8: He would give no ear to the blanchers, he was not moved with these worldly respects, with these prudent considerations, with these policies, he feared not insurrections of the people.

column7: He feared not least his people woulde not beare the glorye of God:
column8: He feared not lest his people would not bear the glory of God:

column7: but he (without any of these respectes, or polycies, or cosideracions, like a good kynge for Goddes sake, and for conscience sake) by & by plucked downe the brasen serpente, and destroyed it vtterlye, and beat it to pouder.
column8: but he (without any of these respects, or policies, or cosideracions, like a good King for Goddess sake, and for conscience sake) by & by plucked down the brazen serpent, and destroyed it utterly, and beatrice it to powder.

column7: He oute of hande, dyd caste downe all Images, he destroyed all Idolatrie, and clerely dyd extirpate all supersticion.
column8: He out of hand, did cast down all Images, he destroyed all Idolatry, and clearly did extirpate all Superstition.

column7: He woulde not heare these blanchers and worldly wyse men, but with out delaye, foloweth gods cause and destroyeth all Idolatrie out of hande.
column8: He would not hear these blanchers and worldly wise men, but with out Delay, Followeth God's cause and Destroyeth all Idolatry out of hand.

column7: Thus dyd good king Ezechias, for he was lyke Apollo, feruet in spirite, and dilygente to promote Goddes glorie.
column8: Thus did good King Hezekiah, for he was like Apollo, fervent in Spirit, and dilygente to promote Goddess glory.

column7: And good hope there is that it shall be lykewyse here in Englande, for the kynges Maiestye is so broughte vp in knowledge, vertue, and godlynesse, that it is not to be mystrusted, but that we shall haue all thynges well, and that the glorye of God shall be spred abrode, throughout al partes of the realme, yf the prelates wil diligetly apply their plough & be preachers, rather then Lordes, but our blaunchers, whiche wyll be Lordes, and no labourers, when they are commaunded to go and be resydente vpon their cures, and preache in theyr benefyces, they would say.
column8: And good hope there is that it shall be likewise Here in England, for the Kings Majesty is so brought up in knowledge, virtue, and godliness, that it is not to be Mistrusted, but that we shall have all things well, and that the glory of God shall be spread abroad, throughout all parts of the realm, if the Prelates will diligetly apply their plough & be Preachers, rather then lords, but our blanchers, which will be lords, and no labourers, when they Are commanded to go and be resydente upon their cures, and preach in their Benefices, they would say.

column7: What, I haue sette a deputie there,
column8: What, I have Set a deputy there,

column7: I haue a deputie that loketh well to my flocke, and the whiche shal discharge my duetie.
column8: I have a deputy that looketh well to my flock, and the which shall discharge my duty.

column7: A deputie quod he. I loked for that worde all this whyle.
column8: A deputy quod he. I looked for that word all this while.

column7: And what a deputie must he be, trowe ye?
column8: And what a deputy must he be, trow you?

column7: Euen one lyke hym selfe, it muste be a cannoniste, that is to saye, one that is broughte up in the studie of the Popes lawes & decrees.
column8: Even one like him self, it must be a cannoniste, that is to say, one that is brought up in the study of the Popes laws & decrees.

column7: One that wyll set forth papistrie as well as hym self wyl do, and one that wyll mayntayne all supersticion, and Idolatrye.
column8: One that will Set forth papistry as well as him self will do, and one that will maintain all Superstition, and Idolatry.

column7: And one that wyll nothynge at all, or els very weakely resist the Deuyls plough, yea happy it is yf he take not part with the Deuyll, and where he shoulde be an enemy to hym, it is wel if he take not the Deuilles parte agaynste Christe.
column8: And one that will nothing At all, or Else very weakly resist the Devils plough, yea happy it is if he take not part with the devil, and where he should be an enemy to him, it is well if he take not the Devils part against Christ.

column7: But in the meane time the Prelares take theyr pleasures.
column8: But in the mean time the Prelates take their pleasures.

column7: They are Lordes and no labourers, but the Deuill is dilygente at his ploughe.
column8: They Are lords and no labourers, but the devil is dilygente At his plough.

column7: He is no vnpreachynge prelate.
column8: He is no vnpreachynge prelate.

column7: He is no Lordelye loyterer from his cure, but a busie ploughe man, so that amonhe all the prelates, and amonge al the packe of them that haue cure, the Deuill shal go for my money.
column8: He is no Lordly loiterer from his cure, but a busy plough man, so that amonhe all the Prelates, and among all the pack of them that have cure, the devil shall go for my money.

column7: For he styll applyeth his busynes.
column8: For he still Applieth his business.

column7: Therefore ye vnpreachynge prelates, learne of the deuill to be diligent in doyng of your offyce.
column8: Therefore you vnpreachynge Prelates, Learn of the Devil to be diligent in doing of your office.

column7: Learne of the deuill. And if you wyl not learne of God nor good manne:
column8: Learn of the Devil. And if you will not Learn of God nor good man:

column7: for shame learne of the Deuyll.
column8: for shame Learn of the devil.

column7: Ad erubescentiam vestram dico. I speake it for your shame.
column8: Ad erubescentiam vestram dico. I speak it for your shame.

column7: If you wil not learne of God nor good man to be diligent in your offyce, learne of the deuill.
column8: If you will not Learn of God nor good man to be diligent in your office, Learn of the Devil.

column7: Howebeit there is nowe verie good hoope that the kynges maiestie, beyng by the healpe of good goueruaunce of his mooste honourable counsaylours, he is trained and brought vp in learnyng and knowledge of Goddes word, wil shortly prouide a remedye and set an ordre herein, whiche thyng that it may so be, lette vs praye for him.
column8: Howbeit there is now very good hoop that the Kings majesty, being by the help of good goueruaunce of his most honourable counsellors, he is trained and brought up in learning and knowledge of Goddess word, will shortly provide a remedy and Set an ordre herein, which thing that it may so be, let us pray for him.

column7: Praye for hym good people, praye for hym, ye haue great cause, and neede to praye for him.
column8: Pray for him good people, pray for him, you have great cause, and need to pray for him.

column7: In nomine Iesu Christi.
column8: In nomine Jesu Christ.

column7: GOD be mercyfull vnto vs:
column8: GOD be merciful unto us:

column7: For the tyme is euen nowe comynge, when as God muste needes eyther of hys mercy here in Englande, worcke suche a wonderfull miracle vnto our conforte, as farre passeth mans expectacion:
column8: For the time is even now coming, when as God must needs either of his mercy Here in England, work such a wonderful miracle unto our Comfort, as Far passes men expectation:

column7: or els of his righteousnes take such vengeaunce of this land to thexample of all other landes, as shal be to our vtter destruccion.
column8: or Else of his righteousness take such vengeance of this land to Exampl of all other Lands, as shall be to our utter destruction.

column7: Ye know, that immediatlie after the preachynge of Noe, came the great stud that drouned ye worlde.
column8: You know, that immediately After the preaching of Noah, Come the great stud that drowned you world.

column7: After the warnynge of Loth, came fyre,
column8: After the warning of Loath, Come fire,

column7: & brimstone vpon the Sodomites and Gomorrians.
column8: & brimstone upon the Sodomites and Gomorrheans.

column7: When Moises had declared gods threatnynges in Egipt, kinge Pharao and hys people were plaged vpon the lad, and drouned in the red sea.
column8: When Moses had declared God's threatnynges in Egypt, King Pharaoh and his people were plagued upon the lad, and drowned in the read sea.

column7: Such plages came euer where gods worde truly preached, is not beleued, receaued, and folowed.
column8: Such plagues Come ever where God's word truly preached, is not believed, received, and followed.

column7: But at is the preaching of Ionas, the Niniuites repented wonderfully.
column8: But At is the preaching of Jonah, the Niniuites repented wonderfully.

column7: When the boke of the lawe was reade vnto Iosias the kynge, he, with all his people spedely repentynge, found exceadyng mercy blessynge and grace:
column8: When the book of the law was read unto Josiah the King, he, with all his people speedily repenting, found exceeding mercy blessing and grace:

column7: as lykewyse all other shalbe sure to find, which heare the word of God and kepe it.
column8: as likewise all other shall sure to find, which hear the word of God and keep it.

column7: For when Christ and his Apostles had preached the gospell vnto the Iewes, those that beleued were delyuered frome the curse of the law, vnto the blessing of grace out of worldly myserye, to be inheritours of the heuenly kingdome:
column8: For when christ and his Apostles had preached the gospel unto the Jews, those that believed were Delivered from the curse of the law, unto the blessing of grace out of worldly misery, to be inheritors of the heavenly Kingdom:

column7: and those that did not beleue, were cast from God, oppressed of men, ouercome, spoyled, murthered, and destroyed of theyr enemies.
column8: and those that did not believe, were cast from God, oppressed of men, overcome, spoiled, murdered, and destroyed of their enemies.

column7: Wherfore Englande, whyche at this presente tyme, by reason of the worde of god set fourth, reade, preached, and communed, dothe in euery place heare ye coucel of Noe, the warning of Loth, the lawe of Moises, the threatnyngs of ye prophetes, and the grace of the gospel, as it was declared and taught by Christ and his Apostles:
column8: Wherefore England, which At this present time, by reason of the word of god Set fourth, read, preached, and communed, doth in every place hear you council of Noah, the warning of Loath, the law of Moses, the threatenings of the Prophets, and the grace of the gospel, as it was declared and taught by christ and his Apostles:

column7: This Englande muste nedes, either by beleuynge of these thinges, obteine of god wonderful grace of amendmente or els by neglectinge them, prouoke the vengeance of god, as a dewe plage and punyshment.
column8: This England must needs, either by believing of these things, obtain of god wondered grace of amendment or Else by neglecting them, provoke the vengeance of god, as a dew plague and punishment.

column7: Take heede therfore England, for if thou by vnbelefe, let and stop God from workynge of miracles to thy comforte, then surely doest thou prouoke god to powre down vengeaunce vpon the, to thy vtter distruccyon:
column8: Take heed Therefore England, for if thou by unbelief, let and stop God from working of Miracles to thy Comfort, then surely dost thou provoke god to pour down vengeance upon thee, to thy utter destruction:

column7: But if thou doo regarde, receiue, and beleue goddes worde, he wyll worke wonderfull miracles to thy conforte, wealthe,
column8: But if thou do regard, receive, and believe God's word, he will work wonderful Miracles to thy Comfort, wealth,

column7: and prosperitie. Yea, let euerye man, of what estate or degree soeuer he be, grope hys owne conscience, for if he dooe not there fele that the worde of God dothe take place to moue him to repentaunce and amendment of lyfe, then shall he be sure soone to haue experience, that the vengeaunce of god, by a shameful shorte ende of hys wretched lyfe, wyl brynge hym vnto an euerlastinge dampnable deathe.
column8: and Prosperity. Yea, let every man, of what estate or degree soever he be, grope his own conscience, for if he do not there feel that the word of God doth take place to move him to Repentance and amendment of life, then shall he be sure soon to have experience, that the vengeance of god, by a shameful short end of his wretched life, will bring him unto an everlasting damnable death.

column7: For all those that wyll not creepe vnder the merciful wings of god, as the chikinnes of Chryst, shal be caught and deuoured of puttocks, haukes, and kytes, as a praye for the deuyll.
column8: For all those that will not creep under the merciful wings of god, as the chikinnes of Christ, shall be caught and devoured of puttock's, hawks, and kites, as a pray for the Devil.

column7: The wynges of god be stretched abrode here in Englande, by the kynges gracious maiesty, and his honourable counsell, of mighty power, wyth ready wyl, to shadowe, defende, and saue all those that wyth reuerent loue, come humbly creping vnder theyr ordynauce, rule,
column8: The wings of god be stretched abroad Here in England, by the Kings gracious majesty, and his honourable counsel, of mighty power, with ready will, to shadow, defend, and save all those that with reverent love, come humbly creeping under their Ordinance, Rule,

column7: & gouernace, which is ye power, ye wings & the order of god.
column8: & governance, which is the power, you wings & the order of god.

column7: The filthye gredy puttockes, wylde haukes, and rauenyng kytes, be supersticious papistes, carnall gospellers, and sedicious rebelles, whych as ye haue seene by late experience, haue most cruelly caught, spoyled, and deuoured the lambes, the chekynnes, the chyldren of God redemed and boughte with Christes bloude.
column8: The filthy greedy puttocks, wild hawks, and ravening kites, be superstitious Papists, carnal Evangelists, and seditious rebels, which as you have seen by late experience, have most cruelly caught, spoiled, and devoured the Lambs, the chekynnes, the children of God redeemed and bought with Christ's blood.

column7: Wherefore as Christ in his owne person dyd once lamente and bewayle Ierusalem, so doeth he nowe many tymes in the persons of hys propheticall Preachers, lament & bewayl Englande, saying:
column8: Wherefore as christ in his own person did once lament and bewail Jerusalem, so doth he now many times in the Persons of his prophetical Preachers, lament & bewail England, saying:

column7: O Englande, howe ofte wold I haue gathered thy chyldren, as a hen gathereth her chikens vnder her wynges, and thou woldest not?
column8: Oh England, how oft would I have gathered thy children, as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, and thou Wouldst not?

column7: Euen wyth the same affeccion that the shepeherde cryeth, seynge the wolfe leeryng towardes the shepe,
column8: Eve with the same affection that the shepherd Cries, sing the wolf leering towards the sheep,

column7: & with the same affeccion that the hen clocketh and calleth, spyeng the kyte houeryng ouer her chekyns:
column8: & with the same affection that the hen clocketh and calls, spying the kite hovering over her chekyns:

column7: wyth the same affeccion it behoueth the minister and preacher of god, seeynge vntollerable vengeaunce hangynge ouer Englande, to crye, to cal, and to geue warnyng vnto the people saying as it is write in ye first of Esay:
column8: with the same affection it behooves the minister and preacher of god, seeing untolerable vengeance hanging over England, to cry, to call, and to give warning unto the people saying as it is writ in you First of Isaiah:

column7: If ye willingly wil heare & obey, ye shal eate the good confortable frutes of ye earth:
column8: If you willingly will hear & obey, you shall eat the good comfortable fruits of the earth:

column7: but if ye wil not,
column8: but if you will not,

column7: & prouoke me vnto anger, the sword shal deuour you.
column8: & provoke me unto anger, the sword shall devour you.

column7: Quid os Domini lo cutum est.
column8: Quid os Domini lo cutum est.

column7: For it is ye mouth of ye lord that hath spoken.
column8: For it is the Mouth of you lord that hath spoken.

column7: Now your reuerende maiesty, most gracyous kyng, and you honourable, wyse godly counsellers, you are the chiefe shepeherds, you are the most reuerende fathers in Chryste, hauynge the wynges of power and authorytye, to shadow, saue, and kepe these lambs of god, these chekens of Christe, and these chyldre of the heauenly father, redemed wyth Chrystes bloude, and comitted vnto your handes, to be saued, kepte, and prouyded for.
column8: Now your reverend majesty, most gracious King, and you honourable, wise godly Counsellers, you Are the chief shepherds, you Are the most reverend Father's in Christ, having the wings of power and authorytye, to shadow, save, and keep these Lambs of god, these chekens of Christ, and these children of the heavenly father, redeemed with Christ's blood, and committed unto your hands, to be saved, kept, and provided for.

column7: God be praysed, wyth thankeful obedience, and louynge reuerence dewe to your gracious maiestye & honourable counsell, whiche haue surely, wysely prouyded for, dylygently kepte, and charitably saued thys realme, by driuing awaye the wyly foxe of papisticall superstycion, and by castinge oute the vncleane spirit of ignorauce, to gods glorye, your honor, & our comfort.
column8: God be praised, with thankful Obedience, and loving Reverence dew to your gracious majesty & honourable counsel, which have surely, wisely provided for, diligently kept, and charitably saved this realm, by driving away the wily fox of papistical superstycion, and by casting out the unclean Spirit of ignorance, to God's glory, your honour, & our Comfort.

column7: But alas most gracious King and godly gouernors, for the tender mercyes of god, in oure Sauiour Iesu Christ, take good and diligent heed when ye be chasyng the wyly foxe of papisticall supersticion,
column8: But alas most gracious King and godly Governors, for the tender Mercies of god, in our Saviour Jesu christ, take good and diligent heed when you be chasing the wily fox of papistical Superstition,

column7: that the gredye wolfe of couetous ambicion, doo not creepe in at your backes:
column8: that the greedy wolf of covetous ambition, do not creep in At your backs:

column7: For surely he wyl do more harme in a weke, then the foxe did in a yere.
column8: For surely he will do more harm in a Week, then the fox did in a year.

column7: Take hede yt the vncleane spirit of ignorace, returning with.vii. other worse then hym selfe. find no place vnwarded, wher he may crepe in again.
column8: Take heed that the unclean Spirit of ignorance, returning with vii other Worse then him self. find no place unwarded, where he may creep in again.

column7: For if he returning wt his felowes, enter in agayne, then wyl he make the ende of thys generacion to be worse then the beginninge.
column8: For if he returning with his Fellows, enter in again, then will he make the end of this generation to be Worse then the begin.

column7: Then shall you leese the rewarde of your former dylygence, and be damned for your later negligence.
column8: Then shall you lose the reward of your former diligence, and be damned for your later negligence.

column7: Then shal the welspring of mercy which of long tyme hath watered this Realm with the grace of god, be closed vp, and the bludy flouds of vengeance gushing out fro the wrath & indignacion of God, ouer flow al togither.
column8: Then shall the wellspring of mercy which of long time hath watered this Realm with the grace of god, be closed up, and the bloody floods of vengeance gushing out from the wrath & Indignation of God, over flow all together.

column7: The wil not god by workinge of miracles declare mercy, but by takinge of vengauce execute rightuousnes.
column8: The will not god by working of Miracles declare mercy, but by taking of vengeance execute righteousness.

column7: But God beyng as mercyfull yet, as euer he was, if you contynewe as faythful, wise, and dylygente as ye haue bene, to handle the wolfe, as you haue done the foxe, to keepe out the deuyll, as to cast out the deuyll:
column8: But God being as merciful yet, as ever he was, if you continue as faithful, wise, and dylygente as you have be, to handle the wolf, as you have done the fox, to keep out the Devil, as to cast out the Devil:

column7: then shall the people of this lade feede in quyetnes, wtout feare of euyl:
column8: then shall the people of this lade feed in quietness, without Fear of evil:

column7: then shall you continuyng to thende, be sure of an hunderdfold reward in thys lyfe, and afterwardes euerlasting lyfe, ioye and glorye.
column8: then shall you Continuing to The end, be sure of an hunderdfold reward in this life, and afterwards everlasting life, joy and glory.

column7: Then shall God doo wonderfull myracles in England, to declare howe mercye shall triumphe ouer rightousnes.
column8: Then shall God do wonderful Miracles in England, to declare how mercy shall triumph over righteousness.

column7: And that we maye all dyspose our selues the more conuenientlye for god to worke suche a miracle amonge vs, wee haue appoynted for the gospel of this day, wrytten in the.vi. of Ihon, a wonderfull miracle of.v. thousande men, fed and satisfied wyth.v. loaues and ii. fyshes, wher as euery man maye & ought to learne hys owne dutye, whiche shall cleare appeare too a king in Christ, to head gouerners vnder the kynge, in the Apostles beyng most neare about Christ,
column8: And that we may all dispose our selves the more conveniently for god to work such a miracle among us, we have appointed for the gospel of this day, written in the vi of John, a wonderful miracle of v thousande men, fed and satisfied with v loaves and ii. fishes, where as every man may & ought to Learn his own duty, which shall clear appear too a King in christ, to head Governors under the King, in the Apostles being most near about christ,

column7: & to all other men, in that multitude of the people, whyche folowynge Christ, were obedient to syt downe at the comaundemet of his Disciples, not knowing, nor enquiring why they were so commaunded.
column8: & to all other men, in that multitude of the people, which following christ, were obedient to fit down At the comaundemet of his Disciples, not knowing, nor inquiring why they were so commanded.

column7: And as suerly as this wonderful, miracle was done to ye great cofort of the in Christs time:
column8: And as surely as this wondered, miracle was done to you great Comfort of thee in Christ time:

column7: so truly is it left in writyng for to learne vs by paciece & coforte of ye Scriptures, to haue good hope at thys tyme.
column8: so truly is it left in writing for to Learn us by patience & coforte of you Scriptures, to have good hope At this time.

column7: And as Christ hauing alwaies special respect vnto his audiece, dyd teach the fishers by talking of nettes, preaching vnto the Iewes by diuers parables,
column8: And as christ having always special respect unto his audience, did teach the Fishers by talking of nets, preaching unto the Jews by diverse parables,

column7: & called the gentyles by the eloquence of Paule:
column8: & called the Gentiles by the eloquence of Paul:

column7: so I, in handlyng of this miracle, hauing respecte vnto thys audyence, wyl aply the wonderful great charitable prouision of Chryste, vnto the Kynges Maiestye:
column8: so I, in handling of this miracle, having respect unto this audience, will aply the wondered great charitable provision of Christ, unto the Kings Majesty:

column7: the fayethful diligence of the Apostles, vnto the nobilitle:
column8: the fayethful diligence of the Apostles, unto the nobilitle:

column7: and the dewe obedyence and hertye thankefulnes of the multitude, vnto all other of the communaltye.
column8: and the dew Obedience and hearty thankfulness of the multitude, unto all other of the communality.

column7: Not doubtynge but that charitable prouision of liberall benefytes, wyll be a thynge most pleasaunt and honorable for the Kynges gracious Maiestye:
column8: Not doubting but that charitable provision of liberal benefits, will be a thing most pleasant and honourable for the Kings gracious Majesty:

column7: and faithful diligence in disposing great benefyts most coueniet,
column8: and faithful diligence in disposing great benefits most coueniet,

column7: & comedable for al that be in high authoryty:
column8: & comedable for all that be in high authoryty:

column7: & finally, humble obediece & vnfained thakfulnes to be most necessary, requisite,
column8: & finally, humble Obedience & unfeigned thakfulnes to be most necessary, requisite,

column7: & loked for, at thys tyme, in all inferiours & commune sort of people in Englande.
column8: & looked for, At this time, in all inferiors & commune sort of people in England.

column7: Marke a litle after the begynning of the sixt Chap. of Iohn, and ye shal heare, when as much people commynge vnto Iesus hauynge nothynge to eate, what Iesus did.
column8: Mark a little After the beginning of the sixt Chap. of John, and you shall hear, when as much people coming unto jesus having nothing to eat, what jesus did.

column7: I wyl passe the discription of the wildernes with ye causes & the maner of the peoples going togither,
column8: I will pass the description of the Wilderness with you Causes & the manner of the peoples going together,

column7: & begin at yt which Chryst dyd, whe they wer comming towardes hym.
column8: & begin At that which Christ did, when they were coming towards him.

column7: I Esus lifting vp his eyes, and seeynge muche people come vnto hym, sayde vnto Philyp:
column8: IEsus IEsus lifting up his eyes, and seeing much people come unto him, said unto Philip:

column7: From whence shall wee bye bread, that these may eat.
column8: From whence shall we buy bred, that these may eat.

column7: Thus he sayed tempting hym:
column8: Thus he said tempting him:

column7: for he hym self knew what he would do.
column8: for he him self knew what he would do.

column7: Philippe aunswered vnto hym: Two hundreth penye worth of bread wyll not be sufficiet vnto these so that euery one myght take a lytell. One of hys disciples Andrew,
column8: Philip answered unto him: Two Hundredth penny worth of bred will not be sufficiet unto these so that every one might take a little. One of his Disciples Andrew,

column7: Simon Peters brother, sayth vnto hym:
column8: Simon Peter's brother, say unto him:

column7: There is one boye here, which hath.v. barely loaues &.ii. fyshes, but what ar those amongest so many?
column8: There is one boy Here, which hath v barely loaves & ii fishes, but what Are those amongst so many?

column7: Iesus sayd, Make the men to sit doun.
column8: jesus said, Make the men to fit down.

column7: Ther was muche grasse in the place:
column8: There was much grass in the place:

column7: The menne therfore sat down about the nuber of.v. thousands Iesus toke the bread, and after thanckes geuynge, did diuide it vnto his disciples, and the discyples to them that were sette:
column8: The men Therefore sat down about the nuber of v thousands jesus took the bred, and After thanks giving, did divide it unto his Disciples, and the Disciples to them that were Set:

column7: And lykewyse of the fyshes, so muche as they woulde.
column8: And likewise of the fishes, so much as they would.

column7: And when they were filled, he sayed vnto hys disciples:
column8: And when they were filled, he said unto his Disciples:

column7: Gather vp the broken meates remayning, that nothynge be lost.
column8: Gather up the broken Meats remaining, that nothing be lost.

column7: They gathered therfore, and filled.xii. baskets ful of those meats which remained, after that they hadde eaten.
column8: They gathered Therefore, and filled xii baskets full of those Meats which remained, After that they had eaten.

column7: The men therfore seeynge what a sygne Iesus hadde done, sayde that thys is trulye the Prophet whych cummeth vnto the world.
column8: The men Therefore seeing what a Signen jesus had done, said that this is truly the Prophet which cometh unto the world.

column7: O Mercyfull Lorde, what a grefe is it to se those which a man loueth hartely, with suche diseases infected, that euerye thinge ministred by the Phisicion to do them good, by theyr own vnquietnes & misusinge of the same doth encrease theyr greuous daungerous sicknes?
column8: O Merciful Lord, what a grief is it to see those which a man loves heartily, with such diseases infected, that every thing ministered by the physician to do them good, by their own unquietness & misusing of the same does increase their grievous dangerous sickness?

column7: For these people, hauing great occasion of comfort, by reason yt in this place, throughe the true preaching of gods worde, al sinne is playnly and frely rebuked, and those thinges especiallye whiche dooe appertayne vnto magystrates, wherby anye man of indifferent iudgemente, maye thinke that these magistrates beinge presente, and willingelye hearynge, be purposed to amende:
column8: For these people, having great occasion of Comfort, by reason that in this place, through the true preaching of God's word, all sin is plainly and freely rebuked, and those things especially which do appertain unto Magistrates, whereby any man of indifferent judgement, may think that these Magistrates being present, and willingly hearing, be purposed to amend:

column7: These people I say, that thus haue a greate occasion of comforte offered vnto them, by theyr owne mistakinge of it, dooe tourne all to theyr further gryefe and daunger.
column8: These people I say, that thus have a great occasion of Comfort offered unto them, by their own mistaking of it, do turn all to their further grief and danger.

column7: For they speake vnreuerently, and vntruly slaunder the magistrates, not only with the faultes that bee here named, but also with rebukynge, imprisoninge, and forbiddinge of the Preachers.
column8: For they speak unreverently, and untruly slander the Magistrates, not only with the Faults that be Here nam, but also with rebuking, imprisoning, and forbidding of the Preachers.

column7: And when as by the same mouth of the true preacher, theyr venemous tounges be rebuked, the they spare not to say, that the Preacher hath learned his lesson in Iacke an apes court:
column8: And when as by the same Mouth of the true preacher, their venomous tongues be rebuked, the they spare not to say, that the Preacher hath learned his Lesson in Jake an Apes court:

column7: doing as much as lyeth in them, to make other men, neither to reuerence the magistrates, nor beleue the Preacher.
column8: doing as much as lies in them, to make other men, neither to Reverence the Magistrates, nor believe the Preacher.

column7: What they them selfes mean thereby, peraduenture by reason of blyndenesse, they wot not.
column8: What they them selves mean thereby, Peradventure by reason of blindness, they wot not.

column7: But we knowinge the craft of the deuill, as Paul writeth.ii. Cor.ii. perceiue that he would haue nothing in thys place layed to the Rulers charge:
column8: But we knowing the craft of the Devil, as Paul Writeth ii Cor ii perceive that he would have nothing in this place laid to the Rulers charge:

column7: Not fearynge howe muche be spoken to those of the people,
column8: Not fearing how much be spoken to those of the people,

column7: whiche be past any amendment by words:
column8: which be passed any amendment by words:

column7: But al yt the deuil feareth, is lest that the rulers be put in remembraunce of the greate daunger that thei be in, for suffring to great enormities vnpunished amongest the people.
column8: But all that the Devil fears, is lest that the Rulers be put in remembrance of the great danger that they be in, for suffering to great enormities unpunished amongst the people.

column7: I therfore trusting to do most good in that whiche the deuyll laboureth the most to hinder, wyll laye great and many fautes vnto them that haue most power,
column8: I Therefore trusting to do most good in that which the Devil Laboureth the most to hinder, will say great and many Faults unto them that have most power,

column7: & authorytye. For sure I am, that rulers ordeyned of God to see the ignoraunte instructed, and the euyll punyshed, be in greate daunger of Gods vengeaunce, for the greate and manifold enormytyes whiche do grow and spryng of ignorance for lacke of knowledge,
column8: & authorytye. For sure I am, that Rulers ordained of God to see the ignorant instructed, and the evil punished, be in great danger of God's vengeance, for the great and manifold enormytyes which do grow and spring of ignorance for lack of knowledge,

column7: & of dissolutenes for lacke of due correccion.
column8: & of dissoluteness for lack of due correction.

column7: And you people be ye sure that the more theyr daunger is, for lack of prouision and punishmente for other mens faultes, the greater is the damnacion of them that comit and do these faultes.
column8: And you people be you sure that the more their danger is, for lack of provision and punishment for other men's Faults, the greater is the damnation of them that Commit and do these Faults.

column7: Nowe I trustinge to God, and not fearinge the deuyll, wyll proceade to declare and applye thys parte of scripture vnto thys Audyence, so that for no man I wyll cloke or flatter any vyce.
column8: Now I trusting to God, and not fearing the Devil, will proceed to declare and apply this part of scripture unto this Audience, so that for no man I will cloak or flatter any vice.

column7: Iesus lyftnge vp hys eyes, and seinge muche people cummynge vnto hym. &c.
column8: jesus lyftnge up his eyes, and sing much people coming unto him. etc.

column7: Here note two thynges: in the people note cominge vnto Christ, and in Christ, note charitable prouision for the people.
column8: Here note two things: in the people note coming unto christ, and in christ, note charitable provision for the people.

column7: For in thys people dothe Christ declare by example,
column8: For in this people doth christ declare by Exampl,

column7: & proue in experyence hys doctryne to be true, whiche he had afore taught, sayinge:
column8: & prove in experience his Doctrine to be true, which he had afore taught, saying:

column7: Fyrste seeke for the kyngdome of God and the ryghtuousnes thereof, and al these other, meaninge necessaryes, shall be ministred vnto you.
column8: First seek for the Kingdom of God and the righteousness thereof, and all these other, meaning necessaries, shall be ministered unto you.

column7: For here they folowinge Chryst, to seke the kyngdome of God, had not onlye this kingdome of God, this bread of lyfe, thys worde of saluacion preached vnto theim, but also all theyr diseases healed,
column8: For Here they following Christ, to seek the Kingdom of God, had not only this Kingdom of God, this bred of life, this word of salvation preached unto them, but also all their diseases healed,

column7: & their hungry bellies with good meates pletifully filled.
column8: & their hungry bellies with good Meats pletifully filled.

column7: Yea the plentye of these people hauinge inoughe euen so muche as they woulde, was farre more then the plentie of crafty Lawers, disceitful Merchauntes, couetous greedyguttes,
column8: Yea the plenty of these people having enough even so much as they would, was Far more then the plenty of crafty Lawyers, disceitful Merchants, covetous greedyguttes,

column7: & ambicious prollers, whiche canne neuer haue inough:
column8: & ambitious prollers, which can never have enough:

column7: but alwayes continewe in vnsaciable hunger, and nede of couetousnes.
column8: but always continue in unsatiable hunger, and need of covetousness.

column7: As the.xiiii. Psal. declareth:
column8: As the xiiii Psalm Declareth:

column7: Diuites eguerunt: The riche haue felt nede & hunger:
column8: Diuites eguerunt: The rich have felt need & hunger:

column7: but they which seke ye lord lacke no goodes
column8: but they which seek you lord lack no goods

column7: He that seeketh to be ryche, bhe neuer so poore a slaue, or so myghtye a Lorde, he falleth into dyuers temptacions and snares of the deuyll:
column8: He that seeks to be rich, bhe never so poor a slave, or so mighty a Lord, he falls into Diverse temptations and snares of the Devil:

column7: but they that seeke the Lorde, shall lacke no goodnes.
column8: but they that seek the Lord, shall lack no Goodness.

column7: Seeke for to be rich,
column8: Seek for to be rich,

column7: & thou shalt fynd sorow, mysery, and mischiefe:
column8: & thou shalt find sorrow, misery, and mischief:

column7: Seeke for to be godlye, and thou shalt find confort, welth, and prosperitie, with al maner of felicity.
column8: Seek for to be godly, and thou shalt find Comfort, wealth, and Prosperity, with all manner of felicity.

column7: If thou wilt be godly, thou must folowe Chryst:
column8: If thou wilt be godly, thou must follow Christ:

column7: thou must not folow the steppes of hys fete, which be taken vp into heauen out of thy syghte, but thou oughtest to folow the doctryne of hys worde, which is here left vpon earthe, to guyde the steppes of thy lyfe, in the way of peace.
column8: thou must not follow the steps of his feet, which be taken up into heaven out of thy sight, but thou Ought to follow the Doctrine of his word, which is Here left upon earth, to guide the steps of thy life, in the Way of peace.

column7: And whyther wyll goddes word gyde the in the tyme of thy trouble and necessytye?
column8: And whither will God's word guide thee in the time of thy trouble and necessytye?

column7: Surely vnto the Lorde, whych saith:
column8: Surely unto the Lord, which Says:

column7: Propter miseriam inopum. &c.
column8: Propter Miseriam inopum. etc.

column7: For the miseryes sakes of the comfortlesse, and syghynges of the poore, now wyl I ryse, sayeth the Lorde.
column8: For the miseries sakes of the comfortless, and syghynges of the poor, now will I rise, Saith the Lord.

column7: O Lorde, seeynge thou haste manye people in Inglande, that as yet be in myseryes without confort, and in pouertye, and lacke helpe, how dooest thou aryse vnto them?
column8: Oh Lord, seeing thou haste many people in England, that as yet be in miseries without Comfort, and in poverty, and lack help, how dost thou arise unto them?

column7: Vnto this the Lorde aunswereth, in the.xxxiiii. of Ezechiel:
column8: Unto this the Lord Answers, in the xxxiiii of Ezechiel:

column7: Suscitabo super eos pastorem unum. &c.
column8: Suscitabo super eos Pastorem Unum. etc.

column7: I wyll set vp ouer theym one pastor, euen my seruaunte Dauyd, he shall feede theym, and he shall be theyr pastor, and I the Lord wyll be theyr God.
column8: I will Set up over them one pastor, even my servant David, he shall feed them, and he shall be their pastor, and I the Lord will be their God.

column7: Thys prophecye was wrytten longe after Dauids tyme.
column8: This prophecy was written long After David time.

column7: Wherefore by Dauid here named, is sygnyfyed and meante suche a Kynge as shalbe as faythfull and diligent to kepe, feede, and cherysh hys subiectes within hys owne Realme, as was Dauid to his people wythin Israell.
column8: Wherefore by David Here nam, is signified and meant such a King as shall as faithful and diligent to keep, feed, and cherish his Subjects within his own Realm, as was David to his people within Israel.

column7: Wee hope, truste and beleue, that oure gracious Kyng, indued wyth the faythfull diligence of Dauid, is ordeyned of God, to gouerne, cherish and feede vs the people of thys his realme.
column8: we hope, trust and believe, that our gracious King, endued with the faithful diligence of David, is ordained of God, to govern, cherish and feed us the people of this his realm.

column7: Wherefore accordinge to the example of Chryst Iesu, most Christe and Gracious Kynge, for the reuerence of God, which hath set you vpon the hygh hyll of honor and authorytye, lyfte vp your gracious eyes of charytable pitie, and behold muche people througheoute all Englande, comminge to seke reliefe, ease and comforte, sente frome God vnto them, by your excellente Maiestye.
column8: Wherefore according to the Exampl of Christ Jesu, most Christ and Gracious King, for the Reverence of God, which hath Set you upon the high hill of honour and authorytye, lift up your gracious eyes of charitable pity, and behold much people througheoute all England, coming to seek relief, ease and Comfort, sent from God unto them, by your excellent Majesty.

column7: For althoughe there hathe bene to much mercy shewed vpon the generacion of vypers, the vngracious rebelles:
column8: For although there hath be to much mercy showed upon the generation of vipers, the ungracious rebels:

column7: Yet is there manye poore people, whiche lyke symple sheepe, shorne to the bare skynne, haue as yet lytle prouision & great neede.
column8: Yet is there many poor people, which like simple sheep, shorn to the bore skin, have as yet little provision & great need.

column7: Euen as.v. thousandes in wildernes folowed Christ and his Apostles, so manye thousandes in Englande, past all other hope and refuge, folowe your gracious maiestye and honourable Counsel.
column8: Eve as v thousandes in Wilderness followed christ and his Apostles, so many thousandes in England, passed all other hope and refuge, follow your gracious majesty and honourable Counsel.

column7: For theyr patsons, whiche should lyke shepheardes feede them, doo lyke theues, robbe, murther and spoyle them.
column8: For their patsons, which should like shepherds feed them, do like thieves, rob, murder and spoil them.

column7: And theyr landlordes which shuld defend them, be moste heauye maisters vnto them:
column8: And their landlords which should defend them, be most heavy masters unto them:

column7: Yea, all maner of officers doo not theyr duties to kepe the people in good order, but rather take such fees as maketh the people veraye poore.
column8: Yea, all manner of Officers do not their duties to keep the people in good order, but rather take such fees as makes the people very poor.

column7: Who so hathe eyes, and wyll see, may easely perceiue that those personages, which be most in number and greateste in value throughout al Englande, be no shepherds houses to laye vp fodder to feede the poore shepe of the parysh, but theeuysh dennes, to conuey awaye great spoyle from all the rych men of the parysh.
column8: Who so hath eyes, and will see, may Easily perceive that those Personages, which be most in number and greatest in valve throughout all England, be no shepherd's houses to say up fodder to feed the poor sheep of the parish, but thievish dens, to convey away great spoil from all the rich men of the parish.

column7: I say ther is no person there, to releue the poore & nedy with natural sustinauce in ke^ynge of house, and to fede all ingenerally with the heauenly foode of goddes worde by preachinge:
column8: I say there is no person there, to relieve the poor & needy with natural sustinauce in ke^ynge of house, and to fede all ingenerally with the heavenly food of God's word by preaching:

column7: But there is a persons deputy or fermer, which hauing neither habilitye, power, nor authorytye to doo the persons dutye in feedyng and teachinge the parish, is able, sufficient, and stout inough to chalenge and take for hys maysters dutye the tenth parte of al the parysh.
column8: But there is a Persons deputy or Fermer, which having neither hability, power, nor authorytye to do the Persons duty in feeding and teaching the parish, is able, sufficient, and stout enough to challenge and take for his masters duty the tenth part of all the parish.

column7: Likewise other officers take many fees, and do few dutyes:
column8: Likewise other Officers take many fees, and do few duties:

column7: And especiallye landlordes take exceadynge fynes and rentes of theyr tenauntes, and doo no good vnto theyr tenauntes.
column8: And especially landlords take exceeding fines and rents of their tenants, and do no good unto their tenants.

column7: Now my Lordes, bothe of the laitie and of the clergy, in the name of god,
column8: Now my lords, both of the laity and of the Clergy, in the name of god,

column7: I aduertyse you to take heede:
column8: I advertise you to take heed:

column7: for when the Lorde of all Lordes shal se his flocke scattred, spylte and loste, if he folowe the trace of the bloude, it wyll leade him euen streyght waye vnto thys court, and vnto your houses, where as these great theues which murther, spoyl, and destroy the flockes of Chryst, be receyued, kept, and mainteined.
column8: for when the Lord of all lords shall see his flock scattered, spylte and lost, if he follow the trace of the blood, it will lead him even straight Way unto this court, and unto your houses, where as these great thieves which murder, spoil, and destroy the flocks of Christ, be received, kept, and maintained.

column7: For you maintain your chaplens to take Pluralities,
column8: For you maintain your Chaplens to take Pluralities,

column7: & youre other seruaunts mo offices then they can or wyl discharge.
column8: & your other Servants more Offices then they can or will discharge.

column7: Fye for synne and shame, eyther gyue your seruauntes wages, or els let them go and scrue those which do gyue them wages.
column8: Fie for sin and shame, either gyve your Servants wages, or Else let them go and scrue those which do gyve them wages.

column7: For now your chaplaynes, your seruaunts,
column8: For now your Chaplains, your Servants,

column7: & you your selues haue the persons, the shepherds,
column8: & you your selves have the Persons, the shepherd's,

column7: & the offycers wages, & nether you nor they, nor other doth ye persons, the shepherds or the officers duty, excepte peradueture ye imagin that ther is a parishe priest, curate, which doth the persons duti.
column8: & the Officers wages, & neither you nor they, nor other does the Persons, the shepherd's or the Officers duty, except Peradventure you imagine that there is a parish priest, curate, which does the Persons duti.

column7: But although ye do so imagin, yet the people do feel and perceiue that he doeth meane no other thing but pay your duty, pay your dutye.
column8: But although you do so imagine, yet the people do feel and perceive that he doth mean no other thing but pay your duty, pay your duty.

column7: Yes forsouth he ministreth Gods sacramentes, he sayeth hys seruice, and he readeth the homilies, as you fyne, flatring, courtiers, which speake by imaginacion, tearme it:
column8: Yes forsooth he Ministereth God's Sacraments, he Saith his service, and he readeth the homilies, as you fine, flattering, courtiers, which speak by imagination, term it:

column7: But the rude lobbes of the countrye, whiche be to symple to paynte a lye, speake foule and truly as thei finde it, and saye.
column8: But the rude lobbes of the country, which be to simple to paint a lie, speak foul and truly as they find it, and say.

column7: He minisheth Goddes sacramentes, he slubbers vp his seruice and he can not reade the humbles.
column8: He minisheth Goddess Sacraments, he slubbers up his service and he can not read the humbles.

column7: Yet is there some that canne reade very well, but how many of those be not either supersticious papystes, or els carnall gospellers, whiche by theyr euyll example of lyuyng, and worse doctrine, do farre more harme then they do good by theyr fayre reading & saying of seruice.
column8: Yet is there Some that can read very well, but how many of those be not either superstitious Papists, or Else carnal Evangelists, which by their evil Exampl of living, and Worse Doctrine, do Far more harm then they do good by their fair reading & saying of service.

column7: But put the case, as it maye be, that there be at a benefyce in some place at somtime, some good curate, all those summes wyll make but a feewe in number, and yet ye see many persons in manye places absente from theyr benifices, whiche if they be seldome absente, may be good, but if they be contynually or for the most part absent, then can they be neither good, honest nor godly.
column8: But put the case, as it may be, that there be At a benefice in Some place At sometime, Some good curate, all those sums will make but a feewe in number, and yet you see many Persons in many places absent from their Benefices, which if they be seldom absent, may be good, but if they be continually or for the most part absent, then can they be neither good, honest nor godly.

column7: For if theyr dutye be vndone, then can no man excuse them:
column8: For if their duty be undone, then can no man excuse them:

column7: if it be done, then is it by other and not by them:
column8: if it be done, then is it by other and not by them:

column7: and then whye dooe they lyue of other mennes laboures?
column8: and then why do they live of other men's labours?

column7: He that preacheth the gospell, shoulde lyue vpon the Gospell, as God hathe ordeyned:
column8: He that Preacheth the gospel, should live upon the Gospel, as God hath ordained:

column7: As for those, Qui mollibus uestiuntur, in domibus Regum, whyche goo gaye in Kynges houses, and either mosell the labouringe oxe, or els spoyl the poore parish in the country, be of the deuyls ordynaunce.
column8: As for those, Qui mollibus uestiuntur, in domibus Regum, which goo gay in Kings houses, and either mosell the labouring ox, or Else spoil the poor parish in the country, be of the Devils Ordinance.

column7: As there is in all offices some putte in by Chryste, some by the deuyll:
column8: As there is in all Offices Some put in by Christ, Some by the Devil:

column7: so is there is personages, some sente from Chryst as shepherdes to fede,
column8: so is there is Personages, Some sent from Christ as shepherdess to fede,

column7: & some from the deuyll, as theues to deuoure.
column8: & Some from the Devil, as thieves to devour.

column7: Yea amongest all kyndes of offycers, some be true Prophetes and sheppeheardes in dede, and some haue shepe skynnes, and be raueninge wolues in dede.
column8: Yea amongst all Kinds of Officers, Some be true prophets and sheppeheardes in deed, and Some have sheep skins, and be ravening wolves in deed.

column7: The one taketh paynes in doyng of hys dutye, and the other seketh gaynes in professyng of hys duty.
column8: The one Takes pains in doing of his duty, and the other seeketh gains in professing of his duty.

column7: Take heede of those, for they ar erraunt theeues.
column8: Take heed of those, for they Are errant thieves.

column7: Alas, if all those whiche take the names and professyons of offycers, for desyre of luker and honor, and do not execute the dutyes belonginge to theyr offyces wyth painful diligence, be errant theues as they be in deede, then is ther mani a strong erraunt theefe amongst the yt be called honest, worshipful, and honorable men.
column8: Alas, if all those which take the names and professyons of Officers, for desire of luker and honour, and do not execute the duties belonging to their Offices with painful diligence, be errant thieves as they be in deed, then is there mani a strong errant thief among the that be called honest, worshipful, and honourable men.

column7: For they haue the names, the authorytyes & vauntages of those offyces gyuen & payed vnto them, the dutyes of the whyche be verye slenderly or nothyng at al executed amongest the people.
column8: For they have the names, the authorytyes & vantages of those Offices given & paid unto them, the duties of the which be very slenderly or nothing At all executed amongst the people.

column7: If I were in anye other place in al England,
column8: If I were in any other place in all England,

column7: I could and wold vse another trade of preachynge afore another audience:
column8: I could and would use Another trade of preaching afore Another audience:

column7: but beinge called of God by your appoyntement, vnto this place at this tyme, my conscience doth compell me to vse this trade and no other, afore this solemne audience.
column8: but being called of God by your appointment, unto this place At this time, my conscience does compel me to use this trade and no other, afore this solemn audience.

column7: Wherfore with dreede and feare of God, with charitable pyty of the people, with moste reuerend loue and homage vnto your honors,
column8: Wherefore with dread and Fear of God, with charitable pyty of the people, with most reverend love and homage unto your honours,

column7: I muste needes cry wyth the Prophete Esaye:
column8: I must needs cry with the Prophet Isaiah:

column7: Principes Sodome, populus Gomorre:
column8: Princes Sodom, populus Gomorrah:

column7: Heare the woorde of the Lorde ye Prynces of Sodome, ye people of Gomorra:
column8: Hear the word of the Lord you Princes of Sodom, you people of Gomorra:

column7: Quo mihi multitudo uictimarum uestrarum.
column8: Quo mihi multitudo uictimarum uestrarum.

column7: What care I for the great number of your sacrifyces,
column8: What care I for the great number of your Sacrifices,

column7: Dicit Dominus, sayth the Lord:
column8: Dicit Dominus, say the Lord:

column7: rebukyng all the sacrifices, Cerimonyes, and feastes of the Iewes which he him self had commaunded to be obserued and kept:
column8: rebuking all the Sacrifices, Cerimones, and feasts of the Jews which he him self had commanded to be observed and kept:

column7: by the which thyng lest in wrytyng he doth teach and commaund me how to speake of your well doyng here in England.
column8: by the which thing lest in writing he does teach and command me how to speak of your well doing Here in England.

column7: Heare therfore ye Prynces of Sodome, and ye people of Gomor, thus sayth the Lord:
column8: Hear Therefore you Princes of Sodom, and you people of Gomor, thus say the Lord:

column7: What pleasure haue I, yea what care I for all your Englysh Bibles,
column8: What pleasure have I, yea what care I for all your English Bibles,

column7: Homelies, & all your other bookes?
column8: Homilies, & all your other books?

column7: set forth no more godly seruice to honor me wyth:
column8: Set forth no more godly service to honour me with:

column7: I hate them al wyth my herte, they are greuous vnto me,
column8: I hate them all with my heart, they Are grievous unto me,

column7: I am wery of them:
column8: I am weary of them:

column7: Yea, it is a great payne for me to suffer them.
column8: Yea, it is a great pain for me to suffer them.

column7: Why, O Lord these be good, these be godly, and these be necessarye thynges.
column8: Why, Oh Lord these be good, these be godly, and these be necessary things.

column7: Truthe it is, the faulte is not in the things that be set forth, but in you yt haue set them furthe.
column8: Truth it is, the fault is not in the things that be Set forth, but in you that have Set them forth.

column7: Manus enim uestre plene sunt sanguine:
column8: Manus enim uestre plene sunt sanguine:

column7: For your handes are ful of bloud.
column8: For your hands Are full of blood.

column7: Your handes, your seruyce and your houses be full of persons liuynges preachers liuinges, and offycers lyuynges.
column8: Your hands, your service and your houses be full of Persons livings Preachers livings, and Officers livings.

column7: And by you, the person hath his dyspensacion, the preacher is put to scilence, and the offycer vnpunyshed, for neglectynge of hys dutye.
column8: And by you, the person hath his dyspensacion, the preacher is put to silence, and the officer unpunished, for neglecting of his duty.

column7: And so through the negligence of the kepers (good order, which is ye pale of the parke of this comunewelth dekaied) the dere therof most dearly bought wyth Chrystes bloude, haue strayed oute of theire owne feedynge, to dystroye the corne of all mens liuinges:
column8: And so through the negligence of the keepers (good order, which is the pale of the park of this comunewelth dekaied) the dear thereof most dearly bought with Christ's blood, have strayed out of their own feeding, to destroy the corn of all men's livings:

column7: Where as very necessytye hath compelled you with such force to driue the backe, as must needes distroye manye of those dere.
column8: Where as very necessytye hath compelled you with such force to driven the back, as must needs destroy many of those dear.

column7: Those people I mean, whych you haue cheryshed & kept & as yet doo loue and pitie aboue al other iewels, commodities and pleasures.
column8: Those people I mean, which you have cherished & kept & as yet do love and pity above all other Jewels, commodities and pleasures.

column7: Alas, these that take the liuinges, and doo not the dutyes of Persons,
column8: Alas, these that take the livings, and do not the duties of Persons,

column7: Preachers, land lordes, Bailyes, and of other officers:
column8: Preachers, land Lords, Bailiffs, and of other Officers:

column7: These flaterers, these wolfes in labes skinnes, these deuils in mens vysers, haue caused you to be thought and taken as cruell oppressers of those people, whose ^^^^ous wulde ^^age ye dyd suppresse and * vnder, of veraye charitable pitie towardes them,
column8: These Flatterers, these wolves in labes skins, these Devils in men's visers, have caused you to be Thought and taken as cruel Oppresses of those people, whose ^^ous would age you did suppress and * under, of very charitable pity towards them,

column7: & all other, whyche wyth that rebellious rage, shoulde haue be al togither distroied, if the help of your power and authoritye hadde bene any longer diff^^ed.
column8: & all other, which with that rebellious rage, should have be all together destroyed, if the help of your power and Authority had be any longer diff^^ed.

column7: Surely, vntyl that these prollets for themselues, these children of the dyuell, these sowers of sedicion be taken out of the way, either by reformacion, or by distruccion, your charitable pity and prouision for the people, and theyr reuerend loue & obedience towardes you, shall neuer be sene, felte, and knowen.
