column8: Surely, until that these prollets for themselves, these children of the Devil, these sower's of sedition be taken out of the Way, either by Reformation, or by destruction, your charitable pity and provision for the people, and their reverend love & Obedience towards you, shall never be seen, felt, and known.

column7: Nowe, as Helye was giltye of the whordome, extorcion, and abhominacion of his sonnes, so are youre hertes ful of crueltye, and youre handes full of bloude, not so muche by doyng, as by sufferynge all these euyls.
column8: Now, as Elijah was guilty of the whoredom, extortion, and abomination of his Sons, so Are your herts full of cruelty, and your hands full of blood, not so much by doing, as by suffering all these evils.

column7: Wherfore Lauamini, mundi estote:
column8: Wherefore Lawman, mundi estote:

column7: Wash, & make your selues cleane, with the teares of repentaunce.
column8: Wash, & make your selves clean, with the tears of Repentance.

column7: Auferte malum cogitacionum uestrarum ab oculis meis:
column8: Auferte malum cogitacionum uestrarum ab oculis meis:

column7: Away wt the euyll of your thoughtes from afore myne eyes.
column8: Away with the evil of your thoughts from afore mine eyes.

column7: Open youre heartes, that the sworde of Gods word maye come to wipe awaye couetousnes, whyche is the roote of all euyll, planted in youre hertes.
column8: Open your hearts, that the sword of God's word may come to wipe away covetousness, which is the root of all evil, planted in your herts.

column7: For yf that roote contyneuether, than ca no good springe from you:
column8: For if that root contyneuether, than circa no good spring from you:

column7: but euen the most pure and holesome worde of God sette forth by you continuinge in couitousnes, wyll be abhominable in the syghte of God, offensyue vnto the people,
column8: but even the most pure and wholesome word of God Set forth by you Continuing in couitousnes, will be abominable in the sight of God, offensyue unto the people,

column7: & damnable vnto you your selues.
column8: & damnable unto you your selves.

column7: Wherefore, Quiescite agere peruerse:
column8: Wherefore, Quiescite agere perverse:

column7: Seasse to peruerte, manye thynges from euyll vnto worse.
column8: Seasse to pervert, many things from evil unto Worse.

column7: Discite benefacere: Learne to do wel, in conforminge al thinges that be a misse, vnto a good order.
column8: Discite benefacere: Learn to do well, in conforming all things that be a miss, unto a good order.

column7: Querite Iudicium: Serche for ryghteous iudgement which is almost banyshed out of Englande.
column8: Query Iudicium: Search for righteous judgement which is almost banished out of England.

column7: Alas what a iudgemente is thys, a supersticious papiste, whyche hath made the faulte shall haue a pension out of a Chauntrye, so longe as he lyueth, and a poore parysh, whych hath greate nede and done ^is faulte shall lose and forfayte many Chauntries vtterly for euer Subuenite oppresso:
column8: Alas what a judgement is this, a superstitious papist, which hath made the fault shall have a pension out of a Chantry, so long as he liveth, and a poor parish, which hath great need and done is fault shall loose and forfeit many Chantries utterly for ever Subuenite oppresso:

column7: Helpe the oppressed people that be loaden with heuye burdeyns of payinge wages to manye offyces, and faynte for lacke of releife,
column8: Help the oppressed people that be loaded with heavy burdens of paying wages to many Offices, and faint for lack of relief,

column7: & dewe seruyce of the offycer.
column8: & dew service of the officer.

column7: Iudicate pupillo: Iudge so to the fatherlesse chyldrens behofe, that wardship mai be a good prouision for fatherles chyldren, and not an vncharitable spoyle of yong mens lands.
column8: Judicate pupillo: Judge so to the fatherless Children's behoof, that wardship mai be a good provision for fatherless children, and not an uncharitable spoil of young men's Lands.

column7: Defendite uiduam: Shielde the widow from al mens iniuryes, and compell them not to mary your vnthrifty seruauntes.
column8: Defend it uiduam: Shield the widow from all men's injuries, and compel them not to marry your unthrifty Servants.

column7: Thus hath God by Esaye in hys tyme, and by me at thys tyme described Rulers Faultes, wyth a waye how to a mend them.
column8: Thus hath God by Isaiah in his time, and by me At this time described Rulers Faults, with a Way how to a mend them.

column7: Therfore, Principes Anglie:
column8: Therefore, Princes English:

column7: Ye heade Rulers and gouernors of England, fyrste see, acknowledge, amende your owne faultes:
column8: You head Rulers and Governors of England, First see, acknowledge, amend your own Faults:

column7: and then, perusynge all vnder offycers, consyder and note how few shepheards and offyces doo feede and kepe,
column8: and then, perusing all under Officers, Consider and note how few shepherds and Offices do feed and keep,

column7: by doynge dutyes, and how many theeues and wolfes do robbe and spoyle the flockes, by takyng fees here in Englande:
column8: by doing duties, and how many thieves and wolves do rob and spoil the flocks, by taking fees Here in England:

column7: and then shall ye perceaue that there must nedes be manye sheepe, that wyth theyr hertes, myndes, and expectacion, do folowe the Kynges Maiestye, and you of hys honorable counsel so farre past the houses and cities of their owne prouysion, that if they haue not spedy reliefe at your handes, manye of theim is lyke to fainte and decaye by the way.
column8: and then shall you perceive that there must needs be many sheep, that with their herts, minds, and expectation, do follow the Kings Majesty, and you of his honourable counsel so Far passed the houses and cities of their own prouysion, that if they have not speedy relief At your hands, many of them is like to faint and decay by the Way.

column7: Therfore thys considered and knowen, as Christ liftinge vp his eyes dyd teach you to see and consyder the people so learne by that whiche foloweth in Christes dooynge, what shalbe your dutye after that ye se and knowe the multitude, the state and condicion of the people.
column8: Therefore this considered and known, as christ lifting up his eyes did teach you to see and Consider the people so Learn by that which Followeth in Christ's doing, what shall your duty After that you see and know the multitude, the state and condition of the people.

column7: And he said vnto Philyp:
column8: And he said unto Philip:

column7: From whence shall we bye breade, that these maye eate?
column8: From whence shall we buy bread, that these may eat?

column7: But thys he sayde to proue hym:
column8: But this he said to prove him:

column7: for he hym selfe knewe what he would do.
column8: for he him self knew what he would do.

column7: Christ said to Philip as euerye Christe Kyng ought to say to his Counsell:
column8: christ said to Philip as every Christ King ought to say to his Counsel:

column7: From whence shall we that be gouernors, kepets and feders, bye & prouyde with our own costes, labor, and diligence, bread, foode and necessaryes, that these may eate and be relieued, which be our subiects in obedience, brethre in Christ, and felow heyres of the heauenly kyngdome?
column8: From whence shall we that be Governors, kepets and feeders, buy & provide with our own costs, labour, and diligence, bred, food and necessaries, that these may eat and be relieved, which be our Subjects in Obedience, brethren in christ, and fellow Heirs of the heavenly Kingdom?

column7: Pharao wyth hys Counsell in Egypte, consulted howe to bryng the welthy people vnto misery:
column8: Pharaoh with his Counsel in Egypt, consulted how to bring the wealthy people unto misery:

column7: so that he is a very Pharonicall tyat, whych laboureth by oppressio to thrust down the welthy people:
column8: so that he is a very Pharaonic tyat, which Laboureth by oppressio to thrust down the wealthy people:

column7: And he is a faithful christen king that humbleth him self by diligece to releiue, conforte, and set vp the afflycted people.
column8: And he is a faithful christian King that Humbleth him self by diligence to relieve, Comfort, and Set up the afflicted people.

column7: For the one, by worldly policy, would haue much honor, and the other of godly charitie wil do much good.
column8: For the one, by worldly policy, would have much honour, and the other of godly charity will do much good.

column7: Christ also said this, to proue and trie Philip, knowyng him self what shuld be done.
column8: christ also said this, to prove and try Philip, knowing him self what should be done.

column7: So that here, Kynges and great men may learne to trye, and proue the honestie, wit, and fidelitie of theyr Cousellers, in such matters as they them selues be so perfect that they can diserne wyth what discrecion and mynd the couseller doth answere.
column8: So that Here, Kings and great men may Learn to try, and prove the honesty, wit, and Fidis of their Counsellors, in such matters as they them selves be so perfect that they can discern with what discretion and mind the couseller does answer.

column7: Philip auswered, that two hudreth peny worth of breade wyll not serue vnto these, so that euerye one myghte take a lyttell
column8: Philip answered, that two hudreth penny worth of bread will not serve unto these, so that every one might take a little

column7: In the which answere, as concernynge his witte, he declareth it to be to slender to prouide for so great a matter in so short tyme.
column8: In the which answer, as Concerning his wit, he Declareth it to be to slender to provide for so great a matter in so short time.

column7: And hys mynde semed to be suche as would not haue Christ to trouble hym selfe wyth so great cares but rather as the other Euangelistes do declare, to sende the people away, and let them prouid for them selfes.
column8: And his mind seemed to be such as would not have christ to trouble him self with so great Cares but rather as the other Evangelists do declare, to send the people away, and let them provide for them selves.

column7: The same minde and affeccion was in Peter, after that Christ hadde tolde hys Disciples howe that we must go to Ierusalem to suffer sore paines and miserable death.
column8: The same mind and affection was in Peter, After that christ had told his Disciples how that we must go to Jerusalem to suffer soar pains and miserable death.

column7: For then Peter tooke hym a syde and sayde:
column8: For then Peter took him a side and said:

column7: Mayster fauour your self, doo not enter in to such daunger and sorowes.
column8: Master favour your self, do not enter in to such danger and sorrows.

column7: And it is not vnlyke, but if youre Magestye;
column8: And it is not unlike, but if your Majesty;

column7: wyth youre Counsell speake vnto youre nobles for prouision now to be made for the people:
column8: with your Counsel speak unto your Nobles for provision now to be made for the people:

column7: ye shall fynde some that bee Philippians and Peters, whyche by settynge afore youre eyes the hardnes of the matter, the tendernes of your yeares, and the wonderfull charges that should be requisite, wyl moue and counsel you to quyet youre selfe, to take youre case, yea to take your pastime, in haukyng,
column8: you shall find Some that be Philippians and Peter's, which by setting afore your eyes the hardness of the matter, the tenderness of your Years, and the wonderful charges that should be requisite, will move and counsel you to quiet your self, to take your case, yea to take your pastime, in haukyng,

column7: Huntyng or gamnyng. Vnto whom your Magestie may aunswer, as Christ dyd vnto Peter:
column8: Hunting or gamnyng. Unto whom your Majesty may answer, as christ did unto Peter:

column7: Auoyde fro me Sathan, thou hyndrest me by thy carnall temptacion, to doo that thyng whyche God hath moued me vnto by hys gracious inspiracion.
column8: Avoid from me Sathan, thou hyndrest me by thy carnal temptation, to do that thing which God hath moved me unto by his gracious inspiration.

column7: Thou hast no tast nor sauour howe delicious God is vnto a pure conscience, in Godly excercise of good worckes.
column8: Thou hast no taste nor savour how delicious God is unto a pure conscience, in Godly Exercise of good works.

column7: But al that thouregardest & felest is voluptuous pleasure in worldly vanities.
column8: But all that thouregardest & Feel is voluptuous pleasure in worldly vanities.

column7: And therefore yu doest not perceiue, how yt they which be indued with a special grace of god may fynd more pleasure & pastime in godly gouernauce, to kepe togither & saue simple me, then in hau king and huntynge, to chase and kyll wylde beasies.
column8: And Therefore thou dost not perceive, how that they which be endued with a special grace of god may find more pleasure & pastime in godly governance, to keep together & save simple me, then in hau King and hunting, to chase and kill wild beasies.

column7: Yea, a godly kyng shall finde more pleasure in castinge lots for Ionas, to trye out offenders, whiche trouble the ship of his commune wealth, then in casting dice at hasarde, to alow & maintaine by his example, such thynges as should not be suffered in a commune wealth.
column8: Yea, a godly King shall find more pleasure in casting lots for Jonah, to try out offenders, which trouble the ship of his commune wealth, then in casting dice At hazard, to allow & maintain by his Exampl, such things as should not be suffered in a commune wealth.

column7: Yea surely, a good King shal take farre more delyte in edifiynge wyth conforte and deckynge wyth good order the Congregacion of hys people, the Churche and house of God, the heauenly Citye of Ierusalem, then in buildinge suche houses as seeme gaye and gorgeous, and be in deede but vyle earthe, stones, tymber and claye.
column8: Yea surely, a good King shall take Far more delight in edifying with Comfort and decking with good order the Congregation of his people, the Church and house of God, the heavenly city of Jerusalem, then in building such houses as seem gay and gorgeous, and be in deed but vile earth, stones, timber and clay.

column7: Suche lyke aunswer ought your Magestye,
column8: Suche like answer ought your Majesty,

column7: & all noble men to make, if ye fynde any of your Counsellers more canal than spiritual, more worldlye then godly.
column8: & all noble men to make, if you find any of your Counsellers more canal than spiritual, more worldly then godly.

column7: Or els tourne awaye your eares from such Philipians,
column8: Or Else turn away your ears from such Philippians,

column7: & heare other, as Christ did.
column8: & hear other, as christ did.

column7: Then saide vnto him one of his Disciples,
column8: Then said unto him one of his Disciples,

column7: Andrew Simon Peters brother, Ther is a boye here that hath fyue barely loanes and two fyshes, but what auaile those amoge so manye?
column8: Andrew Simon Peter's brother, There is a boy Here that hath fyue barely loans and two fishes, but what avail those Among so many?

column7: Note here that this boye was she Apostles page,
column8: Note Here that this boy was she Apostles page,

column7: & these loues and fishes were their vittayles.
column8: & these loves and Fish were their vittayles.

column7: For as appeareth in Marke, whe thei had made search howe manye loaues they them selues had, thys answere was made, yt they had.v. loues &.ii. fishes:
column8: For as appears in Mark, when they had made search how many loaves they them selves had, this answer was made, that they had v loves & ii Fish:

column7: but what be they amogest so many?
column8: but what be they Amongst so many?

column7: As who should say: although these be al yt euer we haue & seme more mete to be kept amongest a few, the to be giuen to many, yet for because thei yt becum whyche beynge many haue more nede then we:
column8: As who should say: although these be all that ever we have & seem more meet to be kept amongst a few, the to be given to many, yet for Because they that become which being many have more need then we:

column7: therefore ar we willinge to giue the to be disposed,
column8: Therefore Are we willing to give thee to be disposed,

column7: & wish yt they were of more value to do more good amogest ye people.
column8: & wish that they were of more valve to do more good Amongst you people.

column7: These men cared more for the Commune people, then they dyd for them selues, and therfore were very mete to be Counsellers, and neare about a great Kyng.
column8: These men cared more for the Commune people, then they did for them selves, and Therefore were very meet to be Counsellers, and near about a great King.

column7: Here we perceyue what symple Phylippe, and good Andrewe thinke, but here is nothyng declared of couetous Iudas counsell.
column8: Here we perceive what simple Philip, and good Andrew think, but Here is nothing declared of covetous Judas counsel.

column7: No, for Christ beynge fully purposed to doo a good deede doeth neither aske, nor heare anye counsell of couetous Iudas:
column8: No, for christ being Fully purposed to do a good deed doth neither ask, nor hear any counsel of covetous Judas:

column7: teachyng all them whych intende any goodnes, neuer to aske nor admit anye counsel of those whom they know to be couetous.
column8: teaching all them which intend any Goodness, never to ask nor admit any counsel of those whom they know to be covetous.

column7: For truely the couetous mans councel, although it seme neuer so good and honest, yet is it in dede nought and deuilish.
column8: For truly the covetous men council, although it seem never so good and honest, yet is it in deed nought and devilish.

column7: For what could seme better counsel then yt a litle ointmet, the swete smel of the whyche continued but a while among a few, should haue ben sould for thre hundreth pence, the greate price of the whyche bestowed amongeste manye poore, should haue done them good for a great season?
column8: For what could seem better counsel then that a little ointmet, the sweet Smell of the which continued but a while among a few, should have been should for Three Hundredth pence, the great price of the which bestowed amongst many poor, should have done them good for a great season?

column7: The Euangelyst doeth shewe howe that Iudas dyd gyue thys counsell, not for that he had anye care of the poore, but bycause he was a thefe, and bare the bagges.
column8: The Evangelist doth show how that Judas did gyve this counsel, not for that he had any care of the poor, but Because he was a thief, and bore the bags.

column7: Iudas pretence was wonders godlye, to sell the oyntmente for a great summe of moneye, to relieue the poore wyth, but hys purpose was deuelyshe, to get the mony in hys bagges, and kepe it to hym selfe.
column8: Judas pretence was wonders godly, to fell the oyntmente for a great sum of money, to relieve the poor with, but his purpose was deuelyshe, to get the money in his bags, and keep it to him self.

column7: And those in England whyche dyd pretende, that besides the abolishinge of supersticion, wyth the landes of Abbeys,
column8: And those in England which did pretend, that beside the abolishing of Superstition, with the Lands of Abbeys,

column7: Coliges and Chauntries, the King should be enryched, learnynge mayntayned, pouertye relieued, and the comune wealthe eased, and by thys pretence purposely haue enriched theym selues, settynge a brode incloystered papistes, to get their liuinges by giuing them pencions, yea, and thrustynge them into benefices to poyson the whole commune welth for the risignacion of those pencions:
column8: Colleges and Chantries, the King should be enriched, learning maintained, poverty relieved, and the Common wealth eased, and by this pretence purposely have enriched them selves, setting a broad incloistered Papists, to get their livings by giving them pensions, yea, and thrusting them into Benefices to poison the Whole commune wealth for the risignacion of those pensions:

column7: & so craftly coueying much fro the King, fro lerning from pouertye,
column8: & so craftily coveying much from the King, from learning from poverty,

column7: & from al the commune wealth, vnto their own priuate vauntage:
column8: & from all the commune wealth, unto their own private vantage:

column7: These mennes counsell semed better then Iudas counsell was:
column8: These men's counsel seemed better then Judas counsel was:

column7: and their couetousnes, by their owne deedes appeareth no lesse then Iudas couetousnesse dyd.
column8: and their covetousness, by their own Deeds appears no less then Judas covetousness did.

column7: Well, beware, for if ye play Iudas part on styll,
column8: Well, beware, for if you play Judas part on still,

column7: & make no restitucion, vntil ye go to hangyng, ye are lyke to fynde desperacio at the end of your life, because ye wold not by restitucion amend your life.
column8: & make no restitution, until you go to hanging, you Are like to find desperacio At the end of your life, Because you would not by restitution amend your life.

column7: Ye noble me, & especialli you of the kings cousel, for the reuerence of God, pitie of the comen wealth, and safegarde of your selfes, awaye wyth these Iudasses, let them go hange them selues:
column8: the noble me, & especialli you of the Kings counsel, for the Reverence of God, pity of the come wealth, and safeguard of your selves, away with these Judases, let them go hang them selves:

column7: excepte perauenture ye thyncke it fytte and necessary, that you fyrst hang them afore thei betray you.
column8: except Peradventure you think it fit and necessary, that you fyrst hang them afore they betray you.

column7: For vndoutedly, he that hath the couetousnes of Iudas in his hert he wyll playe all the other partes of Iudas, if he euer haue suche oportunitie as Iudas had.
column8: For undoubtedly, he that hath the covetousness of Judas in his heart he will play all the other parts of Judas, if he ever have such opportunity as Judas had.

column7: A way with Iudas, and learne at Andrew, to saye vnto thys kynge and his councel intendynge to relieue the multitude of hys people here in Englande, learne ye noble men to saye:
column8: A Way with Judas, and Learn At Andrew, to say unto this King and his council intending to relieve the multitude of his people Here in England, Learn you noble men to say:

column7: Here is a boye: Here be seruauntes and retayners of oures whyche haue fyue loaues and two fyshes, manye benefices, some prebendes, wyth dyuers offyces:
column8: Here is a boy: Here be Servants and retainers of ours which have fyue loaves and two fishes, many Benefices, Some Prebends, with Diverse Offices:

column7: yea, and some of vs our selues haue mo offyces then we can discharge.
column8: yea, and Some of us our selves have more Offices then we can discharge.

column7: Pleaseth it your maiestie to take these into your hands, which haue bene kept for vs, that they now in thys great nede, maye be better disposed amongest youre people.
column8: Pleases it your majesty to take these into your hands, which have be kept for us, that they now in this great need, may be better disposed amongst your people.

column7: Quid hec inter tantos?
column8: Quid hec inter tantos?

column7: These be verye small thynges towardes the amendemet of so many lackes in so great a multitude.
column8: These be very small things towards the amendemet of so many lacks in so great a multitude.

column7: How be it these wyl serue, so that there maye be mo good Persons, good preachers, and good officers placed a brode in euery countrye, which in doing theyr offices, keping of houses, and preachyng of gods worde may teach the ignoraunte, relieue the poore, punyshe the fautye, and cheryshe the honest, and so repayre the pale of good order about thys comen welth.
column8: How be it these will serve, so that there may be more good Persons, good Preachers, and good Officers placed a broad in every country, which in doing their Offices, keeping of houses, and preaching of God's word may teach the ignorant, relieve the poor, Punish the faulty, and cherish the honest, and so repair the pale of good order about this come wealth.

column7: For the loue of God giue your seruauntes wages, and cause the to restore these liuinges, whych coming of the sweate of the labourer, be in dede the relife of ye poore, the mayntenaunce of honestye, and the reward of vertue, yea the verye pale, wall, and bulwarkes of the commen wealth.
column8: For the love of God give your Servants wages, and cause thee to restore these livings, which coming of the sweat of the labourer, be in deed the relife of the poor, the maintenance of honesty, and the reward of virtue, yea the very pale, wall, and bulwarks of the come wealth.

column7: The Apostles gaue all that they had of theyr owne, freelye vnto other:
column8: The Apostles gave all that they had of their own, freely unto other:

column7: stycke not you to restore that now whych ye haue of longe tyme vncharitably kept from other.
column8: stick not you to restore that now which you have of long time uncharitably kept from other.

column7: Heare what foloweth: whan these fishes & loaues were broughte vnto Iesus, make (sayeth he) the people to sit downe.
column8: Hear what Followeth: when these Fish & loaves were brought unto jesus, make (Saith he) the people to fit down.

column7: God alwayes bestoweth his benefites vpon theim that sit doune in quietnes,
column8: God always bestoweth his benefits upon them that fit down in quietness,

column7: & powreth furth hye vegauce vpo those that be vnpacient, vnquiet,
column8: & poureth forth high vegauce upon those that be unpatient, unquiet,

column7: & full of businesse. For as appeareth in Genesis, the people gathered together in the playne of Sanner,
column8: & full of business. For as appears in Genesis, the people gathered together in the plain of Banner,

column7: & made a greate vprore, buildyng a tower lyke rebels agaynst god, to get the a name.
column8: & made a great uproar, building a tower like rebels against god, to get the a name.

column7: Howe be it god destroied their hadyworke, cofouded theyr lagage, & scatered the abrod.
column8: Howe be it god destroyed their hadyworke, cofouded their lagage, & scattered the abroad.

column7: The Scribes & the Phariseys came vnquietly, temptyng Christ, and required a sygne from heaue.
column8: The Scribes & the Pharisees Come unquietly, tempting christ, and required a Signen from heave.

column7: Christ rebuked them sharply, and shewed them no sygne, but called them a frowarde and aduoutrous generacion.
column8: christ rebuked them sharply, and showed them no Signen, but called them a forward and aduoutrous generation.

column7: So the people in England gathered together, they woulde make maisteryes, and bee notable felowes:
column8: So the people in England gathered together, they would make maisteryes, and be notable Fellows:

column7: yea, the towre of theyr presumpcion shuld be built vp vnto heauen, in dyspite of gentyll men and nobilitye:
column8: yea, the tower of their presumption should be built up unto heaven, in dyspite of gentle men and Nobilt:

column7: they haue partlye felte, and we haue ryghte pitifully sene howe sore God was therwith offended.
column8: they have partly felt, and we have right pitifully seen how soar God was therewith offended.

column7: Nowe I heare saye there is as yet remaininge in Englad sum stiffe necked Iewes, which come presumptuously temtyng God, and say:
column8: Now I hear say there is as yet remaining in Englad sum stiff necked Jews, which come presumptuously tempting God, and say:

column7: it these our rulers besent of God, to take better order then other haue done, well then, let theym begynne betime to gyue vs a notable sygne & token, for els we wyll not beleue, truste, nor obey them.
column8: it these our Rulers besent of God, to take better order then other have done, well then, let them begin betime to gyve us a notable Signen & token, for Else we will not believe, trust, nor obey them.

column7: Wel, I wyl tel you that thus whysper:
column8: Well, I will tell you that thus whysper:

column7: Euen as Christe was Positus in resurreccionem et ruinam multorum in Israell:
column8: Even as Christ was Positus in resurreccionem et ruinam multorum in Israel:

column7: Set to restore and decaye manye in Israell:
column8: Set to restore and decay many in Israel:

column7: So be Christen rulers in euerye comune wealth, set and ordayned of God, to beate doune & kepe vnder these sturdye rebels, whyche be so euyll the selues, that they cannot thinke that any man doeth intende to do them good,
column8: So be christian Rulers in every Common wealth, Set and ordained of God, to beat down & keep under these sturdy rebels, which be so evil the selves, that they cannot think that any man doth intend to do them good,

column7: & to rayse vp, conforte and cherish the simple pacient people, whyche be of a good truste towardes theyr rulers, knowynge that they theim selues haue deserued no euyll:
column8: & to raise up, Comfort and cherish the simple patient people, which be of a good trust towards their Rulers, knowing that they them selves have deserved no evil:

column7: or els if they haue done euyl, yet by repentaunce and amendemente, do not doute to obteyne mercye at theyr rulers handes.
column8: or Else if they have done evil, yet by Repentance and amendment, do not doubt to obtain mercy At their Rulers hands.

column7: So God hath ordeyned rulers to cheryshe ye, if thou be meke quyet and paciente, or els to punyshe the, if thou be vnquyet, busy and stubborne.
column8: So God hath ordained Rulers to cherish you, if thou be meek quiet and paciente, or Else to Punish thee, if thou be unquiet, busy and stubborn.

column7: Learne at Paule. Rom. xiii.
column8: Learn At Paul. Rom. xiii.

column7: If thou do wel, to trust well of thy rulers, and if thou doo euyll, not to be wythoute feare of theyr powers, for he beareth not the swerde wythout a cause.
column8: If thou do well, to trust well of thy Rulers, and if thou do evil, not to be without Fear of their Powers, for he bears not the sword without a cause.

column7: Take hede therefore ye rulers, for gods sake, and pitye of people, seynge that God hath geuen you a swerd to cut of rotten cankred members for the safegarde of the hole body, knowyng no caker to be so daungerous as rebellion in a commen wealth:
column8: Take heed Therefore you Rulers, for God's sake, and pity of people, sing that God hath given you a sword to Cut of rotten cankered members for the safeguard of the hold body, knowing no caker to be so dangerous as rebellion in a come wealth:

column7: If ye fynde one person infected wyth that canker, awaye wyth him, for ye safegard of the bodye of that house. If one house be infected, away wyth it, for the safegarde of that toune.
column8: If you find one person infected with that canker, away with him, for you safeguard of the body of that house. If one house be infected, away with it, for the safeguard of that town.

column7: If the toune be infected, awaye wyth it, for the safegarde of the contrey.
column8: If the town be infected, away with it, for the safeguard of the country.

column7: Yea, if a shyre or contrye be all poysoned, awaye wyth it, for the pitye, and safegarde of the hole bodye of the commen welth.
column8: Yea, if a shire or country be all poisoned, away with it, for the pity, and safeguard of the hold body of the come wealth.

column7: So ye se, that the sharper that youre sworde is, and the sooner that ye strike rebellion, the more pyty shewe ye in cutting away the lesse, and sauynge the more part and porcion of the people, beynge all of one bodye, of one realme and common welth.
column8: So you see, that the sharper that your sword is, and the sooner that you strike rebellion, the more pyty show you in cutting away the less, and Saving the more part and portion of the people, being all of one body, of one realm and Common wealth.

column7: Consider that Chryste wente from Ierusalem vnto wildernes, to drawe the Gentle people from amonge the stoborne scribes:
column8: Consider that Christ went from Jerusalem unto Wilderness, to draw the Gentle people from among the stoborne Scribes:

column7: and so Chrysten rulers muste nowe nedes defer the tyme to drawe the people that be good and trust well, from amonge this frowarde generacion, whiche of presumption loke to haue order taken as they require, and appoynte the tyme, the place and the thynge.
column8: and so Christen Rulers must now needs defer the time to draw the people that be good and trust well, from among this forward generation, which of presumption look to have order taken as they require, and appoint the time, the place and the thing.

column7: Wherfore, ye that be good quiet people, beware of these busye felowes, and as thys multitude whiche oughte to be youre example, folowed Chryst in to the wyldernes, so folowe you Christen rulers, goddes offycers, youre chiefe gouerners in Englande.
column8: Wherefore, you that be good quiet people, beware of these busy Fellows, and as this multitude which ought to be your Exampl, followed Christ in to the Wilderness, so follow you christian Rulers, God's Officers, your chief Governors in England.

column7: And as they dyd not murmure, sayinge:
column8: And as they did not murmur, saying:

column7: why shall we sitte downe here in the wyldernes, beyng an infinite number, where no meate is, seynge that in the cityes where was more meate, and lesse gatherynge of the people, we had neuer feaste gyuen of hym by hys Apostles?
column8: why shall we sit down Here in the Wilderness, being an infinite number, where no meat is, sing that in the cities where was more meat, and less gathering of the people, we had never feast given of him by his Apostles?

column7: So I saye, do not you grudge and saye:
column8: So I say, do not you grudge and say:

column7: why shall we quyet oure selues nowe, trustynge to reliefe, where wee see nothynge and were nothynge at al releued when there was great plentye of landes, and goodes of Abbeys,
column8: why shall we quiet our selves now, trusting to relief, where we see nothing and were nothing At all relieved when there was great plenty of Lands, and goods of Abbeys,

column7: Colegis, and Chaunteries? Do not murmour so vngodlye, but see that there be no faulte in you, and ye shal fynd no lacke in GOD.
column8: Colegis, and Chantries? Do not murmur so ungodly, but see that there be no fault in you, and you shall find no lack in GOD.

column7: Suerlye, excepte ye do sytte downe quietly, ye shall soner prouoke goddes vengeaunce to your damnacion, then deserue any reliefe of goddes officers, to your comfort.
column8: Surly, except you do fit down quietly, you shall sooner provoke God's vengeance to your damnation, then deserve any relief of God's Officers, to your Comfort.

column7: Sit downe and be quyet, for the same rulers & ministers are ordeyned of god to feede you wyth plentye:
column8: Fit down and be quiet, for the same Rulers & Ministers Are ordained of god to feed you with plenty:

column7: whych be commaunded of God to make you fyrste to set downe in order & quyetnes.
column8: which be commanded of God to make you First to Set down in order & quietness.

column7: Yea, and herke all ye that be godlye Rulers:
column8: Yea, and Hear all you that be godly Rulers:

column7: there was much grasse in the place, god had prouided muche grasse for theym that loked for no carpets:
column8: there was much grass in the place, god had provided much grass for them that looked for no carpets:

column7: geuyng all godly gouernours example to prouyde thynges necessarye for those people that loketh for no superfluities.
column8: giving all godly Governors Exampl to provide things necessary for those people that looketh for no superfluities.

column7: But alas, here in England, superfluous gorgeous building is so much prouided for ryche mens pleasures, that honest houses do decay, where as labouring men ought to haue necessary lodging.
column8: But alas, Here in England, superfluous gorgeous building is so much provided for rich men's pleasures, that honest houses do decay, where as labouring men ought to have necessary lodging.

column7: It is a commen custome with couetous landlordes, to lette their housynge so decaye, that the fermer shalbe fayne for a smal reward or none at all to gyue vppe hys leasse, that they takynge the groundes into their own handes, may tourne al to pasture:
column8: It is a come custom with covetous landlords, to let their housing so decay, that the Fermer shall fain for a small reward or none At all to gyve up his lease, that they taking the grounds into their own hands, may turn all to pasture:

column7: so nowe Old Fathers, poore Wydowes, and yong children, lie begging in the mirie stretes.
column8: so now Old Father's, poor Widows, and young children, lie begging in the miry streets.

column7: O mercifull Lorde, what a number of poore, feable, haulte Blynde,
column8: Oh merciful Lord, what a number of poor, feeble, haulte Blind,

column7: Lame, sycklye, yea, wyth idle vacaboundes, and dissembelinge kaityffes mixt among them, lie and crepe, begging in the myry streates of London and Westminster?
column8: Lame, sycklye, yea, with idle vacaboundes, and dissembelinge kaityffes mixed among them, lie and creep, begging in the myry streets of London and Westminster?

column7: Nowe speakyng in the behalfe of thefe vile beggers, for as much as I know that ye vilest person vpon earth, is ye liuely image of almightye God,
column8: Now speaking in the behalf of thief vile beggars, for as much as I know that the Vilest person upon earth, is the lively image of almighty God,

column7: I wyll tell the that arte a noble man, worshypfull man, an honest welthye man, especiallye if thou be Maire,
column8: I will tell the that art a noble man, worshipful man, an honest wealthy man, especially if thou be More,

column7: Sherif, Alderma baily, costable or any such officer, it is to thy greate shame afore the worlde,
column8: Sheriff, Alderman baily, costable or any such officer, it is to thy great shame afore the world,

column7: & to thy vtter danacion afore god, to se these beggig as thei vse to do in the streates.
column8: & to thy utter danacion afore god, to see these beggig as they use to do in the streets.

column7: For there is neuer a one of these, but he lacketh eyther thy charitable almes to relieue his nede, or els thy due correction to punyshe hys faute.
column8: For there is never a one of these, but he lacketh either thy charitable alms to relieve his need, or Else thy due correction to Punish his fault.

column7: A great sin and no les shame is it for him that sayeth he is a Christe ma to se Chryst lack things necessary,
column8: A great since and no less shame is it for him that Saith he is a Christ ma to se Christ lack things necessary,

column7: & to bestowe vpon the deuil superfluousli.
column8: & to bestow upon the Devil superfluousli.

column7: It is Christ Iesus hi self that in the nedy doth suffer huger, thrist & cold:
column8: It is christ jesus him self that in the needy does suffer huger, thrist & cold:

column7: It is the deuyll hym selfe, that in the wealthye fareth deintely, goeth gorgeously,
column8: It is the Devil him self, that in the wealthy fareth deintely, Goes gorgeously,

column7: & vseth superfluitie. Looke Mathewe the xxv.
column8: & uses superfluity. Look Matthew the xxv.

column7: & there shal ye se playnly that it is Christ which lacketh sufficient in the neady:
column8: & there shall you see plainly that it is christ which lacketh sufficient in the needy:

column7: and therefore the deuyll beyng contrary to Chryst, contrariwyse hathe to much in the wealthye.
column8: and Therefore the Devil being contrary to Christ, contrariwise hath to much in the wealthy.

column7: You also that do prouyde that your cattel do not longetary pinned in a folde where there is no grasse, whye do you suffer youre owne brethren in Chryst, wythout prouysyon to lye in the streates, where is muche myer?
column8: You also that do provide that your cattle do not longetary pinned in a fold where there is no grass, why do you suffer your own brothers in Christ, without provision to lie in the streets, where is much mire?

column7: These selye soules haue ben neglected thorow oute all Englande, and especiallye in Londo and Westminster:
column8: These selye Souls have been neglected thorough out all England, and especially in London and Westminster:

column7: But nowe I trust that a good ouerseer a godly Byshop I meane, wyll se that they in these two cities, shall haue their nede reliued, and their faultes corrected, to the good ensample of al other tounes & cities.
column8: But now I trust that a good overseer a godly Bishop I mean, will see that they in these two cities, shall have their need relived, and their Faults corrected, to the good ensample of all other Towns & cities.

column7: Take hede that ther be much grasse to sit vpon, there as ye commaud the people to sit downe, that there be sufficiente housynge and other prouisio for the people ther as ye commaud the un to be quiet.
column8: Take heed that there be much grass to fit upon, there as you commaud the people to fit down, that there be sufficient housing and other Provision for the people there as you commaud the un to be quiet.

column7: The men satte downe about fyue thousandes in nuber.
column8: The men sat down about fyue thousandes in nuber.

column7: If they had not bene obedient to sitte downe,
column8: If they had not be obedient to sit down,

column7: Christ wold not haue bene liberal to haue gyuen them meate.
column8: christ would not have be liberal to have given them meat.

column7: Meate was prouided for the Comens of England, and readye to haue bene deliuered.
column8: Meat was provided for the Comens of England, and ready to have be Delivered.

column7: But when they were bydden to sit downe in quietnes, they rose vp by rebellio, and haue lost all the chere of that feast.
column8: But when they were bidden to fit down in quietness, they rose up by Rebellion, and have lost all the cheer of that feast.

column7: Yet that notwithstanding, I trust that those which sat quietly in dede, shal sone be fed with pletye, if they sit styll vntyll it maye conueniently be disposed.
column8: Yet that notwithstanding, I trust that those which sat quietly in deed, shall soon be fed with pletye, if they fit still until it may conveniently be disposed.

column7: I praye GOD they maye,
column8: I pray GOD they may,

column7: I truste they shal. The Euaungelist saith that the men sat, namyng neyther women nor Chyldren, how be it there was both women and Chyldren, as appeareth in the other Euangelistes.
column8: I trust they shall. The Evangelist Says that the men sat, naming neither women nor Children, how be it there was both women and Children, as appears in the other Evangelists.

column7: And men be here named onely, because al women and children did folow the example, and obey the comaundemet of me children of the fathers, and women of their husbandes.
column8: And men be Here nam only, Because all women and children did follow the Exampl, and obey the comaundemet of me children of the Father's, and women of their Husbands.

column7: Let not therefore your wyues and chyldren, when they come abrode, be so bold openly, as to say or do any thinges of them selues, but as they haue example and comaundement of you.
column8: Let not Therefore your wives and children, when they come abroad, be so bold openly, as to say or do any things of them selves, but as they have Exampl and Commandment of you.

column7: Now the multitude placed in quyetnes,
column8: Now the multitude placed in quietness,

column7: Iesus toke the loues, and when he hadde giuen thankes, he deuided them vnto his Disciples:
column8: jesus took the loves, and when he had given thanks, he divided them unto his Disciples:

column7: and the Disciples vnto them that were set downe:
column8: and the Disciples unto them that were Set down:

column7: and lykewyse of the fyshes, so much as they would
column8: and likewise of the fishes, so much as they would

column7: Here learne fyrste of Chryste, to take nothynge, be it neuer so lytell, but wyth thankes rendered therefore vnto God:
column8: Here Learn First of Christ, to take nothing, be it never so little, but with thanks rendered Therefore unto God:

column7: For of God surelye thou haste receiued it, by what messenger or meane soeuer thou came vnto it.
column8: For of God surely thou haste received it, by what Messenger or mean soever thou Come unto it.

column7: Then secondarilye, learne at the Apostles to geue vnto other, that which the Lord hath geuen vnto the, that thou mayest truly say wyth the Apostel Paul.
column8: Then secondarily, Learn At the Apostles to give unto other, that which the Lord hath given unto thee, that thou Mayest truly say with the Apostle Paul.

column7: Quod accepi a domino, hoc tradidi uobis.
column8: Quod accepi a domino, hoc tradidi uobis.

column7: That whiche I receyued of the Lorde, haue I geuen vnto you.
column8: That which I received of the Lord, have I given unto you.

column7: Beware that thou playe not the wycked seruaunt, which kept his talent hyd, and not delyuered vnto any vse, for then it shal be taken fro the, and thou shalt be cast into vtter darkenes.
column8: Beware that thou play not the wicked servant, which kept his talon hid, and not Delivered unto any use, for then it shall be taken from thee, and thou shalt be cast into utter darkness.

column7: Nowe, to applye this miracle vnto this present time, the kynges Magesty may learne at Chryst to take of his seruauntes,
column8: Now, to apply this miracle unto this present time, the Kings Majesty may Learn At Christ to take of his Servants,

column7: Prebendes, Benefices, Improperacions and all maner of Offyces, that be not presently occupyed & executed of a faythful diligent officer, and after thanckes geuen vnto God therfore, to deliuer them vnto his Counsell and Nobilyty to be disposed amongest the people of hys Realme, whych be in such hunger and lacke of faythful officers, and house kepers, and godli preachers that they must nedes faint, excepte they be sone prouided for.
column8: Prebends, Benefices, Improbations and all manner of Offices, that be not presently ocupied & executed of a faithful diligent officer, and After thanks given unto God Therefore, to deliver them unto his Counsel and Nobility to be disposed amongst the people of his Realm, which be in such hunger and lack of faithful Officers, and house keepers, and godly Preachers that they must needs faint, except they be soon provided for.

column7: And in thys dystrybucion of offyces and benefyces, your Magestye wyth your Counsell had nede to stand and beholde the dealyng of your Nobles, as Christ dyd of his Apostles.
column8: And in this dystrybucion of Offices and Benefices, your Majesty with your Counsel had need to stand and behold the dealing of your Nobles, as christ did of his Apostles.

column7: For it is not vnlike but as there was amongest Christes Apostles, so wyll there be amongest euery Chrysten Kynges Counsellers and Nobles, some Iudas whych is to be trusted no further then he can be seene.
column8: For it is not unlike but as there was amongst Christ's Apostles, so will there be amongst every Christen Kings Counsellers and Nobles, Some Judas which is to be trusted no further then he can be seen.

column7: For in syghte Iudas doth as other of hys felowes do:
column8: For in sight Judas does as other of his Fellows do:

column7: but beyng out of lyghte he solde hys Maister.
column8: but being out of Light he sold his Master.

column7: And so the most couetous of them all, wyll be afrayde to do any thynge amysse, yt you loke vpon:
column8: And so the most covetous of them all, will be afraid to do any thing amiss, that you look upon:

column7: but if your backes be turned, then wyll couetous Iudas sell dearly that whych hys liberal maister gyueth frelye.
column8: but if your backs be turned, then will covetous Judas fell dearly that which his liberal master gyveth freely.

column7: As for example of late dayes, the Kynges Magestye that deade is, dyd gyue a Benefyce to be appropryat vnto the Vniuersitye of Cambrydge.
column8: As for Exampl of late days, the Kings Majesty that dead is, did gyve a Benefice to be appropryat unto the university of Cambridge.

column7: In liberam et puram eliemosinam:
column8: In I liberate et puram eliemosinam:

column7: As fre and pure almes.
column8: As from and pure alms.

column7: Howe be it, hys handes were so vnpure, whiche should haue delyuered it, that he receiued.vi. hundreth poundes of the Vnyuersytye for it.
column8: Howe be it, his hands were so unpure, which should have Delivered it, that he received vi Hundredth pounds of the University for it.

column7: Whether that this.vi. C. pouds were conueied to the kings behoofe pryuelye for that almes, whyche by playne wrytynge was geue frely, or els put into some Iudas pouch,
column8: Whither that this vi C. pouds were conveyed to the Kings behoof pryuelye for that alms, which by plain writing was give freely, or Else put into Some Judas pouch,

column7: I would it were knowen.
column8: I would it were known.

column7: For nowe, by suche charitable Almes, the king is slaundered, the parish vndone, and the vniuersyty in worse case then it was afore.
column8: For now, by such charitable Alms, the King is slandered, the parish undone, and the vniuersyty in Worse case then it was afore.

column7: Pleaseth it your Magestye, wyth your honourable Counsell, for the reuerence of God, the pytye of the poore, and the godlye zele that ye haue to good learning, heare what hath bene done in your tyme.
column8: Pleases it your Majesty, with your honourable Counsel, for the Reverence of God, the pity of the poor, and the godly zeal that you have to good learning, hear what hath be done in your time.

column7: Your Magesty hath had gyuen & receiued by Act of Parliament,
column8: Your Majesty hath had given & received by Act of Parliament,

column7: Colleges, Chauntries, & guyldes for mani good consideracions, and especially as appeareth in the same Act, for erectinge of grammer scholes, to the educacion of youthe in vertue & godlynes, to the further augmentynge of the vniuersities, and better prouision for the poore and nedy.
column8: Colleges, Chantries, & guyldes for mani good considerations, and especially as appears in the same Act, for erecting of grammar Schools, to the education of youth in virtue & godliness, to the further augmenting of the universities, and better provision for the poor and needy.

column7: But now, many Grammer scholes, and muche charytable prouision for the poore, be taken, sold, and made awaye, to the greate slaunder of you and youre lawes, to the vtter discomfort of the pore, to the greuous offence of the people, to the mooste miserable drownynge of youthe in ygnoraunce, and soore decaye of the Vniuersities.
column8: But now, many Grammar Schools, and much charitable provision for the poor, be taken, sold, and made away, to the great slander of you and your laws, to the utter discomfort of the poor, to the grievous offence of the people, to the most miserable drowning of youth in ygnoraunce, and sore decay of the Universities.

column7: There was in the North countrye, amongest the rude people in knowledge (whyche be most readye to spend theyr liues and goodes, in seruinge the king at the burnyng of a Beacon) there was a Grammer schole founded, hauynge in the Vniuersitie of Cambrydge, of the same foundacion.viii. scholerships two felowshippes, euer replenished wyth the scholers of that schole, whych schole is now sold, decayed, and loste.
column8: There was in the North country, amongst the rude people in knowledge (which be most ready to spend their lives and goods, in serving the King At the burning of a Beacon) there was a Grammar school founded, having in the university of Cambridge, of the same Foundation viii scholerships two felowshippes, ever replenished with the Scholars of that school, which school is now sold, decayed, and lost.

column7: Mo there be of lyke sort handled:
column8: Mo there be of like sort handled:

column7: But I recyte thys onelye, because I knowe that the sale of it was once stayed of charytye, and yet afterwardes broughte to passe by brybrye, as I hearde saye, and beleue it, because that it is only brybrye that customablye ouer commeth charytye.
column8: But I recite this only, Because I know that the sale of it was once stayed of Charity, and yet afterwards brought to pass by brybrye, as I heard say, and believe it, Because that it is only brybrye that customably over comes Charity.

column7: For gods sake you that be in authorytye, loke vpon it.
column8: For God's sake you that be in authorytye, look upon it.

column7: For if ye winke at suche matters,
column8: For if you wink At such matters,

column7: God wyl scoule vpon you.
column8: God will scowl upon you.

column7: Thinke not that I do burden you wt more than that which God by hys ordynaunce, not wtout your willes & cosentes, hath charged you wythal.
column8: Think not that I do burden you with more than that which God by his Ordinance, not without your wills & cosentes, hath charged you withal.

column7: For by whose faute or negllgence so euer it was, that thynges afore tyme haue ben vncharytably abused, luerlye it is your charge, whiche be nowe in authorytye, to se at thys tyme all such thynges as yet remayne out of order, rightuously, spedely, and charitably redressed.
column8: For by whose fault or negllgence so ever it was, that things afore time have been uncharitably abused, luerlye it is your charge, which be now in authorytye, to see At this time all such things as yet remain out of order, rightuously, speedily, and charitably Redressed.

column7: And as I do perceyue, that the abuse of these thynges afore tyme, hath offended God, troubled the common wealth, and brought some men towardes shame & confusion:
column8: And as I do perceive, that the abuse of these things afore time, hath offended God, troubled the Common wealth, and brought Some men towards shame & confusion:

column7: So do I wyshe, praye, and trust, that nowe the redresse of the same maye be to gods pleasure, the peoples cofort,
column8: So do I wish, pray, and trust, that now the redress of the same may be to God's pleasure, the peoples Comfort,

column7: & to ye honor & establishment of them that be in most highe authorytye.
column8: & to the honour & establishment of them that be in most high authorytye.

column7: Heare therefore, and I wyl tel you more:
column8: Hear Therefore, and I will tell you more:

column7: There were in some townes.vi. some.viii. and some a dosyn kyne, gyuen vnto a stocke for the relyefe of the poore, and vsed in such wyse, that the poore cotingers, which could make any prouision for fodder, had ye milke for a very small hyre,
column8: There were in Some Towns vi Some viii and Some a dosyn kine, given unto a stock for the relyefe of the poor, and used in such wise, that the poor cotingers, which could make any provision for fodder, had you milk for a very small hire,

column7: & then the number of the stocke reserued, al manner of vayles besydes, bothe the hyre of the mylke, and the pryces of the yong veales, and olde fatte wares, was disposed to the reliefe of the poore, these be also soulde, taken, and made awaye.
column8: & then the number of the stock reserved, all manner of vails besides, both the hire of the milk, and the prices of the young veals, and old fat wares, was disposed to the relief of the poor, these be also sold, taken, and made away.

column7: The Kynge beareth the slaunder, the poore feleth the lacke, but who hath the profit of suche thynges.
column8: The King bears the slander, the poor feeleth the lack, but who hath the profit of such things.

column7: I canne not tell: but well I wot, and al the worlde seeth, that the Acte of Parlimente made by the Kynges Magestye, and hys Lordes and Commens of the Parliamente, for the mayntenaunce of learnynge, and reliefe of the poore, hathe serued some, as a most fit instrument to rob learning and to spoyl the pore.
column8: I can not tell: but well I wot, and all the world sees, that the Act of Parliament made by the Kings Majesty, and his lords and Common's of the Parliament, for the maintenance of learning, and relief of the poor, hath served Some, as a most fit Instrument to rob learning and to spoil the poor.

column7: If you that now be in authorytye do not loke vpon such thynges to redresse them, god wyl loke vpon you, to reuenge theym.
column8: If you that now be in authorytye do not look upon such things to redress them, god will look upon you, to revenge them.

column7: Here haue I rehersed theim, that the Kynges Magestye, wyth you of hys counsell maye learne not onelye by the doctrine & examples of scripture, but also by experience in hys own land, to se and consider howe hys benefytes, put into the handes of hys nobles and offycers, be disposed and vsed amongest his inferiour people.
column8: Here have I rehearsed them, that the Kings Majesty, with you of his counsel may Learn not only by the Doctrine & Examples of scripture, but also by experience in his own land, to see and Consider how his benefits, put into the hands of his Nobles and Officers, be disposed and used amongst his inferior people.

column7: For if landed men & offycers by keping of houses,
column8: For if landed men & Officers by keeping of houses,

column7: & doing of theyr dutyes in theyr countryes, do bestowe amonge the people, all that they haue receiued of god, by the kynges gyft, theyr fathers inherytance, or other waies:
column8: & doing of their duties in their countries, do bestow among the people, all that they have received of god, by the Kings gift, their Father's inherytance, or other ways:

column7: then shal god giue such enerese, yt euery man shall haue inough.
column8: then shall god give such enerese, that every man shall have enough.

column7: As Salomon, the.xi. of the Prouerbes testifieth:
column8: As Solomon, the xi of the Proverbs Testifieth:

column7: Alii diuidunt propria, et ditiores fiunt:
column8: Alii diuidunt propria, et ditiores Fluent:

column7: alii rapiunt non sua, et semper in egestate sunt:
column8: alii rapiunt non sua, et semper in egestate sunt:

column7: Some dispose and gyue theyr owne, and become tycher and rycher:
column8: some dispose and gyve their own, and become tycher and Richer:

column7: some doo rauine and spoyle that whiche is not theyr owne, and be euer in lacke and neede.
column8: Some do ravine and spoil that which is not their own, and be ever in lack and need.

column7: As ye see in daylye experience, those that do theyr owne duties in executinge theyre offyces, and bestowe theyr owne goodes in kepynge good houses, baue euer suche plentye, that all other men maruayle from whence god sendeth it.
column8: As you see in daily experience, those that do their own duties in executing their Offices, and bestow their own goods in keeping good houses, have ever such plenty, that all other men marvel from whence god sends it.

column7: And those yt do no duties, nor kepe no houses, but brybe in theyr offyces, and polle theyr teuautes, take so much and haue so litel, that all men wonder how the deuyl they waste it.
column8: And those that do no duties, nor keep no houses, but bribe in their Offices, and Poll their teuautes, take so much and have so little, that all men wonder how the Devil they waste it.

column7: Nothynge is more true then the Gospell:
column8: Nothing is more true then the Gospel:

column7: Date, et dabitur uobis:
column8: Date, et dabitur uobis:

column7: Gyue & it shal be gyuen vnto you.
column8: Gyve & it shall be given unto you.

column7: Gyue plentifully vnto other, and god wil gyue more plentie vnto you.
column8: Gyve plentifully unto other, and god will gyve more plenty unto you.

column7: For God wyll alwayes be afore hand, in giuyng good giftes.
column8: For God will always be afore hand, in giving good Gifts.

column7: For as appeareth in thys gospell, when the Apostles hadde giuen vnto the people so muche good meate as they desyred, then saieth the Euangeliste.
column8: For as appears in this gospel, when the Apostles had given unto the people so much good meat as they desired, then Saith the Evangelist.

column7: When they wer filled, Iesus sayeth to hys dysciples:
column8: When they were filled, jesus Saith to his Disciples:

column7: Gather vp the broken meates that remaine, so that nothynge be lost.
column8: Gather up the broken Meats that remain, so that nothing be lost.

column7: They therefore gathered and fylled.xii. baskets ful wyth the broken meates remaining of that which they had eaten.
column8: They Therefore gathered and filled xii baskets full with the broken Meats remaining of that which they had eaten.

column7: Here they gaue but.v. loues &, two fishes,
column8: Here they gave but v loves &, two Fish,

column7: & ther was giue vnto the.xii baskets ful of meates.
column8: & there was give unto the xii baskets full of Meats.

column7: The Wyddowe of Sarep that gaue but one handfull of flowre, and a litle oile vnto Elias, and had gyuen vnto her againe so much as serued her and her sonne, al the time of the great drought.iii. Reg.xvii.
column8: The Widow of Sarep that gave but one handful of flower, and a little oil unto Elias, and had given unto her again so much as served her and her son, all the time of the great drought iii Reg xvii

column7: Learne therfore that couetous bribry & extorcion hath neuer inough:
column8: Learn Therefore that covetous bribery & extortion hath never enough:

column7: and charytable lyberalytye euer hath plentye.
column8: and charitable lyberalytye ever hath plenty.

column7: Here also maye rych men learne, when and howe to fyll theyr store houses.
column8: Here also may rich men Learn, when and how to fill their store houses.

column7: Surely, euen as the Apostles dyd fyll theyr baskettes, when the people haue inoughe, then by gatherynge vp that whiche elles shoulde be lost.
column8: Surely, even as the Apostles did fill their baskets, when the people have enough, then by gathering up that which Else should be lost.

column7: So dyd Iosephe in Egipt, suffer no corne to be lost in the yeares of plentye, but stored it vp in barnes, to releue the people wyth, in the tyme of darth:
column8: So did Joseph in Egypt, suffer no corn to be lost in the Years of plenty, but stored it up in Barns, to relieve the people with, in the time of darth:

column7: Not as couetous Carles do here in England forstall the markets, and by corne at al tymes, to begyn and encrease a dearthe.
column8: Not as covetous Charles do Here in England forestall the Markets, and by corn At all times, to begin and increase a dearth.

column7: Blessed be they that sell, to make good cheape, and cursed be they that bye, to make it deare.
column8: Blessed be they that fell, to make good cheap, and cursed be they that buy, to make it deer.

column8: For Solomon Saith. Proverbs xi

column8: Qui Abscondit frumenta, maledicetur in populis:
