column8: benediccio autem super caput uendencium:

column7: He that hydeth vp corne, shall be cursed amongest the people:
column8: He that Hideth up corn, shall be cursed amongst the people:

column7: But blessynge be vpon theyr heades, that sell.
column8: But blessing be upon their Heads, that fell.

column7: Nowe, to teache Chrysten rulers theyr dutyes, in the example of Chrystes Apostles:
column8: Now, to teach Christen Rulers their duties, in the Exampl of Christ's Apostles:

column7: marke howe the Apostles dyd fyrst minister vnto the people, and than gathered vp for them selues, teaching thereby all Chrysten ministers, landelordes, offycers, and rulers, fyrste to minister vnto the people, euerye one the dutye of hys owne vocacion, afore they gather of the people, rentes, tythes, or fees by the name and aucthorytye of that vocacion.
column8: mark how the Apostles did fyrst minister unto the people, and than gathered up for them selves, teaching thereby all Christen Ministers, Landlords, Officers, and Rulers, First to minister unto the people, every one the duty of his own vocation, afore they gather of the people, rents, Tithes, or fees by the name and aucthorytye of that vocation.

column7: Qui non labor at, sayeth Paule, non manducet: He that doeth not labour, should not eate.
column8: Qui non labour At, Saith Paul, non manducet: He that doth not labour, should not eat.

column7: He that doth no worke, shoulde take no wages:
column8: He that does not work, should take no wages:

column7: he that doeth no dutyes, shoulde take no fees.
column8: he that doth no duties, should take no fees.

column7: Alas, thys is goddes woorde, wrytten in hys wyll and Testamente, sealed wyth Chrystes bloude, and yet the customes and lawes of Englande be cleane contrarye.
column8: Alas, this is God's word, written in his will and Testament, sealed with Christ's blood, and yet the customs and laws of England be clean contrary.

column7: For it hathe bene customeably vsed, yea, and by lawes commaunded, to paye wages, tythes, and fees, althoughe no labour, no offyce, no dutye be done.
column8: For it hath be customeably used, yea, and by laws commanded, to pay wages, Tithes, and fees, although no labour, no office, no duty be done.

column7: Yea, although he be not a labourer, a pastor or an offycer in dede, but onlye by a pretenced name, vnto whome these for the most part be paied.
column8: Yea, although he be not a labourer, a pastor or an officer in deed, but only by a pretenced name, unto whom these for the most part be paid.

column7: For he that hath the propertyes & useth the trades of a false theife,
column8: For he that hath the properties & uses the trades of a false thief,

column7: & cruell murtherer, can neuer be a faythful offycer in dede, althoughe he be so named by hys owne flatery, in the Patrons presentacion,
column8: & cruel murderer, can never be a faithful officer in deed, although he be so nam by his own flattery, in the Patrons presentation,

column7: in the Byshoppes induccion, yea and in the Kynges Patent, sealed wyth the brode Seale.
column8: in the Bishops induction, yea and in the Kings Patent, sealed with the broad Seal.

column7: I had nede to take hede how that I speake openly agaynst any thynge in any mans Patent, sealed wt the kings great seale:
column8: I had need to take heed how that I speak openly against any thing in any men Patent, sealed with the Kings great seal:

column7: Much more nede hadde you to take hede, how that ye do any thing expressedly against goddes wyll and Testamente, sealed wyth Chrystes precious bloude.
column8: Much more need had you to take heed, how that you do any thing expressedly against God's will and Testament, sealed with Christ's precious blood.

column7: It is expressedly agaynste Goddes Testamente, to clothe a Wolfe in a Lambes skynne:
column8: It is expressedly against Goddess Testament, to cloth a Wolf in a Lambs skin:

column7: to call a thefe, an officer, and a cruell murtherer a charytable pastoure:
column8: to call a thief, an officer, and a cruel murderer a charitable pasture:

column7: to call euyll by the name of good:
column8: to call evil by the name of good:

column7: and good by the name of the euyll.
column8: and good by the name of the evil.

column7: Esaye.v. Ve qui dicitis malum bonum.
column8: Isaiah v We qui dicitis malum bonum.

column7: Wo be to you that call euyl good.
column8: Woe be to you that call evil good.

column7: To you I say, which not only by sayinges but also in wrytynges, do name & call theiues, murtherers,
column8: To you I say, which not only by sayings but also in writings, do name & call theiues, murderers,

column7: & wolfes that be euyll, by the names of officers,
column8: & wolves that be evil, by the names of Officers,

column7: pastors, and lambes, whiche be good.
column8: Pastors, and Lambs, which be good.

column7: I do not onlye meane Persons,
column8: I do not only mean Persons,

column7: Prebendaryes, and other benefised men, but also all manner officers, whiche haue wages, fees, or liuinges, because you geue them such names, and not for that they do such dutyes.
column8: Prebendaries, and other benefised men, but also all manner Officers, which have wages, fees, or livings, Because you give them such names, and not for that they do such duties.

column7: These be al Wolfs, and the names and titles that you gyue them, be nothynge els but shepe skynnes.
column8: These be all Wolf's, and the names and titles that you gyve them, be nothing Else but sheep skins.

column7: Some saye, they wyll take better heede hereafter, but that whiche is nowe past, can not nowe be called backe, and amended.
column8: some say, they will take better heed hereafter, but that which is now past, can not now be called back, and amended.

column7: Yea, and it were great pytye, seynge that they haue payed the fyrst fruites vnto the Kinges Magesty, and no smal reward vnto other men, perchauce bought theyr offyces dearelye, now to put them out of those lyuynges, wyth the losse. of. all those charges whiche they haue bestowed in rewardes, as other wayes, to gette such lyuynges.
column8: Yea, and it were great pity, sing that they have paid the fyrst fruits unto the Kings Majesty, and no small reward unto other men, perchance bought their Offices dearly, now to put them out of those livings, with the loss. of. all those charges which they have bestowed in rewards, as other ways, to get such livings.

column7: Wo, wo wo vnto you hypocrytes that stumble at a strawe, and leape ouer a blocke, that strayne out a gnat, and swalowe vp a camell, that pytye more the losse of mens brybrye, whiche was geuen to corrupt some men, then the treading vnder fote of Christes bloud, whiche was shead, to saue all men, that dooe imagin it pytye to dryue the theues, murtherers and wolfes fro amongest ye lambs of God, redemed wt Christs precious blud,
column8: Woe, woe woe unto you Hypocrites that Stumble At a straw, and leap over a block, that strain out a gnat, and swallow up a camel, that pity more the loss of men's brybrye, which was given to corrupt Some men, then the treading under foot of Christ's blood, which was shed, to save all men, that do imagine it pity to drive the thieves, murderers and wolves from amongst you Lambs of God, redeemed with Christ precious blood,

column7: & comitted vnto your gouernaunce and kepynge.
column8: & committed unto your governance and keeping.

column7: As God shal helpe me,
column8: As God shall help me,

column7: I speake wyth feare, pytye, and reuerence:
column8: I speak with Fear, pity, and Reverence:

column7: if you do not rather pulle the shepes skinnes ouer the wolfes eares, and hang theyr careases vpon the pales, then suffer theym to contynewe styll,
column8: if you do not rather pull the Sheep skins over the wolves ears, and hang their careases upon the pales, then suffer them to continue still,

column7: God wyll plucke you downe wyth some sodein mischiefe,
column8: God will pluck you down with Some sudden mischief,

column7: rather then mainteine or suffer you in so hygh authorytye, to vse such vncharitable, vngodly, and cruell pytye.
column8: rather then maintain or suffer you in so high authorytye, to use such uncharitable, ungodly, and cruel pity.

column7: You knowe that some of the haue bought theyr benefyces, haue bought theyr offyces, than must ye nedes know, that eyther Christ is a lyer, or els that they be entered in as theues, to spoyle, murther, and to destroye.
column8: You know that Some of thee have bought their Benefices, have bought their Offices, than must you needs know, that either christ is a liar, or Else that they be entered in as thieves, to spoil, murder, and to destroy.

column7: If you suffer theues, murtherers and wolfes to take theyr plesures amongest Goddes lambes,
column8: If you suffer thieves, murderers and wolves to take their pleasures amongst Goddess Lambs,

column7: I tell you playne, God wyll not longe suffer you to be ye hedshepherds,
column8: I tell you plain, God will not long suffer you to be you hedshepherds,

column7: & gouernours, & feders of hys labes.
column8: & Governors, & feeders of his labes.

column7: And take hede you people that on the otherside ye tunne not into an vntollerable stobernes, deniyng your retes, your tithes, or other duties:
column8: And take heed you people that on the otherside you tun not into an untolerable stobernes, denying your retes, your Tithes, or other duties:

column7: for ye scripture forbyddeth you vtterly, to deny or withdrawe any thig fro the:
column8: for you scripture forbiddeth you utterly, to deny or withdraw any thig from thee:

column7: thou art comauded if he conted to take thy cloke to geue hym also thy cote.
column8: thou art comauded if he conted to take thy cloak to give him also thy coat.

column7: What soeuer is asked, rather gyue more, than by denyinge of that, not to shewe thy selfe to be an innocent shepe that gyueth hys fleese, but a noysome Goat, that striketh with the horne.
column8: What soever is asked, rather gyve more, than by denying of that, not to show thy self to be an innocent sheep that gyveth his fleece, but a noisome Goat, that striketh with the horn.

column7: You are alwayes bounden to geue the flese.
column8: You Are always bounden to give the flese.

column7: It is the magistrates duties, to consider and note, whether they be theues or shepherds, dogs or woulfes, that taketh the fleese.
column8: It is the Magistrates duties, to Consider and note, whither they be thieves or shepherd's, Dogs or wolves, that Takes the fleece.

column7: Medle not wyth other mennes duties, for if ye do, surely ye shal finde no remedye, but prouoke vncolourable vengeaunce.
column8: Meddle not with other men's duties, for if you do, surely you shall find no remedy, but provoke uncolourable vengeance.

column7: Nowe to tourne to oure particuler purpose, lette all theym that do receiue offices, landes, power, or authorytye frome God, by the kynges gyfte, or by other meanes,
column8: Now to turn to our particular purpose, let all them that do receive Offices, Lands, power, or authorytye from God, by the Kings gift, or by other means,

column7: Firste bestowe & dispose the dutyes of those thynges faithfullye amon gest the people, afore they gather vp to theim selues the reuenues & commodities of the same from the people.
column8: First bestow & dispose the duties of those things faithfully amon gest the people, afore they gather up to them selves the revenues & commodities of the same from the people.

column7: And then when as no man can come to meat, but by doyng of labour, nor none to receyuynge of fees, but by doing of duties, surely euery man shal haue as much as he deserueth,
column8: And then when as no man can come to meat, but by doing of labour, nor none to receiving of fees, but by doing of duties, surely every man shall have as much as he deserves,

column7: & no man shall lacke that which he needeth.
column8: & no man shall lack that which he needs.

column7: For he, that by doing of greate duties deserueth the moste, by atteininge the fees and rewardes due for the same dutyes, shall haue the best.
column8: For he, that by doing of great duties deserves the most, by attaining the fees and rewards due for the same duties, shall have the best.

column7: And he yt is in nede, hauinge no trust to get any thyng by idlenesse, crafte, or flattery, shalbe compelled to vse that labour & honest exercise, whyche shall relyeue hys nede sufficietly.
column8: And he that is in need, having no trust to get any thing by idleness, craft, or flattery, shall compelled to use that labour & honest exercise, which shall relyeue his need sufficietly.

column7: Yea, by thys mean no man shall spende hys tyme in idlenesse, nor vse any labour or dyligence, wythout due recompence,
column8: Yea, by this mean no man shall spend his time in idleness, nor use any labour or diligence, without due recompense,

column7: For nede shall dryue all men from slouthfull idlenesse, vnto labour & diligece:
column8: For need shall drive all men from slothful idleness, unto labour & diligence:

column7: and where as no laboure nor dylygence lacketh hys iust rewarde, there euery labouring and diligent man, shal haue sufficient plenty:
column8: and where as no labour nor diligence lacketh his just reward, there every labouring and diligent man, shall have sufficient plenty:

column7: So ye see how thys doeth consequently ensue, that euery ma shal haue sufficient inough & plentye, wher as men do first dispose, minister,
column8: So you see how this doth consequently ensue, that every ma shall have sufficient enough & plenty, where as men do First dispose, minister,

column7: & giue according to theyr dutyes,
column8: & give according to their duties,

column7: & afterwards receiue kepe & saue that which God doth sende as a rewarde, encreased & augmented, for doing of theyr dutyes.
column8: & afterwards receive keep & save that which God does send as a reward, increased & augmented, for doing of their duties.

column7: So dyd the Apostles, after the faythful diligent disposyng of the v. loues and.ii. fyshes receiue and keepe theyr rewarde wonderfullye augmeted, to replenish and fyl.xii. baskets.
column8: So did the Apostles, After the faithful diligent disposing of the v. loves and ii fishes receive and keep their reward wonderfully augmeted, to replenish and fyl xii baskets.

column7: So God graunt, that all officers in Englad may wyth such faithful diligence do theyr duties yt it may please God to gyue to all the people sufficient inough,
column8: So God grant, that all Officers in Englad may with such faithful diligence do their duties that it may please God to gyve to all the people sufficient enough,

column7: & vnto euery minister, the basket of his honest desire, heaped vp bi the brim
column8: & unto every minister, the basket of his honest desire, heaped up by the brim

column7: The men therfore seynge what a signe Iesus had done, sayd that this is ye Prophet, whiche cometh into the worlde.
column8: The men Therefore sing what a Signen jesus had done, said that this is the Prophet, which comes into the world.

column7: This is euen he whom Moises, the law,
column8: This is even he whom Moses, the law,

column7: & the prophetes do teache, to be the fully & only sufficient sauiour of ye world.
column8: & the Prophets do teach, to be the Fully & only sufficient Saviour of the world.

column7: Moses saying, in ye.xviii. of Deut.
column8: Moses saying, in you xviii of Deuteronomy

column7: A Prophet of thy nacion & of thy brethren, lyke vnto me, shall the Lorde thy God rayse vp vnto the, hym shalt thou heare.
column8: A Prophet of thy Nation & of thy brothers, like unto me, shall the Lord thy God raise up unto thee, him shalt thou hear.

column7: The lawe, as a tutour, leadeth & bryngeth al men to thys sauyour, to receyue of hym that perfeccion, which the law it selfe lacketh.
column8: The law, as a tutor, leads & bringeth all men to this Saviour, to receive of him that perfection, which the law it self lacketh.

column7: The Prophetes dyd tel long afore of this sauiour which is now comen in our tyme, after theyr dayes.
column8: The prophets did tell long afore of this Saviour which is now come in our time, After their days.

column7: Thys was the peoples confession of Chryst, after that they were by so great a miracle;
column8: This was the peoples Confessi of Christ, After that they were by so great a miracle;

column7: so plentyfullye fed. Christe ofte afore had wrought woderfull miracles, disputed learnedly,
column8: so plentifully fed. Christ oft afore had wrought woderfull Miracles, disputed learnedly,

column7: & preached playnely: but by al those meanes did he not so muche perswade the people, and win theyr heartes, as by thys one miracle, in feeding & cheryshinge the people.
column8: & preached plainly: but by all those means did he not so much persuade the people, and win their hearts, as by this one miracle, in feeding & cherishing the people.

column7: Yea, and whosoeuer listeth to mark thorowe out all Englande, he shall se that a meane learned person, keping an house in hys paryshe, and beyng of godly conuersacion shal perswade & teach mo of hys parishnets with communicacion at one meale, than the best learned doctor of diuinitie kepynge no house can perswade or teache in hys parish by preachyng a dosen solemne sermons.
column8: Yea, and whosoever lists to mark thorough out all England, he shall see that a mean learned person, keeping an house in his parish, and being of godly Conversation shall persuade & teach more of his parishnets with communication At one meal, than the best learned Doctor of divinity keeping no house can persuade or teach in his parish by preaching a dosen solemn Sermons.

column7: Lyke wyse the gentle man that kepeth a good house in his cotrey shalbe in better credit with ye people for hys liberalitye, then the best orator or lawier in England, for all hys eloquence.
column8: Like wise the gentle man that Keepeth a good house in his cotrey shall in better credit with you people for his liberality, then the best orator or lawyer in England, for all his eloquence.

column7: I do not prayse those men whych brybe and pol al the yeare to kepe riot in theyr houses for a fortnyght, a moneth, or a quarter of a yeare:
column8: I do not praise those men which bribe and pol all the year to keep riot in their houses for a fortnyght, a Monn, or a quarter of a year:

column7: But those I se beloued, trusted & obeyed, that accordynge to theyr habilitie, keepe good houses continually.
column8: But those I see Beloved, trusted & obeyed, that according to their hability, keep good houses continually.

column7: And the chiefe cause why the commens doo not loue, trust, nor obey the gentleme & officers, is, because the gentlemen and officers buylde many fayre houses, and kepe fewe good houses, haue plentye of eloquence to tell fayre tales, but vse lytell faythfull dylygence in doing of theyr duties.
column8: And the chief cause why the Common's do not love, trust, nor obey the Gentlemen & Officers, is, Because the gentlemen and Officers build many fair houses, and keep few good houses, have plenty of eloquence to tell fair tales, but use little faithful diligence in doing of their duties.

column7: Wherefore, sende forth, and place in euerye countrye godly preachers, wel disposed persons, and faithful diligent officers of all sortes.
column8: Wherefore, send forth, and place in every country godly Preachers, well disposed Persons, and faithful diligent Officers of all sorts.

column7: Yea, but where shuld we now fynd liuyngs for al those?
column8: Yea, but where should we now find livings for all those?

column7: Forsoth I do tel you:
column8: Forsooth I do tell you:

column7: Out and away with the wily foxes, the false flatteryng theues,
column8: Out and away with the wily foxes, the false flattering thieves,

column7: & the rauenyng wolfes, and than se how many loues, how many offices, prebendes and benefices ye finde voyde, howe mani you haue amongest your selues that youre boye caryeth, that your chapleynes, your seruaunts, and your houshold officers haue,
column8: & the ravening wolves, and than se how many loves, how many Offices, Prebends and Benefices you find void, how mani you have amongst your selves that your boy Carrieth, that your Chaplains, your Servants, and your household Officers have,

column7: & let all these be broughte forth:
column8: & let all these be brought forth:

column7: and althoughe at the fyrste syghte they shal seme to litle, and fewe to serue so greate a Realme with so manye shyres, beyng all tunne nowe oute of ciuil order into rude wildernes,
column8: and although At the First sight they shall seem to little, and few to serve so great a Realm with so many shires, being all tun now out of civil order into rude Wilderness,

column7: Yet, after equal diuidyng & faythful diligent ministring of those loues and fyshes, of these prebends, personages, and all kynd of offices amongest the people,
column8: Yet, After equal dividing & faithful diligent ministering of those loves and fishes, of these Prebends, Personages, and all kind of Offices amongst the people,

column7: God of hys goodnesse shall geue suche increase vnto the people, hauynge therby sufficiente plenty of Chrystes holy worde of good ciuil order,
column8: God of his Goodness shall give such increase unto the people, having thereby sufficient plenty of Christ's holy word of good civil order,

column7: & of charitable reliefe, that there shal be remaynyng so much tithes, offrynge, rentes, fees,
column8: & of charitable relief, that there shall be remaining so much Tithes, offering, rents, fees,

column7: & rewards, as wyl fyll the.xii. baskets of the Apostles,
column8: & rewards, as will fill the xii baskets of the Apostles,

column7: I meanethe barnes, the houses, and purses of all fayethfull diligente ministers and offycers.
column8: I meaneth Barns, the houses, and purses of all faithful diligent Ministers and Officers.

column7: Then shall thys one acte perswade and allure the hertes of al Englyshmen, more then all that euer was done afore:
column8: Then shall this one act persuade and allure the herts of all Englishmen, more then all that ever was done afore:

column7: For when they shall see, that by thys Kyng and thys Counsell, the wilye foxe of supersticion is vtterlye banyshed, the false thefe of flaterye apprehended and taken, and the cruel wolfe of couetousenesse slain and hanged vp by the heeles, so that the preachers, the persons, the officers, and all manner of pastores restored to theyr places, doo feede, cherysh, and kepe theyr flockes whiche were afore pylled spoiled and deuoured:
column8: For when they shall see, that by this King and this Counsel, the wily fox of Superstition is utterly banished, the false thief of flattery apprehended and taken, and the cruel wolf of Covetousness slave and hanged up by the heals, so that the Preachers, the Persons, the Officers, and all manner of Pastors restored to their places, do feed, cherish, and keep their flocks which were afore pylled spoiled and devoured:

column7: then shall they of hertye courage, with one minde, and one voice confesse and acknowledge, that thys is a Kyng sent fro God, in dued wyth the wysdome of Salo mon, and the faythfull diligent stoutnesse of Dauyd hys father, nowe guyded by godly counsel to bryng out of mysery, and prosper in welth vs the people of thys hys Real pe.
column8: then shall they of hearty courage, with one mind, and one voice confess and acknowledge, that this is a King sent from God, in dued with the Wisdom of Salo mon, and the faithful diligent stoutness of David his father, now guided by godly counsel to bring out of misery, and prosper in wealth us the people of this his Real pe.

column7: Dixit Dominus The Lorde hathe spoken it.
column8: Dixit Dominus The Lord hath spoken it.

column7: The Gospell on the fyrste sonday in Aduent. Mat. 21.
column8: The Gospel on the First Sunday in Advent. Mathew 21.

column7: AND when they <NOTE> drew nigh vnto Ierusalem, and wer come to Bethphage, vnto mounte Olyuete, then sente Iesus two disciples, sayinge vnto them:
column8: AND when they drew High unto Jerusalem, and were come to Bethphage, unto mount Olyuet, then sent jesus two Disciples, saying unto them:

column7: Go into the towne that lyeth oueragaynst you, and anone ye shall fynde an asse bounde,
column8: Go into the town that lies overagainst you, and anon you shall find an Ass bound,

column7: & a colte with her:
column8: & a colt with her:

column7: lose them, and brynge them vnto me.
column8: loose them, and bring them unto me.

column7: And yf anye man saye ought vnto you, say ye, the Lorde hath neede of them:
column8: And if any man say ought unto you, say you, the Lord hath need of them:

column7: and straight waye he will let them go.
column8: and straight Way he will let them go.

column7: All this was done, that it myght be fulfylled which was spoken by the prophet, saying:
column8: All this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the Prophet, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Tel ye the doughter of Sion, beholde, the kynge commeth, vnto the, meek, syttyng vpon an asse, and a colte, the fole of the asse, vsed so the yoke.
column8: Tell you the daughter of Sion, behold, the King comes, unto thee, meek, sitting upon an Ass, and a colt, the sole of the Ass, used so the yoke.

column7: The disciples went and dyd as Iesus commaunded them, and brought the asse and the colte, and put on them theyr clothes, and set hym thereon And many of the people spred their garmentes in the way. other cut downe braunches from the trees, and strawed them in the waye.
column8: The Disciples went and did as jesus commanded them, and brought the Ass and the colt, and put on them their clothes, and Set him thereon And many of the people spread their garments in the Way. other Cut down branches from the trees, and strawed them in the Way.

column7: Moreouer, the people that went before and they that came after, cried, saying:
column8: Moreover, the people that went before and they that Come After, cried, saying:

column7: Hosanna to the sonne of Dauyd.
column8: Hosanna to the son of David.

column7: <NOTE> Blessed is he that commeth in the name of the Lorde.
column8: Blessed is he that comes in the name of the Lord.

column7: <NOTE> Hosanna in the hyghest. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Hosanna in the highest. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: S Eyng, that nowe from the beginnynge of the worlde, amonge all Godes elect, hath beene hitherto obserued, and in this latter dais, throughe the synguler grace of God, indespite of the deuell, by noble victory hath beene recouered and wonne,
column8: Sing Sing, that now from the beginning of the world, among all God's elect, hath been hitherto observed, and in this latter dais, through the singular grace of God, indespite of the Devil, by noble victory hath been recovered and won,

column7: <NOTE> that only fayth by Christ maketh a man ryghteous, good, and blessed.
column8: that only faith by christ makes a man righteous, good, and blessed.

column7: It shalbe therfore very expedient, that we (whome God hath called to thoffice of preachynge the Gospell) faithfully and with all seueritye, and treuth, do often handle earnestly, and beate into the heddes of men, the doctrine of faith with repentaunce.
column8: It shall Therefore very expedient, that we (whom God hath called to intent of preaching the Gospel) faithfully and with all severity, and truth, do often handle earnestly, and beat into the Heads of men, the Doctrine of faith with Repentance.

column7: For suerly the deuel, the very enemy of this doctryne, slepeth not, nor can by any means leaue of his peruerse malice and deceitfulnes.
column8: For surely the Devil, the very enemy of this Doctrine, Sleepeth not, nor can by any means leave of his perverse malice and deceitfulness.

column7: For it is trewly alwayes his propertye, to sowe cocle, (that is to say, false doctryne) amonge wheate:
column8: For it is truly always his property, to sow Cocle, (that is to say, false Doctrine) among wheat:

column7: <NOTE> and when he hath done harme amongest the god wheate, priuely to wipe hym selfe awaye.
column8: and when he hath done harm amongst the god wheat, privily to wipe him self away.

column7: Therefore when we shall preach or speake any thing of faith to the people, we muste wiselye, playnly, and circumspectly declare, what maner of faith it is, that scripture so greatly commendeth:
column8: Therefore when we shall preach or speak any thing of faith to the people, we must wisely, plainly, and circumspectly declare, what manner of faith it is, that scripture so greatly commends:

column7: Whence it commeth, what it worketh in vs, what her fruictes be, and what things be contrary to the same, or els our aduersaries shall alwayes be readye to slander and misreport vs:
column8: Whence it comes, what it works in us, what her fruits be, and what things be contrary to the same, or Else our Adversaries shall always be ready to slander and misreport us:

column7: saying, that thorowe such learninge, wee geue occasion to synne, and forbidde good workes to be done.
column8: saying, that thorough such learning, we give occasion to sin, and forbid good works to be done.

column7: Therefore yt I may briefly sette forth vnto you an exaumple of this thinge:
column8: Therefore that I may briefly Set forth unto you an Exampl of this thing:

column7: ye shall vnderstande, that faithe is a trewe trust,
column8: you shall understand, that faith is a true trust,

column7: <NOTE> and perfect hope in God.
column8: and perfect hope in God.

column7: That God by Christe forgeueth synnes,
column8: That God by Christ forgiveth Sins,

column7: & iustyfieth vs, and will graunt eternall lyfe of his only grace and mercy, without any our merites or workes.
column8: & iustyfieth us, and will grant Eternal life of his only grace and mercy, without any our merits or works.

column7: And such faith haue we not of our selues,
column8: And such faith have we not of our selves,

column7: <NOTE> but receiue it by the word of God & the holy ghost.
column8: but receive it by the word of God & the holy ghost.

column7: And whe it is so by ye word of God, and the holy ghoste made liuely and effectuall in vs,
column8: And when it is so by you word of God, and the holy ghost made lively and effectual in us,

column7: <NOTE> then thorough Christe it maketh vs good, iuste, and blessed, as the prophet Abacuc witnesseth, saying:
column8: then through Christ it makes us good, just, and blessed, as the Prophet Habakkuk Witnesseth, saying:

column7: The iust ma lyueth by fayth.
column8: The just ma liveth by faith.

column7: And suche a faythe can not stande without hope & loue, it must needes break out, and by good conuersacion and godlye workes be made apparaunt, not after the nature and custome of hypocrisy (whiche is contrary to faith) but of a voluntary wyl, and an vnfayned harte.
column8: And such a faith can not stand without hope & love, it must needs break out, and by good Conversation and godly works be made apparent, not After the nature and custom of hypocrisy (which is contrary to faith) but of a voluntary will, and an unfeigned heart.

column7: Lo, <NOTE> this is the faithe that wee here speake of, which is commended by the testimonye of scripture.
column8: Lo, this is the faith that we Here speak of, which is commended by the testimony of scripture.

column7: <NOTE> And in likewise ye muste instructe of the repentaunce <NOTE> of a christen man.
column8: And in likewise you must instruct of the Repentance of a christian man.

column7: That penance is nothing else but with all thy harte to be sory for thy synne, to leaue synne, and by fayth to cleaue to rigteousnes.
column8: That penance is nothing Else but with all thy heart to be sorry for thy sin, to leave sin, and by faith to cleave to rigteousnes.

column7: But of these things we shal speak mor at large an other tyme, let vs nowe see what is to be noted in this Gospell.
column8: But of these things we shall speak mor At large an other time, let us now see what is to be noted in this Gospel.

column7: Fyrste of all let vs considre, what may alure and prouok vs to the same faith, here mentioned of.
column8: First of all let us Consider, what may allure and prouok us to the same faith, Here mentioned of.

column7: Which thing surly ye peacible coming of our lorde Iesu Christe to Ierusalem,
column8: Which thing surly you peaceable coming of our lord Jesu Christ to Jerusalem,

column7: <NOTE> doth goodly performe and bringe to passe.
column8: does goodly perform and bring to pass.

column7: For what kind of goodnes or mekenes ys not serued therein?
column8: For what kind of Goodness or meekness is not served therein?

column8: Other Princes and lords, as often as they newly enter into their kingdoms and Dominions, lord, what a pope and great company Goes before them?

column7: as it is written in the 19. psal.
column8: as it is written in the 19. Psalm.

column8: some in charettes,

column8: & Some in Horses. They than put etc.

column7: But Christ although he was constituted lord of heauen and earth, as it apeareth in the laste chap. of Math. yet he porely rode vpon an asse back, accompanied with a simple and despised companye.
column8: But christ although he was constituted lord of heaven and earth, as it appeareth in the laste chap. of Math. yet he porely road upon an Ass back, accompanied with a simple and despised company.

column7: Which thinge not onlye of the world had no comendacion, but also gaue to euery body occasion of laughyng and iesting.
column8: Which thing not only of the world had no commendation, but also gave to every body occasion of laughing and jesting.

column7: <NOTE> Neuertheles if all this were printed in our hartes, yt wolde teache vs what a maner of man Christe was and what became euery christian man to loke of hi.
column8: Nevertheless if all this were printed in our hearts, that would teach us what a manner of man Christ was and what became every christian man to look of him.

column7: He is verily such a one, that escheweth, shunneth,
column8: He is verily such a one, that escheweth, shunneth,

column7: & chaseth away no man from hym, but alureth & calleth euery man to hym.
column8: & chases away no man from him, but alureth & calls every man to him.

column7: For certaynly to that intet he cam into this world, that through his onlye desertes and merites he might redeme all.
column8: For Certainly to that intet he cam into this world, that through his only deserts and merits he might Redeem all.

column7: And therfore he sheweth him selfe vnto vs with so great humanitie, not only in words and learnyng, but also in works and miracles.
column8: And Therefore he shows him self unto us with so great humanity, not only in words and learning, but also in works and Miracles.

column7: And here I think yt the prophet Esa. in spirite saw this great clemency & goodnes of Christ, whe he cried so depely in his hert, sayinge.
column8: And Here I think that the Prophet Isaiah in Spirit saw this great clemency & Goodness of christ, when he cried so deeply in his heart, saying.

column7: <NOTE> Break the heauens and come down,
column8: Break the heavens and come down,

column7: Ye & the euangelist also did diligently brig in the testimony of Zachary, to set before our eyes the mekenes of Christ, wt ye which he goeth about to help euery ma saying,
column8: You & the evangelist also did diligently brig in the testimony of Zachary, to Set before our eyes the meekness of christ, with you which he Goes about to help every ma saying,

column7: Ecce rex tuus uenit tibi mansuetus &c. that is Lo, here thy kinge commeth vnto the &c. all these wordes be spoke with a great vehemency.
column8: Ecce rex Thy uenit tibi Mansuetus etc. that is Lo, Here thy King comes unto the etc. all these words be spoke with a great vehemency.

column7: For whe he saieth notablye this worde, loe, it can not be, but that he goeth about to shew a thig of great waight And here in syght was nothinge els done, but that Christe in his lowly entryng into Ierusalem, wold commed toward vs his most bounteful wil & great benefite, as thoughe he shuld say thus.
column8: For when he Saith notably this word, lo, it can not be, but that he Goes about to show a thig of great weight And Here in sight was nothing Else done, but that Christ in his lowly entering into Jerusalem, would communed towards us his most bounteful will & great benefit, as though he should say thus.

column7: <NOTE> Thou my dispised company hast hitherto lyen oppressed vnder the heauye yoke of the lawe, which, seyng thou coldest by no meanes fulfil, was nother help to the nor to none other.
column8: Thou my despised company hast hitherto lyen oppressed under the heavy yoke of the law, which, sing thou Coldest by no means fulfil, was neither help to the nor to none other.

column7: Moreouer before my aduet or coming. yu haddest nothig els but promise But nowe be of good comfort,
column8: Moreover before my Audit or coming. thou Hadst nothing Else but promise But now be of good Comfort,

column7: I wil make an ende of al thy miserie and wretchednes.
column8: I will make an end of all thy misery and wretchedness.

column7: I wil take away the curse of the lawe, and wyll forgeue the thy sinnes, and shall obteyne for the euerlasting lyfe.
column8: I will take away the curse of the law, and will forgive the thy Sins, and shall obtain for the everlasting life.

column7: Verely al this can I do,
column8: Verily all this can I do,

column7: <NOTE> seing I am kynge & lorde ouer synne, death, the deuel, and hell.
column8: sing I am King & lord over sin, death, the Devil, and hell.

column7: And this not only I can do, but will do, cum sim mitis. &c.
column8: And this not only I can do, but will do, cum sim mitis. etc.

column7: On this wise doth the aforesaid prophet Zachary shewe forthe vnto vs this worke of Christe.
column8: On this wise does the aforesaid Prophet Zachary show forth unto us this work of Christ.

column7: Now he that of this place so learneth to knowe Christe, that with all his herte he may say with the people:
column8: Now he that of this place so learneth to know Christ, that with all his heart he may say with the people:

column7: Blessed be he that cometh in the name of God,
column8: Blessed be he that comes in the name of God,

column7: And so beleueth that here Christe with all his goodnes of his only grace is geuen to hym, he beynge delyuered from sinne, is made iuste and good, accordig to this scripture:
column8: And so Believeth that Here Christ with all his Goodness of his only grace is given to him, he being Delivered from sin, is made just and good, according to this scripture:

column7: He ye beleueth in him, shal not be left comforteles, but shall haue euerlasting lyfe.
column8: He you Believeth in him, shall not be left comforteles, but shall have everlasting life.

column7: Secondarely, <NOTE> this gospell teacheth vs the veri trew good workes of a christen man, by the which the same faith is made clear and apparaunt, in that that this place settethe forthe vnto vs the compassion and teres of Christe, at his entrynge vnto Ierusale.
column8: Secondarily, this gospel Teaches us the very true good works of a christian man, by the which the same faith is made clear and apparent, in that that this place setteth forth unto us the compassion and teres of Christ, At his entering unto Jerusalem.

column7: Wold god that al the world knew what scripture calleth good workes.
column8: Wold god that all the world knew what scripture calls good works.

column7: And trewly it is very expedient, that the ministers of the word of god, shulde earnestly and diligently, (but yet wisely) exhort the people to good workes, seeyng that al the worlde is now geuen holy to naught and myschife For as admonitions, wherwith the people are stirred to do good, be necessary, so affiaunce in the deseruinge of workes, and in our owne iustice, is noysome and perniciouse.
column8: And truly it is very expedient, that the Ministers of the word of god, should earnestly and diligently, (but yet wisely) exhort the people to good works, seeing that all the world is now given holy to nought and myschife For as admonitions, wherewith the people Are stirred to do good, be necessary, so affiance in the deserving of works, and in our own Justice, is noisome and pernicious.

column7: As cocernyng good workes these be they, as often as by very loue thou doeste considre the necessitie, pouertye, infirmitie, miserye and aduersitie of thy neighboure as thine owne.
column8: As cocernyng good works these be they, as often as by very love thou dost Consider the necessity, poverty, infirmity, misery and adversity of thy neighbour as thine own.

column7: And in all thinges in thy mynde, thou art ready to helpe him.
column8: And in all things in thy mind, thou art ready to help him.

column7: As we se in saynt Paule, where he speaketh to the Gala. in the 6. chap:
column8: As we see in saint Paul, where he speaks to the Gala. in the 6. chap:

column7: <NOTE> Lette vs alwayes do good towarde euery man, and cheiflye towarde them, that be ioyned in the felowship of faith with vs.
column8: Let us always do good toward every man, and chiefly toward them, that be joined in the fellowship of faith with us

column7: And in the 6. chapter of the first epistle to Tim. he saith:
column8: And in the 6. chapter of the First epistle to Tim. he Says:

column7: <NOTE> Comaund them that be rich in this world that they be not highe mynded, and that thei putte not their hope and truste in their vncertayn riches but in the liuing God.
column8: Command them that be rich in this world that they be not high minded, and that they put not their hope and trust in their uncertain riches but in the living God.

column7: And that they do good, and be rich in good workes, and liberall in geuing and dealing theyr goods.
column8: And that they do good, and be rich in good works, and liberal in giving and dealing their goods.

column7: Here wee maye se, that saynt Paule doth not onlye moue vs to good works, but also sheweth namely vnto vs, whiche be good workes, (that is to say) to do well to euery manne, and willingly to geue and to be liberall.
column8: Here we may see, that saint Paul does not only move us to good works, but also shows namely unto us, which be good works, (that is to say) to do well to every man, and willingly to give and to be liberal.

column7: And here well may be alledgyd the saiyng of Esaie the prophete in the 58. chap.
column8: And Here well may be alledgyd the saying of Isaiah the Prophet in the 58. chap.

column7: Thou shalt not despise thine oune kynde and fleshe.
column8: Thou shalt not despise thine on kind and Flesh.

column7: <NOTE> Yf thou wilte dilligentlye marke this place, and herken vnto suche thynges as the prophete speaketh of in the same, doughtles thou shalt soone perceiue what he calleth good workes, yea and all the prophets do so instauntlye stir vs vnto these workes, that they dare say plainly, that no kind of worshipping god doth preuaile, wherin the loue of thy neighboure is not founde.
column8: If thou wilt diligently mark this place, and harken unto such things as the Prophet speaks of in the same, doughtles thou shalt soon perceive what he calls good works, yea and all the Prophets do so instantly stir us unto these works, that they Dare say plainly, that no kind of worshipping god does prevail, wherein the love of thy neighbour is not found.

column7: And Osee in the 6. chap. saieth,
column8: And Hosea in the 6. chap. Saith,

column7: Complacitum est mihi in misericordia,
column8: Complacitum est mihi in misericordia,

column7: & non in sacrificio. That is,
column8: & non in Sacrificio. That is,

column7: I am well pleased with mercy shewing, and not in sacrifice doyng.
column8: I am well pleased with mercy showing, and not in sacrifice doing.

column7: In this place to be mercifull, signifieth to do good to my neighbour, as it appeareth in ye 6. of Luke.
column8: In this place to be merciful, signifies to do good to my neighbour, as it appears in you 6. of Luke.

column7: <NOTE> Nowe therfore like as Christ became seruaunt vnto vs in learnyng, in lyfe, in miracles doyng,
column8: Now Therefore like as christ became servant unto us in learning, in life, in Miracles doing,

column8: in his death, in his resurrection, (and to be short) in every point of humantie, so he would that we should become Servants one to an other,

column7: <NOTE> in body, power, strenght,
column8: in body, power, strength,

column7: & in all our riches.
column8: & in all our riches.

column7: Neuertheles in suche wise, not that we shuld put our cofidence in these workes, and withstand the wrath of God therewith, but to testifye and shewe forthe our faithe in light.
column8: Nevertheless in such wise, not that we should put our confidence in these works, and withstand the wrath of God therewith, but to testify and show forth our faith in Light.

column7: For saynct Paule by such workes declared his faith, and lette passe diuerse other of his good workes:
column8: For saint Paul by such works declared his faith, and let pass diverse other of his good works:

column7: what thinke you of that, wher he dyd socoure and helpe:
column8: what think you of that, where he did succour and help:

column7: that poore and miserable Onesmus?
column8: that poor and miserable Onesimus?

column7: For willing to reconcile, (he wold reconcile him to Philemo) he calleth hi his own hart:
column8: For willing to reconcile, (he would reconcile him to Philemon) he calls him his own heart:

column7: ys not this a greate parte of loue?
column8: is not this a great part of love?

column7: <NOTE> And afterwarde he excuseth Onesimus of his fleyng and ronnyng away, as verye necessarye to this purpose, that after his suche lapse and falle, he might be not onlye a minister or seruaunt, but as a brother vnto Philemon.
column8: And afterward he excuseth Onesimus of his fling and running away, as very necessary to this purpose, that After his such lapse and fall, he might be not only a minister or servant, but as a brother unto Philemon.

column7: Forthermore the same good saint Paule took on hym selfe the harme, whiche the same fugitiue seruaunt had done his mayster, and wolde all the losse (whatsoeuer it were) to be layde on his necke Be not these good workes?
column8: Furthermore the same good saint Paul took on him self the harm, which the same fugitive servant had done his master, and would all the loss (whatsoever it were) to be laid on his neck Be not these good works?

column7: But by it that other workes do appeare greate and good, yet may thei not well be called good workes, whan they, which haue neede of them, be not releuyd by them.
column8: But by it that other works do appear great and good, yet may they not well be called good works, when they, which have need of them, be not releuyd by them.

column7: Good workes must alway serue thy neyghboure,
column8: Good works must always serve thy neighbour,

column7: & hym that hath need.
column8: & him that hath need.

column7: <NOTE> And that Christ teacheth vs in this story, when in the middest of the peoples ioy, which reioysed and wished all thinges prosperous vnto him, as to the son of Dauyd,
column8: And that christ Teaches us in this story, when in the midst of the peoples joy, which rejoiced and wished all things prosperous unto him, as to the son of David,

column7: & to their power gaue hym the moste honoure they could, he wepte very sore and bitterly.
column8: & to their power gave him the most honour they could, he wept very soar and bitterly.

column7: What shuld stir or moue him so to wepe thinke you?
column8: What should stir or move him so to weep think you?

column7: Verely as he him selfe witnesseth the misery and wretchednes of the people entred into his hert, for seing that by al the time that he was so conuersaunte amongest them, they wolde not vnderstand nor receiue knowledge, it was necessarye that thei in body, soule, honour, and all their goods shuld perishe.
column8: Verily as he him self Witnesseth the misery and wretchedness of the people entered into his heart, for sing that by all the time that he was so conversant amongst them, they would not understand nor receive knowledge, it was necessary that they in body, soul, honour, and all their goods should perish.

column7: All this knewe Christ, and therefore wepte so sore.
column8: All this knew christ, and Therefore wept so soar.

column7: And besides this, he faithfully gaue monicion vnto them before, whereby they mighte learne to auoyd such inconuenience:
column8: And beside this, he faithfully gave monition unto them before, whereby they might Learn to avoid such inconvenience:

column7: but all was in vayne.
column8: but all was in vain.

column7: Now lyke as Christ doth not disemble, but by all meanes goeth aboute to preuente the losse of his people, so shulde we when we are come to the knowledg of God, take vpon vs the care and necessitie of our neighbour, whether it be bodely or gostlye, great or small,
column8: Now like as christ does not dissemble, but by all means Goes about to prevent the loss of his people, so should we when we Are come to the knowledge of God, take upon us the care and necessity of our neighbour, whither it be bodily or ghostly, great or small,

column7: & to procure not only, that there ryse or growe no hurt vnto them or theires, but also that they feele our help at need.
column8: & to procure not only, that there rise or grow no hurt unto them or theirs, but also that they feel our help At need.

column7: As sainct Paule to the Galat. in the 9. chap. saith: Alter alterius one ra portate,
column8: As saint Paul to the Galatians in the 9. chap. Says: Altar alterius one ra portate,

column7: & sic perficietis legem Christi.
column8: & sic perficietis legem Christ.

column7: That is, One of you ease and help an other, and so ye shall fulfill the lawe of Christ.
column8: That is, One of you ease and help an other, and so you shall fulfil the law of christ.

column7: Let it be by vs at all time fulfilled, that God the father by oure workes withoute seasing end may bee glorifyed.
column8: Let it be by us At all time fulfilled, that God the father by our works without seizing end may be glorified.

column7: Amen. The seconde sonday in Aduent, Luc. 21.
column8: Amen. The seconde Sunday in Advent, Luke 21.

column7: AND there shalbe signes in the sonne and in the moone, and in the starres, and in the yearth <NOTE> the people shalbe at theire wittes ende, thorowe dispaire.
column8: AND there shall Signs in the son and in the moon, and in the Stars, and in the earth the people shall At their wits end, thorough despair.

column7: The sea and the water shall roare, and mens hartes shal faile them for fear, and for lokyng after those thynges whiche shall come on the yeerth.
column8: The sea and the water shall roar, and men's hearts shall fail them for Fear, and for looking After those things which shall come on the yeerth.

column7: For the powers of heaue shal moue.
column8: For the Powers of heave shall move.

column7: And then shall they see the sonne of man come in a cloud with power and greate glory.
column8: And then shall they see the son of man come in a cloud with power and great glory.

column7: When these thinges begin to come to passe, then looke vp, and lift vp your heades, tor youre redemption draweth nye.
column8: When these things begin to come to pass, then look up, and lift up your Heads, tor your redemption draws High.

column7: <NOTE> And he shewed them a similitude:
column8: And he showed them a similitude:

column7: Be hold the figge tree, and al the trees, when theye shoote forth their buddes, ye se and knowe of youre owne selues, that sommer is then nye at hande.
column8: Be hold the fig tree, and all the trees, when they shoot forth their buds, you see and know of your own selves, that summer is then High At hand.

column7: So likewise ye also, when ye se these thinges come to passe, be sure that the kingdome of God is nye.
column8: So likewise you also, when you see these things come to pass, be sure that the Kingdom of God is High.

column7: Verely I saye to you, this generacion shal not passe in all be fulfilled.
column8: Verily I say to you, this generation shall not pass in all be fulfilled.

column7: Heauen and earth shall passe, but my wordes shal not passe. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Heaven and earth shall pass, but my words shall not pass. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this gospell first of all is declared vnto vs,
column8: IN this gospel First of all is declared unto us,

column7: <NOTE> the greate carke and care, that Christ taketh for vs.
column8: the great cark and care, that christ Takes for us

column7: And although he speake here of many and horrible signes and tokens, that shalbe before his coming, yet he wolde not that his electe shuld be destitute of comfort.
column8: And although he speak Here of many and horrible Signs and tokens, that shall before his coming, yet he would not that his elect should be destitute of Comfort.

column7: But very gentely taught them, how they shulde behaue them selues, when the tribulacion of this time shall come vpon them.
column8: But very gently taught them, how they should behave them selves, when the tribulation of this time shall come upon them.

column7: Neither wolde he kepe close from them what shulde folowe after this tribulacions, verely the ende of the cursed and wicked world.
column8: Neither would he keep close from them what should follow After this tribulations, verily the end of the cursed and wicked world.

column7: <NOTE> And althoughe these signes at the firste shalbe terrible, and bring muche sorowe and tremblinge with them, yet shall they not all hurte the elect:
column8: And although these Signs At the First shall terrible, and bring much sorrow and trembling with them, yet shall they not all hurt the elect:

column7: bycause thei shal haue knowledg of these thinges long before. <NOTE>
column8: Because they shall have knowledge of these things long before.

column7: And thei shal looke about and lift vp their heads, as they which know by those signes the day of their redemtion from al euel to be at had:
column8: And they shall look about and lift up their Heads, as they which know by those Signs the day of their redemption from all evil to be At had:

column7: And that Christ then shall take from the tirannes, <NOTE> Princes,
column8: And that christ then shall take from the Tyrants, Princes,

column7: Lordes, Kinges, and Emperoures, theyr power, and yelde it vp to his heuenly father.
column8: lords, Kings, and emperors, their power, and yield it up to his heavenly father.

column7: Further, seing that thei know (according to saint Pauls saiyng) that all thinges worke for the best to gods elect:
column8: Further, sing that they know (according to saint Paul's saying) that all things work for the best to God's elect:

Also Christ in this gospell sheweth the maiestye of his laste comminge, for none other cause, but to comforte his people, and to the wicked he bringeth an horrible fear, when he saieth:

column7: Thou my dispised company, hast suffered griefe and paine in this worlde, thou haste beene made the ofscouringe of al, for my worde, in the desence therof thou hast suffered many ieopardies, of goodes, honoure, lyfe, <NOTE> and so forthe.

column8: Therefore now behold him, in whom thou hast laid or Set all thy trust or hope.

column8: being damned both body & soul for ever.

column8: what beseemeth the Ministers of the word to observe, as well in their living as in their learning.

column8: earnestly also to teach & instruct of penance.

column8: Penance, I call, when a ma with his heart is sorry for his sin, willing to amend, and After that to live justly, as scripture speaks of this penance:

column8: and,

column8: He that hath stolen, let him steal no more It is always necessary that I acknowledge my sin and corrupt nature, if the preaching of christ shall any thing profit me.

column8: Now sing that I must come to such knowledge of corrupt nature and hatred of my sin, then must needs the minister of Goddess word Set before me, you law,

column8: that is, That I am a great damnable sinner, and that of my self I can nothing do, and so much the less should glory or magnify my self.

column8: John: First he speaks of penance & ccocludeth every ma to be under since, lest they should glori in the selves.

column8: as who Says. His life is not Set in voluptuousness but is mortefied from all carnal concupiscence and pride, and lives justly to God's word.

column7: And Christ further saith: Poore me do hear ye glad tidings of the preachers of the gospel. (As he shuld say again.) Hitherto ye haue had Moyses & the law But Moyses could not geue you the spirite, wherwith ye myght haue fulfilled the lawe:
column8: And christ further Says: Poor me do hear you glad tidings of the Preachers of the gospel. (As he should say again.) Hitherto you have had Moses & the law But Moses could not give you the Spirit, wherewith you might have fulfilled the law:

column7: And nowe ye heare of an other maner lernyng (that is ye gospell verely) by the which they that be poore in spirit, and knowledg their synnes, do frely through Christe receiue remission of synne, without merite of workes, and shalbe pertakers of the kyngdom of heauen, with the childre of God, so yt they beleue in Christ.
column8: And now you hear of an other manner learning (that is the gospel verily) by the which they that be poor in Spirit, and knowledge their Sins, do freely through Christ receive remission of sin, without merit of works, and shall partakers of the Kingdom of heaven, with the children of God, so that they believe in christ.

column7: Tel Iohn. Lo, yt is preached to the poore people, that is to them that be contrite in herte, and be destitute of all helpe and comforte A ioy ful mesage trewly, that through my benifyte they shal hereafter haue a mercyful God, remission of all sinnes, iustice and euerlasting helth, by very grace and mercye, withoute any merite of workes.
column8: Tell John. Lo, that is preached to the poor people, that is to them that be contrite in heart, and be destitute of all help and Comfort A joy full mesage truly, that through my benifyte they shall hereafter have a merciful God, remission of all Sins, Justice and everlasting health, by very grace and mercy, without any merit of works.

column7: And now yf Iohn hear of these thinges agayne, yt muste playnly be manifest vnto you, whether I be Messias or not.

column7: The Iewes were in this opinio that Christ shulde haue his dominion after the manner of kinges and prynces of this worlde, and bycause that in his suche power, he appeared not a manne of nobilitie to the worlde, therefore they set little by his doctrine, and beleued nothing lesse then that such a one shulde be the trewe Messias.
column8: The Jews were in this opinio that christ should have his dominion After the manner of Kings and Princes of this world, and Because that in his such power, he appeared not a man of Nobilt to the world, Therefore they Set little by his Doctrine, and believed nothing less then that such a one should be the true Messias.

column7: For Christ (as is saide before) besydes that, that he preacheth and baptiseth, doth also by his owne power, forgeue synnes, and send the holy ghoste, that shal lighten and renewe our hartis which Iohn cannot doo, but by his misterye.
column8: For christ (as is said before) besides that, that he Preacheth and baptizeth, does also by his own power, forgive Sins, and send the holy ghost, that shall lighten and renew our hearts which John cannot do, but by his mystery.

column7: And this is the cause whye he doth so greatlye commende and prayse Christe, for that he is the very lambe of God, that takethe awaye the synne of the worlde.
column8: And this is the cause why he does so greatly commend and praise Christ, for that he is the very lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world.

column7: And likewise yt is he, that was before me, and shall come after me:
column8: And likewise that is he, that was before me, and shall come After me:

column7: as who saieth: He is more then Iohn, and forgeueth synne, also I am not worthy to lose the latchet of his showe Is not this the verye waye to knowe, prayse, and describe Christ?
column8: as who Saith: He is more then John, and forgiveth sin, also I am not worthy to loose the latchet of his show Is not this the very Way to know, praise, and describe christ?

column7: And yet when wee are baptised, wee be baptised bothe with the baptisme of Iohn and Christe also,
column8: And yet when we Are baptised, we be baptised both with the Baptism of John and Christ also,

column8: that is,

column7: It is necessary, that that olde Adame be layed vnder feete (as it is signified by that outwarde signe) before Christ dothe baptise in fyer and the spirite.
column8: It is necessary, that that old Adam be laid under feet (as it is signified by that outward Signen) before christ doth baptise in fire and the Spirit.

column7: Moreouer wee muste also come to the knowledge of synne by Iohnes preachyng.
column8: Moreover we must also come to the knowledge of sin by Johns preaching.

column7: And when we be brought in this wise to the knowledge of our sinne, then Christe fyndeth place for the exercising of hys office, to remitte synnes, and geue into our hartes the holye ghoste, which he will do accordyng to S.
column8: And when we be brought in this wise to the knowledge of our sin, then Christ findeth place for the exercising of his office, to remit Sins, and give into our hearts the holy ghost, which he will do according to S.

column7: Iohnes wordes: This is he, that baptiseth in the holye ghoste.
column8: Johns words: This is he, that baptizeth in the holy ghost.

column7: And yt is necessarye that by faithe wee attayne that, yf we will be made newe creatures.
column8: And that is necessary that by faith we attain that, if we will be made new creatures.

column7: The ende of this Exposition.
column8: The end of this Exposition.

column7: Foloweth. The gospell on Christemas daye. Luc. 2.
column8: Followeth. The gospel on Christmas day. Luke 2.

column7: A Nd it chaunsed in tho^e dayes, that there went oute a commaundemente from Augustus the emperoure, that all the worlde should be taxed.
column8: ANd ANd it chanced in Those days, that there went out a Commandment from Augustus the emperor, that all the world should be taxed.

column7: And this taxing was the fyrste, and executed when Sitenius was lift^an^e in Syria And euerye man wente vnto his owne cu^e to bee taxed.
column8: And this taxing was the First, and executed when Sithenius was lift^an^e in Syria And every man went unto his own Cure to be taxed.

column7: And Io^eph also ascended from Galile o^re of the citie called Nazarethe, into Iewry, vnto <NOTE> the citye of Dauyd, whiche is called Bethlehem, bycause he was of the house and lynage of Dauyd, to be taxed with Marye his spoused wyfe, which was wich chylde.
column8: And Joseph also ascended from Galilee o^re of the City called Nazareth, into Jewry, unto the City of David, which is called Bethlehem, Because he was of the house and lineage of David, to be taxed with Mary his spoused wife, which was which child.

column7: And it fortuned, that while theye were there, her tyme was come that she should be delyuered. and she brought forth hee fyrst begotten sonne, and wr^pped him in swad^inge clothes, and laide him in a maunger, bycause there was no come for them in the Inne.
column8: And it fortuned, that while they were there, her time was come that she should be Delivered. and she brought forth he fyrst begotten son, and wr^pped him in swad^inge clothes, and laid him in a manger, Because there was no come for them in the Inn.

column7: And there were in the same region shepcherdes, watchynge and kepynge theyr flocke by nyght.
column8: And there were in the same region shepcherdes, watching and keeping their flock by night.

column8: And lo, the angel of the Lord stood harden by them, and the bryghtenes of the Lord shone round about them, and they were soar afraid.

column8: And the angel said unto them:

column7: Be not afraide. For beholde,
column8: Be not afraid. For behold,

column8: for unto you is born this day in the City of David, a Saviour which is Christ the Lord.

column8: Glory to God on high, and peace on earth and unto men a good will. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this gospell first of all is treated the helthfull byrth of oure Lord Iesu Christ,
column8: IN this gospel First of all is treated the healtful birth of our Lord Jesu christ,

column7: <NOTE> which is the wel hedde of our saluacion, and of eternal lyfe.
column8: which is the well head of our salvation, and of Eternal life.

column7: Wherefore it is necessary that euen as the euangelist hath described the same natiuitie or birthe, so likewise, that euerye manne doo receaue it into the inwarde partes of his harte, and often tymes to reuolue it in himselfe, whereby he may by the meditacion of such thinges be kendeled, lyghtened, and made ioyful, and that they maye take and kepe in theyr hertes, the chylde newelye borne, by the worde of faith:
column8: Wherefore it is necessary that even as the evangelist hath described the same Nativity or birth, so likewise, that every man do receive it into the inward parts of his heart, and often times to revolve it in himself, whereby he may by the meditation of such things be kendeled, lightened, and made joyful, and that they may take and keep in their herts, the child newly born, by the word of faith:

column7: For the lower and poorer that this byrthe appeareth to the worlde,
column8: For the lower and Poorer that this birth appears to the world,

column7: <NOTE> so muche the holsomer and more profitable it is to them, that receau it by faith.
column8: so much the holsomer and more profitable it is to them, that receau it by faith.

column7: And that it was so small of estymacion with the worlde, it may be gathered of that, that Ioseph and the virgyne Mary ascended from the city of Nazareth vnto the citie that is called Bethlehem in the lande of Iudea, none other wise, but as the other subiectes dyd, to geue obedience to theyre superioures, and to yeld tribute as the other did.
column8: And that it was so small of estymacion with the world, it may be gathered of that, that Joseph and the Virgae Mary ascended from the City of Nazareth unto the City that is called Bethlehem in the land of Judea, none other wise, but as the other Subjects did, to give Obedience to their superiors, and to yield tribute as the other did.

column7: Who wold (I pray you) beleue, that Mary shuld be the mother of God, whiche went vnto the professio no otherwise, then the other plebeial one & dispised sort of women dyd.
column8: Who would (I pray you) believe, that Mary should be the mother of God, which went unto the professio no otherwise, then the other plebeial one & despised sort of women did.

column8: And likewise the evangelist Saith:

column8: that in the town of Bethlehem she was had in no respect or regard of any person, in so much that she was fain (that scripture mygt be fulfilled) to wrap her well-beloved son christ (which she there brought forth) in clouts, and lay him in an ox stal.

column8: fear you not. O joyful and sweet message, that for all the great weight of sin, brought into this world with us, we should not Fear:

column7: why so? Bycause ther is to day borne vnto vs suche a sauioure, that shall take awaye the sinne of the world, and through his passion and deathe shall obtaine for all them that beleue in him euerlastinge lyfe.
column8: why so? Because there is to day born unto us such a Saviour, that shall take away the sin of the world, and through his passion and death shall obtain for all them that believe in him everlasting life.

column7: Wherefore it is bery meete, that this natiuitie, of ye which we receyue so great profite & ioy, shuld be glorious in oure syght.
column8: Wherefore it is berry meet, that this Nativity, of you which we receive so great profit & joy, should be glorious in our sight.

column8: But Christ's is pure without sin and holy.

column8: Therefore now if the condenation of our Nativity must be taken away and changed, it must needs be by the pure and undefiled Nativity of our lord Jesu Christ,

column7: And therefore set thei their mindes so much vppo their owne workes, with the which they truste to obtatne both righteousnes and saluacion, euen as thoughe with our owne merites we might stonde in the iudgement of God.

column8: & the holy me of Jerusalem?

column8: Because that God hath chosen such as to the world appear foolish, to the intent to shame you wordly wise men.

column7: Rich me, gentleme, & me of great power of this world, haue no respecte or regarde to this child Iesus, but haue their peculier and priuate God, in whom they put the whole and some of theire trust, that is, in pride, in theire great strenth and power, in riches and in their mightie god mammon.
column8: Rich me, Gentlemen, & me of great power of this world, have no respect or regard to this child jesus, but have their peculiar and private God, in whom they put the Whole and Some of their trust, that is, in pride, in their great strength and power, in riches and in their mighty god mammon.

column7: <NOTE> And in like manner these worke maisters (as thei be called) haue their priuate god, yt is, ye trust in their own works and merites,

column7: Therfore he chose none but poore folkes, and not such as wer pore in this world after the flesh, but poore in spirite, that is, they that knowe all theyre owne sinnes, frailnes, misbeleue and corrupt natur and abid only in his word.
column8: Therefore he chosen none but poor folks, and not such as were poor in this world After the Flesh, but poor in Spirit, that is, they that know all their own Sins, frailness, misbeleue and corrupt Nature and Abided only in his word.

column8: Thirdly we may Learn of this gospel, that when this healtful birth of Christ is laid forth unto us by the Ministers of the gospel, (which for the more part in scripture be signified by Angels) and we thereby ascertained,

column7: <NOTE> that our saluacion consisteth in the same:
column8: that our salvation Consisteth in the same:

column7: Here God is praised of the Aungels & heauenly company, chiefly for this cause, that he of his onlye grace & mercy, hath geuen his onlye begotten son, a sauioure to the world, that through him, the way shuld be to euerlasting lyfe, for al men:
column8: Here God is praised of the Angels & heavenly company, chiefly for this cause, that he of his only grace & mercy, hath given his only begotten son, a Saviour to the world, that through him, the Way should be to everlasting life, for all men:

column7: and that by his goodnes, syn, deth, the deuel, and hel, shuldde taken away.
column8: and that by his Goodness, sin, death, the Devil, and hell, shuldde taken away.

column7: Ys not this benefite worthy of praise & comendacio?
column8: Is not this benefit worthy of praise & comendacio?

column7: Yes trewly no man can geue worthy thankes therefore:
column8: Yes truly no man can give worthy thanks Therefore:

column7: Neueuertheles yet we must persist to say with the prophet Dauid:
column8: Nevertheless yet we must persist to say with the Prophet David:

column7: <NOTE> My soule praise ye Lord,
column8: My soul praise you Lord,

column7: I wil praise the Lord in my lyfe,
column8: I will praise the Lord in my life,

column7: I wil sing to my God as longe as I lyue.
column8: I will sing to my God as long as I live.

column7: And considre here that this honour and thankes geuing can not bee yelded to God, where this oure Christe is not, or not throughly knowen.
column8: And Consider Here that this honour and thanks giving can not be yielded to God, where this our Christ is not, or not thoroughly known.

column7: And that no peace or good will can abide with vs, without Christ.
column8: And that no peace or good will can abide with us, without christ.

column7: & extolled, as such a father, that hath geue vs his only son Christ for a sauiour into al ye world.
column8: & extolled, as such a father, that hath give us his only son christ for a Saviour into all the world.

column7: And there also is found the trew peace, when we beleue that God the father wil not vs to bee damned, but of his ineffable grace wil receiue and geue vs euerlastinge lyfe by Christe.
column8: And there also is found the true peace, when we believe that God the father will not us to be damned, but of his ineffable grace will receive and give us everlasting life by Christ.

column7: And there was a prophetisse, one Anaa, the doughter of Phanuel of the tribe of Aser, which was of greate age, and had lyued wt her husbande seuen yeares, from her vyrginitie.

column7: And she had bene a widowe aboue foure score & foure yere, which departed not from the temple, but serueth God with fastinges and prayers nyght and day.
column8: And she had be a widow above foure score & foure year, which departed not from the temple, but serveth God with Fastings and Prayers night and day.

column8: And she Come forth that same hour and praised the Lord, and spoke of him, to all them that looked for the redemptio in Jerusalem

column7: And when they had performed al thinges, according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galile, to theyr owne city Nazareth And the chylde grewe, and waxed strong in spirite, and was filled with wisedome, <NOTE> and the grace of God was vpon hym. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: Of these words of Simeon it is manifest, that Christ is ye trew Messias & sauiour of ye world, promised in holi scripture, or els why wold he cal him ye lyght, sauiour & glory of Israel, yf he could not help, saue,

column7: And therefore said vnto Mary, that with her welbeloued son she shulde suffre also great sorowes, that the secrete thoughtes of many shulde bee opened, whiche, although they were taken for the moste holyest of al, yet shuld they be of all the most wicked.

column7: And althoughe it be very necessary and instantlye required of a christian man, that he shulde declare and shewe forth his faith, with the workes of Charitie, and other godlye exercise, yet by no worke can he bee iustified, but allonly by the merite of Christe.
column8: And although it be very necessary and instantly required of a christian man, that he should declare and show forth his faith, with the works of Charity, and other godly exercise, yet by no work can he be justified, but allonly by the merit of Christ.

column7: Forthlye this gospell teacheth vs, that the word of God and his workes do striue with our reason:
column8: Fourthly this gospel Teaches us, that the word of God and his works do strive with our reason:

column7: If we go about by reason to knowe the mistery of the circumcision, it wold seme a very iest, that God shulde adorne with his commaundemente, so vile a membre. <NOTE>
column8: If we go about by reason to know the mystery of the circumcision, it would seem a very jest, that God should adorn with his Commandment, so vile a member.

column7: But what shuldest thowe thinke seyng it is so?
column8: But what Shouldst Though think sing it is so?

column7: Verelye God choseth not those things that be pleasaunt, or in great estimacion with vs, but suche thinges as be dispised and abiecte before oure eyes:
column8: Verily God chooses not those things that be pleasant, or in great estimation with us, but such things as be despised and abject before our eyes:

column7: And that for this cause, bicause that our reason shuld be subdued to the worde of God and his workes, and that we shuld commend and accept such things as he hath chosen, and not those things that seeme most pleasaunte and goodly to our sight Circumcision was a thinge that was smal of estymacion,
column8: And that for this cause, Because that our reason should be subdued to the word of God and his works, and that we should commend and accept such things as he hath chosen, and not those things that seem most pleasant and goodly to our sighed Circumcision was a thing that was small of estymacion,

column7: <NOTE> but when the cumaundement and promise of God came, yt was made a noble helthful & a godly worke:

column8: And likewise it is but a trifle to be baptised and washed in water,

column8: But if the Commandment, promise, and word of God be joined thereto, it is surely a thing wondered precious and healtful.

column7: And althoughe to the worlde it appeare but a tryfull to be baptised, yet baptisme that is brought in the steede of circumcision, must be accepted of vs as an hyghe and precious work, bicause it hath the commaundement and promise of Christ,
column8: And although to the world it appear but a tryfull to be baptised, yet Baptism that is brought in the steed of circumcision, must be accepted of us as an high and precious work, Because it hath the Commandment and promise of christ,

column8: When Herod the King hard these things, he was troubled, and all the City of Jerusalem with him.

column8: I pray you how durst the Jews deny, that christ was the very Messias Now like as the place, so does also the time very well agree,
