column7: The scepter shall not be remoued from Iuda, nor a ruler of his posterite, til he come that shal come.
column8: The sceptre shall not be removed from Juda, nor a ruler of his posterity, till he come that shall come.

column7: Of this prophecy yt appeareth, that Christ muste needes haue then be borne, when ye kyngdom of the Iewes was so taken away, that no kinge or ruler of the tribe of Iuda, shuld reign any longer.
column8: Of this prophecy that appears, that christ must needs have then be born, when you Kingdom of the Jews was so taken away, that no King or ruler of the tribe of Juda, should Reign any longer.

column7: And that did chauce at the tyme of Herod, which was not of the tribe of Iuda, nor yet born of ye Iewes blod, but was an Idumee a strauger, and made kyng by the Romanes Wherefore, nother yet of this place can the obstynate Iewe deny, but that Christe is the son of God and the trewe Messias:
column8: And that did chance At the time of Herod, which was not of the tribe of Juda, nor yet born of the Jews blood, but was an Idumea a strauger, and made King by the Romans Wherefore, neither yet of this place can the obstinate Jew deny, but that Christ is the son of God and the true Messias:

column7: And it were to be highelye wished and desieed of vs, that the Iewes allonlye and no christyan man dyd withstande and speake agayne thys natyuyty:
column8: And it were to be highly wished and desieed of us, that the Jews allonlye and no christian man did withstand and speak again this natyuyty:

column7: For althoughe we often tymes say, and confesse, that Christ the sonne of God was borne of the virgyne Mary, yet when we will not knowe nor vnderstande, wherefore yt was done,
column8: For although we often times say, and confess, that christ the son of God was born of the Virgae Marry, yet when we will not know nor understand, Wherefore that was done,

column7: I cannot see what profite wee shall gette thereby.
column8: I cannot see what profit we shall get thereby.

column7: Thou muste knowe and confesse, that to the, to the (I saye) and to thyne redemption and saluacion he was borne.
column8: Thou must know and confess, that to thee, to the (I say) and to thine redemption and salvation he was born.

column7: <NOTE> And that the father in this hys sonne allonlye wilbe knowen and gloryfied.
column8: And that the father in this his son allonlye will known and glorified.

column7: Yf anye chrystyan man doth putte his confidence nowe in the merites of hys owne workes, and trusteth to gette euerlastynge lyfe thereby, he trewlye doth as greuouslye and dispytefullye withstande this natyuytye, as thoughe any Iewe had done it.
column8: If any christian man does put his confidence now in the merits of his own works, and Trusteth to get everlasting life thereby, he truly does as grievously and dispytefullye withstand this natyuytye, as though any Jew had done it.

column7: But he that beleueth, that by the onlye meryte of Chryst he ys iustyfyed, he shall haue euerlastyng lyfe. Ioh. 3.
column8: But he that Believeth, that by the only merit of Christ he is Justified, he shall have everlasting life. John 3.

column7: Secondarelye, wee learne out of this gospell, that Chryste came into thys worlde, not onlye for the Iewes, but also for the Gentyles.
column8: Secondarily, we Learn out of this gospel, that Christ Come into this world, not only for the Jews, but also for the Gentiles.

column7: And so yt ys declared by these wysemen that seeke Christ, that the preachynge of the gospel shulde be taken from ye Iewes,
column8: And so that is declared by these Wise men that seek christ, that the preaching of the gospel should be taken from the Jews,

column7: & geuen to the Gentyles:
column8: & given to the Gentiles:

column7: <NOTE> And yt for thys cause, yt althogh they hard ye gospel fyrst of Chryst & afterward of hys dyscyples, yet did thei dispyse & persecute yt,
column8: And that for this cause, that although they hard the gospel fyrst of Christ & afterwards of his Disciples, yet did they despise & persecute that,

column7: & wyth slaunderous wordes reiected it fro them.
column8: & with slanderous words rejected it from them.

column7: For I pray you, which of all the Iewes ranne to seke this childe?
column8: For I pray you, which of all the Jews ran to seek this child?

column8: although it was openly said, that their King was the At hand, and present with thee.

column7: The heythen which neuer had god, came from the Est, seking and enquiring so long for this chyld, vntil they had founde him:
column8: The Heathen which never had god, Come from the Est, seeking and inquiring so long for this child, until they had found him:

column7: And that the Iewes, through their misbilefe be now abiected, it is by the iust iudgement of God, and it maye bee well of euery man said:
column8: And that the Jews, through their misbilefe be now abjected, it is by the just judgement of God, and it may be well of every man said:

column7: <NOTE> Lord, thou art iust, and thi iudgemet is ryghteouse.
column8: Lord, thou art just, and thy Judgement is righteous.

column7: And in contrary wise: The cause that we miserable hethen be taken and called to the gospell, is the very grace and mercy of God.
column8: And in contrary wise: The cause that we miserable heathen be taken and called to the gospel, is the very grace and mercy of God.

column7: And if therefore we did our dutyes, we shulde neuer cease from geuinge thankes, for the greate clemencye of God, that he hath had towarde vs all.
column8: And if Therefore we did our duties, we should never cease from giving thanks, for the great clemency of God, that he hath had toward us all.

column7: And that we ye wretched & sinful gentiles, through grace are called to ye knowledg of ye gospel, it apeareth by ye wordes of Esai, sayeng:
column8: And that we the wretched & sinful Gentiles, through grace Are called to you knowledge of the gospel, it appeareth by you words of Isaiah, saying:

column7: I am sought of the, that neuer asked for me,
column8: I am sought of thee, that never asked for me,

column7: <NOTE> & am found of the, that neuer sought me,
column8: & am found of thee, that never sought me,

column7: And I haue saide, Lo I, lo I am found of a nation, that neuer called on my name.
column8: And I have said, Lo I, lo I am found of a Nation, that never called on my name.

column7: Thou herist that they shall fynde hym, that neuer sought hym:
column8: Thou herist that they shall find him, that never sought him:

column7: ys not thys playnly spoken of vs the gentiles?
column8: is not this plainly spoken of us the Gentiles?

column7: Therfore of thys place we may learne and knowe, that euerlastyng ioy, commeth not by the merytes of oure owne workes but throughe grace, and accordyng to the saiyng of saynct Paule,
column8: Therefore of this place we may Learn and know, that everlasting joy, comes not by the merits of our own works but through grace, and according to the saying of saint Paul,

column7: <NOTE> wee are saued by grace, throughe fayth, leste we shulde glorye.
column8: we Are saved by grace, through faith, lest we should glory.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdelye, we perceyue by thys gospell what a myserable and wretched thyng the carnall man is, in whome the same olde Adam, through the spyrite and faith is not yet mortified:
column8: Thirdly, we perceive by this gospel what a miserable and wretched thing the carnal man is, in whom the same old Adam, through the Spirit and faith is not yet mortified:

column7: The Kynges come from the east to Ierusalem, inquiring for the king of Iewes newly borne, and shewe that they sawe his star in the East, and that they came to worship him, that is, to geue to him reuerence and honour:
column8: The Kings come from the east to Jerusalem, inquiring for the King of Jews newly born, and show that they saw his star in the East, and that they Come to worship him, that is, to give to him Reverence and honour:

column7: <NOTE> Here it had bene meete, that the whole citye of Ierusalem shulde with all reuerence and ioye haue sought out this kyng, and haue receaued him, seig that they had loked for his coming so many years before.
column8: Here it had be meet, that the Whole City of Jerusalem should with all Reverence and joy have sought out this King, and have received him, seig that they had looked for his coming so many Years before.

column7: They knew by the prophecy of Iacob,
column8: They knew by the prophecy of Jacob,

column7: <NOTE> that at the same tyme he should suerly come.
column8: that At the same time he should surely come.

column7: But what do they? Not only Herod was so sore moued therwt when he hadde herde thereof, but also all Ierusalem with him, that is, the more part of the citizins & especiallye such, as with good Simeon & Anna dyd long for the redemptio of Israel.
column8: But what do they? Not only Herod was so soar moved therewith when he had herd thereof, but also all Jerusalem with him, that is, the more part of the Citizens & especially such, as with good Simeon & Anna did long for the redemptio of Israel.

column7: Wherto now were all the pomises?
column8: Whereto now were all the Promises?

column8: how well do they now Remember the prophecy of Jacob?

column8: And what does it profit them, to be under the law of Moses?

column7: Herod thinketh he had good and iust cause to be moued therewith, although yt was but in vayn,
column8: Herod Thinketh he had good and just cause to be moved therewith, although that was but in vain,

column7: & not necessary But what cause doth the Iewes preted?
column8: & not necessary But what cause does the Jews preted?

column7: to whome by this kyng, sure redemtion was promised? <NOTE>
column8: to whom by this King, sure redemption was promised?

column7: Here thou mayst perceyue the nature and custome of the flesh:
column8: Here thou Mayest perceive the nature and custom of the Flesh:

column7: such is oure strength and power.
column8: such is our strength and power.

column7: The fleshe canne dooe none otherwise, yt is subdued to synne, and bryngeth forth none other frute then synne, whether it bee outwardlye, as manifeste offences and crymes, or inwardlye, as be suche workes that seeme good, wherein the fleshe deliteth and flattereth himselfe.
column8: The Flesh can do none otherwise, that is subdued to sin, and bringeth forth none other fruit then sin, whither it be outwardly, as manifest offences and crimes, or inwardly, as be such works that seem good, wherein the Flesh delighteth and Flattereth himself.

column7: And alwayes suche thinges as it shulde loue, it hateth, and those thinges that be to be hated, yt loueth.
column8: And always such things as it should love, it hates, and those things that be to be hated, that loves.

column7: And in thinges concernyng Gods honour and our saluacio, it alwaies foloweth the cotrary.
column8: And in things Concerning God's honour and our saluacio, it always Followeth the contrary.

column7: And therfore it is necessary yt the flesh and nature be renewed in vs, through the holy ghost,
column8: And Therefore it is necessary that the Flesh and nature be renewed in us, through the holy ghost,

Luke therfore hath set forth these thiges so goodly & that for our eruditio and cofort, to teach vs, first ye Christ came ito this world to teach And although ye at such time as he bega first to dispute, he had not yet take ye office of preachig (which before he was 30. yers of age happened not) yet he wold in his so doing signify vnto vs, what his office & ministery shuld be,
column8: S. Lycia Therefore hath Set forth these thiges so goodly & that for our Eruditio and Comfort, to teach us, First the christ Come Ito this world to teach And although you At such time as he began First to dispute, he had not yet take you office of preachig (which before he was 30. Years of age happened not) yet he would in his so doing signify unto us, what his office & Ministry should be,

column8: And in that he taught us, that like as he took the nature of man upon him, and was made man (and that for our sakes) so in age, Wisdom and grace, he daily increased more and more, and After the manner of other children was brought up under his Parents,

column7: Thou wilt not beleue how nedful & necessary thing it is to instruct children, and bring them well vp in theyre youth, yea and if the thinge had ben of small estimacion, thinkest thou that God wold so ernestly haue comaunded the Iewes, to bring vp their children in the feare of God?
column8: Thou wilt not believe how needful & necessary thing it is to instruct children, and bring them well up in their youth, yea and if the thing had been of small estimation, Thinkest thou that God would so earnestly have commanded the Jews, to bring up their children in the Fear of God?

column8: That that the preacher is in the pulpit, is every householder in his house.

column8: And like as a preacher shall give accompt At the laste day of all his flock, so shalt thou give accompt for thy wife, children, and household to the high judge.

column8: And this was not the First sorrow, for she had proved before what sorrow was, when she was feign (Because of Herod cruelty) to flee into Egypt.

column8: And how is it that I have thus lost him?

column8: And Peradventure God now will not let me any longer take charge of him:

column7: <NOTE> These be ye greate weighty temptacios, that God suffereth his electe sometime to fall in, leste they shulde glory in them selfe, and not learne to knowe, that al perseueraunce and continuauce in faith and vertu, cometh of hym. <NOTE> And Mary findeth comfort no where, but in the temple, where she founde her sonne, not ydel, but hauing the word of God before hym.
column8: These be you great weighty temptacios, that God suffers his elect sometime to fallen in, lest they should glory in them self, and not Learn to know, that all perseverance and Continuance in faith and virtue, comes of him. And Mary finds Comfort no where, but in the temple, where she found her son, not idle, but having the word of God before him.

column7: And shee receiueth no comfort with her kinesfolkes and frendes, nor in the citie of Ierusalem, but in the temple So likewise we, as often as we fall into tribulacio yea into such depe temptacions, that no man vnder standeth, but he that by experience hath lerned, we shulde seeke for helpe and comforte no where, but with Christ, which neuer offereth hiselfe to be seene but in the temple, that is, in his word, althogh that oftentimes, for a while he wilbe hid from our eyes.
column8: And she receiveth no Comfort with her kinesfolkes and Friends, nor in the City of Jerusalem, but in the temple So likewise we, as often as we fallen into Tribulation yea into such deep temptations, that no man under Stands, but he that by experience hath learned, we should seek for help and Comfort no where, but with christ, which never Offereth hiselfe to be seen but in the temple, that is, in his word, although that oftentimes, for a while he will hid from our eyes.

column8: Believe allonlye and despair not,

column8: Forthly, we Learn Here the Obedience of children toward their Parents:

column7: For although Christ saide to his mother, that he must be busied in his fathers busines, yet he submitted himselfe, when he hadde done his fathers busines, and went home with his parentes.
column8: For although christ said to his mother, that he must be busied in his Father's business, yet he submitted himself, when he had done his Father's business, and went home with his Parents.

column7: Here do we lerne not onlye, that obedience shuld be gyuen to our parentes, but howe and in what manner, and howe longe also it shulde bee geuen.
column8: Here do we Learn not only, that Obedience should be given to our Parents, but how and in what manner, and how long also it should be given.

column7: As longe as thy parentes be no hinderauce to thi faith in Christ, but studieth to set the forward therein, and agreeth therein with the, then in no wise must thou deny thy dyligente attendaunce toward them.
column8: As long as thy Parents be no hindrance to thy faith in christ, but studieth to Set the forward therein, and agreeth therein with thee, then in no wise must thou deny thy dyligente attendance towards them.

column7: Thou hast besydes this for an example the commaundement of God:
column8: Thou hast besides this for an Exampl the Commandment of God:

column7: And to this commaundement is added a promise, which none of the other hath.
column8: And to this Commandment is added a promise, which none of the other hath.

column7: Wherby it appeareth, that it is greatly required, that this commaundement be obserued.
column8: Whereby it appears, that it is greatly required, that this Commandment be observed.

column7: But if thy parentes will cal the from thy faith in Christ, to olde abuses and mens tradicions, then know thou, that obedience is no longer to be geue to them, in as much as pertayneth to religion, but we must folowe the saiyng of Christ:
column8: But if thy Parents will call thee from thy faith in christ, to old Abuses and men's traditions, then know thou, that Obedience is no longer to be give to them, in as much as pertaineth to Religion, but we must follow the saying of christ:

column7: Wherefore we maye here learne, that seinge God himselfe did ordaine matrimony, and by Christe dydde so noblye sette it forthe, that trewly there is nothinge vnder this crosse, but the very grace and mercye of God.
column8: Wherefore we may Here Learn, that sing God himself did ordain matrimony, and by Christ did so nobly Set it forth, that truly there is nothing under this cross, but the very grace and mercy of God.

column7: And if therefore vnder this crosse, and carkes, and laboures of this lyfe, is hidden so greate grace of almighty God, no man shuld be afrayd or abasshed of that state of lyfe, what bruntes or sorows so euer he shal think to abyde, but rather shall by all meanes geue his dilygence, that in this crosse or sorowe,

column7: Wherin is meete, that yf the bodelye helthe bee occasion to dooe those thinges that bee repugnant to the wyll of God, that then hee hadde leuer styll to continew in hys sycke and diseased body and to haue the fauoure and grace of God, then to be whole & lusty of body, and fal into the wrath of God.
column8: Wherein is meet, that if the bodily health be occasion to do those things that be repugnant to the will of God, that then he had lever still to continue in his sick and diseased body and to have the favour and grace of God, then to be Whole & lusty of body, and fall into the wrath of God.

column8: And if sometime he seem to tarry longer then thou art able to abide, or that to thy reason he seem heavy in sleep, and to have vterly forgotten thee, yet let not thy mind fallen or despair, but cry to him wythe the Apostles, or Else with David, and say:

column7: & such other like, but when we se the crosse euen at hande, when we shuld then striue and wag battayle with sinne, death, the deuel and hel, then be we very could and cowardes and vnprofitable, and then dooe we with the deede perceaue, that we neuer had trew faith, nor euer were sincerely in our myndes affectionat towards the gospell.
column8: & such other like, but when we see the cross even At hand, when we should then strive and wag battle with sin, death, the Devil and hell, then be we very could and cowards and unprofitable, and then do we with the deed perceive, that we never had true faith, nor ever were sincerely in our minds affectionate towards the gospel.

column7: Now they that in the crosse, in persecution, in tribulacio and in peril will so soone flee from Christ and deny him, and will not suffre so small ieoperdye or perill for his sake if neede were, and so continew alwaies in the same, they neuer had one crome of sincere & trewe faith, but rather a shadow or vysard of faith.
column8: Now they that in the cross, in persecution, in Tribulation and in peril will so soon flee from christ and deny him, and will not suffer so small ieoperdye or peril for his sake if need were, and so continue always in the same, they never had one crome of sincere & true faith, but rather a shadow or vysard of faith.

column7: Therefore they shal say in the latter day when God shall saye:
column8: Therefore they shall say in the latter day when God shall say:

column7: <NOTE> Get ye hence from me ye wicked and cursed into the euerlasting fyer.
column8: Get you hence from me you wicked and cursed into the everlasting fire.

column7: But they that in their owne conscience knowledge, that they do nothinge of their own strength before god, and confesse their infirmitie, nor do seeke or looke for constancye and perseuerance in the crosse and persecutio any other wayes, then of god through Christ, they shall neuer be separated from Christe.
column8: But they that in their own conscience knowledge, that they do nothing of their own strength before god, and confess their infirmity, nor do seek or look for constancy and perseverance in the cross and Persecution any other ways, then of god through christ, they shall never be separated from Christ.

column7: And although their fayth hath beene many tymes feeble in the tyme of the crosse and persecution, yet haue they not alltogether fallen into despiracion, but hath asked pacience and peseueraunce of god.
column8: And although their faith hath been many times feeble in the time of the cross and persecution, yet have they not altogether fallen into despiracion, but hath asked patience and peseueraunce of god.

column7: And so therby thorough the helpe of Christ, and the vertu of the holy ghost, they haue ouercome all their temptacios So likewise did the Appostels, when they were wt Christ in the ship for when their faith was so weak that they weare not able to striue with temptacion in ye very point of death, they then wakened Christ, and called vpon him for his helpe, of whom also in their suche necessitie, they had no small comforte.
column8: And so thereby through the help of christ, and the virtue of the holy ghost, they have overcome all their temptacios So likewise did the Apostles, when they were with christ in the ship for when their faith was so weak that they wear not able to strive with temptation in you very point of death, they then wakened christ, and called upon him for his help, of whom also in their such necessity, they had no small Comfort.

column7: Wherfore I haue tolde you, that it is as necessary for faith to be proued by the crosse, persecution, and all kindes of trowble, as syluer to be tried & pourged with fier.
column8: Wherefore I have told you, that it is as necessary for faith to be proved by the cross, persecution, and all Kinds of trouble, as silver to be tried & purged with fire.

column7: For yf she continewe & abide stedfast in persecutio, then is she a right faith and not fayned,

column7: <NOTE> Fourthly, this gospell comforteth vs, in that, that christ dyd so meekly suffre the infirmity of his disciples, and dyd not by and by reiecte them from him, althoughe theire faith were not yet perfecte.

column7: Now yf Christ then so pacientlye suffered his disciples, when they were weake, and did not repel them for theyr infirmity, vntyl they were made more stedfast and stronger, suerly he wyll also suffre our imbecilitie and febelnes, and will tourne it into the strength of faith,
column8: Now if christ then so patiently suffered his Disciples, when they were weak, and did not repel them for their infirmity, until they were made more steadfast and Stronger, surely he will also suffer our imbecility and febelnes, and will turn it into the strength of faith,

column8: THis THis gospel does chiefli commend and extol you grace & mercy of God, by you which he calls a sinner, and makes him just and good, in that, that the householder gave like reward to them that Come laste into his vineyard, as to thee that Come First:

column7: wherthrough is taken away al presumption of the that putteth trust in their workes, seing that reward is not distributed accordig to ye merite, but according to yt wil & pleasure of ye housholder.

column8: Then if he owe ought to no man, and yet so plenteously does distribute the treasure of his grace, trewli there is no cause, whi I should discorag in my mind, or despair, although I were the greatest sinner under the son. for Therefore Come christ, that he would save Sinners.

column8: And again, to them that be ordained to life, that is a very healtful Doctrine, and full of Comfort They as soon as they hear that those be only saved that be predestinate of God, they meken and submit them self, they despair of them self, they call for grace & mercy,

column8: And although this calling pertaineth unto many, yet sometime it Faileth, and all that be called, Abideth not, not that any lack should be in you word, whereby we be called, but that we so greatly give to our ill affections & Lustiest, be not draw inwardly by you holy ghost,

column7: And in this, we miserable sinners haue one speciall thing and prerogatiue, before those great high & holy men, that when we do good workes, we haue no respect thereto, nor do them for that cause, that therefore we may aske heauen of God, as dewe dette to vs, but wee beleue in hym that maketh the sinner righteous, and oure fayth is imputed to vs to iustificacion.
column8: And in this, we miserable Sinners have one special thing and prerogative, before those great high & holy men, that when we do good works, we have no respect thereto, nor do them for that cause, that Therefore we may ask heaven of God, as dew debt to us, but we believe in him that makes the sinner righteous, and our faith is imputed to us to justification.

column7: <NOTE> And forbicause the iustifiers do aske their rewarde as dette and couenaunt, and not of grace, therefore yt happeneth to them, that they be made of the firste, the laste:
column8: And For because the Justifiers do ask their reward as debt and Covenant, and not of grace, Therefore that Happeneth to them, that they be made of the First, the laste:

column7: Nor yet shal they leaue or forsake their pride so grafte in them, which alwaies foloweth them, but alwaies they shall iudge and condemne, and often tymes haue in theire mouthes, and call here tyckes, heretickes, vntil they them selues be condemned.
column8: Nor yet shall they leave or forsake their pride so graft in them, which always Followeth them, but always they shall judge and condemn, and often times have in their mouths, and call Here tyckes, Heretics, until they them selves be condemned.

column7: Those that are beside the waye, are they that heare, then cometh the deuell, and taketh away the word out of theyr hartes, lest they shuld beleue and bee saued.
column8: Those that Are beside the Way, Are they that hear, then comes the Devil, and Takes away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved.

column7: They on the stones are they, which when they heare, receiue the worde with ioye, and these haue no rootes, which for a while beleue, and in tyme of temptacion go awaye.
column8: They on the stones Are they, which when they hear, receive the word with joy, and these have no roots, which for a while believe, and in time of temptation go away.

column7: And that which fell amonge thornes, are they, which when they haue herde, go forthe, and are choked wyth cares and ryches, and voluptuous lyuing, and bring forth no frute.
column8: And that which fell among thorns, Are they, which when they have herd, go forth, and Are choked with Cares and riches, and voluptuous living, and bring forth no fruit.

column7: That which fell in the good ground, are they which with apure and good herte, hear the worde, and kepe it, and bring forth frute through pacience. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: That which fell in the good ground, Are they which with apure and good heart, hear the word, and keep it, and bring forth fruit through patience. THE EXPOSITION.

column8: For as S. Paul Witnesseth in the third cham. of his First Epistle. to you Cor:

column8: Plant we may, & water may as well as we can, but you increase comes of no ma but of God.

column7: And yt we may learn, how god bi ye outward preaching of his word, doth also inwardly through the holye ghoste worke in oure hartes, there ar fower kides of herers laied here before vs.
column8: And that we may Learn, how god by you outward preaching of his word, does also inwardly through the holy ghost work in our hearts, there Are fower kides of hearers laid Here before us

column7: Fyrste of all, Christe speaketh of the seede that fel by the waies syde, and was trodden vnder foot, and the foules of the aier eate it vp.
column8: First of all, Christ speaks of the seed that fell by the ways side, and was trodden under foot, and the fowls of the air eat it up.

column7: And he calleth the seed, the worde of God, and the byrdes he calleth the deuel, which by innumerable means pluck and rote vp the word of God, out of menes hartes.
column8: And he calls the seed, the word of God, and the Birds he calls the Devil, which by innumerable means pluck and rote up the word of God, out of menes hearts.

column7: And he speaketh as though he shulde saye on this wise:
column8: And he speaks as though he should say on this wise:

column7: <NOTE> Many there be that hear the gospel,
column8: Many there be that hear the gospel,

column7: & wyll in any wise be called christian men,
column8: & will in any wise be called christian men,

column7: & moreouer they vse the sacraments & liberty of a christian ma, but trewly they shal obtain of me nothing els, but the vayne name that they so greatly glory in.
column8: & moreover they use the Sacraments & liberty of a christian ma, but truly they shall obtain of me nothing Else, but the vain name that they so greatly glory in.

column7: And out wardly they shew a certaine grauiti and face of holynes, but inwardely they be filled with al malice.
column8: And out wardly they show a certain grauiti and face of holiness, but inwardly they be filled with all malice.

column7: And why so? Bicause they haue receyued the word of God vnder a pretext, as it were vnder a shadow or visarde, it neuer descended into theyre hartes, neither were they kindeled any thinge therewith, whereby a man myghte perceiue it to haue been any thing liuely or effectual in them.
column8: And why so? Because they have received the word of God under a pretext, as it were under a shadow or vizard, it never descended into their hearts, neither were they kindled any thing therewith, whereby a man might perceive it to have been any thing lively or effectual in them.

column7: There haue entred in false doctours and secte maisters, which thorow their deceitful exposition of scripture, haue suppressed and troden vnder foot the good seede of the word of God.
column8: There have entered in false Doctors and sect masters, which thorough their deceitful exposition of scripture, have suppressed and trodden under foot the good seed of the word of God.

column7: <NOTE> Of whom the prophet Ieremy saith:
column8: Of whom the Prophet Jeremiah Says:

column7: That they shall speak their lyes in the name of the lorde. <NOTE> And S. Paule called the doctrine of those men, idle speach.
column8: That they shall speak their lies in the name of the lord. And S. Paul called the Doctrine of those men, idle speech.

column7: They haue adioyned themselues to suche doctoures, forsaking the fountayne of the water of lyfe, and folowe with all desire, and couet to drinke the troubled and muddye water infected with mans tradicions and hereticall lerning.
column8: They have adjoined themselves to such Doctors, forsaking the fountain of the water of life, and follow with all desire, and covet to drink the troubled and muddy water infected with men traditions and heretical learning.

column7: And afterward cometh in the deuell which is signified by the byrdes.
column8: And afterwards comes in the Devil which is signified by the Birds.

column7: And bicause his ministers the false techers haue wt their false preachig prepared to hi his waies, he goeth forth & entreth priuily ito their hartis, so that thei beig brought fro ye trew doctrine of Christ, shall both body & soule run into ye snares of ye deuel.
column8: And Because his Ministers the false Teachers have with their false preachig prepared to him his ways, he Goes forth & entereth privily Ito their hearts, so that they beig brought from you true Doctrine of christ, shall both body & soul run into you snares of you Devil.

column7: And those deceits & snares,
column8: And those Deceits & snares,

column7: <NOTE> be ye very deuel of yt none tyde, that ye 90 psal. speaketh of:
column8: be you very Devil of that none tIED, that you 90 Psalm. speaks of:

column7: And now forasmuch as we haue perfect knowledg, yt the deuel layeth netis & snares for vs, as wel by his false prophets, which by ye peruerse expositio of scripture go about to deceiue vs:
column8: And now forasmuch as we have perfect knowledge, that the Devil Layeth netis & snares for us, as well by his false Prophets, which by you perverse Exposition of scripture go about to deceive us:

column7: As also by his owne gyles and inspiracios, yt shalbe very necessary, that we so establish our lyues, yt by no meanes we be brought fro the trew & simple doctrine of Christ.
column8: As also by his own gyles and inspiracios, that shall very necessary, that we so establish our lives, that by no means we be brought from the true & simple Doctrine of christ.

column7: For as sone as we begin to despise and set litle by that word of god, that is shewed vnto vs by Christ:
column8: For as soon as we begin to despise and Set little by that word of god, that is showed unto us by christ:

column7: <NOTE> The by & by wt great violence we run into the snares & gynnes of the deuell.
column8: The by & by with great violence we run into the snares & gynnes of the Devil.

column7: And if we stedfastly beleue in ye worde of god:
column8: And if we steadfastly believe in you word of god:

column7: Then neither false prophet, nother ye deuell himselfe shal deceiue vs.
column8: Then neither false Prophet, neither you Devil himself shall deceive us

column7: And the wtout dout he is greater yt is in vs, then he yt is in the world. 1. Io. 4
column8: And thee without doubt he is greater that is in us, then he that is in the world. 1. Io. 4

column7: Secondarylye, Christe speaketh of the seede that fell vpon the stone, which although it sprange vp, yet bicause it lacked moysture, it withered awaye.
column8: Secondarily, Christ speaks of the seed that fell upon the stone, which although it sprang up, yet Because it lacked moisture, it withered away.

column7: And so he declareth, that the seed that fel on ye stone be thei, that when they hear the word of God, they receiue it wt ioy,
column8: And so he Declareth, that the seed that fell on you stone be they, that when they hear the word of God, they receive it with joy,

column7: <NOTE> but thei haue no rotes bicause thei beleue but for a while,
column8: but they have no rotes Because they believe but for a while,

column7: & in tyme of temptacion and tribulacion they fall cleane away.
column8: & in time of temptation and tribulation they fallen clean away.

column7: Wherin Christe sheweth that his gospell shall neuer bee preached withoute aduersaries, that shall striue againste it.
column8: Wherein Christ shows that his gospel shall never be preached without Adversaries, that shall strive against it.

column7: And lykewise, that the perfect and trew faith cannot be knowen, but by tribulacion and temptacious, so proued and tried, as gold and siluer is by fier.
column8: And likewise, that the perfect and true faith cannot be known, but by tribulation and temptacious, so proved and tried, as gold and silver is by fire.

column7: Yf thou wylt then search & know, what faith I haue, and whether it be a trew or a fayned faith, mark wel & behold my lyfe, when I chaunce to fal into temptacion & tribulacion.
column8: If thou wilt then search & know, what faith I have, and whither it be a true or a feigned faith, mark well & behold my life, when I chance to fall into temptation & tribulation.

column7: And yf then it be a pure and righte fayth, and by the worde of god in my harte made liuelye and effectuall, then muste I needes saye with sainct Paule:
column8: And if then it be a pure and right faith, and by the word of god in my heart made lively and effectual, then must I needs say with saint Paul:

column7: <NOTE> I am sure, that nother death, nor lyfe, nor aungell, nor rule or power, nother things present, or thinges to come, nother high, nor low, nor any maner of creature, shal seperate me from the loue of god, that is in Iesu Christ.
column8: I am sure, that neither death, nor life, nor angel, nor Rule or power, neither things present, or things to come, neither high, nor low, nor any manner of creature, shall separate me from the love of god, that is in Jesu christ.

column7: Yea and I will frely confesse, commend & preach the word of god, though I shuld dye an hundreth tymes,
column8: Yea and I will freely confess, commend & preach the word of god, though I should die an Hundredth times,

column7: <NOTE> or forsake all that euer I haue had in this world.
column8: or forsake all that ever I have had in this world.

column7: For it must needes be in such case, that other I forsake all and bere the crosse of Christ, or else cease to be his disciple any lenger.
column8: For it must needs be in such case, that other I forsake all and bear the cross of christ, or Else cease to be his disciple any longer.

column7: And in contrary wise, when my fayth is not pure, but fayned, trewly the wyl I not so hate my selfe, yt for the gospels sake I shuld ronne into daunger of my bodye and lyfe.
column8: And in contrary wise, when my faith is not pure, but feigned, truly the will I not so hate my self, that for the gospels sake I should run into danger of my body and life.

column7: But then wyll I sette moste by, and loue my body, be it neuer so rotten and full of wormes.
column8: But then will I Set most by, and love my body, be it never so rotten and full of worms.

column7: Wherfore I am constrayned to heare Christ in an other place,
column8: Wherefore I am constrained to hear christ in an other place,

column7: <NOTE> saying: He that findeth his lyfe, shall lose it.
column8: saying: He that finds his life, shall loose it.

column7: <NOTE> Thyrdely, Christ speaketh of other seed, that fel amongest thornes, and so sprong vp, was choked amongest the thornes.
column8: Thirdly, christ speaks of other seed, that fell amongst thorns, and so sprung up, was choked amongst the thorns.

column7: And that he expoundeth on this wise.
column8: And that he expoundeth on this wise.

column7: The seed that fell amongest the thornes be they, that haue herd the worde of god, and then thorowgh the cares, ryches, and voluptuosnes, of this worlde, be so ouer growne and choked, that they can not bryng fourth frute.
column8: The seed that fell amongst the thorns be they, that have heard the word of god, and then thorowgh the Cares, riches, and voluptuousness, of this world, be so over grown and choked, that they can not bring fourth fruit.

column7: Thow herist here repeted, that suche heare the word of god:
column8: Thou herist Here repeated, that such hear the word of god:

column7: yf then thei heare the word and yet be reiected of Christ,
column8: if then they hear the word and yet be rejected of christ,

column7: I praye the, what is the cause, or what lettyth, whye they be not saued?
column8: I pray thee, what is the cause, or what lettyth, why they be not saved?

column7: verely euen that, be cause they receyued not the worde of god ernestly, and in theyre hartes:
column8: verily even that, be cause they received not the word of god earnestly, and in their hearts:

column7: and for that they be founde neglegente in fayth, loue, and honest conuersations, and fal from god the creatour vnto creatures.
column8: and for that they be found neglegente in faith, love, and honest conversations, and fall from god the creator unto creatures.

column7: Marke here, how finely Chryst hath paynted and set oute the mindes and harts of riche men:
column8: Mark Here, how finely Christ hath painted and Set out the minds and hearts of rich men:

column7: First of all he geueth vnto them cares, for we commonly se that the more they haue, the more the couet:
column8: First of all he Giveth unto them Cares, for we commonly see that the more they have, the more the covet:

column7: as it is said in the 5. cha.
column8: as it is said in the 5. cham.

column7: Ecclesiastes: The couetous man is neuer satisfied of money &c.
column8: Ecclesiastes: The covetous man is never satisfied of money etc.

column7: And he geueth also vnto the, the loue and affection of riches, and desyre of this worldly lyfe.
column8: And he Giveth also unto thee, the love and affection of riches, and desire of this worldly life.

column7: As though he shulde saye:
column8: As though he should say:

column7: To haue greate riches doth not damne a man:
column8: To have great riches does not damn a man:

column7: for there hath beene sins the beginning of the world, many deuout and holy men, that hath had greate riches, and yet neuerthelesse haue obtayned euerlasting lyfe.
column8: for there hath been Sins the beginning of the world, many devout and holy men, that hath had great riches, and yet nevertheless have obtained everlasting life.

column7: But to sette harte and minde in riches, and through them to seeke the pleasures of this lyfe,
column8: But to Set heart and mind in riches, and through them to seek the pleasures of this life,

column7: & not to knowe, that we be but seruauntes and stewardes of suche riches, to thentent, that the poore and nedye maye be holpen thereby, that is the very thing that condemneth a man.
column8: & not to know, that we be but Servants and Stewards of such riches, to thentent, that the poor and needy may be helped thereby, that is the very thing that Condemneth a man.

column7: Wherfore seing it is so with riche men for the more parte, that they with all theire diligence seeke and folow the pleasures of this lyfe, and do not mortefye the fleshe by the spirite, but passe ouer their lyfe in all securitie and wealthe of this world.
column8: Wherefore sing it is so with rich men for the more part, that they with all their diligence seek and follow the pleasures of this life, and do not mortefye the Flesh by the Spirit, but pass over their life in all security and wealth of this world.

column7: <NOTE> Christ sayeth also in an other place:
column8: christ Saith also in an other place:

column7: Soner may a camell runne thorow the eye of a nedle, then a riche man entre into heaue.
column8: Sooner may a camel run thorough the eye of a needle, then a rich man enter into heave.

column7: And to be briefe, Such rich men,
column8: And to be brief, Such rich men,

column7: <NOTE> and men that abuse their riches in this world, haue but smal prayse in scripture, and in many places we hear of their condemnacion, not bicause they haue much riches, or that they be men of great power and might, but for that they do abuse their such giftes, and take their lusts and pleasure in it, and do not make frends to them, of their wicked mammon.
column8: and men that abuse their riches in this world, have but small praise in scripture, and in many places we hear of their condemnation, not Because they have much riches, or that they be men of great power and might, but for that they do abuse their such Gifts, and take their Lustiest and pleasure in it, and do not make Friends to them, of their wicked mammon.

column7: Fourthly, Christ speaketh of the seede that fell in the good grounde, and sprang vp, and brought forth fruict an hundreth fold.
column8: Fourthly, christ speaks of the seed that fell in the good ground, and sprang up, and brought forth fruit an Hundredth fold.

column7: And that he declared on this wise:
column8: And that he declared on this wise:

column7: That that fell in the good ground, be thei which with good hert & mind,
column8: That that fell in the good ground, be they which with good heart & mind,

column7: <NOTE> do hear ye worde of god, and kepe the same, and bring forth fruict in pacience.
column8: do hear you word of god, and keep the same, and bring forth fruit in patience.

column7: And there be two thinges to be noted in that:
column8: And there be two things to be noted in that:

column7: <NOTE> First, that there be merueilous few christian me in this earth:
column8: First, that there be marvelous few christian me in this earth:

column7: But of them that in body & soule go to the deuel, ther is a great nomber, how highly soeuer they pretend ye name of christians, or boaste of ye gospell, as Christ doth witnes in the 7, chapt. of Mathew, saiyng:
column8: But of them that in body & soul go to the Devil, there is a great number, how highly soever they pretend you name of Christians, or boast of the gospel, as christ does witness in the 7, Chapter. of Matthew, saying:

column7: The gate is larg, and the way is broad that leadeth to perdition, and many there be that entreth into the same.
column8: The gate is large, and the Way is broad that leads to perdition, and many there be that entereth into the same.

column7: But the way that leadeth to lyfe is straite,
column8: But the Way that leads to life is strait,

column7: & the gate very narrow, and fewe haue found the same.
column8: & the gate very narrow, and few have found the same.

column7: And the other thinge yt Christ sheweth vs, is this:
column8: And the other thing that christ shows us, is this:

column7: that although the more parte of menne be euell, and so abyde, yet the word of god shal not be preached in vaine.
column8: that although the more part of men be evil, and so abide, yet the word of god shall not be preached in vain.

column7: In some corner there shalbe found good ground,
column8: In Some corner there shall found good ground,

column7: <NOTE> wherin the good seede of the word of god is, sowen, shal spring vp and bring forth frute plenteously, whereof god speaketh by his prophete Esaias in this wise:
column8: wherein the good seed of the word of god is, sown, shall spring up and bring forth fruit plenteously, whereof god speaks by his Prophet Isaiah in this wise:

column7: Lyke as the shoures of rayne and snow descendeth fro heauen, and retourneth not thither againe, but sinketh into the earth, and norisheth the same, and maketh it bring forth seede vnto the sower,
column8: Like as the showers of rain and snow Descendeth from heaven, and returneth not thither again, but sinks into the earth, and nourisheth the same, and makes it bring forth seed unto the sour,

column7: & bread to the eater, so shal the word that cometh out of my mouth, it shal not retourne vnto me empti, but shal do all that I wil,
column8: & bred to the eater, so shall the word that comes out of my Mouth, it shall not return unto me Empti, but shall do all that I will,

column7: & shall prosper whersoeuer I shal send it.
column8: & shall prosper wheresoever I shall send it.

column7: And although it seme, that ye gospel is preached in vaine, yet must we beleue that amongest so great a company of misbelieuers,
column8: And although it seem, that you gospel is preached in vain, yet must we believe that amongst so great a company of misbelieuers,

column7: God hath some elect, that gladly here his worde, and kepe the same, although (as we haue saide) the numbre of those be very small.
column8: God hath Some elect, that gladly Here his word, and keep the same, although (as we have said) the numbered of those be very small.

column7: The sonday called Quinquagesima. Luc. 18.
column8: The Sunday called Quinquagesima. Luke 18.

column7: I Esus toke vnto hym the twelue,
column8: IEsus IEsus took unto him the twelue,

column7: & sayd vnto them. <NOTE> Behold, we go vp to Ierusalem, and all shalbe fulfilled, that are written by the prophetes of the sonne of man.
column8: & said unto them. Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and all shall fulfilled, that Are written by the Prophets of the son of man.

column7: For he shalbe delyuered vnto the gentyls, and shalbe mocked, and despitefully intreated, and spitted on, and when they haue scourged hym, they wyll put hym to death, and the thyrd day he shal arise again.
column8: For he shall Delivered unto the Gentiles, and shall mocked, and despitefully entreated, and spitted on, and when they have scourged him, they will put him to death, and the Third day he shall arise again.

column7: And they vnderstode none of these thinges.
column8: And they understood none of these things.

column7: And this saying was hyd from them so, that they perceaued not the thinges which wer spoke.
column8: And this saying was hid from them so, that they perceived not the things which were spoke.

column7: <NOTE> And it came to passe, yt as he was come nighe vnto Hierico a certain blind man sate by ye way side begging.
column8: And it Come to pass, that as he was come High unto Jericho a certain blind man sat by you Way side begging.

column7: And when he herd the people passe by, he asked what it ment.
column8: And when he heard the people pass by, he asked what it meant.

column7: And they sayd vnto him yt Iesus of Nazareth passed vi.
column8: And they said unto him that jesus of Nazareth passed vi.

column7: And he cried, sayig.
column8: And he cried, sayig.

column7: Iesu, ye son of Dauid, haue merci on me.
column8: Jesu, you son of David, have merci on me.

column7: And they which wet before, rebuked him yt he shuld hold his peace.
column8: And they which wet before, rebuked him that he should hold his peace.

column7: But he cryed so much ye more <NOTE> thou son of Dauid haue merci on me.
column8: But he cried so much you more thou son of David have merci on me.

column7: And Iesus stode stil, & comauded hi to be brought vnto hi.
column8: And jesus stood still, & comauded him to be brought unto him.

column7: And whe he was cum neare, he asked him, saying What wilt thou that I do vnto the?
column8: And when he was cum near, he asked him, saying What wilt thou that I do unto thee?

column7: And he said: lorde, that I may receaue my syght.
column8: And he said: lord, that I may receive my sight.

column7: And Iesus saide vnto hym:
column8: And jesus said unto him:

column7: receaue thy sighte: thy fayth hath saued the.
column8: receive thy sight: thy faith hath saved thee.

column7: And immediatly he receaued hys syghte, and folowed him and praysed God.
column8: And immediately he received his sight, and followed him and praised God.

column7: And all the people when they sawe it, gaue prayse vnto God. THE EXPOSITION. <NOTE> IT is not without great cause, that Christ so often times did shew and speake to his disci-disciples of his passion and death that was to come, and that not onli in the gospel of this day, but also in diuerse other places.
column8: And all the people when they saw it, gave praise unto God. THE EXPOSITION. IT is not without great cause, that christ so often times did show and speak to his disci-disciples of his passion and death that was to come, and that not only in the gospel of this day, but also in diverse other places.

column7: And (to let passe the other euangelists) I pray you, how often times is it spoken of in the gospell of S.
column8: And (to let pass the other Evangelists) I pray you, how often times is it spoken of in the gospel of S.

column7: Iohn? Ouerlooke the same euangelist through out, from the beginning to the ende, and thou shalt finde, that the same faithful teacher Christ, with all diligence did instruct & strength his Apostels, against the slaunder of the crosse.
column8: John? Overlook the same evangelist through out, from the beginning to the end, and thou shalt find, that the same faithful teacher christ, with all diligence did instruct & strength his Apostles, against the slander of the cross.

column7: Wherefore we shulde considre the same, and marke wherfore Christe did it, and why he made so many wordes thereof to his disciples.
column8: Wherefore we should Consider the same, and mark Wherefore Christ did it, and why he made so many words thereof to his Disciples.

column7: First, yt is manifest & very plain, that our nature flesh (when it is not inlyghtened by the holy ghost) cannot abide stedfast in time of persecution:
column8: First, that is manifest & very plain, that our nature Flesh (when it is not inlyghtened by the holy ghost) cannot abide steadfast in time of persecution:

column7: <NOTE> for the fleshe loueth herselfe, and bitterly hateth persecution, and deliteth more in long and mery dayes, the to abide trouble and vexacion with a quiet mynd.
column8: for the Flesh loves herself, and bitterly hates persecution, and delighteth more in long and merry days, the to abide trouble and vexation with a quiet mind.

column7: As Nicodemus when he came in ye night to Christ for feare of the Iewes,
column8: As Nicodemus when he Come in you night to christ for Fear of the Jews,

column7: <NOTE> hard by and by of him these wordes:
column8: hard by and by of him these words:

column7: That that is borne of the fleshe, is fleshe.
column8: That that is born of the Flesh, is Flesh.

column7: And although the children of Zebedeus said:
column8: And although the children of Zebedee said:

column7: <NOTE> they coulde drinke of the cuppe that Christ shuld drink of.
column8: they could drink of the cup that christ should drink of.

column7: And Peter also might well say,
column8: And Peter also might well say,

column7: <NOTE> that he was readye euen to dye with Christ, yet without the holye ghost it is impossible, and is a highe presumption so to say.
column8: that he was ready even to die with christ, yet without the holy ghost it is impossible, and is a high presumption so to say.

column7: And seinge that oure Lorde Iesu Christe knew very well, the same frailenes of the fleshe, not only in his disciples, but in vs all, he vseth the office of a good and faithfull maister, and instructeth vs with the wholsome doctrine of the word of God againste persecution to come, that when it shulde come vppon vs, wee shulde be ready, and not dispaire.
column8: And sing that our Lord Jesu Christ knew very well, the same frailenes of the Flesh, not only in his Disciples, but in us all, he uses the office of a good and faithful master, and Instructeth us with the wholesome Doctrine of the word of God against persecution to come, that when it should come upon us, we should be ready, and not despair.

column7: As thoughe he shulde saye.
column8: As though he should say.

column7: I knowe verye well that yt is harde for a manne to stande styflye in persecution, and to suffer all aduersities wyth a pacient minde, but the prophecy muste needes bee fulfilled of me.
column8: I know very well that that is harden for a man to stand styflye in persecution, and to suffer all adversities with a patient mind, but the prophecy must needs be fulfilled of me.

column7: Doth not Zacharias say of me?
column8: Does not Zacharias say of me?

column7: <NOTE> I wyll stryke the shepeherde, and all the flocke shalbe sparsed abroad.
column8: I will strike the shepherd, and all the flock shall sparsed abroad.

column7: Wherfore now I shew you before, bycause it muste needes bee, that when so euer it shalbe done, you maye remember this, and not bee offended therewith, but rather beleue that it is my fathers wyll in heauen, which will delyuer you through my death, from sinne, death, the diuel, and hell.
column8: Wherefore now I show you before, Because it must needs be, that when so ever it shall done, you may Remember this, and not be offended therewith, but rather believe that it is my Father's will in heaven, which will deliver you through my death, from sin, death, the Devil, and hell.

column7: And although I shal dye the vylest death, yet wyll I rise the third day, and comforte you.
column8: And although I shall die the Vilest death, yet will I rise the third day, and Comfort you.

column7: Thou seyste here, how Christe comforteth his Apostelles, whereby, they may learne to haue respecte only to the good wyll of god in all tribulacions. <NOTE> And this was not only done for the apostels sake, but for vs also to learne, and folowe the same.
column8: Thou seyste Here, how Christ comforts his Apostles, whereby, they may Learn to have respect only to the good will of god in all tribulations. And this was not only done for the Apostles sake, but for us also to Learn, and follow the same.

column7: In persecution and tribulacion we may not think, that the wicked be as fierse in crueltye towarde vs, as the Iewes were in persecuting Christ euen to very death, but we muste looke to the good and mercyfull wyll of God the father, whose will is, that we for his sake shuld be dispised,
column8: In persecution and tribulation we may not think, that the wicked be as fierce in cruelty toward us, as the Jews were in persecuting christ even to very death, but we must look to the good and merciful will of God the father, whose will is, that we for his sake should be despised,

column7: & suffre persecution in this world.
column8: & suffer persecution in this world.

column7: F Irste of all, in this gospell is shewed vnto vs,
column8: First First of all, in this gospel is showed unto us,

column7: <NOTE> Thou shalte learne thereby that god of his good wyl, sendeth al temptacion to his elect that they may in time of temptacion know, wherof they neede, and with great constancy aske of god, both helpe and comforte.
column8: Thou shalt Learn thereby that god of his good will, sends all temptation to his elect that they may in time of temptation know, whereof they need, and with great constancy ask of god, both help and Comfort.

column8: as the Prophet Saith: When I was troubled, then I cried to the Lord, and he herd me.

column8: And again, when thou Hearst, how mightily christ overcame the Devil, and how with scripture he overthrew his subtle and malicious counsel, thou shalt Remember to Learn, that no temptacio may be overcome, but by christ.

column8: And what claim or right could that enemy make to me, if I had none other weapon in time of temptation to defend me withal, but this only sentence of scripture, conceived through faith?

column8: Have good hope & trust, for I have overcome the world.

column8: If thou be the son of God,

column8: Tarry a while, until a roasted chicken fly in to thy Mouth.

column7: And by this meanes goeth the deuell about to bringe Christe from the cofidece & trust in God, and to burthe him with incredulity and vayne carefulnes, that yet he might so moue him to forsake God, and make of his belly an idol: <NOTE> But what doth Christ? He geueth no place at al to these diabolical instructions, but strongely doth perseuer in that faith and truste, which he receiued of his heuenly father, and saith.
column8: And by this means Goes the Devil about to bring Christ from the cofidece & trust in God, and to burden him with incredulity and vain carefulness, that yet he might so move him to forsake God, and make of his belly an idol: But what does christ? He Giveth no place At all to these diabolical instructions, but strongly does persever in that faith and trust, which he received of his heavenly father, and Says.

column7: Man liueth not only by bread, but by the worde that procedeth from the mouth of God.
column8: Man lives not only by bred, but by the word that Proceedeth from the Mouth of God.

column7: As though he shuld saye:
column8: As though he should say:

column7: I know very wel, that when ther is plenty of bread the lyfe muste be susteined thereby:
column8: I know very well, that when there is plenty of bred the life must be sustained thereby:

column7: But that is not bicause of the bread, but for the word of God, wher by the bread is sactified, and power geuen to it, to feede and replenish men.
column8: But that is not Because of the bred, but for the word of God, where by the bred is sanctified, and power given to it, to feed and replenish men.

column7: And yf there be no plenty of bread, then must we needes lyue by the word of God, yf then faith do wholye depend and hange of this worde, and be wrapped therin, then must ther nedes be also bread, yea, and the same muste come from heauen, as in the olde tyme Manna was geuen to the children of Israel in wildernes.
column8: And if there be no plenty of bred, then must we needs live by the word of God, if then faith do wholly depend and hang of this word, and be wrapped therein, then must there needs be also bred, yea, and the same must come from heaven, as in the old time Manna was given to the children of Israel in Wilderness.

column7: <NOTE> Lo now in this wise doth Christ ouercome the deuell, and that for oure comforte, that we shulde applye oure selues, and prouide, (as often as we fall into suche temptacios) that incredulitie raigne not amongst vs, but to remembre the exaumple of Christ, confirmed with so many promises of god, wherethrough we may withstand the carefulnes of the belly,
column8: Lo now in this wise does christ overcome the Devil, and that for our Comfort, that we should apply our selves, and provide, (as often as we fallen into such temptacios) that incredulity Reign not among us, but to Remember the Exampl of christ, confirmed with so many promises of god, wherethrough we may withstand the carefulness of the belly,

column7: And to bring that to passe, he allegeth (although it bee falsely) a place of scripture, assayig yet by that meanes, if he might with his outward appearaunce,

column8: & under such a Lambs skin, overcome christ, and move him to do contrary to the word of god.

column7: And note well here, that the deuell hath mo wayes then one to circumuente and begile menne, and as he is craftye and subtyll a thousande folde, so hath he a thousande wayes, to bringe men in his snares.
column8: And note well Here, that the Devil hath more ways then one to circumuente and beguile men, and as he is crafty and subtle a thousande fold, so hath he a thousande ways, to bring men in his snares.
