column8: He Knoweth well enough, wherein we be most Weakest, and if he bring not his purpose to pass one Way, he assayeth an other.

column7: He taketh great delite & pleasure in oure destruction and codemnacion.
column8: He Takes great delight & pleasure in our destruction and codemnacion.

column7: And by cause he coulde not bringe Christ to that poynte, to make his belly a god, he yet hadde greate hope to bringe that his other porpose to passe, to moue him to tempte God, and so set hym vp vppon a pinnacle of the temple layng:
column8: And by cause he could not bring christ to that point, to make his belly a god, he yet had great hope to bring that his other porpose to pass, to move him to tempt God, and so Set him up upon a pinnacle of the temple long:

column7: If thou be the son of God cast downe thy selfe hedlinge:
column8: If thou be the son of God cast down thy self hedlinge:

column7: for it is wrytten. <NOTE> He shall giue his angels charge ouer the, and with there handes shal they hold the vp, that thou dashe not thy foote against a stone.
column8: for it is written. He shall give his Angels charge over thee, and with there hands shall they hold thee up, that thou dash not thy foot against a stone.

column7: But wherfore did the deuel leue out,
column8: But Wherefore did the Devil leave out,

column7: Vt custodiat te in omnibus vijs tuis?
column8: Vt custodiat te in omnibus vijs tuis?

column7: that is to say: That they shal kepe the in all thy wayes?
column8: that is to say: That they shall keep thee in all thy ways?

column7: Bicause it was contrary to his purpose, and made nothig for his intent.
column8: Because it was contrary to his purpose, and made nothing for his intent.

column7: Whervpon Christ obiecteth against him this answere,
column8: Whereupon christ Objecteth against him this answer,

column7: <NOTE> saying: It is also writte.
column8: saying: It is also written.

column7: Thou shalt not tempt thi Lord god:
column8: Thou shalt not tempt thy Lord god:

column7: As though he shuld say:
column8: As though he should say:

column7: God doth mightely defend his,
column8: God does mightily defend his,

column7: & will not leaue them in any necessity.
column8: & will not leave them in any necessity.

column7: And moreouer (as thou thy selfe doest knowledg) he hath geuen in comaundemet to his augels, to take the charge, not only of me, but also of all his elect, that they maye walke without any offence or slaunder.
column8: And moreover (as thou thy self dost knowledge) he hath given in comaundemet to his Angels, to take the charge, not only of me, but also of all his elect, that they may walk without any offence or slander.

column7: Wherefore shuld I cast my selfe into the water, when I maye passe by a bridge or ship?
column8: Wherefore should I cast my self into the water, when I may pass by a bridge or ship?

column7: And so. why shuld I cast my selfe downe hedlig from the temple, whe I may easlye go downe by a ladder?
column8: And so. why should I cast my self down hedlig from the temple, when I may Easily go down by a ladder?

column7: The wise man saith: He that loueth ieoperdye,
column8: The wise man Says: He that loves ieoperdye,

column7: <NOTE> shall fall into the same.
column8: shall fallen into the same.

column7: Lo here now again the diuel is ouercome bi Christ and that with no small argumentes of scripture, wherwith he doth confute him.
column8: Lo Here now again the Devil is overcome by christ and that with no small Arguments of scripture, wherewith he does confute him.

column7: Let vs now knowe and perceiue, that all these thinges be done for our instruction, that we may learne likewise, to ouercome the deuell, when neede shall require.
column8: Let us now know and perceive, that all these things be done for our instruction, that we may Learn likewise, to overcome the Devil, when need shall require.

column7: Thirdelye, the dyuell is not yet contented, nor leaueth of Christ, but taketh him vp, vpon a great high hyll, and sheweth to hym all the kingedomes and glory of the wolde, saying:
column8: Thirdly, the Devil is not yet contented, nor Leaveth of christ, but Takes him up, upon a great high hill, and shows to him all the kingdoms and glory of thee would, saying:

column7: All these thinges will I geue vn to the, yf thou wylt fall downe and worshippe me. <NOTE> And of this place we learne, that the deuell is the Lorde and Prince of this worlde, as Christ also nameth him in the 12. chapter of Iohn.
column8: All these things will I give vn to thee, if thou wilt fallen down and worship me. And of this place we Learn, that the Devil is the Lord and Prince of this world, as christ also names him in the 12. chapter of John.

column7: Moreouer all those that so depende and hange of wordly and transitorye thinges, that they sette by nothinge els, nor bee mortyfied to the worlde and their concupiscence, do in no wise appertain to the kyngedome of Christe, but to the kingdome of the diuel.
column8: Moreover all those that so depend and hang of wordly and transitory things, that they Set by nothing Else, nor be mortyfied to the world and their concupiscence, do in no wise appertain to the Kingdom of Christ, but to the Kingdom of the Devil.

column7: For what so euer it be yt I put my hole truste in, besides god, or do prefer and loue it more then god, verely of the same I make to me an ydol.
column8: For what so ever it be that I put my hold trust in, beside god, or do prefer and love it more then god, verily of the same I make to me an idol.

column7: And yf my harte be fully fixed vnto yt,
column8: And if my heart be Fully fixed unto that,

column7: <NOTE> and is giuen to honour, voluptuousnes, riches, power of the world or any such other like thing, then be those thinges my ydoll, and in them I worship the deuell.
column8: and is given to honour, voluptuousness, riches, power of the world or any such other like thing, then be those things my idol, and in them I worship the Devil.

column7: Yea & to be more plaine with you, yf I outwardly shuld be good and honest, and wolde accompte the same outewarde goodnes for righteousnesse before god, then trewly shulde the same be myne Idoll, as Esaias witnesseth, sayinge:
column8: Yea & to be more plain with you, if I outwardly should be good and honest, and would accompt the same outward Goodness for righteousness before god, then truly should the same be mine Idol, as Isaiah Witnesseth, saying:

column7: <NOTE> They haue woshipped the workes of their owne handes.
column8: They have woshipped the works of their own hands.

column7: And saynte Augustine saieth: My God is my loue.
column8: And faint Augustine Saith: My God is my love.

column7: I praye you what is it els to loue creatures aboue god, then to worship the deuell?
column8: I pray you what is it Else to love creatures above god, then to worship the Devil?

column7: But herken here now greately this ydolatry and blasphemy displeaseth god.
column8: But harken Here now greatly this idolatry and blasphemy displeaseth god.

column7: Get the hence (saieth he) thou Sathan, these thy suggestions can not be borne or suffered of any good hart, for it is written:
column8: Get thee hence (Saith he) thou Sathan, these thy suggestions can not be born or suffered of any good heart, for it is written:

column7: <NOTE> Thou shalte worship thy lord god, and him onlye shalte thou serue.
column8: Thou shalt worship thy lord god, and him only shalt thou serve.

column7: Lo, in this wyse is the deuell no we thryse ouercome, and driuen awaye of Christe, onlye by the worde of god.
column8: Lo, in this wise is the Devil no we thrice overcome, and driven away of Christ, only by the word of god.

column7: Nowe as it is necessary for vs, throughe Christe to ouercome all temptacions, the worlde, synne, death, and the deuell, so muste we also be wel instructed & stregthned with ye word of god, wherein is promised to vs, both comforte and helpe, in our Lord Iesu Christe.
column8: Now as it is necessary for us, through Christ to overcome all temptations, the world, sin, death, and the Devil, so must we also be well instructed & stregthned with you word of god, wherein is promised to us, both Comfort and help, in our Lord Jesu Christ.

column7: And if we bee not with this swearde of spirite (which is the word of god) wel armered, then doughteles wil he bring vs out of the right way, and lead vs about so log, vntil he bring vs into his snares, and so entangle vs, that we may scarsely get out agayne:
column8: And if we be not with this sword of Spirit (which is the word of god) well armered, then Doubtless will he bring us out of the right Way, and led us about so log, until he bring us into his snares, and so entangle us, that we may scarcely get out again:

column7: from the which, I besech god the father of his greate goodnes and mercy, to kepe and preserue vs, throughe his sonne our Lorde Iesu Christ.
column8: from the which, I beseech god the father of his great Goodness and mercy, to keep and preserve us, through his son our Lord Jesu christ.

column7: Amen. The seconde sonday in Lent. Math. 15.
column8: Amen. The seconde Sunday in Lent. Math. 15.

column7: A Nd Iesus went thence, and departed into the coastes of Tyrie and Sydon, and behold, a woman of Canaan (which came out of the same coastes) cryed vnto hym, saiyng:
column8: ANd ANd jesus went thence, and departed into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon, and behold, a woman of Canaan (which Come out of the same coasts) cried unto him, saying:

column7: Haue mercy on me (O lorde) thou sonne of Dauid:
column8: Have mercy on me (Oh lord) thou son of David:

column7: My doughter is piteously vexed wyth a deuel.
column8: My daughter is piteously vexed with a Devil.

column7: But he answered her nothyng at all.
column8: But he answered her nothing At all.

column7: And hys disciples came and besought hym, saying:
column8: And his Disciples Come and besought him, saying:

column7: Send her away, for she crieth after vs.
column8: Send her away, for she cries After us

column7: But he answered, and sayde:
column8: But he answered, and said:

column7: I am not sente <NOTE> but vnto the loste sheepe of the house of Israell.
column8: I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

column7: Then came she and worshipped hym, saying:
column8: Then Come she and worshipped him, saying:

column7: Lord helpe me. He answered and sayd:
column8: Lord help me. He answered and said:

column7: It is not meere to take the chyldrens breade, and to caste it to dogges.
column8: It is not mere to take the Children's bread, and to cast it to Dogs.

column7: She answered and sayd: Truth lorde, forthe dogges eate of the crummes which fall from theyr maysters table.
column8: She answered and said: Truth lord, forth Dogs eat of the crumbs which fallen from their masters table.

column7: Then Iesus answered and sayde vnto her:
column8: Then jesus answered and said unto her:

column7: O woman, great is thy fayth, be it vnto the, euen as thou wylte.
column8: Oh woman, great is thy faith, be it unto thee, even as thou wilt.

column7: And her doughter was made whole euen at that same tyme. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And her daughter was made Whole even At that same time. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: <NOTE> F Yrste of all, this gospell layeth before vs an example of faith, in the woma of Chanane, and sheweth vs also, that the Gentils and Heithen shalbe called to the knoweledg of faith.
column8: First First of all, this gospel Layeth before us an Exampl of faith, in the Woman of Canaan, and shows us also, that the Gentiles and Heithen shall called to the knoweledg of faith.

column7: <NOTE> A trew and perfite faith is nothyng else, but to know that Christe is the lorde and the son of Dauid:
column8: A true and perfect faith is nothing Else, but to know that Christ is the lord and the son of David:

column7: For yf I knowledg him as lorde, then do I also beleue, that he is naturally the very sonne of God, yea and god himselfe.
column8: For if I knowledge him as lord, then do I also believe, that he is naturally the very son of God, yea and god himself.

column7: Moreouer God ye father of heaue wyl not be knowen in any other, but in this Christe:
column8: Moreover God you father of heave will not be known in any other, but in this Christ:

column7: as S. Iohn witnesseth in the 14. chapter, sayinge:
column8: as S. John Witnesseth in the 14. chapter, saying:

column7: He that seeth me, seeth my father.
column8: He that sees me, sees my father.

column7: And also in this wise to call Christe the lorde, is not so small a trifle, as yt semeth to the worlde, but trewly it is the worke of the holy ghost, as S.
column8: And also in this wise to call Christ the lord, is not so small a trifle, as that Seemeth to the world, but truly it is the work of the holy ghost, as S.

column7: Paule saith: <NOTE> No man canne say, that Iesus is the lorde, but through the holye ghoste.
column8: Paul Says: No man can say, that jesus is the lord, but through the holy ghost.

column7: And when I knowledg Christ to be the son of Dauyd, then muste I beleue, that he came into this worlde for my sake,
column8: And when I knowledge christ to be the son of David, then must I believe, that he Come into this world for my sake,

column7: And that he was gyuen to me, with all his goodnes, merites, passion & death, that by hym delyuered from sinne,
column8: And that he was given to me, with all his Goodness, merits, passion & death, that by him Delivered from sin,

column7: I may be made the sonne and heyre of al the goodnes of god,
column8: I may be made the son and heir of all the Goodness of god,

column7: <NOTE> as do clearely declare the promises made to Abraham & Dauyd.
column8: as doe clearly declare the promises made to Abraham & David.

column7: Suche a fayth had this woman of Cananee, although she had it not of her selfe, but bicause she herde of Christ, and of her suche hearinge, she receaued faith.
column8: Suche a faith had this woman of Canaanite, although she had it not of her self, but Because she herd of christ, and of her such hearing, she received faith.

column7: Fyrste she knowledged Christ to be the lorde, whych had power (seyng he was god) to delyuer his doughter from the vexacion of the deuell.
column8: First she knowledged christ to be the lord, which had power (sing he was god) to deliver his daughter from the vexation of the Devil.

column7: And therefore she put all her truste in him, as one that coulde and wold help.
column8: And Therefore she put all her trust in him, as one that could and would help.

column7: Or else I pray you why wolde she folowe him, and make exclamacion, yf she had not beleued that?
column8: Or Else I pray you why would she follow him, and make exclamation, if she had not believed that?

column7: Yt must needes be, that this woman had a trew and perfect fayth in Christ and loked for all manner of goodnesse of hym.
column8: It must needs be, that this woman had a true and perfect faith in christ and looked for all manner of Goodness of him.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarely, it foloweth now, what the nature and property of faith is, namely in all temptacion and affliction, to seeke remedy and help none other wher, but at God, through Christ.
column8: Secondarily, it Followeth now, what the nature and property of faith is, namely in all temptation and affliction, to seek remedy and help none other where, but At God, through christ.

column7: For the faith that we haue spoken of before, dyd prouoke the woman to drawe neare to Christ, to open her necessitye and griefe, and to call for his grace and helpe.
column8: For the faith that we have spoken of before, did provoke the woman to draw near to christ, to open her necessity and grief, and to call for his grace and help.

column7: But what doth Christe here?
column8: But what does Christ Here?

column7: The faithe of the woman dothe not dysplease hym, although shee was no woman of Israel,
column8: The faith of the woman doth not displease him, although she was no woman of Israel,

column7: <NOTE> but a Gentile, for he wolde also bringe them into his flocke.
column8: but a Gentile, for he would also bring them into his flock.

column7: Yet bycause the womans faythe shoulde bee proued, and made more cleare,
column8: Yet Because the woman's faith should be proved, and made more clear,

column7: Chryste kepte scilence, and gaue none aunswere to her fyrste peticion.
column8: Christ kept silence, and gave none answer to her First petition.

column7: And what thinke ye that the woman thoughte in her mynde then?
column8: And what think you that the woman Thought in her mind then?

column7: Do ye not beleue that shee was heauye and sadde?
column8: Do you not believe that she was heavy and sad?

column7: But yet she remembreth the great humanitye of Christ, that she had harde so much commended.
column8: But yet she Remember the great humanity of christ, that she had harden so much commended.

column7: And she dyd not forgette the benefites, that he had gyuen to men of his great goodnes vnmocicioned or desyred.
column8: And she did not forget the benefits, that he had given to men of his great Goodness vnmocicioned or desired.

column7: And therfore she departed not at ye first check, nor did dispair of hir doughters helpe, but stiffely sticketh to him, and craueth for a gentel and meeke aunswere.
column8: And Therefore she departed not At you First check, nor did despair of his daughters help, but stiffly sticketh to him, and craveth for a gentle and meek answer.

column7: And in the meane tyme, thappostels come, and intreate for her, sayinge:
column8: And in the mean time, The apostles come, and entreat for her, saying:

column7: Lorde, sende her awaye, for shee excedingelye cr^eth after vs.
column8: Lord, send her away, for she excedingelye cr^eth After us

column7: But what doth Christ nowe?
column8: But what does christ now?

column7: Doth he graunte to the woman her desyre?
column8: Does he grant to the woman her desire?

column7: No, but semeth to continewe still in his firste mynde, that all men woulde iudge, that he woulde not helpe her at all.
column8: No, but Seemeth to continue still in his First mind, that all men would judge, that he would not help her At all.

column7: But why do wee not briefelye shewe, what was hys aunswere?
column8: But why do we not briefly show, what was his answer?

column7: I am not sente (sayeth he) but to the loste sheepe of the house of Israel.
column8: I am not sent (Saith he) but to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

column7: By these words he seemeth in a manner to conclude, as though it were not conuenient for him to help this woman of Canane, seyng that he was not sent, but to the loste shepe of the house of Israell.
column8: By these words he seems in a manner to conclude, as though it were not convenient for him to help this woman of Canaanite, sing that he was not sent, but to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

column7: And this answere in a manner is more bitter and harder, then was hys fyrste sylence:
column8: And this answer in a manner is more bitter and harder, then was his First silence:

column7: Yet the woman doth not so dispayr,
column8: Yet the woman does not so despair,

column7: <NOTE> but as she alwayes dydde truste in the goodnesse of Christ, and woulde not in anye wyse be ryd from him, so likewyse, she wold not prescribe or appoint the tyme and place, or any thinge else wherein shee wold that Christ shuld help her, hauig a perfit trust & hope, yt yet at the last he wold help her, how difficulte & hard so euer he did shewe himselfe vnto her.
column8: but as she always did trust in the Goodness of christ, and would not in any wise be rid from him, so likewise, she would not prescribe or appoint the time and place, or any thing Else wherein she would that christ should help her, hauig a perfect trust & hope, that yet At the last he would help her, how difficult & hard so ever he did show himself unto her.

column7: And yet she leueth not of, but cometh again, and falleth downe to his feete,
column8: And yet she leveth not of, but comes again, and falls down to his feet,

column7: & saith: Lord, helpe me.
column8: & Says: Lord, help me.

column7: And what then? Christ doth not only persist in his firste sentece, but now he calleth her a dog, as though she were vnworthy to be numbered amongest his. <NOTE> And this is a vehemet & woderful great temptacio, and yt is necessary for them yt ar lyke tempted, to haue a great faith,
column8: And what then? christ does not only persist in his First sentece, but now he calls her a dog, as though she were unworthy to be numbered amongst his. And this is a Vehement & woderful great temptacio, and that is necessary for them that Are like tempted, to have a great faith,

column7: & strongly to persist in the same, yf they wil not be ouerthrown or brought into desperacion But what saith ye woma now to this?
column8: & strongly to persist in the same, if they will not be overthrown or brought into desperation But what Says you Woman now to this?

column7: She freely & playnly grauteth, ye Christ in calling her a dog & siner, said right.
column8: She freely & plainly grauteth, you christ in calling her a dog & Synner, said right.

column7: Nor she doth desire yt the bread shuld be take from the children,
column8: Nor she does desire that the bred should be take from the children,

column7: & geuen to her, but only yt she may haue the crumes & leauyngs that the dogges take, which fall vnder theyr maisters table.
column8: & given to her, but only that she may have the crumes & leavings that the Dogs take, which fallen under their masters table.

column7: As thoughe she shulde say:
column8: As though she should say:

column7: My most beloued Lorde, yf thou wylt consydre and haue respect to my person, my dedes, my merits, and to my sinnes, then do I perfectely knowe that I shall get no helpe at thy hand.
column8: My most Beloved Lord, if thou wilt Consider and have respect to my person, my Deeds, my merits, and to my Sins, then do I perfectly know that I shall get no help At thy hand.

column7: And moreouer I know very wel, that I can not be of the numbre of the chyldren, yet neuertheles I desyre and couet thy goodnes, grace and mercy, beseching and praying the, that of thy great and abundaunt pity, thou wylt loke vpon me a wretch, comfort me in this affliction,
column8: And moreover I know very well, that I can not be of the numbered of the children, yet nevertheless I desire and covet thy Goodness, grace and mercy, beseeching and praying thee, that of thy great and abundant pity, thou wilt look upon me a wretch, Comfort me in this affliction,

column7: & delyuer my doughter from the deuell.
column8: & deliver my daughter from the Devil.

column7: And bicause I cannot obteyne yt with any of myne owne merytes,
column8: And Because I cannot obtain that with any of mine own merits,

column7: I desire the for the glory of thy name, that thou wylt shew thy mercye vnto me.
column8: I desire thee for the glory of thy name, that thou wilt show thy mercy unto me.

column7: Lo, now is the harte of Christ wonne, and canne no lenger forbeare.
column8: Lo, now is the heart of christ won, and can no longer forbear.

column7: Now muste he needs open and shew hys mynd to the woman for he saith on this wyse.
column8: Now must he needs open and show his mind to the woman for he Says on this wise.

column7: O woman, thy faith is great, be it to the as thou wylt.
column8: O woman, thy faith is great, be it to the as thou wilt.

column7: And in lyke manner dyd Ioseph in Egypte,
column8: And in like manner did Joseph in Egypt,

column7: <NOTE> after he had long shewed himselfe very harde and cruell towardes hys brethren, yet at the la^te withe greate teares wepynge he sayde:
column8: After he had long showed himself very harden and cruel towards his brothers, yet At the la^te with great tears weeping he said:

column7: I am your welbeloued brother Ioseph, be not afraid &c.
column8: I am your well-beloved brother Joseph, be not afraid etc.

column7: And this we learne, that God in euery temptacion and necessitye will helpe, although sometimes he wil defer for a tyme his ayd & socoure. <NOTE> This alwais consideryng that after the nature & custom of fayth, we shuld only seeke help and comfort at hym, and not to leaue of vntil we shal be harde.
column8: And this we Learn, that God in every temptation and necessity will help, although sometime he will defer for a time his aid & succour. This always considering that After the nature & custom of faith, we should only seek help and Comfort At him, and not to leave of until we shall be harden.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdely, is shewed vnto vs in this gospell, an example of loue which seketh not her owne, but rather the comodity & profyt of her neighboure.
column8: Thirdly, is showed unto us in this gospel, an Exampl of love which seeketh not her own, but rather the commodity & profit of her neighbour.

column7: And that chiefly doth the mother of this mayden, when in great wepyng and praying, she shewith vnto Christ the necessity of hyr doughter.
column8: And that chiefly does the mother of this maiden, when in great weeping and praying, she Showeth unto christ the necessity of her daughter.

column7: And doth as faruently as^ help for hyr, as though she hyr selfe were vexed of the diuell.
column8: And does as faruently as^ help for her, as though she her self were vexed of the Devil.

column7: And so she fulfilleth the commaundement of S.
column8: And so she fulfilleth the Commandment of S.

column7: Paule, where he saith:
column8: Paul, where he Says:

column7: <NOTE> Ye fathers & mothers loue wel your childre.
column8: You Father's & mother's love well your children.

column7: And we se also the same example of loue in the Apostels, whiche so diligently did make intercession for this woman.
column8: And we see also the same Exampl of love in the Apostles, which so diligently did make Intercession for this woman.

column7: & that it had beene also great pleasure vnto them, yf she had beene hearde of Christ at the first.
column8: & that it had been also great pleasure unto them, if she had been heard of christ At the First.

column7: And marke diligently, that heere in this place the lyuyng prayeth for the lyuinge, that thou mayest learne, that the inuocacion of the holy men that be deade, is not grounded vpon this place.
column8: And mark diligently, that Here in this place the living Prayeth for the living, that thou Mayest Learn, that the invocation of the holy men that be dead, is not grounded upon this place.

column7: Trewlye yt can not be denied, but that the Apostles prayed for this woman, but that was doone in theire lyfe tyme,
column8: Truly that can not be denied, but that the Apostles prayed for this woman, but that was done in their life time,

column7: & not after their death. <NOTE>
column8: & not After their death.

column7: Who dyd euer forbid the to praye for thy neighhour, or that in thy mind thou shuldest not beare his necessitye?
column8: Who did ever forbid thee to pray for thy Neighbor, or that in thy mind thou Shouldst not bear his necessity?

column7: Do wee not alwayes instantly require these workes, and saye, that such workes onlye be good and christian workes?
column8: Do we not always instantly require these works, and say, that such works only be good and christian works?

column7: Yea faithe and loue is the whole contente of this gospel, that we teache.
column8: Yea faith and love is the Whole content of this gospel, that we teach.

column7: And moreouer wee knowe very well, that he lyed not, that saide:

column7: T He miracle of Christ mencioned in ye gospel of this day, is a liuely doctrine & sermon. <NOTE> For we do not only learn therby, ye Christ is indued with singuler humanitye and pity, and that he is ready to gyue his diligence & labour to al me, but also, that al thinges be subdued to the dyuell, where Christ is not knowen.

column7: But to be short, whatsoeuer Christ doth, worketh or teacheth, it is verye contrary and repugnant to the worlde, and can not be void from blame & slaudre. <NOTE> So that Christ shall alwayes be a stone and rocke to be stombled at.
column8: But to be short, whatsoever christ does, works or Teaches, it is very contrary and repugnant to the world, and can not be void from blame & slaudre. So that christ shall always be a stone and rock to be stumbled At.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdely, we se in this gospell, how Christe with greate diligence and feruent zeale of loue, dyd defende hys doctrine and godlye workes.

column7: And althoughe in the ende he answered them that asked signes from heauen, and remitted the to the signe of Ionas the prophete, yet did he moste chiefelye stoppe theyr proude mouthes, that did adscribe his doctrine and workes to the deuell, and not to the power of God.
column8: And although in the end he answered them that asked Signs from heaven, and remitted thee to the Signen of Jonah the Prophet, yet did he most chiefly stop their proud mouths, that did adscribe his Doctrine and works to the Devil, and not to the power of God.

column7: He coulde in no wise suffre that, that the Iewes againste theyre owne conscience shulde lye, and saye, that he caste forth dyuels thorowe belzebub the prince of dyuels:

column7: And this properly is the sinne in the holy ghoste, when agaynst thine owne conscience, thou doest blame and persecute the plaine manifest and open knowen veritie. <NOTE> Of the whiche sinne Christe saith, that it shall not be forgeuen in this world, nor in the world to come And as Christe doth here in this place, so dothe he in the eight chapter of S.
column8: And this properly is the sin in the holy ghost, when against thine own conscience, thou dost blame and persecute the plain manifest and open known verity. Of the which sin Christ Says, that it shall not be forgiven in this world, nor in the world to come And as Christ does Here in this place, so doth he in the eight chapter of S.

column7: But here wee wyl note certayne argumentes, as briefelye as wee canne, with the which in this matter,
column8: But Here we will note certain Arguments, as briefly as we can, with the which in this matter,

column7: Christe dyd confute the obstinate Iewes.
column8: Christ did confute the obstinate Jews.

column7: Fyrste, Christ proueth by two similitudes that it was impossible, that one diuel shuld expel an other.
column8: First, christ Proves by two Similitudes that it was impossible, that one Devil should expel an other.

column7: For yf yt were so, then shuld the diuels varye, and dissente betweene themselues, and so shulde theyr kingedome be desolated.
column8: For if that were so, then should the Devils vary, and dissent between themselves, and so should their Kingdom be desolated.

column7: Euery kingdome deuided in it selfe, must nedes fall, and cannot endure.
column8: Every Kingdom divided in it self, must needs fallen, and cannot endure.

column7: And likewyse a house, wherin the dwellers doth discord and varye, can not stande.
column8: And likewise a house, wherein the dwellers does discord and vary, can not stand.

column7: Secondarily, Christ proueth with a playne example, that ye Iews did greuously blaspheme and slaudre him, saying:
column8: Secondarily, christ Proves with a plain Exampl, that the jews did grievously Blaspheme and slaudre him, saying:

column7: If I do cast forth ye diuel by ye power of Belzebub, bi whom the do your childre driue the out?
column8: If I do cast forth you Devil by you power of Belzebub, by whom the doe your children driven the out?

column7: Therfore shal they be youre iudges.
column8: Therefore shall they be your judges.

column7: <NOTE> They wil not say that one diuel driueth out an other, but that yt is done by the power of god.
column8: They will not say that one Devil Driveth out an other, but that that is done by the power of god.

column7: And yf it bee doone by the power and vertue of God, howe can your blasphemy stand?
column8: And if it be done by the power and virtue of God, how can your blasphemy stand?

column7: But ye shuld perceyue and knuwe thereby that the kyngedome of God is come to you, whereunto the dyuell muste needes gyue place.
column8: But you should perceive and knuwe thereby that the Kingdom of God is come to you, whereunto the Devil must needs gyve place.

column7: And then shuld ye not lade your selues with so greate and horrible blasphemye agaynste God.
column8: And then should you not lade your selves with so great and horrible blasphemy against God.

column7: Thirdelye, he maketh an argumente of a familiar similitude, and saith.
column8: Thirdly, he makes an argument of a familiar similitude, and Says.

column7: When a stronge harnessed man keepeth his house, all that he pocesseth is in peace:
column8: When a strong harnessed man Keepeth his house, all that he pocesseth is in peace:

column7: But when a stronger commeth vppon hym, and ouercommeth hym, he taketh frome hym all his weapons, wherein he trusted.
column8: But when a Stronger comes upon him, and Overcometh him, he Takes from him all his weapons, wherein he trusted.

column7: &c. And so he concludeth on this wise. <NOTE> The dyuell is inuincible, excepte he be ouercome by the power and vertue of god.
column8: etc. And so he Concludeth on this wise. The Devil is invincible, except he be overcome by the power and virtue of god.

column7: And I (as ye se) haue here ouercome the deuyll, and haue compelled hym to gyue place to me.
column8: And I (as you see) have Here overcome the Devil, and have compelled him to gyve place to me.

column7: And thys haue I not doone by Belzebub (as yee do saye and slaundre me) but by the power of God And seyng yt is so, ye be very wretches and naught so to slaunder my worke.
column8: And this have I not done by Belzebub (as ye do say and slaundre me) but by the power of God And sing that is so, you be very wretches and nought so to slander my work.

column7: Fourthly, he doth with a goodly sentence stop & restrayne the fowle mouthes of the Iewes, and saith:
column8: Fourthly, he does with a goodly sentence stop & restrain the fowl mouths of the Jews, and Says:

column7: He that is not with me, is agaynste me.
column8: He that is not with me, is against me.

column7: And he that doth not gather with me, scattereth abrode.
column8: And he that does not gather with me, Scattereth abroad.

column7: Nowe it is cleare, that the deuell is againste me, seyng he doth good to no man, and I do profyte euery man.
column8: Now it is clear, that the Devil is against me, sing he does good to no man, and I do profit every man.

column7: And moreouer he gathereth not to lyfe as I do, but laboureth in as much as he canne, to destroye all men.
column8: And moreover he gathereth not to life as I do, but Laboureth in as much as he can, to destroy all men.

column7: Wherefore he shall not departe from the man at my desyre, eycept he be expulsed by the power and vertu of God.
column8: Wherefore he shall not depart from the man At my desire, eycept he be Expulsed by the power and virtue of God.

column7: Fyftely, he answereth to the Iewes with an horrible thretnynge, as thoughe he shuld saye:
column8: Fifty, he Answers to the Jews with an horrible threatening, as though he should say:

column7: Looke well aboute you, and considre what shall become of you.
column8: Look well about you, and Consider what shall become of you.

column7: Now is the diuell caste forthe, and the kyngedome of God is preached vnto you in euery place, through my gospell:
column8: Now is the Devil cast forth, and the Kingdom of God is preached unto you in every place, through my gospel:

column7: But and if ye reiecte my gospel, and make your selues vnworthy of euerlasting lyfe, and wyll agayne lette the deuell haue place in you, ye shall well perceyue and vnderstande, that the end shalbe worse then the beginning. <NOTE> And wheras before, one dyuell onlye in incredulitye and hypocrisie dyd deceyue you, nowe shall come 7. other worse dyuels, that shall besege rounde about your hartes, and shall so kepe you in bondage, that yee shall neuer be able to come to eternall lyfe.
column8: But and if you reject my gospel, and make your selves unworthy of everlasting life, and will again let the Devil have place in you, you shall well perceive and understand, that the end shall Worse then the beginning. And whereas before, one Devil only in incredulity and hypocrisy did deceive you, now shall come 7. other Worse Devils, that shall besiege round about your hearts, and shall so keep you in bondage, that ye shall never be able to come to Eternal life.

column7: And I wyll that ye haue admonisshing before, that when so euer it shall so happen, yee do remembre, that I haue told you thereof before.
column8: And I will that you have admonishing before, that when so ever it shall so happen, ye do Remember, that I have told you thereof before.

column7: Lo, in this wise dothe Christe stoppe their mouthes, that dyd blaspheme the open knowen trewth,
column8: Lo, in this wise doth Christ stop their mouths, that did Blaspheme the open known truth,

column7: And that he doth with invincible argumentes, teachinge vs in the meane tyme, that euery christian man be ready to defende the trewth, as often as it shalbe depressed and laden with slaunder and lies.
column8: And that he does with invincible Arguments, teaching us in the mean time, that every christian man be ready to defend the truth, as often as it shall depressed and laden with slander and lies.

column7: And specially it shal beseme them, that be ministers of the gospel, which of their profession ought to defend and fauoure the truthe, and for that intent be called to the same office, that they teache other.
column8: And specially it shall beseem them, that be Ministers of the gospel, which of their profession ought to defend and favour the truth, and for that intent be called to the same office, that they teach other.

column7: The fowerth sonday in Lent. Ioh. 6.
column8: The fowerth Sunday in Lent. John 6.

column7: After these thynges <NOTE> Iesus wente hys way ouer the sea of Galile which is the sea of Tiberias <NOTE> and a greate multitude folowed hym, bicause they sawe hys miracles which he dyd on them that were diseased.
column8: After these things jesus went his Way over the sea of Galilee which is the sea of Tiberias and a great multitude followed him, Because they saw his Miracles which he did on them that were diseased.

column7: And Iesus went vp into a mountayn,
column8: And jesus went up into a mountain,

column7: and there he sat with his disciples.
column8: and there he sat with his Disciples.

column7: And Easter, a feaste of the Iewes, was nye. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And Easter, a feast of the Jews, was High. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IT is greatly to be wished & desired, yt as ye text of this gospel is plaine & easye, so it might be imprinted in mens hartes, that not only they shuld speake highly therof, but also learne & proue by experience, how great a thing it is, if we be wel instructed with the promises and miracles of God against the detestable carefulnes of the belly.
column8: IT is greatly to be wished & desired, that as you text of this gospel is plain & easy, so it might be imprinted in men's hearts, that not only they should speak highly thereof, but also Learn & prove by experience, how great a thing it is, if we be well instructed with the promises and Miracles of God against the detestable carefulness of the belly.

column7: <NOTE> Fyrste of all, in this place is layed before al christian men a noble example, that God ye father thorow his welbeloued son Iesu Christ, wyll norishe & defend them, both in body & soule, yf they wyll put theyr whole confidence and truste in hym.
column8: First of all, in this place is laid before all christian men a noble Exampl, that God the father thorough his well-beloved son Jesu christ, will nourish & defend them, both in body & soul, if they will put their Whole confidence and trust in him.

column7: Wherby we maye marke and note, that god from the beginnynge, with promisses and exaumples, hath defeded vs against the abhominable carke of the bellye, whiche raigneth almost ouer all the worlde.
column8: Whereby we may mark and note, that god from the beginning, with promises and Examples, hath defeded us against the abominable cark of the belly, which Reigneth almost over all the world.

column7: And chyefly for this cause, that he myght laye before our eyes our incredulity & vnbeliefe, wel knowen of hym, and deepelye grafted in vs.
column8: And chiefly for this cause, that he might say before our eyes our incredulity & unbelief, well known of him, and deeply grafted in us

column7: It is an excellent thyng, and not a little to be commended, yf a man can mortyfie hym selfe, concernynge the carefulnes of worldly riches,
column8: It is an excellent thing, and not a little to be commended, if a man can mortyfie him self, Concerning the carefulness of worldly riches,

column7: & no lenger to be vexed or troubled with the care of meat, drinke,
column8: & no longer to be vexed or troubled with the care of meat, drink,

column7: & cloth, but put al his hope & truste in the promises of God and stedfastelye beleue, that God will mercifully looke and prouyde for our necessaryes, although it appeare farre otherwyse in the syghte of men.
column8: & cloth, but put all his hope & trust in the promises of God and steadfastly believe, that God will mercifully look and provide for our necessaries, although it appear Far otherwise in the sight of men.

column7: And therefore ye we shuld leaue that pernicious in <NOTE> credulitye, and conceyue trewe faith in god, is gyuen vnto vs of God so many promises, confirmed with many noble miracles, that needes must he be blinded, and geuen into a wrong opinio, that is not by them sterid to faith,
column8: And Therefore you we should leave that pernicious in credulity, and conceive true faith in god, is given unto us of God so many promises, confirmed with many noble Miracles, that needs must he be blinded, and given into a wrong opinio, that is not by them sterid to faith,

column7: & can set a parte the carke of the belly.
column8: & can Set a part the cark of the belly.

column7: And moreouer he suffereth that such promises be shewed to the people in sermones, whereby, through the remembraunce of them, wee maye bee allured to the faithe that is in Iesu Christe.
column8: And moreover he suffers that such promises be showed to the people in Sermons, whereby, through the remembrance of them, we may be allured to the faith that is in Jesu Christ.

column7: Who is so hard or dul harted, that ca not be moued to faithe, yf he wyll remembre what greate care Christ toke for this multitude?
column8: Who is so hard or dul hearted, that circa not be moved to faith, if he will Remember what great care christ took for this multitude?

column7: And how he pitied them, when there was no mencion made of meat nor drynke?
column8: And how he pitied them, when there was no mention made of meat nor drink?

column7: Wherein he sheweth, that he knoweth what we haue need of, before we aske any thing of him.
column8: Wherein he shows, that he Knoweth what we have need of, before we ask any thing of him.

column7: And in that he lift vp his eyes (as the Euangelist saith) and beheld the multitude, is signifyed that Christ hath in hys mind compassio on vs, and that his help shal always be ready at hand for vs.
column8: And in that he lift up his eyes (as the Evangelist Says) and beheld the multitude, is signified that christ hath in his mind Compassion on us, and that his help shall always be ready At hand for us

column7: And so must we vnderstad whe scripture saith, that god doth loke vpon vs with his eies, that he mercifully wil defed vs, against al peryls of body & soul. Psal. 10 His eyes loketh vppon the poore.
column8: And so must we Understand when scripture Says, that god does look upon us with his eyes, that he mercifully will defed us, against all perils of body & soul. Psalm 10 His eyes looketh upon the poor.

column7: And in an othee place:
column8: And in an othee place:

column7: Looke vppon me Lorde, and haue mercy on me.
column8: Look upon me Lord, and have mercy on me.

column7: Wherfore seeyng that Christ sheweth in this miracle his such great goodnes, clemencye and carefulnesse for vs, that mercifully he wyll prouyde for vs, both in body and soule.
column8: Wherefore seeing that christ shows in this miracle his such great Goodness, clemency and carefulness for us, that mercifully he will provide for us, both in body and soul.

column7: It were very vnmete that we our selues shuld take lyke carke,
column8: It were very unmeet that we our selves should take like cark,

column7: & not wholy to trust to hym, yt is able to perform that he hath promysed.
column8: & not wholly to trust to him, that is able to perform that he hath promised.

column7: Nor is this to be vnderstand, as thoughe we shuld not care for our helth, but rather that before all thinges we considre, howe to please God thorow Christ, that wee maye be made pertakers of euerlastyng health, which Christ in the gospel requireth of vs,
column8: Nor is this to be understand, as though we should not care for our health, but rather that before all things we Consider, how to please God thorough christ, that we may be made partakers of everlasting health, which christ in the gospel requires of us,

column7: <NOTE> and sayth: Fyrst seeke the kingdom of god and his righteousnes, and al these thinges shalbe geuen vnto you.
column8: and say: Fyrst seek the Kingdom of god and his righteousness, and all these things shall given unto you.

column7: As he myghte say: It is necessary that ye beleue, for and yf ye do not beleue, yt is necessary that ye alwayes lack, although al the world with al his riches were yours.
column8: As he might say: It is necessary that you believe, for and if you do not believe, that is necessary that you always lack, although all the world with all his riches were yours.

column7: <NOTE> as Dauid saith:
column8: as David Says:

column7: Rich men haue lacked and haue hugred.
column8: Rich men have lacked and have hugred.

column7: Here a man myght withstand and say:
column8: Here a man might withstand and say:

column7: If the matter be so, and that God wyll fede and norish me, then wyl I be ydle and wyl no lenger laboure.
column8: If the matter be so, and that God will fede and nourish me, then will I be idle and will no longer labour.

column7: Not so my deare frende, ye shall not so do, for labour is not forbidde vnto the, but the care and carckefulnes therevppon is forbidden.
column8: Not so my deer friend, you shall not so do, for labour is not forbid unto thee, but the care and carckefulnes thereupon is forbidden.

column7: Thou shalte eate thy breade in the sweate of thy face, but yet shalt thou not put thy trust in thy labour, but in God allonly.
column8: Thou shalt eat thy bread in the sweat of thy face, but yet shalt thou not put thy trust in thy labour, but in God allonly.

column7: If thou do this, thou shalte not neede to care for thy lyuyng.
column8: If thou do this, thou shalt not need to care for thy living.

column7: Labour diligently, and by thy faythe (accordinge to thy callynge) leaue the care to God and he wyll norishe the throughe Christ.
column8: Labour diligently, and by thy faith (according to thy calling) leave the care to God and he will nourish thee through christ.

column7: Secondaryly, we haue here a godlye exaumple of the loue of god in Christe toward vs.
column8: Secondarily, we have Here a godly Exampl of the love of god in Christ towards us

column7: Fyrste, in that he dyd not only feede the good and iust,
column8: First, in that he did not only feed the good and just,

column7: <NOTE> but also the euel men, which were not the lesse part amongst this fiue M.
column8: but also the evil men, which were not the less part among this fiue M.

column7: And in that also, that he so mekely suffered the weaknesse of Philip and thother Apostels, hee dothe teache vs, that euerye Christiane man shuld shew forth his faith, by workes of loue, and thereby to prouoke other to doo the same.
column8: And in that also, that he so meekly suffered the weakness of Philip and tother Apostles, he doth teach us, that every Christian man should show forth his faith, by works of love, and thereby to provoke other to do the same.

column7: And suche loue muste alwayes bee perfecte.
column8: And such love must always be perfect.

column7: Imperfecte loue doth neuer good, but to his frendes,
column8: Imperfect love does never good, but to his Friends,

column7: <NOTE> whiche the Publicanes and sinners do also, for they loue, the of who they be loued agayn, as Christ saith, in the 6. chapt. of S.
column8: which the Publicans and Sinners do also, for they love, the of who they be loved again, as christ Says, in the 6. Chapter. of S.

column7: Luke. <NOTE> Perfect loue doth not only good to his frends, but to his enemys also.
column8: Lycia. Perfect love does not only good to his Friends, but to his enemies also.

column7: Wherin we may se the example of Christ and of the heuenly father,
column8: Wherein we may see the Exampl of christ and of the heavenly father,

column7: <NOTE> which suffereth his sunne to shyne vpon the good and bad. and sendeth raine to the iust and vniust.
column8: which suffers his sun to shine upon the good and bad. and sends rain to the just and unjust.

column7: Of this perfection of loue Christe speaketh in an other place, saiyng:
column8: Of this perfection of love Christ speaks in an other place, saying:

column7: Ye shalbe perfect, as your father in heauen is perfecte.
column8: You shall perfect, as your father in heaven is perfect.

column7: In that place Christe commedeth the loue of his father towardes vs, as a moste perfecte loue.
column8: In that place Christ commedeth the love of his father towards us, as a most perfect love.

column7: Wherfore? Bycause he hath receyued vs into his fauour and grace,
column8: Wherefore? Because he hath received us into his favour and grace,

column7: <NOTE> which were yet his enemys, and sayth, that we also must be perfect in brotherly loue, which cometh fro faith.
column8: which were yet his enemies, and say, that we also must be perfect in brotherly love, which comes from faith.

column7: Therfore yf thou be a christian man, and wilt with good works manifest thy selfe to haue a Christian mans harte, go to then, and instructe them that be weak, and leaue them not, vntil thow haue brought them to the knowledge of the fayth.
column8: Therefore if thou be a christian man, and wilt with good works manifest thy self to have a Christian men heart, go to then, and instruct them that be weak, and leave them not, until thou have brought them to the knowledge of the faith.

column7: And moreouer dooe good to all men withoute any respecte, aswell to thyne enemyes as to thy frendes:
column8: And moreover do good to all men without any respect, aswell to thine enemies as to thy Friends:

column7: to the bad as to the good.
column8: to the bad as to the good.

column7: And then thou hast testified with works of loue, that thou art a good tree, in that thou bringest forth good frute.
column8: And then thou hast testified with works of love, that thou art a good tree, in that thou bringest forth good fruit.

column7: Thirdely, this gospell sheweth,
column8: Thirdly, this gospel shows,

column7: <NOTE> how Christ dyd not distribute and geue this breade and fisshes, to the multitude, before that he had giuen thankes in his hart to his heauenly father:
column8: how christ did not distribute and give this bread and fishes, to the multitude, before that he had given thanks in his heart to his heavenly father:

column7: of whose liberality and plenteousnes all creatures be susteined, and norished vp.
column8: of whose liberality and plenteousness all creatures be sustained, and nourished up.

column7: Wherin he teacheth vs that we lykewise shuld gyue hartely thankes, for the great henefites both bodely and ghostly, that we dailye receaue of God the father, through his welbeloued sonne Iesu Christ.
column8: Wherein he Teaches us that we likewise should gyve heartily thanks, for the great henefites both bodily and ghostly, that we daily receive of God the father, through his well-beloved son Jesu christ.

column7: And yf thow wylt knowe the very trewe thankes geuing.
column8: And if thou wilt know the very true thanks giving.

column7: <NOTE> This it is.
column8: This it is.

column7: To knowledg that al that euer we haue, cometh of God through Christ, of his mere grace and goodnes, and not of our selues.
column8: To knowledge that all that ever we have, comes of God through christ, of his mere grace and Goodness, and not of our selves.

column7: This is the trew wayes, to gyue thanks.
column8: This is the true ways, to gyve thanks.

column7: And for the more parte continuall praise and commendacion foloweth such knowledg.
column8: And for the more part continual praise and commendation Followeth such knowledge.

column7: By what means can I geue prayse, honoure and thankes to God, except I knowledge his benefites?
column8: By what means can I give praise, honour and thanks to God, except I knowledge his benefits?

column7: Nowe yf I haue this faith and knowledge, that God throughe Christe hathe destroyed the kyngdome of the diuel,
column8: Now if I have this faith and knowledge, that God through Christ hath destroyed the Kingdom of the Devil,

column7: & made me inheritoure of his heauenly kyngdome, doughteles I do also gyue thankes with all Goddes electe for so greate a benefyte, as the nature of suche that beleue, is sette forthe at large, in the 25. chapiter of Esaias the Prophete, and in Daniel the seconde chapiter.
column8: & made me inheritoure of his heavenly Kingdom, Doubtless I do also gyve thanks with all God's elect for so great a benefit, as the nature of such that believe, is Set forth At large, in the 25. chapter of Isaiah the Prophet, and in daniel the seconde chapter.

column7: Neither shall I do it once, but al dayes of my lyfe withoute ende,
column8: Neither shall I do it once, but all days of my life without end,

column7: I shall saye withe Dauyd:
column8: I shall say with David:

column7: <NOTE> My sowle prayse the Lorde,
column8: My soul praise the Lord,

column7: I shall prayse the Lorde in my lyfe tyme and shall synge vnto the Lorde as long as I shall lyue.
column8: I shall praise the Lord in my life time and shall sing unto the Lord as long as I shall live.

column7: <NOTE> And: I wyll geue prayse to the Lorde at all tymes, his praise shall alwayes be in my mouth.
column8: And: I will give praise to the Lord At all times, his praise shall always be in my Mouth.

column7: Lykewise when I knowledge that God in outeward and worldely thinges wyll of his mercyfulnes norish me (but so that I must needes labore to) then muste I well remembre, that it is not to be adsc^ibed to my laboure, but muste gyue harty thankes to God throughe Christe.
column8: Likewise when I knowledge that God in outward and worldly things will of his mercyfulnes nourish me (but so that I must needs labour to) then must I well Remember, that it is not to be adsc^ibed to my labour, but must gyve hearty thanks to God through Christ.

column7: Howe often tymes doth that iuste man Dauyd confesse that God hath prouided al thinges necessary to him fro his youth to his age?
column8: Howe often times does that just man David confess that God hath provided all things necessary to him from his youth to his age?

column7: <NOTE> <NOTE> To whom doth Salomon ascribe his greate wisdome?
column8: To whom does Solomon ascribe his great Wisdom?

column7: From God is all wisedome saithe he.
column8: From God is all Wisdom Saith he.

column7: And whereby commeth his riches and greate substaunce?
column8: And whereby comes his riches and great substance?

column7: By his laboure? No. <NOTE> But he saith the blessyng of god maketh riche men.
column8: By his labour? No. But he Says the blessing of god makes rich men.

column7: Lo, now in this wise muste we knowledge, that all that wee canne or maye bothe in bodely and ghostly thinges, commeth only of god, which through Christ wyll gyue to vs all goodnes.
column8: Lo, now in this wise must we knowledge, that all that we can or may both in bodily and ghostly things, comes only of god, which through christ will gyve to us all Goodness.

column7: Wherfore it is meet that al the dayes of our lyfe we geue to him thankes therfore.
column8: Wherefore it is meet that all the days of our life we give to him thanks Therefore.

column7: Fourthly this gospell teacheth howe we shulde diligently keepe such giftes as we haue receyued, <NOTE> & not misspende them, whan Christ commaunded hys Apostels to gather the fragmentes, that they shuld not perish.
column8: Fourthly this gospel Teaches how we should diligently keep such Gifts as we have received, & not misspend them, when christ commanded his Apostles to gather the fragments, that they should not perish.

column7: If yu haue receiued more riches of God, then ye necessitie of thine own house requireth, looke thou kepe them well,
column8: If thou have received more riches of God, then you necessity of thine own house requires, look thou keep them well,

column7: <NOTE> not to get the great riches & treasure here in the earth, where the moth and rust shall destroye it, and theues steale it awaye,
column8: not to get the great riches & treasure Here in the earth, where the moth and rust shall destroy it, and thieves steal it away,

column7: But spende it not in any euell vse, or waste it in voluptuousnes, furfetynge, dronkennes, and superfluous apparrel, as it is spoken of in the 15. cha. of Lu. of the prodigall childe.
column8: But spend it not in any evil use, or waste it in voluptuousness, furfetynge, Drunkenness, and superfluous apparel, as it is spoken of in the 15. cham. of Lu. of the prodigal child.

column7: And suche as is lefte to the, more then for thyne owne necessitye, lyke a faithful stewarde and housholder, distribute it amongst the poore at tyme conueniente.
column8: And such as is left to thee, more then for thine own necessity, like a faithful steward and householder, distribute it among the poor At time convenient.

column7: Doest thou thinke that that ys gyuen to the more then for thyne owne necessity and sustentacion, that thow hast it to thentent thou mayst mayntaine thy vuluptuousnes & pride?
column8: Dost thou think that that is given to the more then for thine own necessity and sustentation, that thou hast it to thentent thou Mayest maintain thy vuluptuousnes & pride?

column7: Thou art deceiued if thou so beleue Thow art ordained a seruaunte ouer all thinges,
column8: Thou art deceived if thou so believe Thou art ordained a servant over all things,

column8: and for that cause hast thou all that thou hast, that thereof thou Mightest help the poor and needy, and make the Friends of the mammon of iniquity:

column7: that when neede shalbe, they maye testifie good of the, wherby thou maist fynd grace and fauour with God.
column8: that when need shall, they may testify good of thee, whereby thou Mayest find grace and favour with God.

column7: <NOTE> What happened to the riche man, that despised the poore Lazarus, spoken of in the gospell?
column8: What happened to the rich man, that despised the poor Lazarus, spoken of in the gospel?

column7: He shulde not haue beene damned, bycause he was clothed in purpure and sylke, and faryd so daintily, yf he had had fayth, and had eaten with thankes geuinge, and not haue forgotten the poore miserable Lazarus, the which sate at his gateful of sores, desiryng to be fedde of the cromes, that fell vnder his table.
column8: He should not have been damned, Because he was clothed in purpur and silk, and fared so daintily, if he had had faith, and had eaten with thanks giving, and not have forgotten the poor miserable Lazarus, the which sat At his gateful of sores, desiring to be fed of the cromes, that fell under his table.

column7: But what happeneth? He vtterly forgat the poore Lazarus, and tooke no care at all for hym.
column8: But what Happeneth? He utterly forgot the poor Lazarus, and took no care At all for him.

column7: Besids this, he doth misuse his goodes and riches.
column8: Besides this, he does misuse his goods and riches.

column7: And therfore well worthy to be damned.
column8: And Therefore well worthy to be damned.

column7: And to be shorte. If thou haste more then for thyne owne store, helpe thy neighbour therewith, and mispend it not in ryot, and voluptuousnesse.
column8: And to be short. If thou haste more then for thine own store, help thy neighbour therewith, and misspend it not in riot, and voluptuousness.

column8: The Fifth Sunday in Lente John: 8.

column8: Which Which of you Rebuketh me of sin?

column8: if I say the truth, why do ye not believe me?

column8: the Therefore hear them not, Because you Are not of God.

column8: Then answered the Jews and said unto him:

column8: Say we not well that thou art a Samaritan and haste the Devil?

column8: jesus answered: I have not the Devil, but I honour my father, and you have dishonoured me.

column7: I seeke not myne owne prayse:
column8: I seek not mine own praise:

column8: there is one, that Speaketh & Judgeth.

column8: Verily, verily, I say unto you:

column7: yf a man keepe my sayinge, he shall neuer see death.
column8: if a man keep my saying, he shall never see death.

column8: Then said the Jews unto him:

column8: Abraham is dead, and the Prophets, and thou Sayest:

column8: If a man keep my saying he shall never taste of death Act thou greater then our father Abraham which is dead?

column7: and the prophetes are deade.
column8: and the Prophets Are dead.

column7: Whom makest thou thy selfe?
column8: Whom Makest thou thy self?

column7: Iesus aunswered: If I honoure my selfe, myne honoure is nothing.
column8: jesus answered: If I honour my self, mine honour is nothing.

column7: It is my father that honoureth me, which ye say is your God and yet ye haue not knowen hym.
column8: It is my father that Honoureth me, which you say is your God and yet you have not known him.

column7: But I knowe hym: And yf I saye I knowe hym not,
column8: But I know him: And if I say I know him not,

column7: I am a lyar vnto you.
column8: I am a liar unto you.

column7: But I knowe hym, and keepe hys saying.
column8: But I know him, and keep his saying.

column7: Your father Abraham was glad to se my daye <NOTE> and he sawe yt and reioyseth.
column8: Your father Abraham was glad to see my day and he saw that and Rejoiceth.

column7: Then sayde the Iewes vnto him:
column8: Then said the Jews unto him:

column8: Thou art not yet L. year old, and hast thou seen Abraham?

column7: Iesus sayd vnto them Verely, verely,
column8: jesus said unto them Verily, verily,

column7: I say vnto you: yete Abraham was borne <NOTE> I am. <NOTE> Then cooke they vp stones to caste at hym.
column8: I say unto you: yete Abraham was born I am. Then cook they up stones to cast At him.

column7: But Iesus hyd hym selfe, and <NOTE> wente out of the temple. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: But jesus hid him self, and went out of the temple. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: O Ftentimes haue I sayde before, and it wil be sayde to the end of the worlde, that the worde of god can not be preached in this cursed world, without persecution and greuous aduersaries:
column8: OFtentimes OFtentimes have I said before, and it will be said to the end of the world, that the word of god can not be preached in this cursed world, without persecution and grievous Adversaries:

column7: seing that christ is set for a token, which shalbe spoken against.
column8: sing that Christ is Set for a token, which shall spoken against.

column7: <NOTE> Neyther shuld a man meruayle that suche persecution shulde chaunce to the ministers of the worde, seinge that it hapened so to Christ himselfe, whiche is the very trewth, and did so diligently and most singulerly of all men, teach the word of his father.
column8: Neither should a man marvel that such persecution should chance to the Ministers of the word, sing that it happened so to christ himself, which is the very truth, and did so diligently and most singularly of all men, teach the word of his father.

column7: In so much that he was put to the vileste death, that myghte bee.
column8: In so much that he was put to the Vilest death, that might be.

column7: And that yt so was, yt appeareth very plainlye in the gospell of this daye:
column8: And that that so was, that appears very plainly in the gospel of this day:

column7: He was not only taken and reputed for a Samaritane and a false doctor amongest the Iewes,
column8: He was not only taken and reputed for a Samaritan and a false Doctor amongst the Jews,

column7: <NOTE> but also they take stones, to stone him to death withal.
column8: but also they take stones, to stone him to death withal.

column7: Wherefore, seinge yt suche dissention betweene good and wicked men shall continew vnto the ende of the worlde, we will considre howe a Christian man (and chiefly the minister of the word of god) shuld behaue himselfe.
column8: Wherefore, sing that such dissension between good and wicked men shall continue unto the end of the world, we will Consider how a Christian man (and chiefly the minister of the word of god) should behave himself.

column7: We must always no doute suffre aduersities, yet neuertheles, we muste alwaies resiste the blasphemers of goddes worde.
column8: We must always no doubt suffer adversities, yet nevertheless, we must always resist the blasphemers of God's word.

column7: Fyrste Christe stoppeth their mouthes that persecuted his doctrine, with his clean and perfect lyuing, when he spake vnto theim with gentle wordes in this wise:
column8: First Christ stoppeth their mouths that persecuted his Doctrine, with his clean and perfect living, when he spoke unto them with gentle words in this wise:

column7: Whyche of you can rebuke me of one synne?
column8: Which of you can rebuke me of one sin?

column7: you doo reiecte my learnynge, and wyll not receaue yt, what reasones or causes haue you of youre suche counseyle and doynge?
column8: you do reject my learning, and will not receive that, what Reasons or Causes have you of your such counsel and doing?

column7: yf I taught otherwyse then I doo, or yf I did otherwyse then I teache, then had ye a good cause to forsake my doctrine.
column8: if I taught otherwise then I do, or if I did otherwise then I teach, then had you a good cause to forsake my Doctrine.

column7: But now can ye shewe nothinge at all, wherein my lyuinge doth dissente frome my learnyng.
column8: But now can you show nothing At all, wherein my living does dissent from my learning.

column7: Howebeit, your obstinacy ys so great, that ye will not beleue.
column8: Howbeit, your obstinacy is so great, that you will not believe.

column7: Lo, here the Iewes be reprehended and know not what to saye thereto, or whether to turne the.
column8: Lo, Here the Jews be reprehended and know not what to say thereto, or whither to turn thee.

column7: For the lyfe of Christ was without faulte as Esaias witnesseth in his 53.
column8: For the life of christ was without fault as Isaiah Witnesseth in his 53.

column8: chap. There is no deceit found in his Mouth.

column7: So shuld euery christian man be,
column8: So should every christian man be,

column7: & specially the minister of the worde of god, that a man might not (in deed) blame his lyfe and conuersacion, and chiefly for that cause, that the enemies of goddes worde do looke more to the lyfe of the preacher, then to his doctrine.
column8: & specially the minister of the word of god, that a man might not (in deed) blame his life and Conversation, and chiefly for that cause, that the enemies of God's word do look more to the life of the preacher, then to his Doctrine.

column7: Yea and how can I blame other, when I am not blameles my selfe?
column8: Yea and how can I blame other, when I am not blameless my self?

column8: When I shall reprehend adultery in an other man, it is necessary, that I be fautles thereof my self.

column8: And when I shall speak against surfeiting and Drunkenness, then must not I my self be a glutton.

column8: And if I shall rebuke theft then must I beware, lest I my self At any time be accused of theft.

column8: Look wherein thou Judges an other man, thou Condemnest thy self. in so much that thou that Judges, dost even the same.

column8: Wherefore dost thou show abroad my righteousness and hast my Testament in thy Mouth,

column8: & thou Hatest my Doctrine, and dost cast my saiyngs behind thee?

column8: When thou Sawest a thief, thou rannest with him:

column8: and with Adulterers thou Hadst thy portion.

column7: And very trewth it is, that before god we be all sinners & vncleane, and must therefore continually aske forgiuenes for our dayly fautes, yet must the outward conuersacion of a christian man be vnreprouable,
column8: And very truth it is, that before god we be all Sinners & unclean, and must Therefore continually ask forgiveness for our daily Faults, yet must the outward Conversation of a christian man be unreprovable,

column7: & chiefly of hym that preacheth the word of god, least the enemies of the word, <NOTE> through our vnhonest conuersacion may take occasion, not only to slaunder but also to persecute the gospell.
column8: & chiefly of him that Preacheth the word of god, lest the enemies of the word, through our unhonest Conversation may take occasion, not only to slander but also to persecute the gospel.

column7: Secondarely, <NOTE> Christe dothe commende his doctrine, as it, which is the very trewthe, and therein hee signifieth againe, that the Iewes withoute annye cause or mattier dothe reiecte hys doctrine seinge he teacheth nothynge else, but the playne trewth, receaued of hys heauenlye father.
column8: Secondarily, Christ doth commend his Doctrine, as it, which is the very truth, and therein he signifies again, that the Jews without any cause or matter doth reject his Doctrine sing he Teaches nothing Else, but the plain truth, received of his heavenly father.

column7: And where as before he withstode the Iewes with his most pure and vncleane lyfe, nowe doth he obiecte vnto them his doctrine, whiche trewlye came from his father in heauen, and not (as the Iewes dyd lye and faine) from the diuell.
column8: And where as before he withstood the Jews with his most pure and unclean life, now does he Object unto them his Doctrine, which truly Come from his father in heaven, and not (as the Jews did lie and feign) from the Devil.

column7: But and yf the preache^ can not do this, what shall he do?
column8: But and if the preache^ can not do this, what shall he do?

column7: He must needes be assured of the doctrine, that it is of God, howe so euer his lyfe be.
column8: He must needs be assured of the Doctrine, that it is of God, how so ever his life be.

column7: For through false doctrine, many be brought to the diuell.
column8: For through false Doctrine, many be brought to the Devil.

column7: My vncleane lyfe condemneth no man, but my selfe.
column8: My unclean life Condemneth no man, but my self.

column7: Wherfore, if I shuld needes chuse one of the two, and might none other wise bee,
column8: Wherefore, if I should needs choose one of the two, and might none other wise bee,

column7: I had leuer haue an vnchrifte to my teacher and preacher, that woulde instructe me in the right and trew doctrine, then a good and deuoute man, that wolde leade me frome the worde of god to mennes tradicions, and hypocrisye of workes.
column8: I had lever have an vnchrifte to my teacher and preacher, that would instruct me in the right and true Doctrine, then a good and devout man, that would lead me from the word of god to men's traditions, and hypocrisy of works.

column8: And therein Christ agreeth with me, when he Saith, that we should hear them that fit in Moses chair (that is,

column8: Here he doth reject the evil works of the preacher, and not his Doctrine which is of god.

column8: Wherefore think you did Paul rejoice so much,

column8: Doughteles he would the Jews to understand, that the Doctrine he taught, was not his, but God's.

column7: Now seing we be assertained that the doctrine is not ours but goddes, we muste with all diligence, study and endeuour to defende and knowledg the same, against all aduersaries and slaunderers thereof, euen to blodde shod and death, as in this place Christ defendid al that was laid against his doctrine, and that he was not possessed of a dyuell, nor dyd speake any thinge through the dyuell And as much as touched his personage, he let passe and medled not there with.
column8: Now sing we be ascertained that the Doctrine is not ours but God's, we must with all diligence, study and endeavour to defend and knowledge the same, against all Adversaries and slanderers thereof, even to blodde shod and death, as in this place christ defended all that was laid against his Doctrine, and that he was not possessed of a Devil, nor did speak any thing through the Devil And as much as touched his personage, he let pass and meddled not there with.

column7: Therefore we muste be assured of oure doctrine that we receyue, teache, or preache nothinge els but that is very trewthe.
column8: Therefore we must be assured of our Doctrine that we receive, teach, or preach nothing Else but that is very truth.

column8: Thirdly,

column8: See Here what great difference (in as much as concerns justification) is between the judgement of the Flesh, and the judgement of christ.

column8: The Jews judged this, that sing they Come of the seed of Abraham, and the Patriarchs, and that they had circumcision, Therefore they must needs be God's people and children.

column8: But how does christ judge?

column8: he Saith: They be not of Abraham nor of the Patriarchs, but the children of the Devil.

column8: Because they do not hear the word of god & believe it as Abraham did, but does rather despise, Set At nought and persecute the same.

column8: if the word of god be not herd and steadfastly believed.

column8: Moreover scripture Says:

column8: If now thou wilt know the children of God,

column8: from the children of the Devil, mark this.

column7: The dyuels children can by no meanes abyde or heare Goddes worde, howe good, iuste, and holly so euer they apeare or seeme to vs.
column8: The Devils children can by no means abide or hear Goddess word, how good, just, and holly so ever they appear or seem to us

column8: They will not have their works rejected and condemned, although they deserve none other but condemnacio.

column7: The chyldren of God do willyngly heare goddes word, and receiue it in theyr hartes, and beleue it, considering that all theyr felicity and saluacion is set therin.
column8: The children of God do willingly hear God's word, and receive it in their hearts, and believe it, considering that all their felicity and salvation is Set therein.

Fourthly, this gospell declareth vnto vs the power of the worde of god, in that that Christ sayeth:

column8: No, no, Because they ascribed his Doctrine to the Devil before, they could in no wise be pleased with such a noble commendation of his Doctrine, but were thereby the more steered to envy and hatred.

column8: And let them be angry as long as they will,

column8: Christ nevertheless Goes forth and ceases not to say the truth, how wroth so ever they be.

column7: Therefore we (se^tynge all mennes wrothe apart) shall considre of this texte, what our heauenly father by the words of hys welbeloued sone Iesu Christ wyll worke in them, that hear & beleue the same, he saith,
column8: Therefore we (se^tynge all men's wroth apart) shall Consider of this text, what our heavenly father by the words of his well-beloved soon Jesu christ will work in them, that hear & believe the same, he Says,

column7: They shall neuer se death.

column8: And now comes christ and will teach us how we shall Delivered from the same sentence, that is, by his word In the which is showed unto us his passion and death, considering this always, that we truly understand and keep this word.

column8: There is great power and strength in this word,

column8: Mine. for by that he excludeth the law of all me, and of Moses also, and Giveth justification only to this gospel.

column8: And if we would well look upon the matter,

column8: we shall perceive great difference, between the Doctrine of Moses and christ.

column7: Moyses doth only shew sinne, in that yt he commaudeth and forbiddeth those thinges, whiche of myne owne power and strengthe I can nother doo, nor leaue vndonne:
column8: Moses does only show sin, in that that he commaudeth and forbiddeth those things, which of mine own power and strength I can neither do, nor leave undone:

column8: And yet doth he gyve the holy ghost, wherewith I might do, that he would to be done.

column8: But Christ in his word doth grant the holy ghost, that I may freely and willingly do those things, that be both good and righteous:

column8: yea, and by the gospel he gyveth me remission of sin, righteousness, inheritance, the Kingdom of heaven, and everlasting life,

column8: & that without any my merits or deserts, of his only grace and mercy.

column8: And this can no man, nor Moses y their laws do.

column8: We must in our hearts hear it,

column8: The world Goes about to take it from thee, when she brings thee to the trust in thine own works.

column8: But thou must be strog bold and hardy, and suffer not christ and his word to be taken from thee, but receive it into thy heart,

column8: & keep it: which if thou do, thou shalt live for ever, although thou cast of this corruptible body.

column8: If the Jews would have stoned him to death, for his Doctrine and wholesome Sermons, as this gospel shows us, then must not thou look to be safe and sure from aduarsities, but must suffer as he did, sing the servant is not above or more the his master.

column7: In the only worde of Christ is gyuen vnto vs remission of sinnes, righteousnes & euerlasting lyfe yf we beleue therein, and will in no wyse be pulled from it. which I pray almighty god, through Iesu Christ, to graunte to vs foreuer. Amen.
column8: In the only word of christ is given unto us remission of Sins, righteousness & everlasting life if we believe therein, and will in no wise be pulled from it. which I pray almighty god, through Jesu christ, to grant to us forever. Amen.

column7: Ye, howe mannye be there amongest vs, that bee named Christian men, which doo confesse and knowledge, that Christe rose frome deathe, and yet shalbe damned?
