column8: Now forasmuch as the holy ghost, and the Apostles must testify of the self same thing, it is to be Thought, that their witness must be both one.

column7: And that the holy ghoste bare witnes in the apostles, it is apparaunte, accordynge to Christes sayinge:
column8: And that the holy ghost bore witness in the Apostles, it is apparaunte, according to Christ's saying:

column7: You be not they that speake, but the spyrite of your father,
column8: You be not they that speak, but the Spirit of your father,

column7: <NOTE> that is in you, speakethe.
column8: that is in you, Speaketh.

column7: Where bee they nowe, that hitherto haue taught and preached, that Christe hathe reueled to the apostles, and to the fathers a higher thing, then is contained in the gospell?
column8: Where be they now, that hitherto have taught and preached, that Christ hath revealed to the Apostles, and to the Father's a higher thing, then is contained in the gospel?

column7: Whome shall I beleue? Christ?
column8: Whom shall I believe? christ?

column7: or else theyr chatteringe and vnprofitable ianglinges?
column8: or Else their chattering and unprofitable ianglinges?

column7: Christe saithe: the holy ghoste shall beare witnesse of him, and make the folke mete to receaue and vnderstand the gospell.
column8: Christ Saith: the holy ghost shall bear witness of him, and make the folk meet to receive and understand the gospel.

column7: And plainlye that we shall be taughte none other thinge of him, then that he hymselfe taughte.
column8: And plainly that we shall be taught none other thing of him, then that he himself taught.

column7: And these ianglers chatter, that we must teache higher thinges, then is contayned in the gospell.
column8: And these Janglers chatter, that we must teach higher things, then is contained in the gospel.

column7: After my iudgemente, it is beste, that wee obeye and beleue hym, that hath this testimony and witnes of the father:
column8: After my judgement, it is best, that we obey and believe him, that hath this testimony and witness of the father:

column7: <NOTE> This is my dere sonne in whome I delite, heare him.
column8: This is my dear son in whom I delight, hear him.

column7: And he that is not contente with the doctrine of Christ, of the which not allonlye the Apostels, but also the hollye ghoste beareth witnesse, lette him chose himselfe an other kinde of learninge, and byde the aduenture of yt.
column8: And he that is not content with the Doctrine of christ, of the which not allonlye the Apostles, but also the holly ghost bears witness, let him chosen himself an other kind of learning, and bide the adventure of that.

column7: I had leuer bee suer, then doubtefull herein.
column8: I had lever be sure, then doubtful herein.

column7: <NOTE> Thyrdelye, wee bee taughte in this gospell, that the doctrine of Christe, of which, aswell the holye ghoste as the apostels, shall beare witnesse, shall not please this worlde.
column8: Thirdly, we be taught in this gospel, that the Doctrine of Christ, of which, aswell the holy ghost as the Apostles, shall bear witness, shall not please this world.

column7: For the worlde shall curse and abhorre all those, as heretiques, that shall confesse this doctrine.
column8: For the world shall curse and abhor all those, as Heretics, that shall confess this Doctrine.

column7: And when they haue tourmented and persecuted withe all kyndes of tourmentes, the apostles and faithfull menne, they shall thynke they haue doone a highe seruice vnto God.
column8: And when they have tormented and persecuted with all Kinds of tormets, the Apostles and faithful men, they shall think they have done a high service unto God.

column7: But what sayeth Christe? All these thynges shall they dooe vnto you, bycause they neyther knowe the father nor me.
column8: But what Saith Christ? All these things shall they do unto you, Because they neither know the father nor me.

column7: Beholde the fortune, that this holy and precious worde of the gospell and the faythfull shall haue in this world If thou wylte confesse Christe, looke for no merye nor quiete dayes,
column8: Behold the fortune, that this holy and precious word of the gospel and the faithful shall have in this world If thou wilt confess Christ, look for no merry nor quiet days,

column7: For Paule saieth: <NOTE> All they that wyll lyue godlye in Christe Iesu, muste suffre persecution.
column8: For Paul Saith: All they that will live godly in Christ Jesu, must suffer persecution.

column7: And in an other place hee sayeth:
column8: And in an other place he Saith:

column7: If I shulde please menne,
column8: If I should please men,

column7: <NOTE> I were not the seruaunt of Christe.
column8: I were not the servant of Christ.

column7: Seeynge than that for the confessing of Christe,
column8: Seeing than that for the confessing of Christ,

column7: I muste suffre persecution, it is needfull, that I bee well instructed and armed with the worde of God, and that wee knowe it to be the wyll of God, that with suche temptacion, our faythe shulde bee proued.
column8: I must suffer persecution, it is needful, that I be well instructed and armed with the word of God, and that we know it to be the will of God, that with such temptation, our faith should be proved.

column7: And when wee knowe this, wee shall not lightelye bee offended, but what so euer the worlde for Christes name putteth vnto vs, wee shall patientely suffre it.
column8: And when we know this, we shall not lightly be offended, but what so ever the world for Christ's name putteth unto us, we shall patientely suffer it.

column7: For this is oure comforte, that they that persecute vs, neyther knowe Christe nor the father, thoughe they thinke and boaste them selfe neuer so high.
column8: For this is our Comfort, that they that persecute us, neither know Christ nor the father, though they think and boast them self never so high.

column7: Moreouer lette vs not be ignoraunte,
column8: Moreover let us not be ignorant,

column7: <NOTE> that the persecutios & tribulacios of this world, be not to be compared to the ioye and blysse, that is prepared for vs.
column8: that the persecutios & tribulacios of this world, be not to be compared to the joy and bliss, that is prepared for us

column7: And therewith lette vs comforte our selues that we maye lyue with a quiete mynde in this present worlde, through Christe oure lorde.
column8: And therewith let us Comfort our selves that we may live with a quiet mind in this present world, through Christ our lord.

column7: Amen. The gospell on Whytsonday. Ioh. 14.
column8: Amen. The gospel on Whitsunday. John 14.

column7: Woodcut illustration of the feast of Pentecost, with the Holy Ghost (represented as a dove) descending upon Christ's disciples.
column8: Woodcut illustration of the feast of Pentecost, with the Holy Ghost (represented as a dove) descending upon Christ's Disciples.

column7: IF yee loue me, keepe my commaundementes, and I wyll praye the father and he shall gyue you and other comforter, that he maye byde wythe you for euer, euen the spirite of truthe, whome the worlde can not receaue, bycause the worlde seethe him not, neyther knoweth hym.
column8: IF ye love me, keep my Commandments, and I will pray the father and he shall gyve you and other comforter, that he may bide wythe you for ever, even the Spirit of truth, whom the world can not receive, Because the world seethe him not, neither Knoweth him.

column7: But yee knowe hym, for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you.
column8: But ye know him, for he dwells with you, and shall be in you.

column7: <NOTE> I wyll not leaue you comfortelesse, but wyll come to you.
column8: I will not leave you comfortelesse, but will come to you.

column7: Yet a litle while, and the worlde seeth me no more, but ye se me, for I lyue, and you shall lyue.
column8: Yet a little while, and the world sees me no more, but you see me, for I live, and you shall live.

column7: That day shall ye knowe that I am in my father, and you in me, and I in you.
column8: That day shall you know that I am in my father, and you in me, and I in you.

column7: <NOTE> He that hath my commaundementes and kepeth them, the same is he that loueth me.
column8: He that hath my Commandments and Keepeth them, the same is he that loves me.

column7: And he that loueth me, shalbe loued of my father:
column8: And he that loves me, shall loved of my father:

column7: and I wyll loue hym, and wyll shewe myne owne selfe to hym,
column8: and I will love him, and will show mine own self to him,

column7: <NOTE> Iudas saieth vnto him, not Iudas Iscarioth,
column8: Judas Saith unto him, not Judas Iscariot,

column7: Lord what is done that thou wylt shew thy selfe vnto vs, and not vnto the worlde?
column8: Lord what is done that thou wilt show thy self unto us, and not unto the world?

column7: Iesus aunswered and sayde vnto him.
column8: jesus answered and said unto him.

column7: If a man loue me, he wyll keepe my saiynges:
column8: If a man love me, he will keep my sayings:

column7: and my father wyll loue hym, and we wyll come vnto hym, and dwell with him.
column8: and my father will love him, and we will come unto him, and dwell with him.

column7: He that loueth me not, keepeth not my sayinges:
column8: He that loves me not, Keepeth not my sayings:

column7: And the worde which ye heare is not myne, but the fathers which sente me.
column8: And the word which you hear is not mine, but the Father's which sent me.

column7: These thinges haue I spoken vnto you, beeynge yet present wythe you.
column8: These things have I spoken unto you, being yet present wythe you.

column7: But the comforter, whyche is the hollye ghoste <NOTE> whome my father wyll sende in my name, hee shall teache you all thynges, and bringe all things to your remembraunce, whatsoeuer I haue sayde vnto you.
column8: But the comforter, which is the holly ghost whom my father will send in my name, he shall teach you all things, and bring all things to your remembrance, whatsoever I have said unto you.

column7: Peace I leaue with you, my peace I geue vnto you.
column8: Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you.

column7: Not as the world geueth, geue I vnto you.
column8: Not as the world Giveth, give I unto you.

column7: Let not your hartes be greued, neyther feare.
column8: Let not your hearts be grieved, neither Fear.

column7: Ye haue hearde howe I sayde vnto you:
column8: You have heard how I said unto you:

column7: I go, and come againe vnto you.
column8: I go, and come again unto you.

column7: Yf ye loued me, ye wolde verely reioyse, bicause I sayde:
column8: If you loved me, you would verily rejoice, Because I said:

column7: I go vnto the father.
column8: I go unto the father.

column7: For the father is greater then I,
column8: For the father is greater then I,

column7: <NOTE> And nowe haue I shewed you before it come, that when it is come to passe, ye might beleue.
column8: And now have I showed you before it come, that when it is come to pass, you might believe.

column7: Hereafter wyll I not talke many wordes vnto you.
column8: Hereafter will I not talk many words unto you.

column7: For the prince of this worlde cometh, and <NOTE> hath nought in me.
column8: For the Prince of this world comes, and hath nought in me.

column7: But that the worlde maye knowe that I loue the father.
column8: But that the world may know that I love the father.

column7: And as the father gaue me commaundemente, euen so do I. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And as the father gave me Commandment, even so do I. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T He apostels were euer of that mynd,
column8: THe THe Apostles were ever of that mind,

column7: <NOTE> before the holy ghost was confirmed in them, that the kingedome of Christe shulde haue ben temporall and wordly, wherin he shuld haue mightely raigned, as in times paste did Dauid and Salomon.
column8: before the holy ghost was confirmed in them, that the Kingdom of Christ should have been temporal and wordly, wherein he should have mightily reigned, as in times past did David and Solomon.

column7: Truly when Iudas, not the Iscariot, according to this saiyng, did aske Christ in his laste supper:
column8: Truly when Judas, not the Iscariot, according to this saying, did ask christ in his laste supper:

column7: Lorde what is the cause then, that thou wilt shew thy selfe vnto vs,
column8: Lord what is the cause then, that thou wilt show thy self unto us,

column7: & not vnto the world?
column8: & not unto the world?

column7: Christ did lead him with the other disciples away, from this hope and trusting of a temporall kingedome, to those thinges that were more necessary, which was ye fulfillyng of his word.
column8: christ did led him with the other Disciples away, from this hope and trusting of a temporal Kingdom, to those things that were more necessary, which was the fulfilling of his word.

column7: And therfore he doth teache in this gospell.
column8: And Therefore he does teach in this gospel.

column7: Fyrste of all, hee teachethe heere what the frute of oure loue towarde god is, whiche muste needes flowe oute of the harte, and cannot stande without faith.
column8: First of all, he teacheth Here what the fruit of our love toward god is, which must needs flow out of the heart, and cannot stand without faith.

column7: For how can I loue him,
column8: For how can I love him,

column7: <NOTE> of whome I hope and loke for no goodnes?
column8: of whom I hope and look for no Goodness?

column7: For in that I loke for goodnes of Christe, that I hope and truste in him,
column8: For in that I look for Goodness of Christ, that I hope and trust in him,

column7: and set al my consolacion and comforte in him, that faith (I say) oly bringeth to passe, which receiueth the worde, and thereby knoweth, that the father wyll be knowen and glorified in this Christe alone.
column8: and Set all my consolation and Comfort in him, that faith (I say) oly brings to pass, which receiveth the word, and thereby Knoweth, that the father will be known and glorified in this Christ alone.

column7: <NOTE> And that is the meaninge of this sentence:
column8: And that is the meaning of this sentence:

column7: Who so euer beleueth not that he receiueth of his fulnes,
column8: Who so ever Believeth not that he receiveth of his fullness,

column7: & that by Christe he hathe a mercifull father in heauen, and remission of sinnes, righteousnes and saluacio,
column8: & that by Christ he hath a merciful father in heaven, and remission of Sins, righteousness and saluacio,

column7: & moreouer yt it is God through Christ, that keepeth vs and defendeth vs frome the ieopardyes and periles of this worlde, hee loueth not Christe, but rather his owne propre workes, righteousnes and wisedome.
column8: & moreover that it is God through christ, that Keepeth us and defendeth us from the Jeopardies and perils of this world, he loves not Christ, but rather his own proper works, righteousness and Wisdom.

column7: Moreouer, where Christ is neither loued nor knowen, there (of a suertye) is his worde neither obserued, nor kepte.
column8: Moreover, where christ is neither loved nor known, there (of a surety) is his word neither observed, nor kept.

column7: And contrarye wise: Where the same mercifull father, with all his benefites done vnto vs, is knowen, and all oure hope caste in hym by Christ, yt is not possible but that there shalbe trewe loue towardes Christ.
column8: And contrary wise: Where the same merciful father, with all his benefits done unto us, is known, and all our hope cast in him by christ, that is not possible but that there shall true love towards christ.

column7: Trewe loue wylleth, that god willeth:
column8: True love willeth, that god wills:

column7: lyueth accordinge to his godlye wyll:
column8: liveth according to his godly will:

column7: hath greate delyte and pleasure to heare, what god desireth of vs, and when he heareth it, he fulfilleth it in worke.
column8: hath great delight and pleasure to hear, what god Desires of us, and when he hears it, he fulfilleth it in work.

column7: And suche faith and loue dyd Moyses require of the people of Israell,
column8: And such faith and love did Moses require of the people of Israel,

column7: <NOTE> saying: Heare o Israell, the lord our God is one lord onely, and thou shalt loue the lord thy god, with al thy hart with al thy soule &c.
column8: saying: Hear o Israel, the lord our God is one lord only, and thou shalt love the lord thy god, with all thy heart with all thy soul etc.

column7: <NOTE> Chieffely here note, that Moyses, as a lawe gyuer, requireth faith and hope of the harte towarde the onlye god, that he is the same, that kepeth and preserueth the people;
column8: Chiefly Here note, that Moses, as a law gyuer, requires faith and hope of the heart toward the only god, that he is the same, that Keepeth and Preserveth the people;

column7: and wilbe to vs a mercifull father.
column8: and will to us a merciful father.

column7: And after that he requireth loue towardes god (though he cannot giue it by the lawe) that we shuld loue god with all our hart, with all our soule with all our might.
column8: And After that he requires love towards god (though he cannot give it by the law) that we should love god with all our heart, with all our soul with all our might.

column7: And on this wise Moyses draweth vs from all creature, and directeth vs to god only.
column8: And on this wise Moses draws us from all creature, and directeth us to god only.

column7: Moreouer he desireth such maner of loue,
column8: Moreover he Desires such manner of love,

column7: <NOTE> that not constrained, but frely and volutarily shal serue god, and keepe his commaundementes, and fulfyll his wil, as ye nature of loue is.
column8: that not constrained, but freely and volutarily shall serve god, and keep his Commandments, and fulfil his will, as you nature of love is.

column7: Which more plainly we find in the gospel,
column8: Which more plainly we find in the gospel,

column7: <NOTE> that ye seed that fell in a good groud, gaue frute.
column8: that you seed that fell in a good Ground, gave fruit.

column7: &c. Here thou hearest that ye word of god, taken with the hart through preaching, bringeth forth frute.
column8: etc. Here thou Hearst that the word of god, taken with the heart through preaching, brings forth fruit.

column7: By ye worde we receiue faith:
column8: By you word we receive faith:

column7: from faith cometh loue toward god & our neighboure,
column8: from faith comes love towards god & our neighbour,

column7: & of loue, cometh ye fulfilling of godis comaundemets.
column8: & of love, comes the fulfilling of God's comaundemets.

column7: Finally: Faith & loue bring a godly & a christian couersacion & lyfe.
column8: Finally: Faith & love bring a godly & a christian couersacion & life.

column7: Wherefore Christ in the gospell of this day, constraineth no ma by the law, but exhorteth them to faith and loue, as they that willyngly wolde kepe his word and fulfyll his comaundment accordinge to sainte Paules saiyng:
column8: Wherefore christ in the gospel of this day, constrains no ma by the law, but exhorteth them to faith and love, as they that willingly would keep his word and fulfil his comaundment according to saint Paul's saying:

column7: <NOTE> howe that the lawe is no^ g^uen vnto the righteous, but vnto the vngodly, disobedient, and sinners.
column8: how that the law is no g^uen unto the righteous, but unto the ungodly, disobedient, and Sinners.

column7: Secondaryly, this gospell teacheth,
column8: Secondarily, this gospel Teaches,

column7: <NOTE> wher Christ will haue his kingedome and dominio, namely in ye harts of ye faithfull.
column8: where christ will have his Kingdom and Dominion, namely in you hearts of the faithful.

column7: Likewise he promiseth vs here not onli that if we shew this loue outwardly with ye word, that ye father shal loue vs, but also more greater and more excellent thinges. that is to saue that he with the father, and the vertue of the holy ghost wyll come vnto vs.
column8: Likewise he promises us Here not only that if we show this love outwardly with you word, that you father shall love us, but also more greater and more excellent things. that is to save that he with the father, and the virtue of the holy ghost will come unto us

column7: O comforte O grace. It was out dewty to * vnto him, seing that our nature is so corrupte, and wanteth so muche amedemente.
column8: O Comfort Oh grace. It was out duty to * unto him, sing that our nature is so corrupt, and Wants so much amedemente.

column7: But behold, <NOTE> so mercifull is our god, that he preuenteth vs, and promiseth to come vnto vs, by Christ.
column8: But behold, so merciful is our god, that he preventeth us, and promises to come unto us, by christ.

column7: And what will he do with vs?
column8: And what will he do with us?

column7: He wyll make hym a dwellinge place with vs.
column8: He will make him a Dwelling place with us

column7: If wee considre the disposition of oure nature and firste natiuity, we shall fynde, that our harte is the dwellyng place of the diuell:
column8: If we Consider the disposition of our nature and First Nativity, we shall find, that our heart is the Dwelling place of the Devil:

column7: Which alas is to trewe, in so much that S.
column8: Which alas is to true, in so much that S.

column7: Paul saith: <NOTE> that naturally we were ye childre of wrath, euen as well as other.
column8: Paul Says: that naturally we were you children of wrath, even as well as other.

column7: And for this originall sinne, that is grafte in vs, god by right might condempne vs wretched creatures.
column8: And for this original sin, that is graft in us, god by right might condemn us wretched creatures.

column7: But yet considre how mercifully & goodly he handleth vs, which not all only forgiueth vs our originall and actuall sinne (as they call it) so mercifully through Christ, but also he geueth vnto vs Christ himselfe.
column8: But yet Consider how mercifully & goodly he handleth us, which not all only forgives us our original and actual sin (as they call it) so mercifully through christ, but also he Giveth unto us christ himself.

column7: And so he giueth him vnto vs, yt he with him voutchsafeth to dwell in vs, whereby Satan is expulsed and driuen away, <NOTE> and our hartes made the dwelling place and temple of the holy ghoste.
column8: And so he gives him unto us, that he with him voutchsafeth to dwell in us, whereby Satan is Expulsed and driven away, and our hearts made the Dwelling place and temple of the holy ghost.

column7: He now that here in this worlde sheweth vs so great grace and fauoure and voutchsafeth to haue his kingdome in vs, and whiche doth dayly deliuer and defend vs frome all false doctrine and temptacion of the diuell, and finally,
column8: He now that Here in this world shows us so great grace and favour and voutchsafeth to have his Kingdom in us, and which does daily deliver and defend us from all false Doctrine and temptation of the Devil, and finally,

column7: <NOTE> frome all euell, withoute doubte, in the life to come, will graunte vs also euerlastingly to lyue and raigne with him without ende.
column8: from all evil, without doubt, in the life to come, will grant us also everlastingly to live and Reign with him without end.

column7: So that in any wise, we take hede in the mean season, that we loue and beleue his worde, and fulfill his will.
column8: So that in any wise, we take heed in the mean season, that we love and believe his word, and fulfil his will.

column7: To this pertaineth the sayinge of S.
column8: To this pertaineth the saying of S.

column7: Paule, where he saith, that we are the temple of god. <NOTE> And also in an other place, that god lyueth, dwelleth and moueth in euerye one of vs,
column8: Paul, where he Says, that we Are the temple of god. And also in an other place, that god liveth, dwells and moves in every one of us,

column7: <NOTE> as it is written in the actes of the apostels.
column8: as it is written in the acts of the Apostles.

column7: Thirdely, this gospell learneth vs, wherefore, and for what cause the holy ghost shalbe sent, which Christe before, with so many wordes promiseth to sende, for thus he saieth:
column8: Thirdly, this gospel learneth us, Wherefore, and for what cause the holy ghost shall sent, which Christ before, with so many words promises to send, for thus he Saith:

column7: That Comforter, <NOTE> euen the holy ghoste, whom my father shall send in my name he shall teach you al thinges, and bring all to your remembraunce, what so euer I haue tolde you.
column8: That Comforter, even the holy ghost, whom my father shall send in my name he shall teach you all things, and bring all to your remembrance, what so ever I have told you.

column7: Whereoute it is euident and playne, that the holy ghost is sent into the worlde to teach.
column8: Whereout it is evident and plain, that the holy ghost is sent into the world to teach.

column7: Now yf wee cannot know god in Christ, without the holy ghost muste be presente and learne vs, so muste it needes folowe, that we, as of our selues, can do nothing,
column8: Now if we cannot know god in christ, without the holy ghost must be present and Learn us, so must it needs follow, that we, as of our selves, can do nothing,

column7: <NOTE> in those thinges that pertayne to godlynes and saluacion:
column8: in those things that pertain to godliness and salvation:

column7: And yt (without we are lightned of this spirit) there is nothinge in vs, but darkenes,
column8: And that (without we Are lightened of this Spirit) there is nothing in us, but darkness,

column7: <NOTE> as S.
column8: as S.

column7: Iohn the Euangelist witnesseth, saying:
column8: John the Evangelist Witnesseth, saying:

column7: The lyght shineth in the darkenes, and the darkenes comprehended it not.
column8: The Light shines in the darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not.

column7: Wher is now (I besech you) the glory of the flesh?
column8: Where is now (I beseech you) the glory of the Flesh?

column7: what can oure reason and oure wisedome bringe to passe?
column8: what can our reason and our Wisdom bring to pass?

column7: Thinke you that the holye ghoste was promised to the apostels, and all goddes electe without a cause?
column8: Think you that the holy ghost was promised to the Apostles, and all God's elect without a cause?

column7: But I wolde haue the verely beleue, that Christ did well perceaue and know, that no mortall man coulde haue come vnto the knowledge of god, then by this spirite.
column8: But I would have the verily believe, that christ did well perceive and know, that no Mortal man could have come unto the knowledge of god, then by this Spirit.

column7: Wherefore else wolde he haue promised and sente it?
column8: Wherefore Else would he have promised and sent it?

column7: Nowe for as it is expediente & playne, that the office of the holy ghost is to teache, not part or halfe, but al.
column8: Now for as it is expedient & plain, that the office of the holy ghost is to teach, not part or half, but all

column7: Print this in thine harte that foloweth:
column8: Print this in thine heart that Followeth:

column8: Behold, on this manner Christ is Set forth unto us, as he that only forgives us our sin, and gives us the holy ghost, makes us new creatures, the Sons and Heirs of god, so that we believe and Set our confidence and trust in him.

column7: But when a manne begynneth to make of eatinge, glottonye, and of drinkinge, dronckennesse, in so muche that his harte forgetteth God, and seeketh therein but his owne pleasure and voluptuousnes, it is not possible, but that he shall forgette his poore neighbour, and take little thought for his necessitye.
column8: But when a man beginneth to make of eating, gluttony, and of drinking, Drunkenness, in so much that his heart forgetteth God, and seeks therein but his own pleasure and voluptuousness, it is not possible, but that he shall forget his poor neighbour, and take little Thought for his necessity.

column7: Nowe to forget god & his neigbour, bringeth euerlastig danacio.
column8: Now to forget god & his neighbour, brings euerlastig danacio.

column7: Such an vngodly engorger & glotto doth this gospell here set forth, whiche taketh so great pleasure in his vesture, and in eatinge, that he forgetteth God, and careth not for the poore, and hath so lytle charity towarde his neighbour, that the dogges hath more pity, and dothe more good vnto this poore Lazarus, then he did.
column8: Such an ungodly engorger & glotto does this gospel Here Set forth, which Takes so great pleasure in his vesture, and in eating, that he forgetteth God, and Careth not for the poor, and hath so little charity toward his neighbour, that the Dogs hath more pity, and doth more good unto this poor Lazarus, then he did.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> a certaine poore man Lazarus by name, is here described.
column8: Secondarily, a certain poor man Lazarus by name, is Here described.

column7: The scripture calleth hym a poore man, not only whiche hath nothinge of hys owne, but him also which with his harte forsaketh all wordly thinges, and cleaueth allonly vnto god, so that a riche man may haue this pouertye in hys harte, beinge alway ready, when it shall please god, to forsake all that he hath.
column8: The scripture calls him a poor man, not only which hath nothing of his own, but him also which with his heart Forsaketh all wordly things, and cleaveth allonly unto god, so that a rich man may have this poverty in his heart, being always ready, when it shall please god, to forsake all that he hath.

column8: Here have we now a very Saint, a faithful heart, which in so great misery and calamity, in such great pain and necessity, with patience Overcometh the deliciousness and glory of Princes.

column7: IN this similitude, <NOTE> fyrste of all is praysed the great godnes, grace & mercy of god, whiche he hath so mightely shewed vs, by his sonne Iesus Christe, without any deseruing of our workes, in that, that he compareth it here to a supper.
column8: IN this similitude, First of all is praised the great godnes, grace & mercy of god, which he hath so mightily showed us, by his son jesus Christ, without any deserving of our works, in that, that he compareth it Here to a supper.

column7: For all suppers are moste chiefely prepared and ordained for myrth, and not for heuines, that a man shulde eate, drinke, and be merye.
column8: For all suppers Are most chiefly prepared and ordained for mirth, and not for heaviness, that a man should eat, drink, and be merry.

column7: Lykewise, as a supper here vpon earth, is ordayned and prepared to make men merye and lighte harted, euen so this greate supper of the grace of god and the gospell, hath god prepared for our greate consolacion and comfort, wherin we shuld reioyse & be mery & glad.
column8: Likewise, as a supper Here upon earth, is ordained and prepared to make men merry and Light hearted, even so this great supper of the grace of god and the gospel, hath god prepared for our great consolation and Comfort, wherein we should rejoice & be merry & glad.

column7: For what other thing is the gospell (by the which the great goodnes and mercye of god is shewed vs so gentely and sweetly through Christ) then a good and mery tidinges?
column8: For what other thing is the gospel (by the which the great Goodness and mercy of god is showed us so gently and sweetly through christ) then a good and merry tidings?

column7: <NOTE> It could be no lye that the aungell shewed vnto the shephardes when Christ was borne, saying:
column8: It could be no lie that the angel showed unto the shepherds when christ was born, saying:

column7: Beholde, <NOTE> I bringe you tidinges of greate ioye, whiche shall happen vnto all people Neither doth the prophete Dauid monish vs with out cause to reioyse in these dayes of grace, saying:
column8: Behold, I bring you tidings of great joy, which shall happen unto all people Neither does the Prophet David monish us with out cause to rejoice in these days of grace, saying:

column7: This is the day which the lord hath made,
column8: This is the day which the lord hath made,

column7: <NOTE> let vs reioyse and be gladde in it.
column8: let us rejoice and be glad in it.

column7: Nowe seing that god our mercifull father hath so louingely prepared for vs this supper <NOTE> through Christ, without any deseruing of our part.
column8: Now sing that god our merciful father hath so lovingly prepared for us this supper through christ, without any deserving of our part.

column7: Without dout, it is a toke of his great loue toward vs, specially if we considre, that not allonly the Iewes, but also al the heithe, publicans & siners ar called hervnto.
column8: Without doubt, it is a took of his great love towards us, specially if we Consider, that not allonly the Jews, but also all the Heathen, Publicans & Sinners Are called hereunto.

column7: And therfore Christ might wel say: <NOTE> That god so loued the world, yt he gaue his only son.
column8: And Therefore christ might well say: That god so loved the world, that he gave his only son.

column7: Here thou hearest, that alloly loue moued god by Christe, to prepare this supper of ye grace of the gospel.
column8: Here thou Hearst, that alloly love moved god by Christ, to prepare this supper of you grace of the gospel.

column7: Then if loue moued him to prepare this supper, so it is a greater token of loue, that he hath called vs therunto.
column8: Then if love moved him to prepare this supper, so it is a greater token of love, that he hath called us thereunto.

column7: For what shulde it auayle me, that this greate supper is highely praysed & comended, yf I were fayne to sit without the dore,
column8: For what should it avail me, that this great supper is highly praised & commended, if I were fain to fit without the door,

column7: & were not called nor letten in?
column8: & were not called nor let in?

column7: And that we shuld pe^ceaue that Christ hath not allonly prepared this supper, but hath bidde al men thervnto, the euageliste saieth here, that the lord of the supper sent his seruaut to them that were bidden, to tell them that it was supper tyme, and to byd them come, for all was readye.
column8: And that we should pe^ceaue that christ hath not allonly prepared this supper, but hath bid all men thereunto, the euageliste Saith Here, that the lord of the supper sent his seruaut to them that were bidden, to tell them that it was supper time, and to bid them come, for all was ready.

column7: This seruante signifieth thapostels, whiche Christe firste of all sent to preach to the Iewes, and after when they hadde despised the preaching of the gospel, and made them vnworthy thereof, they were sent to ye Gentyls. <NOTE>
column8: This servant signifies The apostles, which Christ First of all sent to preach to the Jews, and After when they had despised the preaching of the gospel, and made them unworthy thereof, they were sent to the Gentiles.

column7: And what did they preach?
column8: And what did they preach?

column7: They said: Al things are redy, now come.
column8: They said: All things Are ready, now come.

column7: Christ hath shewed vs the will of the father,
column8: christ hath showed us the will of the father,

column7: Christe hath suffered death for our sinnes,
column8: Christ hath suffered death for our Sins,

column7: & is risen for our rightousnes, asceded vp into heaue,
column8: & is risen for our righteousness, asceded up into heave,

column7: & hath gotte vs ye holy ghost wherfore al thingis pertaining to our saluacion are ready This did the holy apostels so diligetly prech so yt Esaias did not speake in vain of them, when he said:
column8: & hath got us you holy ghost Wherefore all things pertaining to our salvation Are ready This did the holy Apostles so diligetly preach so that Isaiah did not speak in vain of them, when he said:

column7: <NOTE> O how bewtiful are the feet of thembassadour that brigeth good tidings & precheth helth What ca we desire any more?
column8: O how beautiful Are the feet of thembassadour that brigeth good tidings & Preacheth health What circa we desire any more?

column7: Helth is obtained vs of meer grace:
column8: Health is obtained us of mere grace:

column7: Bi grace we be called vnto saluacio.
column8: By grace we be called unto saluacio.

column7: This alloly is now required of vs, yt we come.
column8: This alloly is now required of us, that we come.

column7: Therfore let vs not dispise this supper, but rather let vs hast vs to Christe, yt we may get righteousnes & saluacion.
column8: Therefore let us not despise this supper, but rather let us hast us to Christ, that we may get righteousness & salvation.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> we se in this similitude the calling of the Iewes to the grace of the gospell, and in what wyse they be reiected for ther incredulite.
column8: Secondarily, we see in this similitude the calling of the Jews to the grace of the gospel, and in what wise they be rejected for their Incredulity.

column7: For they were the first that shulde be called, as Christe hymselfe witnesseth, saiyng:
column8: For they were the First that should be called, as Christ himself Witnesseth, saying:

column7: I am not sent but vnto the loste sheepe of the house of Israell.
column8: I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.

column7: And Paule withe Barnabas in the actes of thapostles, sayde:
column8: And Paul with Barnabas in the acts of Apostles, said:

column7: <NOTE> It behoued first the word of god to be spoken vnto you &c.
column8: It behooved First the word of god to be spoken unto you etc.

column7: But how did the Iewes heare the callyng?
column8: But how did the Jews hear the calling?

column7: They begon all to excuse the, contrary to the counsel of the prophet Dauid, saiyng:
column8: They begun all to excuse thee, contrary to the counsel of the Prophet David, saying:

column7: <NOTE> To day yf you wil heare his voyce, harden not you hartes.
column8: To day if you will hear his voice, harden not you hearts.

column7: They wyll not folowe this faithfull counsaile, but they excuse themselues & wil not come.
column8: They will not follow this faithful counsel, but they excuse themselves & will not come.

column7: The first saithe: <NOTE> I haue bought a farme, and muste nedes go forth to looke vpon it,
column8: The First Saith: I have bought a farm, and must needs go forth to look upon it,

column7: I praye the holde me excused.
column8: I pray the hold me excused.

column7: The other said: I haue boughte a yoke of oxen, and muste go forthe to proue them,
column8: The other said: I have bought a yoke of oxen, and must go forth to prove them,

column7: I praye the holde me excused.
column8: I pray the hold me excused.

column7: The third sayd: I haue maried a wyfe, and I canot come. as though he could not be a maried ma and a christian. but this it is.
column8: The third said: I have married a wife, and I canot come. as though he could not be a married ma and a christian. but this it is.

column7: From ye beginning hath ye Iews euer be stubborn & disobediet wretches.
column8: From you beginning hath you jews ever be stubborn & disobediet wretches.

column7: How ofte times (I pray you) did thei murmur agaist god i ye wildernes?
column8: How oft times (I pray you) did they murmur aghast god i you Wilderness?

column7: How ofte did thei prouoke god vnto angre?
column8: How oft did they provoke god unto anger?

column7: <NOTE> doth not s.
column8: does not s.

column7: Steue bear witnes yt ye Iews wer both the betrayers and murtherers of Christ?
column8: Stephen bear witness that you jews were both the betrayers and murderers of christ?

column7: sayig Yee stiffe necked, ye haue alwayes resisted the holye ghost.
column8: sayig Ye stiff necked, you have always resisted the holy ghost.

column7: Now yf he that bought the farme, set more by the farme, than he didde by the supper, for bying of the farme he shulde haue bene damned.
column8: Now if he that bought the farm, Set more by the farm, than he did by the supper, for buying of the farm he should have be damned.

column7: For he yt hath much riches is not damned, but he whose hart is set vppon riches. <NOTE> For as Paule saith, we shulde be as hauing nothing,
column8: For he that hath much riches is not damned, but he whose heart is Set upon riches. For as Paul Says, we should be as having nothing,

column7: & yet possessing all thyngs.
column8: & yet possessing all things.

column7: Abraha bought a pece of land of ye childre of Heth, for hys sepulchre and other vses,
column8: Abraham bought a piece of land of you children of Heth, for his Sepulchre and other uses,

column7: <NOTE> was he damned for so doinge?
column8: was he damned for so doing?

column7: No, For to bye lande and oxen, or other cattel, pertayneth not to the kigdom of Christ, but belongeth vnto the politike ordre,
column8: No, For to buy land and oxen, or other cattle, pertaineth not to the Kingdom of christ, but belongeth unto the politic ordre,

column7: & may therfore lawfully be done.
column8: & may Therefore lawfully be done.

column7: But if I wolde so sticke and cleaue to wordly thinges, that I shulde forget heauenly thinges, that shuld damne me.
column8: But if I would so stick and cleave to wordly things, that I should forget heavenly things, that should damn me.

column7: After this maner we speake of mariag:
column8: After this manner we speak of Marriage:

column7: To haue a wyfe is a good thig & lauful.
column8: To have a wife is a good thig & lawful.

column7: But if I loue mi wife better tha god, it is to my damnacion.
column8: But if I love mi wife better than god, it is to my damnation.

column7: Therfore S. Paule teacheh vs, <NOTE> that they that haue wyues, bee as though they had none. that is, in the acknowledging of the gospel,
column8: Therefore S. Paul teacheh us, that they that have wives, be as though they had none. that is, in the acknowledging of the gospel,

column7: I shall not permit my wyfe to be an impedimet vnto me, but rather for the gospels sake (if nede require) I shalbe readye to forsake wyfe children and all.
column8: I shall not permit my wife to be an impedimet unto me, but rather for the gospels sake (if need require) I shall ready to forsake wife children and all.

column7: Finally, those men outwardely appeare here to be good menne, but whyle they wyll not beleue the gospelle of Christe, thys sentence goethe vppon theim:
column8: Finally, those men outwardly appear Here to be good men, but while they will not believe the gospel of Christ, this sentence goeth upon them:

column7: None of those men that were called, shal cast of my supper.
column8: None of those men that were called, shall cast of my supper.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdely, we se here, that while the chiefe in Iury did dispise this supper, how god called thervnto all sinners, whores and publicanes, oute of euerye strete of the towne, that they shuld knowledg there sinnes, and are grace and pardon of Christ.
column8: Thirdly, we see Here, that while the chief in Jury did despise this supper, how god called thereunto all Sinners, whores and Publicans, out of every street of the town, that they should knowledge there Sins, and Are grace and pardon of christ.

column7: Also we see here the gentyles, that were not named the people of god, nowe to be called to this excellente and great supper.
column8: Also we see Here the Gentiles, that were not nam the people of god, now to be called to this excellent and great supper.

column7: Here is two thinges also to be noted Fyrste, that it hath pleased god to call the pore and the weak:
column8: Here is two things also to be noted First, that it hath pleased god to call the poor and the weak:

column7: that is, those that be of a contrite harte,
column8: that is, those that be of a contrite heart,

column7: & a louely spirite, and by the preaching of the law, be come vnto the knowledge and repentaunce of their sinnes.
column8: & a lovely Spirit, and by the preaching of the law, be come unto the knowledge and Repentance of their Sins.

column7: For by those wordes (compell them to come in) properly we vnderstand the preaching of the law For suche be lette into this supper:
column8: For by those words (compel them to come in) properly we understand the preaching of the law For such be let into this supper:

column7: that is, they be comforted through the gospell,
column8: that is, they be comforted through the gospel,

column7: <NOTE> as the virgine Marye saythe:
column8: as the Virgae Marye say:

column7: He filleth the hungry with good thingis and letteth the riche go emptye.
column8: He fills the hungry with good things and lets the rich go empty.

column7: The seconde that thow shalte marke is, that after the resurrection of Christe, all prophecies,
column8: The seconde that thou shalt mark is, that After the resurrection of Christ, all prophecies,

column7: <NOTE> both of the reiecting of the Iews, and of the calling of the gentiles, must needs be fullfilled.
column8: both of thee rejecting of the jews, and of the calling of the Gentiles, must needs be Fulfilled.

column7: To go into the streetes of the towne is none other thinge, then to preach the gospel to al men, as Christ sayth in the gospel of Iohn:
column8: To go into the streets of the town is none other thing, then to preach the gospel to all men, as christ say in the gospel of John:

column7: <NOTE> I haue yet other sheepe that be not of this folde, and those must I bringe.
column8: I have yet other sheep that be not of this fold, and those must I bring.

column7: The calling of the gentiles, wel considered in faith, causeth a man to haue great cofort.
column8: The calling of the Gentiles, well considered in faith, Causes a man to have great Comfort.

column7: For who wolde now be discomforted, when we hear that god all only for incredulity, hathe reiected his people, whiche didde excell vs withe so greate priuileges, and receaued vs sinners vnto his mercye & grace, that neuer did good at al?
column8: For who would now be discomforted, when we hear that god all only for incredulity, hath rejected his people, which did excel us with so great privileges, and received us Sinners unto his mercy & grace, that never did good At all?

column7: Wherfore good people lett vs beware, that we now being called to this supper of grace, be not loth to come therevnto in which supper we shall euerlastingly see and taste howe good and sweete the lorde is.
column8: Wherefore good people let us beware, that we now being called to this supper of grace, be not loath to come thereunto in which supper we shall everlastingly see and taste how good and sweet the lord is.

column7: <NOTE> Which god the father graunte vs, through his son our lord Iesus Christe.
column8: Which god the father grant us, through his son our lord jesus Christ.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the thirde sonday after trinity sonday. Luc. 15.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the Third Sunday After trinity Sunday. Luke 15.

column7: <NOTE> T Hen resorted vnto him all the publicanes & sinners for to hear hym.
column8: THen THen resorted unto him all the Publicans & Sinners for to hear him.

column7: And the phariseys and scribes murmured saiyng:
column8: And the Pharisees and Scribes murmured saying:

column7: He receueth sinners and eateth with them.
column8: He receueth Sinners and Eateth with them.

column7: But he put forth this parable vnto the, saiyng:
column8: But he put forth this parable unto thee, saying:

column7: <NOTE> What man of you hauing an hundreth sheep, if he lose one of the, doth not leaue nynty & nine in the wildernes, and goeth after ye which is lost vntill he fynd it?
column8: What man of you having an Hundredth sheep, if he loose one of thee, does not leave nynty & nine in the Wilderness, and Goes After you which is lost until he find it?

column7: And whe he hath found it, he layeth it on hys shoulders with ioye.
column8: And when he hath found it, he Layeth it on his shoulders with joy.

column7: And as sone as he cometh home, he calleth togither his louers and neighbours, saiyng vnto them.
column8: And as soon as he comes home, he calls together his lovers and neighbours, saying unto them.

column7: Reioyse with me for I haue founde my sheepe which was loste.
column8: Rejoice with me for I have found my sheep which was lost.

column7: I say vnto you, that lykewyse ioye shalbe in heauen ouer one sinner that repenteth, more then ouer ninty and nine iuste persones, which neede no repentauce Eyther what woman hauinge ten grotes, yf shee lose one, doth not lyghte a candle, and sweepe the house and seeke dilligently tyll she fynd it?
column8: I say unto you, that likewise joy shall in heaven over one sinner that Repenteth, more then over ninty and nine just Persons, which need no Repentance Either what woman having ten grotes, if she loose one, does not Light a candle, and sweep the house and seek diligently till she find it?

column7: and when she hath found it, she calleth hir louers & hir neigh boures togither, saiynge:
column8: and when she hath found it, she calls his lovers & his neigh boures together, saying:

column7: Reioyse with me, for I haue founde my grote which I hadde loste.
column8: Rejoice with me, for I have found my groat which I had lost.

column7: Likewyse, I saye vnto you, shall therbe ioye in the presence of the aungels of God ouer one sinner <NOTE> that repenteth. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Likewise, I say unto you, shall therbe joy in the presence of the Angels of God over one sinner that Repenteth. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T His gospel teacheth vs first of al, how that publicans & sinners drew nigh vnto Christ to heare hym.
column8: THis THis gospel Teaches us First of all, how that Publicans & Sinners drew High unto christ to hear him.

column7: And although they were receaued and defended of Christe,
column8: And although they were received and defended of Christ,

column7: <NOTE> yet he is not suche a God, that hathe pleasure in synne.
column8: yet he is not such a God, that hath pleasure in sin.

column7: Therefore it is conuenient, that we learn to know a difference betwene sinners.
column8: Therefore it is convenient, that we Learn to know a difference between Sinners.

column7: <NOTE> There be sinners of such vnshame fastenes, that they lyue in open sinnes, and in suche wyse encrease therein, that they forget god and all honesty, and glory and reioyse in moste abhominable things, and seke prayse in wickednes.
column8: There be Sinners of such unshame fastens, that they live in open Sins, and in such wise increase therein, that they forget god and all honesty, and glory and rejoice in most abominable things, and seek praise in wickedness.

column7: And these villanes, for the greate crymes and grosse sinnes,
column8: And these villains, for the great crimes and gross Sins,

column7: <NOTE> whiche they do vse and daylye committe, euen the worlde counteth and taketh them for knaues and vagabundes, not worthy that any diuine scripture shuld make muche rehersall of theym.
column8: which they do use and daily commit, even the world counteth and Takes them for knaves and vagabonds, not worthy that any divine scripture should make much rehearsal of them.

column7: There bee also other sinners, which outwardly faine holynes, but ar in their hartes most mischieuous wretches.
column8: There be also other Sinners, which outwardly feign holiness, but Are in their hearts most mischievous wretches.

column7: Againste whom both the prophets and the gospell cryeth out.
column8: Against whom both the Prophets and the gospel Cries out.

column7: <NOTE> Esaias accuseth them for this mischiefe bycause they call good, euell, and euell, good, and make lyghte, darkenesse, and darkenesse light,
column8: Isaiah Accuseth them for this mischief Because they call good, evil, and evil, good, and make Light, darkness, and darkness Light,

column7: &c. and Dauid witnesseth of the, that in their hartes they thinke, that there is no god,
column8: etc. and David Witnesseth of thee, that in their hearts they think, that there is no god,

column7: <NOTE> thoughe outwardly they appeare neuer so good and holy.
column8: though outwardly they appear never so good and holy.

column7: Doth not this apeare also in the gospell?
column8: Does not this appear also in the gospel?

column7: Christ saith: <NOTE> Excepte youre righteousnes exceede the righteousnes of the scribes and Phariseis, ye canne not entre into the kingdome of heauen.
column8: christ Says: Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, you can not enter into the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: And suche hypocrits here in this gospell Christ calleth iuste, not that be fore god they be iust, but that they think themselues to bee iuste, and neede not repentaunce. <NOTE> There be also synners, whiche knowledgynge theyr offences bee sorye for theyr euell deedes, and drawe vnto Christe, for to aske pardone and grace.
column8: And such Hypocrites Here in this gospel christ calls just, not that be before god they be just, but that they think themselves to be just, and need not Repentance. There be also Sinners, which knowledging their offences be sorry for their evil Deeds, and draw unto Christ, for to ask pardon and grace.

column7: Suche a synner and publicane was Zacheus, which ioyfully receaued Christ our lord into his house, and at the hearing of his word, sayd:
column8: Suche a sinner and publican was Zacchaeus, which joyfully received christ our lord into his house, and At the hearing of his word, said:

column7: Behold, I geue halfe my good to the poore:
column8: Behold, I give half my good to the poor:

column7: and if I haue defrauded any man,
column8: and if I have defrauded any man,

column7: I restore him four fold.
column8: I restore him four fold.

column7: Of suche sayth Christ in on other place:
column8: Of such say christ in on other place:

column7: <NOTE> I am not come to cal the iust, but sinners to repentaunce.
column8: I am not come to call the just, but Sinners to Repentance.

column7: Suche publicans and sinners drawe nowe nighe vnto Christ.
column8: Suche Publicans and Sinners draw now High unto christ.

column7: And why? To heare his worde.
column8: And why? To hear his word.

column7: For they feele their sin, they knowledge their sinne, they seeke grace, that they might be delyuered frome the borden of sinne.
column8: For they feel their since, they knowledge their sin, they seek grace, that they might be Delivered from the borden of sin.

column7: Now forasmuch as grace, remission of sines, rightousnes and saluacion, is offered and giuen vnto them, through the worde of Christe, withoute any worke or deseruinge:
column8: Now forasmuch as grace, remission of sines, righteousness and salvation, is offered and given unto them, through the word of Christ, without any work or deserving:

column7: Moreouer, for as muche as the doctrine of Christe is the doctrine of lyfe, it becometh them to drawe nighe vnto Christ, and to here him.
column8: Moreover, for as much as the Doctrine of Christ is the Doctrine of life, it Becometh them to draw High unto christ, and to hear him.

column7: To hear Christes word I saye, not the word of the law only that maketh a fearefull conscience.
column8: To hear Christ's word I say, not the word of the law only that makes a fearful conscience.

column7: <NOTE> Where oute learne, that if Christe shalbe profitable vnto the, thou must firste become suche a publicane and synner. that is, that thou maye knoweledge thy selfe to be a sinner
column8: Where out Learn, that if Christ shall profitable unto thee, thou must First become such a publican and sinner. that is, that thou may knowledge thy self to be a sinner

column7: Secondarily, this gospell describeth vnto suche publicans and sinners, what a meeke and mercifull Christe he is vnto suche sinners, which repenteth them of their wicked deedes, and intend to leade a holy and a good lyfe.
column8: Secondarily, this gospel Describeth unto such Publicans and Sinners, what a meek and merciful Christ he is unto such Sinners, which Repenteth them of their wicked Deeds, and intend to lead a holy and a good life.

column7: <NOTE> The phariseis did not allonly saye of Christ:
column8: The Pharisees did not allonly say of christ:

column7: This man doth receiue sinners and eateth with them, but also Christ himselfe, excuseth this his deade, (which not a litle did angre the phariseis) that he lawfully might do it. now seing that Christe receiueth sinners, and reiecteth no man, so that yf he will be penitente and aske grace, yt muste needes folowe, that for sinners he came into the world, and to be the sauiour alonly of sinners:
column8: This man does receive Sinners and Eateth with them, but also christ himself, excuseth this his dead, (which not a little did anger the Pharisees) that he lawfully might do it. now sing that Christ receiveth Sinners, and rejects no man, so that if he will be penitent and ask grace, that must needs follow, that for Sinners he Come into the world, and to be the Saviour alonely of Sinners:

column7: Now for as much as he is a sauiour which forgiueth sin without any worke or deseruinge, allonly of grace, who (I pray you) wolde not beleue in him?
column8: Now for as much as he is a Saviour which forgives since without any work or deserving, allonly of grace, who (I pray you) would not believe in him?

column7: Whoe wolde not truste to receyue all goodnes of him?
column8: Who would not trust to receive all Goodness of him?

column7: If thou doest diligetly cosidre, both those similitudes wherein he declareth and proueth his greate charyty towarde vs, thou shalte fynde, howe plentyfullye thou mayest hope of ye great goodnesse and benignitie of Christe.
column8: If thou dost diligetly Consider, both those Similitudes wherein he Declareth and Proves his great Charity toward us, thou shalt find, how plentifully thou Mayest hope of you great Goodness and benignity of Christ.

column7: <NOTE> Fyrste hee compareth hym selfe to a manne that hath an hundreth sheepe, whyche man, yf hee shulde leese one of theym, he wold leaue the foure score and nynety, and go seeke the one loste, vnto suche tyme that he hath founde it:
column8: First he compareth him self to a man that hath an Hundredth sheep, which man, if he should lose one of them, he would leave the foure score and nynety, and go seek the one lost, unto such time that he hath found it:

column7: And when hee hathe founde it, hee wold laye yt on his shoulders, and bringe it home againe, and therefore reioyce amongest his neyghboures.
column8: And when he hath found it, he would say that on his shoulders, and bring it home again, and Therefore rejoice amongst his neighbours.

column7: Euen as thoughe he wolde saye:
column8: Eve as though he would say:

column7: You Phariseis do iudge euell of me, bycause I receiue sinners, but I wolde you shulde knowe it, that for synners I am come into the worlde:
column8: You Pharisees do judge evil of me, Because I receive Sinners, but I would you should know it, that for Sinners I am come into the world:

column7: For they can not helpe them selues.
column8: For they can not help them selves.

column7: For the synne that is grafte in them, is so greate, and wayeth so heauye on their shulders, and theyr nature is so corrupte, that they bee a greate deale more inclined to sinne, then to goodnes.
column8: For the sin that is graft in them, is so great, and wayeth so heavy on their shoulders, and their nature is so corrupt, that they be a great deal more inclined to sin, then to Goodness.

column7: Finally, their free wyll, reason, wisdome,
column8: Finally, their free will, reason, Wisdom,

column7: <NOTE> maketh theim a greate deale worse, rather then better.
column8: makes them a great deal Worse, rather then better.

column7: For as muche as whatsoeuer is borne of fleshe,
column8: For as much as whatsoever is born of Flesh,

column7: <NOTE> is fleshe:
column8: is Flesh:

column7: and a fleshly man can vnderstand nothing but fleshly things, and cannot perceaue godly thinges.
column8: and a fleshly man can understand nothing but fleshly things, and cannot perceive godly things.

column7: Wherefore I, lyke as a good shepharde ouer my electe and chosen shepe, seeke theim through my worde, and take their sinnes vppon my shulders,
column8: Wherefore I, like as a good shepharde over my elect and chosen sheep, seek them through my word, and take their Sins upon my shoulders,

column7: & so bringe theim to the knowledg of their owne sin, and worshipping of one God.
column8: & so bring them to the knowledge of their own since, and worshipping of one God.

column7: Furthermore, for as muche as my father hath no pleasure in the deathe of a sinner,
column8: Furthermore, for as much as my father hath no pleasure in the death of a sinner,

column7: <NOTE> but rather that he conuert and lyue, truly it cannot be possible, but that the aungels in heauen reioyse with me, bicause I haue found the lost sheepe, and tourned the sinner frome the way of iniquitie, to the folowing of the gospell.
column8: but rather that he convert and live, truly it cannot be possible, but that the Angels in heaven rejoice with me, Because I have found the lost sheep, and turned the sinner from the Way of iniquity, to the following of the gospel.

column7: And you pharyseis likewise wolde I bringe to suche a point, but ye will not be called sinners, but iuste men, wherfore I am constrained to forsake you, and healpe theym that knoweledge them selues sinners.
column8: And you Pharisees likewise would I bring to such a point, but you will not be called Sinners, but just men, Wherefore I am constrained to forsake you, and help them that knowledge them selves Sinners.

column7: In lykewise he compareth hymselfe to a woman that hath tenne grotes, whiche leesinge one of theym, seeketh so longe that she findeth it,
column8: In likewise he compareth himself to a woman that hath tenne grotes, which leesing one of them, seeks so long that she finds it,

column7: &c. And he concludeth both these similitudes, saiyng on this wise:
column8: etc. And he Concludeth both these Similitudes, saying on this wise:

column7: That their is more ioye in heauen vpon one sinner that hathe repentaunce, then vpon foure score and ninetye iuste, that thinke they haue no neede of repentaunce.
column8: That their is more joy in heaven upon one sinner that hath Repentance, then upon foure score and ninetye just, that think they have no need of Repentance.

column7: Behold, thou haste here a Christe that seeketh the, findeth the, receaueth the, iustifieth and saueth the.
column8: Behold, thou haste Here a Christ that seeks thee, finds thee, receiveth thee, Justifieth and Saveth thee.

column7: Beleue in him, and thou arte safe.
column8: Believe in him, and thou art safe.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdelye, wee see here in this gospell the disposition of fained holines, and hypocrites.
column8: Thirdly, we see Here in this gospel the disposition of feigned holiness, and Hypocrites.

column7: For suche menne dooe not allonlye truste in theyr owne workes, but also counte theim selues holye, and contemne and despise other.
column8: For such men do not allonlye trust in their own works, but also count them selves holy, and contemn and despise other.

column7: I wolde haue the considre the cause, whye these phariseis murmure so againste Christe.
column8: I would have the Consider the cause, why these Pharisees murmur so against Christ.

column7: They say, that this Christe receiueth sinners, and eateth with them.
column8: They say, that this Christ receiveth Sinners, and Eateth with them.

column7: O thou most enuious and vnreasonable Ipocrite.
column8: O thou most envious and unreasonable Hypocrite.

column7: It were thy parte to extoll, magnifie, and prayse this excellent and precious worke of charitye of Christe towarde the sinners, and beholde thou arte againste it, and rebukest yt, as though yt were not well and righteouslye done.
column8: It were thy part to extol, magnify, and praise this excellent and precious work of charity of Christ toward the Sinners, and behold thou art against it, and rebukest that, as though that were not well and righteously done.

column7: Thinkest thou, that it is not well done, that a sinner is tourned to repentaunce, and broughte vnto the knowledge of god?
column8: Thinkest thou, that it is not well done, that a sinner is turned to Repentance, and brought unto the knowledge of god?

column7: Christe oure sauioure careth not for meate and drinke, but he regardeth muche the tournynge of a sinner to repentaunce.
column8: Christ our Saviour Careth not for meat and drink, but he Regardeth much the turning of a sinner to Repentance.

column7: Suche exaumples of charitye shuldest thou folowe also, yf thou woldest be a righte iuste manne, bothe in teachinge, informinge, exhortynge praying and deseching, so that righteousnes, not allonlye in the, but also in other, might be found.
column8: Suche Examples of charity Shouldst thou follow also, if thou Wouldst be a right just man, both in teaching, informing, exhorting praying and deseching, so that righteousness, not allonlye in thee, but also in other, might be found.

column7: But the case stondeth thus:
column8: But the case standeth thus:

column7: Thou arte againste the gospell, and the gospell againste the. <NOTE>
column8: Thou art against the gospel, and the gospel against thee.

column7: If thou askest why, I aunswere the:
column8: If thou askest why, I answer thee:

column7: The gospell can not suffre, that thou shuldest hope and truste in thy workes.
column8: The gospel can not suffer, that thou Shouldst hope and trust in thy works.

column7: Againe I saye: Ipocrisy cannot leaue the confidence in theym.
column8: Again I say: Hypocrisy cannot leave the confidence in them.

column7: Hereout springeth the stryfe betwene Abell and Cain, betwene Iacob and Esai, betweene Dauid and Saule:
column8: Hereout springs the strife between Abel and Cain, between Jacob and Isaiah, between David and Saule:

column7: Also, that the workemenne murmured againste the householder, forbicause the laste receaued equall rewarde with the fyrst:
column8: Also, that the workemenne murmured against the householder, For because the laste received equal reward with the fyrst:

column7: Item, <NOTE> that the eldest brother disdained the yogest that was lost.
column8: Item, that the eldest brother disdained the yogest that was lost.

column7: To be short: Christ receiueth and kepeth company with those sinners that knowledg their offeces, and aske grace, and he will not haue them loste.
column8: To be short: christ receiveth and Keepeth company with those Sinners that knowledge their offences, and ask grace, and he will not have them lost.

column7: And againe, hee codemneth hypocrisye,
column8: And again, he codemneth hypocrisy,

column7: for bicause she fained righteousnes, whe in dede she is neither right nor iuste.
column8: for Because she feigned righteousness, when in deed she is neither right nor just.

column7: Therefore all these hipocrites murmure againste Christe and his gospell, but yt helpeth nothinge.
column8: Therefore all these Hypocrites murmur against Christ and his gospel, but that Helpeth nothing.

column7: For Christe foloweth the same way, and proceadeth where he beganne.
column8: For Christ Followeth the same Way, and Proceedeth where he began.

column7: To whome with the father and holy ghoste be honoure and prayse.
column8: To whom with the father and holy ghost be honour and praise.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the fowerth sonday after Trinitye sondaye. Luc. 6.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the fowerth Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Luke 6.

column7: BE you therefore mercyfull, as your father also is mercifull <NOTE> Iudge not, and yee shall not bee iudged.
column8: BE you Therefore merciful, as your father also is merciful Judge not, and ye shall not be judged.

column7: Condemne not, and ye shall not be condemned.
column8: Condemn not, and you shall not be condemned.

column7: Forgiue, and yee shalbe forgiuen,
column8: Forgive, and ye shall forgiven,

column7: <NOTE> Gyue, and it shalbe gyuen vnto you, good measure, and pressed downe, and shaken togyther, and runnynge ouer shall men gyue into your bosomes.
column8: Gyve, and it shall given unto you, good measure, and pressed down, and shaken together, and running over shall men gyve into your bosoms.

column7: <NOTE> For with the same measure that ye meere with all, shall other men meate to you agayne.
column8: For with the same measure that you mere with all, shall other men meat to you again.

column7: And he put forth a similitude vnto <NOTE> them:
column8: And he put forth a similitude unto them:

column7: Can the blinde leade the blynd?
column8: Can the blind lead the blind?

column7: Do they not both fall into the diche?
column8: Do they not both fallen into the diche?

column7: <NOTE> The disciple is not aboue hys mayster.
column8: The disciple is not above his master.

column7: Euery man shall be perfecte, euen as his mayster is.
column8: Every man shall be perfect, even as his master is.

column7: <NOTE> why seeste thou a mote in thy brothers eye, but consideress not the beame that is in thyne owne eye?
column8: why See thou a mote in thy Brother's eye, but consideress not the beam that is in thine own eye?

column7: Eyther howe canste thou say to thy brother:
column8: Either how Canst thou say to thy brother:

column7: <NOTE> Brother, let me pull out ye mote that is in thine eye, when thou seest not the beame that is in thine owne eie?
column8: Brother, let me pull out you mote that is in thine eye, when thou See not the beam that is in thine own eye?

column7: Thou hypocrite, caste out the beame out of thine owne eye firste, and then shalte thou se perfectly, to pull oute the moat that is in thy brothers eye. THE EXPOSITION. <NOTE> H Itherto throughe many instructions & examples, we haue sufficiently proued, how that we attaine and gette remission of sinnes, rightuosnesse and saluacion only throughe faithe.
column8: Thou hypocrite, cast out the beam out of thine own eye First, and then shalt thou see perfectly, to pull out the moat that is in thy Brother's eye. THE EXPOSITION. HItherto HItherto through many instructions & Examples, we have sufficiently proved, how that we attain and get remission of Sins, rightuosnesse and salvation only through faith.

column7: And moreouer that no worke (how holy or precious so euer it mai be) can make a man acceptable before god, excepte only faith, which we haue declared and taught you out of the holye srripture.
column8: And moreover that no work (how holy or precious so ever it mai be) can make a man acceptable before god, except only faith, which we have declared and taught you out of the holy Scripture.

column7: For this faith so comprehendeth the goodnes and the loue of god through Christe, that vtterlye he canne truste to none other thing, then to the merites of Christ, through whom also he hopeth to obteine saluacion.
column8: For this faith so comprehendeth the Goodness and the love of god through Christ, that utterly he can trust to none other thing, then to the merits of christ, through whom also he Hopes to obtain salvation.

column7: <NOTE> By faith (saith the apostle) wee haue an entraunce vnto god.
column8: By faith (Says the apostle) we have an Entrance unto god.

column7: And lykewise as a true and lyuing faith, which knoweth that he hath a mercifull father through Christ, hanleth himselfe towarde his god and father, so muste yt likewise breake forth toward his neighboure, to helpe him in all neede and necessity, that he may be knowen therby vnto ye world, to haue a right and a good faith, and not fained.
column8: And likewise as a true and living faith, which Knoweth that he hath a merciful father through christ, hanleth himself toward his god and father, so must that likewise break forth towards his neighbour, to help him in all need and necessity, that he may be known thereby unto you world, to have a right and a good faith, and not feigned.

column7: The workes of charity be contrary to hipocriticall and fained workes, for it is the nature and disposition of hipocrisy, euer to seke his owne aduauntage, and not the profite and vtilitye of his neighboure, in so much that Christe himselfe for this cause saide vnto the pharise is, for that, that they condemned for a lyghte matter, his disciples:
column8: The works of charity be contrary to hypocritical and feigned works, for it is the nature and disposition of hypocrisy, ever to seek his own advantage, and not the profit and utility of his neighbour, in so much that Christ himself for this cause said unto the Pharisee is, for that, that they condemned for a Light matter, his Disciples:

column7: <NOTE> Goe your waye (saith he) and learn what it is:
column8: Go your Way (Says he) and Learn what it is:

column7: I wyll haue mercy, and no sacrifice.
column8: I will have mercy, and no sacrifice.

column7: Therfore likewise as Christ sometyme reacheth faith, and adscribeth righteousnes allonlye there vnto, yea, and commendeth it as a fountaine whereout all goodnes floweth,
column8: Therefore likewise as christ sometime reaches faith, and adscribeth righteousness allonlye there unto, yea, and commends it as a fountain whereout all Goodness flows,

column7: <NOTE> so other whiles he teacheth the frutes of the faith, not that we are iustified by them, but that they be suer tokens and testimonialles of that faithe, whiche wee oughte to haue in oure harte,
column8: so other while he Teaches the fruits of the faith, not that we Are justified by them, but that they be sure tokens and testimonialles of that faith, which we ought to have in our heart,

column7: as saincte Peter sayeth: <NOTE> Brethren, giue the more dilygence to make youre callynge and election sure.
column8: as saint Peter Saith: Brothers, give the more diligence to make your calling and election sure.

column7: Neuerthelesse sometyme Christe teachethe these workes of charitye with longe processe, some tyme with shorte and fewe wordes.
column8: Nevertheless sometime Christ teacheth these works of charity with long process, Some time with short and few words.

column7: Hee declareth yt shortelye, when he sayeth:
column8: He Declareth that shortly, when he Saith:

column7: Thou shalte loue the lorde thy God,
column8: Thou shalt love the lord thy God,

column7: <NOTE> with all thy harte, with all thy strengthe.
column8: with all thy heart, with all thy strength.

column7: And in an other place:
column8: And in an other place:

column7: What so euer you wolde that menne shulde dooe vnto you, the same dooe vnto theym lykewise.
column8: What so ever you would that men should do unto you, the same do unto them likewise.

column7: But in the gospell of this daye, hee teacheth the workes of charitye in manye wordes and plentyfullye:
column8: But in the gospel of this day, he Teaches the works of charity in many words and plentifully:

column7: For hee thoughte it not sufficiente to speake yt generallye:
column8: For he Thought it not sufficient to speak that generally:

column7: Be mercyfull. but hee declareth the same mercifulnesse here by partes, namelye,
column8: Be merciful. but he Declareth the same mercifulness Here by parts, namely,

column7: Iudge not (sayth he) &c.
column8: Judge not (say he) etc.

column7: To bee mercyfull, <NOTE> in this place signi ieth, to helpe oure neighboure of oure goodnes and charitye, of what so euer neede hee is oppressed withall,
column8: To be merciful, in this place Sign ieth, to help our neighbour of our Goodness and charity, of what so ever need he is oppressed withal,

column7: <NOTE> as wee see in the Samaritane, whiche did so greate mercye on hym, that fell amongest the theues.
column8: as we see in the Samaritan, which did so great mercy on him, that fell amongst the thieves.

column7: Oute of which wordes yt foloweth, that they bee good workes, wherewith we helpe oure neighbour in all neede and necessity.
column8: Out of which words that Followeth, that they be good works, wherewith we help our neighbour in all need and necessity.

column7: Which deedes of charitye, wee wyll by ordre recyte one after an other.
column8: Which Deeds of charity, we will by ordre recite one After an other.

column7: <NOTE> Fyrste of all Christe saith:
column8: First of all Christ Says:

column7: Iudge not, and ye shal not be iudged:
column8: Judge not, and you shall not be judged:

column7: Codemne not, and ye shal not be condemned.
column8: Condemn not, and you shall not be condemned.

column7: With the whiche wordes, Christe teacheth euery christian man, to looke vpon his owne workes, and not vpon the workes of his neighbour,
column8: With the which words, Christ Teaches every christian man, to look upon his own works, and not upon the works of his neighbour,

column7: & thoughe his neighbour sin & erre, he shall not therfore sodainly or rashly dispise hi.
column8: & though his neighbour since & err, he shall not Therefore suddenly or rashly despise him.

column7: For it may chauce that he that standeth to day, maye fall to morowe, <NOTE> & he that falleth to daye, may rise to morow.
column8: For it may chance that he that Stands to day, may fallen to morrow, & he that falls to day, may rise to morrow.

column7: Furthermore, it is not a point of mercy, that yu shuldest iudg or codene thy neighbour, as sone as he of infirmity sinneth.
column8: Furthermore, it is not a point of mercy, that thou Shouldst judge or codene thy neighbour, as soon as he of infirmity Sinneth.

column7: For the hipocrites, and those that glory in workes, were wont to do so, which for the most part, damne that, that of it selfe is nothig danable.
column8: For the Hypocrites, and those that glory in works, were wont to do so, which for the most part, damn that, that of it self is nothing danable.

column7: Therfore we shall not folow the ypocrites, but yt, that our father in heauen teacheth vs, which although lawfully may iudge & codene vs for our sins, yet neuertheles, rather wold shew vs his mercy, in & through his welbeloued son our lord Iesu Christ, so that we are nowe become the children of god by adoption, if we do beleue in the name of his son Iesus Christe.
column8: Therefore we shall not follow the Hypocrites, but that, that our father in heaven Teaches us, which although lawfully may judge & codene us for our Sins, yet nevertheless, rather would show us his mercy, in & through his well-beloved son our lord Jesu christ, so that we Are now become the children of god by adoption, if we do believe in the name of his son jesus Christ.

column7: <NOTE> Wherfore if god (when I was an enemy vnto him) receaued me into his grace,
column8: Wherefore if god (when I was an enemy unto him) received me into his grace,

column7: <NOTE> why shulde not I lykewise shew charity & mercy vnto my neighbour, with teachinge him, enforminge him, exhortynge him, and prayinge him?
column8: why should not I likewise show charity & mercy unto my neighbour, with teaching him, informing him, exhorting him, and praying him?
