column7: For he doth not saye:
column8: For he does not say:

column7: Iudge, and condemne a sinner, but helpe him, dooe good vnto him.
column8: Judge, and condemn a sinner, but help him, do good unto him.

column7: Here is now a differece to be had,
column8: Here is now a difference to be had,

column7: <NOTE> betwen a man hauyng an office, and a pryuate person.
column8: between a man having an office, and a private person.

column7: For it is for bidden a priuate persone to iudge, or condemne, but the magistrate & the iudges by the vertue of their office ought to iudge & punish the euel doers, yea, with extreame punishmente.
column8: For it is for bidden a private person to judge, or condemn, but the magistrate & the judges by the virtue of their office ought to judge & Punish the evil doers, yea, with extreme punishment.

column7: Likewise a preacher, as cocernig his own perso, shal not iudge, but by reason of his office the word of God shall do yt.
column8: Likewise a preacher, as cocernig his own person, shall not judge, but by reason of his office the word of God shall do that.

column7: For Christ saith: The word that I haue spoken,
column8: For christ Says: The word that I have spoken,

column7: <NOTE> shall iudge him at the laste daye.
column8: shall judge him At the laste day.

column7: Here of knoweth nothinge the Pharise, but with a proude hart iudgeth and condemneth al men, ye in those thingis also that hee himselfe is culpable in.
column8: Here of Knoweth nothing the Pharisee, but with a proud heart Judgeth and Condemneth all men, you in those things also that he himself is culpable in.

column7: <NOTE> Wherefore Christe calleth him here a leader of the blinde, that leadeth himselfe into the diche.
column8: Wherefore Christ calls him Here a leader of the blind, that leads himself into the diche.

column7: Also, a disciple that wil be aboue his maister:
column8: Also, a disciple that will be above his master:

column7: And, one that seeth a mote in his brothers eye, and considereth not the beame that is in his owne eye.
column8: And, one that sees a mote in his Brother's eye, and Considereth not the beam that is in his own eye.

column7: And so accordinge to hys owne iudgemente, he shalbe condemned.
column8: And so according to his own judgement, he shall condemned.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarily, Christ teacheth vs here to forgiue and we shalbe forgiuen, with which wordes he teacheth vs an excellente worke of mercy, so that wee muste needes looke againe vpon oure celestiall father. but how so?
column8: Secondarily, christ Teaches us Here to forgive and we shall forgiven, with which words he Teaches us an excellent work of mercy, so that we must needs look again upon our celestial father. but how so?

column7: Bicause that he hath pardoned & forgiuen vs all oure offences and trespasses, of hys mere grace, without any deseruing,
column8: Because that he hath pardoned & forgiven us all our offences and Trespasses, of his mere grace, without any deserving,

column7: & that through his only sonne Iesus Christe, so that we now being clensed from our sinnes, are become heyres of his kyngedome.
column8: & that through his only son jesus Christ, so that we now being cleansed from our Sins, Are become Heirs of his Kingdom.

column7: Nowe for as muche as accordinge to this exaumple, oure heauenly father requireth the same thing of vs, that is, that we hartely shuld for giue them that trespasse vs, why be we then in this behalfe so negligent?
column8: Now for as much as according to this Exampl, our heavenly father requires the same thing of us, that is, that we heartily should for give them that trespass us, why be we then in this behalf so negligent?

column7: why do we hate and enuy one an other?
column8: why do we hate and envy one an other?

column7: Yt is to no purpose, and if thou shuldest complain,
column8: It is to no purpose, and if thou Shouldst complain,

column7: <NOTE> and say:
column8: and say:

column7: This man hath done me greate iniurye, he hath hurte me, and suche lyke.
column8: This man hath done me great injury, he hath hurt me, and such like.

column7: This is no lawfull excuse.
column8: This is no lawful excuse.

column7: For we haue prouoked god vnto angre with weightyer and greater sinnes, then wee canne be prouoked withall, and yet through Christ he pardoneth and forgiueth vs all.
column8: For we have provoked god unto anger with Weightier and greater Sins, then we can be provoked withal, and yet through christ he Pardoneth and forgives us all.

column7: Yea if Christe wold handle vs according to our wickednes which we haue committed against him, and according as we haue deserued, when shulde we come vnto saluacion?
column8: Yea if Christ would handle us according to our wickedness which we have committed against him, and according as we have deserved, when should we come unto salvation?

column7: <NOTE> Choose now one of these two:
column8: Choose now one of these two:

column7: Eyther do well to thine enemy, and forgiue him with all thine hart, that thy sins maye be forgiuen the through Christ,
column8: Either doe well to thine enemy, and forgive him with all thine heart, that thy Sins may be forgiven the through christ,

column7: Or els enuye thy neighboure, that thou maist euer lastingly be damned.
column8: Or Else envy thy neighbour, that thou Mayest ever lastingly be damned.

column7: This sentence agreeth with that, which we haue in our Pater noster.
column8: This sentence agreeth with that, which we have in our Pater Noster.

column7: Thirdely, Christ saith: Geue, and to you it shalbe geuen. wherewith he exhorteth and warneth vs to do well to the nedy, that is, to our neighbour.
column8: Thirdly, christ Says: Give, and to you it shall given. wherewith he exhorteth and warneth us to do well to the needy, that is, to our neighbour.

column7: And for as muche as oure lyfe withoute thys mercye, wherewith we helpe oure neighboure, can not consiste nor stande, and rather to be a diuelish lyfe, if it be forgotton, therfore doth Christ exhort vs vnto this trade of loue, goodnes, mercy and charitye, alluring vs thervnto with this promise, saying:
column8: And for as much as our life without this mercy, wherewith we help our neighbour, can not consist nor stand, and rather to be a devilish life, if it be forgotton, Therefore does christ exhort us unto this trade of love, Goodness, mercy and charity, alluring us thereunto with this promise, saying:

column7: A good measure, pressed downe, shaken togither, and runnyng ouer, shall men giue into youre bosomes.
column8: A good measure, pressed down, shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosoms.

column7: Againe: With what measure yee meete, with the same shal it be measured vnto you again.
column8: Again: With what measure ye meet, with the same shall it be measured unto you again.

column7: Here thou hearest, that thy giuyng shalbe rewarded an hundreth folde.
column8: Here thou Hearst, that thy giving shall rewarded an Hundredth fold.

column7: And so saith Salomon: <NOTE> He that hathe pitye vpon the poore, lendeth vnto the lord.
column8: And so Says Solomon: He that hath pity upon the poor, dares unto the lord.

column7: Therefore if thou wylt do good workes that pleaseth god geue vnto the poore, distribute thy goods vnto the needye, lende him that wanteth, dooe well to thine enemy,
column8: Therefore if thou wilt do good works that Pleases god give unto the poor, distribute thy goods unto the needy, lend him that Wants, do well to thine enemy,

column7: <NOTE> and thou shalte heape coles of fier vpon his heade.
column8: and thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head.

column7: The tyme shall come, that thou wilte wishe that all thy good hadde been giuen vnto the poore.
column8: The time shall come, that thou wilt wish that all thy good had been given unto the poor.

column7: For those goodes that are giuen to the poore, are not loste, but are lent to the lorde, which in tyme to come shall liberally recompence them.
column8: For those goods that Are given to the poor, Are not lost, but Are lent to the lord, which in time to come shall liberally recompense them.

column7: And hereto pertaineth it that is spoken in an other place:
column8: And hereto pertaineth it that is spoken in an other place:

column7: Gather your treasure togither in heauen:
column8: Gather your treasure together in heaven:

column7: And also: <NOTE> Make you friendes of the wicked Mammon &c.
column8: And also: Make you Friends of the wicked Mammon etc.

column7: <NOTE> Finally: As we do behaue vs to our neighbour, so shall god do to vs.
column8: Finally: As we do behave us to our neighbour, so shall god do to us

column7: To whome with the sonne & the holy ghoste, be all honoure for euer.
column8: To whom with the son & the holy ghost, be all honour for ever.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the fyfte sonday after Trinitye sonday. Luc. 5.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the Fifth Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Luke 5.

column7: IT came to passe that when the people preaced vpon hym, to heare the worde of god, he stode by the lake of Genezareth,
column8: IT Come to pass that when the people pressed upon him, to hear the word of god, he stood by the lake of Gennesaret,

column7: <NOTE> and sawe twoo shyppes standynge by the lake side, but the fyshermenne were gone out of them, and were shashynge theyr nettes.
column8: and saw twoo ships standing by the lake side, but the fyshermenne were gone out of them, and were shashynge their nets.

column7: And he entred into one of the shyppes whyche pertained to Simon, and prayed hym, that he woulde thruste oure a little frome the lande.
column8: And he entered into one of the ships which pertained to Simon, and prayed him, that he would thrust our a little from the land.

column7: And he sate downe, and taughte the people oute of the shyppe.
column8: And he sat down, and taught the people out of the ship.

column7: When hee hadde lefte speakynge, he sayde vnto Simon:
column8: When he had left speaking, he said unto Simon:

column7: Launche out into the deepe, and lette slyppe youre nettes, and make a draught.
column8: Launch out into the deep, and let slip your nets, and make a draught.

column7: And Symon aunswered and sayde vnto hym:
column8: And Symon answered and said unto him:

column7: Mayster, wee haue laboured all nyghte, and haue taken nothynge.
column8: Master, we have laboured all night, and have taken nothing.

column7: Neuerthelesse, at thy commaundemente,
column8: Nevertheless, At thy Commandment,

column7: I wyll lose forthe the nette.
column8: I will loose forth the net.

column7: And when they hadde this done, they inclosed a greate multitude of fishes.
column8: And when they had this done, they enclosed a great multitude of Fish.

column7: But theyr net brake: and they beckened to their felowes whiche were in the other shyppe, that they shuld come and helpe them.
column8: But their net brake: and they beckoned to their Fellows which were in the other ship, that they should come and help them.

column7: And they came, and fylled both the shyppes, that they sunke agayne.
column8: And they Come, and filled both the ships, that they sunk again.

column7: When Symon Petersawe this, he felle downe at Iesus knees, saying:
column8: When Symon Peter saw this, he fell down At jesus knees, saying:

column7: Lorde, go frome me, for I am a synfull man.
column8: Lord, go from me, for I am a sinful man.

column7: For he was astonyed, and al that were with hym, at the draught of fyshes which they had take:
column8: For he was astonied, and all that were with him, At the draught of fishes which they had take:

column7: and so was also Iames & Iohn the sonnes of Zebede, which were parteners with Simon.
column8: and so was also James & John the Sons of Zebedee, which were partners with Simon.

column7: And Iesus saide vnto Simon:
column8: And jesus said unto Simon:

column7: Feare not, frome hence forthe thou shalte catche menne.
column8: fear not, from hence forth thou shalt catch men.

column7: And they broughte the shyp to lande <NOTE> and forsoke all, and folowed hym. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And they brought the ship to land and forsook all, and followed him. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: H Ere is commended in this gospel vnto vs, the greate diligence which Christ tooke in the office of preaching.
column8: Here Here is commended in this gospel unto us, the great diligence which christ took in the office of preaching.

column7: And also the great desire that the people had, that folowed him, to hear the worde of god.
column8: And also the great desire that the people had, that followed him, to hear the word of god.

column7: Which thing is not written aloly for the that execute the office of preaching,
column8: Which thing is not written aloly for the that execute the office of preaching,

column7: <NOTE> but also for the hearers, that bothe parts shulde haue an example laid before them to folow.
column8: but also for the hearers, that both parts should have an Exampl laid before them to follow.

column7: When Christ saw now the greedy desire of the people to hear ye worde of god,
column8: When christ saw now the greedy desire of the people to hear you word of god,

column7: & that the people preaced so on him, he went in to a ship that was Simons, (for he stode by the lake of Genezareth) and taught the people out of the ship.
column8: & that the people pressed so on him, he went in to a ship that was Simons, (for he stood by the lake of Gennesaret) and taught the people out of the ship.

column7: But what did he teache & preach? <NOTE> Truly ye that the people came for to hear, which was ye word of god.
column8: But what did he teach & preach? Truly you that the people Come for to hear, which was the word of god.

column7: And as Christ was euer ready to preach and teache, though he had had no more audience the one Magdalen, yea suerly like as he neuer left occasio, but rather alwaies sought means for to teach,
column8: And as christ was ever ready to preach and teach, though he had had no more audience the one Magdalen, yea surely like as he never left Occasion, but rather always sought means for to teach,

column7: So likewise is euery preacher bound to execute diligetly his office to teache & instruct the people, gladly & willingly,
column8: So likewise is every preacher bound to execute diligetly his office to teach & instruct the people, gladly & willingly,

column7: & not alonly for that cause, yt he is therto here in this gospell induced by ye example of Christ, but also by commaundemet, that Christ gaue vnto Peter, sayig:
column8: & not alonely for that cause, that he is thereto Here in this gospel induced by you Exampl of christ, but also by Commandment, that christ gave unto Peter, sayig:

column7: Feed my sheep, <NOTE> for feedig in that place signifieth to teache, which we fynd lykewise in the tenthe chapiter of Iohn.
column8: Feed my sheep, for feedig in that place signifies to teach, which we find likewise in the tenthe chapter of John.

column7: <NOTE> Nowe if Christe wyll haue his, (whome often tymes he compareth vnto sheepe) to be taughte, so ys it needefull, that it bee doone with greate diligence, so that they be not seduced with the inuencions and dreames of me, but be taughte sincerelye and purely throughe goddes worde.
column8: Now if Christ will have his, (whom often times he compareth unto sheep) to be taught, so is it needful, that it be done with great diligence, so that they be not seduced with the Inventions and dreams of me, but be taught sincerely and purely through God's word.

column7: Vnto this, now referre, the firste epistle of Paule to Timothe, <NOTE> where (amongest other vertues that shulde shine in a preacher or Byshop) he requireth of theim,
column8: Unto this, now refer, the First epistle of Paul to Timothy, where (amongst other Virtues that should shine in a preacher or Bishop) he requires of them,

column7: <NOTE> to be apte to teache.
column8: to be apt to teach.

column7: Also, the seruant that hid his maisters talent, and wonne nothinge.
column8: Also, the servant that hid his masters talon, and won nothing.

column7: Therefore let the punishment of this seruaunt fear vs, that haue the office of preachinge, that we with all diligence do that, that is enioyned vs, leaste we also with lyke punishement be rewarded. <NOTE> Furthermore, let the hearers folowe the exaumple of them that folowed Christe, to heare goddes worde, that they likewise be glad to heare the same, and suffre themselues to be instructed and taughte.
column8: Therefore let the punishment of this servant Fear us, that have the office of preaching, that we with all diligence do that, that is enjoined us, jest we also with like punishment be rewarded. Furthermore, let the hearers follow the Exampl of them that followed Christ, to hear God's word, that they likewise be glad to hear the same, and suffer themselves to be instructed and taught.

column7: For what profiteth, if the preacher preache and teache perpetuallye, if there dothe no man heare him or receaue his worde?
column8: For what profiteth, if the preacher preach and teach perpetually, if there doth not man hear him or receive his word?

column7: For it is aswell commaunded the to heare,
column8: For it is aswell commanded thee to hear,

column7: <NOTE> as the preacher to teache.
column8: as the preacher to teach.

column7: For yf they bee pronounced blessed, that hear the word of god and kepe it, so muste it cosequently folowe, that they be damned, that do not heare it and kepe it.
column8: For if they be pronounced blessed, that hear the word of god and keep it, so must it cosequently follow, that they be damned, that do not hear it and keep it.

column7: Wherfore this text serueth both for to teache, and for to hear, namelye, to alure the preacher withe greate dilygence to teache, and lykewise the hearer to heare.
column8: Wherefore this text serveth both for to teach, and for to hear, namely, to allure the preacher with great diligence to teach, and likewise the hearer to hear.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarylye, Christ sheweth vs in this gospel that when his worde is bothe harde and receaued and so therewith the sowle feede, that he likewise will giue the necessaryes for the body.
column8: Secondarily, christ shows us in this gospel that when his word is both harden and received and so therewith the soul feed, that he likewise will give the necessaries for the body.

column7: But marke this. that Christe feedeth and norisheth vs here by a meane.
column8: But mark this. that Christ feeds and nourisheth us Here by a mean.

column7: For he saith vnto Peter:
column8: For he Says unto Peter:

column7: Lanche out into the deepe, and lette slyppe your nettes, and make a draught, as thoughe he wolde saye:
column8: Launch out into the deep, and let slip your nets, and make a draught, as though he would say:

column7: I will feed you and geue you that you lacke, but euerye manne shall do the thinge that he is called vnto, that is, they shall laboure. Gene. 3.
column8: I will feed you and give you that you lack, but every man shall do the thing that he is called unto, that is, they shall labour. Gene. 3.

column7: For if you laboure <NOTE> and put youre confidence in me,
column8: For if you labour and put your confidence in me,

column7: I wyll see that your laborure shall not be loste.
column8: I will see that your laborure shall not be lost.

column7: And this considereth Peter, saiynge:
column8: And this Considereth Peter, saying:

column7: Maister, wee haue laboured all the night, and gatte nothinge, but at thy word,
column8: Master, we have laboured all the night, and gat nothing, but At thy word,

column7: I will lose forthe the nette.
column8: I will loose forth the net.

column7: Whoe dothe not perceiue in these wordes of Peter, that all oure counsailes, thoughtes, and all oure merites, what so euer wee intende for to dooe or leaue, are all in vaine, and to none effecte, excepte that they be taken in hande, and begonne in the name of god?
column8: Who doth not perceive in these words of Peter, that all our Counsels, thoughts, and all our merits, what so ever we intend for to do or leave, Are all in vain, and to none Effect, except that they be taken in hand, and begun in the name of god?

column7: For before they had laboured all the night, and toke nothing.
column8: For before they had laboured all the night, and took nothing.

column7: And that happened vpon theim, which ys written in the psalme, where the prophete saith:
column8: And that happened upon them, which is written in the psalm, where the Prophet Says:

column7: <NOTE> It is but lost laboure, that ye rise vp earlye, and take no reste, but eate the breaded of care fulnes.
column8: It is but lost labour, that you rise up early, and take no rest, but eat the braided of care fullness.

column7: For loke to whome it pleaseth the lorde, he geueth yt in sleepe.
column8: For look to whom it Pleases the lord, he Giveth that in sleep.

column7: But when Christe saide: Lette slyppe your nettes, and the disciples regarded not their owne labour, but hauing respecte to the worde of Christe, then tooke they a greate multitude, in so muche that they were fayne to call to their felows (which were in an other ship) for helpe, and filled bothe the shippes full.
column8: But when Christ said: Let slip your nets, and the Disciples regarded not their own labour, but having respect to the word of Christ, then took they a great multitude, in so much that they were fain to call to their Fellows (which were in an other ship) for help, and filled both the ships full.

column7: <NOTE> Whoe wolde not nowe beleue Christe, whiche not all only wyll, but can helpe vs Therfore beleue nowe, and he will see that thou shalte lacke nothinge, nother for body nor sowle.
column8: Who would not now believe Christ, which not all only will, but can help us Therefore believe now, and he will see that thou shalt lack nothing, neither for body nor soul.

column7: As touchinge thy soule, he wyll keepe it by his worde, and thy body with corporall meates and norishinges, which thinge thou mayst euidently perceaue by this miracle.
column8: As touching thy soul, he will keep it by his word, and thy body with corporal Meats and norishinges, which thing thou Mayest evidently perceive by this miracle.

column7: To this pertayneth that Paule saieth to Timothe:
column8: To this pertaineth that Paul Saith to Timothy:

column7: <NOTE> Godlynes is profitable vnto all thinges, as a thinge whiche hathe promises of the life that is nowe, and of the lyfe that is to come.
column8: Godliness is profitable unto all things, as a thing which hath promises of the life that is now, and of the life that is to come.

column7: And Christe sayeth in the gospell of Mathewe:
column8: And Christ Saith in the gospel of Matthew:

column7: <NOTE> Seeke yee fyrste the kyngedome of heauen, and the righteousnesse therof, so shall all these thynges bee mynystred vnto you.
column8: Seek ye First the Kingdom of heaven, and the righteousness thereof, so shall all these things be ministered unto you.

column7: <NOTE> Thyrdelye, Peter was not allonly here comforted, whiche for simplenes, ignoraunce or feare, bad Christe departe from him, bicause he was a sinner, but also the other likewise whiche were called to the apostolicall office.
column8: Thirdly, Peter was not allonly Here comforted, which for simpleness, ignorance or Fear, bad Christ depart from him, Because he was a sinner, but also the other likewise which were called to the apostolical office.

column7: For Christe sayed: Feare not, as thoughe he wold saye:
column8: For Christ said: fear not, as though he would say:

column7: When a man feeleth and knoweledgeth hys synne, there shulde he not flye frome me, but runne to me, forasmuche as I am come into the worlde for sinners.
column8: When a man feeleth and knoweledgeth his sin, there should he not fly from me, but run to me, forasmuch as I am come into the world for Sinners.

column7: For they that be hole,
column8: For they that be hold,

column7: <NOTE> neede no physicion, but the sycke.
column8: need no Physician, but the sick.

column7: Wherefore my Peter, take heede, that thou biddest me not go frome the, but to tarye with the.
column8: Wherefore my Peter, take heed, that thou biddest me not go from thee, but to tarry with thee.

column7: For I am no tyraunte, whiche for cruelnesse kyll and destroye men, but with mercye and goodnes I wyll alure me vnto me, and truly I will not allonly forgiue you and pardon you your offeces, for bicause you knowledg them, but also I wyl make you fishers of menne, that hereafter ye shal become myne apostels & disciples.
column8: For I am no tyrant, which for cruelness kill and destroy men, but with mercy and Goodness I will allure me unto me, and truly I will not allonly forgive you and pardon you your offences, for Because you knowledge them, but also I will make you Fishers of men, that hereafter you shall become mine Apostles & Disciples.

column7: And likewise as hitherto ye haue taken fyshe wt bodely nettes, so ye shal hereafter get & take me with spirituall nettes, out of the stormie sea of this worlde, and bringe them into my kingedome.
column8: And likewise as hitherto you have taken Fish with bodily nets, so you shall hereafter get & take me with spiritual nets, out of the stormy sea of this world, and bring them into my Kingdom.

column7: And Christ hath here respect to the prophecie of Ieremy where he saith:
column8: And christ hath Here respect to the prophecy of Jeremiah where he Says:

column7: <NOTE> Behold I wil send out many fishers to take them.
column8: Behold I will send out many Fishers to take them.

column7: <NOTE> And in the gospel of S.
column8: And in the gospel of S.

column7: Mathew we haue, that the gospel is compared to a nette, caste into the sea, wherewith are taken al manner of fishes.
column8: Matthew we have, that the gospel is compared to a net, cast into the sea, wherewith Are taken all manner of Fish.

column7: And likewise as Christ comforteth here Peter with the other, bicause they wer abashed and afrayed and were comforted, so we shall learne hereoute, howe a sinner can get no consolacion and comforte by nothinge, but all only by Christ.
column8: And likewise as christ comforts Here Peter with the other, Because they were abashed and afraid and were comforted, so we shall Learn Hereout, how a sinner can get no consolation and Comfort by nothing, but all only by christ.

column7: Also by the calling of Peter,
column8: Also by the calling of Peter,

column7: Iames, & Iohn, we learn that no ma oughte to thrust himselfe into the office of a precher except he be called.
column8: James, & John, we Learn that no ma ought to thrust himself into the office of a preacher except he be called.

column7: For those thre apostles were before in the common callyng, which euery man is called vnto.
column8: For those Three Apostles were before in the Common calling, which every man is called unto.

column7: That is, <NOTE> that in the sweate of theyr face, they shulde eate theyr breade,
column8: That is, that in the sweat of their face, they should eat their bread,

column7: And therein lyke good and symple menne, they wolde haue remayned, yf they hadde not beene otherwise called.
column8: And therein like good and simple men, they would have remained, if they had not been otherwise called.

column7: Fourthly, we haue in this gospel,
column8: Fourthly, we have in this gospel,

column7: <NOTE> what strength and vertue the worde of Christe hathe, and also the obedyence of the aforesayde Apostels.
column8: what strength and virtue the word of Christ hath, and also the Obedience of the aforesaid Apostles.

column7: For as soone as Christe hadde sayde:
column8: For as soon as Christ had said:

column7: Frome hence forthe ye shal be fysshers of men, incontinent when they hadde brought theyr shyppes to lande, they forsoke al, and folowed him.
column8: From hence forth you shall be Fishers of men, incontinent when they had brought their ships to land, they forsook all, and followed him.

column7: Here wee muste needes graunte, that Christe dydde not speake yt allonlye in theyr eares, but also in theyr hartes. for else howe shulde they haue so soone folowed hym?
column8: Here we must needs grant, that Christ did not speak that allonlye in their ears, but also in their hearts. for Else how should they have so soon followed him?

column7: For it is not so lyghte a matter nor so easy, to forsake father and mother, lande, house and money, that a manne canne dooe it of his owne selfe,
column8: For it is not so Light a matter nor so easy, to forsake father and mother, land, house and money, that a man can do it of his own self,

column7: It is the worke of the hollye ghoste,
column8: It is the work of the holly ghost,

column7: <NOTE> and cometh not of the fleshe.
column8: and comes not of the Flesh.

column7: Wherefore seeinge that the wordes of Christe are spiryte and lyfe, yee maye well perceaue this callynge not to haue sounde alonly in the eares of the apostels, but also in their hartes, or else they wolde not haue forsaken their parentes, wyues and children so lightly, and haue take Christ for their sauioure and Lorde.
column8: Wherefore seeing that the words of Christ Are Spirit and life, ye may well perceive this calling not to have sound alonely in the ears of the Apostles, but also in their hearts, or Else they would not have forsaken their Parents, wives and children so lightly, and have take christ for their Saviour and Lord.

column7: <NOTE> But what is that, to forsake all thinges?
column8: But what is that, to forsake all things?

column7: It is none other thinge, but so to be affectioned, that gladly (whensoeuer god wil) a man be ready to forsake wife and children, father and mother, and all that in the worlde is, and to folowe Christe.
column8: It is none other thing, but so to be affectioned, that gladly (whensoever god will) a man be ready to forsake wife and children, father and mother, and all that in the world is, and to follow Christ.

column7: Remembre also, that the folowing of Christe consisteth not alwaies in the outewarde worke, but moste chieflye in the harte.
column8: remember also, that the following of Christ Consisteth not always in the outward work, but most chiefly in the heart.

column7: For wee see many christian menne, that do abide and lyue styll with their wiues and children, whiche are not called to folowe Christe, as the Apostels were, and yet natwithstandinge are so mynded, that at all tymes they bee readye and willynge, when it shall please God, to forsake al, nother suffre them by no meanes to bee called frome the acknowledging and confessynge of the gospell, and the righteousnes thereof, whiche is in Christe Iesu, whiche also folow Christ as well as those apostels did.
column8: For we see many christian men, that do abide and live still with their wives and children, which Are not called to follow Christ, as the Apostles were, and yet natwithstandinge Are so minded, that At all times they be ready and willing, when it shall please God, to forsake all, neither suffer them by no means to be called from the acknowledging and confessing of the gospel, and the righteousness thereof, which is in Christ Jesu, which also follow christ as well as those Apostles did.

column7: But they that be not called there vnto, to forsake wyfe and children,
column8: But they that be not called there unto, to forsake wife and children,

column7: & go run ouer all the wide world, to be a charg & a burthen to other men, as do the Anabaptistes, <NOTE> may be counted rather to be folowers of the diuell, then of Christe oure sauioure.
column8: & go run over all the wide world, to be a charge & a burden to other men, as do the Anabaptists, may be counted rather to be followers of the Devil, then of Christ our Saviour.

column7: To whom with the father and the holly ghost, be all praise and honoure Amen.
column8: To whom with the father and the holly ghost, be all praise and honour Amen.

column7: The gospell on the sixte sondaye after trinitye sonday Math. 5.
column8: The gospel on the sixte Sunday After trinity Sunday Math. 5.

column7: F Or I saye vnto you:
column8: FOr FOr I say unto you:

column7: Except your rightousnes excede the rightousnes of the Scribes and Phariseis, ye can not enter into the kyngedome of heauen.
column8: Except your righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, you can not enter into the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: Ye haue hard that it was sayd vnto the of olde tyme: <NOTE> Thou shalt not kill: whosoeuer kylleth, shalbe in daunger of iudgmet.
column8: You have hard that it was said unto the of old time: Thou shalt not kill: whosoever killeth, shall in danger of Judgment.

column7: But I saye vnto you, that whosoeuer ys angry with hys brother vnaduisedly, shalbe in daunger of iudgmet.
column8: But I say unto you, that whosoever is angry with his brother unadvisedly, shall in danger of Judgment.

column7: And whosoeuer sayth vnto hys brother,
column8: And whosoever say unto his brother,

column7: Racha, shalbe in dauger of a counsayle.
column8: Racha, shall in dauger of a counsel.

column7: But whosoeuer sayth, Thou foole, shalbe in daunger of hell fyer.
column8: But whosoever say, Thou fool, shall in danger of hell fire.

column7: Therefore, yf thou offerest thy gifte at the aultare, and ther remebrest that thy brother hath ought against the leaue there thyne offerynge before the aultare,
column8: Therefore, if thou offerest thy gift At the altar, and their remebrest that thy brother hath ought against the leave there thine offering before the altar,

column7: <NOTE> and go thy waye fyrste, and be reconcyled to thy brother, and than come and offre thy gyfte. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: and go thy Way First, and be reconciled to thy brother, and than come and offer thy gift. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: F Orasmuche as oure lorde Iesus Christe deuideth his righteousnes, fro the righteousnes of the scribes and phariseis, <NOTE> it is to be noted, that ther is two righteousnesses, yt is to say, the righteousnes of workes, and the righteousnes of fayth.
column8: Forasmuch Forasmuch as our lord jesus Christ Divideth his righteousness, from the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, it is to be noted, that there is two Righteousness, that is to say, the righteousness of works, and the righteousness of faith.

column7: The righteousnes of works is, when I intende and go aboute to do workes withoute fayth in Christ, thinking that by suche outward workes, the law is fulfilled.
column8: The righteousness of works is, when I intend and go about to do works without faith in christ, thinking that by such outward works, the law is fulfilled.

column7: And suche righteousnes did the Iewes vse for the moste party, and in especiall the scribes and phariseis.
column8: And such righteousness did the Jews use for the most party, and in especial the Scribes and Pharisees.

column7: For the flesh, wherin is graft hipocrisye, is so affectioned and of suche nature,
column8: For the Flesh, wherein is grafted hypocrisy, is so affectioned and of such nature,

column7: that nothinge can please yt so excellentlye, as the outward shine of workes, and it canne haue none other iudgemente herein, then that suche workes are acceptable before god, and that the same are rewarded with euerlasting life.
column8: that nothing can please that so excellently, as the outward shine of works, and it can have none other judgement herein, then that such works Are acceptable before god, and that the same Are rewarded with everlasting life.

column7: Hereof commeth this damnable and detestable truste in workes, with the whiche the holye prophetes haue so warred and foughten:
column8: Hereof comes this damnable and detestable trust in works, with the which the holy Prophets have so warred and foughten:

column7: <NOTE> and especiall Esaias, complaininge on the Iewes, bicause that they did worshippe the works of their owne handes.
column8: and especial Isaiah, complaining on the Jews, Because that they did worship the works of their own hands.

column7: And in an other place he saith:
column8: And in an other place he Says:

column7: This people draweth nigh me with their mouth, and praiseth me highely with their lyppes, where as their harte neuertheles is farre frome me.
column8: This people draws High me with their Mouth, and Praiseth me highly with their lips, where as their heart nevertheless is Far from me.

column7: But how doth Christ lyke this righteousnes?
column8: But how does christ like this righteousness?

column7: Truly he thrusteth it into the deep pit of hell, in so much that hee denieth his disciples the entringe into the kingedome of heauen, excepte theyr righteousnes excede the rightousnes of the scribes and pharises.
column8: Truly he thrusts it into the deep pit of hell, in so much that he Denieth his Disciples the entering into the Kingdom of heaven, except their righteousness exceed the righteousness of the Scribes and Pharisees.

column7: How could this rightousnes of the Iewes be more contemptuously depressed?
column8: How could this righteousness of the Jews be more contemptuously depressed?

column7: If our spiritual men in tyme paste, and so likewise nowe a dayes, were, and had beene so iudged and condemned vnto hell for their hypocrisy, good lord,
column8: If our spiritual men in time past, and so likewise now a days, were, and had been so judged and condemned unto hell for their hypocrisy, good lord,

column7: I thinke for very pure angre, they wolde spewe out tier.
column8: I think for very pure anger, they would spew out tier.

column7: But the spirite of Christe which is sent to rebuke the world of this in credulity, setteth little by their threatnynges, and angre.
column8: But the Spirit of Christ which is sent to rebuke the world of this in credulity, sets little by their threatnynges, and anger.

column7: <NOTE> The righteousnes of faith is, when I hope and truste in Christ, and not in workes, but in such wise, that I open and declare my selfe in the meanewhile to haue this truste and confidence, throughe fulfilling of his comaundementes & good workes.
column8: The righteousness of faith is, when I hope and trust in christ, and not in works, but in such wise, that I open and declare my self in the meanwhile to have this trust and confidence, through fulfilling of his Commandments & good works.

column7: And suche righteousnes, is the worke of the spirite,
column8: And such righteousness, is the work of the Spirit,

column7: and can not be compreheded nor vnderstand of the flesh.
column8: and can not be compreheded nor understand of the Flesh.

column7: And forbicause she geueth god his honour,
column8: And For because she Giveth god his honour,

column7: & looketh and trusteth allonly in his grace and mercy whiche is giuen vs, in, and by Christe, therefore she pleaseth and is so acceptable before god, that she is suer to haue euerlastinge life.
column8: & looks and Trusteth allonly in his grace and mercy which is given us, in, and by Christ, Therefore she Pleases and is so acceptable before god, that she is sure to have everlasting life.

column7: <NOTE> Marke that this inwarde righteousnes canne in no wise consiste or be without charity and good workes, and withoute an honeste lyfe or conuersacion.
column8: Mark that this inward righteousness can in no wise consist or be without charity and good works, and without an honest life or Conversation.

column7: For it is the same good seede, that fel in the good ground,
column8: For it is the same good seed, that fell in the good ground,

column7: & brought forth muche frute.
column8: & brought forth much fruit.

column7: Againe contrary wise, the outewarde righteousnes, as a worke of the fleshe, may be done without the righteousnes of faythe, as we see in the phariseis,
column8: Again contrary wise, the outward righteousness, as a work of the Flesh, may be done without the righteousness of faith, as we see in the Pharisees,

column7: <NOTE> whiche be likened vnto painted sepulchres, that apeare beutyfull outward,
column8: which be likened unto painted sepulchres, that appear beutyfull outward,

column7: & with in are full of deade mens bones and filthines.
column8: & with in Are full of dead men's bones and filthiness.

column7: But thou wilte say vnto me:
column8: But thou wilt say unto me:

column7: Doth not Christe himselfe here call the righteousnes of the phariseis, a righteousnes?
column8: Does not Christ himself Here call the righteousness of the Pharisees, a righteousness?

column7: Yes, <NOTE> but bicause god hathe not respecte of persones, that is, he careth not so much for the outwarde shininge of thinges, as he dothe require the harte, faith and spirite, therfore he attributeth and giueth euerlastinge lyfe vnto the inwarde righteousnes, forasmuche as the same neuer seeketh nothing so muche, as the glorye of Christe.
column8: Yes, but Because god hath not respect of Persons, that is, he Careth not so much for the outward shining of things, as he doth require the heart, faith and Spirit, Therefore he attributeth and gives everlasting life unto the inward righteousness, forasmuch as the same never seeks nothing so much, as the glory of Christ.

column7: And to the hipocrisye of the phariseis, he hathe assured euerlasting damnacion.
column8: And to the hypocrisy of the Pharisees, he hath assured everlasting damnation.

column7: Secondarily, Christ proueth by a declaracion of a comaundemet take out of the law, yt the exterior & outward rightousnes is not acceptable nor of valu before god, wtout we haue ioyned theruto ye inward rightousnes, which procedeth from the harte.
column8: Secondarily, christ Proves by a declaration of a comaundemet take out of the law, that the exterior & outward righteousness is not acceptable nor of valu before god, without we have joined theruto you inward righteousness, which Proceedeth from the heart.

column7: Yee haue harde (saith he) how it was saide to theim of olde tyme:
column8: Ye have harden (Says he) how it was said to them of old time:

column7: Thou shalte not kill, for whosoeuer killeth, shalbe in daunger of iudgement.
column8: Thou shalt not kill, for whosoever kills, shall in danger of judgement.

column7: But I saye vnto you:
column8: But I say unto you:

column7: Whosoeuer is angry with his brother, is in daunger of iudgement.
column8: Whosoever is angry with his brother, is in danger of judgement.

column7: &c. Likewise also Saint Paule saith:
column8: etc. Likewise also Saint Paul Says:

column7: <NOTE> The law is spirituall that is, the lawe cannot be fulfilled, excepte the spirite, faith and the harte, be ioyned with the outwarde workes, seynge that the lawe requireth not allonly the outward fashion, but also the affection of the harte.
column8: The law is spiritual that is, the law cannot be fulfilled, except the Spirit, faith and the heart, be joined with the outward works, sing that the law requires not allonly the outward fashion, but also the affection of the heart.

column7: Therfore Christe in this commaunde mente that pertayneth to man slaughter, maketh foure degrees, wherein hee counteth giltye, not allonly those, that kyll and slaye with the swearde, but also all them, that with thought and worde sinne against their neighboure.
column8: Therefore Christ in this command mente that pertaineth to man slaughter, makes foure Degrees, wherein he counteth guilty, not allonly those, that kill and slay with the sword, but also all them, that with Thought and word sin against their neighbour.

column7: <NOTE> The firste degree is the anger of the harte, which Christe doth lyken vnto the outwarde worke of man slaughter.
column8: The First degree is the anger of the heart, which Christ does liken unto the outward work of man slaughter.

column7: And forasmuche as this angre is grafte in euery one of vs, no man canne kepe this comaundement and precept, except he be new borne againe through the spirit.
column8: And forasmuch as this anger is graft in every one of us, no man can keep this Commandment and precept, except he be new born again through the Spirit.

column7: The second degre is, Racha,
column8: The second degree is, Racha,

column7: <NOTE> by which worde is signified, tokens of wrathe and hatred:
column8: by which word is signified, tokens of wrath and hatred:

column7: that is, when I beholde my brother wyth a lowrynge and a grimme countinaunce, or passynge by, do disdaine to speake familiarlye vnto him.
column8: that is, when I behold my brother with a lowering and a grim countinaunce, or passing by, do disdain to speak familiarly unto him.

column7: And those outwarde misfashioned manners dooe condemne euen as muche as the deede it selfe.
column8: And those outward misfashioned manners do condemn even as much as the deed it self.

column7: The thirde degree is, if I call my brother;
column8: The Third degree is, if I call my brother;

column7: Foole: <NOTE> By whiche worde is signified and vnderstande all manner of opprobrious and ignominious wordes, and those wordes yf they come oute of rancoure and malyce, they condempne me as well as man slaughter.
column8: Fool: By which word is signified and understand all manner of opprobrious and ignominious words, and those words if they come out of rancour and malice, they condemn me as well as man slaughter.

column7: But it is possible also, that such iniurious wordes, ofte times procede of a faithful hart, as we see that the pharise is were called fooles often tymes of Christe,
column8: But it is possible also, that such injurious words, oft times proceed of a faithful heart, as we see that the Pharisee is were called Fools often times of Christ,

column7: <NOTE> and that is nother hurtefull nor damnable.
column8: and that is neither hurtful nor damnable.

column7: The fourth degre is man slaughter, euen committed with the deede, that is, when I not being contente with mine iniurious and opprobrious words, and straunge vncorteous countenauce, but go farther to handstrokes,
column8: The fourth degree is man slaughter, even committed with the deed, that is, when I not being content with mine injurious and opprobrious words, and strange vncorteous countenance, but go farther to handstrokes,

column7: & with my hande (as did Cain) I kil my neighbour against the comaundemente and precepte of god.
column8: & with my hand (as did Cain) I kill my neighbour against the comaundemente and precept of god.

column7: <NOTE> Nowe for as muche as god in his preceptes doth not allonly forbid the outeward vngracious workes, but also the inward mischiefe and affection of the harte, howe is it then possible, that the outewarde righteousnes can saue and iustifye?
column8: Now for as much as god in his Precepts does not allonly forbid the outward ungracious works, but also the inward mischief and affection of the heart, how is it then possible, that the outward righteousness can save and justify?

column7: Surely hereto pertayneth the saying of S.
column8: Surely hereto pertaineth the saying of S.

column7: Ioh. He that hateth hys brother, <NOTE> is a murtherer. that is,
column8: John He that hates his brother, is a murderer. that is,

column7: It is not sufficient that thou haste not killed thy brother with thy hande, but thou muste haue a louinge and gentle harte towarde all men, not to dooe and wishe well allonlye to thy friendes, but also to thine enemyes.
column8: It is not sufficient that thou haste not killed thy brother with thy hand, but thou must have a loving and gentle heart toward all men, not to do and wish well allonlye to thy Friends, but also to thine enemies.

column7: Finallye. If I desire to be saued, so it is needefull that I be iuste & righteous, both inwardely and outwardely, or else outewarde righteousnesse profyteth the nothynge at all.
column8: Finally. If I desire to be saved, so it is needful that I be just & righteous, both inwardly and outwardly, or Else outward righteousness profiteth thee nothing At all.

column7: Thyrdely, Christ exhorteth & allureth vs here in this gospel to ye loue of oure neighbour, forasmuch as he hath referred this precepte, (Thou shalt not kyll) to the loue of oure brother, and that two manner of wayes.
column8: Thirdly, christ exhorteth & Allureth us Here in this gospel to you love of our neighbour, forasmuch as he hath referred this precept, (Thou shalt not kill) to the love of our brother, and that two manner of ways.

column7: Firste, for as muche as hee teacheth that no worke (how good or precious so euer it be) canne please God, excepte that thou do firste desire thy brother, whome thou haste offended, to pardon and forgiue the.
column8: First, for as much as he Teaches that no work (how good or precious so ever it be) can please God, except that thou do First desire thy brother, whom thou haste offended, to pardon and forgive thee.

column7: Therefore he maketh mention of all oblation commaunded of God in the olde lawe, which is nowe abrogated, and was then a hyghe excellente worke.
column8: Therefore he makes mention of all oblation commanded of God in the old law, which is now abrogated, and was then a high excellent work.

column7: This is the meaning of the wordes of Christe.
column8: This is the meaning of the words of Christ.

column7: If you dooe obserue with neuer so greate diligence, all goddes seruice, whiche heretofore hath beene commaunded you through Moises which nowe after my death shall cease and take no more effecte, yet in that shall ye not please god, excepte you be reconciled to your brother, whome you haue offended.
column8: If you do observe with never so great diligence, all God's service, which heretofore hath been commanded you through Moses which now After my death shall cease and take no more Effect, yet in that shall you not please god, except you be reconciled to your brother, whom you have offended.

column7: For it is not seruinge of god, when thou offendest thy neighboure, but that is called seruyng of god, when thou offendest not thy neighboure.
column8: For it is not serving of god, when thou offendest thy neighbour, but that is called serving of god, when thou offendest not thy neighbour.

column7: For that that, thou doest with hinderaunce of thy brother, cannot please god.
column8: For that that, thou dost with hindrance of thy brother, cannot please god.

column7: Therefore God through the prophete Oseas speaketh,
column8: Therefore God through the Prophet Hosea speaks,

column7: <NOTE> sayinge: I will haue mercy, and not sacrifice.
column8: saying: I will have mercy, and not sacrifice.

column7: Truly, oblacion was commaunded in the lawe by god, yet did he not set by yt, yf thou diddest offende thy neighbour, excepte he that had offended his brother, did fyrste reconcyle himselfe.
column8: Truly, oblation was commanded in the law by god, yet did he not Set by that, if thou didst offend thy neighbour, except he that had offended his brother, did First reconcile himself.

column7: And as Christe speaketh of oblacion vnto the Iewes, as vnto those whiche as yet were vnder the lawe, so likewise, goddes seruyce in the newe testament, is to no purpose, except thou be recociled to thy brother, whom thou hast offeded.
column8: And as Christ speaks of oblation unto the Jews, as unto those which as yet were under the law, so likewise, God's service in the new Testament, is to no purpose, except thou be recociled to thy brother, whom thou hast offended.

column7: Secondarily, Christe warneth vs here to agree with our aduersary, quickly, while we are in ye way with him.
column8: Secondarily, Christ warneth us Here to agree with our adversary, quickly, while we Are in the Way with him.

column7: &c. That is, if any man offend the, and he that hath offended the, desireth the to pardon him, forgiue him gladly, as Christ did, saiyng:
column8: etc. That is, if any man offend thee, and he that hath offended thee, Desires thee to pardon him, forgive him gladly, as christ did, saying:

column7: Father forgiue them, for they knowe not what they do.
column8: Father forgive them, for they know not what they do.

column7: And if you be not desired therunto, yet be alwaies readye to forgiue, or else thy conscience in the day of iugemente shall accuse the, and so thou shalt be caste into prison.
column8: And if you be not desired thereunto, yet be always ready to forgive, or Else thy conscience in the day of judgement shall accuse thee, and so thou shalt be cast into prison.

column7: <NOTE> Verely I say vnto you (saith Christ) thou shalt not come out thence, tyll thou haue payed the vttermost farthing, that is,
column8: Verily I say unto you (Says christ) thou shalt not come out thence, till thou have paid the uttermost farthing, that is,

column7: Thou shalt neuer come out.
column8: Thou shalt never come out.

column7: For this word, vntil, so signifieth in this place.
column8: For this word, until, so signifies in this place.

column7: Therfore let euery christia ma well considre & take heede, that he be founde in brotherly loue, so that his workes, whiche he serueth god withall, may be acceptable and pleasaunte before god, throughe Christ our sauiour.
column8: Therefore let every christian ma well Consider & take heed, that he be found in brotherly love, so that his works, which he serveth god withal, may be acceptable and pleasant before god, through christ our Saviour.

column7: Amen. The seuenth sonday after trinitye sonday. Mark. 8.
column8: Amen. The Seventh Sunday After trinity Sunday. Mark. 8.

column8: IN those days when there was a very great company,

column8: jesus called his Disciples to him, and said unto them:

column8: I have Compassion on the people, Because they have now been with me three days, and have nothing to eat:

column8: and if I send them away fasting to their own houses, they shall faint by the Way.

column8: For diverse of them Come from Far.

column8: And he asked them: how many loaves have you?

column8: They said: seuen. And he commanded the people to fit down on the ground.

column7: And he tooke the seuen loaues:
column8: And he took the seuen loaves:

column8: And they did Set them before the people.

column8: And they had a few small fishes.

column8: And they did eat, and were sufficed.

column8: And they took up of the broken meat that was left, seuen baskets full.
