column7: We haue treated of this gospel vpon the fourth sonday in lente, oute of the syxte chapter of Iohn, whiche shall agree well herevnto also, that allonly excepted, that there is fiue loues and two fishes, & fiue thousande menne,
column8: We have treated of this gospel upon the fourth Sunday in Lente, out of the Sixth chapter of John, which shall agree well hereunto also, that allonly excepted, that there is fiue loves and two Fish, & fiue thousande men,

column7: And here seuen loues and a fewe fishes, and four thousande men, which Christ did feed.
column8: And Here seuen loves and a few Fish, and four thousande men, which christ did feed.

column7: This thing also is to be noted, that there Christe spake allonly vnto Philip, and here vnto all the apostels.
column8: This thing also is to be noted, that there Christ spoke allonly unto Philip, and Here unto all the Apostles.

column7: Looke vppon the exposition. The gospell on the eight sonday after trinitye son. daye. Math. 7.
column8: Look upon the exposition. The gospel on the eight Sunday After trinity son. day. Math. 7.

column7: <NOTE> B Eware of false prophetes, which come to you in sheepes clothyng, but inwardly they are rauenyng wolues, ye shall knowe them by there frutes.
column8: BEware BEware of false Prophets, which come to you in Sheep clothing, but inwardly they Are ravening wolves, you shall know them by there fruits.

column7: <NOTE> Do men gather grapes of thornes?
column8: Do men gather grapes of thorns?

column7: or fygges of thystles? Euen so euerye good tree bringeth forth good frutes.
column8: or figs of thystles? Eve so every good tree brings forth good fruits.

column7: But a corrupt tre bringeth forth euell frutes.
column8: But a corrupt Tree brings forth evil fruits.

column7: <NOTE> A good tree cannot brynge forth bad frutes:
column8: A good tree cannot bring forth bad fruits:

column7: neyther can a bad tree brynge sorthe good frutes.
column8: neither can a bad tree bring forth good fruits.

column7: <NOTE> Euery tre that bringeth not forth good frute, is heue doune, and caste into the fyer.
column8: Every Tree that brings not forth good fruit, is heaven down, and cast into the fire.

column7: Wherefore by theyr frutes yee shall knowe them.
column8: Wherefore by their fruits ye shall know them.

column7: Not euery one that sayeth vnto me <NOTE> Lorde, lorde, shall entre into the kyngdome of heauen, but he that doth the wyll of my father whiche is in heauen, he shall entre into the kyngdome of heauen. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Not every one that Saith unto me Lord, lord, shall enter into the Kingdom of heaven, but he that does the will of my father which is in heaven, he shall enter into the Kingdom of heaven. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: WE haue here in this gospel a good admonition yt we shuld beware of false prophets.
column8: WE have Here in this gospel a good admonition that we should beware of false Prophets.

column7: For yt is comoly seen, that those be alwais mixt with the good and faithful preachers.
column8: For that is comoly seen, that those be always mixed with the good and faithful Preachers.

column7: And in this admonityon Christe hym selfe dothe lyke a good shephearde.
column8: And in this admonityon Christ him self doth like a good shepherd.

column7: <NOTE> For a wise and a diligente shepharde dothe not onlye leade his sheepe into an holsome pasture, but also dilligentlye taketh heede that they be not taken and deuoured of the wolues.
column8: For a wise and a diligent shepharde doth not only lead his sheep into an wholesome pasture, but also diligently Takes heed that they be not taken and devoured of the wolves.

column7: In lyke manner muste a dilligente preacher do.
column8: In like manner must a dilligente preacher do.

column7: He muste instructe and bringe vp the churche committed vnto his charge, withe the holsome doctrine of Christe, and take heede, that hee instructeth not the people with none other doctrine but onlye with the puer word of god.
column8: He must instruct and bring up the Church committed unto his charge, with the wholesome Doctrine of Christ, and take heed, that he Instructeth not the people with none other Doctrine but only with the puer word of god.

column7: For Christ said vnto Peter:
column8: For christ said unto Peter:

column7: <NOTE> Feed my sheepe. and not satisfied with the once rehersall thereof, he repeted the same comaundemet, wherby it might be perceaued how feruentely he desyred the wealth of his shepe.
column8: Feed my sheep. and not satisfied with the once rehearsal thereof, he repeated the same comaundemet, whereby it might be perceived how feruentely he desired the wealth of his sheep.

column7: This done, the pastour ought diligentlye to looke aboute hym, that the flocke of Christe be not seduced and deceyued by false prophetes, which teache peruerse doctrine, contrarye to the holsome doctrine of Christe.
column8: This done, the pastor ought diligently to look about him, that the flock of Christ be not seduced and deceived by false Prophets, which teach perverse Doctrine, contrary to the wholesome Doctrine of Christ.

column7: But that pointe belongeth not allonlye to the pastor and preacher, but also it behoueth euerye christian manne to bee so instructed in things pertainyng to faith, that he by the word of god may iudge, whether he be right taught or no.
column8: But that point belongeth not allonlye to the pastor and preacher, but also it behooves every christian man to be so instructed in things pertaining to faith, that he by the word of god may judge, whither he be right taught or no.

column7: For thikest thou yt this power to iudg euery preachers doctrine, was giuen the of Christe in vaine?
column8: For thikest thou that this power to judge every Preachers Doctrine, was given the of Christ in vain?

column7: <NOTE> Or thinkest thou that Paule commaunded the Thessalonians in vaine, to proue all thinges, and keepe that, whiche was good?
column8: Or Thinkest thou that Paul commanded the Thessalonians in vain, to prove all things, and keep that, which was good?

column7: <NOTE> And also S. Iohn writeth, that we shulde proue the spirites whether they bee of God.
column8: And also S. John Writeth, that we should prove the spirits whither they be of God.

column7: Wherefore seynge that many false prophets are gone into the world, beleue verelye, that this libertye to iudge, is giuen the for somewhat.
column8: Wherefore sing that many false Prophets Are gone into the world, believe verily, that this liberty to judge, is given the for somewhat.

column7: For the diuell is subtyle, and is an extreme enemy of holsome doctrine, and such a one, that hathe in his kyngedome nothynge then lyes,
column8: For the Devil is subtle, and is an extreme enemy of wholesome Doctrine, and such a one, that hath in his Kingdom nothing then lies,

column7: <NOTE> and murdre, whiche hee bringeth in vnder a coloure of holynes.
column8: and murder, which he brings in under a colour of holiness.

column7: For hee canne chaunge hymselfe into the fashion of an aungell of lyghte, so that (yf it were possible) he shulde deceaue and seduce the verye electe of God.
column8: For he can change himself into the fashion of an angel of Light, so that (if it were possible) he should deceive and seduce the very elect of God.

column7: And no manne knoweth this better then Christe, whiche teacheth vs so earnestlye to beware of theim, whiche also painteth the minysters of Satan in theire owne coloures.
column8: And no man Knoweth this better then Christ, which Teaches us so earnestly to beware of them, which also painteth the Ministers of Satan in their own colours.

column7: Wherefore, lette vs take to harte this his faithfull monition.
column8: Wherefore, let us take to heart this his faithful monition.

column7: But howe and with what coloures dothe he describe theym?
column8: But how and with what colours doth he describe them?

column7: <NOTE> He calleth theym prophetes, whereby he declareth, that they shal vse the office of preachinge.
column8: He calls them Prophets, whereby he Declareth, that they shall use the office of preaching.

column7: For to prophecye, signifieth other whyle, to teache and to interprete holy scripture, as we fynde in the 14. chapiter of Saint Paule, in the firste epist. to the Corinthians.
column8: For to prophecy, signifies other while, to teach and to interpret holy scripture, as we find in the 14. chapter of Saint Paul, in the First Epistle. to the Corinthians.

column7: More ouer hee sayeth: <NOTE> They shall come in sheepes clothinge,
column8: More over he Saith: They shall come in Sheep clothing,

column7: That is, they shall come in greate and angelicall meekenes, and withoute all pride, hauinge outwardly the shine of holines, but inwardly they are rauening wolues, euen the destroyers of the lordes flocke.
column8: That is, they shall come in great and angelical meekness, and without all pride, having outwardly the shine of holiness, but inwardly they Are ravening wolves, even the destroyers of the Lords flock.

column7: Now forasmuch as we shall haue such in the ministery of the worde of god, whose outwarde conuersacion shall apeare as most simple and holy, therefore it is necessarye, that wee note and printe in our mindes this doctryne of Christe, wherby we maye auoyde theym, and daily pray vnto god, that he wil vouchsafe to retaine vs in holsome doctrine, and preserue vs from the vaine ianglynge of these false prophetes.
column8: Now forasmuch as we shall have such in the Ministry of the word of god, whose outward Conversation shall appear as most simple and holy, Therefore it is necessary, that we note and print in our minds this Doctrine of Christ, whereby we may avoid them, and daily pray unto god, that he will vouchsafe to retain us in wholesome Doctrine, and preserve us from the vain jangling of these false Prophets.

column7: Secondarily, it is to be noted, that Christe doth not all onlye instructe vs to beware of false prophetes, but also telleth vs howe wee shall knowe theym.
column8: Secondarily, it is to be noted, that Christ does not all only instruct us to beware of false Prophets, but also Telleth us how we shall know them.

column7: Yee shall knowe theym (sayeth hee) by theyr frutes.
column8: Ye shall know them (Saith he) by their fruits.

column7: Whiche thinge, that he myght driue into vs the better, hee putteth forthe a similitude, and sayeth on this wise:
column8: Which thing, that he might driven into us the better, he putteth forth a similitude, and Saith on this wise:

column7: Do menne gather grapes of thornes?
column8: Do men gather grapes of thorns?

column7: or fygges of thystelles? As thoughe he wolde saye:
column8: or figs of thystelles? As though he would say:

column7: Howe possible it is to gather grapes of thornes, or figges of thystles, so possible it is, that a false prophete, in whome the knowledge of god is not, shulde teache anye good thynge, thoughe hee neuer so muche gloryfye hym selfe in the knowledge of the worde of god.
column8: How possible it is to gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thystles, so possible it is, that a false Prophet, in whom the knowledge of god is not, should teach any good thing, though he never so much Glorify him self in the knowledge of the word of god.

column7: A false prophete maye boaste and gloryfye him selfe of the gospell, but the trewe doctrine of the faith, he shal neuer attayne nor folow.
column8: A false Prophet may boast and Glorify him self of the gospel, but the true Doctrine of the faith, he shall never attain nor follow.

column7: All that they haue taught with theyr vaine ianglinge, are but leaues, and remayne leaues, hauinge only an outeward shining.
column8: All that they have taught with their vain jangling, Are but leaves, and remain leaves, having only an outward shining.

column7: And for to knowe these false prophetes, and theyr spirite,
column8: And for to know these false Prophets, and their Spirit,

column7: It is needefull to haue the holye spirit and perfecte knoweledge of God.
column8: It is needful to have the holy Spirit and perfect knowledge of God.

column7: Wherefore wee christian menne, whyche in this daungerous tyme are assaulted with thys pestiferous and straunge learnyng, must so indeuoure our selues,
column8: Wherefore we christian men, which in this dangerous time Are assaulted with this pestiferous and strange learning, must so endeavour our selves,

column7: <NOTE> that fayth and charity, wherin consisteth the hole summe and foundacion of oure doctrine, maye euer bee oure rule, whereby we maye discerne and iudge all manner of doctrine, that shall bee layde before vs.
column8: that faith and charity, wherein Consisteth the hold sum and Foundation of our Doctrine, may ever be our Rule, whereby we may discern and judge all manner of Doctrine, that shall be laid before us

column7: For faythe cleaueth allonlye to the worde of god, and sayeth wyth Saincte Paule.
column8: For faith cleaveth allonlye to the word of god, and Saith with Saint Paul.

column7: I knowe nothinge but Iesus Christ, <NOTE> and hym crucified. that is,
column8: I know nothing but jesus christ, and him Crucified. that is,

column7: I seeke remission of sinnes, righteousnes and saluacion allonlye in the passion and merytes of Christe.
column8: I seek remission of Sins, righteousness and salvation allonlye in the passion and merits of Christ.

column7: And charitie, with the deede and worke, witnesseth suche fayth to be in the harte.
column8: And charity, with the deed and work, Witnesseth such faith to be in the heart.

column7: And what so euer is contrarye to this doctrine of faythe and charitie, commeth of the diuell, thoughe they that teache so, in their so teachinge, leade neuer so relygious a lyfe.
column8: And what so ever is contrary to this Doctrine of faith and charity, comes of the Devil, though they that teach so, in their so teaching, lead never so religious a life.

column7: For the tree is euell, and so likewise is the frute euell:
column8: For the tree is evil, and so likewise is the fruit evil:

column7: Shall we iudge nowe some trees by theyr frutes?
column8: Shall we judge now Some trees by their fruits?

column7: The papistes haue a longe season had the handlyng and administracion of the worde of god and the sacramentes,
column8: The Papists have a long season had the handling and administration of the word of god and the Sacraments,

column7: <NOTE> with so great shyne of holines outwardli, ye thei haue nigh subiected vnto them the whole world.
column8: with so great shine of holiness outwardli, you they have High subjected unto them the Whole world.

column7: But now that the gospell is broken out & come to lyght, through the greatinercy of god, it hath geuen vs power to know the tree by the fruicte thereof, throughe goddes worde.
column8: But now that the gospel is broken out & come to Light, through the greatinercy of god, it hath given us power to know the tree by the fruit thereof, through God's word.

column7: Now we haue the word of god, which we set against their doctrine, concerning works, and we find their learning to striue & be repugnat with the manifest worde of god, and to bringe nothinge to passe, but hipocrisy.
column8: Now we have the word of god, which we Set against their Doctrine, Concerning works, and we find their learning to strive & be repugnat with the manifest word of god, and to bring nothing to pass, but hypocrisy.

column7: Therfore according to their frutes, we reproue and abiect the whole papasie with all that belongeth vnto it, yea if the diuel rage neuer so much:
column8: Therefore according to their fruits, we reprove and abject the Whole papacy with all that belongeth unto it, yea if the Devil rage never so much:

column7: We reproue & detest also those spriteful me, whiche wt their Masses & supersticion haue abused ye supper instituted by Christ, contrary to the manifest words of Christe.
column8: We reprove & detest also those spriteful me, which with their Masses & Superstition have abused you supper instituted by christ, contrary to the manifest words of Christ.

column7: Yea, we reproue theim for the fruicte of their doctrine:
column8: Yea, we reprove them for the fruit of their Doctrine:

column7: For besides the false expoundinge & laiyng out of Christes wordes, they haue brought the sacramentes into greate abusion.
column8: For beside the false expounding & laying out of Christ's words, they have brought the Sacraments into great abusion.

column7: What shall I saye of the anabaptistes?
column8: What shall I say of the Anabaptists?

column7: I wolde to god the vngracious frute of their doctrine were not so manyfest.
column8: I would to god the ungracious fruit of their Doctrine were not so manifest.

column7: To make short, we haue the clear and manifest gospell, by the greate grace of god in our hartes receaued, wherein by his mercye we shall abide, whe all the false prophetes shall go to the diuel.
column8: To make short, we have the clear and manifest gospel, by the great grace of god in our hearts received, wherein by his mercy we shall abide, when all the false Prophets shall go to the Devil.

column7: Thirdelye, Christe expoundeth these wordes (by theyr frutes ye shall knowe theim) euen as he wold haue theim vnderstanded, making a difference betwene hipocrites and those that fulfill his fathers will, and declareth both their rewardes.
column8: Thirdly, Christ expoundeth these words (by their fruits you shall know them) even as he would have them understanded, making a difference between Hypocrites and those that fulfil his Father's will, and Declareth both their rewards.

column7: The iustifiers and glorifiers in workes crye euer,
column8: The Justifiers and glorifiers in works cry ever,

column7: Lord, Lord and that more is, they glorifie in the gospell, and in the holy ghoste. yea and are so bold, that they dare saye:
column8: Lord, Lord and that more is, they Glorify in the gospel, and in the holy ghost. yea and Are so bold, that they Dare say:

column7: Lorde haue wee not prophecied in thy name:
column8: Lord have we not prophesied in thy name:

column7: haue we not caste out diuels in thy name?
column8: have we not cast out Devils in thy name?

column7: &c. But it is but hypocrisye,
column8: etc. But it is but hypocrisy,

column7: & remaineth hypocrisye, for the whiche they haue no rewarde.
column8: & remains hypocrisy, for the which they have no reward.

column7: For Christe sayeth: Depart from me, ye workers of iniquitie,
column8: For Christ Saith: Depart from me, you workers of iniquity,

column7: I knowe you not. And fayth in this present gospell:
column8: I know you not. And faith in this present gospel:

column7: Euerye tree that bringeth not forth good frute, shalbe hewen downe, and caste in to the fier.
column8: Every tree that brings not forth good fruit, shall hewn down, and cast in to the fire.

column7: Beholde with what rewarde the frute of false doctrine shal be rewarded with all.
column8: Behold with what reward the fruit of false Doctrine shall be rewarded with all.

column7: And againe considre what maner of folke shall entre into the kingedome of heauen.
column8: And again Consider what manner of folk shall enter into the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: Those (saith Christ) that fulfil the will of my father that is in heauen.
column8: Those (Says christ) that fulfil the will of my father that is in heaven.

column7: But what is the wil of the father in heauen?
column8: But what is the will of the father in heaven?

column7: That we shulde beleue in him,
column8: That we should believe in him,

column7: <NOTE> whome he hathe sente.
column8: whom he hath sent.

column7: Here thou doest heare, that the kingdome of god is promised not to fained workes, but to those that haue fayth in Christ.
column8: Here thou dost hear, that the Kingdom of god is promised not to feigned works, but to those that have faith in christ.

column7: We do not speak here of an historical faith (as the call it) but of that fayth that commeth by hearynge of the gospell, the whiche also the holye ghoste worketh in vs.
column8: We do not speak Here of an historical faith (as the call it) but of that faith that comes by hearing of the gospel, the which also the holy ghost works in us

column7: This fayth lyke as it obtayneth the grace and mercye of god in Christe, and setteth all his truste in him, and finallye seeketh his rigteousnesse allonly in the merites of Christe, so likewise it worketh & doth good workes throughe loue, and causeth vs to mortefye the olde Adame in vs, and dye vnto all creatures, he prayeth, prayseth and comendeth god, withe giuinge thankes, in what so euer state and degree he is in.
column8: This faith like as it obtaineth the grace and mercy of god in Christ, and sets all his trust in him, and finally seeks his Righteousness allonly in the merits of Christ, so likewise it works & does good works through love, and Causes us to mortefye the old Adam in us, and die unto all creatures, he Prayeth, Praiseth and commendeth god, with giving thanks, in what so ever state and degree he is in.

column7: Finallye, he lyueth accordinge to the wyll of god, and throughe Christe shall hee obtayne euerlastinge lyfe.
column8: Finally, he liveth according to the will of god, and through Christ shall he obtain everlasting life.

column7: Whiche god graunte vs all.
column8: Which god grant us all.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the nynthe sondaye after trinitye sondaye. Luc. 16.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the nynthe Sunday After trinity Sunday. Luke 16.

column7: A Nd he sayd also vnto hys disciples:
column8: ANd ANd he said also unto his Disciples:

column7: Ther was a certayne ryche man, which hadde a stewarde, and the same was accused vnto hym, that hee hadde wasted hys goodes.
column8: There was a certain rich man, which had a steward, and the same was accused unto him, that he had wasted his goods.

column7: And he called him, and sayde vnto hym:
column8: And he called him, and said unto him:

column7: Howe is it that I heare thus of the?
column8: How is it that I hear thus of thee?

column7: Gyue accompte of thy stewardeshyppe:
column8: Gyve accompt of thy stewardeshyppe:

column7: for thou mayest be no lenger stewarde.
column8: for thou Mayest be no longer steward.

column7: The stewarde sayde within hym selfe:
column8: The steward said within him self:

column7: What shall I do? For my mayster taketh awaye frome me the stewarshyppe:
column8: What shall I do? For my master Takes away from me the stewarshyppe:

column7: I can not digge and to begge I am ashamed.
column8: I can not dig and to beg I am ashamed.

column7: I wote what to dooe, that when I am putte pute of the stewarde shyppe, they maye receaue me into theyr houses:
column8: I wot what to do, that when I am put pute of the steward ship, they may receive me into their houses:

column7: So when he hadde called all hys maysters detters togither, hee sayd vnto the fyrste:
column8: So when he had called all his masters debtors together, he said unto the First:

column7: Howe much owest thou vnto my maister?
column8: How much owest thou unto my master?

column7: And he sayde, an hundreth tunnes of oyle.
column8: And he said, an Hundredth tons of oil.

column7: And he sayd vnto hym:
column8: And he said unto him:

column7: Take thy bylle, and sytte downe quickely, and wryte fyftye.
column8: Take thy bylle, and fit down quickly, and write fyftye.

column7: Then sayd he to an other:
column8: Then said he to an other:

column7: Howe muche owest thou? And he sayde, an hundreth quarters of wheate.
column8: How much owest thou? And he said, an Hundredth quarters of wheat.

column7: He sayde vnto hym. Take thy byll and write ^oure score.
column8: He said unto him. Take thy bill and write our score.

column7: And the lorde commended the vniuste stewarde, bicause he hadde done wysely.
column8: And the lord commended the unjust steward, Because he had done wisely.

column7: For the chyldren of this world are in their nation wiser then the chyldren of the lyghte.
column8: For the children of this world Are in their Nation Wiser then the children of the Light.

column7: And I saye vnto you:
column8: And I say unto you:

column7: Make you friendes of the vnrighteous Mammon, that when ye shall haue ^eede, they maye ^^ceaue you into euerlastinge habitacions. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Make you Friends of the unrighteous Mammon, that when you shall have eede, they may ceaue you into everlasting habitations. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T Here be three thinges in this gospell to bee noted.
column8: THere THere be three things in this gospel to be noted.

column7: Fyrste, <NOTE> we rynde in the similitude of this gospel, how the wicked steward is praised, not for his iniquitie and deceitfulnes, but as a wordely childe, which handlethe himselfe wiselye.
column8: First, we rind in the similitude of this gospel, how the wicked steward is praised, not for his iniquity and deceitfulness, but as a wordly child, which handleth himself wisely.

column7: For the children of thys world, in al that they go about, seeke their owne profite and ease, and not the vtilyty and profyte of their neighbour.
column8: For the children of this world, in all that they go about, seek their own profit and ease, and not the vtilyty and profit of their neighbour.

column7: They geue great diligence, that they the selues may be ful, and haue sufficient,
column8: They give great diligence, that they the selves may be full, and have sufficient,

column7: & care not how they get it, other by right or by wrong, so that they haue it, and maye be suer that they do not lacke, not cosidering ye need & pouerty of his neighboure.
column8: & care not how they get it, other by right or by wrong, so that they have it, and may be sure that they do not lack, not considering you need & poverty of his neighbour.

column7: This word Mamon, signifieth here, goodes & riches, and ar called wicked, not ye of the selues they be euel, but forbicause ye thorow great abuses they be both kept & spent, and not distributed to ye profit & vse of ye poore & needy.
column8: This word Mammon, signifies Here, goods & riches, and Are called wicked, not you of the selves they be evil, but For because you thorough great Abuses they be both kept & spent, and not distributed to you profit & use of you poor & needy.

column7: And therfore Christ fetteth before our eyes ye wisedome & craftines of this world, not that he praiseth or commedeth ye disceitfulnes, where through ye goodes of this world be gathered togyther & gotte, but yt we therby ar admonyshed, ye wc lyke study & dilligece, we do indeuor our selues to obtain & get celestyal & heuely ryches, whe we perceaue & marke yt the chyldre of this worlde seke with so greate studye, that which is transitory and earthlye.
column8: And Therefore christ fetteth before our eyes you Wisdom & craftiness of this world, not that he Praiseth or commedeth you disceitfulnes, where through the goods of this world be gathered together & got, but that we thereby Are admonished, you which like study & diligence, we do endeavour our selves to obtain & get celestial & heuely riches, when we perceive & mark that the children of this world seek with so great study, that which is transitory and earthly.

column7: And if they dispise and scorne oure eternall and celestiall goodes, that wee seeke here, wel let them seeke their treasure here on earth, and lette vs gather our treasure in heauen.
column8: And if they despise and scorn our Eternal and celestial goods, that we seek Here, well let them seek their treasure Here on earth, and let us gather our treasure in heaven.

column7: And then hereafter it shalbe tried, which haue kept the better treasure.
column8: And then hereafter it shall tried, which have kept the better treasure.

column7: Moreouer this admonicion, that we with all diligence shulde seeke eternall ryches, is uery necessary, for we be very flowe and negligent, and shulde very lightely forsake the faith and feare of god, yf we were not with suche godlye exhortacions well instructed and armed.
column8: Moreover this admonition, that we with all diligence should seek Eternal riches, is very necessary, for we be very flow and negligent, and should very lightly forsake the faith and Fear of god, if we were not with such godly exhortations well instructed and armed.

column7: <NOTE> For what greater ieoperdy can be vnto a christian man, then to be negligent and slacke in the worde of god?
column8: For what greater jeopardy can be unto a christian man, then to be negligent and slack in the word of god?

column7: We muste euer wake and stande in awe and feare with continuall prayer, that oure faith may be increased and daylye waxe more and more.
column8: We must ever wake and stand in awe and Fear with continual prayer, that our faith may be increased and daily wax more and more.

column7: And in any wise lette vs beware and take hede, that we be not carelesse,
column8: And in any wise let us beware and take heed, that we be not careless,

column7: <NOTE> and to saye with the wicked:
column8: and to say with the wicked:

column7: Pax & securitas, there is no ieoperdy.
column8: Pax & securitas, there is no jeopardy.

column7: Let them, that dispise goddes worde, do so, whiche saye in their hartes, that there is no god.
column8: Let them, that despise God's word, do so, which say in their hearts, that there is no god.

column7: And do thou accordinge to the doctrine of the prophete Dauid, <NOTE> saiynge:
column8: And do thou according to the Doctrine of the Prophet David, saying:

column7: Serue the lorde with feare, and reioyce before him with reuerence, which if thou doest, thou shalt not leese the greate benefite, that thou hast gotten through the gospel.
column8: Serve the lord with Fear, and rejoice before him with Reverence, which if thou dost, thou shalt not lose the great benefit, that thou hast got through the gospel.

column7: Surely thou shalte go and abide in the right way, and thou shalte auoyde all daunger to fall into the broade waye,
column8: Surely thou shalt go and abide in the right Way, and thou shalt avoid all danger to fallen into the broad Way,

column7: <NOTE> that leadeth to damnacion, according to the saying of the wise man:
column8: that leads to damnation, according to the saying of the wise man:

column7: Who so feareth god, walketh in the right pathe:
column8: Who so fears god, walks in the right path:

column7: <NOTE> and he that regardeth not hym, goeth out of his wayes.
column8: and he that Regardeth not him, Goes out of his ways.

column7: Then yf those go the ryghte waye that feare god, then take earnestlye to harte this exhortacion of Christe, and all security or rechelenes layd a parte, with all diligence do that, that is commaunded the of Christe, leaste the children of this world be found in their kynde, more dilligent, then the children of lyght.
column8: Then if those go the right Way that Fear god, then take earnestly to heart this exhortation of Christ, and all security or rechelenes laid a part, with all diligence do that, that is commanded the of Christ, jest the children of this world be found in their kind, more diligent, then the children of Light.

column7: Secondarely, we see in this gospell, that our study and diligence to get euerlastinge treasure, lieth herein, that we do make vs frendes of the wicked Mammon. <NOTE>
column8: Secondarily, we see in this gospel, that our study and diligence to get everlasting treasure, lies herein, that we do make us Friends of the wicked Mammon.

column7: But how doth this agree with our doctrine?
column8: But how does this agree with our Doctrine?

column7: For we haue taughte hitherto, that allonly throughe faythe we be iustified and saued, shall the workes do it nowe?
column8: For we have taught hitherto, that allonly through faith we be justified and saved, shall the works do it now?

column7: No, not so: The wordes sounde as thoughe it shulde seeme so, but well expounded and vnderstande, they pull nothing frome faythe.
column8: No, not so: The words sound as though it should seem so, but well expounded and understand, they pull nothing from faith.

column7: Christe speaketh here of good frutes, and wyll not that the tree that beareth those good frutes, shulde be reproued and caste awaye.
column8: Christ speaks Here of good fruits, and will not that the tree that bears those good fruits, should be reproved and cast away.

column7: For how wolde you haue good frutes, yf there were not fyrste a good tree?
column8: For how would you have good fruits, if there were not First a good tree?

column7: And howe wolde you haue frute, yf the tree didde not beare it, and bring it forth?
column8: And how would you have fruit, if the tree did not bear it, and bring it forth?

column7: Therfore it is necessarye, that the tree be good, before it bringeth forth good frute. <NOTE>
column8: Therefore it is necessary, that the tree be good, before it brings forth good fruit.

column7: And so likewise we speake of good workes:
column8: And so likewise we speak of good works:

column7: No worke, how precious or excellet so euer yt bee, can be acceptable or pleasaut before god, except the person which doth ye worke, be first iustified & acceptable before god.
column8: No work, how precious or excellet so ever that be, can be acceptable or pleasaut before god, except the person which does the work, be First justified & acceptable before god.

column7: If thou wilte be iuste and acceptable, thou must beleue.
column8: If thou wilt be just and acceptable, thou must believe.

column7: And yf thou beleuest, then arte thou iustified.
column8: And if thou Believest, then art thou justified.

column7: For fayth apprehedeth yu mercy of god in Christ, through the which we obtain righteousnes, without any work or deseruinge.
column8: For faith apprehedeth thou mercy of god in christ, through the which we obtain righteousness, without any work or deserving.

column7: And therefore when the person is accepted & iustified before god, then likewise are the works accepted, not that the works be of them selues of such reputacion and worthines, but forbicause they bee wrought of that persone, that is iustified and accepted before god.
column8: And Therefore when the person is accepted & justified before god, then likewise Are the works accepted, not that the works be of them selves of such reputation and worthiness, but For because they be wrought of that person, that is justified and accepted before god.

column7: Wherfore whan Christe doth admonishe vs, for to make vs frendes of the wicked Mammon, and to do good works, doth not regard so muche the worke, as he doth the fountaine, from whens the worke floweth.
column8: Wherefore when Christ does admonish us, for to make us Friends of the wicked Mammon, and to do good works, does not regard so much the work, as he does the fountain, from whence the work flows.

column7: He doth hate & setteth so litle bi hipocrisy, that it is to be thought, that he teacheth not workes without fayth.
column8: He does hate & sets so little by hypocrisy, that it is to be Thought, that he Teaches not works without faith.

column7: For what be workes withoute ^aithe, but hipocrisy?
column8: For what be works without aithe, but hypocrisy?

column7: Those workes, which the Iewes did obserue in the law, which also were commaunded of god himselfe, did not please god when they were done without faith, much lesse shall those workes please god, whiche be inuented & made of men.
column8: Those works, which the Jews did observe in the law, which also were commanded of god himself, did not please god when they were done without faith, much less shall those works please god, which be invented & made of men.

column7: Although Christe saide: Make you frendes of the wicked Mammon, teaching vs therwith the workes of charity, yet doth he not adscribe righteousnes to the same, but he wyl that our faith be declared by them, and brought to lyght, for it is needefull that the tree be knowen by the frutes.
column8: Although Christ said: Make you Friends of the wicked Mammon, teaching us therewith the works of charity, yet does he not adscribe righteousness to the same, but he will that our faith be declared by them, and brought to Light, for it is needful that the tree be known by the fruits.

column7: <NOTE> Cosidre also, that Christe in these wordes (Make you friendes of the wicked Mammon) did loke vpon y workes of charity, namely that then our goodes ar good & right, when they be tourned and distributed to the vse and helpe of the poore and needy:
column8: Consider also, that Christ in these words (Make you Friends of the wicked Mammon) did look upon y works of charity, namely that then our goods Are good & right, when they be turned and distributed to the use and help of the poor and needy:

column7: and contrary wise, they are naught & wicked, when we seke in the only our pleasure and voluptuousnes.
column8: and contrary wise, they Are nought & wicked, when we seek in the only our pleasure and voluptuousness.

column7: Therfore saith Salomon: <NOTE> He that dispiseth his neighboure doth amysse, but whosoeuer hath pity on the poore, is blessed.
column8: Therefore Says Solomon: He that despiseth his neighbour does amiss, but whosoever hath pity on the poor, is blessed.

column7: Thirdly, we haue here the reward that is giue to the faithful, which worketh through a liuely faith works of charitie, for as much as ye poore, whom we haue succoured & helped wt our goodes, shal receiue vs into euerlastig tabernacles.
column8: Thirdly, we have Here the reward that is give to the faithful, which works through a lively faith works of charity, for as much as you poor, whom we have succored & helped with our goods, shall receive us into euerlastig Tabernacles.

column7: This text ye papists apply vnto saintes yt ar departed out of this worlde and go about to stablishe therewith that vngodlye doctrine of inuocacion vnto saintes.
column8: This text you Papists apply unto Saints that Are departed out of this world and go about to establish therewith that ungodly Doctrine of invocation unto Saints.

column7: But take heed of this opinio, for it is against ye first comaundemet of god,
column8: But take heed of this opinio, for it is against the First comaundemet of god,

column7: & agaist ye gospell also,
column8: & aghast you gospel also,

column7: <NOTE> which teacheth vs to pray vnto the father in the name of Christe.
column8: which Teaches us to pray unto the father in the name of Christ.

column7: And it is against ye doctrine of S.
column8: And it is against you Doctrine of S.

column7: Paul, which techeth vs that we haue but only on mediatour. <NOTE> Furthermore this gospel speaketh not of ye dead, but of those saintes that be a liue.
column8: Paul, which teacheth us that we have but only on Mediator. Furthermore this gospel speaks not of the dead, but of those Saints that be a live.

column7: And those shuld we make our fredes & do our charity vpo.
column8: And those should we make our fredes & do our charity upon.

column7: Wherwtal? With ye wicked Mamon.
column8: Wherewithal? With you wicked Mammon.

column7: That is. Let vs think yt our goods & riches are not giue vs of god for our pomp & volupteousnes, but that therby we ar ordained & deputed to be goddes ministers, to deale & giue it out to the poore & needy, and to serue theim in their necessitye.
column8: That is. Let us think that our goods & riches Are not give us of god for our pomp & volupteousnes, but that thereby we Are ordained & deputed to be God's Ministers, to deal & give it out to the poor & needy, and to serve them in their necessity.

column7: Which if we do, thei at ye dai of iudgment shal bear witnes of our charity done vnto the, by which meanes we shalbe receiued into ye euerlastig tabernacle This exposition the bare texte giueth it selfe.
column8: Which if we do, they At the day of judgement shall bear witness of our charity done unto thee, by which means we shall received into you euerlastig tabernacle This exposition the bore text gives it self.

column7: For ye that Christe will do for the poore, he saith that hys christias do it.
column8: For you that Christ will do for the poor, he Says that his Christians do it.

column7: As in an other place he saith vnto yt apostels:
column8: As in an other place he Says unto that Apostles:

column7: <NOTE> In that day ye shall sit vppon the twelue seats, to iudge the twelue tribes of Israel.
column8: In that day you shall fit upon the twelue seats, to judge the twelue tribes of Israel.

column7: Finally what soeuer we do vnto the poore by faithe, shalbe plenteously recompensed and rewarded vs of God, throughe Christe our Lorde.
column8: Finally what soever we do unto the poor by faith, shall plenteously recompensed and rewarded us of God, through Christ our Lord.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the tenthe sonday after trinity sonday. Luc. 19.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the tenthe Sunday After trinity Sunday. Luke 19.

column7: A Nd when he was come neare, he beheld the citye and <NOTE> wepte on it, saying:
column8: ANd ANd when he was come near, he beheld the City and wept on it, saying:

column7: If thou haddest knowen those thinges which belong vnto thy peace, euen in thys thy day, thou woldest take heede.
column8: If thou Hadst known those things which belong unto thy peace, even in this thy day, thou Wouldst take heed.

column7: But nowe are they hidde frome thyne eyes.
column8: But now Are they hid from thine eyes.

column7: For the dayes shall come vpon the <NOTE> that thyne enemyes also shall caste a banke aboute the, and compasse the rounde, and kepe the in on euerye syde, and make the euen with the grounde, and thy chyldren which are in the And <NOTE> they shall not leaue in the, one stone vppon an other, bicause thou knowest not the tyme of thy visitacion.
column8: For the days shall come upon the that thine enemies also shall cast a bank about thee, and compass the round, and keep thee in on every side, and make the even with the ground, and thy children which Are in thee And they shall not leave in thee, one stone upon an other, Because thou Knowest not the time of thy Visitation.

column7: <NOTE> And he wente into the temple, and beganne to caste out theim that solde therein, and them that boughte, saiynge vnto theim:
column8: And he went into the temple, and began to cast out them that sold therein, and them that bought, saying unto them:

column7: It is wrytte: <NOTE>
column8: It is writ:

column7: My house is the house of prayer:
column8: My house is the house of prayer:

column7: but ye haue <NOTE> made it a denne of theues.
column8: but you have made it a den of thieves.

column7: And he taughte daylye in the temple. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And he taught daily in the temple. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this gospel we learn, how we must receiue Christe two manner of wayes:
column8: IN this gospel we Learn, how we must receive Christ two manner of ways:

column7: One waye, as a gifte, an other, as an exaumple.
column8: One Way, as a gift, an other, as an Exampl.

column7: Therfore when I take and receaue hym as a gifte,
column8: Therefore when I take and receive him as a gift,

column7: <NOTE> muste I vnderstand and know, that this his weeping hath doone me seruice, and that hee is so gyuen me, that hee with all that he hath is myne owne.
column8: must I understand and know, that this his weeping hath done me service, and that he is so given me, that he with all that he hath is mine own.

column7: And also I muste know and beleue, that he careth for me, and hath compassion with me, and pytieth me in my calamity and misery.
column8: And also I must know and believe, that he Careth for me, and hath compassion with me, and pytieth me in my calamity and misery.

column7: For there is no greater cofort to vs, neither in heauen not in earth, then to know (when we are assaulted with temptacion) that god careth and prouideth for vs.
column8: For there is no greater Comfort to us, neither in heaven not in earth, then to know (when we Are assaulted with temptation) that god Careth and Provideth for us

column7: If thy sinnes bite the, yf thy conscience accuse the, if thou feare the wrathe and vengeaunce of god, returne and looke vpon Christe, by whome thou art promised remission of sinnes.
column8: If thy Sins bite thee, if thy conscience accuse thee, if thou Fear the wrath and vengeance of god, return and look upon Christ, by whom thou art promised remission of Sins.

column7: <NOTE> For it is he that alone hath taken awaye oure infirmitye and sinnes, and beareth oure payne.
column8: For it is he that alone hath taken away our infirmity and Sins, and bears our pain.

column7: And in any wise take heed, that thou takest not him for so cruel, that wil not be intreated or pleased, and which will not be spoken withal, but rather perswade thy selfe, that he is suche a one, that is not allonly displeased with those, that neglect him and seeke and other waye to saluacion, but also that hee was sory and wept for them, as wee maye lightely perceiue out of this his compassion, that he is redy and prest to help euery man, so that we acknowledg our sinnes and hate them, desiring to be delyuered from theim.
column8: And in any wise take heed, that thou Takest not him for so cruel, that will not be entreated or pleased, and which will not be spoken withal, but rather persuade thy self, that he is such a one, that is not allonly displeased with those, that neglect him and seek and other Way to salvation, but also that he was sorry and wept for them, as we may lightly perceive out of this his compassion, that he is ready and pressed to help every man, so that we acknowledge our Sins and hate them, desiring to be Delivered from them.

column7: For it is he, he alone (I saye) through whome the father wyll helpe troubled consciences, and saye in oure hartes:
column8: For it is he, he alone (I say) through whom the father will help troubled Consciences, and say in our hearts:

column7: Bee of good comforte, thy sinnes be forgiuen the:
column8: be of good Comfort, thy Sins be forgiven the:

column7: which also in worldly tentacion and trouble doth the same.
column8: which also in worldly tentation and trouble does thee same.

column7: For yf in my trouble and misery I call vnto god through Christe,
column8: For if in my trouble and misery I call unto god through Christ,

column7: I am suer that he wyll helpe.
column8: I am sure that he will help.

column7: For Christe hath saide: What so euer ye aske the father in my name,
column8: For Christ hath said: What so ever you ask the father in my name,

column7: <NOTE> it shal be giuen vnto you.
column8: it shall be given unto you.

column7: And in an other place he sayth:
column8: And in an other place he say:

column7: Be of good comforte, I haue ouercome the world. that is,
column8: Be of good Comfort, I have overcome the world. that is,

column7: <NOTE> Through me ye shall nat allonly ouercome the worlde, and that that is in it, but also ye shal ouercome death, the diuell and hel.
column8: Through me you shall nat allonly overcome the world, and that that is in it, but also you shall overcome death, the Devil and hell.

column7: And in lyke wise, when I haue compreheded Christ as a gift,
column8: And in like wise, when I have compreheded christ as a gift,

column7: <NOTE> I must learne thereby, to serue my neighboure bothe with body and goodes, euen as Christe here both wyth his weeping, passion and deathe, hathe serued vs.
column8: I must Learn thereby, to serve my neighbour both with body and goods, even as Christ Here both with his weeping, passion and death, hath served us

column7: As sainte Peter saith: <NOTE> Christe hath suffered for vs, leauinge vs an ensample to folow his footesteppes And these be the very true workes whiche scripture dothe alowe, the which also we muste do, to manifest and declare our faithe withall.
column8: As saint Peter Says: Christ hath suffered for us, leaving us an ensample to follow his footsteps And these be the very true works which scripture doth allow, the which also we must do, to manifest and declare our faith withal.

column7: Secondarily, in this gospel Christ doth morne & weepe for the Iewes, bicause they knewe not what was for their peace, wherwith he declared & shewed vnto vs, the blindenes and wickednes of the flesh.
column8: Secondarily, in this gospel christ does morn & weep for the Jews, Because they knew not what was for their peace, wherewith he declared & showed unto us, the blindness and wickedness of the Flesh.

column7: Wherof (I beseche you) can a man glorify, seing so many excellent sermones, so many and great myracles done by Christ at Ierusalem, and those in a maner all done in vaine?
column8: Whereof (I beseech you) can a man Glorify, sing so many excellent Sermons, so many and great Miracles done by christ At Jerusalem, and those in a manner all done in vain?

column7: Where is here free wil with his power, whiche the prudente and wise men of this worlde, hathe attributed vnto yt?
column8: Where is Here free will with his power, which the prudent and wise men of this world, hath attributed unto that?

column7: Wherefore wolde not they beleue his worde, and knowe him to be the sonne of god, and the trewe Messias?
column8: Wherefore would not they believe his word, and know him to be the son of god, and the true Messias?

column7: Surely it was hidden frome their eies, though notwithstandinge, they did both hear his wordes, and sawe his miracles.
column8: Surely it was hidden from their eyes, though notwithstanding, they did both hear his words, and saw his Miracles.

column7: Wherout it foloweth, that our fleshe while it is not lightened with the holy ghost, and a newe harte giuen vnto it,
column8: Without it Followeth, that our Flesh while it is not lightened with the holy ghost, and a new heart given unto it,

column7: <NOTE> is very blind, indurate, and wicked, whiche canne in no wise know god in Christ.
column8: is very blind, indurate, and wicked, which can in no wise know god in christ.

column7: <NOTE> This blindnes beleue verely, is not in our outward vesture, but is graft in vs in our mothers wombe.
column8: This blindness believe verily, is not in our outward vesture, but is grafted in us in our mother's womb.

column7: Wherfore, if we will entre into the kingedome of heauen, wee muste be newe borne agayne thorowe water and the holye ghoste.
column8: Wherefore, if we will enter into the Kingdom of heaven, we must be new born again thorough water and the holy ghost.

column7: <NOTE> Suche lyke maliciousnes and blyndenes we see in theym, that solde and boughte in the temple, whiche Iesus droue oute.
column8: Such like maliciousness and blindness we see in them, that sold and bought in the temple, which jesus drove out.

column7: Whoe amongest theym knewe theym selues?
column8: Who amongst them knew them selves?

column7: or amended theyr lyues, thoughe they were neuer so muche admonyshed and taughte, that the house of God was a house of prayer?
column8: or amended their lives, though they were never so much admonished and taught, that the house of God was a house of prayer?

column7: They were fleshelye, and therefore as yet they coulde not vnderstande nor iudge ryghte, the wordes and actes of Christe.
column8: They were fleshly, and Therefore as yet they could not understand nor judge right, the words and acts of Christ.

column7: Thyrdely, here is declared vnto the Iewes, the rewarde and punishemente of their blindenes and infidelitie.
column8: Thirdly, Here is declared unto the Jews, the reward and punishment of their blindness and infidelity.

column7: <NOTE> For thy enemies (saieth he) shall caste vp a banke about the and thy children, and shal not leaue in the, one stone vpon an other, bicause thou haste not knowen the tyme, wherein thou hast been visited.
column8: For thy enemies (Saith he) shall cast up a bank about thee and thy children, and shall not leave in thee, one stone upon an other, Because thou haste not known the time, wherein thou hast been visited.

column7: O meruailous greuous ponyshment. First the Iewes are ponished, for bicause they wolde not knowe Christe, and this is a spirituall punishment For they haue eyes and see not, eares and hear not.
column8: O marvelous grievous ponyshment. First the Jews Are ponished, for Because they would not know Christ, and this is a spiritual punishment For they have eyes and see not, ears and hear not.

column7: <NOTE> so that Christe myght well saye:
column8: so that Christ might well say:

column7: <NOTE> I am come to iudgment into this world, that they which se not, might see, and that they whiche see, might be made blinde.
column8: I am come to judgement into this world, that they which see not, might see, and that they which see, might be made blind.

column7: But who ys able to serch the depth of his incomprehensible iudgement?
column8: But who is able to search the depth of his incomprehensible judgement?

column7: No man, but allonly god:
column8: No man, but allonly god:

column7: <NOTE> for we maye not, nor can not.
column8: for we may not, nor can not.

column7: Nowe after this spirituall punishemente foloweth bodylye punishemente, in that he saithe, howe the Iewes shalbe beseeged on euerye side, that there shall not be lefte one stone vpon an other.
column8: Now After this spiritual punishment Followeth bodily punishment, in that he Saith, how the Jews shall besieged on every side, that there shall not be left one stone upon an other.

column7: And euen as it was tolde theym of Christe, so was it brought to passe.
column8: And even as it was told them of Christ, so was it brought to pass.

column7: Surelye it was such an horrible & cruell punishment, that it is lametable to heare.
column8: Surely it was such an horrible & cruel punishment, that it is lametable to hear.

column7: Which if thou wilt know, reade Iosephus de bello Iud.
column8: Which if thou wilt know, read Josephus de bello Iud.

column7: Now ye haue hard of ye punishmet wher wt the Iewes haue bin punished with all,
column8: Now you have hard of the punishment where with the Jews have been punished with all,

column7: <NOTE> for the dispising of ye gospel.
column8: for the despising of the gospel.

column7: What thikest thou shall chaunce and happen vnto vs, which so longe a tyme haue harde the gospell, and yet haue not amended oure vngracyous liuinge and conuersacion, but rather haue troden vnder our feete, neglected and dispysed that precious perle?
column8: What thikest thou shall chance and happen unto us, which so long a time have harden the gospel, and yet have not amended our ungracious living and Conversation, but rather have trodden under our feet, neglected and despised that precious pearl?

column7: Wherefore yf we tourne not, he hath whet his swerde, (saith the prophet Dauid) he hath bente his bowe & made yt ready:
column8: Wherefore if we turn not, he hath whet his sword, (Says the Prophet David) he hath bent his bow & made that ready:

column7: <NOTE> He hath prepared him the weapos of death and ordained his arrowes to destroye.
column8: He hath prepared him the weapos of death and ordained his arrows to destroy.

column7: Here thou doest hear that not allonly the Iewes, but all those that will not tourne to amendement of lyfe, shal he punished.
column8: Here thou dost hear that not allonly the Jews, but all those that will not turn to amendment of life, shall he punished.

column7: Sometyme doth God prolonge the punishemente, but the lenger he suffreth, the greuouser at the laste dothe hee punishe.
column8: Sometime does God prolong the punishment, but the longer he suffers, the greuouser At the laste doth he Punish.

column7: Therefore lette euerye manne tourne frome his wicked waye, and beleue the gospell, leste wee perishe both body and soule.
column8: Therefore let every man turn from his wicked Way, and believe the gospel, lest we perish both body and soul.

column7: Fourthlye, Christe commendeth in this gospell his office, in that, that ye next day folowyng he wet into the temple,
column8: Fourthly, Christ commends in this gospel his office, in that, that you next day following he wet into the temple,

column7: & droue out the byers & sellers, saying:
column8: & drove out the byers & sellers, saying:

column7: <NOTE> It is written,
column8: It is written,

column7: My house is a house of prayer, and ye haue made it a denne of murtherers.
column8: My house is a house of prayer, and you have made it a den of murderers.

column7: And also in that he declareth his office,
column8: And also in that he Declareth his office,

column7: <NOTE> that hee daylye taughte in the temple.
column8: that he daily taught in the temple.

column7: It became Christe to do all these thinges, for hee was sente into the worlde to teache the will of his father, by preaching.
column8: It became Christ to do all these things, for he was sent into the world to teach the will of his father, by preaching.

column7: Bicause for as muche as goddes worde and the oute warde worshipping of god in ceremonyes, (which shortly after shulde be abrogated and taken away) was very muche letted and hindred in the temple at Ierusalem, throughe the couetousnes of the scribes and phariseis, therefore wolde Christe not only teache,
column8: Because for as much as God's word and the out ward worshipping of god in ceremonies, (which shortly After should be abrogated and taken away) was very much letted and hindered in the temple At Jerusalem, through the covetousness of the Scribes and Pharisees, Therefore would Christ not only teach,

column7: <NOTE> but also roote out all the abuses whiche did hyndre the trewe worshipping of God.
column8: but also root out all the Abuses which did hinder the true worshipping of God.

column7: And what so euer Christe doth here, by scripture he approueth it, that hee maye do it by righte.
column8: And what so ever Christ does Here, by scripture he approveth it, that he may do it by right.

column7: For why may not Christ, in so much as he ys lord both of the bodely temple & spirituall also, driue out suche villains?
column8: For why may not christ, in so much as he is lord both of the bodily temple & spiritual also, driven out such villains?

column7: Now, that Christe did here with the handes and with the doctrine, that maye we not do, but all only with the doctrine and worde of god.
column8: Now, that Christ did Here with the hands and with the Doctrine, that may we not do, but all only with the Doctrine and word of god.

column7: For we maye do nothinge but to teache the gospell. but yf that shulde be hindred, and those doctoures (which seeking nothing but their owne profite, through teaching the tradicions of men) shuld defyle the temple of god, which is the harte of faithfull menne, then muste wee holde our hands (I graunte) but not oure mouth, and make suche dreamers ashamed, to the intente that the gospell maye haue his righte course and florishe amongest vs.
column8: For we may do nothing but to teach the gospel. but if that should be hindered, and those Doctors (which seeking nothing but their own profit, through teaching the traditions of men) should defile the temple of god, which is the heart of faithful men, then must we hold our hands (I grant) but not our Mouth, and make such dreamers ashamed, to the intent that the gospel may have his right course and flourish amongst us

column7: Hereto pertaineth the saiyng of saynte Paule to Titus:
column8: Hereto pertaineth the saying of faint Paul to Titus:

column7: <NOTE> A byshoppe muste bee suche a one, that cleaueth to the trewe worde of doctrine, that hee maye be able to exhorte with holesome learnynge, and to improue theim that saye against yt.
column8: A bishop must be such a one, that cleaveth to the true word of Doctrine, that he may be able to exhort with wholesome learning, and to improve them that say against that.

column7: The eleuenth sonday after trinitye. Luc. 18.
column8: The Eleventh Sunday After trinity. Luke 18.

column7: A Nd he tolde this parable vnto certayne which trusted in them selues that they were perfecte and despised other. Two men went vp into ye temple to pray, the one a Pharise, and the other a Publicane.
column8: ANd ANd he told this parable unto certain which trusted in them selves that they were perfect and despised other. Two men went up into you temple to pray, the one a Pharisee, and the other a Publican.

column7: The Pharise stode and praied thus with hymselfe.
column8: The Pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself.

column7: God, I thanke ye that I am not as other men are;
column8: God, I thank you that I am not as other men Are;

column7: extorcioners, vniuste, aduouterers, or as thys publicane:
column8: extortioners, unjust, aduouterers, or as this publican:

column7: I faste twyse in the weke <NOTE> I geue tythe of all that I possesse.
column8: I fast twice in the Week I give tithe of all that I possess.

column7: And the publicane stondinge a farre of, wolde not lyfte vp hys eyes to heauen, but smote vpon his breste, saying:
column8: And the publican standing a Far of, would not lift up his eyes to heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying:

column7: God be mercyfull to me a sinner.
column8: God be merciful to me a sinner.

column7: I tell you, thys man departed home to his house, iustified, more the the other.
column8: I tell you, this man departed home to his house, justified, more the the other.

column7: <NOTE> For euery one that exalteth himselfe, shalbe brought lowe:
column8: For every one that Exalteth himself, shall brought low:

column7: And hee that humbleth hym selfe, shalbe exalted. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And he that Humbleth him self, shall exalted. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this gospel we fynde two rightousnesses, that is to say, rightousnes of faith & of workes, which is here described in these two persons, so that we may clerely perceaue, yt not ye rightousnes of workes, but the righteousnes of faithe, is commended and alowed.
column8: IN this gospel we find two rightousnesses, that is to say, righteousness of faith & of works, which is Here described in these two Persons, so that we may clearly perceive, that not you righteousness of works, but the righteousness of faith, is commended and aloud.

column7: Therefore we will intreate of the thinges that be here to bee noted of, by ordre.
column8: Therefore we will entreat of the things that be Here to be noted of, by ordre.

column7: <NOTE> Fyrste, we muste considre that hipocritical perso, whiche came with the publicane vp into the temple for to pray.
column8: First, we must Consider that Hypocritical person, which Come with the publican up into the temple for to pray.

column7: For he is excellently sette forthe, and described with glorious highe workes and manye, which notwithstanding howe excellent so euer they were, they did not please god, bicause thei wer done without faith.
column8: For he is excellently Set forth, and described with glorious high works and many, which notwithstanding how excellent so ever they were, they did not please god, Because they were done without faith.

column7: Who wold haue reproued the praier of the pharisey, yf it hadde come oute of a perfecte harte and a trewe faythe, and hadde soughte therein the glorye of god, and the vtilitye of his neighboure?
column8: Who would have reproved the prayer of the Pharisee, if it had come out of a perfect heart and a true faith, and had sought therein the glory of god, and the utility of his neighbour?

column7: For wee oughte to commende and prayse suche a worke, for godly and christian, forasmuche as Christe him selfe hathe commaunded it, saying, that wee oughte alwayes to pray, and not to leaue of,
column8: For we ought to commend and praise such a work, for godly and christian, forasmuch as Christ him self hath commanded it, saying, that we ought always to pray, and not to leave of,

column7: <NOTE> but this prayer was not doone in spirite, and in the truth.
column8: but this prayer was not done in Spirit, and in the truth.

column7: <NOTE> The glorye of god was not taught therin.
column8: The glory of god was not taught therein.

column7: Wherefore we maye lyken it to the same thinge wherof Esaias speaketh saying:
column8: Wherefore we may liken it to the same thing whereof Isaiah speaks saying:

column7: <NOTE> This people draweth nighe me with their mouthe, and praiseth me highely with their lyppes, where as their hart neuerthelesse, is farre frome me.
column8: This people draws High me with their Mouth, and Praiseth me highly with their lips, where as their heart nevertheless, is Far from me.

column7: And that this pharisey did not seke the glory of god, the wordes of his prayer plainly declareth yt.
column8: And that this Pharisee did not seek the glory of god, the words of his prayer plainly Declareth that.

column7: For he saithe thus: <NOTE> I thanke the god, that I am not as other men.
column8: For he Saith thus: I thank the god, that I am not as other men.

column7: Thankes geuynge, wherethrough we prayse god for the benefites which we receiue, whether they be bodely or ghostely, is a good and a christiane worke.
column8: Thanks giving, wherethrough we praise god for the benefits which we receive, whither they be bodily or ghostly, is a good and a christian work.

column7: For how can we be called christia me, yf we do not knowledg the benefites of god done vnto vs,
column8: For how can we be called christian me, if we do not knowledge the benefits of god done unto us,

column7: & for ye same geue thankes?
column8: & for you same give thanks?

column7: Do not we finde such frute of faith in the apostle S.
column8: Do not we find such fruit of faith in the apostle S.

column7: Paule, throughe oute all his epistles, that is, euermore giuing of thankes?
column8: Paul, through out all his Epistles, that is, evermore giving of thanks?

column7: But vndoubtedly, the thankes giuing of this pharisey, is not good, but very blasphemy toward god, bicause he seeketh not the glory of god therin, but his owne glory.
column8: But undoubtedly, the thanks giving of this Pharisee, is not good, but very blasphemy towards god, Because he seeks not the glory of god therein, but his own glory.

column7: I am not (saith he) like other me.
column8: I am not (Says he) like other me.

column8: What manner of giving thanks shall we call this?

column7: howe canst thou perceiue here that he geueth god his honour?
column8: how Canst thou perceive Here that he Giveth god his honour?

column7: Wher can we know here, yt god allonly is he, which iustifieth vs through Christ?
column8: Where can we know Here, that god allonly is he, which Justifieth us through christ?

column7: For here we se howe ye pharise hath no nede of god, for he is righteous of himselfe.
column8: For Here we see how you Pharisee hath no need of god, for he is righteous of himself.

column7: O notable pride. But it is so, ypocrisy euer hangeth vpo pride, where wt he extolleth him selfe,

column8: & despiseth other. This Pharisee thiketh not sufficiet, that he Praiseth hiselfe, but he despiseth all other,

column8: & most highli slaudreth thee.

column7: He calleth the robbers, vnrighteous & aduoutrers.
column8: He calls the robbers, unrighteous & aduoutrers.

column7: Also this goodly pharisey is allonly good, and thinketh hee hathe satisfied and fulfilled the lawe, for bicause outwardly he semeth to haue fulfilled yt, and for the same thinketh himselfe righteous before god.
column8: Also this goodly Pharisee is allonly good, and Thinketh he hath satisfied and fulfilled the law, for Because outwardly he Seemeth to have fulfilled that, and for the same Thinketh himself righteous before god.

column7: And in the meane whyle considereth not,
column8: And in the mean while Considereth not,

column7: <NOTE> the lawe (as Paule saieth) to bee spirituall, that is, that the lawe requireth not allonly the outwarde worke, but also to be fulfilled with the harte, affection and spirite.
column8: the law (as Paul Saith) to be spiritual, that is, that the law requires not allonly the outward work, but also to be fulfilled with the heart, affection and Spirit.

column7: It maye well be, that he stole nothing, nor with violence and force toke any thing from his neighbour, with hys handes.
column8: It may well be, that he stole nothing, nor with violence and force took any thing from his neighbour, with his hands.

column7: And likewise, althoughe that he had fulfylled the same withe his herte, haue wee nothinge therfore to say?
column8: And likewise, although that he had fulfilled the same with his heart, have we nothing Therefore to say?

column7: Yea surely, in this giuing of thaks he hathe stolen and robbed god fro his glory.
column8: Yea surely, in this giving of thaks he hath stolen and robbed god from his glory.

column7: And againe, though outwardly with the deed he hathe not ben an aduoultrer,
column8: And again, though outwardly with the deed he hath not been an aduoultrer,

column7: <NOTE> yet he maye haue beene one in his hart.
column8: yet he may have been one in his heart.

column7: All this he doth not beleue, but putteth all to this poore publican, whom all maner of wais he thinketh worse the him selfe.
column8: All this he does not believe, but putteth all to this poor publican, whom all manner of ways he Thinketh Worse the him self.

column7: Thus wha he had boasted him selfe, he goeth forth further & glorified him againe, that he is no glotton nor no dronkard, but that he fasteth twise in a weeke:
column8: Thus wha he had boasted him self, he Goes forth further & glorified him again, that he is no glutton nor no drunkard, but that he fasteth twice in a Week:

column7: Also that he giueth the tenthe of his good to the poore.
column8: Also that he gives the tenthe of his good to the poor.

column7: Call you not that glorifying?
column8: Call you not that glorifying?

column8: But where remains the saying of Jeremiah:

column8: Let him that rejoice, rejoice in god?

column7: <NOTE> The Pharsye doth not thus, but he must glorifye himselfe in his owne workes.
column8: The Pharisee does not thus, but he must Glorify himself in his own works.

column7: Beholde, here thou haste the persone of this righteous and honest Pharisey described.
column8: Behold, Here thou haste the person of this righteous and honest Pharisee described.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarely, we wyll intreate of the publicane, whyche is described ferre vnlyke vnto the pharisey For he, as the Euangelyst writeth, stoode farre of,
column8: Secondarily, we will entreat of the publican, which is described Far unlike unto the Pharisee For he, as the Evangelist Writeth, stood Far of,

column7: and durste not lifte vp his eyes, but knocked on his breste, and sayde:
column8: and durst not lift up his eyes, but knocked on his breast, and said:

column7: God, be mercifull to me a sinner.
column8: God, be merciful to me a sinner.

column7: Here thou hearest no glorifiynge, no pryde, no dispisyng of other menne, but allonlye disablinge of himselfe, in so muche that he iudgeth himselfe vnworthy, to lyfte vp his eyes towarde heauen, or to stand in ye middest of the temple, as the pharisy did.
column8: Here thou Hearst no glorifiynge, no pride, no despising of other men, but allonlye disabling of himself, in so much that he Judgeth himself unworthy, to lift up his eyes toward heaven, or to stand in you midst of the temple, as the Pharisee did.

column7: With these gestures this miserable publicane sufficientlye doth declare, what he thought of himselfe in his harte. but why do not we considre it oute of his wordes?
column8: With these gestures this miserable publican sufficiently does declare, what he Thought of himself in his heart. but why do not we Consider it out of his words?

column7: God (he saieth) be mercifull vnto me a sinner.
column8: God (he Saith) be merciful unto me a sinner.

column7: <NOTE> Here do I heare the trew confession of sinners, which is so necessarye, that withoute that, no christian man can with any frute heare the comfortable tydinges of the gospell.
column8: Here do I hear the true Confessi of Sinners, which is so necessary, that without that, no christian man can with any fruit hear the comfortable tidings of the gospel.

column7: For the preaching of the gospel promiseth vs remissio of sinnes through Christ, but not to them that iustifie themselues, but vnto theim that frome the grounde of their hartes knowledgeth themselues to be sinners.
column8: For the preaching of the gospel promises us Remission of Sins through christ, but not to them that justify themselves, but unto them that from the ground of their hearts knowledgeth themselves to be Sinners.

column7: For so saith Christe: I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners.
column8: For so Says Christ: I am not come to call the righteous, but Sinners.

column7: <NOTE> For yf I knoweledge not my selfe to bee a sinner, howe can my sinnes be forgiuen me?
column8: For if I knowledge not my self to be a sinner, how can my Sins be forgiven me?

column7: Hereto pertayneth, that S. Iohn baptist and Christe, first of all preached repentaunce.
column8: Hereto pertaineth, that S. John baptist and Christ, First of all preached Repentance.

column7: For through the preachinge of the lawe, our sinnes be declared and shewed, that wee maye be brought throughe it to the knowledge of oure selues, and acknoweledge that we haue neede of helpe and comforte.
column8: For through the preaching of the law, our Sins be declared and showed, that we may be brought through it to the knowledge of our selves, and acknowledge that we have need of help and Comfort.

column7: In this wise also S. Paule saith,
column8: In this wise also S. Paul Says,

column7: <NOTE> that both the Iewes and gentyles are vnder sinne.
column8: that both the Jews and Gentiles Are under sin.

column7: And to conclude. Knowledg of sinne, is the fyrste degree to come vnto righteousnes, and where this knowledge is, there is the gospell preached with frute.
column8: And to conclude. Knowledge of sin, is the First degree to come unto righteousness, and where this knowledge is, there is the gospel preached with fruit.

column7: Lyke as Christ sayeth: The gospell is preached vnto the poore,
column8: Like as christ Saith: The gospel is preached unto the poor,

column7: <NOTE> that is, vnto contrite hartes that knowledg their offences, is preached the gospell.
column8: that is, unto contrite hearts that knowledge their offences, is preached the gospel.

column7: And wher the gospell is so preched, the hearer learneth how that all only through Christe of mere grace, wee be iustified and saued.
column8: And where the gospel is so preached, the hearer learneth how that all only through Christ of mere grace, we be justified and saved.

column7: Wherout he beginneth to pray with the publican:
column8: Without he begins to pray with the publican:

column7: God, bee mercifull to me a sinner.
column8: God, be merciful to me a sinner.

column8: For none other work can help him.

column8: Here you have now the description of the publican, which knowledged his offences, and asked mercy.

column8: Thirdly, let us see and hear, what sentence & judgement Christ did give over them both.

column7: Of the publicane he sayth:
column8: Of the publican he say:

column8: He went down into his house justified, more then the other.

column7: For wosoeuer exalteth him selfe, shall be broughte lowe.
column8: For wosoeuer Exalteth him self, shall be brought low.

column7: And hee that humbleth himselfe, shall be exalted.
column8: And he that Humbleth himself, shall be exalted.

column7: But how commeth that to passe, that so righteous a man, is here condemned?
column8: But how comes that to pass, that so righteous a man, is Here condemned?

column7: and contrary wise so great a sinner receyued & saued?
column8: and contrary wise so great a sinner received & saved?

column7: So yt is, This publican knowledging his offences, perceaueth and feleth his vicious and sinful nature, and out of this knowledge he fyndeth himselfe so vnprofitable and miserable, that he cannot in anye wise ayde and socoure hym selfe.
column8: So that is, This publican knowledging his offences, perceiveth and feeleth his vicious and sinful nature, and out of this knowledge he findeth himself so unprofitable and miserable, that he cannot in any wise aid and succour him self.

column7: Wherefore he is not pufte vp, he trusteth in no workes, he dispaireth of hymselfe, he mekeneth himselfe, yet notwithstanding, vpon that hope and confidece, that god will be vnto him a merciful god, and forgiue him his trespasses, he asketh mercy and grace.
column8: Wherefore he is not pufte up, he Trusteth in no works, he dispaireth of himself, he mekeneth himself, yet notwithstanding, upon that hope and confidence, that god will be unto him a merciful god, and forgive him his Trespasses, he asks mercy and grace.

column7: And this hope and confidence meruailously pleaseth god.
column8: And this hope and confidence marvelously Pleases god.

column7: Wherfore this publican is pronouced iuste, that by this exaumple, the righteousnes of faythe myghte be knowen.
column8: Wherefore this publican is pronounced just, that by this Exampl, the righteousness of faith might be known.

column7: And contrary wise. <NOTE> Bicause the pharisey not knowledging himselfe to be a synner, but proude and pufte vp for his workes sake (whiche notwithstanding were doone without faythe) and dispisinge other menne, and exaltinge hymselfe, of verye righte hee is broughte lowe.
column8: And contrary wise. Because the Pharisee not knowledging himself to be a sinner, but proud and pufte up for his works sake (which notwithstanding were done without faith) and despising other men, and exalting himself, of very right he is brought low.

column7: And forbycause that he before the worlde toke the highest place,
column8: And Forbycause that he before the world took the highest place,

column8: now with shame he must give place unto the publican, and fit beneath.

column7: For god wyll not regard his fained ypocriticall works.
column8: For god will not regard his feigned ypocriticall works.

column7: Notwithstandinge, wee dooe not reiecte good workes, so that they come freelye oute of faythe, and are frutes of a good tree, but if they procede not of faith, wee improue theym, sayinge wyth saynte Paule:
column8: Notwithstanding, we do not reject good works, so that they come freely out of faith, and Are fruits of a good tree, but if they proceed not of faith, we improve them, saying with faint Paul:

column7: What so euer is not of faythe, that same is sinne.
column8: What so ever is not of faith, that same is sin.

column8: though the outward appearance shine never so excellentelye.

column8: The joy of hypocrite Continueth but the twinklynge of an eye,

column8: and the praise of the ungodly is short, though his pride Ascendeth up to the heaven, and his head reaches unto the Clouds, yet he shall perish At the laste, like dung, in so much that they which have seen him, shall say:

column8: Where is he? Let this be sufficient for this gospel.
