column8: And straight Way his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue was losed, and he spoke plain.

column7: <NOTE> And hee commaunded theym, that they should tell no man:

column8: He hath done all things well, he hath made both the deaf to hear, and the du^ to speak. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: <NOTE> F Yrste, in this gospell is praysed and commeded an other mannes faythe, whiche afther she herselfe had knowen Christe to be a sauiour, putteth al her trust in him,

column8: & willingly she breaketh forth through charity, taking Thought for other men, Prayeth for thee, seeketh christ for thee, that they also might come into you knowledge of faith,

column8: & to embrace christ to be their alloly Saviour.

column8: The laying of hands upon, was a custom used in the old Testament, and remained likewise by christ and his Apostles, in so much that often times, when they healed the diseased, or would give the holy ghost,

column8: So these men Because they had oft seen Christ say his hands upon those that he healed, they prayed him likewise, that he would vouchsafe to say his hand upon this deaf man.

column7: Here note that these men had true faith and confidence in Christe.
column8: Here note that these men had true faith and confidence in Christ.

column7: For if they had not had faythe, why woulde they haue brought that poore man vnto Christe?
column8: For if they had not had faith, why would they have brought that poor man unto Christ?

column8: or why would they have prayed him, to heal this man?

column7: For to brynge the sicke impotent menne vnto Christe, and not beleue that he could heale theim, were not called, seekinge of Christe, but rather a mockinge of Christe.
column8: For to bring the sick impotent men unto Christ, and not believe that he could heal them, were not called, seeking of Christ, but rather a mocking of Christ.

column7: Vndoubtedly they had a very true faith, and did knowledge Christe to be the sauiour bothe of bodye and soule.
column8: Undoubtedly they had a very true faith, and did knowledge Christ to be the Saviour both of body and soul.

column7: And that thou mayst easyly perceiue, in that, they praying vnto Christe, obtained their peticion, and throughe their prayer and meanes, the deafe was restored vnto health.
column8: And that thou Mayest Easily perceive, in that, they praying unto Christ, obtained their petition, and through their prayer and means, the deaf was restored unto health.

column7: Further thou shalt note, that this deafe is come to faithe and health, thorough an other mannes faithe, but not thereby iustified and saued.
column8: Further thou shalt note, that this deaf is come to faith and health, through an other Man's faith, but not thereby justified and saved.

column7: For to iustificacion and saluacion, euery manne muste haue his owne faithe.
column8: For to justification and salvation, every man must have his own faith.

column8: & fingers. Which things wha he did add there unto he looked up into heaven & sighed.

column7: And now likewise if he for our sake sigheth and praieth, wee neede not to care, for hee will bringe it to passe.
column8: And now likewise if he for our sake sigheth and Prayeth, we need not to care, for he will bring it to pass.

column7: And that he will do the same for vs, he doth testifye it with the deed, so that we knowledging our weaknes & corrupte nature, beleue & hope, yt he likewise as he did help this deafe ma, wil help & haue mercy vpon vs.
column8: And that he will do the same for us, he does testify it with the deed, so that we knowledging our weakness & corrupt nature, believe & hope, that he likewise as he did help this deaf ma, will help & have mercy upon us

column7: Can Christes mercy & benigniti be more plainly described vnto vs?
column8: Can Christ's mercy & benigniti be more plainly described unto us?

column8: He speaks a word, & Helpeth him:

column8: thereby declaring how he could help him.

column7: Now seing he can help vs, and will helpe vs, what greate blyndenes is than in vs, that wee seeke or crye vnto anye other for helpe?
column8: Now sing he can help us, and will help us, what great blindness is than in us, that we seek or cry unto any other for help?

column8: Is it possible, that the oppressed being in necessity, can be helped by any other means, than by god through Christ?

column7: <NOTE> Shal they saue the, which could not helpe them selues, but allonly were saued throughe the grace and mercye of Christ?
column8: Shall they save thee, which could not help them selves, but allonly were saved through the grace and mercy of christ?

column7: I do not speake this to dishonour the saintes, but to stablishe the glory of Christe, which will giue hys honour and glorye to none other.
column8: I do not speak this to dishonour the Saints, but to establish the glory of Christ, which will give his honour and glory to none other.

column8: It is Christ alone that can help us, and will help us, which forgives sin and Justifieth Sinners.

column7: Now if thou canst not abide to hear the truth, nor to confesse it, thou arte strycken with the same disease, that this deafe and dumme man is strycken withall.
column8: Now if thou Canst not abide to hear the truth, nor to confess it, thou art stricken with the same disease, that this deaf and dumb man is stricken withal.

column8: Therefore get thee unto christ, and disclose unto him thy sickness & disease,

column8: & he shall help thee.

column8: Which if thou dost, not doubting of his benignity, truly he will make the hold, even as he made this miserable creature hold.

column7: Howe was that done? Immediately (saith the Euangelist) his eares were opened, and the bond of his tunge was lowsed, and he spake right.
column8: Howe was that done? Immediately (Says the Evangelist) his ears were opened, and the bound of his tongue was lowsed, and he spoke right.

column7: Thirdly, we find here an excellent frute of faith, in those that out of this miracle acknowledged and confessed Christ to be their sauiour.
column8: Thirdly, we find Here an excellent fruit of faith, in those that out of this miracle acknowledged and confessed christ to be their Saviour.

column7: For thei saide: He hathe doone all thinge well:
column8: For they said: He hath done all thing well:

column7: <NOTE> The deafe hath he made to heare, and the dumme to speake.
column8: The deaf hath he made to hear, and the dumb to speak.

column7: Thinkest thou not this to bee an hyghe prayse of Christe?
column8: Thinkest thou not this to be an high praise of Christ?

column8: They say: He hath done all things well.

column7: Of whome vnder heauen myghte thys bee sayed?
column8: Of whom under heaven might this be said?

column7: Oure fyrste father Adame so behaued himselfe in Paradyse,
column8: Oure First father Adam so behaved himself in Paradise,

column7: <NOTE> that throughe his disobedience, deathe and damnacion entred into the worlde.
column8: that through his disobedience, death and damnation entered into the world.

column7: And we folowynge oure fathers footesteppes, daylye prouoke God to angre, that if hee were not so mylde and mercyfull, he myght by right thrust vs recheles and disobediente chyldrene, into euerlastinge damnacion.
column8: And we following our Father's footsteps, daily provoke God to anger, that if he were not so mild and merciful, he might by right thrust us recheles and disobedient chyldrene, into everlasting damnation.

column7: <NOTE> And for that cause was Christe sente into the worlde to helpe vs, and was obediente to the father vnto deathe, yea the dethe of the crosse, and hath taught vs faithfully the way of truth.
column8: And for that cause was Christ sent into the world to help us, and was obedient to the father unto death, yea the death of the cross, and hath taught us faithfully the Way of truth.

column7: He hath allured vs & intised vs vnto him through workes & myracles,
column8: He hath allured us & enticed us unto him through works & Miracles,

column8: wherein he sought nothing Else, the you glory of you father,

column7: & our saluacio. And to be brief, he left nothing vndone in his office, but did all ye pertained other to ye glori of his father, or to our saluacio Therefore by righte we muste adsribe vnto our selues all confusion and shame, and to Christ all glorye.
column8: & our saluacio. And to be brief, he left nothing undone in his office, but did all you pertained other to you glori of his father, or to our saluacio Therefore by right we must adsribe unto our selves all confusion and shame, and to christ all glory.

column7: For that same thing, which we through oure inobedience and sinne had loste,
column8: For that same thing, which we through our inobedience and sin had lost,

column8: christ through his death and merits hath recovered again.

column7: Hereby we are reconciled vnto the father, and of deafe men be made to heare, and of dumme men and spechles haue obtained our speache.
column8: Hereby we Are reconciled unto the father, and of deaf men be made to hear, and of dumb men and spechles have obtained our speech.

column7: The cause why Christe commaunded the people here, that they shulde not manifest nor publyshe this miracle, and yet other where commaunded the same to be shewed, we can not, nor will not reason of yt why hee did it, he knoweth himselfe best.
column8: The cause why Christ commanded the people Here, that they should not manifest nor publish this miracle, and yet other where commanded the same to be showed, we can not, nor will not reason of that why he did it, he Knoweth himself best.

column7: For if it had bene meete for vs to haue knowen it, he wolde not haue hidde it frome vs,
column8: For if it had be meet for us to have known it, he would not have hid it from us,

column7: For yt which cause we wyl not examen his iudgemente, but rather call vppon hym for grace, that we may be able to here his word, and to vnderstand yt with our harte, and afore the world (whiche is so froward and synful) frely to confesse it.
column8: For that which cause we will not examen his judgement, but rather call upon him for grace, that we may be able to hear his word, and to understand that with our heart, and afore the world (which is so froward and sinful) freely to confess it.

column7: Which god through Christe graunte vs,
column8: Which god through Christ grant us,

column8: Amen. The gospel on the Thirtieth Sunday After trinity Sunday. Luke 10.

column7: A Nd he turned to hys dysciples, and sayd secretly:

column8: Happy Are the eyes which see the things that you see.

column7: and to heare those thinges whyche yee heare, and haue not harde them.
column8: and to hear those things which ye hear, and have not harden them.

column8: Master, what shall I do, to inherit Eternal life?

column8: He said unto him: What is written in the law?

column8: Love the lord thy God, with all thy heart and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thy self.

column8: And he said to him.

column8: Thou haste answered right: This do, and thou shalt live.

column8: But he willing to justify himself, said unto jesus.

column7: And who is my neighboure?
column8: And who is my neighbour?

column7: Iesus answered and sayd: A certayne man descended from Ierusalem to Hierico, and fell amonge theues, whyche robbed hym of hys rayment, and wounded hym, and departed, leauing him halfe deade.
column8: jesus answered and said: A certain man descended from Jerusalem to Jericho, and fell among thieves, which robbed him of his raiment, and wounded him, and departed, leaving him half dead.

column7: And yt chaunsed that there came downe a ce^ayne Prieste that same waye, and when he saw hym, he passed by.
column8: And that chanced that there Come down a ce^ayne Priest that same Way, and when he saw him, he passed by.

column8: But a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, Come unto him:

column8: and when he saw him, he had compassion on him,

column7: & went to, and bounde vp hys woundes, and poured in oyle and wine, and set hym on hys owne beaste, and broughte hym to a comon ynne,
column8: & went to, and bound up his wounds, and poured in oil and wine, and Set him on his own beast, and brought him to a Common in,

column8: & made provision for him.

column8: Take cure of him, and what so ever thou speddest more, when I come again,

column8: I will recompense thee. Which now of these Three Thinkest thou, was neighbour unto him that tell amongst the thieves?

column8: And he said: He that showed mercy on him.

column8: Then said jesus unto him:

column8: And though At that time that was allonly spoken to The apostles, yet notwithstanding that is universally spoken unto all the world.

column7: And for as much as they be so counted, let vs therfore serch out the cause why.
column8: And for as much as they be so counted, let us Therefore search out the cause why.

column7: He saith on this wise:
column8: He Says on this wise:

column7: Blessed at the eyes, which see that ye se.
column8: Blessed At the eyes, which see that you see.

column7: Thoughe Christ speaketh here simply of his person, his office and myracles, yet notwithstanding, yf we wyl esteme & count blessed the apostels and those that saw Christe, that is, knew Christe, so is it very needfull & necessary yt thei haue ye inward sight of the hart, which is faith.
column8: Though christ speaks Here simply of his person, his office and Miracles, yet notwithstanding, if we will esteem & count blessed the Apostles and those that saw Christ, that is, knew Christ, so is it very needful & necessary that they have you inward sighed of the heart, which is faith.

column7: For what had profited them the outward & bodelye seing of Christ, if thei had not had in likewise the inward seing?
column8: For what had profited them the outward & bodily sing of christ, if they had not had in likewise the inward sing?

column7: For if the outward seing might haue attained & gotten saluacio, so had Pilate,
column8: For if the outward sing might have attained & got saluacio, so had Pilate,

column7: Annas, Caiphas, and Herode bene saued, forasmuche as they both saw Christ with their bodely eyen,
column8: Annas, Caiaphas, and Herod be saved, forasmuch as they both saw christ with their bodily eyes,

column7: & also spoke with him.
column8: & also spoke with him.

column7: It saueth nor helpeth no more a man to se Christe with hys bodely eyen, then it did the Iewes their boasting in their father Abraham.
column8: It Saveth nor Helpeth no more a man to see Christ with his bodily eyes, then it did the Jews their boasting in their father Abraham.

column7: <NOTE> Here be requiered greater things.
column8: Here be requiered greater things.

column7: But which ar they? A pure hart, that beleueth the worde of god, and Christ the truth, and the same Messias that was promised vnto vs, and also to beleue and knowledg him the sauioure of the worlde.
column8: But which Are they? A pure heart, that Believeth the word of god, and christ the truth, and the same Messias that was promised unto us, and also to believe and knowledge him the Saviour of the world.

column7: And suche faith and confession hadde the apostles when the holye ghoste was not yet openly giuen, but hidde.
column8: And such faith and Confessi had the Apostles when the holy ghost was not yet openly given, but hid.

column7: For Christ asking theym: Wyll ye also go awaye?
column8: For christ asking them: Will you also go away?

column7: <NOTE> Peter answered in the name of theim all:
column8: Peter answered in the name of them all:

column7: Lord to whom shuld we go?
column8: Lord to whom should we go?

column7: thou haste the worde of euerlasting lyfe, and we beleue and know, that thou arte Christ the son of the liuing god.
column8: thou haste the word of everlasting life, and we believe and know, that thou art christ the son of the living god.

column7: Doth not this seeme vnto ye an excellet & glorious confessio?
column8: Does not this seem unto you an excellet & glorious confessio?

column7: which confessio pleased Christ so highly, that he said:
column8: which confessio pleased christ so highly, that he said:

column7: Blessed art thou Symo Bar Iona, for flesh & bloud hath not reueled this thing vnto the, but my father that is in heaue.
column8: Blessed art thou Simo Bar Iona, for Flesh & blood hath not revealed this thing unto thee, but my father that is in heave.

column7: Wherout it is euidet, that ye apostels saw not Christ alloly wt their bodely & fleshly eien, but also saw hi spiritualli, wherby they gat & obtained blessednes.
column8: Without it is euidet, that you Apostles saw not christ alloly with their bodily & fleshly eien, but also saw him spiritualli, whereby they got & obtained blessedness.

column7: In yt thei sawe Christ, they ar to be preferred before kinges & prophetes, forbicause they knewe Christe not only through his word, but also they saw his personage and myracles, and were a lyue at that tyme, in the which his diuine and godly grace through the gospell was diclared vnto the world.
column8: In that they saw christ, they Are to be preferred before Kings & Prophets, For because they knew Christ not only through his word, but also they saw his personage and Miracles, and were a live At that time, in the which his divine and godly grace through the gospel was diclared unto the world.

column7: For Abraham desyered to see this day, and saw it in spirite, and reioysed therein.
column8: For Abraham desired to see this day, and saw it in Spirit, and rejoiced therein.

column7: <NOTE> But he could not come therevnto, to see him bodely.
column8: But he could not come thereunto, to see him bodily.

column7: And bicause we in these dayes can not see Christ, bodely to be conuersaunte amongest vs, to preache and to do miracles, to eate and drink amongest vs, let vs therefore indeuour our cogitacions and thoughts, to se and know him spiritually.
column8: And Because we in these days can not see christ, bodily to be conversant amongst us, to preach and to do Miracles, to eat and drink amongst us, let us Therefore endeavour our cogitations and thoughts, to see and know him spiritually.

column7: And in so doyng, the sayig of Christ vnto Thomas shall be perfurmed in vs, wher he saieth:
column8: And in so doing, the sayig of christ unto Thomas shall be perfurmed in us, where he Saith:

column7: Blessed at they that see not,
column8: Blessed At they that see not,

column7: <NOTE> and yet beleue.
column8: and yet believe.

column7: Secondarely, when Christe had pronounced his disciples blessed for their faithe sake, beholde, there stode vp a scribe and tempted him and sayde:
column8: Secondarily, when Christ had pronounced his Disciples blessed for their faith sake, behold, there stood up a scribe and tempted him and said:

column7: Maister, what muste I do to inherite euerlastinge lyfe?
column8: Master, what must I do to inherit everlasting life?

column7: In the which properly is discribed vnto vs, the nature of hipocrisy.
column8: In the which properly is described unto us, the nature of hypocrisy.

column7: For hipocrites euer treate of works, yea they truste in works, and therfore euer they bee speaking of theim.
column8: For Hypocrites ever Treat of works, yea they trust in works, and Therefore ever they be speaking of them.

column7: Doth yt not seeme vnto the a folishe thinge, to dispute of the frutest, before the tree be planted?
column8: Does that not seem unto thee a foolish thing, to dispute of the frutest, before the tree be planted?

column7: What preuayleth it, to know what is written and commaunded in the law,
column8: What prevaileth it, to know what is written and commanded in the law,

column7: If I know not how to fulfyl it?
column8: If I know not how to fulfil it?

column7: For that knowledge dothe not aloly not preuaile, but also worketh angre & wrath accordyng to the sayinge of S.
column8: For that knowledge doth not aloly not prevail, but also works anger & wrath according to the saying of S.

column7: Paule. <NOTE> Wherefore it is necessary for theim that desier to be saued, to in quiernot only what manner of work they shuld do, but howe and when the lawe is fulfilled.
column8: Paul. Wherefore it is necessary for them that desire to be saved, to in quiernot only what manner of work they should do, but how and when the law is fulfilled.

column7: For the lawe is spirituall,
column8: For the law is spiritual,

column7: <NOTE> as S. Paule writeth to the Romaines.
column8: as S. Paul Writeth to the Romans.

column7: And if the lawe then be spiritual, so can it not be fulfilled with outwarde workes, which haue outwardely a shine, but it is necessary that it bee fulfilled in the spirite and inward affection.
column8: And if the law then be spiritual, so can it not be fulfilled with outward works, which have outwardly a shine, but it is necessary that it be fulfilled in the Spirit and inward affection.

column7: Furthermore, for as muche as the spirite and the affection pertaine necessarily to the fulfilling of the lawe, to what purpose is this questio of the scribe?
column8: Furthermore, for as much as the Spirit and the affection pertain necessarily to the fulfilling of the law, to what purpose is this Question of the scribe?

column7: Yet thou shalte note, that he answered bothe wisely and truly to that questio, that Christ obiected against him:
column8: Yet thou shalt note, that he answered both wisely and truly to that Question, that christ objected against him:

column7: In the lawe is written:
column8: In the law is written:

column7: Thou shalte loue thy lorde god with all thy harte, with all thy sowle, with all thy strength, with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thy selfe.
column8: Thou shalt love thy lord god with all thy heart, with all thy soul, with all thy strength, with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thy self.

column7: This only wanted and lacked whiche Christ bringeth in:
column8: This only wanted and lacked which christ brings in:

column7: Do this (saith he) & thou shalte lyue.
column8: Do this (Says he) & thou shalt live.

column7: And forbicause he didde not enquire by what meanes or how that same mighte be fulfilled, it appeareth thereby, that he was one of those scribes that iustified himselfe, and so styll remayned.
column8: And For because he did not inquire by what means or how that same might be fulfilled, it appears thereby, that he was one of those Scribes that justified himself, and so still remained.

column7: And though he of presumption & pryde, which euer doth folowe hipocrisy, enquired no more of that thinge that he comoned of, yet must not we leaue ther, but are bounde to knowe what is the lawe and what it worketh, and what the gospell is, and what it bringeth to passe.
column8: And though he of presumption & pride, which ever does follow hypocrisy, inquired no more of that thing that he commoned of, yet must not we leave there, but Are bound to know what is the law and what it works, and what the gospel is, and what it brings to pass.

column7: The lawe <NOTE> is a doctrine that teacheth me what I am bound to do and to eschewe, and vndoubtedly the effecte thereof is nothing else, then that it sheweth vs our offences, and our sinne.
column8: The law is a Doctrine that Teaches me what I am bound to do and to eschew, and undoubtedly the Effect thereof is nothing Else, then that it shows us our offences, and our sin.

column7: For whersoeuer the lawe is preached, there I do heare what thinge I am bounde to do and to leaue, but in dede I perceiue, that of myne owne power I can not do nor bringe to passe, that thinge, that is commaunded me to do,
column8: For wheresoever the law is preached, there I do hear what thing I am bound to do and to leave, but in deed I perceive, that of mine own power I can not do nor bring to pass, that thing, that is commanded me to do,

column7: & by that meanes meeked and brought low,
column8: & by that means meeked and brought low,

column7: I come to ye knowledg of my corrupte nature & syn.
column8: I come to you knowledge of my corrupt nature & sin.

column8: Also I find, that without the holy ghost I can not fulfil the law.

column8: Hereto then pertaineth the gospel,

column8: & a working faith in me, so that now I shall fulfil the law, not by coaction, but willingly.

column8: Thirdly, when this scribe justicing him self, asked christ who was his neighbour,

column8: christ by a symilitude Layeth it before his eyes plainly, that he might understand that, and Says on this wise.

column7: A certaine man went downe from Ierusalem vnto Ierycho &c.
column8: A certain man went down from Jerusalem unto Jericho etc.

column7: In thend of this similitude this scribe knowledgeth himselfe, that he was neighbour vnto hym that fell amongest ye murtherers, which holy hym yt was wounded, and had compassion vpon him, wher Christ teacheth vs, not only who is my neighbour, namely he that needeth of my helpe, whether he be frend or fo, but also mihtely cocludeth, yt this scribe had not kept this second comaundement in louing his neighbour, wherout it must needs folow & was euidet, that he had not obserued the first comaundemet, wherin he is comaunded to loue god.
column8: In The end of this similitude this scribe knowledgeth himself, that he was neighbour unto him that fell amongst you murderers, which holy him that was wounded, and had compassion upon him, where christ Teaches us, not only who is my neighbour, namely he that needs of my help, whither he be friend or foe, but also mihtely cocludeth, that this scribe had not kept this second Commandment in loving his neighbour, Without it must needs follow & was euidet, that he had not observed the First comaundemet, wherein he is commanded to love god.

column7: For why else wold Christ haue sayd:
column8: For why Else would christ have said:

column7: Go thy way then and do thou likewise?
column8: Go thy Way then and do thou likewise?

column7: If he had done it, there had bene no nede of a commaundemet, to haue done yt againe.
column8: If he had done it, there had be no need of a Commandment, to have done that again.

column7: Wherefore in conclusion. Though this scribe outwardely appeared neuer so vertuous & iuste, yet is he here ouercome, that he neither kept the fyrste nor the second commaundement.
column8: Wherefore in conclusion. Though this scribe outwardly appeared never so virtuous & just, yet is he Here overcome, that he neither kept the First nor the second Commandment.

column7: Wherfore let vs take here an example, not of the scribe, but of the Samaritan, whom the loue of god so allured to do this benefyte vpon him that was wounded.
column8: Wherefore let us take Here an Exampl, not of the scribe, but of the Samaritan, whom the love of god so allured to do this benefit upon him that was wounded.

column7: But note this also, how priuily he toucheth this scribe, in speakig of the Priest and of the Leuite, that passed by thys wounded man, without shewing of any mercy vnto him.
column8: But note this also, how privily he touches this scribe, in speakig of the Priest and of the Levite, that passed by this wounded man, without showing of any mercy unto him.

column7: For therwith all, Christe accuseth al the priestis at Ierusalem, that they had neither the loue of god nor of their neighbour, without there chauced therby some profite.
column8: For therewith all, Christ Accuseth all the priestis At Jerusalem, that they had neither the love of god nor of their neighbour, without there chanced thereby Some profit.

column8: And that Come to pass, that as they went they were cleansed. And one of them when he saw that he was cleansed, turned back again, and with a loud voice praised god, and fell down on his face At his feet, and gave him thanks.

column7: F Yrste, this gospell declareth vnto vs meruailous excellent examples of fayth in these leepers, whiche togither with one voice cryed and called vpon Christe for helpe.
column8: First First, this gospel Declareth unto us marvelous excellent Examples of faith in these leepers, which together with one voice cried and called upon Christ for help.

column7: And these examples are meruailouslye well ioyned to that doctrine that Christe taughte before, teaching vs (as S.
column8: And these Examples Are meruailouslye well joined to that Doctrine that Christ taught before, teaching us (as S.

column7: Luc. testifieth) to saye and confesse:
column8: Luke Testifieth) to say and confess:

column7: <NOTE> We be vnprofitable seruauntes, yea though we do all that is commaunded vs to do.
column8: We be unprofitable Servants, yea though we do all that is commanded us to do.

column7: Out of which wordes wee maye gather, that seying there is no worke sufficiet before god without fayth, that there is no worke at all, wherby we can get or obtaine any thing of god, in especyall yf it pertayne vnto saluacion.
column8: Out of which words we may gather, that saying there is no work sufficiet before god without faith, that there is no work At all, whereby we can get or obtain any thing of god, in especial if it pertain unto salvation.

column7: For that that he gyueth, he gyueth of hys mere mercy, wherfore if we will obtayne any thinge of hym, we must gape after mercy.
column8: For that that he gyveth, he gyveth of his mere mercy, Wherefore if we will obtain any thing of him, we must gape After mercy.

column7: For yf we regard our workes and haue confidence in theym, yt ys vnpossyble but wee shall doubte, whether he wyll helpe vs or not, for as muche as no mortall manne doeth so muche as hee ys bounde to dooe.
column8: For if we regard our works and have confidence in them, that is unpossible but we shall doubt, whither he will help us or not, for as much as no Mortal man doth so much as he is bound to do.

column7: Is yt not blasphemye to god contrarye and repugnaunte to the fayth in Chryst, to doubte, whether wee be hearde or not?
column8: Is that not blasphemy to god contrary and repugnaunte to the faith in Christ, to doubt, whither we be heard or not?

column7: Wherefore wee maye see in these tenne lepoures, that they beleued and doubted not, but that freely wythout anye deseruynge,
column8: Wherefore we may see in these tenne lepoures, that they believed and doubted not, but that freely without any deserving,

column7: Chryst wold restore them to helth.
column8: Christ would restore them to health.

column7: Whych yf they had doubted, surely they wolde not baue hasted vnto Chryst wt so great desier, neyther wolde haue cryed oute so loude before they came at hym.
column8: Which if they had doubted, surely they would not have hasted unto Christ with so great desire, neither would have cried out so loud before they Come At him.

column7: But thys ys the matter:
column8: But this is the matter:

column7: They had herd how meeke and mercifull Christ was, and that he mercifully helpt euery manne, that desired helpe of him.
column8: They had heard how meek and merciful christ was, and that he mercifully helped every man, that desired help of him.

column7: Through suche fame and speakyng of Christ, they conceiued a certain hope & trust to be restored vnto helth.
column8: Through such fame and speaking of christ, they conceived a certain hope & trust to be restored unto health.

column7: And so was it brought to passe. <NOTE> And whan as he entred into a certaine toune, there mette him ten Leperous men, whiche stode styll for ioy accordyng to the nature and disposicion of fayth.
column8: And so was it brought to pass. And when as he entered into a certain town, there met him ten Leperous men, which stood still for joy according to the nature and disposition of faith.

column7: They stoode, as though they would saye:
column8: They stood, as though they would say:

column7: Here is he that can helpe vs, and wyll helpe vs, what wyll wee go any further?
column8: Here is he that can help us, and will help us, what will we go any further?

column7: Let vs open oure infirmitie to this mercyfull Lord, and suerly he wyll not suffre vs to go away without comfort.
column8: Let us open our infirmity to this merciful Lord, and surely he will not suffer us to go away without Comfort.

column7: <NOTE> And after foloweth their peticion, whiche was not done priuely, but with a loud voyce, wherout we may note, howe they hoped for great cofort of Christ.
column8: And After Followeth their petition, which was not done privily, but with a loud voice, Without we may note, how they hoped for great Comfort of christ.

column7: But what say they? Iesu maister, haue mercy vpo vs.
column8: But what say they? Jesu master, have mercy upon us

column7: Howe could they haue made suche an excellent prayer, if they had not been instructed by the holy ghost?
column8: How could they have made such an excellent prayer, if they had not been instructed by the holy ghost?

column7: For to acknowledge Christ to be their gouernour and maister, is to professe that he was sent from God, and his doctrin to be suche, as is worthy to be receyued of all menne.
column8: For to acknowledge christ to be their governor and master, is to profess that he was sent from God, and his Doctrine to be such, as is worthy to be received of all men.

column7: And to desire of him to shewe his mercy vpon vs, is nothyng els, but to confesse that wee of oure owne righteousnesse, goodnes and woorkes, can obtaine nothyng, but must receiue al thyng through grace.
column8: And to desire of him to show his mercy upon us, is nothing Else, but to confess that we of our own righteousness, Goodness and works, can obtain nothing, but must receive all thing through grace.

column7: Wee geue vnto God his owne honour, when wee knowlege him true in his saiyng, where he sayth:
column8: we give unto God his own honour, when we knowledge him true in his saying, where he say:

column7: Without me ye can do nothyng.
column8: Without me you can do nothing.

column7: <NOTE> Nowe forasmuch as these Lepres haue so great hope and trust in the goodnes of Christ, and doubt nothyng, but that he wyll helpe them,
column8: Now forasmuch as these Lepers have so great hope and trust in the Goodness of christ, and doubt nothing, but that he will help them,

column7: We must nedes confesse, that thei had a true fayth.
column8: We must needs confess, that they had a true faith.

column7: Wherfore let vs here cosider, that we learne likewyse to seke and call vpon Christe in our trouble and necessitie.
column8: Wherefore let us Here Consider, that we Learn likewise to seek and call upon Christ in our trouble and necessity.

column7: Secondarily, we see in this Gospel, yt if we seke Christ with a true fayth, he wyll shewe him selfe as good and mercyfull towarde vs, as he hath done towarde these Lepres.
column8: Secondarily, we see in this Gospel, that if we seek christ with a true faith, he will show him self as good and merciful toward us, as he hath done toward these Lepers.

column7: Fyrst he beholdeth them. Blessed are we if Christ with his mercyfull eyen loketh vpon vs,
column8: Fyrst he beholdeth them. Blessed Are we if christ with his merciful eyes looketh upon us,

column8: & findeth faith in our hearts.

column7: For where that chaunseth, we be sure to haue saluacion, both of body and soule.
column8: For where that chaunseth, we be sure to have salvation, both of body and soul.

column8: And that the beholding of christ signified no wrath, but grace, the words that follow declare it, for he say:

column8: Go your ways, and show your selves unto the Priests.

column7: Nowe when Christe perceiued the fayth of these Lepres, he sayth not that he wyll helpe them, but as though they were alredy holpe, he biddeth them to go and shewe them selues to the priestes, whose office and duetie was to iudge and discerne Lepre.
column8: Now when Christ perceived the faith of these Lepers, he say not that he will help them, but as though they were already help, he bids them to go and show them selves to the Priests, whose office and duty was to judge and discern Lepre.

column8: What do now these Lepers?

column8: They do even as Abraham did,

column8: when God commanded him to go out of his country and from his kindred and from his Father's house, he asked not where he should become, but obeyed unto God, and in his so going, conceived a sure confidence, that God would not lede him amiss.

column8: And in likewise do these ten Leper's.

column8: which Helpeth so willingly, so lovingly & so gladly, so that for his benignity, familiarity and mercy sake, all the Whole world is bound to hast unto him, to ask mercy.

column8: But we, alas, Are so ungracious & indurate that no benevolence or gratiousnes (although it be never so great) can move us to seek christ.

column8: If you can believe, my help shall always be At hand.

column7: Thyrdly, we see in this gospel the geuyng of thakes of this Samaritane, which when he perceiued himselfe to be cleane, he returned againe, and with a loude voyce magnifyed God, geuyng him thankes for the great benefite done vnto him.
column8: Thirdly, we see in this gospel the giving of Takes of this Samaritan, which when he perceived himself to be clean, he returned again, and with a loud voice magnified God, giving him thanks for the great benefit done unto him.

column7: And againe wee see here the ingratitude and vnthankefulnes of the other nyne, whiche fell from their fayth, and gaue no thankes to Christ for the great benefite done vnto them.
column8: And again we see Here the ingratitude and unthankfulness of the other nyne, which fell from their faith, and gave no thanks to christ for the great benefit done unto them.

column7: Wherout we learne, <NOTE> that there be many called to the fayth,
column8: Without we Learn, that there be many called to the faith,

column7: & but fewe which perseuer therin vnto the ende.
column8: & but few which persever therein unto the end.

column7: It is a meruailous thynge and wonderfull to say, that these ten menne had fayth, and therby obtayned helth, and yet was there but one of them that perseuered therein, and was saued.
column8: It is a marvelous thing and wonderful to say, that these ten men had faith, and thereby obtained health, and yet was there but one of them that persevered therein, and was saved.

column7: Who would not nowe feare him selfe, and stande in dreade, to see these nyne Iewes that first beleued,
column8: Who would not now Fear him self, and stand in dread, to see these nyne Jews that First believed,

column7: This is a true saiyng, where Christ sayth:

column8: Whosoever persevereth unto The end, shall saved.

column7: There are many of vs, which heare the worde of God, and receiue it with ioye, and shewe theim selues as though they would deuour the whole Gospell, and yet for all that, in the ende they do not alonely forsake their fayth, but also against their owne conscience,
column8: There Are many of us, which hear the word of God, and receive it with joy, and show them selves as though they would devour the Whole Gospel, and yet for all that, in the end they do not alonely forsake their faith, but also against their own conscience,

column7: <NOTE> they do persecute the manyfest trueth.
column8: they do persecute the manifest truth.

column7: Vnto whom might very well bee spoken:
column8: Unto whom might very well be spoken:

column7: <NOTE> Briefely: Christ is true in that he hath spoken, saiyng:
column8: Briefly: christ is true in that he hath spoken, saying:

column7: There be many called, but there be but fewe chosen.
column8: There be many called, but there be but few chosen.

column7: Wherfore by right the ingratitude and vnthankefulnes of these nyne Iewes, ought to feare vs, and not only to feare vs, but also to constraine vs dayly and hourely to pray vnto God, that we may obtayne through Christ this constancie and perseuerance.
column8: Wherefore by right the ingratitude and unthankfulness of these nyne Jews, ought to Fear us, and not only to Fear us, but also to constrain us daily and hourly to pray unto God, that we may obtain through christ this constancy and perseverance.

column7: Also the thankefulnes of the Samaritane, may prouoke vs to laude & praise God for his goodnes, that we receiue of him.
column8: Also the thankfulness of the Samaritan, may provoke us to laud & praise God for his Goodness, that we receive of him.

column7: Forasmuche as our mercyfull God meruaylously deliteth in rendryng and geuyng suche thankes, as he speaketh through the Prophete Dauid:
column8: Forasmuch as our merciful God marvelously delighteth in rendering and giving such thanks, as he speaks through the Prophet David:

column7: <NOTE> Who so offereth vnto me thankes and praise, he honoureth me.
column8: Who so Offereth unto me thanks and praise, he Honoureth me.

column7: Why (I pray you) doth Christ aske after these nyne that were cleane, and doth not returne again vnto him, to geue him thankes?
column8: Why (I pray you) does christ ask After these nyne that were clean, and does not return again unto him, to give him thanks?

column7: Truely therfore, that their ingratitude and vnthankefulnes highly displeased him.
column8: Truly Therefore, that their ingratitude and unthankfulness highly displeased him.

column7: And wherfore thynke you doth the Euangelist so diligently discribe, that this Samaritane, whiche criyng out, did fall doune vpon his face at Iesus feete, and magnifyed God, and gaue him thankes?
column8: And Wherefore think you does the Evangelist so diligently describe, that this Samaritan, which crying out, did fallen down upon his face At jesus feet, and magnified God, and gave him thanks?

column7: doubteles that hee therwith woulde commend, publishe and shewe vs the constancy of his faith, and how highely the sacrifice of giuinge thankes and praise, pleaseth god.
column8: doubtless that he therewith would commend, publish and show us the constancy of his faith, and how highly the sacrifice of giving thanks and praise, Pleases god.

column7: Nowe forasmuch as the kingdome of god is taken from the vnthankful Iewes, and giuen vnto vs Gentiles, we knowledging this benefite, let vs daily giue thankes vnto God throughe Christe, that hee will vouchsafe to make vs constant in faith, and bring vs to euerlasting saluacion, through Christe our lord.
column8: Now forasmuch as the Kingdom of god is taken from the unthankful Jews, and given unto us Gentiles, we knowledging this benefit, let us daily give thanks unto God through Christ, that he will vouchsafe to make us constant in faith, and bring us to everlasting salvation, through Christ our lord.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the fyftenth sonday after trinitie sonday. Math. 6.

column7: NO man can serue two maisters:

column7: Is not the lyfe more worth than meate?
column8: Is not the life more worth than meat?

column7: and the bodye more of valewe than rayment?
column8: and the body more of valve than raiment?

column8: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor carry into their Barns, and your heavenly father feeds them.

column7: Are ye not muche better then they?
column8: are you not much better then they?

column8: And why care you for ray^ente?

column8: They labour not, neither do they spynne.

column8: And yet I say unto you, that even Solomon in all his royalty, was not arayedlyke unto one of these.

column8: Oh you of little faith?

column8: Item: Consider the lilies of the field, they labour not, neither spin.

column7: <NOTE> But wee bee of little faithe, as Christe saithe here, and in frayle and transitory thinges so blinded & indurat, that neither intreaty, neither threatnyng, neyther promise, nor miracles, nor yet no teaching can moue vs.

column8: we will not forsake the care of the belly, which Causes us against the Doctrine of Christ, to heap up riches Here upon earth, and serve that idol our belly, whereby we forget the true and right serving of God, and do neither hope nor yet beeleue in God, but all our care is, to have our Barns full.

column8: To seek the Kingdom of god, is no other thing, then to pray that he will bring us unto faith, and through his holy ghost Comfort and hold us in the same faith, unto our end, as the Prophet David did, of whom we read in the 50. Psalm. and in the 118.

column7: Whiche if we diligently doo, our faith (for the which we pray) shall not bee allonly encresed and augmented, according to Christes promise,

column7: Therfore let vs wel considre and comprehend this promise in our harte, that we may learn, both in our spirituall and worldly matters, to hope, trust, and put our confidence only in god through Christ, that we may not through such ethnicall carefulnes for bodely thinges, be separated frome Christe, and the true seruing of god.
column8: Therefore let us well Consider and comprehend this promise in our heart, that we may Learn, both in our spiritual and worldly matters, to hope, trust, and put our confidence only in god through christ, that we may not through such ethnical carefulness for bodily things, be separated from Christ, and the true serving of god.

column7: A Nd it fortuned after this, that he betwente into a citie whiche is called Naim, and manye of hys disciples went with hym, and muche people.
column8: ANd ANd it fortuned After this, that he betwente into a City which is called Nain, and many of his Disciples went with him, and much people.

column7: When he came nighe to the gate of the citye, beholde, there was a deade man caried out, which was the only sonne of hys mother and she was a widow, and much people of the citye was with her.

column8: Weep not. And he Come High, and touched the coffin, and they that bore him, stood still.

column8: And he said: Young man,

column8: I say unto thee, arise.

column8: And he that was dead, sat up, and began to speak. And he Delivered him to his mother.

column7: And there came a feare on them all and they gaue the glory vnto god, saying: <NOTE> A greate prophete is risen vp among vs, and god hath visited his people. THE EXPOSION.
column8: And there Come a Fear on them all and they gave the glory unto god, saying: A great Prophet is risen up among us, and god hath visited his people. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: F Orasmuche as in this gospell we find what great benefite and charity was shewed vnto this widow, therfore let vs search out afore al things with what sorowe & misfortune shee was oppressed with al.
column8: Forasmuch Forasmuch as in this gospel we find what great benefit and charity was showed unto this widow, Therefore let us search out afore all things with what sorrow & misfortune she was oppressed with all

column8: Peter, If now that incommodity also chance unto her, to lose her husband, than utterly she hath no Comfort in this world.

column7: Herof it cometh, that ther is no man welnigh, that more moueth a good hart, and allureth him to pitye and compassion, then the name of a wydowe and a fatherlesse childe, yea god him selfe, bycause that this kind of people liue without comfort and consolation,
column8: Hereof it comes, that there is no man Wellnigh, that more moves a good heart, and Allureth him to pity and compassion, then the name of a widow and a fatherless child, yea god him self, Because that this kind of people live without Comfort and consolation,

column7: & vtterly are dispised of the world, helpeth them, and careth for them, ye & with this example he comedeth them vnto vs, that we herein shuld folow him.
column8: & utterly Are despised of the world, Helpeth them, and Careth for them, you & with this Exampl he comedeth them unto us, that we herein should follow him.

column7: For it is written in the fift boke of Moises:
column8: For it is written in the fift book of Moses:

column7: <NOTE> The lord your god is god of al goddes, and lord ouer all lordes, a great, mighty,
column8: The lord your god is god of all God's, and lord over all Lords, a great, mighty,

column7: & terrible god, which regardeth no parso & taketh no gift.

column8: He does right unto the fatherless & widow.

column8: He loves the stranger, & gives him food and raymet Therefore love you also the Strangers. etc. Two things Are Here to be noted.

column7: The one is, That God wil not forsake the widowes and fatherles children, but that he wil kepe and mercifully saue them.
column8: The one is, That God will not forsake the Widows and fatherless children, but that he will keep and mercifully save them.

column7: Another is, that we shal loue and helpe poore miserable and forsaken people.
column8: another is, that we shall love and help poor miserable and forsaken people.

column8: To the First the Prophets and in espetiall David hath much respect and regard, comending and praising god to be the father of Widows & of orphans,

column8: saying: O sing unto god, sing praises unto his name,

column8: Magnify him that rideth above you heaves, whose name is the lord.

column7: Pure deuocion and vndefiled before God the father is this, to visite the frendles & wydowes in their aduersitee, and to kepe him selfe vnspotted of the worlde.
column8: Pure devotion and undefiled before God the father is this, to visit the frendles & Widows in their adversity, and to keep him self unspotted of the world.

column7: Nowe forasmuche as this woma had lost her husband and was become a wydowe, vndoubtedly she was in a miserable state.
column8: Now forasmuch as this Woman had lost her husband and was become a widow, undoubtedly she was in a miserable state.

column7: Neuerthelesse she had some comforte & solace left in her only sonne, in whom was her delite.
column8: Nevertheless she had Some Comfort & solace left in her only son, in whom was her delight.

column7: But he in like maner died also, so that nowe all her ioy & comforte in this worlde, was spent and gone.
column8: But he in like manner died also, so that now all her joy & Comfort in this world, was spent and gone.

column7: He that knoweth with what great affections the mother loueth and embraceth her children after the death of the father, may lightly perceiue and vnderstand, in what trouble and misery this woma was in.
column8: He that Knoweth with what great affections the mother loves and Embraceth her children After the death of the father, may lightly perceive and understand, in what trouble and misery this Woman was in.

column7: But what should I make many wordes?
column8: But what should I make many words?

column7: vndoubtedly I thinke there could skant chaunce more trouble vnto this woman, then to lese both her husband & her childe, and to be so vtterly comfortles.
column8: undoubtedly I think there could skant chance more trouble unto this woman, then to less both her husband & her child, and to be so utterly comfortless.

column7: Wherfore let a man first consider her misery as it is written of the Euangelist.
column8: Wherefore let a man First Consider her misery as it is written of the Evangelist.

column7: Secondarily we see & perceiue in this gospel the goodnes and loue of Christ, with the whiche he pityeth this woman.
column8: Secondarily we see & perceive in this gospel the Goodness and love of christ, with the which he pityeth this woman.

column7: And this is to be noted, that though the loue of Christ is highly commeded and praised in al the histories of the gospel, yet chifly we may perceiue it here in this place more plainer and excellent, for here was no fayth that should expresse the sorowe of this woman, and seke for grace.
column8: And this is to be noted, that though the love of christ is highly commeded and praised in all the histories of the gospel, yet chifly we may perceive it Here in this place more plainer and excellent, for Here was no faith that should express the sorrow of this woman, and seek for grace.

column7: All that is done here of Christ, is done of mercy & loue, and of great pitie and compassion of the heart, that was had towarde this woman.
column8: All that is done Here of christ, is done of mercy & love, and of great pity and compassion of the heart, that was had toward this woman.

column7: I shall heare them. Seyng that all is done here of mere grace, who would presumptuously glory in woorkes, though he had wrought neuer so muche?
column8: I shall hear them. Sing that all is done Here of mere grace, who would presumptuously glory in works, though he had wrought never so much?

column7: And againe. who would dispayre for synne, and would not rather hast him to Christ?
column8: And again. who would despair for sin, and would not rather hast him to christ?

column7: This benefite done to this wydowe, is and may be to vs a lyuely doctrine, that we shall hope for all goodnes of Christ, if that vngratious infidelite did not hynder vs, and leade vs awaye from the confidence in Christ. <NOTE> Suche examples of the great loue and charite of Christ, do leade & instruct vs to true fayth, so that we may perceiue that we be not onely restored vnto health by grace, but also thereby are iustified and saued.
column8: This benefit done to this widow, is and may be to us a lively Doctrine, that we shall hope for all Goodness of christ, if that ungracious infidelite did not hinder us, and lead us away from the confidence in christ. Such Examples of the great love and charity of christ, do lead & instruct us to true faith, so that we may perceive that we be not only restored unto health by grace, but also thereby Are justified and saved.

column7: This fayth requireth of vs the whole scripture, with al thapostolical Epistles,
column8: This faith requires of us the Whole scripture, with all thapostolical Epistles,

column7: But reason and maisters subtiltie wyll not vnderstande it, but thynketh to obtayne all thynges through her workes.
column8: But reason and masters subtlety will not understand it, but Thinketh to obtain all things through her works.

column7: And if the scripture sixehudreth tymes did wytnesse,
column8: And if the scripture sixehudreth times did witness,

column7: <NOTE> That he that worketh not, but beleueth in him that iustifyeth the wicked, that his fayth were reputed to righteousnes,
column8: That he that works not, but Believeth in him that Justifieth the wicked, that his faith were reputed to righteousness,

column7: Yet our curiosite can a great deale better do it and vnderstand it.
column8: Yet our curiosity can a great deal better do it and understand it.

column7: But lette euery man take hede, that he go the right way, and erre not.
column8: But let every man take heed, that he go the right Way, and err not.

column7: For the tyme is nere at had, that we shall either for true doctrine reioyce with God, or els for false doctrin be vtterly cofounded.
column8: For the time is never At had, that we shall either for true Doctrine rejoice with God, or Else for false Doctrine be utterly cofounded.

column7: Surely this woman had neither fayth before in Christe, nor yet had done any worke, where through she had deserued so great benefite, and yet great grace was shewed vnto her.
column8: Surely this woman had neither faith before in Christ, nor yet had done any work, where through she had deserved so great benefit, and yet great grace was showed unto her.

column7: He that not beyng desired, nor yet intreated, doth so great benefite vnto this woman, thynkest thou that he wyll not do the same to those that praye to him for it?
column8: He that not being desired, nor yet entreated, does so great benefit unto this woman, Thinkest thou that he will not do the same to those that pray to him for it?

column7: Briefly. At all tymes he is ready to helpe vs and to do vs good, so that we can beleue & doubte not.
column8: Briefly. At all times he is ready to help us and to do us good, so that we can believe & doubt not.

column7: And for the moste partie, then doth he helpeth vs, whe we haue most neede of him, yea, when we thinke that God himselfe, heauen and yearth,
column8: And for the most party, then does he Helpeth us, when we have most need of him, yea, when we think that God himself, heaven and earth,

column7: & all is against vs,
column8: & all is against us,

column7: & that we be vtterly forsaken, then (I say) doth he begyn to helpe.
column8: & that we be utterly forsaken, then (I say) does he begin to help.

column7: And the same thou seest to happen to this woman.
column8: And the same thou See to happen to this woman.

column7: For when her sorowe was greatest, then did he helpe her.
column8: For when her sorrow was greatest, then did he help her.

column7: And that is the same that Dauid sayth:
column8: And that is the same that David say:

column7: When I call, <NOTE> heare me,
column8: When I call, hear me,

column7: O God of my righteousnes, and comforte me in my trouble.
column8: Oh God of my righteousness, and Comfort me in my trouble.

column7: Thyrdly, we see in this miracle the strength and vertue of Gods woorde,
column8: Thirdly, we see in this miracle the strength and virtue of God's word,

column7: <NOTE> and what it worketh in vs when we coprehend it by fayth.
column8: and what it works in us when we coprehend it by faith.

column7: For the Euangelist after that he hath shewed & declared vnto vs, howe Christ had pitie on this woman and comforted her, after he wryteth, howe Christ through his woorde, raysed this child fro death,
column8: For the Evangelist After that he hath showed & declared unto us, how christ had pity on this woman and comforted her, After he writes, how christ through his word, raised this child from death,

column7: & sayth: He came nigh & touched the coffyn,
column8: & say: He Come High & touched the coffin,

column7: & they that bare him stode stil,
column8: & they that bore him stood still,

column8: & he said: Young ma,

column7: I say vnto thee, aryse.
column8: I say unto thee, arise.

column7: Here you heare, that Christ is Lorde aswell ouer the dead as ouer ye quicke,
column8: Here you hear, that christ is Lord aswell over the dead as over you quick,

column7: & what he speaketh to this yong ma that is dead.
column8: & what he speaks to this young ma that is dead.

column8: But what happened? The dead sat up and began to speak.

column7: Beholde the great vertue of Christes worde, that by the same the dead are raised to life.
column8: Behold the great virtue of Christ's word, that by the same the dead Are raised to life.

column8: And whatsoever is done Here, After you history to this young ma, the same must be done daily, spiritually in us

column7: For who is without synne?
column8: For who is without sin?

column7: And the reward of synne is death.
column8: And the reward of sin is death.

column7: Therfore if we wyll be deliuered fro synne,
column8: Therefore if we will be Delivered from sin,

column7: & escape euerlastyng death, Christ with his worde must come & do it.
column8: & escape everlasting death, christ with his word must come & do it.

column7: For Christ sayth: He that kepeth my worde,
column8: For christ say: He that Keepeth my word,

column7: <NOTE> shal not dye euerlastyngly.
column8: shall not die everlastingly.

column7: And his worde must bee comprehended & vnderstanded by a true fayth.
column8: And his word must be comprehended & understanded by a true faith.

column7: For where the knowlege of this worde lacketh,
column8: For where the knowledge of this word lacketh,

column7: <NOTE> there Christ which is the word, is not knowen.
column8: there christ which is the word, is not known.

column7: And againe, where Christ is not knowen, there cannot God be praised nor glorified with the woordes of this people, saiyng:
column8: And again, where christ is not known, there cannot God be praised nor glorified with the words of this people, saying:

column7: A great prophet is risen amongst vs, and God hath visited his people. <NOTE> And contrary wise, where this worde is comprehended & in heart conceyued, there is Christ knowen,
column8: A great Prophet is risen among us, and God hath visited his people. And contrary wise, where this word is comprehended & in heart conceived, there is christ known,

column7: & when he is knowen, then is God praised and glorifyed, because that he hath visited vs, not in his wrath, but with his infinite mercy, and hath geue vs his only welbeloued sone, so that through his passion & death, he hath redemed vs fro synne, death, deuil, and hell,
column8: & when he is known, then is God praised and glorified, Because that he hath visited us, not in his wrath, but with his infinite mercy, and hath give us his only well-beloved soon, so that through his passion & death, he hath redeemed us from sin, death, Devil, and hell,

column7: For the whiche great benefite we are bounde to thanke him euerlastyngly.
column8: For the which great benefit we Are bound to thank him everlastingly.

column7: Fynally, the benignitee of Christ allureth vs vnto fayth and fayth acknowlegeth the power of Gods worde, and this knowlege prayseth and glorifyeth God euerlastyngly.
column8: Finally, the benignity of christ Allureth us unto faith and faith acknowledgeth the power of God's word, and this knowledge Praiseth and glorifyeth God everlastingly.

column7: To whom with the sonne and holy ghost be all honour and praise.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost be all honour and praise.

column7: Amen. The gospel on the.xvii. sonday after Trinitee sonday. Luc. 14.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the xvii Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Luke 14.

column7: A Nd it chaunsed, that he went into the house of one of the chiefe Pharises, to eat bread, on a Sabboth day, and they watched him.
column8: ANd ANd it chanced, that he went into the house of one of the chief Pharisees, to eat bred, on a Sabbath day, and they watched him.

column7: And behold, there was a certain man before him, whiche had the dropsye.
column8: And behold, there was a certain man before him, which had the dropsy.

column7: And Iesus answered and spake vnto the lawyers and Pharisies, saiyng,
column8: And jesus answered and spoke unto the Lawyers and Pharisees, saying,

column7: <NOTE> is it lawful to heale on the sabboth day?
column8: is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath day?

column7: And they helde their peace.
column8: And they held their peace.

column7: And he toke him and healed him, and let him go,
column8: And he took him and healed him, and let him go,

column7: & answered theim, saiyng:
column8: & answered them, saying:

column8: Which of you have an Ass or an ox fallen into a pit,

column7: <NOTE> and wyl not straight waye pull him out on the Sabboth daye?
column8: and will not straight Way pull him out on the Sabbath day?

column7: And they could not answere him again to these thynges.
column8: And they could not answer him again to these things.

column8: He put forth also a similitude to the gests:

column8: when he marked how they pressed to the highest rooms,

column7: & sayd vnto them, when thou art bydden of any man to a weddyng, sitte not doune in the hyest roume, lest a more honorable man than thou, be bydden of him, and he (that bad him and the) come & say to the:
column8: & said unto them, when thou art bidden of any man to a wedding, sit not down in the highest room, lest a more honourable man than thou, be bidden of him, and he (that bade him and thee) come & say to thee:

column7: Geue this man roume, and thou then begyn with shame to take the lowest roume.
column8: Give this man room, and thou then begin with shame to take the lowest room.

column7: But rather when thou art bydden, go and sytte in the lowest roume, that when he that bad the commeth, he may say vnto thee:
column8: But rather when thou art bidden, go and fit in the lowest room, that when he that bade the comes, he may say unto thee:

column7: Frende sytte vp hyer. <NOTE> Then shalt thou haue worship in the presence of them that sytte at meate with thee.
column8: Friend fit up higher. Then shalt thou have worship in the presence of them that fit At meat with thee.

column7: <NOTE> For who soeuer exalteth himselfe, shalbe brought lowe.
column8: For who soever Exalteth himself, shall brought low.

column7: And he that humbleth himselfe, shalbe exalted. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And he that Humbleth himself, shall exalted. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this gospell Christ had to do & handleth with two maner of persones.
column8: IN this gospel christ had to do & handleth with two manner of Persons.

column7: Fyrst with the Pharisies, whiche wayted him to fynde occasion to reprehende him,
column8: Fyrst with the Pharisees, which waited him to find occasion to reprehend him,

column7: & also with this man that had the dropsye.
column8: & also with this man that had the dropsy.

column7: Let vs therfore see fyrst howe he handleth him selfe towarde these Phariseis, and howe the Phariseis handle themselfes towardes Christ. <NOTE> The Phariseis euer went aboute to blaspheme Christes doyng, accordyng to their nature and custome.
column8: Let us Therefore see fyrst how he handleth him self toward these Pharisees, and how the Pharisees handle themselves towards christ. The Pharisees ever went about to Blaspheme Christ's doing, according to their nature and custom.

column7: As for his doctryne semed vnto theim nothyng at all, by reason it was cotrary to hypocrisy.
column8: As for his Doctrine seemed unto them nothing At all, by reason it was contrary to hypocrisy.

column7: Wherfore there was neuer nothyng that pleased them, whatsoeuer Christe taught.
column8: Wherefore there was never nothing that pleased them, whatsoever Christ taught.

column7: And though they sawe neuer so muche his great miracles, whiche they could not denye, yet would they not geue God the glory, but sayd, that it was all done through Belzebub, prince of the deuils.
column8: And though they saw never so much his great Miracles, which they could not deny, yet would they not give God the glory, but said, that it was all done through Belzebub, Prince of the Devils.

column7: Muche suche blaspemye, deceite and enuy, shalt thou finde in the histories of the gospel.
column8: Much such blasphemy, deceit and envy, shalt thou find in the histories of the gospel.

column7: <NOTE> For euen as the Pharisies persecuted Christ,
column8: For even as the Pharisees persecuted christ,

column7: <NOTE> condempned his doctrine, and blasphemed his workes and miracles, so Christ set himselfe against them,
column8: condemned his Doctrine, and blasphemed his works and Miracles, so christ Set himself against them,

column7: & withstode them, as moste great enemies to his holy doctrine.
column8: & withstood them, as most great enemies to his holy Doctrine.

column7: If you loke in the histories of the gospel, you shall fynde cotinual warre betwene Christ and the Phariseis.
column8: If you look in the histories of the gospel, you shall find cotinual war between christ and the Pharisees.

column7: And it could bee no other wyse.
column8: And it could be no other wise.

column7: For he was the stombling stone, <NOTE> & a rocke to be offended at, and a token whiche shalbe spoken against of the worlde.
column8: For he was the stumbling stone, & a rock to be offended At, and a token which shall spoken against of the world.

column7: Wherfore it had not been well done, if he should haue graunted them any thyng pertainyng and touchyng the glory of his father.
column8: Wherefore it had not been well done, if he should have granted them any thing pertaining and touching the glory of his father.

column7: It was sufficient, that he did declare with his dede his doctrine of christian pacience, in those thynges that pertayned to his person. <NOTE> Wherfore Christ after his accustomed maner (though ye Phariseis neuer so muche wayted him) healed this dropsy man vpon the sabboth daye, shewyng with the same miracle, that aswell Gods lawes as mannes lawes, ought to serue and geue place vnto charitee.
column8: It was sufficient, that he did declare with his deed his Doctrine of christian patience, in those things that pertained to his person. Wherefore christ After his accustomed manner (though you Pharisees never so much waited him) healed this dropsy man upon the Sabbath day, show with the same miracle, that aswell God's laws as Man's laws, ought to serve and give place unto charity.

column7: And though the sabbot was comaunded vnto the Iewes most straightly to be kept, yet that commaundement did not extende to the hynderaunce of charite, wherof Christ in another place sheweth the reason why, saiyng:
column8: And though the Sabbath was commanded unto the Jews most straightly to be kept, yet that Commandment did not extend to the hindrance of charity, whereof christ in Another place shows the reason why, saying:

column7: The sabbot was made for mans sake, <NOTE> and not man for the sabbothes sake. <NOTE> And S. Paule sayth: The chiefe somme of the commaundement is loue from a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of fayth vnfayned.
column8: The Sabbath was made for men sake, and not man for the Sabbaths sake. And S. Paul say: The chief sum of the Commandment is love from a pure heart, and of a good conscience, and of faith unfeigned.

column7: Wherfore when I see my neighbour in necessitee,
column8: Wherefore when I see my neighbour in necessity,

column7: I am bounde to shewe him charitee and loue, if it were xx. tymes holy day, because loue is the rule and maistres of all lawes.
column8: I am bound to show him charity and love, if it were xx. times holy day, Because love is the Rule and masters of all laws.

column7: Nowe consider well with thy selfe, whether Christe did not right in healyng of this manne that had the dropsye, howe frowardly soeuer the Phariseis toke it.
column8: Now Consider well with thy self, whither Christ did not right in healing of this man that had the dropsy, how frowardly soever the Pharisees took it.

column7: If an Oxe or an asse had fallen into a hole on the sabboth day, thynkest thou that they would haue taryed tyll the sabboth day had been past?
column8: If an Ox or an Ass had fallen into a hold on the Sabbath day, Thinkest thou that they would have tarried till the Sabbath day had been passed?

column7: No surely. Why then should not Christe shewe vnto a manne, that they shewed vnto a beast?
column8: No surely. Why then should not Christ show unto a man, that they showed unto a beast?

column7: <NOTE> And so let vs likewise vse the libertie yt we haue in Christ Iesu our Lorde.
column8: And so let us likewise use the liberty that we have in christ Jesu our Lord.

column7: Let vs receiue those that be weake, into the faith,
column8: Let us receive those that be weak, into the faith,

column7: & beware to trouble not their conscience.
column8: & beware to trouble not their conscience.

column7: And as for these obdurate and stubburne iustifiers of theim selfe, whiche haue heard oure doctrine of christian libertie, and yet dispiseth it, against theim let vs vse the same libertie.
column8: And as for these obdurate and stubborn Justifiers of them self, which have herd our Doctrine of christian liberty, and yet despiseth it, against them let us use the same liberty.

column7: For whatsoeuer we do or leaue for their pleasure and weakenesse sake, it wyll healpe nothyng at all, but styll they wyll obstinately remayne in their blyndnes.
column8: For whatsoever we do or leave for their pleasure and weakness sake, it will help nothing At all, but still they will obstinately remain in their blindness.

column7: For so are the Phariseis against Christ, and Christ against the Phariseis,
column8: For so Are the Pharisees against christ, and christ against the Pharisees,

column7: & yet is there so great power & stregth in the trueth, yt the Phariseis are constrayned to holde their peace.
column8: & yet is there so great power & strength in the truth, that the Pharisees Are constrained to hold their peace.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> we see in this gospel howe familiarly and gentely Christ handeleth this man sicke of the dropsy, he handeled & healeth him,
column8: Secondarily, we see in this gospel how familiarly and gently christ handleth this man sick of the dropsy, he handled & heals him,

column7: & letteth him go. Fyrst he was in hand with these Pharisies, who he would haue gladly instructed, howe all lawes in tyme of neede are bounde to geue place vnto loue and charitee, but they would neither heare, not yet receyue his doctrine, their heartes were stricken with so great blyndes.
column8: & lets him go. Fyrst he was in hand with these Pharisees, who he would have gladly instructed, how all laws in time of need Are bound to give place unto love and charity, but they would neither hear, not yet receive his Doctrine, their hearts were stricken with so great blinds.

column7: Yea, they would not onely refuse to heare Christe, but sought alwayes & meanes to distroy him, whiche thyng happened chiefly vpon the Sabboth daye,
column8: Yea, they would not only refuse to hear Christ, but sought always & means to destroy him, which thing happened chiefly upon the Sabbath day,

column7: <NOTE> when in the synagoge he made whole the mans hand that was drye and wythered.
column8: when in the synagogue he made Whole the men hand that was dry and withered.

column7: Neuerthelesse Christ is frendly to this man that had the dropsy, he healeth him,
column8: Nevertheless christ is friendly to this man that had the dropsy, he heals him,

column7: & byddeth him go his waies.
column8: & biddeth him go his ways.

column7: Howbeit, it is to be thought that this man that had the dropsye had a good hope & trust in Christ, insomuch that he folowed Christ into the Phariseis house.
column8: Howbeit, it is to be Thought that this man that had the dropsy had a good hope & trust in christ, insomuch that he followed christ into the Pharisees house.

column7: And without doubt he had not been healed, if he had not had suche an hope in Christe.
column8: And without doubt he had not been healed, if he had not had such an hope in Christ.

column7: And as the blyndnes of these Phariseis ought to abashe and feare vs, because that thei had eyen and sawe not, eares and heard not, an heart & beleued not, so the goodnes & benignite of Christe, shewed vnto this man that had the dropsy, ought to moue vs to lift vp our heartes, and to put al our trust and confidence in Christ.
column8: And as the blindness of these Pharisees ought to abash and Fear us, Because that they had eyes and saw not, ears and herd not, an heart & believed not, so the Goodness & benignity of Christ, showed unto this man that had the dropsy, ought to move us to lift up our hearts, and to put all our trust and confidence in christ.

column7: Therfore this miracle and suche like,
column8: Therefore this miracle and such like,

column7: <NOTE> are written vnto vs, that therout we may learne, what maner a man Christ is,
column8: Are written unto us, that therout we may Learn, what manner a man christ is,

column7: & why the father hath sent him into this worlde, and what from him is to be hoped for of a christen ma.
column8: & why the father hath sent him into this world, and what from him is to be hoped for of a christian ma.

column7: He did good vnto this man that had the dropsye, because he hoped well in him.
column8: He did good unto this man that had the dropsy, Because he hoped well in him.

column7: Wherfore then should he deny vs any good thyng, if we beleue in him?
column8: Wherefore then should he deny us any good thing, if we believe in him?

column7: Is his hand shortened, <NOTE> that it can not helpe? No truely.
column8: Is his hand shortened, that it can not help? No truly.

column7: His mercy endureth for euer.
column8: His mercy Endureth for ever.

column7: The faute is in vs,
column8: The fault is in us,

column7: & not in his helpyng hand,
column8: & not in his helping hand,

column7: & that forbecause we wyll neither acknowlege our infirmite, nor yet beleue.
column8: & that forbecause we will neither acknowledge our infirmity, nor yet believe.

column7: But if we wyl acknowlege our imbecilite & weakenes, specially in those thinges that partayne to our soule, and aske grace of Christ in a true fayth, it is not possible, but it shall be graunted vs.
column8: But if we will acknowledge our imbecilite & weakness, specially in those things that partayne to our soul, and ask grace of christ in a true faith, it is not possible, but it shall be granted us

column7: Furthermore, it is requisite, that we once obtaynyng this his grace and mercy, endeuour our selues to shewe lyke loue and charity to our neighbour, as Christe shewed here vnto this man that had the dropsye.
column8: Furthermore, it is requisite, that we once obtaining this his grace and mercy, endeavour our selves to show like love and charity to our neighbour, as Christ showed Here unto this man that had the dropsy.

column7: Thirdely, The Pharises styl remaining in their blyndnes, and so that they could neither throughe Christes wordes, nor yet through his myracles be moued to beeleue,
column8: Thirdly, The Pharisees still remaining in their blindness, and so that they could neither through Christ's words, nor yet through his Miracles be moved to beeleue,

column7: Christe payed them home, and forasmuch as he perceaued in them a desirous appety of vaine glory, and euer chosing themselues the vppermost seates at feastes, and sayd:
column8: Christ paid them home, and forasmuch as he perceived in them a desirous appety of vain glory, and ever choosing themselves the uppermost seats At feasts, and said:

column7: <NOTE> When thou art bidde to dinner to a mariage, thou shalt not set thy selfe in the highgest place, lest peraduenture one that is more honourable then thou, be also bidden.
column8: When thou art bid to dinner to a marriage, thou shalt not Set thy self in the highgest place, lest Peradventure one that is more honourable then thou, be also bidden.

column7: And then he that bad bothe the and him, come and saye vnto the:
column8: And then he that bade both the and him, come and say unto thee:

column7: Giue this man place. But when thou art called, set the doune in the lowest place, that he may say:
column8: Give this man place. But when thou art called, Set the down in the lowest place, that he may say:

column7: Friend syt vp higher. With these wordes Christ would haue corrected the ambitio of the phariseis.
column8: Friend fit up higher. With these words christ would have corrected the ambitio of the Pharisees.

column7: For they sought the glory of thys world, and were in their hartes al giuen to pomp and pride,
column8: For they sought the glory of this world, and were in their hearts all given to pomp and pride,

column7: <NOTE> As he saith in an other place,
column8: As he Says in an other place,

column7: That all the workes they did, were done for the intent, that thei might be seen of men.
column8: That all the works they did, were done for the intent, that they might be seen of men.

column7: <NOTE> And in the syxt chap. of Math. wher Christ taught vs truly to pray, to fast,
column8: And in the syxt chap. of Math. where christ taught us truly to pray, to fast,

column7: & giue almes. Ther likewise hee warned vs to take heede of suche phariseis, and not to do good works in that intent, like as thei did,
column8: & give alms. There likewise he warned us to take heed of such Pharisees, and not to do good works in that intent, like as they did,

column7: & ther he addeth, sayig:
column8: & there he adds, sayig:
