column7: Wherfore he sayd to the ma that had the Palsey:
column8: Wherefore he said to the ma that had the Palsy:

column7: My sone, be of a good chere, thy synnes bee forgeuen thee.
column8: My soon, be of a good cheer, thy Sins be forgiven thee.

column7: Here thou hearest the name of synne, and hearest also that ioyfull name of forgeuyng.
column8: Here thou Hearst the name of sin, and Hearst also that joyful name of forgeuyng.

column7: And if diligently thou wylte considre who it is that speaketh these thynges, thou mayst lightly perceiue and fynde what he is, that wyl forgeue vs our synnes, so that we knowlege and confesse theim and desire grace, we may perceiue I say, that it is Iesus Christe oure Lorde, to whom is graunted of God the father this power to forgeue synne, as the Angell wytnesseth, saiyng:
column8: And if diligently thou wilt Consider who it is that speaks these things, thou Mayest lightly perceive and find what he is, that will forgive us our Sins, so that we knowledge and confess them and desire grace, we may perceive I say, that it is jesus Christ our Lord, to whom is granted of God the father this power to forgive sin, as the Angel Witnesseth, saying:

column7: <NOTE> He shall saue his people from their synne.
column8: He shall save his people from their sin.

column7: And as wee necessarily may note and marke here, that remission of synnes, is and commeth of mere grace, by Christe, without any deseruyng of woorkes, so lykewyse it is to bee noted, howe gentely and mercyfully Christ here in this place doth shewe him selfe.
column8: And as we necessarily may note and mark Here, that remission of Sins, is and comes of mere grace, by Christ, without any deserving of works, so likewise it is to be noted, how gently and mercifully christ Here in this place does show him self.

column7: This man that had the palsey, prayeth and desireth onely for his bodily health, and Christ healeth him both in body and soule, yea, and maketh him the sonne and heyre of God, and sayth:
column8: This man that had the palsy, Prayeth and Desires only for his bodily health, and christ heals him both in body and soul, yea, and makes him the son and heir of God, and say:

column7: Sonne be of a good chere.
column8: Son be of a good cheer.

column7: O vnspeakeable charitee, whiche can not bee expressed.
column8: O unspeakable charity, which can not be expressed.

column7: O mercyfull and louyng Lorde, can there be shewed greatter grace to this ma that had the Palsey?
column8: O merciful and loving Lord, can there be showed greater grace to this ma that had the Palsy?

column7: <NOTE> But note howe that his synnes be forgeuen him double.
column8: But note how that his Sins be forgiven him double.

column7: Fyrst they be driuen from his heart, and grace powred in it, whiche alonely God doeth, as Esaias wytnesseth saiyng:
column8: Fyrst they be driven from his heart, and grace poured in it, which alonely God doth, as Isaiah Witnesseth saying:

column7: I am he, that taketh away your sines, so that I wyl neuer thinke vpon theim.
column8: I am he, that Takes away your sines, so that I will never think upon them.

column7: Secondarily, forgeuenes of synnes is only declared here, which if it be coprehended with fayth, it is not without effect, for it hath both a comaundement of Christ,
column8: Secondarily, forgiveness of Sins is only declared Here, which if it be coprehended with faith, it is not without Effect, for it hath both a Commandment of christ,

column7: & also a promise. Wherout we may note, that if we receiue fayth through hearyng of the woorde of God, promisyng to vs by the minister forgeuenes of oure synnes,
column8: & also a promise. Without we may note, that if we receive faith through hearing of the word of God, promising to us by the minister forgiveness of our Sins,

column7: & do knowlege our offences, surely our sinnes be forgeuen vs.
column8: & do knowledge our offences, surely our Sins be forgiven us

column7: For he in that office of preachyng hath the keyes in the name of the Churche, as we fynde euidently in the xx. chapi. of Ihon:
column8: For he in that office of preaching hath the keys in the name of the Church, as we find evidently in the xx. Chapter. of John:

column7: <NOTE> Whose synne ye forgeue &c.
column8: Whose sin you forgive etc.

column7: And in ye xvi. <NOTE> chapiter of Mathewe,
column8: And in you xvi. chapter of Matthew,

column7: Whatsoeuer ye lose vpo yearth &c.
column8: Whatsoever you loose upon earth etc.

column7: So that in any wyse we doubte not, but do coprehend the promise of Christ with fayth.
column8: So that in any wise we doubt not, but do coprehend the promise of christ with faith.

column7: <NOTE> Secodarily, we see here what another mas faith preuaileth,
column8: Secondarily, we see Here what Another mass faith prevaileth,

column7: & howe greatly it healpeth.
column8: & how greatly it Helpeth.

column7: Vndoubtedly, it healpeth no more, then yt he in his prayer may pray for me, that I my selfe may attain vnto fayth, wherby I may be saued.
column8: Undoubtedly, it Helpeth no more, then that he in his prayer may pray for me, that I my self may attain unto faith, whereby I may be saved.

column7: Whiche if I do not obtain and get, another mannes fayth shall healpe me but a litle in my last ende, in the point death.
column8: Which if I do not obtain and get, Another Man's faith shall help me but a little in my last end, in the point death.

column7: Therfore the gospel here sayth plainly,
column8: Therefore the gospel Here say plainly,

column7: That Christ sawe the fayth of them that brought this diseased man.
column8: That christ saw the faith of them that brought this diseased man.

column7: For surely those honest men had heard a good report of Christ, and paraduenture had seene also, with what great beneuolence and charitee Christ had healed those that were diseased, hauyng therby great trust and confidence, that he likewyse would not forsake them.
column8: For surely those honest men had herd a good report of christ, and Peradventure had seen also, with what great benevolence and charity christ had healed those that were diseased, having thereby great trust and confidence, that he likewise would not forsake them.

column7: This their great fayth & cofidence is plainly expressed in that, yt they were not only not ashamed to cary this sicke man in his bed, but also (as sainct Marke testifieth) insomuch as thei could not come nigh Christ for the multitude of people,
column8: This their great faith & confidence is plainly expressed in that, that they were not only not ashamed to carry this sick man in his Bed, but also (as saint Mark Testifieth) insomuch as they could not come High christ for the multitude of people,

column7: <NOTE> they vncouered the rooffe of the house where he was,
column8: they uncovered the Roof of the house where he was,

column7: & when they had made a hole, they let doune the bedde by cordes, wherein the sicke of the Palsey laye.
column8: & when they had made a hold, they let down the Bed by cords, wherein the sick of the Palsy say.

column7: With this fayth surely they moued Christ to restore this sicke man vnto health, to receiue him, and to make him the sonne of God.
column8: With this faith surely they moved christ to restore this sick man unto health, to receive him, and to make him the son of God.

column7: And surely it must needes be that this man that had the palsey, did comprehend this article of remission of synne,
column8: And surely it must needs be that this man that had the palsy, did comprehend this article of remission of sin,

column7: & that with fayth, or els his synne had neuer been forgeuen him, as wytnesseth scripture:
column8: & that with faith, or Else his sin had never been forgiven him, as Witnesseth scripture:

column7: <NOTE> He that beleueth and is baptized, shalbe saued.
column8: He that Believeth and is baptised, shall saved.

column7: He sayth not: If another beleueth for thee &c.
column8: He say not: If Another Believeth for thee etc.

column7: Therfore forasmuche as the praier or intercession of theim that are aliue, done & made for other in fayth, is both a good worke and a charitable.
column8: Therefore forasmuch as the prayer or Intercession of them that Are alive, done & made for other in faith, is both a good work and a charitable.

column7: Let vs therfore folowe the saiyng of sainct Iames, warnyng vs thus:
column8: Let us Therefore follow the saying of saint James, warning us thus:

column7: Praye one for another, <NOTE> that you may bee saued.
column8: Pray one for Another, that you may be saved.

column7: For true and perfect fayth breaketh out, and is shewed through suche good deedes of charitie, if it commeth to passe that sainct Paule sayth:
column8: For true and perfect faith breaks out, and is showed through such good Deeds of charity, if it comes to pass that saint Paul say:

column7: <NOTE> One beare anothers burden &c.
column8: One bear another's burden etc.

column7: Thyrdly we see here, how yt the Scribes & Phariseis toke Christ for a blasphemer of God, and besides this, when Christ knew their thoughtes, how he answered theim.
column8: Thirdly we see Here, how that the Scribes & Pharisees took christ for a blasphemer of God, and beside this, when christ knew their thoughts, how he answered them.

column7: For he could in no wyse suffre this contumely and blasphemye.
column8: For he could in no wise suffer this contumely and blasphemy.

column7: But consider the Scribes, forasmuche as they had red in the Prophetes, that God alonely forgeueth sinne, and thinkyng Christ to bee but a symple man, they thought that Christ with those wordes had highly dishonored and blasphemed God, chalegyng vnto him the honour that belonged vnto God.
column8: But Consider the Scribes, forasmuch as they had read in the prophets, that God alonely forgiveth sin, and thinking christ to be but a simple man, they Thought that christ with those words had highly dishonoured and blasphemed God, chalegyng unto him the honour that belonged unto God.

column7: Wherewith they declare and euidently shewe, that they knewe not Christ,
column8: Wherewith they declare and evidently show, that they knew not christ,

column7: <NOTE> nor also the father, whiche wilbe knowen in Christ.
column8: nor also the father, which will known in christ.

column7: It is surely true and can not be denyed, that God only forgeueth synne.
column8: It is surely true and can not be denied, that God only forgiveth sin.

column7: But here must be considered and knowen, that Christ is very God, whiche also hath power to remit synnes.
column8: But Here must be considered and known, that christ is very God, which also hath power to remit Sins.

column7: <NOTE> And the same power gaue he vnto his churche, that in his name remission of synnes should be annouced vnto thende of the world.
column8: And the same power gave he unto his Church, that in his name remission of Sins should be announced unto The end of the world.

column7: Wherfore Christ doth reprehend here the Scribes, forbecause they should comme to the true knowlege.
column8: Wherefore christ does reprehend Here the Scribes, forbecause they should comme to the true knowledge.

column7: He iudgeth their thoughtes, which was aboue all mannes vnderstandyng & learnyng.
column8: He Judgeth their thoughts, which was above all Man's understanding & learning.

column7: And finally, with this great miracle he declareth him selfe to haue power here vpon yearth to forgeue synne, and sayth to him that had the Palsey:
column8: And finally, with this great miracle he Declareth him self to have power Here upon earth to forgive sin, and say to him that had the Palsy:

column7: Aryse, take thy bedde and go home.
column8: Arise, take thy Bed and go home.

column7: And he arose and went home.
column8: And he arose and went home.

column7: But the Scribes and Phariseis remayned styll in their blyndnes, and would not knowe Christes high power.
column8: But the Scribes and Pharisees remained still in their blindness, and would not know Christ's high power.

column7: Therfore it is mete vnto vs, that will be counted faythful men, to leaue and forsake these blynde and leaders of the blynd, and glorifie God with the rest of the people, whiche did geue suche power vnto men.
column8: Therefore it is meet unto us, that will be counted faithful men, to leave and forsake these blind and leaders of the blind, and Glorify God with the rest of the people, which did give such power unto men.

column7: Amen. The gospel on the.xx. sonday after Trinitee sonday. Math. 22.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the xx Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Math. 22.

column7: T He <NOTE> kyngdome of heauen is lyke vnto a manne that was a kyng, whiche made a mariage for his sonne, and sent furth his seruauntes, to call them that were byd to the weddyng, and they would not come.
column8: THe THe Kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that was a King, which made a marriage for his son, and sent forth his Servants, to call them that were bid to the wedding, and they would not come.

column7: Agayne he sent furth other seruauntes, saiyng:
column8: Again he sent forth other Servants, saying:

column8: Tell them which Are bidden:

column7: beholde, I haue prepared my dynner:
column8: behold, I have prepared my dinner:

column8: mine oxen and my fattlynges Are killed, and all things Are ready, come unto this marriage.

column8: But they made Light of it, and went their ways:

column8: one to his farmeplace, Another to his merchandise, and the remnant took his Servants, and entreated them shamefully and slew them.

column8: But when the King herd thereof, he was wroth,

column8: & sent forth his men of war,

column8: & destroyed those murderers, and brent up their City.

column8: Go you Therefore out into the high ways,

column8: & as many as you find, bid them to the marriage.

column8: Then the King Come in, to see the gests,

column8: & when he spied a man, which had not on a wedding garment, he said unto him:

column8: Friend, how camest thou hither not having a wedding garment?

column8: And he was even speechless.

column8: Then said the King to the Ministers, take & bind him hand and foot, and cast him into utter darkness there shall weeping and gnashing of teeth.

column8: For many Are called, but few Are chosen. THE EXPOSITION.

column8: THis THis Gospel agreeth almost with the symilitude which is written in the fourtenth chapter of S.

column8: Lycia, of the which we have a part spoken of on the First Sunday After Trinity Sunday,

column7: And as the grace of the gospell is there likened vnto a supper, so is it here likened vnto a mariage,
column8: And as the grace of the gospel is there likened unto a supper, so is it Here likened unto a marriage,

column7: Howbeit, the vnion and couplyng of Christ with the church,
column8: Howbeit, the Union and coupling of christ with the Church,

column7: & in what wise he hath take her, and maried her vnto him by faith, is here more plainly and more euidently sette forth and declared by this mariage, the there, through the parable of ye souper.
column8: & in what wise he hath take her, and married her unto him by faith, is Here more plainly and more evidently Set forth and declared by this marriage, the there, through the parable of the souper.

column7: For it is true, that euen as a souper here vpon earth, is prepared and ordained for mirth and ioyfulnes, so likewise there is perpetual peace & ioy in the kingdom of Christ.
column8: For it is true, that even as a souper Here upon earth, is prepared and ordained for mirth and ioyfulnes, so likewise there is perpetual peace & joy in the Kingdom of christ.

column7: But in a mariage ther is not onli ioy, but the bridegrome & the bride ar made one flesh,
column8: But in a marriage there is not only joy, but the bridegroom & the bride Are made one Flesh,

column7: <NOTE> as ye scripture testifieth:
column8: as you scripture Testifieth:

column8: For you cause shall a man forsake father & mother,

column7: & stycke to his wife,
column8: & stick to his wife,

column8: & they shall two in one Flesh.

column8: And even likewise as you bride & the bridegroom Are one Flesh, so shall we be in christ one body, so that we have a true faith.

column7: And as a man and his wife haue al their goodes in common betwene them so haue we likewise al that was Christes, so that we are not founde vnfaithful.
column8: And as a man and his wife have all their goods in Common between them so have we likewise all that was Christ's, so that we Are not found unfaithful.

column8: To this pertaineth that S. Paul Writeth to the Ephesians:

column8: You men love your wives, as christ loved the congregation,

column7: & hathe giuen himselfe for it to sanctifie it, and clense it in the fountaine of water, by ye word, to make it vnto him self a glorious cogregacion, hauing no spot nor wrinkle nor any such thing,
column8: & hath given himself for it to sanctify it, and cleanse it in the fountain of water, by the word, to make it unto him self a glorious cogregacion, having no spot nor wrinkle nor any such thing,

column8: but that it should be holy and without blame.

column8: Secondarily, there is commended in this gospel the outward word. wherethrough we Are called and bidden to this marriage.

column8: For even as gorgeously as he prepared this marriage with all things belonging thereunto, so diligently by his Servants, he sends and calls his gests.

column7: Fyrst of al through the word of the gospell the Iewes were called vnto this mariage, to whome also Christ was promised, as we finde in the eightene chap. of Deutronomy.
column8: Fyrst of all through the word of the gospel the Jews were called unto this marriage, to whom also christ was promised, as we find in the eightene chap. of Deuteronomy.

column7: <NOTE> And were called also againe the seconde time, and would not yet come.
column8: And were called also again the seconde time, and would not yet come.

column7: For thei were so combred with worldly thinges, that they cared not for the welthe of their soule, and therefore were forsaken and condemned, in whose place the poore Fentiles succede.
column8: For they were so cumbered with worldly things, that they cared not for the wealth of their soul, and Therefore were forsaken and condemned, in whose place the poor Gentiles succeed.

column7: And that it is here spoken, that they gathered togither al that they found both good & euel, that is not spoke that we shuld think,
column8: And that it is Here spoken, that they gathered together all that they found both good & evil, that is not spoke that we should think,

column7: <NOTE> that the ill men for their maliciousnes, shall receiue a special reward in heauen,
column8: that the ill men for their maliciousness, shall receive a special reward in heaven,

column7: <NOTE> but that we must suffre to grow here vpo earth the tares with the good wheat, vnto such tyme, that god by Christ shall deuide the sheep from the kyddes, and receiue the sheepe into his kingedome.
column8: but that we must suffer to grow Here upon earth the tares with the good wheat, unto such time, that god by christ shall divide the sheep from the kyddes, and receive the sheep into his Kingdom.

column7: Thyrdely, in that the Iewes didde contempne and dispise the woorde of god and the gospell, and distroyed the ministers therof, wherwith the kinge being angry, sent forth his warriers, and destroyed those murtherers, and sette fier vppon their citye.
column8: Thirdly, in that the Jews did contemn and despise the word of god and the gospel, and destroyed the Ministers thereof, wherewith the King being angry, sent forth his warriors, and destroyed those murderers, and Set fire upon their City.

column7: These wordes declareth how hardly and withoute any mercy god shal punish them both body & soule, <NOTE> & al other worldly comodities, which dispise & persecute his word.
column8: These words Declareth how hardly and without any mercy god shall Punish them both body & soul, & all other worldly commodities, which despise & persecute his word.

column7: Were not ye Iewes punished wt lyke ponishement?
column8: Were not the Jews punished with like ponishement?

column8: If no man will receive you,

column7: <NOTE> nor heare your preachyng, departe out of that house or citie, and shake the dust of your fete.
column8: nor hear your preaching, depart out of that house or City, and shake the dust of your feet.

column8: Truly I say unto you, it shall be Easier for the land of Sodom and Gomorra, in the day of judgement, then for that City.

column7: Fourthly, we haue in this parable, him whiche entred in wtout a weddyng garment, who the kyng comaunded to be bound & cast into vtter darkenes, because he could not excuse him selfe.
column8: Fourthly, we have in this parable, him which entered in without a wedding garment, who the King commanded to be bound & cast into utter darkness, Because he could not excuse him self.

column7: That, that is spoken here of the wedding garment, is to be vnderstand of those that iustifye them selfes.
column8: That, that is spoken Here of the wedding garment, is to be understand of those that justify them selves.

column8: For those though outwardly they appear to be good & holy, yet forbecause they be Hypocrites,

column8: But they Therefore that have not this vesture (which,

column8: though many be called, yet is there but a few that hath it) they shall not have part with Christ, but with Sathan.

column7: Thy sonne lyueth, <NOTE> And he beeleued, and al hys houshold. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: F Irst, <NOTE> in this gospell we haue an exaumple of vnperfecte faith, which is a greate comfort for vs, that ar not as yet strong in the true faith, when we se this ruler, hauing little faith and yet not reiected of Christ, but rebuked familiarly, and afterwarde by the vertue of the worde, made stronge in the faithe.
column8: First First, in this gospel we have an Exampl of unperfect faith, which is a great Comfort for us, that Are not as yet strong in the true faith, when we see this ruler, having little faith and yet not rejected of christ, but rebuked familiarly, and afterward by the virtue of the word, made strong in the faith.

column7: Whereout we learne howe Christe suffereth the weakenes of our faith, and that wee shall not bee reiected of him, so that we with like pacience wil suffre his correctio, where withall he rebuketh our misbeliefe, as we se here ye that this ruler did,
column8: Whereout we Learn how Christ suffers the weakness of our faith, and that we shall not be rejected of him, so that we with like patience will suffer his Correction, where withal he Rebuketh our misbelief, as we see Here you that this ruler did,

column7: & perseuere euer in prayer with the Apostels, saying:
column8: & persevere ever in prayer with the Apostles, saying:

column8: Lord augment and increase our faith.

column7: And as Christ doth not reiecte this man, weake in the faith, beyng not as yet perfecte, so like wyse wee shall not dispaire, thoughe wee feele lyke weaknes in vs, but suerly hope in Christ that is so mercifull, and wyl beare and suffre our weaknes vnto such tyme, that through his word and holy ghost we shall be brought vnto more perfection.
column8: And as christ does not reject this man, weak in the faith, being not as yet perfect, so like wise we shall not despair, though we feel like weakness in us, but surely hope in christ that is so merciful, and will bear and suffer our weakness unto such time, that through his word and holy ghost we shall be brought unto more perfection.

column7: <NOTE> Secondaryly, we see here how faith muste euer augment and increase.

column8: He truesteth in the Goodness of christ, and Believeth that he is ready to help every body, and that he is a most gentle & a meek lord.

column8: Hither may be referred the saying of Saint Paul in all his Epistles, where he Prayeth and wisheth, that the faithful might grow and increase in faith, and in the knowledge of god.

column7: For Christe although he was desired of the ruler to go home with him, yet for al yt, he went not but denyed him the same, wtout doubt for that intent, that when he shuld perceiue his son to be made hole by the word, he shuld hereafter so muche the more cleaue to the same word,
column8: For Christ although he was desired of the ruler to go home with him, yet for all that, he went not but denied him the same, without doubt for that intent, that when he should perceive his son to be made hold by the word, he should hereafter so much the more cleave to the same word,

column7: & learne therwt to be content.
column8: & Learn therewith to be content.

column7: And though Christ heareth vs no further, then in those thinges that pertaine to ye glory of god and our saluacion, yet neuertheles we ought stil to be diligent in prayer without ceassing for bicause that the holy spirit it selfe (although we know not how & what to pray) maketh intercession myghtely for vs with vnspeakable syghynge.
column8: And though christ hears us no further, then in those things that pertain to you glory of god and our salvation, yet nevertheless we ought still to be diligent in prayer without ceasing for Because that the holy Spirit it self (although we know not how & what to pray) makes Intercession mightily for us with unspeakable sighing.

column7: Vnto vs therefore is made a promise that what so euer wee desier in CHRISTES name, shall bee geuen vs.
column8: Unto us Therefore is made a promise that what so ever we desire in CHRIST'S name, shall be given us

column8: All the promises of god Are yea in him, and Are Amen in him, to the praise of god by us

column8: And if we desire any thing, that is both contrary to the glory of god, and against our salvation, and if we be not herd, it is for our wealth, and it is so meet that we be not herd.

column7: For it is better not to be heard in our prayer and receiue therwith saluacion, then to obtain our petition and owne wyll, in thinges beinge to our damnacion.

column7: Fourthelye, wee see in this gospell,
column8: Fourthly, we see in this gospel,

column7: <NOTE> that signes and myracles are testimonials, wherwith was confirmed that the word came from god, and to be his woorde.
column8: that Signs and Miracles Are testimonials, wherewith was confirmed that the word Come from god, and to be his word.

column7: And also throughe myracles, menne are alured vnto faythe.
column8: And also through Miracles, men Are allured unto faith.

column7: But wee do not speake here, of those sygnes and myracles, whiche happen after a doctrine once taken, receiued and confyrmed but of those myracles whiche approue euery new doctrine to be of god.
column8: But we do not speak Here, of those Signs and Miracles, which happen After a Doctrine once taken, received and confirmed but of those Miracles which approve every new Doctrine to be of god.

column7: <NOTE> As we see in the second book of Moyses, that the lawe was stablished by and through many signes and myracles.
column8: As we see in the second book of Moses, that the law was established by and through many Signs and Miracles.

column7: And if a false prophete had come, and taughte contrary to that lawe, (as often times god suffereth vs to be tempted) and had approued it with miracles, yet ought we to geue no faith to such prophetes. <NOTE> As wee see lykewyse in the gospell, whiche was preached by Christ in the world, after the abrogacion of the law, and approued throughe so manye myracles, that no doctrine, (yf it bee contrarye to that) oughte to be receiued, thoughe the false prophetes shewe neuer so greate myracles.
column8: And if a false Prophet had come, and taught contrary to that law, (as often times god suffers us to be tempted) and had approved it with Miracles, yet ought we to give no faith to such Prophets. As we see likewise in the gospel, which was preached by christ in the world, After the abrogation of the law, and approved through so many Miracles, that no Doctrine, (if it be contrary to that) ought to be received, though the false Prophets show never so great Miracles.

column7: For in the beginnynge by Christe, and after throughe the Apostels, hathe the gospell beene sufficiently approued, and he that nowe seeketh any more signes or myracles, let him heare this sentence:

column8: Wherefore tokens and Miracles which were done in the beginning of the gospel by Christ, bore witness unto the word, that it was of god, and was the truth.

column7: T Herefore is the kingdome of heauen likened vnto a certaine manne that was a kynge, whiche woulde take accomptes of hys seruauntes.
column8: Therefore Therefore is the Kingdom of heaven likened unto a certain man that was a King, which would take accounts of his Servants.

column7: And when he had begon to recken, one was brought vnto hym, whiche ought hym ten thousad talentes, but for as muche as hee was not able to paye, hys Lorde commaunded hym to be solde, and hys wyfe and chyldren, and all that he had, and payment to be made.
column8: And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him, which ought him ten thousad Talents, but for as much as he was not able to pay, his Lord commanded him to be sold, and his wife and children, and all that he had, and payment to be made.

column7: The seruaunt fell downe, and besought hym, saying:
column8: The servant fell down, and besought him, saying:

column7: Syr, haue pacience wyth me, and I wyll paye the all.
column8: Sir, have patience with me, and I will pay the all.

column7: Then hadde the Lorde pitye on that seruaunt, and loosed hym and forgaue him, the dette.
column8: Then had the Lord pity on that servant, and loosed him and forgave him, the debt.

column7: So the same seruaunte went out, and founde one of hys felowes which ought hym an hundreth pence, and he layed handes on hym, and tooke him by the throte, saying:
column8: So the same servant went out, and found one of his Fellows which ought him an Hundredth pence, and he laid hands on him, and took him by the throat, saying:

column7: Pay that thouowest. And his felowe fell doune, and besought him, sayinge:
column8: Pay that thouowest. And his fellow fell down, and besought him, saying:

column7: Haue pacience with me, and I wyll paye the all.
column8: Have patience with me, and I will pay the all.

column7: And he would not, but went and cast hym ^nto pryson, tyl he shulde pay the det.
column8: And he would not, but went and cast him unto prison, till he should pay the debt.

column7: So, when his felowes sawe what was doone they were very sory, and came and tolde vnto their lorde, all that had happened.
column8: So, when his Fellows saw what was done they were very sorry, and Come and told unto their lord, all that had happened.

column7: Then hys lorde called him, and sayd vnto hym:
column8: Then his lord called him, and said unto him:

column7: O thou vngracious seruaunt, I forgaue the all that dette, whan thou desiredst me:
column8: Oh thou ungracious servant, I forgave the all that debt, when thou desiredst me:

column7: shuldest not thou also haue had compassion on thy felowe, euen as I had pitye on the?
column8: Shouldst not thou also have had compassion on thy fellow, even as I had pity on thee?

column7: And hys lord was wroth, and delyuered hym to the taylers, tyll he shulde paye all that was due vnto hym.
column8: And his lord was wroth, and Delivered him to the tailors, till he should pay all that was due unto him.

column7: So <NOTE> lykewise shal my heauenly father do also vnto you, if ye from your heartes forgiue not euerye one his brother their trespasses. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: So likewise shall my heavenly father do also unto you, if you from your hearts forgive not every one his brother their Trespasses. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T He summe of this gospell is,
column8: THe THe sum of this gospel is,

column8: that by grace our Sins Are forgiven us, Wherefore we likewise Are bound, to forgive our neighbour their offences done unto us

column7: But forasmuch as it is wrytten here goodly in order, in what wise a manne is iustified, therefore dilygently we shall entreat of euery parte therof, as yt stondeth.
column8: But forasmuch as it is written Here goodly in order, in what wise a man is justified, Therefore diligently we shall entreat of every part thereof, as that standeth.

column7: Fyrste, we heare in this parable, a certaine part of the lawe.
column8: First, we hear in this parable, a certain part of the law.

column8: It must be fulfilled and done with all thy heart with all thy soul, and with all thy might, according as god hath commanded it.

column7: And forasmuche as the saintes and the elect of god, often times do stumble here & offend, and haue need to praye vnto god, for to obtaine forgiuenes of their sinnes at all houres, how shall an ypocrite then be iustified beefore god, through his workes?
column8: And forasmuch as the Saints and the elect of god, often times do Stumble Here & offend, and have need to pray unto god, for to obtain forgiveness of their Sins At all hours, how shall an Hypocrite then be justified before god, through his works?

column7: Blessed is that man, vnto whome the lorde imputeth no sinne, in whose spirite ther is no gyle.
column8: Blessed is that man, unto whom the lord imputeth no sin, in whose Spirit there is not gyle.

column7: Wherfore we must needs say, that we all are this kinges detters. that is, we be al sinners.
column8: Wherefore we must needs say, that we all Are this Kings debtors. that is, we be all Sinners.

column7: For els how can my sinnes be forgiuen me, without I felt them and knowledged them?
column8: For Else how can my Sins be forgiven me, without I felt them and knowledged them?

column7: Yf thys physicion Christ, shal be profitable vnto me, so must I needs knowledg my deadly syckenes & infirmitie.
column8: If this Physician christ, shall be profitable unto me, so must I needs knowledge my deadly sickness & infirmity.

column7: And also, yf I shal know my synne and debte, so must this kyng bryng furth his reckenyng booke, whiche is the lawe, wherein my synnes & trasgressios be noted, to shew me the same, to thentent that I may meke my selfe,
column8: And also, if I shall know my sin and debt, so must this King bring forth his reckoning book, which is the law, wherein my Sins & trasgressios be noted, to show me the same, to thentent that I may meek my self,

column7: & aske mercy, where at the last I fall doune prostrate before his feete, and knowlege my selfe a very debter.
column8: & ask mercy, where At the last I fallen down prostrate before his feet, and knowledge my self a very debtor.

column7: This seruant promised to paye it all (as troubled consciences are wont to do) but the kyng knewe well that it was impossible for him to doo.
column8: This servant promised to pay it all (as troubled Consciences Are wont to do) but the King knew well that it was impossible for him to do.

column7: Wherfore he discharged him, and forgaue him of very pitie and mercy, the debt frely.
column8: Wherefore he discharged him, and forgave him of very pity and mercy, the debt freely.

column7: Out of all this we must learne, from whence forgeuenes of synnes commeth.
column8: Out of all this we must Learn, from whence forgiveness of Sins comes.

column7: For remission of synne standeth not in workes or in any deseruyng, but is graunted and geuen vs frely by Christ, of mere grace & mercy.
column8: For remission of sin Stands not in works or in any deserving, but is granted and given us freely by christ, of mere grace & mercy.

column7: For why would this kyng haue had mercy of this seruant and forgeue him, if he had had wherewith to paye?
column8: For why would this King have had mercy of this servant and forgive him, if he had had wherewith to pay?

column7: But truely, <NOTE> reason and the fleshe vnderstandeth not this, nor comprehendeth it, but goeth aboute to bryng this thyng better to passe through workes.
column8: But truly, reason and the Flesh understandeth not this, nor comprehendeth it, but Goes about to bring this thing better to pass through works.

column7: Surely there is contencion and strife throughout all the worlde of this one article.
column8: Surely there is contention and strife throughout all the world of this one article.

column7: The worlde will not permit and suffre, that Christe is true herein and yet notwithstadyng reason shall here bee confounded, and Christ shalbe true, or els wee certainly shalbe dampned euerlastyngly.
column8: The world will not permit and suffer, that Christ is true herein and yet notwithstanding reason shall Here be confounded, and christ shall true, or Else we Certainly shall dampened everlastingly.

column7: For thou must needes bee sure and certaine, if you wyll be saued, that thy synnes bee forgeuen thee.
column8: For thou must needs be sure and certain, if you will be saved, that thy Sins be forgiven thee.

column7: And thou canst neuer bee sure of this article, if thou do leane and haue confidence in woorkes or merites.
column8: And thou Canst never be sure of this article, if thou do lean and have confidence in works or merits.

column7: Wherfore, if thou desirest a peaceable conscience, thou must comprehende the great grace and mercy of God in Christe, and that through fayth.
column8: Wherefore, if thou Desirest a peaceable conscience, thou must comprehend the great grace and mercy of God in Christ, and that through faith.

column7: And if thou doest perceiue this, thou hast on thy syde the holy Gospel, that euery where ascribeth remission of synnes vnto the grace of God,
column8: And if thou dost perceive this, thou hast on thy side the holy Gospel, that every where ascribeth remission of Sins unto the grace of God,

column7: & not to thy workes.
column8: & not to thy works.

column7: <NOTE> Dyd not sainct Ihon Baptist declare euidently, that Christ was the Lamme of God, that taketh away the synnes of the worlde?
column8: Did not saint John Baptist declare evidently, that christ was the Lamb of God, that Takes away the Sins of the world?

column7: Now then, if Christ taketh away synne, through his owne merites and deseruyng, how can our workes do it then?
column8: Now then, if christ Takes away sin, through his own merits and deserving, how can our works do it then?

column7: Further more thapostles teacheth vs so likewse iin ye Actes,
column8: Further more Apostles Teaches us so likewise iin you Acts,

column7: <NOTE> where they treate of this article,
column8: where they Treat of this article,

column7: & say: There is no other name geue to me wherin we must be saued &c.
column8: & say: There is no other name give to me wherein we must be saved etc.

column7: And here on this parable we haue, howe the kyng of great mercy and compassion forgaue this debt.
column8: And Here on this parable we have, how the King of great mercy and compassion forgave this debt.

column7: Thirdly, this seruant should haue been myndful of the great benefite whiche was shewed vpon him, and by right should haue had pacience with him that was in his debte, forasmuche as fayth, whiche comprehedeth remission of synnes in Christ, is euer wont accustomably to come vnto light and breake furth through charitee.
column8: Thirdly, this servant should have been myndful of the great benefit which was showed upon him, and by right should have had patience with him that was in his debt, forasmuch as faith, which comprehedeth remission of Sins in christ, is ever wont accustomably to come unto Light and break forth through charity.

column7: But as an vnthankefull, & forgetfull man of suche great goodnes done vnto him, he would haue no pacience with his companio whiche ought him an hundreth pence.
column8: But as an unthankful, & forgetful man of such great Goodness done unto him, he would have no patience with his companio which ought him an Hundredth pence.

column7: Doth this ma seme vnto the a christia ma, although his synne afore was dimitted him?
column8: Does this ma seem unto thee a christian ma, although his sin afore was dimitted him?

column7: No surely. For a christian ma knoweth, that of mere grace through Christ, his synnes bee forgeuen him:
column8: No surely. For a christian ma Knoweth, that of mere grace through christ, his Sins be forgiven him:

column7: and knoweth also that in like maner he should handle his neighbor.
column8: and Knoweth also that in like manner he should handle his neighbour.

column7: Therfore in that I apprehende forgeuenes of synne by fayth in Christ, and for Christes sake serue and forgeue my neighbour, in so doyng and cotinuyng in the same I am a christian man,
column8: Therefore in that I apprehend forgiveness of sin by faith in christ, and for Christ's sake serve and forgive my neighbour, in so doing and cotinuyng in the same I am a christian man,

column7: Whiche if I do not,
column8: Which if I do not,

column7: I am no christian man.
column8: I am no christian man.

column7: <NOTE> For the scripture witnesseth that all the lawe and the Prophetes hang and consist in the loue of God and my neighbour, as in two of the principal comaundemetes.
column8: For the scripture Witnesseth that all the law and the prophets hang and consist in the love of God and my neighbour, as in two of the principal comaundemetes.

column7: <NOTE> Wherfore Christ in another place saith:
column8: Wherefore christ in Another place Says:

column7: Forgeue, and you shalbe forgeuen.
column8: Forgive, and you shall forgiven.

column7: Whiche thou mayst not vnderstande, as though thou couldest deserue remission of synnes throug thy forgeuyng.
column8: Which thou Mayest not understand, as though thou Couldst deserve remission of Sins through thy forgeuyng.

column7: The fyrst part of this knowlege, is the preachyng of repentaunce, declaryng vnto the, what thou oughtest to do with thy neighbour, namely to forgeue him.
column8: The fyrst part of this knowledge, is the preaching of Repentance, declaring unto thee, what thou Ought to do with thy neighbour, namely to forgive him.

column7: And the second parte is a promise, that thy synnes shalbe forgeuen the in Christ, by grace and mercy.
column8: And the second part is a promise, that thy Sins shall forgiven the in christ, by grace and mercy.

column7: And hereto pertayneth our dayly prayer, wherin we say:
column8: And hereto pertaineth our daily prayer, wherein we say:

column7: Remitte nobis debita nostra &c.
column8: Remit nobis Debita nostra etc.

column7: Forgeue vs oure dettes, as we forgeue oure detters.
column8: Forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors.

column7: Wherfore if thou haue pleasure to do good workes, to testifie by charitie that thy fayth is a right & a true fayth in Christe, serue thy neighbor, as God by his sonne hath serued the.
column8: Wherefore if thou have pleasure to do good works, to testify by charity that thy faith is a right & a true faith in Christ, serve thy neighbour, as God by his son hath served thee.

column7: For by this shall euery man knowe, that ye are the disciples of Christ, if you haue loue one to another, as Christ sayth in the xiiii. chapiter of Ihon. <NOTE> Fourthly, we see in ye fourth part of this parable howe God shall punishe those that leaue & departe from the fayth,
column8: For by this shall every man know, that you Are the Disciples of christ, if you have love one to Another, as christ say in the xiiii. chapter of John Fourthly, we see in you fourth part of this parable how God shall Punish those that leave & depart from the faith,

column7: & forget the charitee and loue,
column8: & forget the charity and love,

column7: <NOTE> that they owe to their neighbor.
column8: that they owe to their neighbour.

column7: For assone as the kyng had heard howe extremely the seruaunt, to whom he had forgeuen his debt, had handled his companion, he was very wrothe.
column8: For As soon as the King had herd how extremely the servant, to whom he had forgiven his debt, had handled his Companion, he was very wroth.

column7: Wherfore he called him before him, and rigorously rebuked him, and deliuered him to the iaylours vntyll he payed all that he ought.
column8: Wherefore he called him before him, and rigorously rebuked him, and Delivered him to the jailers until he paid all that he ought.

column7: This worde, Vntyl, signfieth here, tyme without ende.
column8: This word, Until, signfieth Here, time without end.

column7: As though the kyng would saye.
column8: As though the King would say.

column7: Of my great mercye and grace I forgaue thee all thy synnes, that thou beyng myndefull of this great benefite, shouldest haue likewise hadled thy debter.
column8: Of my great mercy and grace I forgave thee all thy Sins, that thou being mindful of this great benefit, Shouldst have likewise hadled thy debtor.

column7: But forsomuche as thou arte so vnthankefull, and hast vtterly forgotten charitee, thou shalt be dampned euerlastyngly.
column8: But forsomuch as thou art so unthankful, and hast utterly forgotten charity, thou shalt be dampened everlastingly.

column7: Out of all these thynges consider, howe euery thyng ought to bee done in the kyngdome of Christ.
column8: Out of all these things Consider, how every thing ought to be done in the Kingdom of christ.

column7: Fyrst we ought to knowlege our selfe to be synners, and that we cannot be iustified in the sight of God by workes.
column8: Fyrst we ought to knowledge our self to be Sinners, and that we cannot be justified in the sighed of God by works.

column7: And that is the fyrst parte of this parable.
column8: And that is the fyrst part of this parable.

column7: Secondarily we must knowe, that oure synnes bee forgeuen vs of grace through Christ, and that teacheth the second parte of this parable.
column8: Secondarily we must know, that our Sins be forgiven us of grace through christ, and that Teaches the second part of this parable.

column7: And thyrdly wee are here taught, that when we haue receiued remission of synne by fayth, it is needefull that we by charitee testifie to haue this fayth.
column8: And Thirdly we Are Here taught, that when we have received remission of sin by faith, it is needful that we by charity testify to have this faith.

column7: Fourthly, wee bee here taught, that if wee do not these foresayd thynges, wee shall be dampned without mercy,
column8: Fourthly, we be Here taught, that if we do not these foresaid things, we shall be dampened without mercy,

column7: & that is the last parte of this parable.
column8: & that is the last part of this parable.

column7: Geue thankes vnto God. The Gospel on the xxiii. sonday after Trinitee sonday. Mathewe. 22.
column8: Give thanks unto God. The Gospel on the xxiii. Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Matthew. 22.

column7: T Hen went the Phariseys, <NOTE> and toke counsell howe they might tangle him in his wordes.
column8: THen THen went the Pharisees, and took counsel how they might tangle him in his words.

column8: And they Set out unto him their Disciples with Herod Servants, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Mayster, we knowe that thou art true, and teachest the way of God truely, neither carest thou for any man, for thou regardest not the outwarde apparaunce of men.
column8: Master, we know that thou art true, and Teachest the Way of God truly, neither Carest thou for any man, for thou regardest not the outward appearance of men.

column7: Tell vs therfore: Howe thynkest thou?
column8: Tell us Therefore: How Thinkest thou?

column8: Is it lawful that tribute be given unto Cesar or not?

column8: But jesus perceiving their wickedness, said:

column8: Why tempt you me the Hypocrites?

column8: Show me the tribute money.

column8: And they took him a penny.

column8: And he said unto them:

column8: Whose is this image and superscription?

column8: They say unto him. Caesars:

column8: Then said he unto thee:

column7: and vnto God, those thynges that are Gods. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: and unto God, those things that Are God's THE EXPOSITION.

column7: WE haue in this Gospell a very subtill and crafty inuented question of the Phariseys, wherwith they went about to take Christ in some tryp, in his wordes, wherby they might haue brought him in some slaunder.
column8: WE have in this Gospel a very subtle and crafty invented question of the Pharisees, wherewith they went about to take christ in Some tryp, in his words, whereby they might have brought him in Some slander.

column7: Whiche question diligently considered, we shall fynde, that the children of this worlde in their kynde, to bee no fooles, but neuerthelesse, their wysedome, craft,
column8: Which question diligently considered, we shall find, that the children of this world in their kind, to be no Fools, but nevertheless, their Wisdom, craft,

column7: & subtiltie euer beyng clothed and myxt with great maliciousnes and blyndnes.
column8: & subtlety ever being clothed and mixed with great maliciousness and blindness.

column7: Therfore fyrst of all the Phariseys tooke counsayl,
column8: Therefore fyrst of all the Pharisees took counsel,

column7: But at what thyng? Certainly of an euil matter.
column8: But At what thing? Certainly of an evil matter.

column7: For when they could fynd no occasion nor meanes wherby to hurt Christ, they toke counsayl and with one consent did al agree & determyne to take & trippe Christ craftely in his speakyng.
column8: For when they could find no occasion nor means whereby to hurt christ, they took counsel and with one consent did all agree & determine to take & trip christ craftily in his speaking.

column7: Whereout we may consider the Phariseis to be of that sort, of whom the Prophete Dauid had before spoken, saiyng:
column8: Whereout we may Consider the Pharisees to be of that sort, of whom the Prophet David had before spoken, saying:

column7: <NOTE> The kynges of the yearth stande vp, and the rulers are come together, against the Lorde and against his annoynted.
column8: The Kings of the earth stand up, and the Rulers Are come together, against the Lord and against his anointed.

column7: But whereof do they treate in their counsail, and what do they conclude?
column8: But whereof do they Treat in their counsel, and what do they conclude?

column7: They conclude to sende their ministers with thofficers of kyng Herode, to aske and demaunde of Christ, whether it were mete to pay tribute to the Emperour, or not.
column8: They conclude to send their Ministers with thofficers of King Herod, to ask and demand of christ, whither it were meet to pay tribute to the Emperor, or not.

column7: For herein he was costrained either to say yea, or nay.
column8: For herein he was costrained either to say yea, or nay.

column7: If he had sayd no, it was not lawful to paye tribute vnto themperour, straight were the officers ready to accuse him before Herode as a sedicious person.
column8: If he had said no, it was not lawful to pay tribute unto Emperor, straight were the Officers ready to accuse him before Herod as a seditious person.

column7: And if he had sayd and affirmed, that they should haue payed tribute, then should he haue lost the fauoure of the people, because he spake against the liberty of the Iewes,
column8: And if he had said and affirmed, that they should have paid tribute, then should he have lost the favour of the people, Because he spoke against the liberty of the Jews,

column7: & so beyng out of fauour & in great displeasure, thought by that meanes he might be deliuered into their handes.
column8: & so being out of favour & in great displeasure, Thought by that means he might be Delivered into their hands.

column7: This was a subtill, deceiptful,
column8: This was a subtle, deceitful,

column7: & deuilishe pollice. And without a christian ma had not the wisedome of Serpetes,
column8: & devilish pollice. And without a christian ma had not the Wisdom of Serpents,

column7: <NOTE> whiche was comaunded also to ye Apostles to haue, who could withstand suche subtyl obiections?
column8: which was commanded also to you Apostles to have, who could withstand such subtle objections?

column8: Here out it comes, that which David the Prophet Complaineth of these wicked Persons,

column8: saying: Lo, they have bent their bows,

column7: & made ready their arrowes in the quiuer, yt they may priuily shote at the, which are true in heart.
column8: & made ready their arrows in the quiver, that they may privily shote At thee, which Are true in heart.

column7: So likewyse do these Phariseys here, they go to counsel howe they might take Iesus in his saiynges,
column8: So likewise do these Pharisees Here, they go to counsel how they might take jesus in his sayings,

column8: & even the same that they cocluded, they command their Disciples, instructing thee how & what they should say unto him, namely this:

column7: Mayster, we know that thou art true,
column8: Master, we know that thou art true,

column7: & teachest the way of God truly,
column8: & Teachest the Way of God truly,

column7: & carest for no man.
column8: & Carest for no man.

column7: For thou regardest not ye outwarde apparance of men &c.
column8: For thou regardest not you outward appearance of men etc.

column7: Howe goodly are these wolues drest with shepes garmet?
column8: Howe goodly Are these wolves dressed with Sheep garmet?

column7: They cal Christ a maister,
column8: They call christ a master,

column7: & al for to constrain him with suche flatteryng wordes to make answer vnto them, yet be not they of suche disposicion to become his disciples, although ther had been taught neuer so much goodnes vnto the.
column8: & all for to constrain him with such flattering words to make answer unto them, yet be not they of such disposition to become his Disciples, although there had been taught never so much Goodness unto thee.

column7: Furthermore thei adde that he is true,
column8: Furthermore they add that he is true,

column7: & teacheth the worde of God truely.
column8: & Teaches the word of God truly.

column7: This is not euil spoken of Christe.
column8: This is not evil spoken of Christ.

column7: <NOTE> For he teacheth not only Gods worde truly, but also he is the truth himselfe.
column8: For he Teaches not only God's word truly, but also he is the truth himself.

column7: And this is required of al preachers, that they so endeuor them selfes, yt these wordes may be truly spoken of the.
column8: And this is required of all Preachers, that they so endeavour them selves, that these words may be truly spoken of thee.

column7: For it is our office to be true,
column8: For it is our office to be true,

column7: & to teache Gods word truly.
column8: & to teach God's word truly.

column7: Furthermore that thei say: Thou carest for no ma, nor regardest ye outward apparance of men, partaineth vnto vs also.
column8: Furthermore that they say: Thou Carest for no ma, nor regardest the outward appearance of men, partaineth unto us also.

column7: For the truth is not to be hidden for no mans pleasure, but faythfully to bee preached & teached, yea although his distructio shuld folow & should be put to death as S.
column8: For the truth is not to be hidden for no men pleasure, but faithfully to be preached & teached, yea although his distructio should follow & should be put to death as S.

column7: Ihon Baptist was. And although Christ is excellently described vnto vs by these wordes, yet they yt were sent did speake it, with a false fainyng & dissemblyng heart.
column8: John Baptist was. And although christ is excellently described unto us by these words, yet they that were sent did speak it, with a false feigning & dissembling heart.

column7: Wherout we may learne the disposicio of those hypocrites, which persecute ye word of god.
column8: Without we may Learn the disposicio of those Hypocrites, which persecute you word of god.

column7: Thei omit ye head & the principal of ye thing, and bryng in vnprofitable questions.
column8: They omit you head & the principal of you thing, and bring in unprofitable questions.

column7: They speake nothing with ye heart,
column8: They speak nothing with you heart,

column8: But whatsoever they speak, is for that purpose, that they may take and tryp the innocetes and good men in their communication.

column8: Secondarily, After that the Pharisees had put forth their subtle devised question,

column8: & christ knowing that they did it to tempt him, so he did answer them, that it was not spoken in vain of the wise man,

column8: saying: There is no Wisdom, there is no vnderstadyng, there is no counsel against the Lord.

column8: Therefore he calls them Hypocrites.

column8: And that they might well understand, that he knew their malicious thoughts, he added:

column8: Why do you tempt me?

column7: Whiche wordes by right should haue reuoked the Phariseys and the ministers from their maliciousnes and deceit, and caused them to haue amended their liues.
column8: Which words by right should have revoked the Pharisees and the Ministers from their maliciousness and deceit, and caused them to have amended their lives.

column7: But they were blynde & remayned styll blynd.
column8: But they were blind & remained still blind.

column8: Yet notwtstadyng, christ bade them to show him their tribute money, and said:

column8: Whose is this image & superscription?

column8: They said unto him: The emperors.

column8: Then said he unto them:

column8: Give Therefore unto the Emperor that, which is the emperors, and give unto God that which is God's

column8: As though he would say:

column7: Forasmuche as you are come therto, that for your synne you are brought vnder the yoke of the Emperour of Rome, you must nedes geue, as vnto your head & highest lorde here vpon yearth vnder God, that whiche belogeth vnto him.
column8: Forasmuch as you Are come thereto, that for your sin you Are brought under the yoke of the Emperor of Room, you must needs give, as unto your head & highest lord Here upon earth under God, that which belogeth unto him.

column7: Here is to be noted, ye difference that Christ maketh betwene the kyngdome of God and this worlde.
column8: Here is to be noted, you difference that christ makes between the Kingdom of God and this world.

column7: For he doth not onely approue and allowe this high power and polliticke life,
column8: For he does not only approve and allow this high power and politic life,

column7: <NOTE> but also confermeth it.
column8: but also confirmeth it.

column7: For the kyngdome of God or of Christ, is spiritual, whiche consisteth in the spirite, fayth, and truth, wherfore it commeth not with outwarde doynges, but it must be inwardly in vs.
column8: For the Kingdom of God or of christ, is spiritual, which Consisteth in the Spirit, faith, and truth, Wherefore it comes not with outward doings, but it must be inwardly in us

column7: Now because that it is a spiritual kyngdome,
column8: Now Because that it is a spiritual Kingdom,

column7: God requireth and wyll be worshypped in spirite,
column8: God requires and will be worshipped in Spirit,

column7: <NOTE> and in the trueth, as Christ sayth in the fourth chapiter of sainct Ihon.
column8: and in the truth, as christ say in the fourth chapter of saint John

column7: The true worshippers shall worship the father in spirite and in truthe.
column8: The true worshippers shall worship the father in Spirit and in truth.

column7: But to worship God in spirite and truth, is, to loue him with all thy heart,
column8: But to worship God in Spirit and truth, is, to love him with all thy heart,

column7: <NOTE> with all thy power, and to truste in him.
column8: with all thy power, and to trust in him.

column7: For suche fayth and loue, geueth God his honor, and kepeth his comaundementes, as Christ sayeth in an other place:

column7: He that loueth me, shall keepe my woorde.
column8: He that loves me, shall keep my word.

column7: <NOTE> Wherefore, when I put my whole truste in god the father, through Christe, and loue him aboue all creatures, then doo I gyue god that pertaineth to god, and pull from him none of his honour.
column8: Wherefore, when I put my Whole trust in god the father, through Christ, and love him above all creatures, then do I gyve god that pertaineth to god, and pull from him none of his honour.

column8: And hereunto pertaineth the fruitful admonition of the Prophet David, saying:

column8: Adscribe unto the Lord Oh ye mighty, ascribe unto the Lord worship & strength.

column7: And contrary wise, <NOTE> the kyngdome of the Emperour is worldly, it is visible, in the which the Emperour him selfe gouerneth and beareth rule mightely with hys lordes and prynces, as the scripture witnesseth in an other place, sayinge:
column8: And contrary wise, the Kingdom of the Emperor is worldly, it is visible, in the which the Emperor him self Governs and bears Rule mightily with his Lords and Princes, as the scripture Witnesseth in an other place, saying:

column7: <NOTE> The Kynges of the worlde haue dominion ouer the people, and they that beare rule ouer them, are called gracious lordes.
column8: The Kings of the world have dominion over the people, and they that bear Rule over them, Are called gracious Lords.

column7: Neuertheles that kingdome is of god,
column8: Nevertheless that Kingdom is of god,

column7: <NOTE> and stablished by goddes ordinaunce, in suche wise, that he that resisteth this ordinaunce, resisteth god him selfe.
column8: and established by God's Ordinance, in such wise, that he that Resisteth this Ordinance, Resisteth god him self.

column7: Thinkest thou, that princes and greate lordes in the scripture, are called goddes in vaine and withoute a cause?
column8: Thinkest thou, that Princes and great Lords in the scripture, Are called God's in vain and without a cause?

column7: For if they bee goddes,
column8: For if they be God's,

column7: <NOTE> and are made by god partakers of his magnificence, then muste they needes be in goddes steed, whose roome they beare.
column8: and Are made by god partakers of his magnificence, then must they needs be in God's steed, whose room they bear.

column7: Therfore, seyng they rule in gods steed it is both meete and conuenient, to giue theim that wee are bounde to giue theim.
column8: Therefore, sing they Rule in God's steed it is both meet and convenient, to give them that we Are bound to give them.

column7: But what are those thinges?
column8: But what Are those things?

column7: S. Paule setteth them furthe, and sayth:
column8: S. Paul sets them forth, and say:

column7: Geue vnto euery man his dutie,
column8: Give unto every man his duty,

column7: <NOTE> Tribute, to whom tribute belogeth,
column8: Tribute, to whom tribute belogeth,

column7: Custome, to who custome is due,
column8: Custom, to who custom is due,

column7: Feare, to whom feare belongeth, honour, to whom honour pertayneth.
column8: fear, to whom Fear belongeth, honour, to whom honour pertaineth.

column7: Here thou hearest what yu art bound to geue vnto highe powers.
column8: Here thou Hearst what thou art bound to give unto high Powers.

column7: But paraduenture thou wilt say:
column8: But Peradventure thou wilt say:

column7: Shall I geue obedience vnto a tyrant & an vngracious prince or Lord?
column8: Shall I give Obedience unto a tyrant & an ungracious Prince or Lord?

column7: Yea truly, thou art bound both to geue & obey him.
column8: Yea truly, thou art bound both to give & obey him.

column7: For what hast thou to do with his tyranny?
column8: For what hast thou to do with his tyranny?

column7: If the magistrate doth naught & contrary to equitie, he hath a iudge, whom he must answere in that appointed day.
column8: If the magistrate does nought & contrary to equity, he hath a judge, whom he must answer in that appointed day.

column7: Iudgement is not here graunted vnto thee, except he constrayneth thee to do any thyng against God.
column8: Judgement is not Here granted unto thee, except he constraineth thee to do any thing against God.

column7: Then thou mayst say with the Apostles:
column8: Then thou Mayest say with the Apostles:

column7: <NOTE> We ought more to obay God, then men.
column8: We ought more to obey God, then men.

column7: But if he costrayneth the do nothyng against God, then hast thou here the sentence of Christe:
column8: But if he costrayneth thee do nothing against God, then hast thou Here the sentence of Christ:

column7: Geue to Cesar that belongeth vnto him, and to God, that is Gods.
column8: Give to Cesar that belongeth unto him, and to God, that is God's

column7: Whiche answere is so good and godly, that they that were sent of the,
column8: Which answer is so good and godly, that they that were sent of thee,
