column8: Pharisees marveled At it. And for Because they could say nothing against it.

column7: They wet their wayes. God graunt vs his grace.
column8: They wet their ways. God grant us his grace.

column7: The gospel on the.xxiiii. sonday after Trinitee sonday. Math. 9.
column8: The gospel on the xxiiii Sunday After Trinity Sunday. Math. 9.

column7: W Hyles he thus spake vnto them <NOTE> beholde there came a certaine ruler,
column8: Whiles Whiles he thus spoke unto them behold there Come a certain ruler,

column7: & worshipped him, saiyng:
column8: & worshipped him, saying:

column7: My doughter is euen nowe disceased, but come and lay thy hand vpo her, and she shall liue.
column8: My daughter is even now diseased, but come and lay thy hand upon her, and she shall live.

column7: And Iesus arose & folowed him, and so did his disciples.
column8: And jesus arose & followed him, and so did his Disciples.

column7: <NOTE> and behold, a woma which was diseased with an issue of bloud xii. yeres, came behynd him, and touched the hemme of his vesture.
column8: and behold, a Woman which was diseased with an issue of blood xii. Years, Come behind him, and touched the hem of his vesture.

column7: For she sayd within her selfe:
column8: For she said within her self:

column7: If I may touche but euen his vesture only,
column8: If I may touch but even his vesture only,

column7: I shalbe safe. But Iesus turned him about,
column8: I shall safe. But jesus turned him about,

column7: & when he sawe her, he sayd:
column8: & when he saw her, he said:

column7: Daughter be of good comforte, thy fayth hath made the safe, and the woman was made whole, euen that same tyme. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Daughter be of good Comfort, thy faith hath made the safe, and the woman was made Whole, even that same time. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: WE haue two examples of fayth in this Gospel.
column8: WE have two Examples of faith in this Gospel.

column7: One in the Ruler that came to Christ to get helpe for his doughter, whiche Ruler sainct Marke calleth Iayrus.
column8: One in the Ruler that Come to christ to get help for his daughter, which Ruler saint Mark calls Jairus.

column7: And another in the woman that was diseased with a bluddy fluxe, and healed by Christe.
column8: And Another in the woman that was diseased with a bloody flux, and healed by Christ.

column7: In this woman was a perfecte sayth, but the rulers fayth as yet was not perfect, but weake.
column8: In this woman was a perfect say, but the Rulers faith as yet was not perfect, but weak.

column7: Fyrst, it was a point of fayth in this ruler, because he beleued that Christ could rayse his daughter to life, though she were dead:
column8: Fyrst, it was a point of faith in this ruler, Because he believed that christ could raise his daughter to life, though she were dead:

column7: wherewith he confesseth Christ to be God, and a Lorde ouer life and death.
column8: wherewith he Confesses christ to be God, and a Lord over life and death.

column7: Then if Christe bee a Lorde ouer death, he must nedes bee a Lorde ouer synne (forasmuche as Adam through his synne, brought death into the worlde) and suche a Lorde dothe of death and of synne is he, that both death and synne by his death he hath ouercome, abrogated and taken away.
column8: Then if Christ be a Lord over death, he must needs be a Lord over sin (forasmuch as Adam through his sin, brought death into the world) and such a Lord doth of death and of sin is he, that both death and sin by his death he hath overcome, abrogated and taken away.

column7: But howe and to what purpose?
column8: But how and to what purpose?

column7: That they should haue no power to codempne vs that beleue in Christ.
column8: That they should have no power to codempne us that believe in christ.

column7: For vndoubtedly, we can not liue without synne, whyle wee bee in this mortal life, as it is written:
column8: For undoubtedly, we can not live without sin, while we be in this Mortal life, as it is written:

column7: <NOTE> A iust man falleth vii. tymes in a day,
column8: A just man falls vii. times in a day,

column7: & ryseth vp againe. But ye synne (so that we beleue) shal haue no power ouer vs, nor condempne vs.
column8: & Riseth up again. But you sin (so that we believe) shall have no power over us, nor condemn us

column7: Lykewise, <NOTE> although this naturall death is not cleane taken awaye, yet is it so ouerthrowne, that it is no more dampnable vnto vs, but is the beginnyng of the true & principal life,
column8: Likewise, although this natural death is not clean taken away, yet is it so overthrown, that it is no more damnable unto us, but is the beginning of the true & principal life,

column7: <NOTE> as Christ saith:
column8: as christ Says:

column7: He that beleueth in me, shal not dye euerlastyngly.
column8: He that Believeth in me, shall not die everlastingly.

column7: This must wee surely holde fast if we will be christian menne,
column8: This must we surely hold fast if we will be christian men,

column7: That is, we must beleue, that by the death and bloud of Christ, wee are deliuered from synne, death, deuil and hell, so that we perseuer in a true fayth, we shall haue euerlastyng life through Christ.
column8: That is, we must believe, that by the death and blood of christ, we Are Delivered from sin, death, Devil and hell, so that we persever in a true faith, we shall have everlasting life through christ.

column7: And this beleueth Iayrus partly.
column8: And this Believeth Jairus partly.

column7: But in asmuche that he beleueth not that Christe by the might & power of his worde could make whole his doughter, except he had been personally present, we must nedes confesse that his fayth was imperfect.
column8: But in asmuch that he Believeth not that Christ by the might & power of his word could make Whole his daughter, except he had been personally present, we must needs confess that his faith was imperfect.

column7: But what shall we say of the fayth of this woman?
column8: But what shall we say of the faith of this woman?

column7: She surely had so great confidence in Christ, that she cocluded by her selfe, that she should bee whole, if she might touche only the hemme of his vesture.
column8: She surely had so great confidence in christ, that she cocluded by her self, that she should be Whole, if she might touch only the hem of his vesture.

column7: Not that the vesture dyd make her whole, (for as S.
column8: Not that the vesture did make her Whole, (for as S.

column7: Marke sayth, he felte great vertue go from him, and speaketh nothyng of the vesture) but only the great fayth that she had in Christ.
column8: Mark say, he felt great virtue go from him, and speaks nothing of the vesture) but only the great faith that she had in christ.

column7: Wherfore Christ highly prayseth and comendeth ye fayth of this woman, saiyng:
column8: Wherefore christ highly Praiseth and commendeth you faith of this woman, saying:

column7: Doughter be of good comforte, thy fayth hath made the safe.
column8: Daughter be of good Comfort, thy faith hath made the safe.

column7: Lo, there thou hast an example both of perfect and vnperfect fayth.
column8: Lo, there thou hast an Exampl both of perfect and unperfect faith.

column7: Secondarily, we see in this gospel howe frendly and familiarly Christe suffered the weakenes and imbecilitie of this Ruler, and with the miracle done vnto the woman, augmentyng and bryngyng him to more parfect fayth.
column8: Secondarily, we see in this gospel how friendly and familiarly Christ suffered the weakness and imbecility of this Ruler, and with the miracle done unto the woman, augmenting and bringing him to more perfect faith.

column7: For he sheweth himselfe willyng at ye desire of Iayrus,
column8: For he shows himself willing At you desire of Jairus,

column7: & foloweth him straight wayes home, declaryng with his dede that whiche he had taught before, saiyng:
column8: & Followeth him straight ways home, declaring with his deed that which he had taught before, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Come to me al ye that labour and are laden,
column8: Come to me all you that labour and Are laden,

column7: & I wyll ease you.
column8: & I will ease you.

column7: But what happened in the way?
column8: But what happened in the Way?

column7: Beholde, a woman that had been diseased xii. yere with an issue of bloudde, holdyng her peace, by fayth gat and obtayned health.
column8: Behold, a woman that had been diseased xii. year with an issue of blood, holding her peace, by faith got and obtained health.

column7: She had determined also by her selfe, that in holdyng her peace, and in silence, would haue gone home againe.
column8: She had determined also by her self, that in holding her peace, and in silence, would have gone home again.

column7: <NOTE> But as a citie buylded vpon an high hyll, can not be hyd, so likewyse it was neither mete nor yet conuenient, that suche great, high, and excellent fayth, should be hyd.
column8: But as a City builded upon an high hill, can not be hid, so likewise it was neither meet nor yet convenient, that such great, high, and excellent faith, should be hid.

column7: And dothe not Christe say in the Gospell:
column8: And doth not Christ say in the Gospel:

column7: <NOTE> There is nothyng hyd that shal not bee openly shewed, and nothyng secrete that shall not be knowen?
column8: There is nothing hid that shall not be openly showed, and nothing secret that shall not be known?

column7: So likewyse he wyl, that the fayth of this woman should be manyfest & brought to light.
column8: So likewise he will, that the faith of this woman should be manifest & brought to Light.

column7: And enquireth and sayth: Who hath touched me?
column8: And enquireth and say: Who hath touched me?

column7: The Apostles ignoraunt of this miracle, answered him and sayd:
column8: The Apostles ignorant of this miracle, answered him and said:

column7: The people thruste thee. But the woman feared and trembled, for she knewe what was done in her, came and fell doune before him and tolde him the whole truth.
column8: The people thrust thee. But the woman feared and trembled, for she knew what was done in her, Come and fell down before him and told him the Whole truth.

column7: Wherin Christ commendeth her fayth before al the people, not only that this should bee an example for the people to folowe, but also to strength Iayrus fayth, that he should not doubte, but that suche benignitee and mercy as was shewed vnto this woma, should likewyse bee shewed vnto his daughter.
column8: Wherein christ commends her faith before all the people, not only that this should be an Exampl for the people to follow, but also to strength Jairus faith, that he should not doubt, but that such benignity and mercy as was showed unto this Woman, should likewise be showed unto his daughter.

column7: Could Christe behaue him selfe more gentely, or bee indued with greatter loue, mekenes, pitie and mercy?
column8: Could Christ behave him self more gently, or be endued with greater love, meekness, pity and mercy?

column7: He declareth with the very deede, that he can helpe and succour vs in all trouble & necessitee, yea in the point of death, and is ready and willyng therto.
column8: He Declareth with the very deed, that he can help and succour us in all trouble & necessity, yea in the point of death, and is ready and willing thereto.

column7: But we of our nature are so indurate, deaffe and blind, that we wil neither with holsome doctrin and teachyng, nor yet with miracle be moued vnto fayth.
column8: But we of our nature Are so indurate, deaf and blind, that we will neither with wholesome Doctrine and teaching, nor yet with miracle be moved unto faith.

column7: Truely it is to be feared, lest we take and receiue like ende with the styffe necked and blynde Iewes.
column8: Truly it is to be feared, lest we take and receive like end with the stiff necked and blind Jews.

column7: For wee can not excuse oure selues, but the same that was spoken vnto the Iewes, might likewyse be spoken vnto vs,
column8: For we can not excuse our selves, but the same that was spoken unto the Jews, might likewise be spoken unto us,

column7: <NOTE> where Christe sayd:
column8: where Christ said:

column7: If I my selfe had not come and spoken vnto theim, then should they haue had no sinne.
column8: If I my self had not come and spoken unto them, then should they have had no sin.

column7: Is not Christ come through his gospel, and hath shewed the same?
column8: Is not christ come through his gospel, and hath showed the same?

column7: Do we not heare his worde dayly?
column8: Do we not hear his word daily?

column7: but when do we heare ye same for any amedement of our life?
column8: but when do we hear you same for any amedement of our life?

column7: I pray the take it once to heart, and remembre the goodnes, frendlynes,
column8: I pray the take it once to heart, and Remember the Goodness, frendlynes,

column7: & myldenes of Christe, howe louyngly through his worde and miracles, he intyseth & allureth vs vnto fayth.
column8: & mildness of Christ, how lovingly through his word and Miracles, he intyseth & Allureth us unto faith.

column7: Howe familiarly he taketh and suffereth our imbecilitee and weakenes, and howe feruently he desireth vs to be iust and blessed.
column8: Howe familiarly he Takes and suffers our imbecility and weakness, and how fervently he Desires us to be just and blessed.

column7: Let these thynges so moue vs, that by the meditacion hereof, we may not only encrease in fayth, but perseuer in the same, and therby get euerlastyng saluacion.
column8: Let these things so move us, that by the meditation hereof, we may not only increase in faith, but persever in the same, and thereby get everlasting salvation.

column7: Thyrdly wee see in this miracle, howe the woorkes of Christe are counted and adiudged in the world for foolishenes, yea and are skorned and dispised.
column8: Thirdly we see in this miracle, how the works of Christ Are counted and adjudged in the world for foolishenes, yea and Are scorned and despised.

column7: For Christ saiyng: The mayd is not dead but sleapeth, what did they but laught him to skorne?
column8: For christ saying: The maid is not dead but Sleepeth, what did they but laughed him to scorn?

column7: Doest thou not thinke it a miserable thynge, that the creature shuld scorne his maker, creatour of all thinges?
column8: Dost thou not think it a miserable thing, that the creature should scorn his maker, creator of all things?

column7: That vngracious and blynde fleshe, stondeth well in his owne conceite, and thinkinge him selfe to haue done a highe feate, when it doth bothe scorne, deride, and blaspheme the doctrine, workes, and myracles of Christe, ye his harte in his bodye laughed at it.
column8: That ungracious and blind Flesh, standeth well in his own conceit, and thinking him self to have done a high feat, when it does both scorn, deride, and Blaspheme the Doctrine, works, and Miracles of Christ, you his heart in his body laughed At it.

column7: But what get they thereby?
column8: But what get they thereby?

column7: Herken, The people is put forth, that they shuld not be present, at the raysing of this dead vnto lyfe.
column8: Harken, The people is put forth, that they should not be present, At the raising of this dead unto life.

column7: Lo, so it goeth with them, that scorne and dispise the gospel of Christ,
column8: Lo, so it Goes with them, that scorn and despise the gospel of christ,

column7: that god giueth theym vp vnto shameful lustes, and blyndeth their foolishe hartes, so that they shal neither se nor vnderstand the great misterye of the death and resurrection of CHRIST, but shalbe euerlastingly dampned.
column8: that god gives them up unto shameful lusts, and blinds their foolish hearts, so that they shall neither see nor understand the great mystery of the death and resurrection of CHRIST, but shall everlastingly dampened.

column7: Herevnto is to bee referred the saying of Dauid the prophete, saying:
column8: Hereunto is to be referred the saying of David the Prophet, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Blessed is the man, that goeth not in the councell of the vngodly, that abideth not in the way of synners, and setteth not in the seate of the scornefull.
column8: Blessed is the man, that Goes not in the council of the ungodly, that Abideth not in the Way of Sinners, and sets not in the seat of the scornful.

column7: But delyteth in the lawe of the lorde, and exerciseth himselfe in his lawe, bothe daye and nyghte.
column8: But delighteth in the law of the lord, and Exerciseth himself in his law, both day and night.

column7: Scorners calleth Dauid here all those, that thynketh all to be both foolyshnes and trifles, that god hath spoken and doone.
column8: Scorner's calls David Here all those, that Thinketh all to be both foolishness and trifles, that god hath spoken and done.

column7: <NOTE> And hee counteth theym blessed, that medle not and haue nothinge to doo with suche scorners.
column8: And he counteth them blessed, that meddle not and have nothing to do with such Scorner's.

column7: Out alas, howe full is the worlde nowe a dayes of suche scorners?
column8: Out alas, how full is the world now a days of such Scorner's?

column7: They bee counted glorious and goodly felowes in this world whiche scorne, dispise, persecute and blaspheme the woorde of CHRIST.
column8: They be counted glorious and goodly Fellows in this world which scorn, despise, persecute and Blaspheme the word of CHRIST.

column7: They bee loued and muche made of, yee with goodes and ryches accumulated, so that they shall lacke nothyng, neither cease to skorne Christ and his membres.
column8: They be loved and much made of, ye with goods and riches accumulated, so that they shall lack nothing, neither cease to scorn christ and his members.

column7: But good menne shall here thynke and haue in remembraunce, howe this is not onely chaunsed vnto theim, but afore tyme hath suche like blasphemye happened to our sauiour Iesu Christe.
column8: But good men shall Here think and have in remembrance, how this is not only chanced unto them, but afore time hath such like blasphemy happened to our Saviour Jesu Christ.

column7: For if they haue called the good man of the house,
column8: For if they have called the good man of the house,

column7: <NOTE> Belzebub, howe muche more shall they call them of his householde so?
column8: Belzebub, how much more shall they call them of his household so?

column7: Besydes this, wee haue also a cause of greate consolacion and comforte, insomuche as our quarel is iust, godly, conformable, and consonant with Goddes holy woorde.
column8: Besides this, we have also a cause of great consolation and Comfort, insomuch as our quarrel is just, godly, conformable, and consonant with Goddess holy word.

column7: For wee can not glorifye God more highely, then to adscribe vnto his onely begotten sonne, whom he hath for great loue and mercy that he bare vs, sent into the worlde to bee crucifyed, to bee our righteousnes, holynes, and redempcion, so that we may remayne and assuredly stande nowe in him as oure onely saluacion.
column8: For we can not Glorify God more highly, then to adscribe unto his only begotten son, whom he hath for great love and mercy that he bore us, sent into the world to be Crucified, to be our righteousness, holiness, and redemption, so that we may remain and assuredly stand now in him as our only salvation.

column7: For if we should adscribe vnto our workes, righteousnes or saluacion, we could neuer be sure.
column8: For if we should adscribe unto our works, righteousness or salvation, we could never be sure.

column7: Wherfore lette all the worde skorne, blaspheme, and persecute this our doctryne.
column8: Wherefore let all the word scorn, Blaspheme, and persecute this our Doctrine.

column7: Hereof wee are sure, that God,
column8: Hereof we Are sure, that God,

column7: Christ, the woorde of God and all the Angels in heauen, bee all on oure syde.
column8: christ, the word of God and all the Angels in heaven, be all on our side.

column7: From the beginnyng, the preachyng of the gospel was foolishenes vnto the Gentyles, and occasion of fallyng vnto the Iewes, <NOTE> as sainct Paule beareth wytnes, and so shall remayne vnto the ende.
column8: From the beginning, the preaching of the gospel was foolishenes unto the Gentiles, and occasion of falling unto the Jews, as saint Paul bears witness, and so shall remain unto the end.

column7: God almightie so merciful, geue vs grace through the vertue of the holy ghost, that we may dayly more and more increase in holsome doctryne, true fayth, and godly conuersacion, vnto thende, that at the last through Christ we may obtaine and get euerlastyng saluacion. Amen.
column8: God almighty so merciful, give us grace through the virtue of the holy ghost, that we may daily more and more increase in wholesome Doctrine, true faith, and godly Conversation, unto The end, that At the last through christ we may obtain and get everlasting salvation. Amen.

column7: The sonday next before Aduent ye shall fynde in the fourth sonday in Lent, and is written.
column8: The Sunday next before Advent you shall find in the fourth Sunday in Lent, and is written.

column8: John. 6. Here Endeth the Sermons upon the Sundays through the Whole year.

column8: THE SECONDE PARTE of this book Containeth the Sermons upon the gospels, which commonly Are read on the festival days, through the Whole year.

column8: AS jesus walked by the sea of Galilee, he saw two brothers:

column8: Symon, which was called Peter,

column7: & Andrewe his brother, castyng a nette into the sea (for they wer fishers) & he sayth vnto them:
column8: & Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea (for they were Fishers) & he say unto them:

column7: folowe me, and I wyll make you (to become) <NOTE> fyshers of menne.
column8: follow me, and I will make you (to become) Fishers of men.

column7: And they straight way left the nettes, and folowed him.
column8: And they straight Way left the nets, and followed him.

column7: And when he was gone furthe from thece, he sawe other two brethren,
column8: And when he was gone forth from thence, he saw other two brothers,

column7: Iames the sonne of Zebede,
column8: James the son of Zebedee,

column7: & Ihon his brother, in the shyp with Zebede their father, mendyng their nettes, and he called them.
column8: & John his brother, in the ship with Zebedee their father, mending their nets, and he called them.

column7: And they immediatly <NOTE> left the shyp and their father, and folowed him. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And they immediately left the ship and their father, and followed him. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: ORDINATELY and very fruitful hath sainct Mathewe the Euangelist discribed, howe, and by whom it were mete and necessary that the kyngdome of Christ wer ministred.
column8: ORDINATELY and very fruitful hath saint Matthew the Evangelist described, how, and by whom it were meet and necessary that the Kingdom of christ were ministered.

column7: For inasmuche as the same is brought to passe through the worde of God by ministers, therefore he declareth fyrst in what maner of wyse Christ begane his preachyng:
column8: For inasmuch as the same is brought to pass through the word of God by Ministers, Therefore he Declareth fyrst in what manner of wise christ began his preaching:

column7: and afterward, howe vnto the same gift of preachinge, he called certaine of his disciples, and sayeth:
column8: and afterwards, how unto the same gift of preaching, he called certain of his Disciples, and Saith:

column7: From that time forth beganne Iesus to preache, and saye.
column8: From that time forth began jesus to preach, and say.

column7: &c. Here he nameth the man that fyrste preached the gospell, yea which by his word offered vnto all men the grace of God vnto saluacion, and nameth hym Iesus, and that for the same intent and purpose, that we might clearly perceaue and vnderstand by the name, what manner of preacher he is.
column8: etc. Here he names the man that First preached the gospel, yea which by his word offered unto all men the grace of God unto salvation, and names him jesus, and that for the same intent and purpose, that we might clearly perceive and understand by the name, what manner of preacher he is.

column7: For he doth not onlye preache and offre vnto all men saluacion freely and willynglye, but also hee wyll geue it vnto all those that hope and truste in him, onlye by his propre merites and desert, without any respecte of our works, yee of mere grace and mercy,
column8: For he does not only preach and offer unto all men salvation freely and willingly, but also he will give it unto all those that hope and trust in him, only by his proper merits and desert, without any respect of our works, ye of mere grace and mercy,

column7: <NOTE> according to the saying of Saint Iohn, which saith:
column8: according to the saying of Saint John, which Says:

column7: The lawe is geuen by Moyses, but grace and truthe by Iesus Christe. <NOTE> Now peraduenture thou wilte demaund of me, what the preachinge of Christe was, and the some thereof.
column8: The law is given by Moses, but grace and truth by jesus Christ. Now Peradventure thou wilt demand of me, what the preaching of Christ was, and the Some thereof.

column7: In shorte woordes he spake as foloweth:
column8: In short words he spoke as Followeth:

column7: Amend your selues, for the kinkedome of heauen is at hande.
column8: Amend your selves, for the kinkedome of heaven is At hand.

column7: To amende our selues, to walke in a newe lyfe, and to forsake our olde vitious lyuynge, requireth the preaching of ye law of penaunce.
column8: To amend our selves, to walk in a new life, and to forsake our old vicious living, requires the preaching of the law of penance.

column7: And forasmuch as the preaching of ye gospel of the grace of god, bringeth little vtilitie or profite to ma, except he first be brought to the knowledg of his offences & sinnes,
column8: And forasmuch as the preaching of the gospel of the grace of god, brings little utility or profit to ma, except he First be brought to the knowledge of his offences & Sins,

column7: <NOTE> & haue a contryte harte, therefore it is very requisite & necessary, that the lawe, whereby we be brought to the same knowledge, be euer fyrste preached and taught:
column8: & have a contrite heart, Therefore it is very requisite & necessary, that the law, whereby we be brought to the same knowledge, be ever First preached and taught:

column7: <NOTE> Whych done, the other foloweth:
column8: Which done, the other Followeth:

column7: namelye this: The kyngedome of heauen is at hande.
column8: namely this: The Kingdom of heaven is At hand.

column7: The kyngedome of heauen in this place, is taken for the godly grace of the gospel,
column8: The Kingdom of heaven in this place, is taken for the godly grace of the gospel,

column7: As though Christ would say:
column8: As though christ would say:

column7: If I may this only thyng obtayn of you, that your synnes may earnestly displease you,
column8: If I may this only thing obtain of you, that your Sins may earnestly displease you,

column7: & aske for grace with all your whole heart, it shal be brought to passe, that grace shall not bee denyed you.
column8: & ask for grace with all your Whole heart, it shall be brought to pass, that grace shall not be denied you.

column7: For nowe truely, that acceptable tyme and daies of saluacion be at hand, in the which remission of synnes is not onely offered vnto you, but through my merites and of mere grace, shalbe forgeuen you.
column8: For now truly, that acceptable time and days of salvation be At hand, in the which remission of Sins is not only offered unto you, but through my merits and of mere grace, shall forgiven you.

column7: At the lest be warned of this, that you may knowe this tyme of visitacon, and that you do not dispise my worde.
column8: At the lest be warned of this, that you may know this time of visitacon, and that you do not despise my word.

column7: Here thou hast out of the gospell of sainct Mathew, the true preacher of grace, and the whole somme of his preachyng, with the whiche Christe wyll haue his kyngdome begonne and ministred.
column8: Here thou hast out of the gospel of saint Matthew, the true preacher of grace, and the Whole sum of his preaching, with the which Christ will have his Kingdom begun and ministered.

column7: But wyll he alone bee occupyed and charged with the administracion of the same?
column8: But will he alone be ocupied and charged with the administration of the same?

column7: No truely. For as before this tyme he hath had ministers and seruantes, so likewyse he wyll haue theim nowe.
column8: No truly. For as before this time he hath had Ministers and Servants, so likewise he will have them now.

column7: <NOTE> The Prophetes, and in especiall sainct Ihon Baptyst, were needefull and very necessarye, to prepare the waye to this preachyng of grace.
column8: The prophets, and in especial saint John Baptist, were needful and very necessary, to prepare the Way to this preaching of grace.

column7: And so likewyse as in his tyme, and also after his departyng, he would haue suche healpers (suche I say) as sainct Paule nameth theim, <NOTE> whiche faythfully and earnestly should teache the woorde of God, and doo that laye in theim, to holde it in estimacion and his dignitee.
column8: And so likewise as in his time, and also After his departing, he would have such helpers (such I say) as saint Paul names them, which faithfully and earnestly should teach the word of God, and do that say in them, to hold it in estimation and his dignity.

column7: But where shall he picke out those, or gette suche?
column8: But where shall he pick out those, or get such?

column7: Shall he gette them in the highe schole at Athenes?
column8: Shall he get them in the high school At Athens?

column7: or out of the noumbre of the doctoures in Egypte?
column8: or out of the number of the Doctors in Egypt?

column7: Or els shall they bee found at Ierusalem, where so great a company of honest Scribes & Phariseis are found?
column8: Or Else shall they be found At Jerusalem, where so great a company of honest Scribes & Pharisees Are found?

column7: No verely: He wyl picke and chose theim out of the nombre of laboryng menne.
column8: No verily: He will pick and chosen them out of the number of labouring men.

column7: Why, and wherfore wyl he do so?
column8: Why, and Wherefore will he do so?

column7: Therfore, forbecause his doctrine was so vyle couted, and had of so litle estimacion before the worlde, whiche doctrine whersoeuer it is brought to light, for the moste parte there foloweth persecucion and mortall hatred.
column8: Therefore, forbecause his Doctrine was so vile couted, and had of so little estimation before the world, which Doctrine wheresoever it is brought to Light, for the most part there Followeth persecution and Mortal hatred.

column7: In somuche that sainct Paule nameth the same woorde,
column8: In So much that saint Paul names the same word,

column7: The worde of the Crosse.
column8: The word of the Cross.

column7: Also note and marke, euen as the worde is dispised and abiected before the worlde, so shall likewise his ministers bee.
column8: Also note and mark, even as the word is despised and abjected before the world, so shall likewise his Ministers be.

column7: <NOTE> For the seruaunt is not greater then his maister. <NOTE> And sainct Paule sayth:
column8: For the servant is not greater then his master. And saint Paul say:

column7: There is not many wyse menne after the fleshe, not many mightie, not many of high degree called, but that folishe is before the worlde, hath God chosen, yt he might confounde the wise.
column8: There is not many wise men After the Flesh, not many mighty, not many of high degree called, but that foolish is before the world, hath God chosen, that he might confound the wise.

column7: But howe dyd Christe vse this callyng?
column8: But how did Christ use this calling?

column7: Iesus walked (sayth the Euangelist) by the sea of Galile, he sawe Simon Peter, and Adrewe his brother castyng a nette into the sea, and sayd vnto them:
column8: jesus walked (say the Evangelist) by the sea of Galilee, he saw Simon Peter, and Adrew his brother casting a net into the sea, and said unto them:

column7: Folowe me. The same sone after dothe he to Iames and Iohn, <NOTE> whiche also were fyshers.
column8: Follow me. The same soon After doth he to James and John, which also were Fishers.

column7: Where is to be noted, that there is two maner of callyng.
column8: Where is to be noted, that there is two manner of calling.

column7: The one is discribed in the fyrst booke of Moses where it is wrytten, that in the sweate of thy face thou shalte eate thy bread.
column8: The one is described in the fyrst book of Moses where it is written, that in the sweat of thy face thou shalt eat thy bred.

column7: Whiche partayneth vnto all men.
column8: Which partayneth unto all men.

column7: And thother is, when any man is called of God, or by some other lawefull meanes to bee a Kynge, a prince, a ruler of the common wealth, or chosen to be a preacher of goddes word.
column8: And tother is, when any man is called of God, or by Some other lawful means to be a King, a Prince, a ruler of the Common wealth, or chosen to be a preacher of God's word.

column7: And thys pertayneth not vnto all men, but to a certaine.
column8: And this pertaineth not unto all men, but to a certain.

column7: In the first callyng were the Apostels, wherein doubtles as good and vertuous men, they wold haue remained and abiden, in case they had not bene called to none other.
column8: In the First calling were the Apostles, wherein doubtless as good and virtuous men, they would have remained and abiden, in case they had not be called to none other.

column7: After whose insample are we bounde to abide in our calling.
column8: After whose insample Are we bound to abide in our calling.

column7: And if it fortune any man to be called to any office or dignitie concernyng the como wealth, he shal not onli take it vpo him willingly, but also he is boud to beware, that he behaue hiself therin righteously,
column8: And if it fortune any man to be called to any office or dignity Concerning the Common wealth, he shall not only take it upon him willingly, but also he is boud to beware, that he behave himself therein righteously,

column7: & iustly. <NOTE> And if any ma seem meete to teach the congregacion of Christ, let hym folowe the counsaile of good men, and be instructed with the warnyng, <NOTE> that (as S.
column8: & justly. And if any ma seem meet to teach the congregation of christ, let him follow the counsel of good men, and be instructed with the warning, that (as S.

column7: Paule saith) he bee founde faitstfull therein.
column8: Paul Says) he be found faitstfull therein.

column7: And where there is no callyng, there let euery man abide in the fyrste calling.
column8: And where there is no calling, there let every man abide in the First calling.

column7: And no manne taketh the honoure vnto hym selfe,
column8: And no man Takes the honour unto him self,

column7: <NOTE> but hee that is called of God, as was Aaron.
column8: but he that is called of God, as was Aaron.

column7: Secondaryly, <NOTE> after that Christe had segregated and called to him these fower Apostels frome their fyrste callyng, hee declared what hee woulde doo with theim, and sayeth:
column8: Secondarily, After that Christ had segregated and called to him these fower Apostles from their First calling, he declared what he would do with them, and Saith:

column7: I wyll make you fyshers of men.
column8: I will make you Fishers of men.

column7: Fysshinge in this place is as much to say,
column8: Fishing in this place is as much to say,

column7: <NOTE> as preachinge the woorde of god or the gospell.
column8: as preaching the word of god or the gospel.

column7: As wee haue also in the xiii. chapiter of Mathewe,
column8: As we have also in the xiii. chapter of Matthew,

column7: <NOTE> Where hee lykeneth the kingedome of heauen to a nette, caste into the sea, wherewith are taken all manner of fysshes.
column8: Where he likeneth the Kingdom of heaven to a net, cast into the sea, wherewith Are taken all manner of fishes.

column7: For as a net is cast into the sea for none other intent or purpose, then ther to catch fish, so is it conuenient and meet that thei which by lawfull callynge come to the office of preachynge,
column8: For as a net is cast into the sea for none other intent or purpose, then there to catch Fish, so is it convenient and meet that they which by lawful calling come to the office of preaching,

column7: ofte declare the worde of god, and that for none other intent, then to allure and bring men therby in the true faythe of Christe, to the laude and prayse of god, and for the saluacion of their sowles.
column8: oft declare the word of god, and that for none other intent, then to allure and bring men thereby in the true faith of Christ, to the laud and praise of god, and for the salvation of their Souls.

column7: As wee reade of Christe oure lorde, howe hee glorified by good righte, bycause he soughte only the glorye of his father.
column8: As we read of Christ our lord, how he glorified by good right, Because he sought only the glory of his father.

column7: <NOTE> And in an other place, hee sayeth:
column8: And in an other place, he Saith:

column7: The sonne of manne came to seeke and to saue that whyche was loste.
column8: The son of man Come to seek and to save that which was lost.

column7: And when Christ spake these woordes of fysshynge,
column8: And when christ spoke these words of fishing,

column7: <NOTE> hee hadde a respecte vnto the prophecye of Ieremye, whan hee saide:
column8: he had a respect unto the prophecy of Jeremiah, when he said:

column7: Beholde, I wyll sende oute manye fisshers to take theim.
column8: Behold, I will send out many Fishers to take them.

column7: Out of all these sayinges a man may lightely gather, what Christe desiered of the Apostels, and what they were bounde to doo, whiche was nothinge else, but to preache and teache, and not to deuoure and slaye.
column8: Out of all these sayings a man may lightly gather, what Christ desired of the Apostles, and what they were bound to do, which was nothing Else, but to preach and teach, and not to devour and slay.

column7: For CHRIST neuerment, that to fisshe, was as muche to saye, as to kyll and slaye, or to oppresse anye manne by violence, but contrarye wyse, to handle the worde of God with all faithfulnes and gentlenes, as wee haue in the laste chapiter of Saynte Marke:
column8: For CHRIST neuerment, that to Fish, was as much to say, as to kill and slay, or to oppress any man by violence, but contrary wise, to handle the word of God with all faithfulness and gentleness, as we have in the laste chapter of Faint Mark:

column7: Go your wayes (sayeth Christe) into all the world and preache the Gospell to all creatures.
column8: Go your ways (Saith Christ) into all the world and preach the Gospel to all creatures.

column7: And Saynte Paule when he describeth and informeth a Bysshoppe, <NOTE> hee requireth not of him, that hee shoulde be experte howe to handle a weapon, but that hee shoulde bee apte and meete to preache and teache. <NOTE>
column8: And Faint Paul when he Describeth and Informeth a Bishop, he requires not of him, that he should be expert how to handle a weapon, but that he should be apt and meet to preach and teach.

column7: For in the fyrste Epistle to the Corinthians, hee declareth what a preacher is, and also setteth forthe his office, saying:
column8: For in the First Epistle to the Corinthians, he Declareth what a preacher is, and also sets forth his office, saying:

column7: Lette euery man this wyse esteme vs, euen for the ministers of Christe, and stewardes of the secretes of God.
column8: Let every man this wise esteem us, even for the Ministers of Christ, and Stewards of the secrets of God.

column7: Nowe is there no more required of the Stewarde, then that he bee founde faythfull &c.
column8: Now is there no more required of the Steward, then that he be found faithful etc.

column7: The saiyng of the Prophete Esay agreeth well with this sentence, saiyng:
column8: The saying of the Prophet Isaiah agreeth well with this sentence, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Crye as loude as thou canst, and leaue not of.
column8: Cry as loud as thou Canst, and leave not of.

column7: Lyfte vp thy voyce lyke a Trompette, and shewe my people their offences.
column8: Lift up thy voice like a Trumpet, and show my people their offences.

column7: Lyfte vppe thy voyce and bee not afrayde.
column8: Lift up thy voice and be not afraid.

column7: We must needes confesse that all this is spoken of the office of preachyng and teachyng.
column8: We must needs confess that all this is spoken of the office of preaching and teaching.

column7: What neede we many wordes?
column8: What need we many words?

column7: The office of a preacher is to teache, to rebuke, to comforte, to exhorte, and to be founde faythfull in his office.
column8: The office of a preacher is to teach, to rebuke, to Comfort, to exhort, and to be found faithful in his office.

column7: Therefore, he that wyll bee taken for a true preacher, shall not come to that madnesse, for to drawe agayne sainct Peters swoorde, whiche was ones putte into the sheath.
column8: Therefore, he that will be taken for a true preacher, shall not come to that madness, for to draw again saint Peter's sword, which was ones put into the sheath.

column7: But all his authoritee and office standeth in this, that he is bounde to remayne with sainct Ihon Baptyst, the voyce of a cryer,
column8: But all his Authority and office Stands in this, that he is bound to remain with saint John Baptist, the voice of a crier,

column7: <NOTE> or els he doth vsurpe another office, and should rather bee named a sedicious manqueller, then a preacher of the woorde of God.
column8: or Else he does usurp Another office, and should rather be nam a seditious manqueller, then a preacher of the word of God.

column7: Thyrdly this Gospel declareth vnto vs the obedience and simplicitee of the Apostles,
column8: Thirdly this Gospel Declareth unto us the Obedience and simplicity of the Apostles,

column7: <NOTE> whiche were called of Christe to preache.
column8: which were called of Christ to preach.

column7: For assone as they heard this voyce of Christe:
column8: For As soon as they herd this voice of Christ:

column7: Come and folowe me. straight wayes they did geue theim selues ouer into the wylle of God, were obedient, not disputed whether it were lawefull & meete to forsakee father and mother, wyfe and children, to folowe a man of so lytle reputacion before the world, as was Christ, but did euen as we reade in another place of Abraham, when he was commaunded to go out of his countrey into a lande that God should shewe him, he disputed not whether he should goo, or whether he might not serue God aswel in his fathers house, as in a straunge countrey, but most symply obeyed the worde of God.
column8: Come and follow me. straight ways they did give them selves over into the will of God, were obedient, not disputed whither it were lawful & meet to forsakee father and mother, wife and children, to follow a man of so little reputation before the world, as was christ, but did even as we read in Another place of Abraham, when he was commanded to go out of his country into a land that God should show him, he disputed not whither he should goo, or whither he might not serve God aswell in his Father's house, as in a strange country, but most simply obeyed the word of God.

column7: So likewyse were these Apostles found obedient. <NOTE> Wherfore that mightie woorde of God and the gospell is highly to be magnified and extolled, which doth not onely penetrate the eares, but stryketh and toucheth the heart,
column8: So likewise were these Apostles found obedient. Wherefore that mighty word of God and the gospel is highly to be magnified and extolled, which does not only penetrate the ears, but striketh and touches the heart,

column7: Or els truely fleshe and bloud had aswell remayned disobedient in the Apostles as in ye Phariseis.
column8: Or Else truly Flesh and blood had aswell remained disobedient in the Apostles as in you Pharisees.

column7: For they, though Christ neuer so ofte repeted and cryed vnto theim:
column8: For they, though christ never so oft repeated and cried unto them:

column7: Amende your selfe, the kyngdome of heauen is at hand. yet would they neither heare him nor folowe him.
column8: Amend your self, the Kingdom of heaven is At hand. yet would they neither hear him nor follow him.

column7: But where Christe cryeth aswell in the heart as in the eare, there without any busynes, willyngly, men both heareth him and foloweth him.
column8: But where Christ Cries aswell in the heart as in the ear, there without any business, willingly, men both hears him and Followeth him.

column7: But when he cryeth onely but in the eare, then remayne we as blynde and as harde hearted, as that blynde Pharao did.
column8: But when he Cries only but in the ear, then remain we as blind and as harden hearted, as that blind Pharaoh did.

column7: Neuerthelesse it is all our faulte that we do not heare and folowe Christ.
column8: Nevertheless it is all our fault that we do not hear and follow christ.

column7: Furthermore, wee shall with all diligence seeke Christe and bee feruent in hearyng of the Gospell, forasmuche as he sayeth:
column8: Furthermore, we shall with all diligence seek Christ and be fervent in hearing of the Gospel, forasmuch as he Saith:

column7: <NOTE> Who so hath eares to heare, lette him heare.
column8: Who so hath ears to hear, let him hear.

column7: And though the Apostles are bound to geue thankes vnto God, and knowlege that it all came of him, in that they were so obedient and folowed Christe, yet is this wrytten for an example for vs, so that I knowe not how to geue greatter honour and worshippe to the sainctes,
column8: And though the Apostles Are bound to give thanks unto God, and knowledge that it all Come of him, in that they were so obedient and followed Christ, yet is this written for an Exampl for us, so that I know not how to give greater honour and worship to the Saints,

column7: <NOTE> then when through their ensample I am induced to folowe Christ.
column8: then when through their ensample I am induced to follow christ.

column7: And here is to be noted, that there is two maner of folowyng of Christe.
column8: And Here is to be noted, that there is two manner of following of Christ.

column7: The one is bodily wyse,
column8: The one is bodily wise,

column7: <NOTE> and the other spiritually.
column8: and the other spiritually.

column7: Of the bodily folowyng of Christe speaketh this present Gospell, and doth not pertayne vnto all menne, but vnto those onely that be commaunded, as the Apostles wer, and also Abraham.
column8: Of the bodily following of Christ speaks this present Gospel, and does not pertain unto all men, but unto those only that be commanded, as the Apostles were, and also Abraham.

column7: Or when through the wyll of God, the Tyrantes of this worlde shall take thee from thy wyfe and children by violence, and put the to execucion for the Gospell sake,
column8: Or when through the will of God, the Tyrants of this world shall take thee from thy wife and children by violence, and put thee to execution for the Gospel sake,

column7: And so there is Christ to bee folowed, not onely spiritually, but also bodily.
column8: And so there is christ to be followed, not only spiritually, but also bodily.

column7: For of that it is wrytten:
column8: For of that it is written:

column7: <NOTE> Whosoeuer denyeth me before men, him will I also denye before my father whiche is in heauen. <NOTE> The other folowyng of Christ is spiritual,
column8: Whosoever denyeth me before men, him will I also deny before my father which is in heaven. The other following of christ is spiritual,

column7: & partayneth vnto all christian men.
column8: & partayneth unto all christian men.

column7: For as long as I determyne with my selfe to forsake all thynges that I haue in the worlde wyllyngly, whensoeuer it shall please God so to ordain it, yea and at all tymes am readye to dye for the truth sake, so long I folowe Christe.
column8: For as long as I determine with my self to forsake all things that I have in the world willingly, whensoever it shall please God so to ordain it, yea and At all times am ready to die for the truth sake, so long I follow Christ.

column7: And so may this spirituall folowyng of Christe stande, and bee acceptable before God, without the bodily folowyng, as chaunseth often tymes.
column8: And so may this spiritual following of Christ stand, and be acceptable before God, without the bodily following, as chaunseth often times.

column7: But the bodily folowyng without the spiritual ought not to bee.
column8: But the bodily following without the spiritual ought not to be.

column7: For suche thynges ought in suche a chaunce bothe to be ioyned together.
column8: For such things ought in such a chance both to be joined together.

column7: Wylte thou knowe nowe, in what wyse thou shalt behaue and instruct thy selfe herein?
column8: Wilt thou know now, in what wise thou shalt behave and instruct thy self herein?

column7: Herken to. If God ordaine it so, that thou must forsake all thyng,
column8: Harken to. If God ordain it so, that thou must forsake all thing,

column7: & for the truth sake sufferest all aduersitee, put awaye and expell from thee all feare, and be of good comforte, and folowe Christe faythfully, not consideryng neither wyfe nor children,
column8: & for the truth sake sufferest all adversity, put away and expel from thee all Fear, and be of good Comfort, and follow Christ faithfully, not considering neither wife nor children,

column7: <NOTE> for great shal be thy rewarde in heauen.
column8: for great shall be thy reward in heaven.

column7: And although God doth not visite the with suche affliccion and tribulacion, neuerthelesse it is mete and conuenient that thy heart and mynde bee setteled, and vtterly persuaded at all tymes to be ready to folowe Christ.
column8: And although God does not visit thee with such affliction and tribulation, nevertheless it is meet and convenient that thy heart and mind be settled, and utterly persuaded At all times to be ready to follow christ.

column7: But in the meane tyme, thou shalte not temerously and without great causes forsake neither wyfe nor children, nor no other thyng that God hath sent thee and endued with all.
column8: But in the mean time, thou shalt not temerously and without great Causes forsake neither wife nor children, nor no other thing that God hath sent thee and endued with all.

column7: For in that to be willyng to suffre all trouble, persecucion and pouertie, when it shall please God to send it thee, is called the true obaiyng and folowyng of Christ.
column8: For in that to be willing to suffer all trouble, persecution and poverty, when it shall please God to send it thee, is called the true obaiyng and following of christ.

column7: To whom with the father & holy gost be all honor.
column8: To whom with the father & holy ghost be all honour.

column7: Amen. The Gospell on sainct Thomas day. Ihon. 20.
column8: Amen. The Gospel on saint Thomas day. John 20.
