column8: Woodcut illustration of the apostle Saint

column7: Thomas. B Vt <NOTE> Thomas one of the xii. (which is called Didymus) was not with them, when Iesus came.
column8: Thomas. But But Thomas one of the xii. (which is called Didymus) was not with them, when jesus Come.

column7: The other disciples therefore sayd vnto him:
column8: The other Disciples Therefore said unto him:

column7: We haue sene the Lord.
column8: We have seen the Lord.

column7: But he sayd vnto the:
column8: But he said unto thee:

column7: Except I see in his hades the print of the nayles,
column8: Except I see in his hades the print of the nails,

column7: & put my fynger into the prynt of the nayles, and thurst my hand into his syde,
column8: & put my finger into the print of the nails, and thirst my hand into his side,

column7: I wyll not beleue. And after eight dayes againe his disciples wer within, and Thomas with them.
column8: I will not believe. And After eight days again his Disciples were within, and Thomas with them.

column7: Then came Iesus when the doores were shut, and stoode in the middes, and sayd: Peace be vnto you.
column8: Then Come jesus when the doors were shut, and stood in the mids, and said: Peace be unto you.

column7: After that sayd he to Thomas:
column8: After that said he to Thomas:

column7: Bryng thy fynger hether, and see my handes, and reache hether thy hand, and thurst it into my syde, and be not faythles, but beleuyng.
column8: Bring thy finger hither, and see my hands, and reach hither thy hand, and thirst it into my side, and be not faythles, but believing.

column7: Thomas answered and sayd vnto him:
column8: Thomas answered and said unto him:

column7: My Lorde, and my God.
column8: My Lord, and my God.

column7: Iesus sayd vnto him: Thomas, because thou hast sene me, thou hast beleued:
column8: jesus said unto him: Thomas, Because thou hast seen me, thou hast believed:

column7: Blessed are they that haue not sene, and yet haue beleued. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Blessed Are they that have not seen, and yet have believed. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: <NOTE> F Yrst wee haue in this Gospell an ensample of incredulite in sainct Thomas,
column8: FYrst FYrst we have in this Gospel an ensample of Incredulity in saint Thomas,

column7: & so grosse, that worthily any man might wonder at it, in especial in suche an Apostle whiche had heard so often tymes of Christ, howe that he should be put to death, and ryse againe the thyrde day. except that the imbecilitee and weakenes of oure nature and fleshe were not sufficiently knowen vnto vs, yea excepte that oure detestable incredulite that is grafte in vs, were not better knowen vnto vs, then is nedefull here to recite with many wordes.
column8: & so gross, that worthily any man might wonder At it, in especial in such an Apostle which had herd so often times of christ, how that he should be put to death, and rise again the Third day. except that the imbecility and weakness of our nature and Flesh were not sufficiently known unto us, yea except that our detestable Incredulity that is graft in us, were not better known unto us, then is needful Here to recite with many words.

column7: And wherein I beseche you may wee wretches glorifye in, when suche notable incredulite can be found in suche an Apostle?
column8: And wherein I beseech you may we wretches Glorify in, when such notable Incredulity can be found in such an Apostle?

column7: But for no other intent or purpose is this layde before vs, then onely that wee therby may learne to knowe the weakenes and maliciousnes of our fleshe.
column8: But for no other intent or purpose is this laid before us, then only that we thereby may Learn to know the weakness and maliciousness of our Flesh.

column7: For as long as this blyndnes and maliciousnes of oure fleshe is not holpen and redressed through Christ and his spirit, so long shall that fayth whiche Christ requireth of vs with so many woordes bee no greater in vs, then it was here in S.
column8: For as long as this blindness and maliciousness of our Flesh is not helped and Redressed through christ and his Spirit, so long shall that faith which christ requires of us with so many words be no greater in us, then it was Here in S.

column7: Thomas. Many there be which suppose that fayth is so common a thyng, that it is in euery mannes freewylle to beleue who wyll, that Christe dyed & rose againe the third day.
column8: Thomas. Many there be which suppose that faith is so Common a thing, that it is in every Man's freewylle to believe who will, that Christ died & rose again the third day.

column7: Whiche if it were so in deede, what needed Christ to saye these words:
column8: Which if it were so in deed, what needed christ to say these words:

column7: Suppose you that the sonne of man,
column8: Suppose you that the son of man,

column7: <NOTE> when he commeth, shall finde faithe vppon earthe?
column8: when he comes, shall find faith upon earth?

column7: Moreouer, what was the cause that the Apostels in the tyme of the resurrection of Christ, were so rude and ignoraunt, in the matter of fayth and iustificacion?
column8: Moreover, what was the cause that the Apostles in the time of the resurrection of christ, were so rude and ignorant, in the matter of faith and justification?

column7: Nor it is not to be thought, that suche thinge happened only vnto S.
column8: Nor it is not to be Thought, that such thing happened only unto S.

column7: Thomas, and not to the reste of the Apostests, except that wee wyll saye, that all suche tokens and actes which we fynde in the story of the resurrection of Christ (fyrst doon through angels, and then by Christe himselfe, whereby the Apostels in this article were confirmed) were vanities and lyes.
column8: Thomas, and not to the rest of the Apostates, except that we will say, that all such tokens and acts which we find in the story of the resurrection of christ (fyrst done through Angels, and then by Christ himself, whereby the Apostles in this article were confirmed) were vanities and lies.

column7: I may suffre euery man to say herein his pleasure.
column8: I may suffer every man to say herein his pleasure.

column7: Yet doo I thus thinke, and can approue yt by many testimonies of scripture, that no mortal man, how well learned or wise so euer he be, how good or sharpe witted so euer he be, can learne or be instructed in the faith of Christ,
column8: Yet do I thus think, and can approve that by many testimonies of scripture, that no Mortal man, how well learned or wise so ever he be, how good or sharp witted so ever he be, can Learn or be instructed in the faith of christ,

column7: <NOTE> except the singular grace of the holy ghoste drawe him and instruct him therin.
column8: except the singular grace of the holy ghost draw him and instruct him therein.

column7: The prophete sayth: They shal be all taught of god,
column8: The Prophet say: They shall be all taught of god,

column7: Then if I can instructe and teache my selfe in those thinges, that concerne our faythe, what need hath god to teach me?
column8: Then if I can instruct and teach my self in those things, that concern our faith, what need hath god to teach me?

column7: Vpon this reason S. Iohn the euangelyst, saith:
column8: Upon this reason S. John the Evangelist, Says:

column7: Hee came into his owne,
column8: He Come into his own,

column7: <NOTE> and his owne receyued him not.
column8: and his own received him not.

column7: If faith be such a light and an easye thinge to come by, what was the cause that the Iewes were so ignoraunt in the comynge of their Messias, whiche were taught and brought vp in the lawe?
column8: If faith be such a Light and an easy thing to come by, what was the cause that the Jews were so ignorant in the coming of their Messias, which were taught and brought up in the law?

column7: Or for what cause dothe the lyghte shine in darkenes, and the darkenes can not comprehende it?
column8: Or for what cause doth the Light shine in darkness, and the darkness can not comprehend it?

column7: Wherefore it is meete that wee learne hereout, that it is not in euery mannes power to haue fayth, but that it is a gyfte and a woorke of God only, as we fynde in this place of sainct Thomas, that in no maner of wyse he would beleue, excepte he sawe with his eyen, and felte with his fyngers.
column8: Wherefore it is meet that we Learn hereout, that it is not in every Man's power to have faith, but that it is a gift and a work of God only, as we find in this place of saint Thomas, that in no manner of wise he would believe, except he saw with his eyes, and felt with his fingers.

column7: Secondarily, wee fynde in this ensample howe paciently, and gently Christe suffereth suche imbecilitee and weakenes in his seruauntes.
column8: Secondarily, we find in this ensample how patiently, and gently Christ suffers such imbecility and weakness in his Servants.

column7: Yea, he turneth suche mekenesse into a strong fayth.
column8: Yea, he turns such meekness into a strong faith.

column7: For as we reade in the history of the resurrection, howe he fyrst did appeare vnto the women and the Apostles, so he dothe seeme here likewyse in this place vnto the vnfaythfull Thomas, because he should not styl perseuer in incredulitee, but should become faythfull.
column8: For as we read in the history of the resurrection, how he fyrst did appear unto the women and the Apostles, so he doth seem Here likewise in this place unto the unfaithful Thomas, Because he should not still persever in incredulity, but should become faithful.

column7: He came the eight daye after his resurrection vnto the disciples, and besydes that he saluted theim with his peace, he shewed vnto Thomas his handes and his feete, saiyng:
column8: He Come the eight day After his resurrection unto the Disciples, and besides that he saluted them with his peace, he showed unto Thomas his hands and his feet, saying:

column7: Bryng thy fynger hither, and see my handes, and reche hether thy hande and thrust it into my syde, and bee not faythlesse, but beleuyng.
column8: Bring thy finger hither, and see my hands, and reche hither thy hand and thrust it into my side, and be not faithless, but believing.

column7: Is not this a highe and an excellent pacience and gentylnes, in suche wyse to suffre the weakenes of his electe?
column8: Is not this a high and an excellent patience and gentleness, in such wise to suffer the weakness of his elect?

column7: And I beseche you, howe could bee done vnto Thomas a greatter pleasure?
column8: And I beseech you, how could be done unto Thomas a greater pleasure?

column7: For except he had sene and felt, he would not haue beleued.
column8: For except he had seen and felt, he would not have believed.

column7: And yet was Christ so good and so full of pitie, that Thomas had all his wylle and mynde.
column8: And yet was christ so good and so full of pity, that Thomas had all his will and mind.

column7: For besydes that he rebuked him with most gentle and swete woordes, he suffered him to put his fynger in his syde.
column8: For besides that he rebuked him with most gentle and sweet words, he suffered him to put his finger in his side.

column7: O good Lord, what great affection and loue thynkest thou dothe he beare to his electe seruauntes?
column8: O good Lord, what great affection and love Thinkest thou doth he bear to his elect Servants?

column7: Doth not this place approue and confirme the same saiyng, that he vsed whyle he was yet in this mortal life, saiyng:
column8: Does not this place approve and confirm the same saying, that he used while he was yet in this Mortal life, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Come vnto me all ye that labour and are laden, and I wyl ease you?
column8: Come unto me all you that labour and Are laden, and I will ease you?

column7: Note also here, howe Christ throughly learneth and instructeth Thomas, bothe with wordes and tokens.
column8: Note also Here, how christ thoroughly learneth and Instructeth Thomas, both with words and tokens.

column7: The wordes wherewith he is taught, driueth away and expelleth his incredulite, which wordes are so layde against him, that therby thou mayest perceiue no greatter synne to be vpon yearth, then is incredulitee.
column8: The words wherewith he is taught, Driveth away and expelleth his Incredulity, which words Are so laid against him, that thereby thou Mayest perceive no greater sin to be upon earth, then is incredulity.

column7: Whereout, <NOTE> as out of a fountayne and sprynge, floweth all other synnes.
column8: Whereout, as out of a fountain and spring, flows all other Sins.

column7: For he sayth: Bee not faythlesse, but beleue.
column8: For he say: be not faithless, but believe.

column7: As though he would saye:
column8: As though he would say:

column7: If thou fall from the fayth, thou art vtterly vndone.
column8: If thou fallen from the faith, thou art utterly undone.

column7: But if thou bee faythfull and beleuest,
column8: But if thou be faithful and Believest,

column7: & hereafter do not doubt of the merites of my resurrection, then trust surely, that this incredulitee shall not in any wyse hynder or hurte thee, but shall so and in suche maner of wyse be forgeuen thee, that hereafter I wyll neuer remembre it more.
column8: & hereafter do not doubt of the merits of my resurrection, then trust surely, that this incredulity shall not in any wise hinder or hurt thee, but shall so and in such manner of wise be forgiven thee, that hereafter I will never Remember it more.

column7: For I require nothyng els for this great benefite, whiche I haue purchased for the whole world, through my bitter passion, then only a faythfull heart, whiche shall not putte his confidence in no creature, whether it bee in heauen or in yearth, excepte onely in my merites and deseruyng.
column8: For I require nothing Else for this great benefit, which I have purchased for the Whole world, through my bitter passion, then only a faithful heart, which shall not put his confidence in no creature, whither it be in heaven or in earth, except only in my merits and deserving.

column7: Beholde, howe with these wordes, thapostle is reduced and brought to true fayth.
column8: Behold, how with these words, apostle is reduced and brought to true faith.

column7: And likewyse as he is strengthened and comforted with wordes, so also is he holpen with signes & tokens,
column8: And likewise as he is strengthened and comforted with words, so also is he helped with Signs & tokens,

column7: <NOTE> which for the most part is shewed to confirme our fayth.
column8: which for the most part is showed to confirm our faith.

column7: And yet it is done after a most symple maner, by reason he may ye easyer be brought to a true fayth and beleue.
column8: And yet it is done After a most simple manner, by reason he may you Easier be brought to a true faith and believe.

column7: Who would not put and set his trust in suche a mercyfull and a gentle Lorde?
column8: Who would not put and Set his trust in such a merciful and a gentle Lord?

column7: Who would set his hope in any other except him onely?
column8: Who would Set his hope in any other except him only?

column7: Thirdly, this Gospel prayseth and commendeth tranquilitee,
column8: Thirdly, this Gospel Praiseth and commends tranquillity,

column7: <NOTE> quietnes and peace of conscience, and sheweth likewise howe that Christ hath communicated the same to the Apostles.
column8: quietness and peace of conscience, and shows likewise how that christ hath communicated the same to the Apostles.

column7: And of this peace Christ speaketh before his passion,
column8: And of this peace christ speaks before his passion,

column7: <NOTE> saiyng: Peace I leaue with you, my peace I geue vnto you:
column8: saying: Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you:

column7: not as the worlde geueth, geue I vnto you &c.
column8: not as the world Giveth, give I unto you etc.

column7: With the whiche wordes Christ maketh a difference betwene a ciuile & a christian fayth.
column8: With the which words christ makes a difference between a civil & a christian faith.

column7: The peace of the wolrde lyeth in ciuile and corporal thynges, wherevnto if ryches and goodes chaunce plenteously, it maketh menne very negligent and careles, incase it bee not prouided and preuented through the word of God.
column8: The peace of the wolrde lies in civil and corporal things, whereunto if riches and goods chance plenteously, it makes men very negligent and careless, incase it be not provided and prevented through the word of God.

column7: But a christian peace cosisteth in spiritual thynges which maketh a man hardy & strong in persecution and temptacion, and suche a one, as when extreme necessitee and the honour of God dothe so require, they shall not onely not fear ye deuil with the world and all their adherentes, but also shal dispise them and set nothing by them,
column8: But a christian peace cosisteth in spiritual things which makes a man hardy & strong in persecution and temptation, and such a one, as when extreme necessity and the honour of God doth so require, they shall not only not Fear you Devil with the world and all their adherentes, but also shall despise them and Set nothing by them,

column7: <NOTE> as we see the Apostles did after that the holy ghost was confirmed in them.
column8: as we see the Apostles did After that the holy ghost was confirmed in them.

column7: Suche a fayth doth Christ worke in his seruantes, and is apprehended of theim onely, that with a true fayth knowledge & embrace Iesus Christ their lord.
column8: Suche a faith does christ work in his Servants, and is apprehended of them only, that with a true faith knowledge & embrace jesus christ their lord.

column7: And this peace I haue, so longe as I beleue in Christ.
column8: And this peace I have, so long as I believe in christ.

column7: And nowe if I do not beleeue, it is not possible that I can haue any peace in my conscience towarde God for my synnes sake, whiche alwayes accuseth me in my conscience, nor wyll not suffre me to come nor attaine to this spiritual peace.
column8: And now if I do not believe, it is not possible that I can have any peace in my conscience toward God for my Sins sake, which always Accuseth me in my conscience, nor will not suffer me to come nor attain to this spiritual peace.

column7: Fourthly, <NOTE> wee fynde here an excellent confession in Thomas, in whiche he knowlegeth Christ to bee his God and his Lorde.
column8: Fourthly, we find Here an excellent Confessi in Thomas, in which he knowledgeth christ to be his God and his Lord.

column7: And this confession is so nedefull and necessary, without the whiche no man can haue the true righteousnes that preuaileth before God, nor entre into the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: And this Confessi is so needful and necessary, without the which no man can have the true righteousness that prevaileth before God, nor enter into the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: But note also, howe afore that Christe had shewed his handes and his feete vnto Thomas, he could not haue this cofession. <NOTE> Handes and feete in scripture betokeneth often tymes workes and conuersacion.
column8: But note also, how afore that Christ had showed his hands and his feet unto Thomas, he could not have this confession. Hands and feet in scripture Betokeneth often times works and Conversation.

column7: Therfore when Christ sheweth vs his handes and feete, that is,
column8: Therefore when christ shows us his hands and feet, that is,

column7: When he hath brought vs to that point, throught his spirite and worde, that we acknowlege his merites, passion, death, and finally all his workes, onely to be the cause of our righteousnes and saluacion, then may we saye with the Apostle:
column8: When he hath brought us to that point, brought his Spirit and word, that we acknowledge his merits, passion, death, and finally all his works, only to be the cause of our righteousness and salvation, then may we say with the Apostle:

column7: My Lorde, my God and put all our trust in him, accordig to the saiyng of Dauid:
column8: My Lord, my God and put all our trust in him, according to the saying of David:

column7: <NOTE> Set your trust in the Lorde, and he shall care for you.
column8: Set your trust in the Lord, and he shall care for you.

column7: When Christ doth not in suche wyse shewe vs his handes and fete, so is it for vs vnpossible to make any such confession.
column8: When christ does not in such wise show us his hands and feet, so is it for us unpossible to make any such Confessi.

column7: For sainct Paule sayeth not without a cause to the Corinthians, saiyng:
column8: For saint Paul Saith not without a cause to the Corinthians, saying:

column7: No man can say that IESVS is the Lorde, then through the holy ghost.
column8: No man can say that JESUS is the Lord, then through the holy ghost.

column7: Wherefore it is Christe that must bryng vs to this confession.
column8: Wherefore it is Christ that must bring us to this Confessi.

column7: Further note, that Thomas beyng enflamed with the holy ghost, calleth Christ his god.
column8: Further note, that Thomas being inflamed with the holy ghost, calls christ his god.

column7: This & such lyke sentences, by the whiche it is proued that Christ is the true & naturall God,
column8: This & such like sentences, by the which it is proved that christ is the true & natural God,

column7: ought diligently to bee noted, and surely layde vp in our mindes, and especially nowe in this last and perilous tyme.
column8: ought diligently to be noted, and surely laid up in our minds, and especially now in this last and perilous time.

column7: Wherfore it is very necessary, when suche errors & abuses crepe in (whiche God forbid) that wee bee well instructed with this confession of Thomas, lest wee bee vtterly drawen from the true fayth of Christe.
column8: Wherefore it is very necessary, when such errors & Abuses creep in (which God forbid) that we be well instructed with this Confessi of Thomas, lest we be utterly drawn from the true faith of Christ.

column7: With this confession of Thomas, sainct Ihon in his canonical Epistle agreeth very aptely, <NOTE> where he calleth Christ very God and euerlastyng light, whiche is freely confessed Christ to be the true God.
column8: With this Confessi of Thomas, saint John in his canonical Epistle agreeth very aptly, where he calls christ very God and everlasting Light, which is freely confessed christ to be the true God.

column7: He that wyll (these admonicions notwithstandyng) be deceiued, on his perill be it.
column8: He that will (these admonitions notwithstanding) be deceived, on his peril be it.

column7: For we truely (through ye helpe of God) wyll stand, liue and dye in this article, in suche hope and trust, that the almightie God of his great mercy & goodnes, will maintayn vs here euerlastyngly, through his only sonne our Lord Iesus Christ.
column8: For we truly (through you help of God) will stand, live and die in this article, in such hope and trust, that the almighty God of his great mercy & Goodness, will maintain us Here everlastingly, through his only son our Lord jesus christ.

column7: Amen. The Gospell on sainct Stephin his day the Martyr. Math. 23.
column8: Amen. The Gospel on saint Stephen his day the Martyr. Math. 23.

column7: Woodcut illustration of St. Stephen 's martyrdom;
column8: Woodcut illustration of Saint Stephen is martyrdom;

column7: the apostle is being stoned to death as he prays.
column8: the apostle is being stoned to death as he prays.

column7: W Herfore beholde <NOTE> I sende vnto you prophetes and wyse men,
column8: Wherefore Wherefore behold I send unto you Prophets and wise men,

column7: ^ Scribes, and some of theim ye shall kyll and crucifie:
column8: ^ Scribes, and Some of them you shall kill and crucify:

column7: and some of theim shall ye scourge in your synagoges, and perse cure theim fro citie to citie:
column8: and Some of them shall you scourge in your Synagogues, and pierce cure them from City to City:

column7: that vpo you may come all the righteous bloud whiche hath been shedde vpon the yearth, fro the bloud of righteous <NOTE> Abel, vnto the bloud of Zacharye the sonne o^ Barachias, <NOTE> whom ye flewe betwene the temple and the altar.
column8: that upon you may come all the righteous blood which hath been shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel, unto the blood of Zacharye the son oh Barachiah, whom you flew between the temple and the altar.

column7: Verely I say vnto you:
column8: Verily I say unto you:

column7: all these thynges shall come vpon this generacion.
column8: all these things shall come upon this generation.

column7: <NOTE> O Ierusalem, Ierusalem, thou that kyilest the prophetes, and stonest theim whiche are sent vnto thee, howe often would <NOTE> I haue gathered thy children together, euen as the Henne gathereth her chickyns vnder her wynges, and ye would not?
column8: Oh Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that kyilest the Prophets, and Stonest them which Are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered thy children together, even as the Hen gathereth her chickyns under her wings, and you would not?

column7: Behold <NOTE> your house is lefte vnto you desolate.
column8: Behold your house is left unto you desolate.

column7: For I say vnto you:
column8: For I say unto you:

column7: ye shall not see me hencefurth, tyll that ye say <NOTE> Blessed is he, that commeth in the name of the Lorde. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: you shall not see me Henceforth, till that you say Blessed is he, that comes in the name of the Lord. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this Gospell Christ handeleth the Iewes somewhat roughly, like as one that almost had made an ende of his course & runnyng, and nere to his death, ready to be offered vppe:
column8: IN this Gospel christ handleth the Jews somewhat roughly, like as one that almost had made an end of his course & running, and never to his death, ready to be offered up:

column7: Yea, he reproueth them in suche wyse of their blyndnes, maliciousnes and their indurate heart, and that with so great vehemency and so ernestly, that he could not hardlyer assault them.
column8: Yea, he Reproveth them in such wise of their blindness, maliciousness and their indurate heart, and that with so great vehemency and so earnestly, that he could not hardlyer assault them.

column7: And that their ingratitude shuld be the better knowen vnto them and be brought to light, he reciteth vnto theim the great benefites that God from the beginnyng of the worlde had visited theim with all, yea, and that whiche was yet commyng before that their great cicie of Ierusalem should bee destroyed:
column8: And that their ingratitude should be the better known unto them and be brought to Light, he reciteth unto them the great benefits that God from the beginning of the world had visited them with all, yea, and that which was yet coming before that their great cicie of Jerusalem should be destroyed:

column7: And sayd howe he sent theim Prophetes,
column8: And said how he sent them prophets,

column7: Wysemen and Scribes, and euer had sought all meanes and occasions to bryng them through their preachyng to saluacion, yet al would not helpe.
column8: Wise men and Scribes, and ever had sought all means and occasions to bring them through their preaching to salvation, yet all would not help.

column7: <NOTE> He calleth Prophetes those whiche throughe the inspiracion of the holy ghost, and by the commaundement of God prophecie and teache the people the will of God:
column8: He calls prophets those which through the inspiration of the holy ghost, and by the Commandment of God prophecy and teach the people the will of God:

column7: And which haue been taught of no ma, except of God onely, as Moses was.
column8: And which have been taught of no ma, except of God only, as Moses was.

column7: <NOTE> And he calleth wyse men those, that haue learned and heard all their wysdome of other good men, and are ready to vtter it againe to all men, as was Aaron in the olde Testament, and sainct Stephin in the newe Testament.
column8: And he calls wise men those, that have learned and herd all their Wisdom of other good men, and Are ready to utter it again to all men, as was Aaron in the old Testament, and saint Stephen in the new Testament.

column7: Scrybes <NOTE> he calleth those, whiche not onely throughe preachyng the woorde of God, but also through their diligent labour in writyng, teache other menne, and profiteth theim highely, as were many after the Apostles tyme, and likewyse in our tyme there be many that haue done muche good in the church of Christ, and dayly yet dothe.
column8: Scribes he calls those, which not only through preaching the word of God, but also through their diligent labour in writing, teach other men, and profiteth them highly, as were many After the Apostles time, and likewise in our time there be many that have done much good in the Church of christ, and daily yet doth.

column7: Of the whiche in another place Christ sayth:
column8: Of the which in Another place christ say:

column7: <NOTE> Euery Scribe taught vnto the kyngdome of heauen, is like an housholder, which bringeth furth of his treasure thynges newe and olde,
column8: Every Scribe taught unto the Kingdom of heaven, is like an householder, which brings forth of his treasure things new and old,

column7: Out of whiche woordes lightly may bee gathered, the greate benefites that God had shewed vpon the Iewes.
column8: Out of which words lightly may be gathered, the great benefits that God had showed upon the Jews.

column7: And how (I pray you) can be so wyse or wel learned that can comprehend with words al the benefites that god had shewed vnto the Iewes, from that tyme that he had brought them out of Egypt, and deliuered them fro bondage?
column8: And how (I pray you) can be so wise or well learned that can comprehend with words all the benefits that god had showed unto the Jews, from that time that he had brought them out of Egypt, and Delivered them from bondage?

column7: <NOTE> And yet amongst all other, this was the greatest & highest benefite that he had geuen them his worde, without doubt a most precious and excellent gyfte.
column8: And yet among all other, this was the greatest & highest benefit that he had given them his word, without doubt a most precious and excellent gift.

column7: Whiche gyfte was so great,
column8: Which gift was so great,

column7: <NOTE> that as sainct Paule sayth, they farre excelled vs Heathen people, forasmuche as God hadde committed his woorde vnto theim.
column8: that as saint Paul say, they Far excelled us Heathen people, forasmuch as God had committed his word unto them.

column7: And the prophete Dauid boasteth,
column8: And the Prophet David boasts,

column7: <NOTE> that god had doone no suche thinge to all nations, lyke as he had done vnto the Iewes.
column8: that god had done no such thing to all Nations, like as he had done unto the Jews.

column7: But they shewed them selues againe so vnthankefull, that it constrained god to take awaye that same worde from them, as wee see in the eight chapiter of the prophet Amos, saying:
column8: But they showed them selves again so unthankful, that it constrained god to take away that same word from them, as we see in the eight chapter of the Prophet Amos, saying:

column7: Beholde the tyme commeth, sayeth the lorde god,
column8: Behold the time comes, Saith the lord god,

column7: <NOTE> that I shall sende an hunger into the earthe, not the hunger of breade, neither the thruste of water, but an hunger to heare the worde of the lorde.
column8: that I shall send an hunger into the earth, not the hunger of bread, neither the thrust of water, but an hunger to hear the word of the lord.

column7: And the truthe of suche a prophecy dothe god sometyme fulfyl, as in fewe yeares after it did chaunce, when the Iewes were brought into Assiria. &c.
column8: And the truth of such a prophecy doth god sometime fulfil, as in few Years After it did chance, when the Jews were brought into Assyria. etc.

column7: And yet neuertheles yt is to bee thoughte a greate grace and benefite, that they were not depryued of the word of god.
column8: And yet nevertheless that is to be Thought a great grace and benefit, that they were not deprived of the word of god.

column7: For they had Moyses, Aaron, and so manye prophetes besydes, as Saynte Iohn baptiste,
column8: For they had Moses, Aaron, and so many Prophets besides, as Faint John baptist,

column7: Christe himselfe and the Apostels, that Christe myghte well reherse vnto theym:
column8: Christ himself and thee Apostles, that Christ might well rehearse unto them:

column7: I sende vnto you Prophetes, wyse men, and scribes. &c.
column8: I send unto you prophets, wise men, and Scribes. etc.

column7: Secondarilye, he reproueth theim of theyr crueltye, whiche they vsed agaynste the Prophetes and other that were sente vnto theim, receiuinge theym with no reuerence, but moste abhominably dyd handle theim.
column8: Secondarily, he Reproveth them of their cruelty, which they used against the prophets and other that were sent unto them, receiving them with no Reverence, but most abominably did handle them.

column7: And where they hadde beene woorthye of greate rewardes, they contrary wise, kylled theym. <NOTE> Some of them (sayth he) shal you kyll and crucifye, and some of them shal you scourg in your sinagoges, and persecute theim frome citye to citye.
column8: And where they had been worthy of great rewards, they contrary wise, killed them. some of them (say he) shall you kill and crucify, and Some of them shall you scourg in your Synagogues, and persecute them from City to City.

column7: &c. This was a greate blyndenes that the Iewes slewe all the Prophetes, and would not suffre none to liue that spoke against their false worshippyng of God, whiche they contrary to the worde of God, had inueted of their owne braynes.
column8: etc. This was a great blindness that the Jews slew all the prophets, and would not suffer none to live that spoke against their false worshipping of God, which they contrary to the word of God, had inueted of their own brains.

column7: And in this blyndnes and maliciousnes they abode and remayned styll in Christes tyme, and long after, and would in no wyse suffre any thyng that should learne theim to amende their blyndnes.
column8: And in this blindness and maliciousness they Abided and remained still in Christ's time, and long After, and would in no wise suffer any thing that should Learn them to amend their blindness.

column7: But so it is wont to go with theim that wyll not harken vnto the worde of God, but abuse the same.
column8: But so it is wont to go with them that will not harken unto the word of God, but abuse the same.

column7: Wherfore worthily happeneth vnto them the saiyng of Esaias:
column8: Wherefore worthily Happeneth unto them the saying of Isaiah:

column7: <NOTE> Blynde the heart of this people &c.
column8: Blind the heart of this people etc.

column7: Surely they can not blame Christ, seyng that the waye of trueth was so diligently taught vnto them, before his commyng.
column8: Surely they can not blame christ, sing that the Way of truth was so diligently taught unto them, before his coming.

column7: Fyrst through the Prophetes other ministers of his worde, and in his tyme by Christ himselfe, and after Christes ascencion, by the Apostles and other mo, so that they can laye no blame to no man, nor can in no wyse excuse them selues.
column8: Fyrst through the prophets other Ministers of his word, and in his time by christ himself, and After Christ's Ascension, by the Apostles and other more, so that they can say no blame to no man, nor can in no wise excuse them selves.

column7: Dyd not Christe geue theim sufficient warnyng in this present Gospell, where he sayeth:
column8: Did not Christ give them sufficient warning in this present Gospel, where he Saith:

column7: Ierusalem, Ierusalem, Thou that slayest the Prophetes and stonest theim that are sent vnto thee,
column8: Jerusalem, Jerusalem, Thou that slayest the prophets and Stonest them that Are sent unto thee,

column7: Howe ofte would I haue gathered thy children together, euen as the Henne gathereth her chickyns vnder her wynges, and ye would not?
column8: How oft would I have gathered thy children together, even as the Hen gathereth her chickyns under her wings, and you would not?

column7: &c. He that had leasure or time to declare the worthines of this similitude, and in what wyse the Henne is affeccioned toward her chickyns, and in what wyse she retayneth theim, and getteth theim their foode, and with what desire and feruentnesse she fighteth for their safegarde, and in howe many thynges she dissembleth and suffereth theim paciently:
column8: etc. He that had leisure or time to declare the worthiness of this similitude, and in what wise the Hen is affectioned towards her chickyns, and in what wise she retaineth them, and gets them their food, and with what desire and ferventness she fights for their safeguard, and in how many things she dissembleth and suffers them patiently:

column7: fynally, in what wise she kepeth and defendeth them vnder her winges, whiche all aptely may be apropriated vnto Christe, whiche for our sakes dyd and suffered so many thinges, withoute doubte yt shoulde bee euident vnto all men, ye the Iews them selues were the very cause & occasion of their blindnes & damnacion,
column8: finally, in what wise she Keepeth and defendeth them under her wings, which all aptly may be appropriated unto Christ, which for our sakes did and suffered so many things, without doubt that should be evident unto all men, you the jews them selves were the very cause & occasion of their blindness & damnation,

column7: As the prophet Oseas witnesseth, saying:
column8: As the Prophet Hosea Witnesseth, saying:

column7: <NOTE> O Israell, thy iniquitie hathe destroyed the:
column8: Oh Israel, thy iniquity hath destroyed thee:

column7: But in me only is thy healpe.
column8: But in me only is thy help.

column7: To whom of the prophets haue they obeyed?
column8: To whom of the Prophets have they obeyed?

column7: Or whiche of theim haue they not persecuted?
column8: Or which of them have they not persecuted?

column7: What trouble and busynes suffered Moyses amonge theim?
column8: What trouble and business suffered Moses among them?

column7: Yea how shamefully thei behaued theim selues against Christe, and how did they handle him?
column8: Yea how shamefully they behaved them selves against Christ, and how did they handle him?

column7: Which of the Apostels were euer safe and suer amongest theim?
column8: Which of the Apostles were ever safe and sure amongst them?

column7: Did they not stone to deathe that blessed Saint Steuen the holy martyre of god?
column8: Did they not stone to death that blessed Saint Stephen the holy martyr of god?

column7: Out of their dooinges it is manifest,
column8: Out of their doings it is manifest,

column7: <NOTE> that there was nothinge more pleasaunter to the Iewes, than to stone, crucifye, to obtruncat, scourg, and persecute with most greuous ponishments, the blessed saintes of Christ.
column8: that there was nothing more pleasanter to the Jews, than to stone, crucify, to obtruncat, scourg, and persecute with most grievous ponishments, the blessed Saints of christ.

column7: But to hear the holy word of god, to knowledg that most ioyfull tyme of their Messias, there were very few of them so to do.
column8: But to hear the holy word of god, to knowledge that most joyful time of their Messias, there were very few of them so to do.

column7: Yea and thoughe we were ignoraunt with howe greate crueltye they intreated all those that were sente to them from god, yet might a man sufficiently learn it in the only story of Steuen, which is writen in ye seuenth chapiter of the actes of the Apostles. <NOTE> Thirdely, <NOTE> Christe declareth the ponishement that shuld happen vnto the Iews for their ingratitude which shuld not only be a corporal ponishment, but also a spirituall ponishmente.
column8: Yea and though we were ignorant with how great cruelty they entreated all those that were sent to them from god, yet might a man sufficiently Learn it in the only story of Stephen, which is written in you Seventh chapter of the acts of the Apostles. Thirdly, Christ Declareth the ponishement that should happen unto the jews for their ingratitude which should not only be a corporal ponishment, but also a spiritual ponishmente.

column7: Fyrste shall come vppon theim all the righteous bloud that was shedde vpon the earth, from the bloud of righteous Abell, vnto the bloude of Zacharye the sonne of Barachias, <NOTE> whome they slewe betwene the temple and the altare.
column8: First shall come upon them all the righteous blood that was shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel, unto the blood of Zacharye the son of Barachiah, whom they slew between the temple and the altar.

column7: O what an horrible and a greuous punishment shuld this be?
column8: O what an horrible and a grievous punishment should this be?

column7: For god will no more suffre vnpunished this effusion of bloud, then he will suffre vnpunished the effusion of the Precious bloud of his only sonne, as the scripture witnesseth, saying:
column8: For god will no more suffer unpunished this effusion of blood, then he will suffer unpunished the effusion of the Precious blood of his only son, as the scripture Witnesseth, saying:

column7: <NOTE> He that toucheth you, shall touche the apple of his owne eye.
column8: He that touches you, shall touch the apple of his own eye.

column7: And againe in an other place:
column8: And again in an other place:

column7: Verely I saye vnto you,
column8: Verily I say unto you,

column7: <NOTE> whatsoeuer you do to one of the leaste that beleue in me, that same do you to me O you tyrantes why doth not these sayings touche you and moue you?
column8: whatsoever you do to one of the jest that believe in me, that same do you to me Oh you Tyrants why does not these sayings touch you and move you?

column7: Why doth not the greate ponishment of the sowle withdrawn you frome your greate curelnes, that you myght be afraid to committe any more suche vnworthye actes against the wordes of god?
column8: Why does not the great ponishment of the soul withdrawn you from your great curelnes, that you might be afraid to commit any more such unworthy acts against the words of god?

column7: Do you not heare that the bloude of those, whiche you do kyll for the worde of god, shal not allonly come vpon you, but also all the bloude that hathe beene shedde vppon the earth, from the bloud of righteous Abell vnto this day?
column8: Do you not hear that the blood of those, which you do kill for the word of god, shall not allonly come upon you, but also all the blood that hath been shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel unto this day?

column7: Yee wyll not beeleue these thinges, but daylye go aboute to mayntaine your wanto and abhominable minde But synce it is so, that you wyll doo none other, take your pleasure.
column8: Ye will not beeleue these things, but daily go about to maintain your wanto and abominable mind But since it is so, that you will do none other, take your pleasure.

column7: For wee truely shall abide pacientlye (by the grace of God) that tyme, in the whiche wee shall resiste you, and all the aduersaries of the worde of god openly, with greate truste and constancye.
column8: For we truly shall abide patiently (by the grace of God) that time, in the which we shall resist you, and all the Adversaries of the word of god openly, with great trust and constancy.

column7: For doubte you not but that daye of vengeaunce shall come. Sapient. 5.
column8: For doubt you not but that day of vengeance shall come. Sapient. 5.

column7: Besides thys, you shall be punished with corporall ponishment for your ingratitude and vnthankfulnes,
column8: Beside this, you shall be punished with corporal ponishment for your ingratitude and unthankfulness,

column7: For thus saith the lorde:
column8: For thus Says the lord:

column7: Behold your habitacion shall bee lefte vnto you desolate.
column8: Behold your habitation shall be left unto you desolate.

column7: And in an other place, he saithe:
column8: And in an other place, he Saith:

column7: <NOTE> There shall not bee lefte one stone vpon an other.
column8: There shall not be left one stone upon an other.

column7: These bee those thinges that Christe gaue the Iewes warnyng of, which shuld happen vpon them, and partely he tolde it by similitudes, and partlye without anye similitude.
column8: These be those things that Christ gave the Jews warning of, which should happen upon them, and partly he told it by Similitudes, and partly without any similitude.

column7: But what preuailed it to them?
column8: But what prevailed it to them?

column7: Dyd they either repent them or amend theim?
column8: Did they either Repent them or amend them?

column7: No snerly. And Christe also after his ascention lefte theim his blessed apostels, giuing theim fourtye yeares space to repent theim, and yet all wold not help, nor cause them to forsake their mischeuous incredulitie & pertinacy, but as S.
column8: No snerly. And Christ also After his Ascension left them his blessed Apostles, giving them fourtye Years Molle to Repent them, and yet all would not help, nor cause them to forsake their mischievous incredulity & pertinacy, but as S.

column7: Paule sayeth: <NOTE> They heaped them selfe a treasure of wrath, against the day of wrath.
column8: Paul Saith: They heaped them self a treasure of wrath, against the day of wrath.

column7: &c. Wherefore it is come to passe, that the iudgemente of god, his wrath & indignacion is come vpon them, which is euidente to the whole worlde.
column8: etc. Wherefore it is come to pass, that the judgement of god, his wrath & Indignation is come upon them, which is evident to the Whole world.

column7: And they whiche afore tyme wolde not heare Christe and his Apostels, in the name of god, afterward were constrained to heare the Romaines in the dyuels name.
column8: And they which afore time would not hear Christ and his Apostles, in the name of god, afterwards were constrained to hear the Romans in the Devils name.

column7: I praye god the father,
column8: I pray god the father,

column7: <NOTE> that wee be not ones constrained to learne, what a thynge it is, so manyfestly to dispise, forbidde and driue awaye by forse goddes worde, and in no wise to giue place to the truthe.
column8: that we be not ones constrained to Learn, what a thing it is, so manifestly to despise, forbid and driven away by force God's word, and in no wise to give place to the truth.

column7: The word of god shineth so clere amongst vs, ye yt ca not be denied, but be confessed to be the very trew worde.
column8: The word of god shines so clear among us, you that circa not be denied, but be confessed to be the very true word.

column7: And on the other syde, our ingratitude and maliciousnes is so great, that it is not vnknowen.
column8: And on the other side, our ingratitude and maliciousness is so great, that it is not unknown.

column7: Wherfore I thynke that suche punishment as pleaseth God shall folowe, yet I knowe not what God purposeth to do, but I knowe what I am bound to feare, and to be afrayde of.
column8: Wherefore I think that such punishment as Pleases God shall follow, yet I know not what God Purposes to do, but I know what I am bound to Fear, and to be afraid of.

column7: Neuerthelesse, lette vs aske for grace, and he of his goodnes shall turne his wrath from vs.
column8: Nevertheless, let us ask for grace, and he of his Goodness shall turn his wrath from us

column8: Amen. The Gospel on saint John his day the and Apostle Evangelist. John 21.

column8: JESUS said unto Peter:

column8: Follow me. Peter turned him about and saw the disciple whom jesus loved, following (which also leaned on his breast At supper and said:

column7: Lorde, which is he that betrayeth thee?
column8: Lord, which is he that betrayeth thee?

column7: ) When Peter therfore sawe him, he sayth to Iesus:
column8: ) When Peter Therefore saw him, he say to jesus:

column7: Lorde, what shall he here do?
column8: Lord, what shall he Here do?

column7: Iesus sayeth vnto him: If I wyll haue him to tarye tyll I come, what is that to thee?
column8: jesus Saith unto him: If I will have him to tarry till I come, what is that to thee?

column7: folowe thou me. Then went this saiyng abrode among the brethren, that ye disciple should not dye. yet Iesus sayd not to him, he shall not dye, but if I wyll that he tary tyll I come, what is that to thee?
column8: follow thou me. Then went this saying abroad among the brothers, that you disciple should not die. yet jesus said not to him, he shall not die, but if I will that he tarry till I come, what is that to thee?

column7: The same disciple is he, whiche testifyed of these thynges, and wrote these thynges.
column8: The same disciple is he, which testified of these things, and wrote these things.

column7: And we knowe that his testimony true. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: And we know that his testimony true. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN the last chapiter of the Gospel of sainct Ihon,
column8: IN the last chapter of the Gospel of saint John,

column7: Christ demaudeth thre tymes of Peter if that he loued him At the whiche demaunde Peter answered thre tymes, and sayd that he loued him.
column8: christ demaudeth Three times of Peter if that he loved him At the which demand Peter answered Three times, and said that he loved him.

column7: And because that Peter should not lacke an occasion to declare his loue,
column8: And Because that Peter should not lack an occasion to declare his love,

column7: & to proue it in dede,
column8: & to prove it in deed,

column7: Christ goeth to and declareth vnto him wherwith he might gratifie and serue him, namely, if he loued him, he shuld feade his shepe. <NOTE> To feade is as muche to say as to teache and preache.
column8: christ Goes to and Declareth unto him wherewith he might gratify and serve him, namely, if he loved him, he should feade his sheep. To feade is as much to say as to teach and preach.

column7: And so taketh it Dauid, when he sayth:
column8: And so Takes it David, when he say:

column7: The Lorde is my shepeherd,
column8: The Lord is my shepherd,

column7: I can want nothyng. He feadeth me in a grene pasture,
column8: I can want nothing. He feadeth me in a green pasture,

column7: & ledeth me to a freshe water.
column8: & leadeth me to a fresh water.

column7: He calleth the shepe, <NOTE> his electe christians, as he sayeth in the.x. chapiter of Ihon:
column8: He calls the sheep, his elect Christians, as he Saith in the x chapter of John:

column7: My shepe heareth my voyce.
column8: My sheep hears my voice.

column7: And in the Gospell of Mathew Christe sayeth:
column8: And in the Gospel of Matthew Christ Saith:

column7: <NOTE> Beholde I send you as shepe in the myddes of Wolfes.
column8: Behold I send you as sheep in the mids of Wolves.

column7: As though Christ would say vnto Peter:
column8: As though christ would say unto Peter:

column7: My Peter, I haue bought my shepe, that is my christians, dearly, wt an vnestimable price, wherfore I would not see any of them neither neglected nor yet lost.
column8: My Peter, I have bought my sheep, that is my Christians, dearly, with an unestimable price, Wherefore I would not see any of them neither neglected nor yet lost.

column7: Therfore if yu louest me, as thou hast spoken, thou shalt vnderstad, that there can be nothing more acceptable vnto me, then that my sheepe haue good feadyng:
column8: Therefore if thou love me, as thou hast spoken, thou shalt Understand, that there can be nothing more acceptable unto me, then that my sheep have good feadyng:

column7: That is, that they be diligently taught & instructed in the worde of God.
column8: That is, that they be diligently taught & instructed in the word of God.

column7: <NOTE> And if thou wilt know who thou shouldest folowe in this office of preachyng, herken to this saiyng:
column8: And if thou wilt know who thou Shouldst follow in this office of preaching, harken to this saying:

column7: Folow me. For thou knowest and hast sene in what wyse I haue behaued my selfe herein &c.
column8: Follow me. For thou Knowest and hast seen in what wise I have behaved my self herein etc.

column7: Nowe that in this place Peter is commaunded to folowe Christ,
column8: Now that in this place Peter is commanded to follow christ,

column7: I thynke that the same commaundement and precept partayneth not onely vnto Peter but generally vnto all christian menne.
column8: I think that the same Commandment and precept partayneth not only unto Peter but generally unto all christian men.

column7: For synce we be named christians,
column8: For since we be nam Christians,

column7: & take our name of Christ, who should we folowe but Christ?
column8: & take our name of christ, who should we follow but christ?

column7: who sayth here: Folowe me?
column8: who say Here: Follow me?

column7: But there hath been in the world, and is yet vnto this hour, diuers & sondry ways prescribed vs to folow,
column8: But there hath been in the world, and is yet unto this hour, diverse & sundry ways prescribed us to follow,

column7: For this foloweth S. Francys, the other S.
column8: For this Followeth S. Francis, the other S.

column7: Benedict, the third S. Dominick, the fowerth foloweth S.
column8: Benedict, the third S. Dominick, the fowerth Followeth S.

column7: Bruno, as a moste suer rule of his lyuing.
column8: Bruno, as a most sure Rule of his living.

column7: And as touching this thing, there hath been amongst christen men, so variable & sondry opinions & ways to folow, that who so euer wil note the wel, it can not be, but he must needs be sore greued in his hart at them, in so muche that they be all fained & made repugnaunt to the manifest word of Christ.
column8: And as touching this thing, there hath been among christian men, so variable & sundry opinions & ways to follow, that who so ever will note the well, it can not be, but he must needs be soar grieved in his heart At them, in so much that they be all feigned & made repugnant to the manifest word of christ.

column7: For who of ye fathers can be found, yt dare avow & say of the selues:
column8: For who of you Father's can be found, that Dare avow & say of the selves:

column7: He that foloweth me in my rule, walketh not in darknes.
column8: He that Followeth me in my Rule, walks not in darkness.

column7: Though in need yt is not euel if we folow our fathers,
column8: Though in need that is not evil if we follow our Father's,

column7: Paul describeth it sayig: Be ye my folowers (wher he doth adde) as I folow Christ.
column8: Paul Describeth it sayig: Be you my followers (where he does add) as I follow christ.

column7: Wherfore yt is needful, yt this comaudemet of Christ shuld moue & stere vs,
column8: Wherefore that is needful, that this comaudemet of christ should move & steer us,

column7: & not to thik that it was geue only to Peter, but also vnto al christen me, nameli vnto those, that glorify theselues of Christ, therfore shuld thei lykewise folow hi, of who thei bear ye name.
column8: & not to thick that it was give only to Peter, but also unto all christen me, nameli unto those, that Glorify themselves of christ, Therefore should they likewise follow him, of who they bear you name.

column7: For it is Christ oly yt dare auowe and sai:
column8: For it is christ oly that Dare avow and sai:

column7: <NOTE> He yt foloweth me, walketh not in darknes.
column8: He that Followeth me, walks not in darkness.

column7: Secodarily, forasmuch as we haue heard & learned, yt ther is no suerer thig in this life, the to folow Christ, therfore it is necessary, that we learne how & in what maner of wise it is needful yt we folow him. that is, yt euery ma must folow Christ in his callig.
column8: Secondarily, forasmuch as we have herd & learned, that there is no Surer thig in this life, the to follow christ, Therefore it is necessary, that we Learn how & in what manner of wise it is needful that we follow him. that is, that every ma must follow christ in his callig.

column7: For this preset gospell teacheth vs that in Peter, yt whe he heard Christ say:
column8: For this preset gospel Teaches us that in Peter, that when he herd christ say:

column7: Folow me. he tourned him selfe aboute, and sawe the disciple whome Christe loued, and sayd vnto Iesus:
column8: Follow me. he turned him self about, and saw the disciple whom Christ loved, and said unto jesus:

column7: Lorde, but what shall he do?
column8: Lord, but what shall he do?

column7: Peter had a commaundement of Christ to folowe him, and that in his callyng, whiche was before declared vnto him,
column8: Peter had a Commandment of christ to follow him, and that in his calling, which was before declared unto him,

column7: <NOTE> namely in feadyng Christ his shepe.
column8: namely in feadyng christ his sheep.

column7: And forbecause he had so sone forgotte it, lookyng to another, he is here reproued of Christe with these woordes:
column8: And forbecause he had so soon forgotten it, looking to Another, he is Here reproved of Christ with these words:

column7: what is that to the?
column8: what is that to thee?

column7: And agayne he heareth, Folowe thou me.
column8: And again he hears, Follow thou me.

column7: But this was not only done for Peter, but for vs also, that wee should not charge our selues with other cares & busynes, but with good aduisement & counsail beyng diligent in our owne busynesses, should endeuor our selfe to do faithfully & with a christia mynde that thing, whervnto wee are called.
column8: But this was not only done for Peter, but for us also, that we should not charge our selves with other Cares & business, but with good advisement & counsel being diligent in our own businesses, should endeavour our self to do faithfully & with a christian mind that thing, whereunto we Are called.

column7: For truely, if euery man in his degre would diligently endeuor them selfes, to do yt thyng whervnto they are ordained & called of God, and not to set so litle by it as they do, wtout doubt, or should fynd him selfe so charged, that he should sone forget to remembre what other men had to do.
column8: For truly, if every man in his degree would diligently endeavour them selves, to do that thing whereunto they Are ordained & called of God, and not to Set so little by it as they do, without doubt, or should find him self so charged, that he should soon forget to Remember what other men had to do.

column7: And take an example: <NOTE> If I am called to the office of preachyng, to be a minister of the worde of God, so is it very necessarye, that I do the same with all diligence, in preachyng, readyng, rebukyng comfortyng, and prouidyng for the poore &c.
column8: And take an Exampl: If I am called to the office of preaching, to be a minister of the word of God, so is it very necessary, that I do the same with all diligence, in preaching, reading, rebuking comforting, and providing for the poor etc.

column7: Furthermore it is necessarye, that I behaue my selfe in all thynges appertainyng to that office, that men may perceiue, that I seke none other thyng, but the honour of God, and vtilitee of the congregacion.
column8: Furthermore it is necessary, that I behave my self in all things aPPERTAINING to that office, that men may perceive, that I seek none other thing, but the honour of God, and utility of the congregation.

column7: Then if I wyll diligently & studiously fulfyll this office as here is a comaundement geuen to Peter, and as sainct Paule in his Epistles gloryeth that he hath done, <NOTE> doubtles I shall haue so muche to do in myne owne office, that I shall not nede to medle with other mens offices & duties, nor take theim vpon me, but euer be studious with all my strength to do according to mine owne callyng.
column8: Then if I will diligently & studiously fulfil this office as Here is a Commandment given to Peter, and as saint Paul in his Epistles Glorieth that he hath done, doubtless I shall have so much to do in mine own office, that I shall not need to meddle with other men's Offices & duties, nor take them upon me, but ever be studious with all my strength to do according to mine own calling.

column7: In like maner, <NOTE> if I were chosen to the office of the magistrate, and had receiued of god the power of the sweard, to defend the good and vertuous, and to punish the euell and transgressours, and in that office did aply my selfe with all diligence to doo, as it becommeth me before god to doo in that office, surely I shulde not haue leasure in mine office, to beholde what other men doo, but it shuld be necessarye for me with diligence to endeuour my selfe to be found faithful in mine owne callynge.
column8: In like manner, if I were chosen to the office of the magistrate, and had received of god the power of the sword, to defend the good and virtuous, and to Punish the evil and transgressors, and in that office did aply my self with all diligence to do, as it becomes me before god to do in that office, surely I should not have leisure in mine office, to behold what other men do, but it should be necessary for me with diligence to endeavour my self to be found faithful in mine own calling.

column7: The lyke manner it is in the office of a good and dylygente father of the housholde or mother of an housholde, seruaunte or handemayde, that euerye one doo well remembre their owne duetye, and faithfullye serue and dooe in their vocation, neuer takynge one the others offyce vppon hym, seeynge that it ys an vniuste and a sinnefull thynge to see the matter come to this poynte, that the seruaunte shoulde take vppon hym the maisters parte, or the maister the seruauntes.
column8: The like manner it is in the office of a good and dylygente father of the household or mother of an household, servant or handemayde, that every one do well Remember their own duty, and faithfully serve and do in their vocation, never taking one the Others office upon him, seeing that it is an unjust and a sinful thing to see the matter come to this point, that the servant should take upon him the masters part, or the master the Servants.

column7: And therefore Saynt Paule saithe:
column8: And Therefore Saint Paul Saith:

column7: <NOTE> Lette euerye manne continue in that same callynge that hee is called vnto.
column8: Let every man continue in that same calling that he is called unto.

column7: And heere note, that wee speake of that vocation that God calleth vs vnto.
column8: And Here note, that we speak of that vocation that God calls us unto.

column7: Neither are the fayned religious menne of oure tyme to be heard, if at this texte they seeke a defence for their erroure, and saye:
column8: Neither Are the feigned religious men of our time to be herd, if At this text they seek a defence for their error, and say:

column7: Thou are called vnto a Monasticall lyfe, therefore needes muste thou contynue in the Monestarye, and lyue a religious lyfe.
column8: Thou Are called unto a Monastical life, Therefore needs must thou continue in the Monastery, and live a religious life.

column7: And the cause why they are not to be heard, is this.
column8: And the cause why they Are not to be herd, is this.

column7: God called theym not to that lyuing, but men:
column8: God called them not to that living, but men:

column7: that is, they were brought vnto it by the tradycion of dyuels.
column8: that is, they were brought unto it by the tradycion of Devils.

column7: Thirdely, <NOTE> in this gospell is comended and highly praysed the auctoritee and office of the Apostels, especially against those that saye:
column8: Thirdly, in this gospel is commended and highly praised the Authority and office of the Apostles, especially against those that say:

column7: If mannes doctrine is not to bee receiued, no more is the Apostels doctrine, for they were menne also.
column8: If Man's Doctrine is not to be received, no more is the Apostles Doctrine, for they were men also.

column7: But who euer taught the, or of whom euer haste thou heard that it is not couenient to heare those men, that teache the truthe and word of god?
column8: But who ever taught thee, or of whom ever haste thou herd that it is not convenient to hear those men, that teach the truth and word of god?

column7: In this point it is necessary that men vnderstand well.
column8: In this point it is necessary that men understand well.

column7: For when we say that the doctrines & tradicions of men are nothing worth in the mattiers of iustificacion and faith, we speake nothing of the worde of god whiche is preached by men, but suche doctrine as men haue ymagined against the worde of god.
column8: For when we say that the doctrines & traditions of men Are nothing worth in the mattiers of justification and faith, we speak nothing of the word of god which is preached by men, but such Doctrine as men have imagined against the word of god.

column7: And suerly if oure aduersaries wold in this matter shew and behaue theim selues as the Apostles did, wee wolde righte gladly receiue them, nothing considering that they are but me.
column8: And surely if our Adversaries would in this matter show and behave them selves as the Apostles did, we would right gladly receive them, nothing considering that they Are but me.

column7: And if ye will knowe what the Apostels did, herken what is written in this gospell of Iohn the Euangelist, for we wil not now speake of the other Apostels.
column8: And if you will know what the Apostles did, harken what is written in this gospel of John the Evangelist, for we will not now speak of the other Apostles.

column8: For John Says in this place:

column8: Of the truth doubtless & that he wrote no lie.

column7: Now seing he hath written the truth, why shuld I not beleue him?
column8: Now sing he hath written the truth, why should I not believe him?

column8: Truly I can not denay, but I ought to receive a Prophet in the name of a Prophet. and on the other part,

column8: I am bound to forsake him that comes not in the name of a Prophet, that is, he that speaks not the word of god and the truth.

column7: Wherefore if we will that men shall receiue and heare vs, go to then, let vs speak and preache the truth of the worde of god,
column8: Wherefore if we will that men shall receive and hear us, go to then, let us speak and preach the truth of the word of god,

column8: & bring not dross for silver,

column8: but Set it forth puerly,

column8: & led not you people into a confidence of their own works, but bring them unto christ.

column8: Let us follow the Apostles in the office of preaching, especially S.

column8: John in this gospel, which justly may glory, that he preached you truth, and so shall you people on the other part Remember their duty towards us again.

column8: Behold Behold, an angel of the Lord appeared in sleep to Joseph in Egypt, saying:

column8: Arise and take the child and his mother, and go into the land of Israel.

column8: For they Are dead which sought the child's life.

column8: And he arose, and took the child and his mother, and Come into the land of Israel.

column7: But when he heard, that Archelaus dyd raigne in Iewry, in the roume of his father Herode, he was afraide to go thy ther.
column8: But when he herd, that Archelaus did Reign in Jewry, in the room of his father Herod, he was afraid to go thy ther.

column7: Notwithstandyng, after he was warned of God in sleepe, he tourned aside into the partyes of Galile, and went and dwelt in a citye whiche is called Nazareth, that it might be fulfylled whiche was spoken by the Prophetes:
column8: Notwithstanding, After he was warned of God in sleep, he turned aside into the parties of Galilee, and went and dwelled in a City which is called Nazareth, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophets:

column7: <NOTE> He shall bee called a Nazarite. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: He shall be called a Nazarite. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T His gospel deare christians, is replenished and ful of many godly doctrines and helthsom lessons.
column8: THis THis gospel deer Christians, is replenished and full of many godly doctrines and helthsom Lessons.

column7: Therfore wee ought to wyshe & desire with heartie prayer, that God of his great mercye would vouchesafe to lighten our myndes, that we may receiue, gather, and print in oure heartes suche thynges, as in it are profitable and necessary for our instruction.
column8: Therefore we ought to wish & desire with hearty prayer, that God of his great mercy would vouchsafe to lighten our minds, that we may receive, gather, and print in our hearts such things, as in it Are profitable and necessary for our instruction.

column7: And first the Euangelist describeth in this place howe Mary,
column8: And First the Evangelist Describeth in this place how Marry,

column7: Ioseph & the childe fled into Egypte:
column8: Joseph & the child fled into Egypt:

column7: <NOTE> Which doubtles was a great sorowe to Mary and Ioseph:
column8: Which doubtless was a great sorrow to Marry and Joseph:

column7: yea suche a crosse, as day and night turmented them.
column8: yea such a cross, as day and night tormented them.

column7: Thynke you this did not right sore vexe theim, seyng that they had heard before that this childe should, as a most mightye kyng, reigne in the house of Iacob eternally, and nowe they are constrained to flee with him into Egipt, and (as banished persones) there to liue in all miserye?
column8: Think you this did not right soar vex them, sing that they had herd before that this child should, as a most mighty King, Reign in the house of Jacob eternally, and now they Are constrained to flee with him into Egypt, and (as banished Persons) there to live in all misery?

column7: But in this God would declare, that the kyngdome of his beloued sonne is not of this worlde, and that he must entre into his glorye and kyngdome through many persecutions, and muche trouble.
column8: But in this God would declare, that the Kingdom of his Beloved son is not of this world, and that he must enter into his glory and Kingdom through many persecutions, and much trouble.

column7: Yea, <NOTE> furthermore it declareth that all suche as depende vpon him, and repose their whole hope in him, shall haue none other fortune in this worlde, then Christ him selfe had.
column8: Yea, furthermore it Declareth that all such as depend upon him, and repose their Whole hope in him, shall have none other fortune in this world, then christ him self had.

column7: And here note the profound iudgementes of God.
column8: And Here note the profound Judgments of God.

column7: Christ beyng the beloued sonne of the father, with Iosephe and his louyng mother Mary, must needes flee and geue place to Herode, a most wretched caytife and cruel tyrant:
column8: christ being the Beloved son of the father, with Joseph and his loving mother Marry, must needs flee and give place to Herod, a most wretched caitiff and cruel tyrant:

column7: Where as yet God might (yea with one woorde of his mouth) haue destroyed him, and punished him accordyng to his demerites.
column8: Where as yet God might (yea with one word of his Mouth) have destroyed him, and punished him according to his demerits.

column7: Why was this done? Doubtlesse, forasmuche as Christ was geuen into this worlde to dye for vs, and to suffre al maner of euils, it was necessary that some profe of it shuld be now shewed in his childhod.
column8: Why was this done? Doubtless, forasmuch as christ was given into this world to die for us, and to suffer all manner of evils, it was necessary that Some proof of it should be now showed in his childhood.

column7: <NOTE> And furthermore, it was necessary to fulfyll the prophecie of Oseas saiynge.
column8: And furthermore, it was necessary to fulfil the prophecy of Hosea saying.

column7: Out of Egypte I haue called my sonne.
column8: Out of Egypt I have called my son.

column7: And also Herode himself (as yet) had not fulfilled the measure of his fury,
column8: And also Herod himself (as yet) had not fulfilled the measure of his fury,

column7: And needes must he dayly more & more heape the wrath and indignacion of God vpon him selfe.
column8: And needs must he daily more & more heap the wrath and Indignation of God upon him self.

column7: For wretchedly he lyued all his life, therefore he wretchedly dyed.
column8: For wretchedly he lived all his life, Therefore he wretchedly died.

column7: He cruelly executed the tyraunts parte, wherefore he had the rewarde of a tyraunt.
column8: He cruelly executed the Tyrants part, Wherefore he had the reward of a tyrant.

column7: And suche is the fortune of Christians, that theyr enemyes doo lyue a mooste pleasaunt lyfe and are exalted as hygh as the Cedre trees of ye high mountains of Lybane,
column8: And such is the fortune of Christians, that their enemies do live a most pleasant life and Are exalted as high as the Cedre trees of the high Mountains of Libanus,

column7: <NOTE> but the Christians ar oppressed & troden vnder foote, as you see here, yt it chaunced, to Christ himselfe, to Mary his blessed mother, and to Ioseph.
column8: but the Christians Are oppressed & trodden under foot, as you see Here, that it chanced, to christ himself, to Marry his blessed mother, and to Joseph.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarily, in this Gospell is declared, howe lyke a father, and howe mercyfully,
column8: Secondarily, in this Gospel is declared, how like a father, and how mercifully,

column7: God taketh vpon him the cure and charge to prouide for his beloued sonne Christ, and his parentes.
column8: God Takes upon him the cure and charge to provide for his Beloved son christ, and his Parents.

column7: And fyrst, lest they might fall into the handes of that mooste cruel tyraunt, he commaunded theim to flee into Egypte, and to tarry there vnto ye death of Herode.
column8: And fyrst, lest they might fallen into the hands of that most cruel tyrant, he commanded them to flee into Egypt, and to tarry there unto you death of Herod.

column7: And this doth he by a noble messanger. that is to saye, an angell.
column8: And this does he by a noble Messenger. that is to say, an angel.

column7: Besides this, where as Iesus parentes were poore folkes and had small comforte, either of kinnesmen, or of theyr neyghboures, yet god so looketh vnto theym, that the wyse men came frome the Easte countreies, bringinge theim gyftes, wherewith they might sustaine both themselues, and the babe, vntyll the tyrannous crueltye of Herode were ceased, and at an ende.
column8: Beside this, where as jesus Parents were poor folks and had small Comfort, either of kinsman, or of their neighbours, yet god so looks unto them, that the wise men Come from the East countries, bringing them Gifts, wherewith they might sustain both themselves, and the babe, until the tyrannous cruelty of Herod were ceased, and At an end.

column7: Nowe, althoughe god layde a very heauye crosse vppon Marye,
column8: Now, although god laid a very heavy cross upon Marye,

column7: Ioseph, and the babe Iesus, yet withdrewe he not frome them his fatherly mynde, but cherisshed theim with suche goodnesse and mercye, that althoughe they were in tribulacion, yet they perished not, but were fortunately delyuered, euen as god hathe promised vnto all christians, that suffre tribulacion for his woorde.
column8: Joseph, and the babe jesus, yet withdrew he not from them his fatherly mind, but cherished them with such Goodness and mercy, that although they were in tribulation, yet they perished not, but were fortunately Delivered, even as god hath promised unto all Christians, that suffer tribulation for his word.

column7: And althoughe god for a tyme withdrawe hys healpe, and appeareth that in verye deede hee hathe forsaken vs, yet at the laste wee shall euidentlye proue and playnely see, that in very deed no manne can bee more studiouslye carefull for vs, than the Lorde our God.
column8: And although god for a time withdraw his help, and appears that in very deed he hath forsaken us, yet At the laste we shall evidently prove and plainly see, that in very deed no man can be more studiously careful for us, than the Lord our God.

column7: In the meane time lette vs onlye studye to doo after the Prophete Dauids councell, to abide pacientelye the lorde,
column8: In the mean time let us only study to do After the Prophet David council, to abide pacientelye the lord,

column7: <NOTE> to doo his pleasure manfullye, that oure heartes maye bee comforted, and by hope lyfted vppe vnto hym, so that pacientlye wee abyde what aduersytye so euer chaunce vnto vs.
column8: to do his pleasure manfully, that our hearts may be comforted, and by hope lifted up unto him, so that patiently we abide what aduersytye so ever chance unto us

column7: Thys (I saye) if wee doo, it is impossible that we shulde be forsaken & left without comfort.
column8: This (I say) if we do, it is impossible that we should be forsaken & left without Comfort.

column7: And though men wolde not comfort vs, yet needs must it come to passe that God by his holy Angels shall comforte vs, as here you haue a noble example in Iosephe,
column8: And though men would not Comfort us, yet needs must it come to pass that God by his holy Angels shall Comfort us, as Here you have a noble Exampl in Joseph,

column7: Mary & the childe Iesu, whiche although for a tyme they gaue place to Herode, yet after Herodes death, they were againe called out of Egypt by the Angel.
column8: Marry & the child Jesu, which although for a time they gave place to Herod, yet After Herod death, they were again called out of Egypt by the Angel.

column7: Thyrdly the Euangelist describeth the crueltie and tyrany of Herode.
column8: Thirdly the Evangelist Describeth the cruelty and tyranny of Herod.

column7: For after that he had geuen commaundement vnto the Wysemen, that they should go and diligently searche for the childe, and when they had founde him to bryng worde to him, that he also might come & worship him, and do him reuerence, he now seyng that he was mocked of the Wysemen, was excedyng wroth, and sent & slewe al the children that were in Bethleem two yeres olde or vnder, according to the tyme that he had serched furth of the Wysemen.
column8: For After that he had given Commandment unto the Wise men, that they should go and diligently search for the child, and when they had found him to bring word to him, that he also might come & worship him, and do him Reverence, he now sing that he was mocked of the Wise men, was exceeding wroth, and sent & slew all the children that were in Bethlehem two Years old or under, according to the time that he had searched forth of the Wise men.

column8: For as touching such men, when they speak Fairest, then get they soonest and farthest of from them.

column7: For fyrst before them he pretended himselfe to be a simple person,
column8: For fyrst before them he pretended himself to be a simple person,
