column8: & a man with out guile or fraud, promising that he would honour and Reverence that new born child:

column7: euen as in our tyme some euell persones seeme to do, whiche can fashion theym selues to euery mannes company, and with fair & swete words wype symple mens mouthes so smoothly, that any man wolde thynke theyr myndes and wordes were all one, tyll at the laste, the poore and simple doo proue by experience that thei dissemble with theim,
column8: even as in our time Some evil Persons seem to do, which can fashion them selves to every Man's company, and with fair & sweet words wipe simple men's mouths so smoothly, that any man would think their minds and words were all one, till At the laste, the poor and simple do prove by experience that they dissemble with them,

column7: & intended nothing lesse the the godly wordes that they spake.
column8: & intended nothing less the the godly words that they spoke.

column7: But let vs speak of Herod, which before these wise men promiseth that he entendeth to bee vertuous & to worship this Christ, that shuld come in to ye world,
column8: But let us speak of Herod, which before these wise men promises that he entendeth to be virtuous & to worship this christ, that should come in to you world,

column7: But fulfilleth he this promise?
column8: But fulfilleth he this promise?

column7: Yea god wot: His prayer was so strong, that no mother in Bethlehem nor in al the coasts, might kepe her children a liue.
column8: Yea god wot: His prayer was so strong, that no mother in Bethlehem nor in all the coasts, might keep her children a live.

column7: For as many as were two yeare and vnder, were slain.
column8: For as many as were two year and under, were slave.

column7: Oh excellent prayer. Are there not thinke ye in our time yt wold worship Christ in like maner, yf they might therto be suffered & haue occasion?
column8: O excellent prayer. are there not think you in our time that would worship christ in like manner, if they might thereto be suffered & have occasion?

column7: Suerly it were yl done, to surmise any such thing of our hypocrites syth thei do daily hear so many sermons.
column8: Surely it were ill done, to surmise any such thing of our Hypocrites sith they do daily hear so many Sermons.

column7: Yet I fear me, if it shuld come to that point, that thei wold destroy & root vs out whom the world counteth heretiques (for flesh is flesh and so continueth) that many woulde be readye to do suche goddes seruice (as Christe calleth it in S.
column8: Yet I Fear me, if it should come to that point, that they would destroy & root us out whom the world counteth Heretics (for Flesh is Flesh and so Continueth) that many would be ready to do such God's service (as Christ calls it in S.

column7: Iohnes gospell) yea and ryght gladly proffer their seruice to do it.
column8: Johns gospel) yea and right gladly proffer their service to do it.

column7: And this I know that we (with the grace of god) shalbe readye not only to suffre all aduersitie for the gospels sake, but also to dye for it, be Herod and all his vngodly membres neuer so mad with it.
column8: And this I know that we (with the grace of god) shall ready not only to suffer all adversity for the gospels sake, but also to die for it, be Herod and all his ungodly members never so mad with it.

column7: Fourthelye, the Euangelist in this place recyteth the sayinge of Ieremy the Prophet which so many yeres before prophecied that miserable murderyng of the infantes,
column8: Fourthly, the Evangelist in this place reciteth the saying of Jeremiah the Prophet which so many Years before prophesied that miserable murdering of the Infants,

column7: <NOTE> whiche were slayne vnder that cruel tyrant Herode, and also the great lamentacion and weaping of those mothers for their childrent.
column8: which were slain under that cruel tyrant Herod, and also the great lamentation and weeping of those mother's for their childrent.

column7: And in this place fyrst is declared & praysed the trueth of all the prophecies,
column8: And in this place fyrst is declared & praised the truth of all the prophecies,

column7: <NOTE> that those thynges whiche they before spake of, must needes be accomplished and fulfylled, euen as Christ sayd:
column8: that those things which they before spoke of, must needs be accomplished and fulfilled, even as christ said:

column7: Heauen and yearth shal passe, but my worde shall not passe.
column8: Heaven and earth shall pass, but my word shall not pass.

column7: Furthermore here is an example to all ministers of the worde,
column8: Furthermore Here is an Exampl to all Ministers of the word,

column7: <NOTE> that with all diligencie they consider it and endeuour theim selues,
column8: that with all diligency they Consider it and endeavour them selves,

column7: <NOTE> that whatsoeuer they teache, preache, or otherwyse do in their office, that they do it vpo a good foundacion of the holy scriptures, so that they may euer be ready to answere to those, as are not sufficiently instructed in their doctrine or workes, or that vnderstand not their preachyng.
column8: that whatsoever they teach, preach, or otherwise do in their office, that they do it upon a good Foundation of the holy Scriptures, so that they may ever be ready to answer to those, as Are not sufficiently instructed in their Doctrine or works, or that understand not their preaching.

column7: For euen Christ him selfe in likewyse approued his doctrine out of the olde testament and the Prophetes, and that in many places.
column8: For even christ him self in likewise approved his Doctrine out of the old Testament and the prophets, and that in many places.

column7: And did not the Apostles in like maner?
column8: And did not the Apostles in like manner?

column7: Howe excellent an artificer dothe Paule shewe himselfe in recityng the textes of the olde Testament?
column8: Howe excellent an Artificer doth Paul show himself in reciting the texts of the old Testament?

column7: For whatsoeuer it be that is buylded vpon that sure foundacion of the holy scripture, be it doctrine, or worke begon or finished, it standeth sure and stedfast.
column8: For whatsoever it be that is builded upon that sure Foundation of the holy scripture, be it Doctrine, or work begun or finished, it Stands sure and steadfast.

column7: Contrary, whatsoeuer is not buylded vpon that foundacion, there is no remedy, it must nedes fall.
column8: Contrary, whatsoever is not builded upon that Foundation, there is no remedy, it must needs fallen.

column7: God through Christ geue vs the knowlege of of his holy worde.
column8: God through christ give us the knowledge of of his holy word.

column7: T Hen aunswered Peter, and sayde vnto hym.
column8: THen THen answered Peter, and said unto him.

column7: Beholde <NOTE> we haue forsaken all, and folowed the, what shall we haue therfore?
column8: Behold we have forsaken all, and followed thee, what shall we have Therefore?

column7: Iesus sayde vnto them: Verely I saye vnto you:
column8: jesus said unto them: Verily I say unto you:

column7: that when the sonne of man shall sytte in the seat of hys maiestye, ye that haue folowed me, in the regeneracio <NOTE> shal sit vpon twelue seates, and iudge the twelue trybes of Israel <NOTE> And euery one that forsaketh house, or brethren, or systers, or father, or mother, or wife, or childre, or lands for my names sake,
column8: that when the son of man shall fit in the seat of his majesty, you that have followed me, in the regeneracio shall fit upon twelue seats, and judge the twelue tribes of Israel And every one that Forsaketh house, or brothers, or Sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or Lands for my names sake,

column7: <NOTE> shall receiue an hundreth fold, and shal inheryte euerlastynge lyfe. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: shall receive an Hundredth fold, and shall inheryte everlasting life. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN the gospell of S. Mathewe ys made mentio of a certaine ruler, which did aske Christ what he shuld do, that he might inherite and haue euerlasting lyfe.
column8: IN the gospel of S. Matthew is made Mentio of a certain ruler, which did ask christ what he should do, that he might inherit and have everlasting life.

column7: Vnto whom Christ answered saying:
column8: Unto whom christ answered saying:

column7: If thou wylt entre into lyfe, keepe the commaundementes.
column8: If thou wilt enter into life, keep the Commandments.

column7: And forbicause he dyd aske lyke a iustifier that wolde be iustifed by his owne workes without fayth, therefore he receaueth suche an answere as concernyng workes.
column8: And For because he did ask like a justifier that would be iustifed by his own works without faith, Therefore he receiveth such an answer as Concerning works.

column7: This ioyly felow by and by boasteth and rufleth out (as the fashion of iustifiers alwayes is for to do) and proudely answered of his works which he had done, and sayth:
column8: This ioyly fellow by and by boasts and rufleth out (as the fashion of Justifiers always is for to do) and proudly answered of his works which he had done, and say:

column7: All these haue I kepte from my youth vp,
column8: All these have I kept from my youth up,

column7: What lacke I yet? <NOTE>
column8: What lack I yet?

column7: What shall we say or think of thys vaine and proude confidence?
column8: What shall we say or think of this vain and proud confidence?

column7: Peraduenture he shuld not haue had answered much amysse, yf the law had not been spiritual (as sainct Paule sayth) and had not required the affection of the heart and the inwarde man, and not only the outward apparance of workes,
column8: Peradventure he should not have had answered much amiss, if the law had not been spiritual (as saint Paul say) and had not required the affection of the heart and the inward man, and not only the outward appearance of works,

column7: <NOTE> wherin this iustifier was deceiued.
column8: wherein this justifier was deceived.

column7: Nowe for-because that he should learne to knowe his imperfection and hypocrisy,
column8: Now for-because that he should Learn to know his imperfection and hypocrisy,

column7: Christ sayth vnto him: One thyng ye wat.
column8: christ say unto him: One thing the wat.

column7: If thou wilt be perfect, go thy way & sel that yu hast, and geue it vnto the poore.
column8: If thou wilt be perfect, go thy Way & sell that thou hast, and give it unto the poor.

column7: Here was sodenly a wyndow opened into his heart, so that he might haue sene, vpo what a feble & weake foundacion & imperfect fayth he stode.
column8: Here was suddenly a window opened into his heart, so that he might have seen, upon what a feeble & weak Foundation & imperfect faith he stood.

column7: But what doth he? He goeth not about to do yt,
column8: But what does he? He Goes not about to do that,

column7: <NOTE> whiche Christ comaunded him, but left him,
column8: which christ commanded him, but left him,

column7: & goeth his wayes. Wherout it cometh well to passe whiche Christ sayth:
column8: & Goes his ways. Without it comes well to pass which christ say:

column7: O how hardly shal they that put their cofidence in ryches, come into ye kingdom of god?
column8: Oh how hardly shall they that put their confidence in riches, come into you Kingdom of god?

column7: It is easier (sayth he) for Camel to go thorowe the eye of a nedle, than for a riche ma to entre into the kyngdom of heauen &c.
column8: It is Easier (say he) for Camel to go thorough the eye of a needle, than for a rich ma to entre into the Kingdom of heaven etc.

column7: Whiche thynges when S. Peter had heard that it was no smal thing to leaue all & folowe Christ, and that he had already done it voluntarily & not compelled thervnto, he doth aske Christ, what shall become of him & thother Apostles.
column8: Which things when S. Peter had herd that it was no small thing to leave all & follow christ, and that he had already done it voluntarily & not compelled thereunto, he does ask christ, what shall become of him & tother Apostles.

column7: It canot be denied but that S.
column8: It canot be denied but that S.

column7: Peter with his brother Andrew, frely & voluntarily did leaue & forsoke al (although it was but litle) & folowed Christ.
column8: Peter with his brother Andrew, freely & voluntarily did leave & forsook all (although it was but little) & followed christ.

column7: And surely, if Peter had been so riche as euer was Cresus, yet when he had heard Christ speake in his hart this saiyng,
column8: And surely, if Peter had been so rich as ever was Croesus, yet when he had herd christ speak in his heart this saying,

column7: Folow me. <NOTE> he would haue left al & folowed him.
column8: Follow me. he would have left all & followed him.

column7: Neuerthelesse it was a carnal affectio in him, taking thought for his reward, before he had done his diligence, or before he had brought his worke to an end.
column8: Nevertheless it was a carnal affectio in him, taking Thought for his reward, before he had done his diligence, or before he had brought his work to an end.

column7: And as touchig this matter, it semeth that Peter was like vnto those workmen, which when thei were agreed for their wages, wet into ye vyneyard, but yet requireth a greater reward, then thei that came about ye ix. and xi. hour.
column8: And as touchig this matter, it Seemeth that Peter was like unto those workmen, which when they were agreed for their wages, wet into you Vineyard, but yet requires a greater reward, then they that Come about you ix. and xi. hour.

column7: For when did Abraha (I pray you) require any such thyng when he was commaunded of God to forsake his fathers house and folowe the Lorde into a strange lande?
column8: For when did Abraham (I pray you) require any such thing when he was commanded of God to forsake his Father's house and follow the Lord into a strange land?

column7: Therfore Peter is set furth in this place as an exaple of mans infirmitee which notwithstadyng, <NOTE> Christ (accordyng to his getle & fatherly affection) doth gladly beare & take in good part, eue as it often tymes chaused in ye Apostles, who Christ wt such lenitie & myldnes of mynd did so long beare withall, vntill at his tyme he did bryng the vnto perfection.
column8: Therefore Peter is Set forth in this place as an Exampl of men infirmity which notwithstanding, christ (according to his getle & fatherly affection) does gladly bear & take in good part, eve as it often times chased in you Apostles, who christ with such lenity & myldnes of mind did so long bear withal, until At his time he did bring thee unto perfection.

column7: Yea if that good & most bountiful Christ should reiect & cast away all them whiche were weake in ye fayth, what should become of vs I beseche you?
column8: Yea if that good & most bountiful christ should reject & cast away all them which were weak in you faith, what should become of us I beseech you?

column7: There is not one of vs whiche would not gladly take a reward, though he had not deserued the same by any maner of seruice.
column8: There is not one of us which would not gladly take a reward, though he had not deserved the same by any manner of service.

column7: Besides that, all wee with good wyll would raigne with Christ, though we haue neueer suffered any thyng with him or for him.
column8: Beside that, all we with good will would Reign with christ, though we have neueer suffered any thing with him or for him.

column7: But loke not, that that shal so come to passe, but thus it shalbe,
column8: But look not, that that shall so come to pass, but thus it shall,

column7: He that suffereth with me, shall also raigne with me.
column8: He that suffers with me, shall also Reign with me.

column7: Secodarily, though it be mete and couenient, yt we do our dutie & seruice vnto God of very loue of the heart, without any respect of reward (for the reward shal folowe of his owne accorde) yet notwithstandyng Christ sheweth vnto Peter & to the other Apostles, how he will intreate them, and what they shal at length receiue of him.
column8: Secondarily, though it be meet and convenient, that we do our duty & service unto God of very love of the heart, without any respect of reward (for the reward shall follow of his own accord) yet notwithstanding christ shows unto Peter & to the other Apostles, how he will entreat them, and what they shall At length receive of him.

column7: And this his promise he also confirmeth with an othe, saiyng:
column8: And this his promise he also confirmeth with an other, saying:

column7: Verely I say vnto you, that when the sonne of man shal sit in the seate of his Maiestie, ye whiche haue folowed me in the newe byrth, shall syt also vpon the twelue seates, and iudge the twelue tribes of Israel.
column8: Verily I say unto you, that when the son of man shall fit in the seat of his Majesty, you which have followed me in the new birth, shall fit also upon the twelue seats, and judge the twelue tribes of Israel.

column7: Heare howe large a promyse is made in this place vnto the Apostles.
column8: Hear how large a promise is made in this place unto the Apostles.

column7: For he wyll not onely conferre this benefite vnto theim, (although a greater can not be desired) that by him they shall be made good and righteous,
column8: For he will not only confer this benefit unto them, (although a greater can not be desired) that by him they shall be made good and righteous,

column7: <NOTE> and (if they perseuer vnto the ende in a true fayth) partakers also of euerlastyng life, by his only grace and mercy:
column8: and (if they persever unto the end in a true faith) partakers also of everlasting life, by his only grace and mercy:

column7: but also he wyll make them iudges, that in the newe byrthe, when we shal be receiued into euerlastyng health, they shall sitte nere vnto Christ.
column8: but also he will make them judges, that in the new birth, when we shall be received into everlasting health, they shall sit never unto christ.

column7: Of the whiche iudgement sainct Paule also speaketh:
column8: Of the which judgement saint Paul also speaks:

column7: <NOTE> Do ye not knowe (sayth he) that we shall iudge Angelles.
column8: Do you not know (say he) that we shall judge Angels.

column7: Albeit wee must not referre this iudgement to the last iudgement only, but it must also be vnderstanded of the laste iudgement of the spirit among christians in this life.
column8: Albeit we must not refer this judgement to the last judgement only, but it must also be understanded of the laste judgement of the Spirit among Christians in this life.

column7: For assone as by the worde wee receiue the holy ghost,
column8: For As soon as by the word we receive the holy ghost,

column7: & and are made the sons of God through fayth, the is this gyfte geuen vs also, that by the worde we may iudge al thynges, euen as sainct Paule wytnesseth in another place.
column8: & and Are made the Sons of God through faith, the is this gift given us also, that by the word we may judge all things, even as saint Paul Witnesseth in Another place.

column7: The spiiritual man iudgeth all thynges, <NOTE> and he is iudged of no man.
column8: The spiiritual man Judgeth all things, and he is judged of no man.

column7: And Christ also: Nowe is come the iudgement of this worlde, and the prince of this worlde shalbe thrust out.
column8: And christ also: Now is come the judgement of this world, and the Prince of this world shall thrust out.

column7: Are not the thynges, which are promised vnto the Apostles in this place, great and excellent?
column8: are not the things, which Are promised unto the Apostles in this place, great and excellent?

column7: And it is to be vnderstand that to leaue all thynges,
column8: And it is to be understand that to leave all things,

column7: & to folow Christ, must be done at the fyrst.
column8: & to follow christ, must be done At the fyrst.

column7: For although the Apostles had left all thynges and folowed Christe when he spake these woordes, yet was fayth at that tyme vnperfect in them.
column8: For although the Apostles had left all things and followed Christ when he spoke these words, yet was faith At that time unperfect in them.

column7: Moreouer the holy ghost was not yet confirmed in them, as it came to passe afterwarde vpon the day of Pentecost.
column8: Moreover the holy ghost was not yet confirmed in them, as it Come to pass afterward upon the day of Pentecost.

column7: Yea, euen Christe himselfe affirmeth, that they lefte all thynges vnperfectly,
column8: Yea, even Christ himself Affirmeth, that they left all things unperfectly,

column7: & folowed him, when he sayth that he sent furth his disciples without staffe and scrippe,
column8: & followed him, when he say that he sent forth his Disciples without staff and scrip,

column7: & yet they lacked nothyng.
column8: & yet they lacked nothing.

column7: And in another place. The children of the spouse fast not, whiles the spouse is with them.
column8: And in Another place. The children of the spouse fast not, while the spouse is with them.

column7: The Apostles in very dede folowed Christ, <NOTE> & were sent furth to preache in Iury.
column8: The Apostles in very deed followed christ, & were sent forth to preach in Jury

column7: But where was persecution? yea, rather where was fayth, whiche could haue borne suche persecucion if it had happened?
column8: But where was persecution? yea, rather where was faith, which could have born such persecution if it had happened?

column7: Wherfore it is to be vnderstand, that the Apostles left all thynges,
column8: Wherefore it is to be understand, that the Apostles left all things,

column7: & folowed Christ perfectly then,
column8: & followed christ perfectly then,

column7: & not before, when vpon ye dai of Pentecost, they did with costant mynde confesse Christ before the Scribes & Phariseis, and all the people.
column8: & not before, when upon you day of Pentecost, they did with Constant mind confess christ before the Scribes & Pharisees, and all the people.

column7: Moreouer, when they preached not only in Iurye, but in all the worlde vnto the people with suche sedulitee, diligence and constancy, that at last they wer also compelled to dye for preachyng of the Gospel. <NOTE> And truely as concernyng this matter of folowyng Christ, sainct Paule, whose feast wee celebrate this day, is not to be counted the least.
column8: Moreover, when they preached not only in Jury, but in all the world unto the people with such sedulity, diligence and constancy, that At last they were also compelled to die for preaching of the Gospel. And truly as Concerning this matter of following christ, saint Paul, whose feast we celebrate this day, is not to be counted the least.

column7: For after that he was couerted of God (as we reade in the nynth chapiter of the Actes of the Apostles) and of a Wolfe was made a shepe, he preached his Lorde Christ with suche zeale and earnest affection of mynde, that euen at this day his voyce is heard of this matter, and that not in one place onely, but throughout all the whole worlde.
column8: For After that he was coverted of God (as we read in the nynth chapter of the Acts of the Apostles) and of a Wolf was made a sheep, he preached his Lord christ with such zeal and earnest affection of mind, that even At this day his voice is herd of this matter, and that not in one place only, but throughout all the Whole world.

column7: The almightie God graunt that we may receiue his doctrine and direct our life accordyng to the same.
column8: The almighty God grant that we may receive his Doctrine and Direct our life according to the same.

column7: Thyrdly, forasmuche as Christe hath promised vnto his Apostles, iudgement ouer the xii. tribes of Israel, because that in his name they left all thynges,
column8: Thirdly, forasmuch as Christ hath promised unto his Apostles, judgement over the xii. tribes of Israel, Because that in his name they left all things,

column7: & folowed him: Nowe he procedeth to declare further, what he wyll geue to all those that for his names sake shall lose any thyng,
column8: & followed him: Now he Proceedeth to declare further, what he will give to all those that for his names sake shall loose any thing,

column7: <NOTE> and sayth. Euery one that forsaketh house, or brethren or systers, or father or mother, or wyfe or children, or landes for my names sake, shal receiue an hundreth folde, and the inheritance of euerlastyng life.
column8: and say. Every one that Forsaketh house, or brothers or Sisters, or father or mother, or wife or children, or Lands for my names sake, shall receive an Hundredth fold, and the inheritance of everlasting life.

column7: If any ma wyll referre the former promise only to the Apostles, let him know, that this promise is spoken so plainly to all christians generally, that it must nedes remayne a general truth.
column8: If any ma will refer the former promise only to the Apostles, let him know, that this promise is spoken so plainly to all Christians generally, that it must needs remain a general truth.

column7: Only let vs marke this well, howe it must be vnderstad, to leaue all things,
column8: Only let us mark this well, how it must be Understand, to leave all things,

column7: & to folow Christ. For to do this truly & vnfaynedly, doubtles is required a true fayth. yea, if I haue a true fayth, whiche is dead vnto all creatures, and liueth vnto Christ alone & vnto righteousnes, then haue I left all thinges in my heart,
column8: & to follow christ. For to do this truly & unfeignedly, doubtless is required a true faith. yea, if I have a true faith, which is dead unto all creatures, and lives unto christ alone & unto righteousness, then have I left all things in my heart,

column7: <NOTE> although by the good will of God I may christianly & godly vse & enioye my goodes so long as I liue:
column8: although by the good will of God I may christianly & godly use & enjoy my goods so long as I live:

column7: yet neuerthelesse I am alwaies redy, if nede be, to leaue al thinges & willyngly to folow Christ, yea eue vnto death, hauyng this hope & assured trust, yt it pleaseth God that it be so,
column8: yet nevertheless I am always ready, if need be, to leave all things & willingly to follow christ, yea eve unto death, having this hope & assured trust, that it Pleases God that it be so,

column7: & that he requireth ye same of me.
column8: & that he requires you same of me.

column7: Besydes that, I am certain, yt God wyll vse me wt suche liberalite, yt I shal receiue an hudreth fold for ye thynges yt I haue forsake in this world.
column8: Besides that, I am certain, that God will use me with such liberality, that I shall receive an hudreth fold for you things that I have forsake in this world.

column7: Finally, I knowe this also, yt in that other lyfe,
column8: Finally, I know this also, that in that other life,

column7: I shall receiue euerlastynge life.
column8: I shall receive everlasting life.

column7: For Christ, which is ye truth it selfe, in no wyse doth lye, but without dout dothe performe this promise with me.
column8: For christ, which is the truth it self, in no wise does lie, but without doubt doth perform this promise with me.

column7: But in this place it shal be expedient that we doo rightly vnderstand, what it is to receiue an hundreth folde.
column8: But in this place it shall be expedient that we do rightly understand, what it is to receive an Hundredth fold.

column7: <NOTE> For the Anabaptistes go aboute hereof to proue a corporall kingedome of Christe, and a suer and quiete lyfe, which the christians muste inioye a thousand yeares after the resurrection of the deade, all the wycked and vngodly being destroyed.
column8: For the Anabaptists go about hereof to prove a corporal Kingdom of Christ, and a sure and quiet life, which the Christians must enjoy a thousand Years After the resurrection of the dead, all the wicked and ungodly being destroyed.

column7: And of this erroure they make this the chiefe grounde, bicause it is added in S.
column8: And of this error they make this the chief ground, Because it is added in S.

column8: Luke, and also in S.

column7: Marke: In this lyfe.
column8: Mark: In this life.

column7: <NOTE> But I praye you, howe do these agree togyther, that wher Christe in an other place dyd refuse to bee chosen a kynge amongest the Iewes, after a corporall and worldly manner, and sayde vnto Pilate:
column8: But I pray you, how do these agree together, that where Christ in an other place did refuse to be chosen a King amongst the Jews, After a corporal and worldly manner, and said unto Pilate:

column7: My kingdome is not of this worlde?
column8: My Kingdom is not of this world?

column7: nowe as one forgetful of his former sentence, is of a contrarye mynd, and is come to administre a corporal kyngdome in this world, and to geue vnto his christians earthly pleasures, the pride and power of this worlde?
column8: now as one forgetful of his former sentence, is of a contrary mind, and is come to administre a corporal Kingdom in this world, and to give unto his Christians earthly pleasures, the pride and power of this world?

column7: No, <NOTE> not so.
column8: No, not so.

column7: But to receiue an hundreth folde in this worlde is nothinge els, than to haue a mercy, quiete and suer conscience, whiche esteemeth more his redemtion, iustice and euerlasting health, which he hath gotten by Christe onlye, then all the ryches of this world, be they neuer so glorious and delectable to the vngodly.
column8: But to receive an Hundredth fold in this world is nothing Else, than to have a mercy, quiet and sure conscience, which esteems more his redemption, Justice and everlasting health, which he hath got by Christ only, then all the riches of this world, be they never so glorious and delectable to the ungodly.

column7: And in very deede, suche a good thing is a quiet coscience, through the benefite of Christ.
column8: And in very deed, such a good thing is a quiet conscience, through the benefit of christ.

column7: And this so great a good thyng, wyll Christe gyue in this lyfe vnto all theim, which with a trew faith faith do hange vppon hym, or leaue any thinge for his sake.
column8: And this so great a good thing, will Christ gyve in this life unto all them, which with a true faith faith do hang upon him, or leave any thing for his sake.

column7: And in the countrey euerlastinge to come he will giue that felicitie of lyfe which euer shall indure.
column8: And in the country everlasting to come he will give that felicity of life which ever shall endure.

column7: To the whiche, the almighty god preserue and keepe vs all, through his welbeloued sonne Iesus Christ our lorde.
column8: To the which, the almighty god preserve and keep us all, through his well-beloved son jesus christ our lord.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the purificacion of the Virgin Maryes daye. Luc. 2.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the purification of the Virgae Maryes day. Luke 2.

column8: Woodcut illustration of the Virgae Mary holding the infant jesus.

column7: A Nd when the tyme of theyr purificacion <NOTE> after the law of Moyses was come, they <NOTE> broughte him to Ierusalem to presente hym to the Lord, as it is written in the lawe of ye Lord: <NOTE> Euery manne chylde that fyrste openeth the matrix, shall be called holye to the Lord, and to offre (as it is sayd in the law of the Lord) a payre of turtle doues or two yonge pigeons.
column8: ANd ANd when the time of their purification After the law of Moses was come, they brought him to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord, as it is written in the law of the Lord: Every man child that First Openeth the matrix, shall be called holy to the Lord, and to offer (as it is said in the law of the Lord) a pair of turtle Dove or two young pigeons.

column7: And behold, there was a man in Ierusalem, whose name was Simeon,
column8: And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem, whose name was Simeon,

column7: & the same ma was iuste and godly, and loked for the consolac^on of Israel and the holy ghost was in hym.
column8: & the same ma was just and godly, and looked for the consolac^on of Israel and the holy ghost was in him.

column7: And an answer had he receiued of the holy ghost, that he shulde not see death, except he fyrst saw the Lordes Christ.
column8: And an answer had he received of the holy ghost, that he should not see death, except he fyrst saw the lords christ.

column7: And he came by inspiration into the Temple.
column8: And he Come by inspiration into the Temple.

column7: And when the father and mother brought in the chylde Iesus, to doo for hym after the custome of the <NOTE> lawe, then tooke hee him vppe in his armes, and sayde:
column8: And when the father and mother brought in the child jesus, to do for him After the custom of the law, then took he him up in his arms, and said:

column7: Lorde, now lettest thou thy seruaunt depart in peace, accordyng to thy promyse.
column8: Lord, now Lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, according to thy promise.

column7: For mine eyes haue seene thy saluacion, whiche thou haste prepared before the face of al people.
column8: For mine eyes have seen thy salvation, which thou haste prepared before the face of all people.

column7: <NOTE> A lyght to lyghten the Gentiles, and the glorye of thy people Israell. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: A Light to lighten the Gentiles, and the glory of thy people Israel. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: T He gospel thys daye red (deareli beloued) describeth first the purificacion of Mary, and the offeryng vp of the childe Iesu into the temple.
column8: THe THe gospel this day read (deareli Beloved) Describeth First the purification of Mary, and the offering up of the child Jesu into the temple.

column7: And doubtles, there was a meruelouse great meekenes and lowlynes in the blessed vigin Mary, and also in the child Iesus, to submit themselues so lowly and so diligently to fulfyl that lawe, which they were nothing at al bound vnto.
column8: And doubtless, there was a marvelous great meekness and lowliness in the blessed Virgae Marry, and also in the child jesus, to submit themselves so lowly and so diligently to fulfil that law, which they were nothing At all bound unto.

column7: I praye you, who can say, they were bound vnto the lawe?
column8: I pray you, who can say, they were bound unto the law?

column7: Let vs fyrst speake of Mary.
column8: Let us fyrst speak of Mary.

column7: The law of purificacio containeth this in summe:
column8: The law of purificacio Containeth this in sum:

column7: <NOTE> That whe a woman hath borne a man child, she must remaine fourty dayes in the bloud of her purifiyng:
column8: That when a woman hath born a man child, she must remain fourty days in the blood of her purifying:

column7: & if she bare a woman child, fourscore days.
column8: & if she bore a woman child, fourscore days.

column7: But this law could by no means include Mary, forasmuch as she was vyrgin before the byrth & in the byrth of her chyld,
column8: But this law could by no means include Marry, forasmuch as she was Virgin before the birth & in the birth of her child,

column7: <NOTE> & perpetually for euer continueth virgin.
column8: & perpetually for ever Continueth Virgae.

column7: Neyther ought she to be accopted among those women, who that law speaketh of, which haue conceiued & borne by the seed of ma.
column8: Neither ought she to be accopted among those women, who that law speaks of, which have conceived & born by the seed of ma.

column7: Neither saith the scripture: <NOTE> A certain woma. but a virgin shuld bere Christ.
column8: Neither Says the scripture: A certain Woman. but a Virgae should bear christ.

column7: Yet that notwithstanding, in this matter she gladly doth as other women, yea and that with the pure loue of ye heart, wherin she wold serue & teache other.
column8: Yet that notwithstanding, in this matter she gladly does as other women, yea and that with the pure love of you heart, wherein she would serve & teach other.

column7: And in this she instructeth vs, that we shulde many times do by brotherly loue, some thinges that we are not bounde to doo.
column8: And in this she Instructeth us, that we should many times do by brotherly love, Some things that we Are not bound to do.

column7: But what shall wee saye of the chylde Iesus?
column8: But what shall we say of the child jesus?

column7: Was not hee aboue the lawe, and lorde of the whole lawe?
column8: Was not he above the law, and lord of the Whole law?

column7: yet for all that he is offered vp in the temple as another childe should be, with the accustomable sacrifice, by the lawe required at suche purifiynges,
column8: yet for all that he is offered up in the temple as Another child should be, with the accustomable sacrifice, by the law required At such purifiynges,

column7: & that for this cause, that in the oblacion of this childe it might bee signifyed, that oure fyrst natiuitee is so vnpure, so full of malice & so fylthy,
column8: & that for this cause, that in the oblation of this child it might be signified, that our fyrst Nativity is so unpure, so full of malice & so filthy,

column7: <NOTE> as nothing is fylthyer.
column8: as nothing is fylthyer.

column7: And in like maner by this purifciacion it is signified, yt by this childe as by the fyrst borne among many brethren, al men must needes be purifyed.
column8: And in like manner by this purifciacion it is signified, that by this child as by the fyrst born among many brothers, all men must needs be purified.

column7: Furthermore, Christ also submitteth himselfe vnder the lawe, not that it was necessary for him so to do, as concernyng his owne person, but that he would satisfie the lawe for vs,
column8: Furthermore, christ also submitteth himself under the law, not that it was necessary for him so to do, as Concerning his own person, but that he would satisfy the law for us,

column7: & so abrogate it, <NOTE> that in the matter, concernyng iustificacio, it shuld haue nothyng to do, euen as Christ hath brought it to passe.
column8: & so abrogate it, that in the matter, Concerning iustificacio, it should have nothing to do, even as christ hath brought it to pass.

column7: For doth not sainct Paule say:
column8: For does not saint Paul say:

column7: <NOTE> You are not vnder the lawe, but vnder grace?
column8: You Are not under the law, but under grace?

column7: This nowe is very comfortable to vs.
column8: This now is very comfortable to us

column7: For the law commaunded many thynges, whiche wee were vnable to fulfyll, Actes xv. yet neuerthelesse it was necessary, and that vnder paine of eternal damnacion, that we should fulfill the lawe, and satisfie it.
column8: For the law commanded many things, which we were unable to fulfil, Acts xv. yet nevertheless it was necessary, and that under pain of Eternal damnation, that we should fulfil the law, and satisfy it.

column7: Wherfore without doubt, we all must needes haue dispayred, if Christ had not come and fulfylled it,
column8: Wherefore without doubt, we all must needs have despaired, if christ had not come and fulfilled it,

column7: & abrogate it, and by his grace and merites only obtayned for vs remission of synnes, righteousnes, and eternal he^lth.
column8: & abrogate it, and by his grace and merits only obtained for us remission of Sins, righteousness, and Eternal he^lth.

column7: And here note, that the lawe in ^he matter of iustificacion is abrogate, as wee haue before monished.
column8: And Here note, that the law in he matter of justification is abrogate, as we have before monished.

column7: But in asmuche as partayneth vnto the obedience of fayth, so muche it becommeth vs to fulfyl and do, as christians and the children of God.
column8: But in asmuch as partayneth unto the Obedience of faith, so much it becomes us to fulfil and do, as Christians and the children of God.

column7: Secondarilye, for as muche as Simeon shulde bear witnesse of this child and of his doctrine that shuld folow, to the intent, that his testimony might take (as it is worthy) more waight and estimacion, therfore is he so wel described of the Euangelist by his vertu and godlines.
column8: Secondarily, for as much as Simeon should bear witness of this child and of his Doctrine that should follow, to the intent, that his testimony might take (as it is worthy) more weight and estimation, Therefore is he so well described of the Evangelist by his virtue and godliness.

column7: For thus sayth the euangelist.
column8: For thus say the evangelist.

column7: And this man was righteous and godly.
column8: And this man was righteous and godly.

column7: <NOTE> But no man can be righteous and godli, without the holy ghost,
column8: But no man can be righteous and godly, without the holy ghost,

column7: & faith. For why, faith only maketh vertuous & righteous, as the scripture witnesseth.
column8: & faith. For why, faith only makes virtuous & righteous, as the scripture Witnesseth.

column7: Furthermore, he that beleueth, feareth god,
column8: Furthermore, he that Believeth, fears god,

column7: <NOTE> not with seruile or bond fear, but with a childly fear, or suche a fear, as becometh a son to beare vnto his father.
column8: not with servile or bound Fear, but with a childly Fear, or such a Fear, as Becometh a son to bear unto his father.

column7: If the it be true that the euangelist writeth of Simeo (as wtout doubt it is) needs must it folow that Symeon had a faithfull and godly heart.
column8: If the it be true that the evangelist Writeth of Simeon (as without doubt it is) needs must it follow that Symeon had a faithful and godly heart.

column7: But suche a faith, wherevnto did she pretend, or wherin did she put her truste and confidence?
column8: But such a faith, whereunto did she pretend, or wherein did she put her trust and confidence?

column7: To woorkes of the lawe?
column8: To works of the law?

column7: Nay. But he looked for the consolacion of Israell, as the euangelist saithe.
column8: Nay. But he looked for the consolation of Israel, as the evangelist Saith.

column7: What is this that I do heare?
column8: What is this that I do hear?

column7: Is this babe the only comforte of Israel?
column8: Is this babe the only Comfort of Israel?

column7: Suerly & without dout he is euen so. <NOTE>
column8: Surely & without doubt he is even so.

column7: How many think you were ther among so many thousandes of men in Israel & Iuda, that knew this?
column8: How many think you were there among so many thousandes of men in Israel & Juda, that knew this?

column7: I warant ye a smal numbre, if ye take away from theim,
column8: I warrant you a small numbered, if you take away from them,

column7: Mary, Ioseph, Anna the prophetisse,
column8: Marry, Joseph, Anna the Prophetess,

column7: & this Simeon. What a woderful thing is this.
column8: & this Simeon. What a woderful thing is this.

column7: Yea ther is no such meruaile as this, that among so holy a people & enryched with so many prerogatiues fro god him self, ar found so smal a numbre, that acknowledged this time of grace & saluacion.
column8: Yea there is no such marvel as this, that among so holy a people & enriched with so many prerogatives from god him self, Are found so small a numbered, that acknowledged this time of grace & salvation.

column7: Only this old man Simeon,
column8: Only this old man Simeon,

column7: & Anna the prophetisse, toke heed vnto ye prophecy of Christ, and marked this tyme of grace:
column8: & Anna the Prophetess, took heed unto you prophecy of christ, and marked this time of grace:

column7: certainly beleuing that it shulde be so in deed, that he shulde not taste of death, but that he shulde firste beholde the Christ of the lorde.
column8: Certainly believing that it should be so in deed, that he should not taste of death, but that he should First behold the christ of the lord.

column7: And what folowed? For asmuche as his faithe and hope was certayne and right, therefore he receaued an oracle or answer of the holy ghost, that he shuld not se death, before he had seene the lordes Christ.
column8: And what followed? For asmuch as his faith and hope was certain and right, Therefore he received an oracle or answer of the holy ghost, that he should not see death, before he had seen the Lords christ.

column7: Oh in what ioy was this good father then?
column8: O in what joy was this good father then?

column7: And on the other side, howe greuous was the abidyng so longe tyme vnto him, tyl he myght see that daye and attaine to that ioye.
column8: And on the other side, how grievous was the abiding so long time unto him, till he might see that day and attain to that joy.

column7: Notwithstandyng at the laste it came, and he obtained his herty desire.
column8: Notwithstanding At the laste it Come, and he obtained his hearty desire.

column7: For whe the parents brought in the childe Iesus, to do for him after the custome of the law, this Simeon came also into the temple not of his awne heade, but by the mocion of the holy ghost.
column8: For when the Parents brought in the child jesus, to do for him After the custom of the law, this Simeon Come also into the temple not of his awn head, but by the motion of the holy ghost.

column7: And the receiued the babe into his armes and confessed him to be his lorde and sauioure, and wished vnto him all thinges fortunate and prosperous, as in this place in goodly ordre and frutefully the Euangelyst describeth it.
column8: And the received the babe into his arms and confessed him to be his lord and Saviour, and wished unto him all things fortunate and prosperous, as in this place in goodly ordre and fruitfully the Evangelist Describeth it.

column7: <NOTE> Thirdelye here note, in howe greate myrthe, in what great ioy, this old man triumphed as it were when the eyes of his hearte were opened to knowe his Messias.
column8: Thirdly Here note, in how great mirth, in what great joy, this old man triumphed as it were when the eyes of his heart were opened to know his Messias.

column7: Nowe (saide he) O lord, thou lettest thy seruaunt depart in peace, accordyng to thy promise.
column8: Now (said he) Oh lord, thou Lettest thy servant depart in peace, according to thy promise.

column7: Oh, howe noble a thinge is a heart that beleueth well?
column8: O, how noble a thing is a heart that Believeth well?

column7: For, I praye you, what thinge careth Simeon for nowe?
column8: For, I pray you, what thing Careth Simeon for now?

column7: when he knoweth his king and fauiour?
column8: when he Knoweth his King and fauiour?

column7: Doutles nothing nowe can make him pensiue or sorowfull.
column8: Doubtless nothing now can make him pensive or sorrowful.

column7: Neither careth he much, whether he liue or dye.
column8: Neither Careth he much, whither he live or die.

column7: As though he shulde saye:
column8: As though he should say:

column7: Oh lorde God, I haue with great and feruent desire longed to see thy sonne, the sauiour of the worlde, and now by thy goodnes and mercye I haue that I euer desired.
column8: O lord God, I have with great and fervent desire longed to see thy son, the Saviour of the world, and now by thy Goodness and mercy I have that I ever desired.

column7: And therfore, now I feale my felfe in so great ioye, that it is all one to me whether I liue or dye.
column8: And Therefore, now I feal my self in so great joy, that it is all one to me whither I live or die.

column7: <NOTE> Now if I must liue longer,
column8: Now if I must live longer,

column7: I knowe that my sauiour, yea the sauiour of al the whole worlde is come, and therfore there is nothyng can make me sorowfull.
column8: I know that my Saviour, yea the Saviour of all the Whole world is come, and Therefore there is nothing can make me sorrowful.

column7: But if I must dye, then am I sure that death is to me auantage.
column8: But if I must die, then am I sure that death is to me advantage.

column7: Yea verely (oh Lord) I heartely desire to be dissolued & be with thee.
column8: Yea verily (o Lord) I heartily desire to be dissolved & be with thee.

column7: For I am sure, that neither synne nor death, nor deuil nor hell can hurt me, for asmuche as I haue seen thy sonne my lorde, and I haue knowen him as my Messias and sauiour.
column8: For I am sure, that neither sin nor death, nor Devil nor hell can hurt me, for asmuch as I have seen thy son my lord, and I have known him as my Messias and Saviour.

column7: Beholde howe after this maner Symeon maketh his song, and declareth what fayth he hath in this childe.
column8: Behold how After this manner Symeon makes his song, and Declareth what faith he hath in this child.

column7: And what dothe he more?
column8: And what doth he more?

column7: Sufficeth it that he only beleueth,
column8: Suffices it that he only Believeth,

column7: <NOTE> and that this ioye tickleth his heart onely?
column8: and that this joy tickleth his heart only?

column7: Nay not so. But he would make this ioy knowen vnto all men, and he sayth,
column8: Nay not so. But he would make this joy known unto all men, and he say,

column7: That God hath prepared this sauiour, before the face of all people.
column8: That God hath prepared this Saviour, before the face of all people.

column7: Wherevnto? A light to lighten among the Heathen, and the glory of thy people of Israel.
column8: Whereunto? A Light to lighten among the Heathen, and the glory of thy people of Israel.

column7: Surely that is it that I would so gladly haue hard spoken of.
column8: Surely that is it that I would so gladly have hard spoken of.

column7: And I beseche you what thyng might wee poore heathen require more?
column8: And I beseech you what thing might we poor heathen require more?

column7: Wee were bonde vnto this tyme in darkenes & great incredulite, vtterly ignorant what we shuld do to attaine euerlasting saluacion.
column8: we were bond unto this time in darkness & great Incredulity, utterly ignorant what we should do to attain everlasting salvation.

column7: But God hath set furth this light, and nowe hath he ended this miserye.
column8: But God hath Set forth this Light, and now hath he ended this misery.

column7: Who hath done this? This childe, of whom Symeon speaketh suche excellent thynges.
column8: Who hath done this? This child, of whom Symeon speaks such excellent things.

column7: And by what thyng hath he brought this to passe?
column8: And by what thing hath he brought this to pass?

column7: By his helthsom doctrine and gospell.
column8: By his helthsom Doctrine and gospel.

column7: For as he only is the glory of his people, when they acknowledge him by faith, so also is he a light vnto vs, when he wolde that his most holy worde shuld come vnto vs.
column8: For as he only is the glory of his people, when they acknowledge him by faith, so also is he a Light unto us, when he would that his most holy word should come unto us

column7: For then in deede began it to be fulfilled, that the prophet longe before sawe in spirite, and saide:
column8: For then in deed began it to be fulfilled, that the Prophet long before saw in Spirit, and said:

column7: The people that dwelt in darknes sawe a great lyght &c.
column8: The people that dwelled in darkness saw a great Light etc.

column7: Wherfore (deerely beloued) let vs with harty affection indeuour oure selues, that in as much as we are made the childre of god, by the worde of god, that we acknowledge the same with Simeon, and be thankefull.
column8: Wherefore (dearly Beloved) let us with hearty affection endeavour our selves, that in as much as we Are made the children of god, by the word of god, that we acknowledge the same with Simeon, and be thankful.

column7: And neuer admitte to seeke remission of sinnes, iustice and eternal health at any other, then this childe, whom Simeon acknowledgeth and nameth the sauioure of the whole worlde.
column8: And never admit to seek remission of Sins, Justice and Eternal health At any other, then this child, whom Simeon acknowledgeth and names the Saviour of the Whole world.

column7: Who with the father and the holy ghoste preserue and keepe vs all Amen.
column8: Who with the father and the holy ghost preserve and keep us all Amen.

column8: I thank thee, Oh father, lord of heaven and earth, Because thou haste hid those things from the wife and prudent,

column8: & hast showed them unto babes, verily father eve so was it thy good pleasure. All things Are given over unto me of my father.

column7: <NOTE> And no man knoweth the son, but the father:

column8: neither Knoweth any man the father, save the son, and he to whom so ever the son will open him.

column8: Take my yoke upon you,

column7: & learn of me, for I am meek and lowly in heart,
column8: & Learn of me, for I am meek and lowly in heart,

column8: & you shall find rest unto your Souls.

column8: For my yoke is easy, and my burden is Light. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: TO the right vnderstandyng of this presente Gospell, <NOTE> it is necessary that we consider wel, two natures in Christ.
column8: TO the right understanding of this present Gospel, it is necessary that we Consider well, two nature's in christ.

column7: And verely if these two natures bee well and christianly cosidered, it shal open and make plaine many places of the godly scriptures, which at the fyrst sight might seme to be contrary, so that in very dede there shall appeare in them no repugnauncye at all.
column8: And verily if these two nature's be well and christianly considered, it shall open and make plain many places of the godly Scriptures, which At the fyrst sighed might seem to be contrary, so that in very deed there shall appear in them no repugnauncye At all.

column7: As for an example: I and my father are one.
column8: As for an Exampl: I and my father Are one.

column8: And again in Another place:

column8: Now if you refer this sentece unto Christ's divine nature,

column7: I pray you, shall not these saiynges well agree?
column8: I pray you, shall not these sayings well agree?

column7: For that he geueth thankes to his father, it belongeth to his manhod:
column8: For that he Giveth thanks to his father, it belongeth to his manhood:

column7: and that he sayth, All thynges are geuen me of my father. it must be referred vnto his godhead.
column8: and that he say, All things Are given me of my father. it must be referred unto his godhead.

column7: But wherfore geueth Christ thankes vnto his father?
column8: But Wherefore Giveth christ thanks unto his father?

column7: Forsoth because the worde whiche is contemned of Corazin, and Bethsaida, is hyd fro the wyse and prudet, and is reueled or opened vnto yong children.
column8: Forsooth Because the word which is contemned of Chorazin, and Bethsaida, is hid from the wise and prudet, and is revealed or opened unto young children.

column7: <NOTE> In this place he calleth theim wyse and prudet, that trust to their ownes wysdome, and by their owne wyttes and vnderstandynges, will searche out all thynges.
column8: In this place he calls them wise and prudet, that trust to their owns Wisdom, and by their own wits and understandings, will search out all things.

column7: Of whom also the prophet sayth:
column8: Of whom also the Prophet say:

column7: Wo to you that are wise in your owne eyes,
column8: Woe to you that Are wise in your own eyes,

column7: <NOTE> & prudent in your owne conceites.
column8: & prudent in your own conceits.

column7: Suche wysedome and suche prudence (that is) suche as will not be subdued and submit it selfe captiue vnder the worde of God, and to the folishe preachyng of the crosse, shal neuer bee able to perceiue any thyng at all of the matter of his iustificacion, nor in any thyng that appertayneth to the glorye of God.
column8: Suche Wisdom and such prudence (that is) such as will not be subdued and submit it self captive under the word of God, and to the foolish preaching of the cross, shall never be able to perceive any thing At all of the matter of his justification, nor in any thing that appertaineth to the glory of God.

column7: And why? God can by no meanes, nor will suffre suche pride, as comonly cometh of carnal wysedome, as it is written:
column8: And why? God can by no means, nor will suffer such pride, as commonly comes of carnal Wisdom, as it is written:

column7: God resisteth the proud, <NOTE> and geueth grace vnto the lowly.
column8: God Resisteth the proud, and Giveth grace unto the lowly.

column7: Furthermore wee see that suche as are carnally wyse and ciuily prudent menne, very seldome they come vnto the knowlege of God.
column8: Furthermore we see that such as Are carnally wise and civilly prudent men, very seldom they come unto the knowledge of God.

column7: But who then are they that are admitted vnto the knowlege of God, and vnto fayth? Forsothe litle children.
column8: But who then Are they that Are admitted unto the knowledge of God, and unto faith? Forsooth little children.

column7: And in this place Christe calleth theim children,
column8: And in this place Christ calls them children,

column7: <NOTE> that dispayre of theim selues of all their carnall wysedome and prudence, that only considereth and depely fyxeth in their heart, those thynges whiche Christ taught, preached & wrought.
column8: that despair of them selves of all their carnal Wisdom and prudence, that only Considereth and deeply fyxeth in their heart, those things which christ taught, preached & wrought.

column7: Knowyng also that in matter appertainyng vnto the honour of God, to righteousnes & our saluacion, or our own carnall wytte, is of no waytte nor value, but onely the worde of God.
column8: Knowing also that in matter aPPERTAINING unto the honour of God, to righteousness & our salvation, or our own carnal wit, is of no wait nor valve, but only the word of God.

column7: <NOTE> And knowyng also that no man can kmowe or apprehende that iustice without the reuelacion of God.
column8: And knowing also that no man can kmowe or apprehend that Justice without the Revelation of God.

column7: And nowe, vnto the fyrst nobre that is of carnall wyse men and prudent, pertayne the hye priestes,
column8: And now, unto the fyrst nobre that is of carnal wise men and prudent, pertain the high Priests,

column7: Phariseys, and Scribes, and all iusticiaries, that from the beginnyng of the worlde vnto this day, defende & maintayne iustice of workes, contrary & against the iustice of fayth.
column8: Pharisees, and Scribes, and all Justiciaries, that from the beginning of the world unto this day, defend & maintain Justice of works, contrary & against the Justice of faith.

column7: And of such at this tyme in so ope light of the Gospel ther are innumerable.
column8: And of such At this time in so open Light of the Gospel there Are innumerable.

column7: On the other parte, that is to say, among theim that bee litle children,
column8: On the other part, that is to say, among them that be little children,

column7: <NOTE> are to bee nombred the Apostles, and all that beleue, whiche esteme the Euangelye as a most precious and holy relique, and in nothyng are against it, but with all gentilnes and lowly mynde do receyue it.
column8: Are to be numbered the Apostles, and all that believe, which esteem the Evangelical as a most precious and holy relic, and in nothing Are against it, but with all gentleness and lowly mind do receive it.

column7: Therfore if thou wylt come with these children vnto the knowlege of the gospell and eternal felicitee (well) be not wise and prudent in thine owne conceite, but meake thy selfe in thyne heart. for the worde continueth hyd vnto carnall wysedome.
column8: Therefore if thou wilt come with these children unto the knowledge of the gospel and Eternal felicity (well) be not wise and prudent in thine own conceit, but meake thy self in thine heart. for the word Continueth hid unto carnal Wisdom.

column7: Wherfore also sainct Paule calleth it a misterye or a preuie secrete that all menne vnderstande not, nor perceiue.
column8: Wherefore also saint Paul calls it a mystery or a preuie secret that all men understand not, nor perceive.

column7: Wee speake (sayth he) the wisedome of God in a mistery.
column8: we speak (say he) the Wisdom of God in a mystery.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> when Christe as very manne had ascribed the reuelacion of his Euangelie or gospel vnto his father, he would nowe also shewe himselfe to be very God, equal with the father:
column8: Secondarily, when Christ as very man had ascribed the Revelation of his Evangelist or gospel unto his father, he would now also show himself to be very God, equal with the father:

column7: and he sayth, All thynges are geuen vnto me of my father.
column8: and he say, All things Are given unto me of my father.

column8: And, No man Knoweth the son but the father, neither Knoweth any man the father but the son, and he to whom the son will open him.

column7: Of these wordes it is euident, that Christ is not only very man, but also very God.
column8: Of these words it is evident, that christ is not only very man, but also very God.

column7: For seyng yt in this place he sheweth that the knowlege of his heauenly father is in his power to geue it vnto whom he wyll, whiche thyng in another place he ascribeth vnto his father onely:
column8: For sing that in this place he shows that the knowledge of his heavenly father is in his power to give it unto whom he will, which thing in Another place he ascribeth unto his father only:

column7: needes must it folowe, <NOTE> that as concernyng ye deuine nature, he is equal with his father.
column8: needs must it follow, that as Concerning you divine nature, he is equal with his father.

column7: And if he bee equal with his father, it foloweth of necessitee, that he is very God.
column8: And if he be equal with his father, it Followeth of necessity, that he is very God.

column7: Nowe if he be very God, why should I not beleue in him?
column8: Now if he be very God, why should I not believe in him?

column7: why shuld I refuse to put in him all my whole hope, trust and cosolacion?
column8: why should I refuse to put in him all my Whole hope, trust and cosolacion?

column7: especially seyng that he is so minded toward me and all men that beleue in him, that both he will, and also is hable to helpe vs.
column8: especially sing that he is so minded towards me and all men that believe in him, that both he will, and also is able to help us

column7: And that he wyl gladly succour vs, it appeareth in this, that for our sakes he geueth thankes vnto his heauenly father, as one that hath great pleasure in our saluacion and health.
column8: And that he will gladly succour us, it appears in this, that for our sakes he Giveth thanks unto his heavenly father, as one that hath great pleasure in our salvation and health.

column7: Besides that, he is able to helpe vs, for all thinges are geue vnto him of his father.
column8: Beside that, he is able to help us, for all things Are give unto him of his father.

column8: And to this partaineth it,

column8: that he said unto Philip.

column8: Philip, he that sees me, sees also my father:

column8: & the father is in me.

column8: They Are such as labour, and Are laden in their conscience.

column8: And who be those? Those doubtless that feel their Sins and knowledge them, and for them be fearful and trembling, without Comfort,

column7: & of a contrite heart.
column8: & of a contrite heart.

column7: For to suche consciences there is no worke, no holy deede, no wysedome, that canne succour theim, but Christ onely by his death and passion, and by that precious effusion of his bloud. Many one there are, that in suche trouble of conscience, and in the great conflictes and anguishe of ye same, seke remedyes, by certaine prescribed holynes and woorkes.
column8: For to such Consciences there is no work, no holy deed, no Wisdom, that can succour them, but christ only by his death and passion, and by that precious effusion of his blood. Many one there Are, that in such trouble of conscience, and in the great conflicts and anguish of you same, seek remedies, by certain prescribed holiness and works.

column8: The Doctrine of christ, Because of the cross, which it ever bringeth with it, is a great yoke and heavy burden to the Flesh.

column8: But when the Spirit comes, it is made easy and Light, were it afore never so heavy, as saint John say:

column8: His Precepts Are not heavy. That almighty lord give us grace that we never suffer our selves to be withdrawn from that yoke.

column8: ANd ANd in the Sixth Monn, the angel Gabriel was sent from God unto a City of Galilee, nam Nazareth, to a Virgae spoused to a man, whose name was Joseph, of the house of David, and the Virgins name was Marye.

column7: Fyrst, that Mary founde so great grace with God. <NOTE> For that which is founde, surely it is founde without any merites of any woorkes that went before, and so it commeth vnloked for. <NOTE> Then if Mary found suche grace afore God,
column8: Fyrst, that Mary found so great grace with God. For that which is found, surely it is found without any merits of any works that went before, and so it comes unlooked for. Then if Mary found such grace afore God,

column8: And thereupon do make an Idol of her, setting it above God.

column7: I can well beare, and truely so is it worthy, that Mary be praised, and exalted as a goodly virgyn, and full of grace afore God, yea, and also to be set furth vnto all christians, as a liuely ensample of fayth. yet (that notwithstadyng) suffre her to continue a creature that attayned vnto that dignitee, by grace without merites, and that neuer desired to be extolled aboue her sonne, as ye may wel perceiue by her owne woordes, where she sayth in the gospell:
column8: I can well bear, and truly so is it worthy, that Mary be praised, and exalted as a goodly Virgae, and full of grace afore God, yea, and also to be Set forth unto all Christians, as a lively ensample of faith. yet (that notwithstanding) suffer her to continue a creature that attained unto that dignity, by grace without merits, and that never desired to be extolled above her son, as you may well perceive by her own words, where she say in the gospel:

column7: Whatsoeuer my sonne shall say vnto you, that do.
column8: Whatsoever my son shall say unto you, that do.

column7: <NOTE> Doth not this mooste blessed virgyn Mary in this place sende men from her selfe vnto Christ, and vnto his woorde?
column8: Does not this most blessed Virgae Marry in this place send men from her self unto christ, and unto his word?

column7: Surely wee confesse, that Mary obtayned of God greatter fauour or grace, then all other women, in that she was full of the holy ghost, and the Lorde was with her.
column8: Surely we confess, that Mary obtained of God greater favour or grace, then all other women, in that she was full of the holy ghost, and the Lord was with her.

column7: But nowe it foloweth not of this, that I shuld make an Idol of her, that we shuld esteme her to be our life, swetenes,
column8: But now it Followeth not of this, that I should make an Idol of her, that we should esteem her to be our life, sweetness,

column8: For these words pertain unto the humanity of christ, which in our time is impugned, without shame,

column8: But this text Teaches plainly that doubtless christ fyrst was coceiued of the holy ghost,

column8: & then by the operation of the same holy ghost, he received (as every other child does) Form, figure,

column8: & nourishementes, Flesh and blood of his mother the Virgae Marry, and so was born of her as the article of our faith Declareth.

column7: And we by the assistance of Goddes grace shal euer continue in this fayth and confesse it,
column8: And we by the assistance of Goddess grace shall ever continue in this faith and confess it,

column8: & never depart from it, though the Anabaptists wax never so wood, and babble never so much vain words in waste.

column7: Secondarily, in this Gospel is excelletly described the kyngdome of Christe.
column8: Secondarily, in this Gospel is excelletly described the Kingdom of Christ.

column7: <NOTE> For the Angel sayth:
column8: For the Angel say:

column8: And the Lord God shall give unto him the seat of David his father, and he shall Reign over you house of Jacob eternally:

column7: and there shalbe no ende of his kyngdome.
column8: and there shall no end of his Kingdom.

column7: In these woordes Christ is called the sonne of Dauid,
column8: In these words christ is called the son of David,

column7: & I thynke because he was so long before promised to Dauid, and that he toke fleshe & bloud of Mary,
column8: & I think Because he was so long before promised to David, and that he took Flesh & blood of Mary,

column7: <NOTE> whiche was of the seade of Dauid.
column8: which was of the seade of David.

column7: And this seate or maiestie of Dauid, whiche should be geuen vnto him, is no corporal seate, but a spiritual seate.
column8: And this seat or majesty of David, which should be given unto him, is no corporal seat, but a spiritual seat.

column7: For if it were a corporal seat, it could not endure for euer, but it must needes haue an ende.
column8: For if it were a corporal seat, it could not endure for ever, but it must needs have an end.

column7: And therfore the Angel added:
column8: And Therefore the Angel added:

column7: And his kyngdome shall haue none ende.
column8: And his Kingdom shall have none end.

column7: Suche a kyngdome of Christ is also excellently described by the Prophete Esaie in the ix. chapiter, where among other thynges he sayth thus:
column8: Suche a Kingdom of christ is also excellently described by the Prophet Isaiah in the ix. chapter, where among other things he say thus:

column7: <NOTE> His imperie shalbe dilated or multiplied, and peace shalbe without end vpo the throne of Dauid,
column8: His impery shall dilated or multiplied, and peace shall without end upon the throne of David,

column7: & vpon his kyngdome, that he may confirme & strengthen it, in iustice and iudgement, fro thencefurth and for euermore.
column8: & upon his Kingdom, that he may confirm & strengthen it, in Justice and judgement, from thencefurth and for evermore.

column7: Marke, that suche a peace shalbe in the kyngdome of Christe, whiche shal not endure for a tyme, but for euermore.
column8: Mark, that such a peace shall in the Kingdom of Christ, which shall not endure for a time, but for evermore.

column7: And how could this peace be referred vnto Dauid, whiche neither had this peace, nor yet could geue it vnto other?
column8: And how could this peace be referred unto David, which neither had this peace, nor yet could give it unto other?

column7: Furthermore, in this kyngdome iustice shalbe made strong in iudgement.
column8: Furthermore, in this Kingdom Justice shall made strong in judgement.

column7: <NOTE> Nowe, howe shall this be?
column8: Now, how shall this be?

column7: Where as is no knowlege of synnes, there can not folowe the iustice of fayth.
column8: Where as is no knowledge of Sins, there can not follow the Justice of faith.

column7: Therfore that I may come vnto the knowlege of synne, and after that, by fayth attayn vnto ye righteousnes of fayth,
column8: Therefore that I may come unto the knowledge of sin, and After that, by faith attain unto you righteousness of faith,

column7: Christ fyrst causeth me, so to be throwe doune at the preachyng of repentaunce, that I shall feale my selfe worthy for my synnes to haue hell and eternal dampnacion.
column8: christ fyrst Causes me, so to be throw down At the preaching of Repentance, that I shall feale my self worthy for my Sins to have hell and Eternal damnation.

column7: But then through the preachyng of free remission of synnes for Christes sake,
column8: But then through the preaching of free remission of Sins for Christ's sake,

column7: I shal be againe comforted, and raysed vp, so that in tyme commyng I shall feare nothyng for my synnes, but I shal stand stedfast in fayth, and wayte for eternal health.
column8: I shall be again comforted, and raised up, so that in time coming I shall Fear nothing for my Sins, but I shall stand steadfast in faith, and wait for Eternal health.

column7: After this maner is iustice stablished by iudgement in the kyngdome of Christ.
column8: After this manner is Justice established by judgement in the Kingdom of christ.

column7: Vpon this againe it foloweth, that this seate of Dauid, which here is promised vnto Christ, is nothyng els but a spiritual kyngdome of Christ, whiche is gouerned and ruled by ye scripture of the Euagely, or gospell.
column8: Upon this again it Followeth, that this seat of David, which Here is promised unto christ, is nothing Else but a spiritual Kingdom of christ, which is governed and ruled by you scripture of the Evagely, or gospel.

column7: Neither can it stad in any maner other thyng, then in spirite and trueth.
column8: Neither can it stad in any manner other thing, then in Spirit and truth.

column7: For it can not bee a corporall kyngdome.
column8: For it can not be a corporal Kingdom.

column7: For why, these thynges that wee haue nowe spoken of, and the corporal kyngdome that Dauid sometyme gouerned, differre as farre as heauen and yerth.
column8: For why, these things that we have now spoken of, and the corporal Kingdom that David sometime governed, differre as Far as heaven and yerth.

column7: And to speake briefly, Christ him selfe in the gospel of Luke concludeth this, saiyng:
column8: And to speak briefly, christ him self in the gospel of Luke Concludeth this, saying:

column7: The kyngdome of God is within you. <NOTE> Thyrdly, wee haue here a noble ensample of true fayth in Mary.
column8: The Kingdom of God is within you. Thirdly, we have Here a noble ensample of true faith in Marry.

column7: For although at the fyrst she was abashed at the Angels worde, and afterwarde also wondered right sore,
column8: For although At the fyrst she was abashed At the Angels word, and afterward also wondered right soar,

column8: how she should be the mother of the Lord, sing that she knew no man:

column8: Yet now when she hears, that the holy ghost should work all this in her, she gladly Committeth her self unto the will of God, with great meekness & lowliness, and Believeth the Angel which God had sent unto her.

column7: Wherfore also Elizabeth highly praised this fayth,
column8: Wherefore also Elizabeth highly praised this faith,

column7: <NOTE> saiyng: Blessed art thou which hast beleued, for those thynges shalbe accoplished in thee, which were tolde thee from the Lord.
column8: saying: Blessed art thou which hast believed, for those things shall accoplished in thee, which were told thee from the Lord.

column7: <NOTE> For this is the true nature of fayth, which appeareth here in Mary, to beleueue the worde, to leane vnto the worde, and to cleaue vnto the worde, yea though that thyng whiche the worde speaketh of, can in no wise be compreheded by mans reason.
column8: For this is the true nature of faith, which appears Here in Marry, to beleueue the word, to lean unto the word, and to cleave unto the word, yea though that thing which the word speaks of, can in no wise be compreheded by men reason.

column7: For why shuld it bee called fayth, but that it beleueth thynges inuisible & not apparat, yea,
column8: For why should it be called faith, but that it Believeth things invisible & not apparat, yea,

column8: For as S. Paul Says:

column8: He staggered not thorough unbelief At the promise of god, but he was strong in faith, and gave to god the honour, full certefyed, that whatsoever god promised, he was able to perform it.

column8: Inlike manner must we do.

column8: Whensoever god speaks any thing which I can not obtain nor perceive by my reason or Wisdom, it Becometh me not to dispute, by what means it may come to pass, but thus must I say:

column7: Behold, I am ready the lordes bonde seruaunt, and gladly do I meekely submitte my selfe captiue vnto thy woorde, althouge I perceiue it not, nor can not comprehende it.

column8: But I say unto you:

column8: & that we purpose At this time to Treat upon unto your loving charity.

column8: For so it see we think it profitable to council and help the weak, which about this time Are wont for the more part of a custom to come unto the communion of the Lords supper & participate of it. and Therefore they shall love and more gladly desire Some brief instruction in this matter.

column7: Secondarily, after that Christ with suche frendly wordes (although in vaine) had called Iudas to repentance, and with his welbeloued Apostles had eaten that Easter lambe, he ordained and instituted the remembraunce and commemoracion of our redempcion whiche here in this place of the newe testamet is aswel expressed and declared by figures & figuratiue speaches, as it was in the olde testamet.
column8: Secondarily, After that christ with such friendly words (although in vain) had called Judas to Repentance, and with his well-beloved Apostles had eaten that Easter lamb, he ordained and instituted the remembrance and commemoration of our redemption which Here in this place of the new Testament is aswell expressed and declared by figures & figurative Speeches, as it was in the old Testament.
