column8: And as almighty God passing through Egypt, killed all the egyptians Heirs in every house, and left not one alive,

column7: & neuerthelesse he passed by the children of Israels houses, where he sawe the Lambes bloud vpon the doores, and hurted none of them, but saued them al by the meanes of the Lambes bloud:
column8: & nevertheless he passed by the children of Israel's houses, where he saw the Lambs blood upon the doors, and hurted none of them, but saved them all by the means of the Lambs blood:

column7: so likewyse at the last iudgement of the whole worlde, none shall be passed ouer and saued, but that shall be founde marked with the bloud of that moste pure and immaculate lambe Iesus Christ.
column8: so likewise At the last judgement of the Whole world, none shall be passed over and saved, but that shall be found marked with the blood of that most pure and immaculate lamb jesus christ.

column7: And for asmuch as the sheddyng of that lambes bloud was a token and figure of the sheddyng of Christes bloud then to come,
column8: And for as as the shedding of that Lambs blood was a token and figure of the shedding of Christ's blood then to come,

column7: <NOTE> and forasmuche also as all the sacramentes and figures of the olde testament, ceassed and had an ende in Christe:
column8: and forasmuch also as all the Sacraments and figures of the old Testament, ceased and had an end in Christ:

column7: lest by our great vnkyndnes we shuld peradueture be forgetfull of ye great benefite of Christ, therfore at his last supper (when he toke his leaue of his Apostles to depart out of the world) he did make a newe wylle & testament, wherin he bequeathed vnto vs cleane remission of all our synnes, and the euerlastyng inheritaunce of heauen.
column8: lest by our great unkindness we should Peradventure be forgetful of you great benefit of christ, Therefore At his last supper (when he took his leave of his Apostles to depart out of the world) he did make a new will & Testament, wherein he bequeathed unto us clean remission of all our Sins, and the everlasting inheritance of heaven.

column7: And the same he confirmed the next day with his owne bloud and death.
column8: And the same he confirmed the next day with his own blood and death.

column7: And lest we should forget the same, he ordayned not a yerely memorye (as the Paschal Lambe was eate but ones euery yere) out a dayly remembrance he ordained therof in bread & wyne sanctified & dedicated to that purpose,
column8: And lest we should forget the same, he ordained not a yearly memory (as the Paschal Lamb was eat but ones every year) out a daily remembrance he ordained thereof in bred & wine sanctified & dedicated to that purpose,

column7: <NOTE> saiyng: This is my body:
column8: saying: This is my body:

column7: This cuppe is my bloud, whiche is shed for the remission of synnes.
column8: This cup is my blood, which is shed for the remission of Sins.

column7: Do this in the remembraunce of me.
column8: Do this in the remembrance of me.

column7: Admonishyng vs by these woordes, spoken at the makyng of his last wyll and testament,
column8: Admonishing us by these words, spoken At the making of his last will and Testament,

column7: & at his departyng out of the worlde (because thei should be the better remembred) that whensoeuer wee do eate the bread in his holy supper,
column8: & At his departing out of the world (Because they should be the better remembered) that whensoever we do eat the bred in his holy supper,

column7: & drinke of that cuppe, wee should remembre how muche Christ hath done for vs, and howe he dyed for oure sakes.
column8: & drink of that cup, we should Remember how much christ hath done for us, and how he died for our sakes.

column7: Therfore, sayth sainct Paule:
column8: Therefore, say saint Paul:

column7: <NOTE> As ofte as you shal eate of this bread, and drynke the cuppe, you shall shewe furth the Lordes death vntyll he come.
column8: As oft as you shall eat of this bred, and drink the cup, you shall show forth the lords death until he come.

column7: And forasmuche as this holy bread broken, and the wyne deuided, do represent vnto vs the death of Christe nowe passed, as the killyng of the Paschal Lambe did represent the same yet to come:
column8: And forasmuch as this holy bred broken, and the wine divided, do represent unto us the death of Christ now passed, as the killing of the Paschal Lamb did represent the same yet to come:

column7: therfore our sauiour Christ vsed thesame maner of speche of the bread & wyne, as God before vsed of the Paschal lambe.
column8: Therefore our Saviour christ used The same manner of speech of the bred & wine, as God before used of the Paschal lamb.

column7: For as in the olde testament God sayd:
column8: For as in the old Testament God said:

column7: <NOTE> This is the Lordes Passeby, or Passeouer, euen so sayth Christ in ye newe testament,
column8: This is the lords Passerby, or Passover, even so say christ in the new Testament,

column7: This is my body: <NOTE> This is my bloud.
column8: This is my body: This is my blood.

column7: But in the old mistery and sacrament, the Lambe was not the Lordes very Passeouer or passyng by, but it was a figure whiche represented his passyng by.
column8: But in the old mystery and sacrament, the Lamb was not the lords very Passover or passing by, but it was a figure which represented his passing by.

column7: So likewise in the newe testament, the bread and wyne bee not Christes very body and bloud, but they be figures, whiche by Christes institucion bee vnto the godly receiuers therof, sacramentes, tokens, significacions, and represetacions of his very fleshe & bloud instructyng their fayth, that as the bread and wyne feede theim corporally, and continue this temporal life:
column8: So likewise in the new Testament, the bred and wine be not Christ's very body and blood, but they be figures, which by Christ's Institution be unto the godly Receivers thereof, Sacraments, tokens, significations, and represetacions of his very Flesh & blood instructing their faith, that as the bred and wine feed them corporally, and continue this temporal life:

column7: so the very fleshe & bloud of Christ feedeth theim spiritually,
column8: so the very Flesh & blood of christ feeds them spiritually,

column7: & geueth them euerlastyng life.
column8: & Giveth them everlasting life.

column7: For vnto the faythful Christ is at his owne holy table present, with his mightie spirite and grace, and is of them more fruitfully receyued, than if corporally they should receiue him bodily preset.
column8: For unto the faithful christ is At his own holy table present, with his mighty Spirit and grace, and is of them more fruitfully received, than if corporally they should receive him bodily preset.

column7: And therfore they that shal worthely come to this Goddes borde, muste after due trial of themselues, consider fyrst, who ordained this table, also what meate and drynke they shall haue that come thereto, and howe they ought to behaue them selues thereat.
column8: And Therefore they that shall worthily come to this Goddess board, must After due trial of themselves, Consider fyrst, who ordained this table, also what meat and drink they shall have that come thereto, and how they ought to behave them selves thereat.

column7: He that prepared the table is Christ himselfe.
column8: He that prepared the table is christ himself.

column7: The meate and drynke wherewith he feedeth theim that come thereto as they ought do, is his owne very fleshe and bloud.
column8: The meat and drink wherewith he feeds them that come thereto as they ought do, is his own very Flesh and blood.

column7: They that come thereto, muste occupye their myndes in consideryng howe his bodye was broken for them, and his bloud shed for their redempcion, and so ought they to approche to this heauenly table wt all humblenes of heart, and godlynes of mynde, as to the table wherein Christ himselfe is geuen.
column8: They that come thereto, must occupy their minds in considering how his body was broken for them, and his blood shed for their redemption, and so ought they to approach to this heavenly table with all humbleness of heart, and godliness of mind, as to the table wherein christ himself is given.

column7: And they that come otherwyse to this holy table, they come vnworthely, and do not eat & drynke Christes fleshe and bloud, but eate & drynke their owne damnacion:
column8: And they that come otherwise to this holy table, they come unworthily, and do not eat & drink Christ's Flesh and blood, but eat & drink their own damnation:

column7: because they do not duely consider Christes very fleshe & bloud, whiche be offered there spiritually to bee eaten & dronken, but dispisyng Christes most holy supper, do come therto as it were to other meates & drynkes, without regarde of the Lordes body, whiche is the spiritual meate of that table.
column8: Because they do not duly Consider Christ's very Flesh & blood, which be offered there spiritually to be eaten & drunken, but despising Christ's most holy supper, do come thereto as it were to other Meats & drinks, without regard of the lords body, which is the spiritual meat of that table.

column7: Therfore, let a ma (as sainct Paule sayth) examine himselfe, and so eate of the bread and drynke of the cuppe, for he that eateth and drynketh vnworthely, eateth and drinketh his owne damnacion, not desernyng the Lordes body.
column8: Therefore, let a ma (as saint Paul say) examine himself, and so eat of the bred and drink of the cup, for he that Eateth and Drinketh unworthily, Eateth and Drinketh his own damnation, not desernyng the lords body.

column7: <NOTE> Thyrdly, we can not deny, but that both the good and bad do eate and drynke the sacramental bread and wine, but besides the sacramentes the good eateth euerlastyng life, the euil and wicked membres of the deuil euerlastyng death.
column8: Thirdly, we can not deny, but that both the good and bad do eat and drink the sacramental bred and wine, but beside the Sacraments the good Eateth everlasting life, the evil and wicked members of the Devil everlasting death.

column7: For they do not eate and drynke the body & blud of Christ, but (as sainct Paule sayth) they are gyltie of the body & bloud of the Lord, and eate & drynke their owne damnacion.
column8: For they do not eat and drink the body & blood of christ, but (as saint Paul say) they Are guilty of the body & blood of the Lord, and eat & drink their own damnation.

column7: Fourthly, it is necessary that we knowe, wherevnto this sacrament profiteth, and what vtilitee cometh to vs by it, and what is the power of it.
column8: Fourthly, it is necessary that we know, whereunto this sacrament profiteth, and what utility comes to us by it, and what is the power of it.

column7: And this can no ma learne better any where, then of the very wordes, wherewith this sacrament was instituted, whiche say:
column8: And this can no ma Learn better any where, then of the very words, wherewith this sacrament was instituted, which say:

column7: This is my body, geuen for you, vnto the remission of synnes.
column8: This is my body, given for you, unto the remission of Sins.

column7: Christe ordayned this sacrament of his body and bloud in bread and wine, to preache vnto vs, that as our bodies be fed, norished and preserued with meate & drynke, so are our hungry soules fed, norished and preserued by ye body & bloud of Christ.
column8: Christ ordained this sacrament of his body and blood in bred and wine, to preach unto us, that as our bodies be fed, nourished and preserved with meat & drink, so Are our hungry Souls fed, nourished and preserved by you body & blood of christ.

column7: This same spiritual eatyng and drinkyng of the sayd body and bloud of Christ, is not receiued in the mouthe,
column8: This same spiritual eating and drinking of the said body and blood of christ, is not received in the Mouth,

column7: & digested in the stomacke, but it is receyued with a pure heart & a syncere fayth, beleuyng that Christe gaue his body to death & shed his bloud vpon the crosse for vs,
column8: & digested in the stomach, but it is received with a pure heart & a sincere faith, believing that Christ gave his body to death & shed his blood upon the cross for us,

column7: & that he doth so ioyne and incorporate himself to vs, that he is our heade, and we his membres, hauyng him dwellyng in vs,
column8: & that he does so join and incorporate himself to us, that he is our head, and we his members, having him Dwelling in us,

column7: & wee in him. What thyng can bee more comfortable to vs, than to eat this meate and drynke this drynke?
column8: & we in him. What thing can be more comfortable to us, than to eat this meat and drink this drink?

column7: For he sayth himselfe: <NOTE> He that eateth me, shal liue by me.
column8: For he say himself: He that Eateth me, shall live by me.

column7: Wherfore in this sacramet, receiued with a true fayth, we are assured that our synnes be forgeuen, whiche thing when we fele in our heates, at the receiuyng of ye Lordes supper, what thyng can be more ioyfull, more pleasaunt or more comfortable vnto vs? <NOTE>
column8: Wherefore in this Sacrament, received with a true faith, we Are assured that our Sins be forgiven, which thing when we feel in our heats, At the receiving of the lords supper, what thing can be more joyful, more pleasant or more comfortable unto us?

column7: Who is it that would not apply his whole study, cast in his mynde day & night, yea & go though it were neuer so long a iourney, so yt he might attaine this treasure?
column8: Who is it that would not apply his Whole study, cast in his mind day & night, yea & go though it were never so long a journey, so that he might attain this treasure?

column7: Suppose you there bee any ryches in this worlde lyke vnto this?
column8: Suppose you there be any riches in this world like unto this?

column7: Naye verely. Why so?
column8: Nay verily. Why so?

column7: For the goodes of this worlde, be they neuer so excellent, neuer so precious & great in value, neuer so pleasant & beautifull, yet they ebbe & flowe, they fall as leaues, and thei passe away, although in this life onely they comfort man much, yea, and rather vexe & trouble him:
column8: For the goods of this world, be they never so excellent, never so precious & great in valve, never so pleasant & beautiful, yet they ebb & flow, they fallen as leaves, and they pass away, although in this life only they Comfort man much, yea, and rather vex & trouble him:

column7: But this treasure of forgeuenes of synnes, when by fayth it is obtained, found, and set hande vpon, it bringeth with it no incertaine, deceiuable nor transitory life, but a continuall, euerlasting, and perpetual lyfe,
column8: But this treasure of forgiveness of Sins, when by faith it is obtained, found, and Set hand upon, it brings with it no incertain, deceivable nor transitory life, but a continual, everlasting, and perpetual life,

column7: & also it causeth peace & ioye in the holy ghost, which shall last for euer.
column8: & also it Causes peace & joy in the holy ghost, which shall last for ever.

column7: Wherefore yt is very necessarye, that we with al diligence and studiouse mind, serch for this treasure.
column8: Wherefore that is very necessary, that we with all diligence and studious mind, search for this treasure.

column7: There ar some that are so minded that they thinke that when they haue the worde, it is not verye necessary nor maketh no great matter whether they come vnto the sacrament or no, and yt it is in their liberty whether they wyll take part of the lords table or no. <NOTE> But I deny that liberty,
column8: There Are Some that Are so minded that they think that when they have the word, it is not very necessary nor makes no great matter whither they come unto the sacrament or no, and that it is in their liberty whither they will take part of the Lords table or no. But I deny that liberty,

column7: & lai, yt al me are so sore bound to remembre this benefite receiued of God through Christ, as ye apostels wer, and often to reuolue it in heart and to giue thanks for it.
column8: & lai, that all me Are so soar bound to Remember this benefit received of God through christ, as you Apostles were, and often to revolve it in heart and to give thanks for it.

column7: For though I neither can, nor will bynd me vnto a certaine prescript, or peculier time to receiue this sacrament, yet it is necessarye, that wee consider the commaundement of Christe, and that oftentymes we accomplishe and in deede fulfyll it.
column8: For though I neither can, nor will bind me unto a certain prescript, or peculiar time to receive this sacrament, yet it is necessary, that we Consider the Commandment of Christ, and that oftentimes we accomplish and in deed fulfil it.

column7: Furthermore, it is a trewth and can not bee denied, but that by the woorde, there is offered vnto vs the remission of sinnes.
column8: Furthermore, it is a truth and can not be denied, but that by the word, there is offered unto us the remission of Sins.

column7: And in the same worde is this sacrament commaunded and comprehended, so that the one can not bee in onye wise deuided frome the other.
column8: And in the same word is this sacrament commanded and comprehended, so that the one can not be in onye wise divided from the other.

column7: Fiftely, considre nowe, who these be that vse this sacrament accordyngly: <NOTE> Douteles that are such as beleue.
column8: Fifty, Consider now, who these be that use this sacrament accordingly: Doubtless that Are such as believe.

column7: Ther is a promise in the lordes supper, that Christ wold giue his owne body vnto death for vs,
column8: There is a promise in the Lords supper, that christ would give his own body unto death for us,

column7: & that he wold shed his blud, to wash away our sinnes.
column8: & that he would shed his blood, to wash away our Sins.

column7: And in this promise there is no douting.
column8: And in this promise there is no doubting.

column7: But what profiteth this promise vnto me, excepte I receiue & take hold vpon it by faith?
column8: But what profiteth this promise unto me, except I receive & take hold upon it by faith?

column7: But yet if I wil be partaker of these thinges, it is necessary that I come in faith.
column8: But yet if I will be partaker of these things, it is necessary that I come in faith.

column7: For euery promise of God is receiued by faith.
column8: For every promise of God is received by faith.

column7: So likewise teacheth the senteces in ye gospell of Iohn:
column8: So likewise Teaches the senteces in you gospel of John:

column7: <NOTE> He that eateth this bread shal liue eternally.
column8: He that Eateth this bred shall live eternally.

column7: Item, The breade which I wil giue, it ys my flesh for the lyfe of the world.
column8: Item, The bread which I will give, it is my Flesh for the life of the world.

column7: Item, He that eateth my flesh and drinketh my bloud, continueth in me, and I in him &c.
column8: Item, He that Eateth my Flesh and Drinketh my blood, Continueth in me, and I in him etc.

column7: Al these sentences ar spoken of faith.
column8: All these sentences Are spoken of faith.

column7: Now who so cometh vnto the communion of the lordes supper not hauing this faithe, then not only hee eateth it not vnto his health and eternall life, but muche rather he taketh part of this sacramet vnto eternal codemnacio, as S.
column8: Now who so comes unto the communion of the Lords supper not having this faith, then not only he Eateth it not unto his health and Eternal life, but much rather he Takes part of this Sacrament unto Eternal codemnacio, as S.

column7: Paul in the epistle to the Cor. sufficiently sheweth and teacheth. <NOTE> Therfore if thou feele thy sinnes & knowest them,
column8: Paul in the epistle to the Cor. sufficiently shows and Teaches. Therefore if thou feel thy Sins & Knowest them,

column7: & woldest right gladly be delyuered from them,
column8: & Wouldst right gladly be Delivered from them,

column7: & desirest to growe, increase and waxe strong in faith, well, make hast & come to this supper.
column8: & Desirest to grow, increase and wax strong in faith, well, make haste & come to this supper.

column7: For in it thou shalt find, not only forgiuenes of sinnes,
column8: For in it thou shalt find, not only forgiveness of Sins,

column7: & that bi ye word, but also thou shalt feed thy soul with ye body & blud of Iesu Christ, a great coforting to thi faith.
column8: & that by you word, but also thou shalt feed thy soul with you body & blood of Jesu christ, a great coforting to thy faith.

column7: Furthermore, this sacrament shuld moue & stir vs to friendship, to liue quietly in peace, vnitie & concord,
column8: Furthermore, this sacrament should move & stir us to friendship, to live quietly in peace, unity & concord,

column7: & to put away all hatred, variance & discord.
column8: & to put away all hatred, variance & discord.

column7: & to testifie a brotherly & vnfained loue betwene vs.
column8: & to testify a brotherly & unfeigned love between us

column7: For whe we be made al partakers of this one table what ought we to thinke, but that we be al mebres of one spiritual body?
column8: For when we be made all partakers of this one table what ought we to think, but that we be all mebres of one spiritual body?

column7: that we be ioyned togither in one Christe, as a greate numbre of graines of corne bee ioyned togither in one lofe.
column8: that we be joined together in one Christ, as a great numbered of grains of corn be joined together in one lofe.

column7: Wherefore they that can not bee persuaded to bee good to their christian brethren (for whome Christ suffered death) when in this sacrament they be put in remembraunce, that the sonne of god bestowed his lyfe for his enemyes.
column8: Wherefore they that can not be persuaded to be good to their christian brothers (for whom christ suffered death) when in this sacrament they be put in remembrance, that the son of god bestowed his life for his enemies.

column7: We see dayly that eating and drinking togither, maketh friendes, and continueth friendship:
column8: We see daily that eating and drinking together, makes Friends, and Continueth friendship:

column7: Muche more then oughte the table of Christ to moue vs so to do, whereby we confesse vs to be all membres of one body, and acknowledge Christ to be giuen vs of God his father.
column8: Much more then ought the table of christ to move us so to do, whereby we confess us to be all members of one body, and acknowledge christ to be given us of God his father.

column7: To whome with the sonne and holye ghoste, be all honoure and glorye, for euer and euer.
column8: To whom with the son and holy ghost, be all honour and glory, for ever and ever.

column7: Amen. The gospell on the second sermon vppon the passion of our lorde. Iohn. 18.
column8: Amen. The gospel on the second sermon upon the passion of our lord. John. 18.

column7: W Hen Iesus had spoken these woordes,
column8: WHen WHen jesus had spoken these words,

column7: <NOTE> he went forth with his disciples, ouer the brooke Cedron, wher was a garden, into whyche he entred, and hys disciples.
column8: he went forth with his Disciples, over the brook Cedron, where was a garden, into which he entered, and his Disciples.

column7: Iudas also whiche betrayed him, knew the place, for Iesus ofte tymes resorted thyther with his disciples.
column8: Judas also which betrayed him, knew the place, for jesus oft times resorted thither with his Disciples.

column7: Iudas then after he had receiued a bonde of men,
column8: Judas then After he had received a bond of men,

column7: & ministers of the highe priestes and pharisees, came thither with lanternes, and fier brandes, and weapons.
column8: & Ministers of the high Priests and Pharisees, Come thither with lanterns, and fire brands, and weapons.

column7: And Iesus knowyng all things that shulde come on him, went forth, and sayde vnto them:
column8: And jesus knowing all things that should come on him, went forth, and said unto them:

column7: Whom seeke ye? They answered him:
column8: Whom seek you? They answered him:

column7: Iesus of Nazareth. Iesus sayth vnto them:
column8: jesus of Nazareth. jesus say unto them:

column7: I am he. Iudas also which betrayed hym, stode with them:
column8: I am he. Judas also which betrayed him, stood with them:

column7: As sone then as he had sayde vnto them,
column8: As soon then as he had said unto them,

column7: I am he. they went backeward and fell to the grounde.
column8: I am he. they went backward and fell to the ground.

column7: Then asked he them againe:
column8: Then asked he them again:

column7: Whom seek ye? They sayde:
column8: Whom seek you? They said:

column7: Iesus of Nazareth. Iesus answered:
column8: jesus of Nazareth. jesus answered:

column7: I haue tolde you, that I am he.
column8: I have told you, that I am he.

column7: If ye seeke me therfore, let these go theyr way, that the sayinges might be fulfilled whiche he spake:
column8: If you seek me Therefore, let these go their Way, that the sayings might be fulfilled which he spoke:

column7: <NOTE> Of them which thou gauest me, haue I not loste one.
column8: Of them which thou Gavest me, have I not lost one.

column7: Then Simon Peter hauynge a sworde, drewe it, and smote the high priestes seruaunt, and cutte of his right eare.
column8: Then Simon Peter having a sword, drew it, and smote the high Priests servant, and Cut of his right ear.

column7: The seruantes name was Maichus.
column8: The Servants name was Maichus.

column7: Therfore sayth Iesus vnto Peter:
column8: Therefore say jesus unto Peter:

column7: <NOTE> putte vp thy sworde into the sheath:
column8: put up thy sword into the sheath:

column7: Shall I not drynke of the cuppe whiche my father hath geuen me? THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Shall I not drink of the cup which my father hath given me? THE EXPOSITION.

column7: F Orasmuche (dearely beloued) as wee haue vndertake, to declare vnto you, and to set out the deare death and most bytter passion of our Lorde Iesus Christ:
column8: Forasmuch Forasmuch (dearly Beloved) as we have undertake, to declare unto you, and to Set out the deer death and most bitter passion of our Lord jesus christ:

column7: I haue thought it conuenient, and nede also requireth the same, that wee should first shew briefly, what is the vse of the same passion, and what vtilitee and fruit may come by it vnto vs.
column8: I have Thought it convenient, and need also requires the same, that we should First show briefly, what is the use of the same passion, and what utility and fruit may come by it unto us

column7: For there is no greatter folye, nor more worthye laughter, than to make only suche preachynges, as should moue mennes myndes to fret at the Iewes, because they dyd suche an horrible cryme against Christ & by such wordes take an occasion to curse & rebuke the traitour Iudas, and to condempne him.
column8: For there is no greater folly, nor more worthy laughter, than to make only such preachings, as should move men's minds to fret At the Jews, Because they did such an horrible crime against christ & by such words take an occasion to curse & rebuke the traitor Judas, and to condemn him.

column7: For surely here are to bee considered, thynges farre greatter and higher then those.
column8: For surely Here Are to be considered, things Far greater and higher then those.

column7: And what thynges are they that we ought here to consider?
column8: And what things Are they that we ought Here to Consider?

column7: Fyrst wee ought to ponder, what were the principal causes of that so great passion, whiche the most innocent labe of God suffered.
column8: Fyrst we ought to ponder, what were the principal Causes of that so great passion, which the most innocent Laban of God suffered.

column7: For if this be depely wayed and cosidered in the heart, it shall worke as muche in oure heartes, as dothe the preachyng of the lawe, whose office is commonly to set before oure eyes the huge greatnes of our synnes, to feare vs and to driue vs vnto dispayre.
column8: For if this be deeply weighed and considered in the heart, it shall work as much in our hearts, as doth the preaching of the law, whose office is commonly to Set before our eyes the huge greatness of our Sins, to Fear us and to driven us unto despair.

column7: But nowe, who were they that were the cause of that so paynful death and passion vnto Christ:
column8: But now, who were they that were the cause of that so painful death and passion unto christ:

column7: But then specially is it agreable, that he yt prayeth be alone, and farre from other, when his necessitee & panges of his mynd are great, that he may so much the more frely shed furth his whole heart, before the Lorde his God, and in his lappe laye furth all his aduersitee, whatsoeuer it be.
column8: But then specially is it agreeable, that he that Prayeth be alone, and Far from other, when his necessity & pangs of his mind Are great, that he may so much the more freely shed forth his Whole heart, before the Lord his God, and in his lap say forth all his adversity, whatsoever it be.

column8: Whensoever Therefore in our necessity, we ask any thing of our heavenly father for Christ's sake, we shall doubtless for christ, obtain help, Comfort, and all our hearts desire, and be assured of most sure consolation.

column8: Besides this, it was not long before, that he sat At one table with christ and his Apostles, and was partner of his Supper, and had heard, with how great patience and meekemes, (although in close words) the lord had called him unto Repentance.

column8: For there have been Some, which in the beginning when the gospel began to flourish, were so fervent and exceeding hearty, that in manner they did durst out all together with fervent love, and seemed as they would At ones devour the Whole gospel.

column8: What needeth more words? When such men ones fallen from the gospel, they run into such envy and hatred against it, that without doubt they would do as Judas Here does to his lord and master, if god Word permit unto them, occasion to do it.

column8: Paul of such false brothers? Therefore all christian men have a great cause, without ceasing to offer Prayers unto god by Christ, that not only he would bring us unto the true and right faith, but also that of his great mercy and unspeakable Goodness, he vouchsafe to conserve us in the same, unto the end.

column8: That he is merciful he shows in this, that in the midst of his adversity, he Cast not of the care for his Disciples, but is so careful for the that in their behalf he said unto his Adversaries the most greedily sought to drink his blood:

column8: I ever taught in the synnagog and in the Temple, whither all the jews resort, and in secret have I said nothing, why askest thou me?

column8: Answerest thou the high priest so?

column8: jesus answered him:

column8: If I have evil spoken, bear witness of evil:

column8: But if I have well spoken, why smytest thou me?

column8: Simon Peter stood and warmed him self.

column7: IN this part of the gospel we may consider, whyther Iesus was caryed after that Iudas had betrayd him, namely vnto the houses, fyrst of Annas & then vnto Cayphas.
column8: IN this part of the gospel we may Consider, whither jesus was carried After that Judas had betrayed him, namely unto the houses, fyrst of Annas & then unto Caiaphas.

column7: For Annas was Cayphas father in law.
column8: For Annas was Caiaphas father in law.

column7: What do I hear? <NOTE> Thynketh any ma that this is credyble, yt these men so vertuous, holy, and well learned, would couet to destroy a prophet of so great fame, a ma of suche innocent liuyng, yea one in whose mouth was found no guile, and would they (thynke you) laye assaultes to destroye him?
column8: What do I hear? Thinketh any ma that this is credyble, that these men so virtuous, holy, and well learned, would covet to destroy a Prophet of so great fame, a ma of such innocent living, yea one in whose Mouth was found no guile, and would they (think you) say assaults to destroy him?

column7: I praye you, howe agree these two to gether, that they be bothe so vertuous fathers,
column8: I pray you, how agree these two to gether, that they be both so virtuous Father's,

column7: & suche bloudthursty butchers? Surely these two thynges agree not very well, yet here wee see they agree in one.
column8: & such bloudthursty butchers? Surely these two things agree not very well, yet Here we see they agree in one.

column7: And though the Prophete Dauid often accuseth theim, as men mooste greadye to suppe innocent bloud, yet perchance they can cloke this theyr malicious mynde, and so hyde it, and excuse it, that they wyll, men should report them, as though thei did all this of an exceadyng great zeale, to defende the lawe of Moses, and the tradicions of the fathers, like as it is commonly practised, that their can bee imagined none so great or haynous a cryme against ye truth, but hypocrisie can before the worlde paint it out wt fayre colours,
column8: And though the Prophet David often Accuseth them, as men most greedy to sup innocent blood, yet perchance they can cloak this their malicious mind, and so hide it, and excuse it, that they will, men should report them, as though they did all this of an exceeding great zeal, to defend the law of Moses, and the traditions of the Father's, like as it is commonly practised, that their can be imagined none so great or heinous a crime against you truth, but hypocrisy can before the world paint it out with fair colours,

column7: <NOTE> yea and set it furthe with a glorious shyne of godlynes.
column8: yea and Set it forth with a glorious shine of godliness.

column7: Well, let hypocrisye vse her colours as long as she lust,
column8: Well, let hypocrisy use her colours as long as she lust,

column7: & deceiue men as much as she can.
column8: & deceive men as much as she can.

column7: For surely when ye truth cometh,
column8: For surely when you truth comes,

column7: & the light of the Gospell dothe shyne abrode, doubtlesse then it shall euidently appeare, what lay hydde in suche mennes heartes, and wherof that their zeale came, that is, of mere enuye and stubburne hatred, where with they are so set on fyre, and do fret against the truth, that they can by no meanes abyde it.
column8: & the Light of the Gospel doth shine abroad, doubtless then it shall evidently appear, what lay hid in such men's hearts, and whereof that their zeal Come, that is, of mere envy and stubborn hatred, where with they Are so Set on fire, and do fret against the truth, that they can by no means abide it.

column7: For why? the trueth so rebuketh and reprehendeth that outwarde shyne of righteous woorkes and all their holynes, and it sheweth, that althoughe outwardely they bee honest and vertuous, yet in heart they are detestable wretches, and bloudthursty dogges, vnto whom also God shall say at the laste day:
column8: For why? the truth so Rebuketh and reprehendeth that outward shine of righteous works and all their holiness, and it shows, that although outwardly they be honest and virtuous, yet in heart they Are detestable wretches, and bloudthursty Dogs, unto whom also God shall say At the laste day:

column7: Depart from me you workers of iniquitee,
column8: Depart from me you workers of iniquity,

column7: <NOTE> I know you not.
column8: I know you not.

column7: But this they can suffre in no wyse, and it is a double edged sworde in their heartes, when so euer they are compelled to heare these thynges spoken.
column8: But this they can suffer in no wise, and it is a double edged sword in their hearts, when so ever they Are compelled to hear these things spoken.

column7: Nowe forasmuche as Christ had tolde them their faultes many tymes, and euermore rebuked sharply their hypocrisy, they nowe therfore swarme together and gather their counsels, and for money do hyer the traytor to betray him,
column8: Now forasmuch as christ had told them their Faults many times, and evermore rebuked sharply their hypocrisy, they now Therefore swarm together and gather their Counsels, and for money do higher the traitor to betray him,

column7: <NOTE> and delyuer him into their handes.
column8: and deliver him into their hands.

column7: Yet do they not this to conserue and defede their lawe,
column8: Yet do they not this to conserve and defede their law,

column7: <NOTE> but this they do to oppresse ye truth, wherwith Christ had sore troubled them, and would in no wyse suffre their hypocrisye to bee estemed as righteousnes.
column8: but this they do to oppress you truth, wherewith christ had soar troubled them, and would in no wise suffer their hypocrisy to be esteemed as righteousness.

column7: This I say is ye only cause, why thei would so gladly rid Christ out of the way.
column8: This I say is the only cause, why they would so gladly rid christ out of the Way.

column7: I pray you who wyll nowe woder that in our daies our religious fathers, surely induced by this example, rage with suche crueltie against the woorde of God & his gospel?
column8: I pray you who will now woder that in our days our religious Father's, surely induced by this Exampl, rage with such cruelty against the word of God & his gospel?

column7: I assure you, they are not so vnwyse, but rightwell they can considre, what is expedient for them to do in this behalfe, and therefore they often assemble and cosulte among themselfes.
column8: I assure you, they Are not so unwise, but rightwell they can Consider, what is expedient for them to do in this behalf, and Therefore they often assemble and cosulte among themselves.

column7: For why, they see, if the gospell may goo furth and prospere, that this outward and carnal goddes seruice that they haue, this outward shewe of holynes that they crake vpon, wyll in shorte tyme bee very litle set by.
column8: For why, they see, if the gospel may goo forth and prosper, that this outward and carnal God's service that they have, this outward show of holiness that they crake upon, will in short time be very little Set by.

column7: And if these thynges ones be had in no reputacion, then doubtlesse that holy god of theirs (the belly) shall be iacke out of office,
column8: And if these things ones be had in no reputation, then doubtless that holy god of theirs (the belly) shall be jack out of office,

column7: & no more worshipped. And then men shal syng to him an Anthem nothyng pleasaunt, that is to say,
column8: & no more worshipped. And then men shall sing to him an Anthem nothing pleasant, that is to say,

column7: Labores manuum tuarum manducabis,
column8: Labores manuum tuarum manducabis,

column7: Thou shalt eate the labours of thyne owne handes.
column8: Thou shalt eat the labours of thine own hands.

column7: I pray you who wyll not with this be disquieted, and discotent in his mynd?
column8: I pray you who will not with this be disquieted, and discotent in his mind?

column7: Who of them wyll not take counsel to rydde this doctrin out of the waye?
column8: Who of them will not take counsel to rid this Doctrine out of the Way?

column7: Therefore in this place note diligently who they are that take Christe, bynde him, skourge him, and geue commaundement to crucify him, and you shal euidetly perceiue, what lyeth hyd vnder the hypocrisye of all men.
column8: Therefore in this place note diligently who they Are that take Christ, bind him, skourge him, and give Commandment to crucify him, and you shall euidetly perceive, what lies hid under the hypocrisy of all men.

column7: Secondarily it is not lightly to bee passed ouer,
column8: Secondarily it is not lightly to be passed over,

column7: <NOTE> but diligetly to be noted, that Christ, when he was examined before ye bishop as cocernyng his doctrin, he appealed vnto the hearers of his sermons, and defeded boldly and constatly the same his doctrin, as true doctrine.
column8: but diligetly to be noted, that christ, when he was examined before you bishop as cocernyng his Doctrine, he appealed unto the hearers of his Sermons, and defeded boldly and constatly the same his Doctrine, as true Doctrine.

column7: And so was it very necessary, that Christ should do.
column8: And so was it very necessary, that christ should do.

column7: For God not only requireth, that we shuld cotinually apply his doctrin, by teachyng, hearyng & learning it:
column8: For God not only requires, that we should continually apply his Doctrine, by teaching, hearing & learning it:

column7: but also that we should frely confesse it, and defende it, whensoeuer we should be examined of it.
column8: but also that we should freely confess it, and defend it, whensoever we should be examined of it.

column7: For Christendome standeth not, as somesay, in beleue well and holde thy tongue, but beleue and cofesse, as the Prophet sayth:
column8: For Christendom Stands not, as somesay, in believe well and hold thy tongue, but believe and cofesse, as the Prophet say:

column8: I believed and Therefore I spoke.

column7: But thou wylt say: I am no enemy of the worde, and asmuche as in me is,
column8: But thou wilt say: I am no enemy of the word, and asmuch as in me is,

column7: I can well suffre the gospel to be preached, if at the least it should not breake peace and concorde among the people.
column8: I can well suffer the gospel to be preached, if At the least it should not break peace and concord among the people.

column7: What is this? Sekest thou peace in this worlde, and wouldest thou haue constant frendship with it?
column8: What is this? Seekest thou peace in this world, and Wouldst thou have constant friendship with it?

column7: Doubtles it were a fayre thyng, if it might be possible to bryng it to passe.
column8: Doubtless it were a fair thing, if it might be possible to bring it to pass.

column7: And also I thynke there can no ma be found, but he rather would haue glad and mery dayes, then tribulacion and persecucions.
column8: And also I think there can no ma be found, but he rather would have glad and merry days, then tribulation and persecutions.

column7: <NOTE> But would he so that sayd:
column8: But would he so that said:

column7: I am not come to sende peace vpon yearth, but a sworde?
column8: I am not come to send peace upon earth, but a sword?

column7: I suppose his mynde is not so.
column8: I suppose his mind is not so.

column7: <NOTE> For if thou wylt haue peace wt this worlde, then nedes must thou lacke the worde, and all the good thynges that in it are offered and geuen to thee.
column8: For if thou wilt have peace with this world, then needs must thou lack the word, and all the good things that in it Are offered and given to thee.

column7: But if yu wylt haue the worde, nedes must thou also haue the crosse, whiche ye worde bryngeth with it, and thou muste willyngly take it and perseuer in the same vnto the ende of thy life.
column8: But if thou wilt have the word, needs must thou also have the cross, which you word bringeth with it, and thou must willingly take it and persever in the same unto the end of thy life.

column7: Yea though one crosse would folowe vpon another, and lye moste heauily vpon thy necke. euen as the prophet Dauid also sayth:
column8: Yea though one cross would follow upon Another, and lie most heavily upon thy neck. even as the Prophet David also say:

column7: <NOTE> And I spake of thy testimonies in the presence of Kynges, and I was not ashamed.
column8: And I spoke of thy testimonies in the presence of Kings, and I was not ashamed.

column7: <NOTE> And note that vnto the sufferance of ye crosse, wee neede muche pacience:
column8: And note that unto the sufferance of the cross, we need much patience:

column7: and vnto the defence of the worde we must haue a mouthe, that can speake with out fear.
column8: and unto the defence of the word we must have a Mouth, that can speak with out Fear.

column7: <NOTE> For although Christ had taught that if a manne were stryken vpon the right cheake, he should turne the other also, yet wyll he not nowe approue this strype geue him, by sylence and holdyng his peace, but he sayd:
column8: For although christ had taught that if a man were stricken upon the right cheake, he should turn the other also, yet will he not now approve this stripe give him, by silence and holding his peace, but he said:

column7: If I haue spoken euil, bryng wytnesse of that euil.
column8: If I have spoken evil, bring witness of that evil.

column7: But if I sayd well, why doest thou stryke me?
column8: But if I said well, why dost thou strike me?

column7: Christ toke this strype paciently, as the scripture sayth:
column8: christ took this stripe patiently, as the scripture say:

column7: When he was raysed vpon, he dyd not geue euil woordes agayne.
column8: When he was raised upon, he did not give evil words again.

column7: When he was euil intreated, he did not thret them.
column8: When he was evil entreated, he did not thret them.

column7: Yet could not hee approue that their iniust delyng, as a thyng well done.
column8: Yet could not he approve that their injust dealing, as a thing well done.

column7: And euen so it is expedient for euerye christian manne to do, that is, he ought doubtlesse freely to confesse the trueth before the worlde and all men, as did the Prophetes, sainct Ihon Baptist,
column8: And even so it is expedient for every christian man to do, that is, he ought doubtless freely to confess the truth before the world and all men, as did the prophets, saint John Baptist,

column7: Christ himselfe and the Apostles, and as al the elect synce the beginnyng of the worlde haue done.
column8: christ himself and thee Apostles, and as all the elect since the beginning of the world have done.

column7: And if he therfore be skorned, beaten, persecuted, and codempned of menne, he ought after the ensample of Christ, with quiete and pacient mynde, to take vpo him, and suffre suche iniurye & persecucion.
column8: And if he Therefore be scorned, beaten, persecuted, and codempned of men, he ought After the ensample of christ, with quiet and patient mind, to take upon him, and suffer such injury & persecution.

column7: Yet not withstandyng, he ought not to approue nor prayse their quarel that so do, nor yet suffre, that by his silence suche tyrannye bee approued or lauded, but with free and vnfearful open mouth, let him shewe that this their vniust dealyng is euil and vnrighteous, as in ded it is nothyng els but vnrighteous and wycked.
column8: Yet not withstanding, he ought not to approve nor praise their quarrel that so do, nor yet suffer, that by his silence such tyranny be approved or lauded, but with free and unfearful open Mouth, let him show that this their unjust dealing is evil and unrighteous, as in dead it is nothing Else but unrighteous and wicked.

column7: <NOTE> And therfore also is it that S.
column8: And Therefore also is it that S.

column7: Paule requireth in a bishop, that he bee mightie and able to exhorte with true doctryne, and to conuince the againsayers.
column8: Paul requires in a bishop, that he be mighty and able to exhort with true Doctrine, and to convince the againsayers.

column7: Thyrdly, wee haue nowe the fall of sainct Peter,
column8: Thirdly, we have now the fallen of saint Peter,

column7: <NOTE> whom we ought diligently to consider and marke.
column8: whom we ought diligently to Consider and mark.

column7: For we not only beholde in him, how foolish, rashe and vnwise the presumption of man is, but also we learne in him, that when a manne hath by frailtye fallen, he shulde not by and by dispaire, but muche rather looke vnto the goodnesse and clemencye of Christe, by the which Peter was againe receiued,
column8: For we not only behold in him, how foolish, rash and unwise the presumption of man is, but also we Learn in him, that when a man hath by frailty fallen, he should not by and by despair, but much rather look unto the Goodness and clemency of Christ, by the which Peter was again received,

column7: & obtained remission of all his sinnes.
column8: & obtained remission of all his Sins.

column7: Doubteles, it was a greate presumption that hee promised to go with Christ, euen vnto the very death, and by this presumtion fel he into so great sinne.
column8: Doubtless, it was a great presumption that he promised to go with christ, even unto the very death, and by this presumption fell he into so great sin.

column7: For how shuld fleshe wishe for death, seing that very nature hathe so disposed the flesh, that she rather desireth a quiet and pleasant liuinge?
column8: For how should Flesh wish for death, sing that very nature hath so disposed the Flesh, that she rather Desires a quiet and pleasant living?

column7: For euen he that is indued with the holye ghost, hath much a do to take heed, least in death he be ouercome or dispair:
column8: For even he that is endued with the holy ghost, hath much a do to take heed, lest in death he be overcome or despair:

column7: much lesse may we thinke, that of our owne strength we maye be able to stande againste it.
column8: much less may we think, that of our own strength we may be able to stand against it.

column7: Wherefore we oughte to be very circumspecte and ware, that we presume not, but that we stand in fear euermore. yet for all that, contynually beseching god the father, that he will voutchsafe for his sonne Christes sake, to comforte vs with his holy spirite, that we be ouercome in no temptacion, but that euermore wee maye perceiue and feele his helpe, strength and consolacion.
column8: Wherefore we ought to be very circumspect and aware, that we presume not, but that we stand in Fear evermore. yet for all that, continually beseeching god the father, that he will vouchsafe for his son Christ's sake, to Comfort us with his holy Spirit, that we be overcome in no temptation, but that evermore we may perceive and feel his help, strength and consolation.

column7: For certainly this is truthe that the prophet saith:
column8: For Certainly this is truth that the Prophet Says:

column7: The lorde is my helper,
column8: The lord is my helper,

column7: <NOTE> I will not feare what man can doo to me. <NOTE> And thoughe it chaunce sometyme while we liue here, that we fal, yet let not our heart giue ouer, nor we maye not dispaire, but by and by arise againe, and also call againe for the grace and mercy of god.
column8: I will not Fear what man can do to me. And though it chance sometime while we live Here, that we fall, yet let not our heart give over, nor we may not despair, but by and by arise again, and also call again for the grace and mercy of god.

column7: For surely Christe hath euen now the same mynd,
column8: For surely Christ hath even now the same mind,

column7: <NOTE> that he had then, when he receiued Peter againe into his fauoure.
column8: that he had then, when he received Peter again into his favour.

column7: The Anabaptystes of this our tyme, deny that those maye retorne again to grace, which ones knew the truth and afterward againe fell into synne:
column8: The Anabaptists of this our time, deny that those may return again to grace, which ones knew the truth and afterwards again fell into sin:

column7: and as muche as in them is, poore Peter and wee all should perishe and be perpetually codempned.
column8: and as much as in them is, poor Peter and we all should perish and be perpetually codempned.

column7: But sett their folishe bablyng light, for they bee vayne, and vayne they continue.
column8: But Set their foolish babbling Light, for they be vain, and vain they continue.

column7: But rather consider thou howe Peter fell, and was againe receiued into grace, and so shalte thou gette profite by consideryng it. <NOTE> And note diligently in what place Peter fel & commytted that great sinne, namely, he fell in the Byshoppes palace.
column8: But rather Consider thou how Peter fell, and was again received into grace, and so shalt thou get profit by considering it. And note diligently in what place Peter fell & committed that great sin, namely, he fell in the Bishops palace.

column7: And of this place mayst thou learne, howe great ieopardy it is to preachers of the woorde of God, often to vse the courtes of great men of the worlde:
column8: And of this place Mayest thou Learn, how great jeopardy it is to Preachers of the word of God, often to use the Courts of great men of the world:

column7: and especially for these consideracions.
column8: and especially for these considerations.

column7: Fyrst, <NOTE> it is an honesty for a man (as courtyers repute it) ofte to haunt voluptuous pleasures, with a certain pride & dignitie to excell other, whiche thynges in deede as suche tempatacions, maye easely moue and breake a right godly man.
column8: Fyrst, it is an honesty for a man (as courtiers repute it) oft to haunt voluptuous pleasures, with a certain pride & dignity to excel other, which things in deed as such tempatacions, may Easily move and break a right godly man.

column7: Then furthermore, Sathan him selfe also is very ready,
column8: Then furthermore, Sathan him self also is very ready,

column7: & our fleshe is exceadyng weake, so that without doubt here needeth great carefulnes and studious hede to be taken.
column8: & our Flesh is exceeding weak, so that without doubt Here needs great carefulness and studious heed to be taken.

column7: But what shal the preacher of Gods truth do here?
column8: But what shall the preacher of God's truth do Here?

column7: Forsoth thus. He may not haue to great loue vnto the courtly daintie fare, nor to muche acquaint himselfe with those whiche in the court do seke none other thyng but voluptuous pleasures, honor, porte,
column8: Forsooth thus. He may not have to great love unto the courtly dainty fare, nor to much acquaint himself with those which in the court do seek none other thing but voluptuous pleasures, honour, port,

column7: & in suche thynges haue their heauen, but he ought diligently to remembre his office, and geue all his care and studye, well to rule with the sworde of God, and continually to whet that vpon theim.
column8: & in such things have their heaven, but he ought diligently to Remember his office, and give all his care and study, well to Rule with the sword of God, and continually to whet that upon them.

column7: Doubtlesse the maner of courtiers is suche, that for a tyme yu shalt be welbeloued & accepted, and thou shalt haue geue the swete wordes enough, especially if thou seldom talke of the truth and can well lyft a great chalice, and be a fayre Masser:
column8: Doubtless the manner of courtiers is such, that for a time thou shalt be well-beloved & accepted, and thou shalt have give the sweet words enough, especially if thou seldom talk of the truth and can well lift a great chalice, and be a fair Masser:

column7: But if thou wylt play ye true preacher, and tell euery man his vice and synne (as in deede it shalbe thy duetie) surely thou shalte sone perceiue, whether moo Iosephes & Danyels dwell in the court, or els Herodes and Aman.
column8: But if thou wilt play you true preacher, and tell every man his vice and sin (as in deed it shall thy duty) surely thou shalt soon perceive, whither moo Joseph's & Daniel's dwell in the court, or Else Herod and Haman

column7: And to say the truth,
column8: And to say the truth,

column7: Herode could very well abyde Ihon Baptist,
column8: Herod could very well abide John Baptist,

column7: <NOTE> and gladly hearde he him.
column8: and gladly heard he him.

column7: But when Ihon rebuked him for the adultry, by and by all his fauour was lost,
column8: But when John rebuked him for the adultery, by and by all his favour was lost,

column7: & Ihon was fayne to pay no lesse then his head for ye great fauor he had in the court.
column8: & John was fain to pay no less then his head for you great favour he had in the court.

column7: Finally, In kynges and prynces courtes, thou shalte fynde very fewe Daniels, but as Christ sayd, suche as are clothed in fyne softe sylkes, so that thou shalt haue great nede, to be verye ware and wyse, if thou wylte dwell and be conuersant among courtiers.
column8: Finally, In Kings and Princes Courts, thou shalt find very few Daniel's, but as christ said, such as Are clothed in fine soft sylkes, so that thou shalt have great need, to be very aware and wise, if thou wilt dwell and be conversant among courtiers.

column7: The fourth sermon on the Passion of our Lord Iesu Christ. Ihon. xviii.
column8: The fourth sermon on the Passion of our Lord Jesu christ. John xviii.

column7: T Hen led they Iesus from Cayphas into the hall of iudgement.
column8: THen THen led they jesus from Caiaphas into the hall of judgement.

column7: It was in the mornyng, and they them selues went not into the iudgement hall, lest they should be defyled, but that they might eate the passeouer.
column8: It was in the morning, and they them selves went not into the judgement hall, lest they should be defiled, but that they might eat the passover.

column7: Pylate then went out vnto theim,
column8: Pilate then went out unto them,

column7: & sayd: what accusacios bryng you against this man?
column8: & said: what accusacios bring you against this man?

column7: They answered and sayd vnto him:
column8: They answered and said unto him:

column7: If he were not an euil doer, wee would not haue deliuered him vnto thee.
column8: If he were not an evil doer, we would not have Delivered him unto thee.

column7: Then sayd Pylate vnto them, take ye him, and iudge him after your owne lawe.
column8: Then said Pilate unto them, take you him, and judge him After your own law.

column7: The Iewes therfore sayd vnto him:
column8: The Jews Therefore said unto him:

column7: it is not lawful for vs to put any manne to death.
column8: it is not lawful for us to put any man to death.

column7: That the woordes of Iesus might bee fulfylled <NOTE> whiche he spake, signifiyng what death he should dye.
column8: That the words of jesus might be fulfilled which he spoke, signifying what death he should die.

column7: <NOTE> Then Pylate entred into the iudgement hall againe,
column8: Then Pilate entered into the judgement hall again,

column7: & called Iesus, and sayd vnto him:
column8: & called jesus, and said unto him:

column7: Art thou the kyng of the Iewes?
column8: Art thou the King of the Jews?

column7: <NOTE> Iesus answered:
column8: jesus answered:

column7: Sayest thou that of thy self, or hath any other told it thee of me?
column8: Sayest thou that of thy self, or hath any other told it thee of me?

column7: Pylate answered: Am I a Iewe?
column8: Pilate answered: Am I a Jew?

column7: Thyne owne nation & hye priestes haue deliuered the vnto me.
column8: Thine own Nation & high Priests have Delivered thee unto me.

column7: What hast thou done? Iesus answered:
column8: What hast thou done? jesus answered:

column7: My kyngdom is not of this world, if my kyngdome were of this worlde, then would my ministers surely fight, that I should not be deliuered to ye Iewes, but nowe is my kyngdome not from hence.
column8: My Kingdom is not of this world, if my Kingdom were of this world, then would my Ministers surely fight, that I should not be Delivered to you Jews, but now is my Kingdom not from hence.

column7: Pylate therfore sayd vnto him:
column8: Pilate Therefore said unto him:

column7: Arte thou a kyng the?
column8: Art thou a King the?

column7: Iesus answered: Thou sayst that I am a kyng.
column8: jesus answered: Thou Sayest that I am a King.

column7: <NOTE> For this cause was I borne, and for this cause came I into the worlde, that I should beare wytnesse vnto the truth.
column8: For this cause was I born, and for this cause Come I into the world, that I should bear witness unto the truth.

column7: And al that are of ye truth heare my voyce.
column8: And all that Are of the truth hear my voice.

column7: Pilate sayd vnto him: What thing is truth?
column8: Pilate said unto him: What thing is truth?

column7: And when he had sayd this, he wet out againe vnto the Iewes, and sayth vnto them: <NOTE> I fynde in him no cause at all.
column8: And when he had said this, he wet out again unto the Jews, and say unto them: I find in him no cause At all.

column7: Ye haue a custome, that I should deliuer you one lose at Easter. will ye that I lose vnto you the kyng of the Iewes?
column8: You have a custom, that I should deliver you one loose At Easter. will you that I loose unto you the King of the Jews?

column7: Then cryed they all again, saiyng:
column8: Then cried they all again, saying:

column7: <NOTE> Not him, but Barrabas.
column8: Not him, but Barabbas.

column7: Thesame Barrabas was a murtherer THE EXPOSITION.
column8: The same Barabbas was a murderer THE EXPOSITION.

column7: AS before the Euangelist hath plainly described the hypocrisy of the Bishops and Phariseis, in that they (as men zelous for the lawe) tooke Christ and bound him,
column8: AS before the Evangelist hath plainly described the hypocrisy of the Bishops and Pharisees, in that they (as men zealous for the law) took christ and bound him,

column7: & caried him to and fro, from post to pyller, nowe hether, nowe thyther, euen so now in this part of the gospel, is set out the hypocrisy of al the people:
column8: & carried him to and from, from post to pyller, now hither, now thither, even so now in this part of the gospel, is Set out the hypocrisy of all the people:

column7: so that it is true that the prophet Oseas sayth:
column8: so that it is true that the Prophet Hosea say:

column7: that as the people is,
column8: that as the people is,

column7: <NOTE> suche are ye priestes.
column8: such Are the Priests.

column7: For in yt they ledde vnto their lawe hall,
column8: For in that they led unto their law hall,

column7: Christ that innocent lambe of God,
column8: christ that innocent lamb of God,

column7: & there to deliuer him to the slaughter, they haue no coscience nor grudge at this:
column8: & there to deliver him to the slaughter, they have no conscience nor grudge At this:

column7: but rather they are persuaded, that they do God high seruice. <NOTE> Furthermore they thynke them selues sufficietly clensed and pure, if they take hede to this onely, that they go not into the lawe hall.
column8: but rather they Are persuaded, that they do God high service. Furthermore they think them selves sufficietly cleansed and pure, if they take heed to this only, that they go not into the law hall.

column7: What is this, <NOTE> but to strain out a gnat, and swalow or deuour a Camel:
column8: What is this, but to strain out a gnat, and swallow or devour a Camel:

column7: to make cleane the outwarde part of the cuppe and platter, but to leaue it within full of rauin and intemperancye?
column8: to make clean the outward part of the cup and platter, but to leave it within full of ravine and intemperancy?

column7: To this also pertaineth it yt thei say vnto Pylate:
column8: To this also pertaineth it that they say unto Pilate:

column7: It is not leful for vs to sley any ma.
column8: It is not leful for us to slay any ma.

column7: I beseche ye, durst not they murther a man, yt in their heartes had adiudged Christ to death?
column8: I beseech you, durst not they murder a man, that in their hearts had adjudged christ to death?

column7: You see now in this, what is the nature of Hypocrisy.
column8: You see now in this, what is the nature of Hypocrisy.

column7: <NOTE> Truely this, with outwarde workes to beare a beutyful shewe, willyng outwardly to be reputed good and honest, rather then to be so in dede:
column8: Truly this, with outward works to bear a beutyful show, willing outwardly to be reputed good and honest, rather then to be so in deed:

column7: contemnyng all other, dispisyng and condemnyng them, in comparison to them selues.
column8: contemning all other, despising and condemning them, in comparison to them selves.

column7: And especially hypocrisy is ragyng wod,
column8: And especially hypocrisy is raging wood,

column7: & in a fury against suche as condempne her outward workes and reiecte her as an enemy vnto righteousnes that is of fayth.
column8: & in a fury against such as condemn her outward works and reject her as an enemy unto righteousness that is of faith.

column7: Nowe then begynneth she to bee horne wodde and can not containe her wrath, but rather would (if she had power so to do) murther all men,
column8: Now then beginneth she to be horn wood and can not contain her wrath, but rather would (if she had power so to do) murder all men,

column7: & comyt them to tormentors to be hewen in pieces, then she would suffre one iote of her outwarde holynes & honestye to bee defaced.
column8: & comyt them to tormentors to be hewn in Pieces, then she would suffer one jot of her outward holiness & honesty to be defaced.

column7: <NOTE> And of this commeth it, that Christe sayd himselfe:
column8: And of this comes it, that Christ said himself:

column7: that when suche should murther christians, they shuld thynke that they did high seruice to God.
column8: that when such should murder Christians, they should think that they did high service to God.

column7: Wherfore, whosoeuer wyl be a true christian, he must nedes leaue all hypocrisy,
column8: Wherefore, whosoever will be a true christian, he must needs leave all hypocrisy,

column7: & onely study howe to abtain the rightousnes of fayth.
column8: & only study how to abtain the righteousness of faith.

column7: For fayth gladly is occupied in inward and spiritual thinges and forceth not greatly for outward thynges.
column8: For faith gladly is occupied in inward and spiritual things and forceth not greatly for outward things.

column7: Furthermore, it more gladly suffereth paciently all damage and iniurye, then to do any to other.
column8: Furthermore, it more gladly suffers patiently all damage and injury, then to do any to other.

column7: But how do the Iewes here?
column8: But how do the Jews Here?

column7: Forsoth they wyl not entre into the Consistorye, but this they woulde,
column8: Forsooth they will not enter into the Consistory, but this they would,

column7: <NOTE> ye and that with all their hartes, that Christe were murthered, and hanged vpon the crosse.
column8: you and that with all their hearts, that Christ were murdered, and hanged upon the cross.

column7: Neither is ther anye that one whit is moued with mercy or pitye toward Christe, but they al at ones with a loud voice crye:
column8: Neither is there any that one whit is moved with mercy or pity towards Christ, but they all At ones with a loud voice cry:

column7: Crucifie him, Crucifie him.
column8: Crucify him, Crucify him.

column7: They all are vnpure in heart, therfore must it needes be vnpure all that euer they do.
column8: They all Are unpure in heart, Therefore must it needs be unpure all that ever they do.

column7: Wherfore is it right yt the Iewes receiue such reward.
column8: Wherefore is it right that the Jews receive such reward.

column7: Contrarily, for as much as al christias ar pure in hert, al things also that thei do, are pure & cleane.
column8: Contrarily, for as much as all Christians Are pure in heart, all things also that they do, Are pure & clean.

column7: And doubtles this benefite obtain we by ye faith, which is in Christ Iesu our lord.
column8: And doubtless this benefit obtain we by you faith, which is in christ Jesu our lord.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> we haue in this talkyng of Pylat with Christe a notable sentence, and woorthy to bee kepte in memorie, of the kyngdome of Christ, what forme it muste haue in this worlde, and what state it shall haue in the world to come.
column8: Secondarily, we have in this talking of Pilate with Christ a notable sentence, and worthy to be kept in memory, of the Kingdom of christ, what Form it must have in this world, and what state it shall have in the world to come.

column7: For Pylat scornfully aposeth Christ in this manner:
column8: For Pilate scornfully aposeth christ in this manner:

column7: Arte thou that kynge of the Iewes?
column8: Art thou that King of the Jews?

column7: Euen as scornefullye hee asked him:
column8: Eve as scornfully he asked him:

column7: What is trewth? And nowe to this question Christ giueth a noble answer, not for Pilates sake, whiche in deede not so muche as desired to be partener of this kingedome, but for oure sake, that we myght knowe howe to prepare oure selues well to thys kyngedome, and ryghtlye to thynke, and teache of it.
column8: What is truth? And now to this question christ gives a noble answer, not for Pilate's sake, which in deed not so much as desired to be partner of this Kingdom, but for our sake, that we might know how to prepare our selves well to this Kingdom, and rightly to think, and teach of it.

column7: For suerly euerye man can not iudge rightlye of this kingdome, for as much as in it all things are done contrary to our iudgment. <NOTE>
column8: For surely every man can not judge rightly of this Kingdom, for as much as in it all things Are done contrary to our judgement.

column7: And I pray you, how shuld we haue any beliefe, or certain knowledg of this kingdome, except God wold giue vs his spirite?
column8: And I pray you, how should we have any belief, or certain knowledge of this Kingdom, except God would give us his Spirit?

column7: For doubteles this kyngedome is hidde wyth a crosse in this worlde, and lyethe secret vnder it.
column8: For doubtless this Kingdom is hid with a cross in this world, and lieth secret under it.

column7: And the lorde of this kingdom was as a malefactor betwene two murtherers nailed to ye crosse.
column8: And the lord of this Kingdom was as a Malefactor between two murderers nailed to you cross.

column7: I assure you Pilate him selfe beleued not, that Christ had ony kingdome, although he heard that layd to Christes charge.
column8: I assure you Pilate him self believed not, that christ had only Kingdom, although he herd that laid to Christ's charge.

column7: Nor the Iewes them selues beleued it, that he had a kingdom, although in very deede, at a certaine time they wold violently haue taken him, and haue made him their king, as S.
column8: Nor the Jews them selves believed it, that he had a Kingdom, although in very deed, At a certain time they would violently have taken him, and have made him their King, as S.

column7: Iohn writeth in his gospel,
column8: John Writeth in his gospel,

column7: <NOTE> saying: But Iesus when he knew yt they wold come & by strengthe take him, and make him kinge, he fled agayne into the mountayne him selfe alone. &c. <NOTE> Wherefore, it is verye conuenient for a christian man, diligently to considre & note what is here said, that he may perceiue and vnderstand it.
column8: saying: But jesus when he knew that they would come & by strength take him, and make him King, he fled again into the mountain him self alone. etc. Wherefore, it is very convenient for a christian man, diligently to Consider & note what is Here said, that he may perceive and understand it.

column7: My kingdome (saith Christ) is not of this world.
column8: My Kingdom (Says christ) is not of this world.

column7: Yf it be not of this world, what kingdom is it the,
column8: If it be not of this world, what Kingdom is it the,

column7: & in what thiges cosisteth it?
column8: & in what thiges cosisteth it?

column7: <NOTE> Blessed S. Paul shal answer this.
column8: Blessed S. Paul shall answer this.

column7: The kigdom of god (saith he) is not meat & drink, but righteousnes, peace and ioy in the holy ghoste.
column8: The Kingdom of god (Says he) is not meat & drink, but righteousness, peace and joy in the holy ghost.

column7: Suerly he that with these things serueth god is accepted vnto god, and aloweable afore men.
column8: Surely he that with these things serveth god is accepted unto god, and aloweable afore men.

column7: Thou hearest in this place, that the kingdome of Christ is nothing else, but righteousnes, peace and ioy in the holy ghost.
column8: Thou Hearst in this place, that the Kingdom of christ is nothing Else, but righteousness, peace and joy in the holy ghost.

column7: But fro whence cometh this righteousnes?
column8: But from whence comes this righteousness?

column7: <NOTE> Of faith, as the scripture saithe:
column8: Of faith, as the scripture Saith:

column7: To him that beleueth, his faithe is imputed for ryghteousnes.
column8: To him that Believeth, his faith is imputed for righteousness.

column7: But now whereof commeth faythe?
column8: But now whereof comes faith?

column7: Of the worde. (as S.
column8: Of the word. (as S.

column7: Paule saith) Faith cometh of hearing,
column8: Paul Says) Faith comes of hearing,

column7: <NOTE> and hearing, by the worde of god.
column8: and hearing, by the word of god.

column7: Furthermore, where the woorde is, there is also faithe:
column8: Furthermore, where the word is, there is also faith:

column7: and where fayth is, there is ryhhteousnes, and wher ryghteousnes is, there ys peace in conscience,
column8: and where faith is, there is ryhhteousnes, and where righteousness is, there is peace in conscience,

column7: & where peace in consciences is, there is spiritual ioy.
column8: & where peace in Consciences is, there is spiritual joy.

column7: Wherfore, where righteousnes, peace and ioye is, there is also the kyngdom of God, as the Apostle sayth, and we also haue alleged it before.
column8: Wherefore, where righteousness, peace and joy is, there is also the Kingdom of God, as the Apostle say, and we also have alleged it before.

column7: Of this nowe it foloweth, yt the kyngdome of Christe standeth not in outwarde thynges, in outwarde power and administracion of cyuil thynges, nor in any pompe or any proude porte, but in the worde of God, in spirite and fayth, like as Christ sayd in another place:
column8: Of this now it Followeth, that the Kingdom of Christ Stands not in outward things, in outward power and administration of cyuil things, nor in any pomp or any proud port, but in the word of God, in Spirit and faith, like as christ said in Another place:

column7: <NOTE> The kyngdom of God is wtin you.
column8: The Kingdom of God is within you.

column7: Yet notwithstadig, it is so couered with ye crosse, that it can be seen or knowe of no ma, but of him, to whom it is geuen of God to se it.
column8: Yet notwithstadig, it is so covered with you cross, that it can be seen or know of no ma, but of him, to whom it is given of God to see it.

column7: Thyrdly, <NOTE> here is set furth the example of a wicked Iudge in Pylate.
column8: Thirdly, Here is Set forth the Exampl of a wicked Judge in Pilate.

column7: For he, although he well considered ye innocency of Christ,
column8: For he, although he well considered you innocency of christ,

column7: & was well ascertained that he had not deserued ye death, as he himself also confessed:
column8: & was well ascertained that he had not deserved you death, as he himself also confessed:

column7: yet for the frendship & fauor of the Iewes only, he deliuered Iesus to ye ministers to be scourged, to be crouned with thornes, to bee spyt vpon & stryken.
column8: yet for the friendship & favour of the Jews only, he Delivered jesus to you Ministers to be scourged, to be crowned with thorns, to be spit upon & stricken.

column7: Besydes all this (was it not a great blyndnes) hee was scourged and most vyllainously entreated.
column8: Besides all this (was it not a great blindness) he was scourged and most vyllainously entreated.

column7: Furthermore, he brought him furth & sayd:
column8: Furthermore, he brought him forth & said:

column7: Behold, I bring him furth to you, yt you may know that I haue founde in him no cause worthy death.
column8: Behold, I bring him forth to you, that you may know that I have found in him no cause worthy death.

column7: If yu fynde no cause in him worthy of death,
column8: If thou find no cause in him worthy of death,

column7: I pray the Pylate, why dyddest yu delyuer him to the Iewes to be scourged, and sufferest ye souldiers & seruantes to vse so great tyrannye and euyl agaynst hym?
column8: I pray the Pilate, why didst thou deliver him to the Jews to be scourged, and sufferest the Soldiers & Servants to use so great tyranny and evil against him?

column7: Or wherefore sayest thou afterwarde:
column8: Or Wherefore Sayest thou afterward:

column7: Take him you, and crucify him accordyng to your lawe, as for me I fynd no cause in hym?
column8: Take him you, and crucify him according to your law, as for me I find no cause in him?

column7: Is this ye offce of a Iudge to deliuer an innocent couict by no wytnesse, into ye hades of his enemyes?
column8: Is this the office of a Judge to deliver an innocent couict by no witness, into the hades of his enemies?

column7: Euen thus surely it cometh to passe, when men wyll be Iudges and retayne the fauour of menne, as it chaunsed here vnto Pylate.
column8: Eve thus surely it comes to pass, when men will be Judges and retain the favour of men, as it chanced Here unto Pilate.

column7: But what sayth God in this matter?
column8: But what say God in this matter?

column7: Forsoth thus: In waye of iudgement bee not thou an acceptor of persones.
column8: Forsooth thus: In Way of judgement be not thou an acceptor of Persons.

column7: <NOTE> that is: In iudgement thou shalt do to a straunger and vnknowen, as to thy frende and acquayntaunce.
column8: that is: In judgement thou shalt do to a stranger and unknown, as to thy friend and acquaintance.

column7: Deale with the poore as with the ryche.
column8: Deal with the poor as with the rich.

column7: And briefly, be to one man, as to another, so that no man maye haue iust occasion to complayne either of violence, tyranny, affection or fauour, parcialitee or iniustice.
column8: And briefly, be to one man, as to Another, so that no man may have just occasion to complain either of violence, tyranny, affection or favour, parcialitee or injustice.

column7: But this dothe not Pylate here regarde, but lest he should lese Cesars fauour, he willyngly doth that thyng for ye Iewes pleasure, that he was very well ascertayned to be vniust and vntrue.
column8: But this doth not Pilate Here regard, but lest he should less Caesars favour, he willingly does that thing for the Jews pleasure, that he was very well ascertained to be unjust and untrue.

column7: For why, with his owne mouthe he pronounceth, that he founde no cause in Christ worthy death, and yet presumeth he to doo this horrible facte to condempne Christe, and to adiudge him to deathe.
column8: For why, with his own Mouth he pronounceth, that he found no cause in christ worthy death, and yet Presumeth he to do this horrible fact to condemn Christ, and to adjudge him to death.

column7: Nowe lette vs not thynke, but that euen in oure tyme lyke iniquitee maye bee founde,
column8: Now let us not think, but that even in our time like iniquity may be found,

column7: <NOTE> yea dayly lyke ensamples are doone before our eyes, if menne wyll at the least open theyr eyes and looke vpon theim.
