column8: yea daily like ensamples Are done before our eyes, if men will At the least open their eyes and look upon them.

column7: For where Christ oure Lorde is, and reigneth by his woorde, spirite and Gospell, there muste it needes bee also, that the poore Christians suffre all tyranny of the enemyes of the Gospel, yea though theyr behauour be suche, that they offende and hurte no man.
column8: For where christ our Lord is, and Reigneth by his word, Spirit and Gospel, there must it needs be also, that the poor Christians suffer all tyranny of the enemies of the Gospel, yea though their behaviour be such, that they offend and hurt no man.

column7: Furthermore it is impossible, but suche as bee aduersaryes of the trueth, shall together conspire against it, yea though they before were most vtter enemies, as in this place we se Pylate & Herode do.
column8: Furthermore it is impossible, but such as bee Adversaries of the truth, shall together conspire against it, yea though they before were most utter enemies, as in this place we see Pilate & Herod do.

column7: Euen so in our tyme, wee see them that before were mortal enemies,
column8: Eve so in our time, we see them that before were Mortal enemies,

column7: & at dissencion wt in them selues, nowe they become hye louers & frendes, and agree in one to persecute the gospel, and to murther innocentes.
column8: & At dissension with in them selves, now they become high lovers & Friends, and agree in one to persecute the gospel, and to murder innocentes.

column7: But be thou of a good cofort, thou I say, that hast receiued the trueth & louest it.
column8: But be thou of a good Comfort, thou I say, that hast received the truth & love it.

column7: We haue this Christ, whiche rose fro death ye thyrd day,
column8: We have this christ, which rose from death you Third day,

column7: & ouercame all his enemies and aduersaries,
column8: & overcame all his enemies and Adversaries,

column7: & furthermore hath receyued al power in heauen and yearth.
column8: & furthermore hath received all power in heaven and earth.

column7: This Christ, if we continue stedfast in faith vnto the ende, wyll take our part, stad on our side & saue vs, so that we shal neuer be seperate from him.
column8: This christ, if we continue steadfast in faith unto the end, will take our part, stad on our side & save us, so that we shall never be separate from him.

column7: Fourthly, <NOTE>
column8: Fourthly,

column7: Pylate again skornfully asketh Christ saiyng:
column8: Pilate again skornfully asks christ saying:

column7: What is truth? takyng occasio to aske that question, because he heard Christ say:
column8: What is truth? taking Occasion to ask that question, Because he herd christ say:

column7: I came into ye worlde for this intent, that I might beare wytnesse vnto the truth.
column8: I Come into you world for this intent, that I might bear witness unto the truth.

column7: And as in this place we lerne, that ye truth & gospel shal euer by this worlde be mocked, dispised & iested out of countenance, and that mans reason, nor any wyt of man can by it selfe take or apprehed it, so also must we know what Christ in this place calleth the truth.
column8: And as in this place we Learn, that you truth & gospel shall ever by this world be mocked, despised & jested out of countenance, and that men reason, nor any wit of man can by it self take or apprehed it, so also must we know what christ in this place calls the truth.

column7: <NOTE> Neither may wee take this diffinicion of the truth out of our owne brayne, but of the gospel of S.
column8: Neither may we take this definition of the truth out of our own brain, but of the gospel of S.

column7: Ihon, where Christ himself teacheth & defineth it:
column8: John, where christ himself Teaches & defineth it:

column7: Thy sermon or worde O father (sayth he) is ye truth.
column8: Thy sermon or word Oh father (say he) is the truth.

column7: But what sermon is it, or what maner woorde is it?
column8: But what sermon is it, or what manner word is it?

column7: Truely none other sermon or worde, but the same woorde of his heauenly father, that is to say, ye most holy gospel.
column8: Truly none other sermon or word, but the same word of his heavenly father, that is to say, you most holy gospel.

column7: For this is suche a worde,
column8: For this is such a word,

column7: & of so great power, that it is able to comfort the brused & feareful cosciences, and geueth the holye ghoste, whiche leadeth vs from all hipocrisy, whiche most of al thinges is enemy vnto the truth.
column8: & of so great power, that it is able to Comfort the Bruised & fearful cosciences, and Giveth the holy ghost, which leads us from all hypocrisy, which most of all things is enemy unto the truth.

column7: And of this worde also, speaketh the apostle Paul, sayinge:
column8: And of this word also, speaks the apostle Paul, saying:

column7: <NOTE> The gospell is the power of god, vnto health or saluacion, to euery manne that beleueth.
column8: The gospel is the power of god, unto health or salvation, to every man that Believeth.

column7: It was necessary for Christ to bear witnes to those thinges, as he sayth vnto Pilate, that is, he muste needs in his preachinge set forth this truth, which truth is none other, but the worde of god and the gospell, whereby ys sette forthe vnto all men, the good will of god, toward all those that receiue and professe his gospell:
column8: It was necessary for christ to bear witness to those things, as he say unto Pilate, that is, he must needs in his preaching Set forth this truth, which truth is none other, but the word of god and the gospel, whereby is Set forth unto all men, the good will of god, towards all those that receive and profess his gospel:

column7: But nowe if I wyll know this truthe, and by the knowledge of it, attaine vnto eternall health,
column8: But now if I will know this truth, and by the knowledge of it, attain unto Eternal health,

column7: I maye not go aboute it scornefully as Pylate dothe in this place,
column8: I may not go about it scornfully as Pilate doth in this place,

column7: But I must doo as the Tessalonians dyd in the actes of the apostels.
column8: But I must do as the Thessalonians did in the acts of the Apostles.

column7: <NOTE> Those that receiued the worde were very studious, and dayly searched the scriptures, whether it were so as the Apostels preached.
column8: Those that received the word were very studious, and daily searched the Scriptures, whither it were so as the Apostles preached.

column7: For if I do so, without doubt the vnderstanding and sence of the scripture, shal not be denayed me, but aboundantly giuen vnto me,
column8: For if I do so, without doubt the understanding and sense of the scripture, shall not be denied me, but abundantly given unto me,

column7: <NOTE> as the scripture testifieth:
column8: as the scripture Testifieth:

column7: The witnesse of the lord is faithfull, giuing wisdome vnto babes.
column8: The witness of the lord is faithful, giving Wisdom unto babes.

column7: And to this pertaineth it, that Christe saithe in Iohn.
column8: And to this pertaineth it, that Christ Saith in John.

column7: Search the scripture, for thei beare witnes of me.
column8: Search the scripture, for they bear witness of me.

column7: The fowerth sermon on the passion. Ioh. 19.
column8: The fowerth sermon on the passion. John 19.

column7: T Hen Pylate took Iesus therfore & scourged him.
column8: THen THen Pilate took jesus Therefore & scourged him.

column7: <NOTE> And the souldiers wounde a croune of thornes, and put on his heade.
column8: And the Soldiers wound a crown of thorns, and put on his head.

column7: And thei did on him a purple garmente, and came vnto him, and sayd:
column8: And they did on him a purple garment, and Come unto him, and said:

column7: Hayl kyng of the Iewes:
column8: Hail King of the Jews:

column7: and they smote him on the face.
column8: and they smote him on the face.

column7: Pylate went forth againe, and said vnto them:
column8: Pilate went forth again, and said unto them:

column7: Behold, I bringe him forthe to you, that ye may know, that I fynd nofaute in him.
column8: Behold, I bring him forth to you, that you may know, that I find nofaute in him.

column7: Then came Iesus forthe, wearinge a croune of thorne, and a robe of purple.
column8: Then Come jesus forth, wearing a crown of thorn, and a robe of purple.

column7: And he saieth vnto them:
column8: And he Saith unto them:

column7: Beholde the man. <NOTE>
column8: Behold the man.

column7: When the high Priestes therfore and ministers sawe him, they cryed, saying:
column8: When the high Priests Therefore and Ministers saw him, they cried, saying:

column7: Crucifye him, Crucifye him.
column8: Crucify him, Crucify him.

column7: Pilate saithe vnto them: Take ye hym, and crucifi hym, for I fynd no cause in him The Iewes answered hym:
column8: Pilate Saith unto them: Take you him, and crucifi him, for I find no cause in him The Jews answered him:

column7: We haue <NOTE> a law, and by our law he ought to dye, bycause <NOTE> be made hymselfe the sonne of god.
column8: We have a law, and by our law he ought to die, Because be made himself the son of god.

column7: Whe Pylate hearde that saying, he was the more afrayde, and went agayn into the iudgement hall, and sayth vnto Iesus:
column8: When Pilate heard that saying, he was the more afraid, and went again into the judgement hall, and say unto jesus:

column7: Whence arte thou? But Iesus gaue him none answere.
column8: Whence art thou? But jesus gave him none answer.

column7: Then sayde Pylate vnto him:
column8: Then said Pilate unto him:

column7: Speakest thou not vnto me?
column8: Speakest thou not unto me?

column7: Knowest thou not that I haue power to crucifye the, and haue power to lose the?
column8: Knowest thou not that I have power to crucify thee, and have power to loose thee?

column7: Iesus answered. Thou couldest haue no power at all againste me,
column8: jesus answered. Thou Couldst have no power At all against me,

column7: <NOTE> excepte it were gyuen the from aboue.
column8: except it were given thee from above.

column7: Therefore hee that delyuered me vnto the, hath the more synne.
column8: Therefore he that Delivered me unto thee, hath the more sin.

column7: <NOTE> And from thence forthe, sought Pylate meanes to lose hym, but the Iewes cryed, saying:
column8: And from thence forth, sought Pilate means to loose him, but the Jews cried, saying:

column7: If thou lette him go, thou art not Cesares friend.
column8: If thou let him go, thou art not Caesars friend.

column7: For <NOTE> whosoeuer maketh hym selfe a kyng, is agaynst Cesar.
column8: For whosoever makes him self a King, is against Cesar.

column7: When Pylate heard that sayinge, he brought Iesus forthe, and sate doune to gyue sentence, in a place that is called the Pauemente, but in the Hebrue tonge Gabbatha.
column8: When Pilate herd that saying, he brought jesus forth, and sat down to gyve sentence, in a place that is called the Pavement, but in the Hebrew tongue Gabbatha.

column7: It was the preparyng day of the easter, about the syxte hour.
column8: It was the preparing day of the easter, about the Sixth hour.

column7: And he sayth vnto the Iewes:
column8: And he say unto the Jews:

column7: Behold your kyng. They cryed:
column8: Behold your King. They cried:

column7: Away with hym, away with hym, crucifie him.
column8: Away with him, away with him, crucify him.

column7: Pylate saythe vnto them: Shal I crucifie your kinge?
column8: Pilate say unto them: Shall I crucify your King?

column7: The highe priestes answered: Wee haue no kynge but Cesar. <NOTE> Then delyuered hee hym vnto theym, to bee crucified.
column8: The high Priests answered: we have no King but Cesar. Then Delivered he him unto them, to be Crucified.

column7: And they tooke Iesus, and ledde hym awaye.
column8: And they took jesus, and led him away.

column7: And hee bare hys crosse,
column8: And he bore his cross,

column7: <NOTE> and wente forthe into a place, whiche is called the place of dead mennes sculles, but in Hebrue,
column8: and went forth into a place, which is called the place of dead men's skulls, but in Hebrew,

column7: Golgatha, where they crucified hym, and two other with hym, one on eyther side,
column8: Golgotha, where they Crucified him, and two other with him, one on either side,

column7: And Iesus in the myddest.
column8: And jesus in the midst.

column7: <NOTE> Pylat wrote a title and put it on the crosse.
column8: Pilate wrote a title and put it on the cross.

column7: The writing was: Iesus of Nazareth,
column8: The writing was: jesus of Nazareth,

column7: Kyng of the Iewes. This title red many of the Iews, for ye place wher Iesus was crucified was nighe to the citye.
column8: King of the Jews. This title read many of the jews, for you place where jesus was Crucified was High to the City.

column7: And it was written in Hebrue,
column8: And it was written in Hebrew,

column7: Greeke and Latine. Then sayde the hygh priestes of the Iewes to Pylate:
column8: Greek and Latin. Then said the high Priests of the Jews to Pilate:

column7: Wryte not kynge of the Iewes, but that hee sayd:
column8: Write not King of the Jews, but that he said:

column7: I am kyng of the Iewes.
column8: I am King of the Jews.

column7: Pylate answered: What I haue wrytten, that haue I wrytten.
column8: Pilate answered: What I have written, that have I written.

column7: Then the sowldiers, <NOTE> when they had crucified Iesus, tooke hys garmentes and made foure partes, to euery sowdier a part,
column8: Then the Soldiers, when they had Crucified jesus, took his garments and made foure parts, to every sowdier a part,

column7: and also his coate. The coate was without seame, wrought vpo throughout.
column8: and also his coat. The coat was without seam, wrought upon throughout.

column7: They sayd therfore among themselues:
column8: They said Therefore among themselves:

column7: Let vs not deuide it, but cast lottes for it, who shal haue it.
column8: Let us not divide it, but cast lots for it, who shall have it.

column7: That ye scripture might bee fulfylled, saiyng:
column8: That you scripture might be fulfilled, saying:

column7: <NOTE> They parted my rayment among them, and for my coate did thei cast lottes.
column8: They parted my raiment among them, and for my coat did they cast lots.

column7: And the souldiers did suche thynges in dede.
column8: And the Soldiers did such things in deed.

column7: There stode by the crosse of Iesus his mother,
column8: There stood by the cross of jesus his mother,

column7: & his mothers syster, Mary the wyfe of Cleophas,
column8: & his mother's sister, Marry the wife of Cleophas,

column7: & Mary Magdalen. When Iesus therfore sawe his mother, and the disciple standyng <NOTE> who he loued, he sayth vnto his mother:
column8: & Marry Magdalen. When jesus Therefore saw his mother, and the disciple standing who he loved, he say unto his mother:

column7: Woman, beholde thy sonne.
column8: Woman, behold thy son.

column7: Then sayd he to the disciple:
column8: Then said he to the disciple:

column7: Behold thy mother. And from that houre the disciple toke her for his owne.
column8: Behold thy mother. And from that hour the disciple took her for his own.

column7: After these thynges, Iesus knowyng that all thynges were nowe performed, that <NOTE> the scripture might be fulfylled, he sayth:
column8: After these things, jesus knowing that all things were now performed, that the scripture might be fulfilled, he say:

column7: I thyrst. So there stode a vessel by, ful of vineger.
column8: I thirst. So there stood a vessel by, full of vinegar.

column7: <NOTE> Therfore thei fylled a Spunge with vyneger, wound it about with Isope,
column8: Therefore they filled a Sponge with vinegar, wound it about with Hysop,

column7: & put it to his mouth.
column8: & put it to his Mouth.

column7: Assone as Iesus then receiued of the vineger, he sayd:
column8: As soon as jesus then received of the vinegar, he said:

column7: <NOTE> It is finished, and bowed his head,
column8: It is finished, and bowed his head,

column7: & gaue vp the ghost. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: & gave up the ghost. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this place againe we see both the hypocrisy of Pylate, and also the malice of the Iewes.
column8: IN this place again we see both the hypocrisy of Pilate, and also the malice of the Jews.

column7: For I pray you, what more greuous thyng could they do to Iesu, then to scourge him wt whyppes,
column8: For I pray you, what more grievous thing could they do to Jesu, then to scourge him with whyppes,

column7: & croune him with thornes, because he named him selfe kyng of the Iewes?
column8: & crown him with thorns, Because he nam him self King of the Jews?

column7: Well, it was well done.
column8: Well, it was well done.

column7: For doubtles suche hypocrysy <NOTE> and blyndnes must nedes be bothe wonderful, and horrible.
column8: For doubtless such hypocrysy and blindness must needs be both wondered, and horrible.

column7: Pylate himselfe confessed that he found no cause worthy death in him:
column8: Pilate himself confessed that he found no cause worthy death in him:

column7: & that not ones, but twyse or thryse.
column8: & that not ones, but twice or thrice.

column7: The Iewes also before this tyme, had seen his miracles, had heard his preachyng, and estemed him as an excellet Prophet That notwithstadyng, here they gather together & one counselleth with another, yea, and one geueth earnest healpe to another, that at the last they may murther Christe.
column8: The Jews also before this time, had seen his Miracles, had herd his preaching, and esteemed him as an excellet Prophet That notwithstanding, Here they gather together & one counselleth with Another, yea, and one Giveth earnest help to Another, that At the last they may murder Christ.

column7: Pylate byddeth the Iewes take and crucifie hym.
column8: Pilate biddeth the Jews take and crucify him.

column7: And the Iewes affirme that hee muste needes suffre.
column8: And the Jews affirm that he must needs suffer.

column7: Yet to haue some cloke to couer with their enuye and malyce, wherin they were altogither fyered against Christe, they alleadg the cause,
column8: Yet to have Some cloak to cover with their envy and malice, wherein they were altogether fyered against Christ, they allege the cause,

column7: Bicause (say they) hee hathe made hym selfe the sonne of god.
column8: Because (say they) he hath made him self the son of god.

column7: What is this, but outwardely to pretende an honest cloke, and inwardely and in the hearte, to be excedyng thyrstye of innocent bloude? <NOTE> But marke wherevnto Pilate is come withe his blindenes.
column8: What is this, but outwardly to pretend an honest cloak, and inwardly and in the heart, to be exceeding thirsty of innocent blood? But mark whereunto Pilate is come with his blindness.

column7: Bycause Christe answereth not Pylate after his mind & phantasie, he contemneth Christe and presumeth thus to boast and say:
column8: Because Christ Answers not Pilate After his mind & fantasy, he contemneth Christ and Presumeth thus to boast and say:

column7: Knowest not thou, that I haue power to crucifie the, and I haue power to acquit the?
column8: Knowest not thou, that I have power to crucify thee, and I have power to acquit thee?

column7: This proude bragge coulde not Christ abide, and therefore hee aunswered him thus:
column8: This proud brag could not christ abide, and Therefore he answered him thus:

column7: Thou cowldest haue no power against me, except it were giuen the from aboue.
column8: Thou cowldest have no power against me, except it were given thee from above.

column7: <NOTE> This sentence if it be well considered and loked vpon, and deeply grauen in ye heart, is a very comfortable sentence, especiallye to those that haue receaued the gospell, and for the gospels sake, dayly looke for blowes.
column8: This sentence if it be well considered and looked upon, and deeply graven in you heart, is a very comfortable sentence, especially to those that have received the gospel, and for the gospels sake, daily look for blows.

column7: For whose quarrell is this?
column8: For whose quarrel is this?

column7: <NOTE> Goddes quarrell or oures?
column8: Goddess quarrel or ours?

column7: If it be goddes quarrell, tell me I praye you, is not he able to defende it?
column8: If it be God's quarrel, tell me I pray you, is not he able to defend it?

column7: Yes truely hee is able ynoughe.
column8: Yes truly he is able enough.

column7: For he hathe mightely shewed hym selfe able in Pharao, in all Egipte, in Herode, and all tyrauntes, when they did the vttermost of theyr tyranny.
column8: For he hath mightily showed him self able in Pharaoh, in all Egypt, in Herod, and all Tyrants, when they did the uttermost of their tyranny.

column7: But is he also readye to defende this quarell?
column8: But is he also ready to defend this quarrel?

column7: Yea doubteles. <NOTE> For thus he saith to Abraham I wyll blysse those that blysse the, and I will curse those that curse the.
column8: Yea doubtless. For thus he Says to Abraham I will bliss those that bliss the, and I will curse those that curse thee.

column7: Suerly he that promised this to Abraham, wil not forsake vs at our necessitie, if so be that we suffre for his names sake, yea, all our aduersaries can not so muche as hurt our litle fynger, except it be the will of God whiche is in heaue, as Christ in this place answered Pylate.
column8: Surely he that promised this to Abraham, will not forsake us At our necessity, if so be that we suffer for his names sake, yea, all our Adversaries can not so much as hurt our little finger, except it be the will of God which is in heave, as christ in this place answered Pilate.

column7: Therfore if at any tyme thou by the good wyll of God fall into temptacion, knowe thou, that God is faythfull, which will not suffre the to be tempted, <NOTE> more then yt canst beare, but he will wt the temptacion a profite.
column8: Therefore if At any time thou by the good will of God fallen into temptation, know thou, that God is faithful, which will not suffer thee to be tempted, more then that Canst bear, but he will with the temptation a profit.

column7: <NOTE> And diligently note this, firyng it depely in thy memory, that our synnes scourged Christ, and set ye croune of thorne vpon his heade:
column8: And diligently note this, firing it deeply in thy memory, that our Sins scourged christ, and Set you crown of thorn upon his head:

column7: neither was this only ones done, but yet it is dayly done by vs when we wyl be called christians,
column8: neither was this only ones done, but yet it is daily done by us when we will be called Christians,

column7: & yet we do no this will, of who wee beare that moste holy & glorious name.
column8: & yet we do not this will, of who we bear that most holy & glorious name.

column7: Secodarily note, that ye Iewes wyll haue Cesar for their Lord,
column8: Secondarily note, that the Jews will have Cesar for their Lord,

column7: <NOTE> but they wyl not acknowlege Christ to be their kyng.
column8: but they will not acknowledge christ to be their King.

column7: For thei cry: away with him, away with him.
column8: For they cry: away with him, away with him.

column7: Nowe is not this most ingratitude afore God, yt when he hath sent to them his only begotte sonne, a sauior, who they so many yeres had loked & trusted for, nowe with suche crueltie to cast him fro them?
column8: Now is not this most ingratitude afore God, that when he hath sent to them his only begotten son, a Saviour, who they so many Years had looked & trusted for, now with such cruelty to cast him from them?

column7: Thei might doubtles haue receiued Christ,
column8: They might doubtless have received christ,

column7: & been deliuered fro sinne, death, deuil & hell, but thei will rather refuse Christ,
column8: & been Delivered from sin, death, Devil & hell, but they will rather refuse christ,

column7: & serue a forein lorde,
column8: & serve a foreign lord,

column7: & perishe bothe body & soule.
column8: & perish both body & soul.

column7: And for this purpose, they more wylligly desired to let go a notable murtherer Barraba,
column8: And for this purpose, they more wylligly desired to let go a notable murderer Barabbas,

column7: & to pardon him, because of their feastful daies custome, then Christ.
column8: & to pardon him, Because of their feastful days custom, then christ.

column7: To this pertaineth also yt thei sayd to Pylate.
column8: To this pertaineth also that they said to Pilate.

column7: Wryte not kyng of the Iewes, but that he sayd,
column8: Write not King of the Jews, but that he said,

column7: I am king of the Iewes.
column8: I am King of the Jews.

column7: What is this but to refuse Christ,
column8: What is this but to refuse christ,

column7: & to cast him from theim?
column8: & to cast him from them?

column7: But what is wont to folowe suche cotempt?
column8: But what is wont to follow such contempt?

column7: Truly this. <NOTE> That the childre of the kyngdome be throwen out, and the poore Gentyles bee receyued into their place, as S.
column8: Truly this. That the children of the Kingdom be thrown out, and the poor Gentiles be received into their place, as S.

column7: Paule also sayth. By their fal, health chaunsed vnto the Getyles, that he might prouoke them to be zelous after them.
column8: Paul also say. By their fall, health chanced unto the Gentiles, that he might provoke them to be zealous After them.

column7: For if the fall of them be the riches of the worlde,
column8: For if the fallen of them be the riches of the world,

column7: & the minishyng of them the riches of the heathen, howe muche more should it bee so, if they all beleued?
column8: & the minishing of them the riches of the heathen, how much more should it be so, if they all believed?

column7: yet it is done for theim that shall be receyued, that theyr nombre may bee fulfylled.
column8: yet it is done for them that shall be received, that their number may be fulfilled.

column7: For in the Actes of the Apostles sainct Paule sayeth, that the Gospell and woorde of God, must fyrst bee preached vnto the Iewes:
column8: For in the Acts of the Apostles saint Paul Saith, that the Gospel and word of God, must fyrst be preached unto the Jews:

column7: <NOTE> but because they thurst it from theim, and iudged them selues vnworthy eternal life, wee must turne vnto the heathen.
column8: but Because they thirst it from them, and judged them selves unworthy Eternal life, we must turn unto the heathen.

column7: And this punishment is a plage of the soule.
column8: And this punishment is a plague of the soul.

column7: And this blyndnes haue the Iewes dearely bought, because they persecuted with suche hatred,
column8: And this blindness have the Jews dearly bought, Because they persecuted with such hatred,

column7: & suche stubburnes their Messias & kyng promised vnto them,
column8: & such stubbornness their Messias & King promised unto them,

column7: & so mocked & skorned him, and nayled him vnto a crosse.
column8: & so mocked & scorned him, and nailed him unto a cross.

column7: Besides this, thei escaped not also corporall punishement.
column8: Beside this, they escaped not also corporal punishment.

column7: <NOTE> For they lost their bodyes, honours, all their goodes, wife & children, and were banished from their owne countrey, insomuch that vnto this daye, there lyueth no people vnder the Sunne more wretched, forsaken and dispised, and that for this cause (as I haue sayd) that they would not receiue this Christ, for their king.
column8: For they lost their bodies, honours, all their goods, wife & children, and were banished from their own country, insomuch that unto this day, there liveth no people under the Sun more wretched, forsaken and despised, and that for this cause (as I have said) that they would not receive this christ, for their King.

column7: What thinke you shal chaunse vnto vs, if we nowe in oure tyme, hauyng the worde of God so rychely among vs, we reade and heare it dayly,
column8: What think you shall chance unto us, if we now in our time, having the word of God so richly among us, we read and hear it daily,

column7: & yet so yrke and be werye of it, that neither would wee heare it or reade it?
column8: & yet so yrke and be weary of it, that neither would we hear it or read it?

column7: Surely we be like the Gergesines.
column8: Surely we be like the Gergesenes.

column7: For as they desired Christ to depart vnto some other countrey out of their coastes, so we had muche rather that Christ should departe into some other straunge countrey, then we wold for his woordes sake, lose any of oure gaynes, honor or riches.
column8: For as they desired christ to depart unto Some other country out of their coasts, so we had much rather that christ should depart into Some other strange country, then we would for his words sake, loose any of our gains, honour or riches.

column7: Surely God will punishe suche vnthankefulnes in vs, except we be turned & do penance,
column8: Surely God will Punish such unthankfulness in us, except we be turned & do penance,

column7: & other wise dispose our selues towarde the woorde of God.
column8: & other wise dispose our selves toward the word of God.

column7: For euen so sayth sainct Paule to the Romaynes:
column8: For even so say saint Paul to the Romans:

column7: If God spared not the natural braunches, take heede, leste it come to passe, that he spare not thee.
column8: If God spared not the natural branches, take heed, lest it come to pass, that he spare not thee.

column7: Thyrdly, considre here & reuolue in mynde with what wrath, wodnes and furour, the Iewes drewe Christ out of the citie,
column8: Thirdly, Consider Here & revolve in mind with what wrath, wodnes and Furor, the Jews drew christ out of the City,

column7: & hanged him vpon the crosse & that not at aduenture, but of set purpose, betwene two theues and murtherers, as the worste and one that had most greuously offeded in like cryme with them.
column8: & hanged him upon the cross & that not At adventure, but of Set purpose, between two thieves and murderers, as the worst and one that had most grievously offended in like crime with them.

column7: When thou cosiderest thy selfe, and reuoluest this in thy mynde, knowe thou, that thou must not so muche consider the malice of the Iewes, as thine owne most greuous synnes.
column8: When thou cosiderest thy self, and reuoluest this in thy mind, know thou, that thou must not so much Consider the malice of the Jews, as thine own most grievous Sins.

column7: <NOTE> And this lesson must yu learne in this most dispised and villaynous death, that God is an extreme enemye vnto synne.
column8: And this Lesson must thou Learn in this most despised and villainous death, that God is an extreme enemy unto sin.

column7: For is he not moste highly displeased with it,
column8: For is he not most highly displeased with it,

column7: & is an vtter enemye vnto it, when he would receiue none other satisfaction for it, but the death of his only begotte sonne?
column8: & is an utter enemy unto it, when he would receive none other satisfaction for it, but the death of his only begotten son?

column7: Thoughe nothyng els were, yet verely this should ouerthrowe our consciences, that we might learne to knowe our sinnes and viciate nature, and to seke with heartie intercessio, yea with teares, the clemency and mercy of Christ.
column8: Though nothing Else were, yet verily this should overthrown our Consciences, that we might Learn to know our Sins and viciate nature, and to seek with hearty intercessio, yea with tears, the clemency and mercy of christ.

column7: <NOTE> For certainely those do farre sorer torment Christ, that wilbe called christians,
column8: For Certainly those do Far Sorer torment christ, that will called Christians,

column7: & yet consider not why Christe would dye for theyr synnes, then did the blynde Iewes that crucifyed him.
column8: & yet Consider not why Christ would die for their Sins, then did the blind Jews that Crucified him.

column7: For if the Iewes had knowen him (sayth S.
column8: For if the Jews had known him (say S.

column7: Paule) they would in no wise haue crucified the Lord of glorye. <NOTE> But when do wee acknowlege oure synnes?
column8: Paul) they would in no wise have Crucified the Lord of glory. But when do we acknowledge our Sins?

column7: When do we apprehend ye meryte of Christ by fayth?
column8: When do we apprehend you merit of christ by faith?

column7: Where is oure thankefulnes for those so many and so great vnspeakeable benefytes?
column8: Where is our thankfulness for those so many and so great unspeakable benefits?

column7: Yea, wee dare plucke this Christes glory from him, whiche he hath so dearely bought that it can not be expressed, and we seke newe waies, whiche we also prescribe vnto righteousnes & eternal helth,
column8: Yea, we Dare pluck this Christ's glory from him, which he hath so dearly bought that it can not be expressed, and we seek new ways, which we also prescribe unto righteousness & Eternal health,

column7: <NOTE> as al iusticiariers do, whiche are persuaded in coscience, that they may by their owne righteousnes and vertues, worthily deserue no lesse then heaue it self,
column8: as all iusticiariers do, which Are persuaded in conscience, that they may by their own righteousness and Virtues, worthily deserve no less then heave it self,

column7: & eternal saluacion. But certifie, if we by our owne workes, and our owne powers might obtayn helth and eternal life, then it must nedes folowe, that Christ suffered suche vexacion & greuous paynes, yea & offered himselfe vnto so horrible a death & passion, but vainly for his pleasure and phantasy, euen as S.
column8: & Eternal salvation. But certify, if we by our own works, and our own Powers might obtain health and Eternal life, then it must needs follow, that christ suffered such vexation & grievous pains, yea & offered himself unto so horrible a death & passion, but vainly for his pleasure and phantasy, even as S.

column7: Paule saith: If rightwisenes came by ye law,
column8: Paul Says: If rightwiseness Come by you law,

column7: <NOTE> then is Christ dead in vain.
column8: then is christ dead in vain.

column7: Wherfore, if thou wylt bee thankeful vnto Christ for his passion & death, consider it well, and knowlege yt thy synnes haue geuen hym those woundes in his body, and that for them he suffered that most painful passio.
column8: Wherefore, if thou wilt be thankful unto christ for his passion & death, Consider it well, and knowledge that thy Sins have given him those wounds in his body, and that for them he suffered that most painful passio.

column7: Then pray vnto him, that it will please him to geue thee ye merite of his passio vnto thy profite.
column8: Then pray unto him, that it will please him to give thee the merit of his passio unto thy profit.

column7: For if yu do this with true fayth, then wyll he forgeue the thy synnes,
column8: For if thou do this with true faith, then will he forgive the thy Sins,

column7: & washe away all thyne iniquities, in his owne bloud.
column8: & wash away all thine iniquities, in his own blood.

column7: Of this there is no doubt, for he him selfe sayth in ye gospel of sainct Ihon:
column8: Of this there is no doubt, for he him self say in you gospel of saint John:

column7: <NOTE> As Moses exalted the serpent in wildernes, so must the sonne of man be exalted, that euery ma that beleueth in him shal not perishe, but shal haue life eternal.
column8: As Moses exalted the serpent in Wilderness, so must the son of man be exalted, that every ma that Believeth in him shall not perish, but shall have life Eternal.

column7: And this is confirmed by all places throughout all the scripture, that spake of the passion of Christ, as is this sentece of S.
column8: And this is confirmed by all places throughout all the scripture, that spoke of the passion of christ, as is this sentece of S.

column7: Paule to the Rommaynes: <NOTE> Christe dyed for our synnes,
column8: Paul to the Romans: Christ died for our Sins,

column7: & hath risen again for our iustificacion.
column8: & hath risen again for our justification.

column7: And without doubt, <NOTE> whosoeuer suffereth this article of the death and passion of Christ,
column8: And without doubt, whosoever suffers this article of the death and passion of christ,

column7: & of his blessed bloud sheding to be taken from him, needes must that man at the houre of death (when his conscience shall haue that great conflict with synne) dispayre, yea thoughe he had in one heape gathered together the merites of all sainctes that euer were since the beginnyng of ye worlde.
column8: & of his blessed blood shedding to be taken from him, needs must that man At the hour of death (when his conscience shall have that great conflict with sin) despair, yea though he had in one heap gathered together the merits of all Saints that ever were since the beginning of the world.

column7: For in this matter that pertayneth to remission of synne, iustificacion, and eternal health, it is not required to worke,
column8: For in this matter that pertaineth to remission of sin, justification, and Eternal health, it is not required to work,

column7: <NOTE> but to beleue.
column8: but to believe.

column7: Obserue also and note diligently, that the Euangelistes describyng the passion of Christ, howe the Iewes entreated him, thei many tymes haue respect vnto the scripture, which shewed before ye selfe same thinges, the which scripture thei also alege, as in this place, where thei shewe howe he was crucified betwene ii. theues:
column8: Observe also and note diligently, that the Evangelists describing the passion of christ, how the Jews entreated him, they many times have respect unto the scripture, which showed before you self same things, the which scripture they also allege, as in this place, where they show how he was Crucified between ii. thieves:

column7: Also howee the souldiers cast lotte for his garmentes &c.
column8: Also howee the Soldiers cast lot for his garments etc.

column7: Neither do they this for any other purpose, but to admonishe vs to direct our eyes vnto the scriptures, and euer more in matter appertainyng vnto saluacion, to waygh them,
column8: Neither do they this for any other purpose, but to admonish us to Direct our eyes unto the Scriptures, and ever more in matter aPPERTAINING unto salvation, to weigh them,

column7: & direct oure iudgement, accordyng to the same.
column8: & Direct our judgement, according to the same.

column7: Fourthly, Christ hangyng vpon the crosse, doth excedyngly set furth that his moste heartie loue toward vs, in this,
column8: Fourthly, christ hanging upon the cross, does exceedingly Set forth that his most hearty love towards us, in this,

column7: <NOTE> that he comendeth his most derely beloued mother to the Apostle Ihon,
column8: that he commendeth his most dearly Beloved mother to the Apostle John,

column7: & againe Iho vnto his mother, that he might be to her as a defender and comfortable patrone, in that her extreme necessite and trouble.
column8: & again Who unto his mother, that he might be to her as a defender and comfortable patron, in that her extreme necessity and trouble.

column7: For as he nowe is careful for his mother & prouideth for her, euen so is he careful and prouideth for al that loue his name, receiue his gospel, and through faith repose it in their heartes, and so furthermore shewe it furth of theyr heartes, doyng the workes of it through loue.
column8: For as he now is careful for his mother & Provideth for her, even so is he careful and Provideth for all that love his name, receive his gospel, and through faith repose it in their hearts, and so furthermore show it forth of their hearts, doing the works of it through love.

column7: And that we might ascertainly chalenge to our selues suche clemency and goodnes in Christ, therefore he sayth in another place:
column8: And that we might ascertainly challenge to our selves such clemency and Goodness in christ, Therefore he say in Another place:

column7: Who is my mother, <NOTE> or who are my brethren?
column8: Who is my mother, or who Are my brothers?

column7: Truely, whosoeuer dothe the wylle of my father that is in heaue, he is my brother and syster, and mother.
column8: Truly, whosoever doth the will of my father that is in heave, he is my brother and sister, and mother.

column7: <NOTE> By these woordes thou mayest well perceyue that Christ wyll take thee for his brother, syster, yea, and for his mother also,
column8: By these words thou Mayest well perceive that christ will take thee for his brother, sister, yea, and for his mother also,

column7: & wyl euen so acknowlege thee, if thou beleue in him, and not onely will he defende and surely kepe thee in this life, but also he wyll conserue the into eternal life.
column8: & will even so acknowledge thee, if thou believe in him, and not only will he defend and surely keep thee in this life, but also he will conserve thee into Eternal life.

column7: Only let this be thy heartie study to do the will of his father that is in heauen.
column8: Only let this be thy hearty study to do the will of his father that is in heaven.

column7: But what calleth he the wyll of his father?
column8: But what calls he the will of his father?

column7: This is the will of him that hath set me,
column8: This is the will of him that hath Set me,

column7: <NOTE> euen the fathers, that euery man that seeth the sone and beleueth in him, should haue life eternal, and I wyl againe rayse him in the last day.
column8: even the Father's, that every man that sees the soon and Believeth in him, should have life Eternal, and I will again raise him in the last day.

column7: In this place he playnly & euidently sayth,
column8: In this place he plainly & evidently say,

column7: <NOTE> that he that beleueth in him, doth the wyll of his father.
column8: that he that Believeth in him, does the will of his father.

column7: And truely, it is very necessary for vs, earnestly to considre those examples, that sheweth what mynde Christe beareth vnto vs.
column8: And truly, it is very necessary for us, earnestly to Consider those Examples, that shows what mind Christ bears unto us

column7: For the tyme wyll come, yea, it is all ready at hand, that these places of scripture shall do vs excedyng muche good, and singularly comforte vs in all oure necessitee and troubles.
column8: For the time will come, yea, it is all ready At hand, that these places of scripture shall do us exceeding much good, and singularly Comfort us in all our necessity and Troubles.

column7: But if persecucion fynde me here vnarmed, sure it is, that I shal not cotinue constant, but sodenly forgette God, and seeke helpe and coforte at creatures.
column8: But if persecution find me Here unarmed, sure it is, that I shall not cotinue constant, but suddenly forget God, and seek help and coforte At creatures.

column7: And what shal then chaunce to me?
column8: And what shall then chance to me?

column7: Truly this, that for mine vnthakefulnes,
column8: Truly this, that for mine vnthakefulnes,

column7: God wyll forsake me, and because I am not armed with his worde, therfore wyll he withdrawe his hand from me, and forsake me, so that I shal fal into destruction, and for euer perishe, bothe in body and soule.
column8: God will forsake me, and Because I am not armed with his word, Therefore will he withdraw his hand from me, and forsake me, so that I shall fall into destruction, and for ever perish, both in body and soul.

column7: Fyftly, we see that Christe when he nowe knewe that al thynges were finished, and he had tasted the vyneger, and had sayd:
column8: Fifthly, we see that Christ when he now knew that all things were finished, and he had tasted the vinegar, and had said:

column8: It is ended. He bowed his head & gave up the Spirit,

column7: That he cryed: I thrust, and by and by vyneger is geuen him to drynke,
column8: That he cried: I thrust, and by and by vinegar is given him to drink,

column7: <NOTE> it was done for this cause, that we should beleue (seyng that all thynges done in this passion agree so wel with the scriture) that this ma without doubt, is the same Christe, whom the holy fathers haue so long tyme before wayted for.
column8: it was done for this cause, that we should believe (sing that all things done in this passion agree so well with the scripture) that this ma without doubt, is the same Christ, whom the holy Father's have so long time before waited for.

column7: And that before he dyed, he cryed:
column8: And that before he died, he cried:

column7: It is ended. This is so excellent a worde and so precious,
column8: It is ended. This is so excellent a word and so precious,

column7: <NOTE> that not onely it is be graue in oure heartes by fayth, but also bee in all places written, euen with letters of golde before our eyes.
column8: that not only it is be graven in our hearts by faith, but also be in all places written, even with letters of gold before our eyes.

column7: Wyll you knowe why? Herken.
column8: Wyll you know why? Harken.

column7: We were by nature the children of wrath & condempnacion, so burthened in synne & vnfaythfulnes, that wee should perpetually haue perished, if wee had not been succoured and helped.
column8: We were by nature the children of wrath & condemnation, so burdened in sin & unfaithfulness, that we should perpetually have perished, if we had not been succored and helped.

column7: Therfore onely this Iesus Christe our Lorde assisted vs with his helpe and comforte.
column8: Therefore only this jesus Christ our Lord assisted us with his help and Comfort.

column7: And bicause afore the heauely father, we could find no fauour or grace, without oblation and sacrifice, therfore Christ offered him selfe vpon the crosse for vs,
column8: And Because afore the heavily father, we could find no favour or grace, without oblation and sacrifice, Therefore christ offered him self upon the cross for us,

column7: & reconciled his father with his owne blud, and obtained of him for vs, fauour & forgiuenes, righteousnes, and eternall life.
column8: & reconciled his father with his own blood, and obtained of him for us, favour & forgiveness, righteousness, and Eternal life.

column7: <NOTE> as the epistle to the Hebrues, saith:
column8: as the epistle to the Hebrews, Says:

column7: With one offering, hath he made perfect for euer, those that are sanctified.
column8: With one offering, hath he made perfect for ever, those that Are sanctified.

column7: I besech you, what could we more desier, or what greater benefites may be done vnto vs?
column8: I beseech you, what could we more desire, or what greater benefits may be done unto us?

column7: Sin is conquered, death is conquered, the diuel & hel are conquered, so that we may now freely sai:
column8: since is conquered, death is conquered, the Devil & hell Are conquered, so that we may now freely sai:

column7: <NOTE> Death is swalowed into victory.
column8: Death is swallowed into victory.

column7: Death wher is thy sting?
column8: Death where is thy sting?

column7: Hel wher is thy victory?
column8: Hell where is thy victory?

column7: But thankes to god, that hath gyuen vs the victory, by our lord Iesus Christ.
column8: But thanks to god, that hath given us the victory, by our lord jesus christ.

column7: <NOTE> This now is our dueti, that we remembre to giue to Christ only this his glory & honor,
column8: This now is our dueti, that we Remember to give to christ only this his glory & honour,

column7: & to knowledg him for our high Byshop, which offered him self for vs, and so by his passion and death, finished and brought to perfecte ende, all our saluacion.
column8: & to knowledge him for our high Bishop, which offered him self for us, and so by his passion and death, finished and brought to perfect end, all our salvation.

column7: For if we nowe giue to hym this his honor as our duty is, and stedfastly beleue that al this that was done, was done altogither for vs and for our saluacion, douteles we shall so haue it, that this his merite shall not be taken as vaine or frustrate, but of most greatest strength & efficacy for vs.
column8: For if we now give to him this his honour as our duty is, and steadfastly believe that all this that was done, was done altogether for us and for our salvation, doubtless we shall so have it, that this his merit shall not be taken as vain or frustrate, but of most greatest strength & efficacy for us

column7: On the other party, if we wyl not giue vnto him this his glorye, but rather wyll ascribe to our owne deseruinge, merites and workes, that thing, which cost him that so great and inestimable price, that is, the effusion and sheding of his moste precious and holy bloud, then truly we make our selues vnworthy to haue this passio and inerite of Christ,
column8: On the other party, if we will not give unto him this his glory, but rather will ascribe to our own deserving, merits and works, that thing, which cost him that so great and inestimable price, that is, the effusion and shedding of his most precious and holy blood, then truly we make our selves unworthy to have this passio and inerite of christ,

column7: gyuen vnto vs: neither are we lyke (except we repent) to haue ony other fauoure at Christes iudgement, then the Iewes that crucified him.
column8: given unto us: neither Are we like (except we Repent) to have only other favour At Christ's judgement, then the Jews that Crucified him.

column7: The whiche thing, the almighty god kepe farre from vs, for his greate mercy and goodnes, thorow the merites of Iesus Christe our Lorde.
column8: The which thing, the almighty god keep Far from us, for his great mercy and Goodness, thorough the merits of jesus Christ our Lord.

column7: Amen. The syxte sermon on the Passion Ioh. xix.
column8: Amen. The Sixth sermon on the Passion John xix.

column7: T He Iewes therefore bycause it was the preparyng day of the Sabboth, that the bodyes shoulde not remaine on the crosse on the Sabboth daye (for the Sabboth day was an hyghe day) besought Pylate that their legges might ve broken,
column8: THe THe Jews Therefore Because it was the preparing day of the Sabbath, that the bodies should not remain on the cross on the Sabbath day (for the Sabbath day was an high day) besought Pilate that their legs might we broken,

column7: & that they myght be taken doune.
column8: & that they might be taken down.

column8: Then Come the Soldiers, and brake the legs of the First, and of the other which was Crucified with him.

column7: But when they came to Iesus, and sawe that he was deade already, they brake not his legges, but one of the sowldiers wyth a speare, thruste hym into the syde,
column8: But when they Come to jesus, and saw that he was dead already, they brake not his legs, but one of the Soldiers with a spear, thrust him into the side,

column7: & forth with came therout bloude and water.
column8: & forth with Come therout blood and water.

column7: And he that sawe it, bare record, and his record is true.
column8: And he that saw it, bore record, and his record is true.

column7: And he knoweth that he sayth true. that ye myght beleue also.
column8: And he Knoweth that he say true. that you might believe also.

column7: For these thynges were done, that the scripture myghte be fulfilled.
column8: For these things were done, that the scripture might be fulfilled.

column8: You shall not break one bone of him.

column8: And again Another scripture Saith:

column8: After this,

column7: Ioseph of Aramathia (whych was a disciple of Iesus, but secretly for fear of the Iewes) besought Pylat, that he myght take doune the body of Iesus.
column8: Joseph of Arimathea (which was a disciple of jesus, but secretly for Fear of the Jews) besought Pilate, that he might take down the body of jesus.

column7: And Pylate gaue him licence.
column8: And Pilate gave him licence.

column7: He came therfore and toke the body of Iesus, and ther came also Nicodemus, (whiche at the beginninge came to Iesus by nyght) and brought of Myrre and Aloes myngeled togither, about an hundreth pound wayght.
column8: He Come Therefore and took the body of jesus, and there Come also Nicodemus, (which At the begin Come to jesus by night) and brought of Myrrh and Aloes myngeled together, about an Hundredth pound weight.

column7: Then toke they the body of Iesus, and wounde it with linnen clothes with the odoures, as the maner of the Iewes is to bury.
column8: Then took they the body of jesus, and wound it with linen clothes with the odours, as the manner of the Jews is to bury.

column7: And in the place where he was crucified, there was a garden, and in the garden a newe sepulchre, wherein was neuer manne layde.
column8: And in the place where he was Crucified, there was a garden, and in the garden a new Sepulchre, wherein was never man laid.

column7: There layde they Iesus therfore, because of the preparyng of the Sabboth of the Iewes, for the sepulchre was nye at hand. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: There laid they jesus Therefore, Because of the preparing of the Sabbath of the Jews, for the Sepulchre was High At hand. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: WE haue treated dearely beloued, in these former sermons, very plainly vpon the prisonment or bindyg, scourgyng, spittyng vpon, derision or scornyng,
column8: WE have treated dearly Beloved, in these former Sermons, very plainly upon the prisonment or bindyg, scourging, spitting upon, derision or scorning,

column7: & lastly the very death of oure Lord Iesus Christ, and accordyng to these articles we haue diligently put in your memory, that ye very chiefe and principal cause why Christ should suffre this, was our synnes.
column8: & lastly the very death of our Lord jesus christ, and according to these Articles we have diligently put in your memory, that you very chief and principal cause why christ should suffer this, was our Sins.

column7: Furthermore we haue declared vnto you what vtilitee and profite commeth by this passion vnto those that by fayth apprehend it, acknowledgyng theyr sinnes, and beyng for the same confounded, for feare in their consciences, that is to say, they obtayne forgeuens of synnes, accordyng as blessed S.
column8: Furthermore we have declared unto you what utility and profit comes by this passion unto those that by faith apprehend it, acknowledging their Sins, and being for the same confounded, for Fear in their Consciences, that is to say, they obtain forgeuens of Sins, according as blessed S.

column7: Peter testifyeth saiyng: <NOTE> Christ ones suffered for oure synnes, the righteous for the vnrighteous, and to bryng vs to God he was mortified in the fleshe, but quickened in the spitite.
column8: Peter Testifieth saying: christ ones suffered for our Sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, and to bring us to God he was mortified in the Flesh, but quickened in the spitite.

column7: And nowe foloweth what was done after his death, before he was buryed.
column8: And now Followeth what was done After his death, before he was buried.

column7: The Euangelist writeth thus. Then ye Iewes because it was the preparyng day, besought Pylate, that the legges of those that wer crucifyed might be broken, and that they might be taken doune, and Pylate agreed to their peticion, and permitted it.
column8: The Evangelist Writeth thus. Then you Jews Because it was the preparing day, besought Pilate, that the legs of those that were Crucified might be broken, and that they might be taken down, and Pilate agreed to their petition, and permitted it.

column8: But was it so done in deed?

column7: & testified of him. And as in this place he tooke the care for his son, and so defeded him, that his bones wer not broken, euen so wil he mercifully conserue and keep al that beleue, that receiue the word of his son Iesu Christ, and continue in it vnto the ende, so that nothynge may be able to chaunce vnto them, but only that, which is the good wil of god, as we haue an example in Dauid,
column8: & testified of him. And as in this place he took the care for his son, and so defeded him, that his bones were not broken, even so will he mercifully conserve and keep all that believe, that receive the word of his son Jesu christ, and continue in it unto the end, so that nothing may be able to chance unto them, but only that, which is the good will of god, as we have an Exampl in David,

column8: We also Learn in this place of this history, that sing the words spoken of the paschal lamb in the seconde book of Moses, Are Here by the evangelist applied and referred unto christ.

column8: that Christ is Therefore the true paschal lamb, signified by that lamb in the old Testament and now offered upon the cross for our Sins, by cause all that believe in him shall not perish, nor be ashamed, but shall have life everlasting.

column7: Therfore let vs kepe our feaste, not in olde leuen, nor in leuen of malice & wickednes, but in vnleuened bread, that is purenes and truthe. <NOTE> Now to cleaue to this true paschal lamb (whose bones according to the scripture wer not broken) and by fayth to be planted in him, bringeth a farre other holynes then any the Iews had, which sought it in extreme outwarde thinges, that is, it bringeth holynes of the hearte, whiche consysteth in spirite, faith and truth.
column8: Therefore let us keep our feast, not in old Leven, nor in Leven of malice & wickedness, but in unleavened bred, that is pureness and truth. Now to cleave to this true paschal lamb (whose bones according to the scripture were not broken) and by faith to be planted in him, brings a Far other holiness then any the jews had, which sought it in extreme outward things, that is, it brings holiness of the heart, which Consisteth in Spirit, faith and truth.

column7: But nowe the frutes and vtility of Christes passion, somwhat openeth it self, she winge what shulde ensue the passion and deathe of Christ, when a litle and a litle, it comech to mennes knowledg, both what manner a man Christ is, and also how innocently and vndeseruedly he was persecuted by the Iewes,
column8: But now the fruits and utility of Christ's passion, somewhat Openeth it self, she wing what should ensue the passion and death of christ, when a little and a little, it comech to men's knowledge, both what manner a man christ is, and also how innocently and undeservedly he was persecuted by the Jews,

column7: & condemned vnto the crosse.
column8: & condemned unto the cross.

column8: And these two doubtless Come After the true knowledge of god and his son Jesu christ, which now so manifestly do this humanity unto christ, contemned and Crucified, having no respect that he was so hated of the Jews.

column7: For that they here do, it cometh of an imperfecte faith, for they were yet far from the perfection that Paul speaketh of,

column8: saying: I am not ashamed of the gospel of christ, for it is the power of god unto salvation, to every man that Believeth.

column8: And Here note, how the death and sepulture of Christ is esteemed afore the world, both his death and burial Are ignominious and shameful.

column7: Besydes this, the blynde Iewes had none other opinion of Christ, neither by his life nor in his death, as it is euident vnto this day.
column8: Besides this, the blind Jews had none other opinion of christ, neither by his life nor in his death, as it is evident unto this day.

column7: But before God, this death & buryall is honest and precious, as also it is estemed amog al that beleue, whiche know assuredly, that by that dispised death, the beleuers are delyuered from synne, death, deuil and hel.
column8: But before God, this death & burial is honest and precious, as also it is esteemed Among all that believe, which know assuredly, that by that despised death, the believers Are Delivered from sin, death, Devil and hell.

column7: Doth not S. Paule say often tyme:
column8: Does not S. Paul say often time:

column7: <NOTE> I haue knowen no man but Christ, and euen the same that was crucifyed?
column8: I have known no man but christ, and even the same that was Crucified?

column7: And this is an vndoubted trueth,
column8: And this is an undoubted truth,

column7: <NOTE> take awaye this contemptible death and buryal of Christ, and you shal perceyue, that all men must be compelled to dispayre and to fall into the daunger of the deuil.
column8: take away this contemptible death and burial of christ, and you shall perceive, that all men must be compelled to despair and to fallen into the danger of the Devil.

column7: On the other part, set before your eyes the passion, death and buryal of Christ, apprehendyng them by true fayth, as most precious iewels & deuine treasures, done for thee, and thou shalt fynd thy coscience able to resyst against all the assaultes of Sathan, and also of synne.
column8: On the other part, Set before your eyes the passion, death and burial of christ, apprehending them by true faith, as most precious Jewels & divine treasures, done for thee, and thou shalt find thy conscience able to resist against all the assaults of Sathan, and also of sin.

column7: And as Ioseph and Nycodemus, by fayth shewed this humanitee vnto Christ, so endeuor thy selfe by fayth, that vnto sinne thou may bee dead & buryed with Christ,
column8: And as Joseph and Nicodemus, by faith showed this humanity unto christ, so endeavour thy self by faith, that unto sin thou may be dead & buried with christ,

column7: <NOTE> and after agayne ryse through fayth with him.
column8: and After again rise through faith with him.

column7: For surely this pleaseth Christ, and is necessary, and very profytable vnto thy saluacion.
column8: For surely this Pleases christ, and is necessary, and very profitable unto thy salvation.

column7: Fourthly, we see howe contemtuously Pylate delyuereth Christ to be buryed, forsyng not for him, nothyng regardyng that he should ryse agayne the thyrd day.
column8: Fourthly, we see how contemptuously Pilate Delivereth christ to be buried, forcing not for him, nothing regarding that he should rise again the Third day.

column7: <NOTE> In this mynde are al the enemyes of the gospel and truth of God.
column8: In this mind Are all the enemies of the gospel and truth of God.

column8: When they have slain you Ministers of the word, then they think all thing very well & safe, and all whyst, as they would have it.

column7: <NOTE> Euen so did Pharao, with intollerable burthens oppresse the chyldren of Israel, thynkyng by that meanes to stoppe the ordynaunce of God, that the Israelites should not so much growe and increase:
column8: Even so did Pharaoh, with intolerable burdens oppress the children of Israel, thinking by that means to stop the Ordinance of God, that the Israelites should not so much grow and increase:

column7: but the more they were oppressed, so muche more they grewe and multiplyed, and at the laste by his owne crueltee, he was his owne destruccion.
column8: but the more they were oppressed, so much more they grew and multiplied, and At the laste by his own cruelty, he was his own destruction.

column7: Euen so chaunsed it to Pylate and the Iewes, whiche thynke all sure, nowe yt they haue slayne Christ, whose preachyng so muche moueth the people:
column8: Even so chanced it to Pilate and the Jews, which think all sure, now that they have slain christ, whose preaching so much moves the people:

column8: This fire was kindled & brent, when After the resurrection and Ascension of christ, he sent his Apostles into all the Whole world,

column7: & comaunded them to preache penance in his name, and remission of synnes to all creatures. <NOTE> And though the Iewes gaue ye souldiers money, to say that Christ was not rysen againe, but his disciples had taken him away out of the graue, yet that notwithstandyng,
column8: & commanded them to preach penance in his name, and remission of Sins to all creatures. And though the Jews gave the Soldiers money, to say that christ was not risen again, but his Disciples had taken him away out of the graven, yet that notwithstanding,

column8: christ rose again, and appeared unto his Apostles, declaring by many Miracles, that he had verily risen,

column7: & that vnto him, as vnto the kyng & most hyest Lord, was deliuered al power in heauen and in yearth.
column8: & that unto him, as unto the King & most highest Lord, was Delivered all power in heaven and in earth.

column7: Neither Herode, Pylate & all the Iewes could then lette this,
column8: Neither Herod, Pilate & all the Jews could then let this,

column8: nor yet afterward were the Roman emperors able to quench it, no nor At this perilous time can the enemies of the truth prevail, but christ will continue Eternal Lord and King, yea maugre their berdes, that go about to suppress the truth.

column7: They thynke that if they may murther the chiefe authors & capitaynes,
column8: They think that if they may murder the chief Authors & Captains,

column7: and make away with them, then shall theyr power and magnificence floryshe and haue no hynderance nor hurte.
column8: and make away with them, then shall their power and magnificence flourish and have no hynderance nor hurt.

column7: <NOTE> But Christe that exalteth the lowly, and throweth doune the mightie from theyr seate, knoweth whan and howe to ouerthrowe those Nembrothes & theyr ymaginacions, that wyll they nyll they, they shal be fayne to heare the truth.
column8: But Christ that Exalteth the lowly, and throweth down the mighty from their seat, Knoweth when and how to overthrown those Nimrod & their Imaginations, that will they nyll they, they shall be fain to hear the truth.

column7: And euen in our tyme, god hath so set furth the strength of his power, that by his grace, we haue the syncere truth and pure gospell, spite of all the vngodly aduersaries, though they would burst for payne.
column8: And even in our time, god hath so Set forth the strength of his power, that by his grace, we have the sincere truth and pure gospel, spite of all the ungodly Adversaries, though they would burst for pain.

column7: I beseche God graunt, that wee may acknowlege the same his truth, and apprehend & take hold vpo the same, and vnto the ende cleaue faste vnto this contempned Christe crucifyed, so that after this life, we may come vnto his glory and eternal lyfe, by the merytes of thesame our only sauior, mediator and aduocate,
column8: I beseech God grant, that we may acknowledge the same his truth, and apprehend & take hold upon the same, and unto the end cleave fast unto this contemned Christ Crucified, so that After this life, we may come unto his glory and Eternal life, by the merits of The same our only Saviour, Mediator and advocate,

column7: Iesus Christe, to who with the father and the holy gost, be al honor, laude and glory, for euer and euer.
column8: jesus Christ, to who with the father and the holy ghost, be all honour, laud and glory, for ever and ever.

column7: F Yrst of all dearely beloued, let vs cosidre the vnbeleiefe & infirmitee of these two disciples, that went from Ierusale to Emaus.
column8: FYrst FYrst of all dearly Beloved, let us Consider the vnbeleiefe & infirmity of these two Disciples, that went from Jerusalem to Emaus.

column7: For as it chaunsed to these, euen so chaunsed it to diuers other, as wee may read in this history of ye resurrection of Christ.
column8: For as it chanced to these, even so chanced it to diverse other, as we may read in this history of the resurrection of christ.

column7: Neither was it possible, that this article of Christes resurrection shuld be perceiued or beleued, without great difficultee:
column8: Neither was it possible, that this article of Christ's resurrection should be perceived or believed, without great difficulty:

column8: Christ was in a manner copelled to serve them in words, Deeds, Miracles & the Angels.

column7: Furthermore in shewyng his woundes, and yet for all this verye hardely could they be persuaded in this article of ye resurrection.
column8: Furthermore in show his wounds, and yet for all this very hardly could they be persuaded in this article of the resurrection.

column7: So peruerse is the fleshe, and so ful of euil, if it be not by the spirit of God illuminate and brought to the knowlege of God.
column8: So perverse is the Flesh, and so full of evil, if it be not by the Spirit of God illuminate and brought to the knowledge of God.

column7: Notwithstadyng there remayned yet in these two, certaine smal sparkes of loue towarde Christ, so that they must nedes talke of Christ, and the one open his grief vnto the other.
column8: Notwithstanding there remained yet in these two, certain small sparks of love toward christ, so that they must needs talk of christ, and the one open his grief unto the other.

column7: Christ gladly commeth vnto them, and as a straunger iournyeth with them, saluteth them, and asketh the cause of their comunicacion and reasonyng, and why they were so sorowful.
column8: christ gladly comes unto them, and as a stranger iournyeth with them, salutes them, and asks the cause of their communication and reasoning, and why they were so sorrowful.

column7: Wherein we haue a lesson, that Christe hath a meruaylous delite in deuout, godly & christian communyng or talkyng,
column8: Wherein we have a Lesson, that Christ hath a marvelous delight in devout, godly & christian communing or talking,

column7: <NOTE> ye be his owne doctrin he alloweth it and sheweth it (saiyng whersoeuer it, are come together in my name, there wyll I bee the thyrde) thus callyng vs from vayne and filthy vncomly woordes and talkyng.
column8: you be his own Doctrine he alloweth it and shows it (saying wheresoever it, Are come together in my name, there will I be the Third) thus calling us from vain and filthy uncomely words and talking.

column7: It is to be wyshed, that this lesson were diligetly inculcate in mennes memorye.
column8: It is to be wished, that this Lesson were diligetly inculcate in men's memory.

column7: For truely menne are to nothyng so muche enclyned, as vnto euil talkyng, detraction and filthye communicacion:
column8: For truly men Are to nothing so much inclined, as unto evil talking, detraction and filthy communication:

column7: so that a manne maye fynde more honesty and nurture in the talkyng of ye heathen & vnchristened, then among those that bost them selues of Christes name, nothyng cosideryng nor regardyng,
column8: so that a man may find more honesty and nurture in the talking of you heathen & unchristened, then among those that boast them selves of Christ's name, nothing cosideryng nor regarding,

column7: <NOTE> that of euery idle woorde wee must geue accompt in the day of iudgement:
column8: that of every idle word we must give account in the day of judgement:

column7: Paule so earnestly forbad christians, that in any wyse no fylthy worde shuld be herd out of their mouth.
column8: Paul so earnestly forbade Christians, that in any wise no filthy word should be heard out of their Mouth.

column7: Wherefore, if thou wylte haue Christ present at thy communication and talkyng, do as these two disciples did.
column8: Wherefore, if thou wilt have christ present At thy communication and talking, do as these two Disciples did.

column7: Talke of those thynges that pertayne to the honour of God, and thyne owne saluacion.
column8: Talk of those things that pertain to the honour of God, and thine own salvation.

column7: Let thy wyll and studye be euer in the law of God, and so shal Christ not be farre from thee.
column8: Let thy will and study be ever in the law of God, and so shall christ not be Far from thee.

column7: But if in thy talkyng thou forget God, then looke not for God, but for the deuil to bee presente with thee.
column8: But if in thy talking thou forget God, then look not for God, but for the Devil to be present with thee.

column7: Secondarily, we haue here also what Christ did when he was come into the companye of these two disciples.
column8: Secondarily, we have Here also what christ did when he was come into the company of these two Disciples.

column7: And fyrst he maketh himself so, as though he knewe nothyng, nor had heard what was doone in Ierusalem in those dayes.
column8: And fyrst he makes himself so, as though he knew nothing, nor had herd what was done in Jerusalem in those days.

column7: And this dothe he to drawe furth their incredulitee, and to rebuke theim for it, and to haue occasion to instructe them, as he dyd after warde.
column8: And this doth he to draw forth their incredulity, and to rebuke them for it, and to have occasion to instruct them, as he did After ward.

column7: And they by and by plainly declared theyr myndes, so talkyng of Christe, that a man may easely perceyue, that as concernyng him, his worde and promises, though they had not vtterly, yet for the most part, they wer fallen into dispayre.
column8: And they by and by plainly declared their minds, so talking of Christ, that a man may Easily perceive, that as Concerning him, his word and promises, though they had not utterly, yet for the most part, they were fallen into despair.

column7: Besydes this, though they acknowleged him to be a Prophete, mightie in woordes and deedes before God, yet nowe they thought theyr hope frustrate,
column8: Besides this, though they acknowledged him to be a Prophet, mighty in words and Deeds before God, yet now they Thought their hope frustrate,

column7: <NOTE> that he should redeme Israel.
column8: that he should Redeem Israel.

column7: But what dothe Christe? Christe our Lorde knoweth very well and perfectly what is oure infirmitee and incredulitee, neither is he ignorant that no good thing is in our fleshe.
column8: But what doth Christ? Christ our Lord Knoweth very well and perfectly what is our infirmity and incredulity, neither is he ignorant that no good thing is in our Flesh.

column7: Wherfore, although wee bee vnperfecte in fayth, yet wyll not he cast vs away, but rebuke and teache vs, as he dothe here the disciples, teachyng vs by his owne ensample, to do likewyse.
column8: Wherefore, although we be unperfect in faith, yet will not he cast us away, but rebuke and teach us, as he doth Here the Disciples, teaching us by his own ensample, to do likewise.

column7: And fyrst he correcteth vs, and sayeth:
column8: And fyrst he Correcteth us, and Saith:

column7: O fooles and harde hearted, to beleue in all thynges that ye Prophetes haue spoken.
column8: Oh Fools and harden hearted, to believe in all things that you prophets have spoken.

column7: Must not Christ suffre these thynges, and so entre into his glorye?
column8: Must not christ suffer these things, and so enter into his glory?

column7: It is neither vnright nor crueltie, that he here calleth his disciples foles, whiche yet he forbad Mathew.v.
column8: It is neither unright nor cruelty, that he Here calls his Disciples Fools, which yet he forbade Matthew v

column7: <NOTE> For that he here doth, he doth it of a godly zeale and fatherly loue, and so also may any manne do likewyse, especially when theyr heart nor mynde be none otherwyse affecte, then was Christ towarde his disciples.
column8: For that he Here does, he does it of a godly zeal and fatherly love, and so also may any man do likewise, especially when their heart nor mind be none otherwise affect, then was christ toward his Disciples.

column7: Then beganne he at Moses and all the prophetes, and interpreted to theim in all their writynges, suche places as were written of him.
column8: Then began he At Moses and all the Prophets, and interpreted to them in all their writings, such places as were written of him.

column7: It is not comly to rebuke onely, and not to comfort againe.
column8: It is not comely to rebuke only, and not to Comfort again.

column7: Furthermore he that shall rebuke another man, ought not onely to recite to his rebuke, what he had done vnrightfully, but he must also shewe what he hath done honestly, vertuously, and also profitably:
column8: Furthermore he that shall rebuke Another man, ought not only to recite to his rebuke, what he had done unrightfully, but he must also show what he hath done honestly, virtuously, and also profitably:

column7: Eue so doth Christ here.
column8: Eue so does christ Here.

column7: Fyrst he rebuketh their incredulitee or vnfaythfulnes.
column8: Fyrst he Rebuketh their incredulity or unfaithfulness.

column7: Then forasmuche as fayth cometh of hearing of the worde, he proueth & alloweth their saiyng out of the deuine scriptures, that Christ must suffre.
column8: Then forasmuch as faith comes of hearing of the word, he Proves & alloweth their saying out of the divine Scriptures, that christ must suffer.

column7: And walkyng with them he earnestly cotinueth his sermo with suche maiestie & power, that ye disciples after wer copelled to knowlege it & say:
column8: And walking with them he earnestly cotinueth his sermon with such majesty & power, that you Disciples After were copelled to knowledge it & say:

column8: Did not our heart burn in us, when he talked with us in the Way, and opened to us the Scriptures?

column8: O blessed is that man, who christ thus draws by his word, and which is by Christ's Spirit instruct into the true knowledge of God.
