column8: Happy art thou Simon the son of Jonah, for Flesh and blood hath not opened that unto thee,

column7: <NOTE> but my father which is in heauen.
column8: but my father which is in heaven.

column7: And I saye also vnto the, that thou art Peter, and vpon thys rocke, <NOTE> I wyll buyld my congregacion.
column8: And I say also unto thee, that thou art Peter, and upon this rock, I will build my congregation.

column7: And the gates of hell shall not preuayle agaynst it.
column8: And the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.

column7: And wyll giue vnto the, the keyes of the kyngedome of heauen, and <NOTE> what so euer thou byndest in earthe, shall bee bounde in heauen:
column8: And will give unto thee, the keys of the Kingdom of heaven, and what so ever thou byndest in earth, shall be bound in heaven:

column7: and what so euer thou losest in earth, shall be loed in heauen. THE EXPOSITION. <NOTE> WE haue fyrst set forth in this gospel, that excellent confession of S.
column8: and what so ever thou losest in earth, shall be lo in heaven. THE EXPOSITION. WE have fyrst Set forth in this gospel, that excellent Confessi of S.

column7: Peter and the other Apostels, wherein they confesse that hee is Christe the sonne of the lyuynge god.
column8: Peter and the other Apostles, wherein they confess that he is Christ the son of the living god.

column7: This confession is so excellente and noble, yea and so christian, that wee dare boldlye saye, that where this confession is not, doubteles there is no saluacion at all, as the Apostell Saynte Paule witnesseth,
column8: This Confessi is so excellent and noble, yea and so christian, that we Dare boldly say, that where this Confessi is not, doubtless there is no salvation At all, as the Apostle Faint Paul Witnesseth,

column7: <NOTE> saying: The hearte beleueth vnto righteousnes, and the mouthe confesseth vnto saluacion.
column8: saying: The heart Believeth unto righteousness, and the Mouth Confesses unto salvation.

column7: Fyrste CHRIST asketh what opinyon the people had of hym, and whome they sayde he was.
column8: First CHRIST asks what opinion the people had of him, and whom they said he was.

column7: The Apostels aunswered him: Some saye, thou arte Iohn the Baptist:
column8: The Apostles answered him: some say, thou art John the Baptist:

column7: some saye, Helias: some Hieremias, or one of the prophetes.
column8: Some say, Elias: Some Jeremiah, or one of the Prophets.

column7: Christe was not ignoraunte what was spoken of him, and also he knewe it better then the apostels could tell him, that where the gospell is preached, there muste nedes arise manye lyes, whiche are imagined not only against the truth, but also against them ye preach the truthe, whereout it chaunceth often times that the worlde rageth and waxeth woode with them.
column8: Christ was not ignorant what was spoken of him, and also he knew it better then the Apostles could tell him, that where the gospel is preached, there must needs arise many lies, which Are imagined not only against the truth, but also against them you preach the truth, whereout it chanceth often times that the world rages and Waxes wood with them.

column7: Therfore nedes must it be, that Christ aposing his disciples, sought some other thinge at his apostels, that is to sai, their cofession of faith as ye shal hear.
column8: Therefore needs must it be, that christ aposing his Disciples, sought Some other thing At his Apostles, that is to sai, their confession of faith as you shall hear.

column7: For thus he saith: But whome say you that I am?
column8: For thus he Says: But whom say you that I am?

column7: The answered Petre in the name of them al: <NOTE> Thou art the same Christ the son of the liuyng god.
column8: The answered Petre in the name of them all: Thou art the same christ the son of the living god.

column7: Considre inwardly this confession, & thou shalt see that the faith of al the Apostels was a true and a righte faith, excepte that as yet it was not confirmed with the crosse, and that yet the holy ghost was not come vpon them.
column8: Consider inwardly this Confessi, & thou shalt see that the faith of all the Apostles was a true and a right faith, except that as yet it was not confirmed with the cross, and that yet the holy ghost was not come upon them.

column7: Fyrst of all they confesse that he is the same Christ, that is to saye, the same anointed and capitaine, whom god had longe before promised,
column8: Fyrst of all they confess that he is the same christ, that is to say, the same anointed and Captain, whom god had long before promised,

column7: <NOTE> to theyr fathers, and whome they hadde so long time looked for, that doubtles he shuld come and fulfyll all suche thinges as the holy scriptures hadde prophecied of.
column8: to their Father's, and whom they had so long time looked for, that doubtless he should come and fulfil all such things as the holy Scriptures had prophesied of.

column7: Furthermore also they confesse, that he is Christe sonne of the lyuing god, sente into this worlde, that by hys meryte, passion and deathe, all menne myghte bee made good, righteous, and blessed.
column8: Furthermore also they confess, that he is Christ son of the living god, sent into this world, that by his merit, passion and death, all men might be made good, righteous, and blessed.

column7: And thus (as it is in dead conueniente to do) they confesse the same one Christ to be both god and man.
column8: And thus (as it is in dead convenient to do) they confess the same one christ to be both god and man.

column7: For as concernyng his humane nature, hee is the sonne of Dauyd, annoynted of the father kinge and Prieste, and that after the order of Melchisedech:
column8: For as Concerning his humane nature, he is the son of David, anointed of the father King and Priest, and that After the order of Melchizedek:

column7: and God hathe gyuen vnto him the seate of Dauid, that is, the spirituall kyngedome, whyche is admynistred by the spyryte, that hee maye sytte vppon it eternallye.
column8: and God hath given unto him the seat of David, that is, the spiritual Kingdom, which is admynistred by the Spirit, that he may fit upon it eternally.

column7: But as concernynge his godheade, he is the sonne of the liuing god, one in substance, essence or being and maiestye with the father, so yt neither mai the father bee separate from the son, nor the sonne from the father, as sainct Paule sayth:
column8: But as Concerning his godhead, he is the son of the living god, one in substance, essence or being and majesty with the father, so that neither mai the father be separate from the son, nor the son from the father, as saint Paul say:

column7: <NOTE> In Christ dwelleth all fulnesse of the godhead corporally.
column8: In christ dwells all fullness of the godhead corporally.

column7: Nowe whosoeuer with suche fayth,
column8: Now whosoever with such faith,

column7: & after this maner as the Apostles here dyd, confesseth Christe, without doubt he shall also with the Apostles be made partaker of eternal saluacion, as Christ here sayth vnto Peter, like as to al his disciples:
column8: & After this manner as the Apostles Here did, Confesses Christ, without doubt he shall also with the Apostles be made partaker of Eternal salvation, as christ Here say unto Peter, like as to all his Disciples:

column7: Blessed art thou Symon the sonne of Iona &c.
column8: Blessed art thou Symon the son of Iona etc.

column7: Secondarily we see in this gospel that this confession commeth not of oure strengthes, but by the reuelacion of God.
column8: Secondarily we see in this gospel that this Confessi comes not of our strength's, but by the Revelation of God.

column7: For assone as Peter had in the name of them all declared what opinion thei had of him,
column8: For As soon as Peter had in the name of them all declared what opinion they had of him,

column7: <NOTE> by and by Christe sayd:
column8: by and by Christ said:

column7: Fleshe and bloud hath not opened it to thee, but my father which is heaue.
column8: Flesh and blood hath not opened it to thee, but my father which is heave.

column7: Shal then our fleshe, that is, reason, wyt, prudence, freewyll and the strengthes of man bee of no value in matter of our iustificacion & confessyng of God?
column8: Shall then our Flesh, that is, reason, wit, prudence, freewyll and the strength's of man be of no valve in matter of our justification & confessing of God?

column7: Surely nothing. For without doubt here nothyng is of value, but mere grace and mercy.
column8: Surely nothing. For without doubt Here nothing is of valve, but mere grace and mercy.

column7: Nowe if it be grace, than I beleue, that I may do good woorkes, that I can confesse Christ as the Apostles do in this place, nedes must I let flesh contynue as fleshe, and bloud as bloud, so ye inasmuche as partayneth vnto our saluacion, ye flesh not only can do nothing, but also it can do nothyng but synne, as S.
column8: Now if it be grace, than I believe, that I may do good works, that I can confess christ as the Apostles do in this place, needs must I let Flesh continue as Flesh, and blood as blood, so you inasmuch as partayneth unto our salvation, you Flesh not only can do nothing, but also it can do nothing but sin, as S.

column7: Ihon ye Euangelist sayth: <NOTE> As many as receiue him, he gaue them power to be made the sones of God, to those yt beleue in his name which are not borne of bloudes nor of the will of the fleshe, nor of the will of ma, but they are borne of God.
column8: John the Evangelist say: As many as receive him, he gave them power to be made the Sons of God, to those that believe in his name which Are not born of bloods nor of the will of the Flesh, nor of the will of ma, but they Are born of God.

column7: Doth not the Euagelist here cleane refuse & reiect in matter of iustificacio al together that is borne of bloudes, or of ye wyl of fleshe or of the wylle of man?
column8: Does not the Evangelist Here clean refuse & reject in matter of iustificacio all together that is born of bloods, or of the will of Flesh or of the will of man?

column7: Euen so it is necessary that we consider here in this place the cofession of Peter and the other Apostles, that it came not of their reason, wysedome or frewyll.
column8: Eve so it is necessary that we Consider Here in this place the confession of Peter and the other Apostles, that it Come not of their reason, Wisdom or freewill.

column7: For surely Christ would in this worde dryue backe, make blunt & ouerthrow our presumpcion, and meke that pride that is borne in vs, that we shuld learne to distrust of our selues and our owne strengthes, and to seke righteousnes and health otherwhere, then at our selues or in our owne workes.
column8: For surely christ would in this word drive back, make blunt & overthrow our presumption, and meek that pride that is born in us, that we should Learn to distrust of our selves and our own strength's, and to seek righteousness and health otherwhere, then At our selves or in our own works.

column7: But where shuld it be sought?
column8: But where should it be sought?

column7: Forsoth at him that opened vnto the Apostles that excellent cofession of Christ, that is to say, at the heauenly father, of whom Christ also sayth in another place:
column8: Forsooth At him that opened unto the Apostles that excellent confession of christ, that is to say, At the heavenly father, of whom christ also say in Another place:

column7: Noman knoweth the father, but onely the sonne:
column8: Roman Knoweth the father, but only the son:

column7: and noman knoweth the sone, but the father only, and he to whom the father will open him.
column8: and Roman Knoweth the soon, but the father only, and he to whom the father will open him.

column7: Thyrdly, <NOTE> wee haue in this Gospell a promyse of Christ geuen to the churche, that is this:
column8: Thirdly, we have in this Gospel a promise of christ given to the Church, that is this:

column7: That the gates of hell, that is,
column8: That the gates of hell, that is,

column7: Sathan and all power & wysedome of the worlde, shal not preuayle against it.
column8: Sathan and all power & Wisdom of the world, shall not prevail against it.

column7: Nowe note vpo what foundacion this church must be buylded, to whom this excellent promise pertayneth.
column8: Now note upon what Foundation this Church must be builded, to whom this excellent promise pertaineth.

column7: Christ sayth: Thou art Peter, that is stonye, that is, yu standest stedfast in thy confession as doth the stony rocke.
column8: christ say: Thou art Peter, that is stony, that is, thou Standest steadfast in thy Confessi as does the stony rock.

column7: For thou cofessest and beleuest, that I am Christ & the sonne of the liuyng God, that is, thou beleuest that I am the sauiour and redemer of the whole worlde.
column8: For thou cofessest and Believest, that I am christ & the son of the living God, that is, thou Believest that I am the Saviour and redeemer of the Whole world.

column7: Wherfore nowe, suche fayth shal be in my church, that hath respect to me & my worde and only dependeth vpon me and stand sure & firme in the same confession as thou hast done nowe.
column8: Wherefore now, such faith shall be in my Church, that hath respect to me & my word and only dependeth upon me and stand sure & firm in the same Confessi as thou hast done now.

column7: And vpon suche a fayth as only putteth confidence vpo my word,
column8: And upon such a faith as only putteth confidence upon my word,

column7: I wyll buyld my church so strongly, that not the gates of hel, that is, what so euer be against me, other in hel or in earth, shal preuaile against it.
column8: I will build my Church so strongly, that not the gates of hell, that is, what so ever be against me, other in hell or in earth, shall prevail against it.

column7: Doubtles persecution shal arise, and Sathan him selfe shall not cease by thousand meanes to tempte,
column8: Doubtless persecution shall arise, and Sathan him self shall not cease by thousand means to tempt,

column8: Whosoever hears of me these words & does them,

column8: Now sing that christ hath with this his so rich & excellent a promise provided for his Church,

column8: I pray you, who will be so mad to separate him self from Christ's Church?

column8: I say again, from Christ Church, for the which as S.

column8: Paul Says he hath give him self to death, to sanctify it,

column7: & clense it in the fountaine of water by the word, to make it vnto him self a glorious congregacion, hauing no spot nor wrinkell, nor any suche thinge, but that it shuld be holy and without blame.
column8: & cleanse it in the fountain of water by the word, to make it unto him self a glorious congregation, having no spot nor wrinkell, nor any such thing, but that it should be holy and without blame.

column7: Fourthly, we se to whom Christ hath comitted the power of ye keies,
column8: Fourthly, we see to whom christ hath committed the power of you keys,

column7: & how far ye same power extendeth it self.
column8: & how Far you same power extendeth it self.

column7: It was said afore, that Peter answered in the name of al the Apostels,
column8: It was said afore, that Peter answered in the name of all the Apostles,

column7: & that Christs words were to Peter & to al ye other Apostels.
column8: & that Christ words were to Peter & to all the other Apostles.

column7: Seing it is so, nedes must we confesse, that power & autorite to lose & binde, was not giuen to Peter alone, but generally to al the Apostels.
column8: Sing it is so, needs must we confess, that power & Authority to loose & bind, was not given to Peter alone, but generally to all the Apostles.

column7: Now if any wyll be contencious & hold opinio that the power was giue to Peter only, yet is his mouthe stopped with these places of Math.
column8: Now if any will be contentious & hold opinio that the power was give to Peter only, yet is his Mouth stopped with these places of Math.

column7: & Iohn, where Christ saide to his Apostles:
column8: & John, where christ said to his Apostles:

column7: <NOTE> Whose sins so euer ye forgiue, they be forgiue, and whose sins so euer ye retaine, they are retained.
column8: Whose Sins so ever you forgive, they be forgive, and whose Sins so ever you retain, they Are retained.

column7: Although it be without questio, that those yt dispute & stryue by the swords (as they saye) for the power of Peter, thei take vpon them those disputacions, not for Peters sake, but oli to flatter therwith their Roman Antichrist.
column8: Although it be without Question, that those that dispute & strive by the swords (as they say) for the power of Peter, they take upon them those disputations, not for Peter's sake, but oli to flatter therewith their Roman Antichrist.

column7: But truth it is, yt the gates of hell haue so sore preuailed against him, that euery child may perceiue easily, yt this promise ought not to be wrested & falsly applied to the Roman seat.
column8: But truth it is, that the gates of hell have so soar prevailed against him, that every child may perceive Easily, that this promise ought not to be wrested & falsely applied to the Roman seat.

column7: Besides yt, what with his false doctrine & his diuelishe pride he hath so sore ouerthrowen him self, that his estimacion hath but smal place in the hertes of those that beleue.
column8: Beside that, what with his false Doctrine & his devilish pride he hath so soar overthrown him self, that his estimation hath but small place in the herts of those that believe.

column7: But nowe, what is the power of the keyes?
column8: But now, what is the power of the keys?

column7: Truly nothing els but ye administracion of ye word & sacraments.
column8: Truly nothing Else but you administration of the word & Sacraments.

column7: For Christ hath giuen this his word and sacraments vnto his churche.
column8: For christ hath given this his word and Sacraments unto his Church.

column7: And the churche committeth the same power vnto ye ministers of the word, which execute this office in ye name of ye whol church.
column8: And the Church Committeth the same power unto you Ministers of the word, which execute this office in you name of you Whole Church.

column7: Therfore whersoeuer the worde is preched, receiued & beleued, there also without doubt is remission of sinnes, and that is it that here is vnderstad by losyng.
column8: Therefore wheresoever the word is preached, received & believed, there also without doubt is remission of Sins, and that is it that Here is Understand by losing.

column7: <NOTE> And whersoeuer the word of god is preached & men beleue it not, surely ther remaineth perpetual codemnacio,
column8: And wheresoever the word of god is preached & men believe it not, surely there remains perpetual codemnacio,

column7: & ther is no remissio of sins,
column8: & there is no Remission of Sins,

column7: & that same is here vnderstad by binding.
column8: & that same is Here Understand by binding.

column7: For doutles the promise stadeth here stedfastly & assuredly, yt what so euer ye ministers of ye worde lose vpo earth in the name of the whole congregacion, the same is losed also in earthe:
column8: For doubtless the promise stadeth Here steadfastly & assuredly, that what so ever you Ministers of you word loose upon earth in the name of the Whole congregation, the same is losed also in earth:

column7: And what so euer thei bind vppon earth, the same is bounde also in heauen.
column8: And what so ever they bind upon earth, the same is bound also in heaven.

column7: And doubteles this power is not to bee contemned, for that the minister or priest dothe in this matter, hee doothe it not of himselfe, but god himselfe doothe it, whyche for the same intente, hathe gyuen vnto vs hys woorde and Sacramentes.
column8: And doubtless this power is not to be contemned, for that the minister or priest doth in this matter, he doth it not of himself, but god himself doth it, which for the same intent, hath given unto us his word and Sacraments.

column7: To whome with the sonne and the holy ghost be all honor and prayse, worlde without ende.
column8: To whom with the son and the holy ghost be all honour and praise, world without end.

column7: Amen. The gospell on sainct Mary Magdalenes daye. Luc. 7.
column8: Amen. The gospel on saint Mary Magdalene's day. Luke 7.

column8: Woodcut illustration of Saint Mary Magdalen with long lose hair, helmet and a jar of oil. ANd ANd one of the Pharisees desired him that he would eat with him.

column7: And he went into the Phariseis house,
column8: And he went into the Pharisees house,

column7: & sate downe to meat <NOTE> And beholde, a woman in that Cytye (whyche was a sinner) as soone as shee knewe that Iesus sate at meate in the Phariseis house, she brought and alablaster boxe of oyntement and stode at hys feet behynd hym weeping, and began to washe his feet wyth teares, and did wipe them wyth the heares of hyr heade, and kyssed hys feete, and annoynted theym wyth the oyntement.
column8: & sat down to meat And behold, a woman in that city (which was a sinner) as soon as she knew that jesus sat At meat in the Pharisees house, she brought and alabaster box of ointment and stood At his feet behind him weeping, and began to wash his feet with tears, and did wipe them with the hears of her head, and kissed his feet, and anointed them with the ointment.

column7: When the Pharesey which had bydden hym sawe, hee spake within him selfe, saying:
column8: When the Pharisees which had bidden him saw, he spoke within him self, saying:

column7: If thys man were a prophete, he wold suerly knowe, who, and what maner of woman this is that toucheth hym, for shee is a sinner.
column8: If this man were a Prophet, he would surely know, who, and what manner of woman this is that touches him, for she is a sinner.

column7: And Iesus answered, and sayde vnto hym:
column8: And jesus answered, and said unto him:

column7: Symon, I haue somewhat to saye vnto the.
column8: Symon, I have somewhat to say unto thee.

column7: And he sayde: Maister saye on.
column8: And he said: Master say on.

column7: There was a certaine lender which had two detters:
column8: There was a certain lender which had two debtors:

column7: the one oughte fyue hundreth pence, and the other fyfty.
column8: the one ought fyue Hundredth pence, and the other fyfty.

column7: When they hadde nothynge to pay, he forgaue them both Tell me therfore whyche of theim wyll loue him most?
column8: When they had nothing to pay, he forgave them both Tell me Therefore which of them will love him most?

column7: Symon answered and sayd: I suppose that he to whom he forgaue most.
column8: Symon answered and said: I suppose that he to whom he forgave most.

column7: And he saide vnto him: Thou hast truely iudged.
column8: And he said unto him: Thou hast truly judged.

column7: And he turned to the woman & sayd vnto Symo:
column8: And he turned to the woman & said unto Simo:

column7: Seest thou this woman? I entred into thy house, thou gauest me no water for my feete:
column8: See thou this woman? I entered into thy house, thou Gavest me not water for my feet:

column7: but she hath washed my feete with teares,
column8: but she hath washed my feet with tears,

column7: & wyped them with the heeres of her head.
column8: & wiped them with the Heres of her head.

column7: Thou gauest me no kysse, but she, sence the tyme I came in, hath not ceassed to kysse my feete.
column8: Thou Gavest me not kiss, but she, sense the time I Come in, hath not ceased to kiss my feet.

column7: Myne head with oyle thou dyddest not annoynt, but she hath annoynted my feete with oyntment.
column8: Mine head with oil thou didst not anoint, but she hath anointed my feet with ointment.

column7: Wherfore I say vnto thee, many synnes are forgeuen her, for she loued muche.
column8: Wherefore I say unto thee, many Sins Are forgiven her, for she loved much.

column7: To whom lesse is forgeuen, thesame doth lesse loue.
column8: To whom less is forgiven, The same does less love.

column7: And he sayd vnto her, thy synnes are forgeuen thee.
column8: And he said unto her, thy Sins Are forgiven thee.

column7: And they that satte at meate with him began to say within the selues:
column8: And they that sat At meat with him began to say within the selves:

column7: who is this which forgeueh synnes also?
column8: who is this which forgeueh Sins also?

column7: And he sayd to the woman:
column8: And he said to the woman:

column7: <NOTE> Thy fayth hath saued thee.
column8: Thy faith hath saved thee.

column7: Go in peace. THE EXPOSITION.
column8: Go in peace. THE EXPOSITION.

column7: IN this Gospell deare Christians is fyrst descrybed a poore synner, whiche not onely was come to the knowledge of her synnes, but also by fayth obtained remissio of the.
column8: IN this Gospel deer Christians is fyrst described a poor sinner, which not only was come to the knowledge of her Sins, but also by faith obtained Remission of the.

column7: Wherfore it is a verye necessarye thyng, that this worde,
column8: Wherefore it is a very necessary thing, that this word,

column7: A synfull woman, <NOTE> be well cosidered and wayed in our heartes, that by it we may put a true difference betwene an indurate & blynde synner as was ye Pharisey,
column8: A sinful woman, be well considered and weighed in our hearts, that by it we may put a true difference between an indurate & blind sinner as was the Pharisee,

column7: & a synner that acknowlegeth his myserye & synnes.
column8: & a sinner that acknowledgeth his misery & Sins.

column7: For there are synners whiche are doubtlesse blynded and deliuered into a reprouable sence, as was Pharao, of whom ye scripture sayth, that his heart was hardened.
column8: For there Are Sinners which Are doubtless blinded and Delivered into a reprovable sense, as was Pharaoh, of whom you scripture say, that his heart was hardened.

column7: <NOTE> There are also some that are synners only afore God and not afore the worlde, as the hypocrites, of who the scrip sayth sayth:
column8: There Are also Some that Are Sinners only afore God and not afore the world, as the Hypocrites, of who the scrip say say:

column7: <NOTE> You are those that iustifye your selues afore men.
column8: You Are those that justify your selves afore men.

column7: Notwithstandyng God knoweth your heartes.
column8: Notwithstanding God Knoweth your hearts.

column7: Also there are synners both before God and the world.
column8: Also there Are Sinners both before God and the world.

column7: And forasmuche as their synnes displease them, and thei acknowlege their synnes, therfore especially is the gospell occupyed aboute these afore any other.
column8: And forasmuch as their Sins displease them, and they acknowledge their Sins, Therefore especially is the gospel ocupied about these afore any other.

column7: And suche a synner also was this woman that is spoken of in this gospel.
column8: And such a sinner also was this woman that is spoken of in this gospel.

column7: For she felt her synnes,
column8: For she felt her Sins,

column7: & acknowleged that she had broken the lawe, and further that she had nede of helpe & counsel.
column8: & acknowledged that she had broken the law, and further that she had need of help & counsel.

column7: And therfore maketh she so great hast and deferreth it not, when she had heard that Iesus was in ye Phariseys house, sekyng grace of him that had power and authoritee to remyt sinne.
column8: And Therefore makes she so great haste and deferreth it not, when she had herd that jesus was in the Pharisees house, seeking grace of him that had power and Authority to remit sin.

column7: Furthermore with weapyng teares, annoyntyng, washyng and wypyng his feet, she testifyeth what strong fayth and loue she bare vnto Christ.
column8: Furthermore with weeping tears, anointing, washing and wiping his feet, she Testifieth what strong faith and love she bore unto christ.

column7: <NOTE> And nowe ponder it well, howe excellent a thyng fayth is, that fyrste acknowlegeth her sinnes, and after that fleeth vnto Christ.
column8: And now ponder it well, how excellent a thing faith is, that First acknowledgeth her Sins, and After that fleeth unto christ.

column7: This woman beyng a publike open synner, knewe right well that she should haue but a syngle welcome into the Phariseys house, neither should she escape the rebukes and tauntes of theim, yet so great is her loue and fayth toward Christ, that neglectyng and contemnynge al their rebukes, checkes & other contumelyes, without feare she hasteth vnto Christe, of whom she might obtayne remission of her synnes.
column8: This woman being a public open sinner, knew right well that she should have but a single welcome into the Pharisees house, neither should she escape the rebukes and taunts of them, yet so great is her love and faith towards christ, that neglecting and contemning all their rebukes, Checks & other Contumelies, without Fear she hastes unto Christ, of whom she might obtain remission of her Sins.

column7: Wherfore, nowe note diligetly and cosider the processe & also the successe of this woma, for doubtles she shal teach both the & me, how they must be disposed that wyll obtain remission of their syns of god the father through Christ.
column8: Wherefore, now note diligetly and Consider the process & also the success of this Woman, for doubtless she shall teach both the & me, how they must be disposed that will obtain remission of their Sins of god the father through christ.

column7: Thus sayth the Euangelist: She began to weete his feete with teares.
column8: Thus say the Evangelist: She began to weet his feet with tears.

column7: Teares are a mooste certayne sygne of a penitent mynde, that the synnes displease from the heart.
column8: Tears Are a most certain Signen of a penitent mind, that the Sins displease from the heart.

column7: But what were suche repentaunce without fayth?
column8: But what were such Repentance without faith?

column7: But this woman hath fayth also.
column8: But this woman hath faith also.

column7: <NOTE> Truely it is a great token of fayth in this woman, that settyng light the threttes and checkes of the Phariseys, she hasteth vnto Christe, and that Christe him selfe testifyed, saiyng:
column8: Truly it is a great token of faith in this woman, that setting Light the Treats and Checks of the Pharisees, she hastes unto Christ, and that Christ him self testified, saying:

column7: Thy fayth hath made the safe.
column8: Thy faith hath made the safe.

column7: Nowe doubtles this fayth was not idle in this woman, but is shed furth it selfe through loue.
column8: Now doubtless this faith was not idle in this woman, but is shed forth it self through love.

column7: Are not these manyfest sygnes of loue, that accordyng to the custome of the region, she enbalmeth Christes head with moste precious oyntment, weeteth his feete with teares, kysseth them and wypeth theim with the heares of her heade?
column8: are not these manifest Signs of love, that according to the custom of the region, she enbalmeth Christ's head with most precious ointment, weeteth his feet with tears, kysseth them and wipeth them with the hears of her head?

column7: Euen so it is expedient that wee bee lyke this woman, if at the least wee wyll obtayne eternall health.
column8: Eve so it is expedient that we be like this woman, if At the least we will obtain Eternal health.

column7: <NOTE> Needes muste wee haue a perpetuall penaunce, that is to say, the knowlege of synne, the forsakyng of synne, and the hatyng of synne.
column8: Needs must we have a perpetual penance, that is to say, the knowledge of sin, the forsaking of sin, and the hating of sin.

column7: Furthermore wee muste haue fayth, whereby wee may take holde vpon the promyse of the Gospell:
column8: Furthermore we must have faith, whereby we may take hold upon the promise of the Gospel:

column7: Last of all, it is necessarye that wee declare oure fayth with woorkes of loue, euen as we here se ensaple set surth in this woman.
column8: Last of all, it is necessary that we declare our faith with works of love, even as we Here se Ensample Set surth in this woman.

column7: Secondarily, in this Gospel is Christ descrybed as a good, gentle and mercyfull Lorde.
column8: Secondarily, in this Gospel is christ described as a good, gentle and merciful Lord.

column7: <NOTE> For he receyueth this woman with so great humanitee and gentlenes, nothyng consideryng the murmuryng of the Phariseys, so that this receyuyng should well moue and styrre vppe all synners to true fayth.
column8: For he receiveth this woman with so great humanity and gentleness, nothing considering the murmuring of the Pharisees, so that this receiving should well move and stir up all Sinners to true faith.

column7: Lette vs marke all thynges orderly as they stand, and we shal fynde Christ in all thynges merciful, gentle and ful of compassion, lyke as hee is set forth vnto vs in the scriptures.
column8: Let us mark all things orderly as they stand, and we shall find christ in all things merciful, gentle and full of compassion, like as he is Set forth unto us in the Scriptures.

column7: Fyrst Christ suffereth the sinful woman to annoynt him, he suffereth her to washe his feete and to wype them, he suffereth her to kysse him, whiche no Pharisey would haue suffered to bee done, especially of suche a woman.
column8: Fyrst christ suffers the sinful woman to anoint him, he suffers her to wash his feet and to wipe them, he suffers her to kiss him, which no Pharisee would have suffered to be done, especially of such a woman.

column7: Furthermore, when the Pharisey murmured that he receiued so great a sinner,
column8: Furthermore, when the Pharisee murmured that he received so great a sinner,

column7: Christ defedeth this his facte by a similitude of a creditor that had two debters, the one ought fiue hundreth pence,
column8: christ defedeth this his fact by a similitude of a creditor that had two debtors, the one ought fiue Hundredth pence,

column7: & the other fyfty. Now seyng neither of both wer able to pay, he forgaue them both.
column8: & the other fyfty. Now sing neither of both were able to pay, he forgave them both.

column7: And then he asked Symo:
column8: And then he asked Simo:

column7: Tel me, whether of these twayne shal loue him most? <NOTE> Surely with this similitude Christ sheweth wherfore he came into this worlde, namely for synners.
column8: Tell me, whither of these twayne shall love him most? Surely with this similitude christ shows Wherefore he Come into this world, namely for Sinners.

column7: For without doubt we all are his debters.
column8: For without doubt we all Are his debtors.

column7: And who is it that is not a debter, or that wyll deny this debte?
column8: And who is it that is not a debtor, or that will deny this debt?

column7: If we wyll say (sayth sainct Ihon) that we haue not synne, we deceiue our selues,
column8: If we will say (say saint John) that we have not sin, we deceive our selves,

column7: & the truth is not in vs.
column8: & the truth is not in us

column7: <NOTE> And S. Paule sayeth:
column8: And S. Paul Saith:

column7: All haue synned, and want the glorye of God.
column8: All have sinned, and want the glory of God.

column7: What shall I say of the similitude whiche is written in the gospel of sainct Luke?
column8: What shall I say of the similitude which is written in the gospel of saint Lycia?

column7: To make short, wee all are debters of this Lord which way soeuer we turne our selues.
column8: To make short, we all Are debtors of this Lord which Way soever we turn our selves.

column7: <NOTE> And would to God he would geue vs this grace to knowlege our debt,
column8: And would to God he would give us this grace to knowledge our debt,

column7: & to beleue in Christ whiche for geueth it,
column8: & to believe in christ which for Giveth it,

column7: & also furthermore yt we might find grace as this woman did.
column8: & also furthermore that we might find grace as this woman did.

column7: Doubtles she knowleged her synnes, sought grace, and found it.
column8: Doubtless she knowledged her Sins, sought grace, and found it.

column7: And inasmuche as fiue hundred pence were forgeue her, all her iniquite remitted & pardoned, therfore also she shewed her selfe thankefull and heartely loued him of who she was thus receiued into grace.
column8: And inasmuch as fiue hundred pence were forgive her, all her iniquity remitted & pardoned, Therefore also she showed her self thankful and heartily loved him of who she was thus received into grace.

column7: <NOTE> Wherfore if thou also wylte haue remission of thy synnes, set thy selfe among these debters that owe fyue hundred pence, know thy selfe to be the greatest synner liuyng vpo the yearth, say with ye Publicane:
column8: Wherefore if thou also wilt have remission of thy Sins, Set thy self among these debtors that owe fyue hundred pence, know thy self to be the greatest sinner living upon the earth, say with you Publican:

column7: I am not worthy to looke vp into the heauen, and then aske grace at Christ, beleue the woordes of his Gospel.
column8: I am not worthy to look up into the heaven, and then ask grace At christ, believe the words of his Gospel.

column7: If thou thus do, doubtles thou shalt obtayne thy request.
column8: If thou thus do, doubtless thou shalt obtain thy request.

column7: For that swete worde spoken vnto the woman, pertayneth also aswell vnto yt as vnto her.
column8: For that sweet word spoken unto the woman, pertaineth also aswell unto that as unto her.

column7: The worde is this: Thy synnes are forgeuen thee.
column8: The word is this: Thy Sins Are forgiven thee.

column7: And this worde ought euer to sounde in a christians eare, as oft as our sinnes oppresse vs, and we would gladly be deliuered from them, as wee say in the confession of our fayth:
column8: And this word ought ever to sound in a Christians ear, as oft as our Sins oppress us, and we would gladly be Delivered from them, as we say in the Confessi of our faith:

column7: I beleue that in this life there is perpetually forgeuenes of synnes.
column8: I believe that in this life there is perpetually forgiveness of Sins.

column7: The Churche hath euer synners, as the scripture testifyeth:
column8: The Church hath ever Sinners, as the scripture Testifieth:

column7: The righteous falleth vii. tymes in the day & ryseth agayne.
column8: The righteous falls vii. times in the day & Riseth again.

column7: Therfore seyng that we are so weake that we synne continually, therfore is it nedeful that we may haue contynually remission of synnes in the Churche of Christ, and the christian ought to knowe that these wordes:
column8: Therefore sing that we Are so weak that we sin continually, Therefore is it needful that we may have continually remission of Sins in the Church of christ, and the christian ought to know that these words:

column7: Thy synnes are forgeuen thee, are wordes for all tymes that neuer shalbe disanulled but contynue for euer.
column8: Thy Sins Are forgiven thee, Are words for all times that never shall Disannulled but continue for ever.

column7: Thyrdly, <NOTE> this gospel cotaineth the grudgynges of the Phariseys against Christ, whiche ryse vpon this occasion, that Christ receyued the synful woma and forgaue her all her synnes.
column8: Thirdly, this gospel cotaineth the grudgings of the Pharisees against christ, which rise upon this occasion, that christ received the sinful Woman and forgave her all her Sins.

column7: The cheife of theim was Symon, whiche sayd wtin himselfe:
column8: The chief of them was Symon, which said within himself:

column7: If he were a Prophete, surely he should knowe, who and what woman it is that toucheth him, for she is a synner.
column8: If he were a Prophet, surely he should know, who and what woman it is that touches him, for she is a sinner.

column7: Of these cogitacions a man may perceyue, what is the nature of hypocrisy.

column7: F Yrst we see here in this gospel the ignorance of the Apostles Iames & Ihon, whiche had often heard of Christ, although thei did not receiue it, nor printed it in their memory, that Christes kingdome shuld be a spiritual kyngdom,
column8: FYrst FYrst we see Here in this gospel the ignorance of the Apostles James & John, which had often herd of christ, although they did not receive it, nor printed it in their memory, that Christ's Kingdom should be a spiritual Kingdom,

column7: & euen within them. Yea they were yet so ignoraunt, that they thought they should without any crosse at all been wholly promoted and made great Lordes, and so reigne wt Christe, accordyng to the pompe and glorye of this worlde.
column8: & even within them. Yea they were yet so ignorant, that they Thought they should without any cross At all been wholly promoted and made great lords, and so Reign with Christ, according to the pomp and glory of this world.

column7: But these so fond imaginacions dare they them selues not vtter vnto Christe, althoughe they set not a litle by these, but moued their mother to go to Christ, to proue whether she might obtayn yt they desired.
column8: But these so found Imaginations Dare they them selves not utter unto Christ, although they Set not a little by these, but moved their mother to go to christ, to prove whither she might obtain that they desired.

column7: But what was their request?
column8: But what was their request?

column7: Forsoth that in the kyngdome of Christe, whiche they thought a worldely kyngdome, one might haue his seate vpo the right hand, another vpon the lefte hand, and so to enioy the honor of this worlde.
column8: Forsooth that in the Kingdom of Christ, which they Thought a worldly Kingdom, one might have his seat upon the right hand, Another upon the left hand, and so to enjoy the honour of this world.

column7: Here it had been the mothers duetye, to bryng her sonnes from this purpose & mynde,
column8: Here it had been the mother's duty, to bring her Sons from this purpose & mind,

column7: & to haue enstructed them muche better.
column8: & to have instructed them much better.

column7: But in these matters that appertayne to the kyndome of Christ, the mother is as blynde & ignorant as her sonnes.
column8: But in these matters that appertain to the kyndome of christ, the mother is as blind & ignorant as her Sons.

column7: She would gladly haue had her sonnes promoted and made great men, euen as customably many mothers boast ye pompe & ryches with their children.
column8: She would gladly have had her Sons promoted and made great men, even as customably many mother's boast you pomp & riches with their children.

column7: But the kyngdome of Christ is not so ordered, to haue in it muche pope & boasting, but as it is a spirituall kyngdome, euen so it hath onely a spiritual scepter, namely the worde and the holy gospel.
column8: But the Kingdom of christ is not so ordered, to have in it much pope & boasting, but as it is a spiritual Kingdom, even so it hath only a spiritual sceptre, namely the word and the holy gospel.

column7: And nowe this worde is suche a worde that it bringeth with it not a pleasant lyfe, but contradiction & persecucion, <NOTE> insomuche that S.
column8: And now this word is such a word that it brings with it not a pleasant life, but contradiction & persecution, insomuch that S.

column7: Paule calleth it the worde of the crosse, saiyng:
column8: Paul calls it the word of the cross, saying:

column8: The word of the cross is to them that perish, folly, but to us that obtain health, it is the power of God.

column7: If then it be the worde of the crosse, how can we haue in the kyngdome of Christe, other pleasure, pompe or honours of this worlde?
column8: If then it be the word of the cross, how can we have in the Kingdom of Christ, other pleasure, pomp or honours of this world?

column7: It is not to be loked for, but nedes must wee here suffre,
column8: It is not to be looked for, but needs must we Here suffer,

column7: <NOTE> that he must needes suffre and ryse agayne from the dead,
column8: that he must needs suffer and rise again from the dead,

column7: & so to entre into his glorye.
column8: & so to enter into his glory.

column7: But as yet Iames and Ihon vnderstoode not this, therefore they iudged it should bee in the kyngdome of Christe, as it was in other ciuyl kyngdomes.
column8: But as yet James and John understood not this, Therefore they judged it should be in the Kingdom of Christ, as it was in other ciuyl kingdoms.

column7: And surely as these Apostles were then ignoraunt of the kyngdome of Christ, so doubtles are wee, excepte wee bee lightened by the holy ghost.
column8: And surely as these Apostles were then ignorant of the Kingdom of christ, so doubtless Are we, except we be lightened by the holy ghost.

column7: Secondarily, <NOTE> wee haue here also an example of the presumpcion of manne.
column8: Secondarily, we have Here also an Exampl of the presumption of man.

column8: For besides their petition which was against God, they Dare also say, that they were able to drink the cup which the Lord should drink, and to be baptised with the Baptism, which the Lord should be baptised in.

column7: What iudge you of this presumpcion?
column8: What judge you of this presumption?

column7: But what is that? Forsoth the same commyng that is wrought in vs only by the holy ghost.

column8: Therefore if Christ cast not of his Disciples,

column7: <NOTE> bicause of their weakenes, but beareth with them with all humanitie and gentlenes, tyll they might come to the trewe vnderstanding, doubtles no more becometh it vs to condemn those yt are weake, but muche rather it is our deuty to instructe & teache them, and to bring them vnto better knowledge.
column8: Because of their weakness, but bears with them with all humanity and gentleness, till they might come to the true understanding, doubtless no more Becometh it us to condemn those that Are weak, but much rather it is our duty to instruct & teach them, and to bring them unto better knowledge.

column7: Here note diligently, that Christ speaketh sometimes as a man, and sometime as god.

column8: In the gospel of saint John christ say:

column8: Here christ makes himself in all things equal with you father.

column8: Therefore needs must this place be understand of you godly nature of christ.

column8: Except this be understand of Christ's human nature,

column7: Wherfore it is very necessary to note diligently (as we before admonished) when Christ speaketh as ma and whe he speaketh as God.
column8: Wherefore it is very necessary to note diligently (as we before admonished) when christ speaks as ma and when he speaks as God.

column7: And also furthermore note this, that vnto the kyngdome of Christ & vnto that ioy that is euerlasting none can bryng vs, but God only, which prepared it for vs from the beginnyng of the worlde.
column8: And also furthermore note this, that unto the Kingdom of christ & unto that joy that is everlasting none can bring us, but God only, which prepared it for us from the beginning of the world.

column7: This is altogether in his power to geue it vnto whom he wyll.
column8: This is altogether in his power to give it unto whom he will.

column7: Nowe if this power bee all in him, where are then oure woorkes?
column8: Now if this power be all in him, where Are then our works?

column7: where is our vertue, righteousnesse or holynes?
column8: where is our virtue, righteousness or holiness?

column7: Doubtles we are bound to do good workes, ye and to be vertuous, righteous & holy, for Christes wyll is that oure light should shyne before menne to the glory of our heauenly father.
column8: Doubtless we Are bound to do good works, you and to be virtuous, righteous & holy, for Christ's will is that our Light should shine before men to the glory of our heavenly father.

column7: This is very truth, & who can deny it?
column8: This is very truth, & who can deny it?

column7: But here must wee diligently take hede, that vnto our iustificacion no mannes worke or merite be ioyned with al, for that cometh onely of fayth, wherin also the grace, goodnes and mercy of God worketh altogether, whiche onely is apprehended by fayth.
column8: But Here must we diligently take heed, that unto our justification no Man's work or merit be joined with all, for that comes only of faith, wherein also the grace, Goodness and mercy of God works altogether, which only is apprehended by faith.

column7: And where as this fayth is, there is also forgeuenes of synnes, righteousnes & eternall saluacion is.
column8: And where as this faith is, there is also forgiveness of Sins, righteousness & Eternal salvation is.

column7: Then folowe good workes, as ye fruites, tokens and argumetes of true fayth.
column8: Then follow good works, as you fruits, tokens and Arguments of true faith.

column8: But this have we sufficiently treated upon before.

column8: Only the Lord God give us grace to perceive it and retain it in our hearts.

column8: And I appoint unto you a Kingdom, as my father hath appointed to me, that you may eat and drink At my table im my Kingdom, and syttee on seats, judging the xii. tribes of Israel. column7: And surely a ma might wel meruaile, that the Apostles whiche had heard Christ so long, yet had obtayned no more vnderstadyng of ye spiritual kyngdome of Christ, and of spiritual thynges.
column8: And surely a ma might well marvel, that the Apostles which had herd christ so long, yet had obtained no more vnderstadyng of you spiritual Kingdom of christ, and of spiritual things.

column7: Yea, and if we consider at what tyme this strife and contencion was, surely the infirmitee of ye Apostles shal appeare farre more and greater, then if it had chaunced at some other tyme.

column7: <NOTE> The wisedome of the flesh, is enmitye to god, for it is not subiect to the lawe of god, nor in very deede it can not be.
column8: The Wisdom of the Flesh, is enmity to god, for it is not Subject to the law of god, nor in very deed it can not be.

column7: You heare nowe in this place, that it is not in our power to obey to the law of god.
column8: You hear now in this place, that it is not in our power to obey to the law of god.

column7: Why then defend we so earnestly and so highly commend the strengthes of man and free will?
column8: Why then defend we so earnestly and so highly commend the strength's of man and free will?

column7: I beseche the knowledg it, euen in the example of the Apostles, what and how greate the infirmitie and powers of man is, the without doubt shalt thou the better vnderstand, what thou must looke for of Christe.
column8: I beseech the knowledge it, even in the Exampl of the Apostles, what and how great the infirmity and Powers of man is, the without doubt shalt thou the better understand, what thou must look for of Christ.

column7: For truelye thou shalte neuer haue the knoweledge of Christe, except thou fyrste knowe thy selfe.
column8: For truly thou shalt never have the knowledge of Christ, except thou First know thy self.

column7: <NOTE> Secondarily, we se here with howe great pacyence Christe beareth this infirmity of the Apostels, and many times familiarly talketh with them and teacheth them.
column8: Secondarily, we see Here with how great patience Christ bears this infirmity of the Apostles, and many times familiarly talketh with them and Teaches them.

column7: The kinges (saithe Christe) of the heythen, beare rule ouer theym, and those that vse power ouer theym, are called gracious lordes.
column8: The Kings (Saith Christ) of the Heathen, bear Rule over them, and those that use power over them, Are called gracious Lords.

column7: In which wordes Christ confirmeth the ciuyl empiers and dominions of this world, but he approueth it not in the Apostles.
column8: In which words christ confirmeth the ciuyl empires and Dominions of this world, but he approveth it not in the Apostles.

column7: For other men are called vnto those degrees and offices.
column8: For other men Are called unto those Degrees and Offices.

column7: Who ar they? Kinges of the Heithen, princes & other great men.
column8: Who Are they? Kings of the Heithen, Princes & other great men.

column7: For douteles vnto them is the sweard giuen and committed, (as Paule saith) to punish the euel,
column8: For doubtless unto them is the sword given and committed, (as Paul Says) to Punish the evil,

column7: <NOTE> and defend the good and vertuous.
column8: and defend the good and virtuous.

column7: And forasmuche as they haue this sweard comitted to them of god,
column8: And forasmuch as they have this sword committed to them of god,

column7: & not of theim selues, therfore we the residue of the people must obey and be subiect to this ordinaunce of god, for coscience sake.
column8: & not of them selves, Therefore we the residue of the people must obey and be Subject to this Ordinance of god, for conscience sake.

column7: <NOTE> And S. Peter saith:
column8: And S. Peter Says:

column7: Bee subiect vnto euery humane ordinaunce for the lordes sake.
column8: be Subject unto every humane Ordinance for the Lords sake.

column7: And when the souldiers came to S.
column8: And when the Soldiers Come to S.

column7: Iohn & asked hym, <NOTE> saying:
column8: John & asked him, saying:

column7: What shall we do to be saued?
column8: What shall we do to be saved?

column7: He comaunded not them to lay away their sweardes, but that they shuld oppresse no man, nor do no man wrong.
column8: He commanded not them to lay away their swords, but that they should oppress no man, nor do not man wrong.

column7: And euen so Christe in this place acknowledgeth, ye kinges and prynces & other magistrates must haue the dominion,
column8: And even so Christ in this place acknowledgeth, you Kings and Princes & other Magistrates must have the dominion,

column7: & that their dominions and regimentes are gods owne ordinaunce, notwithstanding he wil bi no meanes admit his apostels and ministers of his worde vnto suche cyuyle impery.
column8: & that their Dominions and regiments Are God's own Ordinance, notwithstanding he will by no means admit his Apostles and Ministers of his word unto such Cuvile impery.

column7: As for you (saith Christ) you shal not be so.
column8: As for you (Says christ) you shall not be so.

column7: How then? He that is the greater among you, shal be as the yongest:
column8: How then? He that is the greater among you, shall be as the youngest:

column7: & the chiefest shalbe as a seruaunt.
column8: & the chiefest shall as a servant.

column7: You se here howe goodly Christ turneth all otherwise.
column8: You see Here how goodly christ turns all otherwise.

column7: The disciples would be rulers, and Christ deposeth them from al cyuile goueruenaile.
column8: The Disciples would be Rulers, and christ deposeth them from all Civil goueruenaile.

column7: The disciples wold be lordes,
column8: The Disciples would be Lords,

column7: & Christ maketh the seruantes.
column8: & christ makes the Servants.

column7: Doth he this (think ye) lawfully, and did he him self abstaine from such imperye and power?
column8: Does he this (think you) lawfully, and did he him self abstain from such impery and power?

column7: Yea doubteles. <NOTE> For thus wryteth S.
column8: Yea doubtless. For thus writes S.

column7: Paul: Let the same mynde be among you, that was in Christ Iesu, which whe he was in form of god, he thought it not robbery to be equal with god, but he humbleth him self, taking the forme of a seruant, made in the similitude of men, and in habite found as man, he meketh himselfe & was made obedient vnto the death, yea the death of the crosse.
column8: Paul: Let the same mind be among you, that was in christ Jesu, which when he was in from of god, he Thought it not robbery to be equal with god, but he Humbleth him self, taking the Form of a servant, made in the similitude of men, and in habit found as man, he meketh himself & was made obedient unto the death, yea the death of the cross.

column7: And euen so Christ in this gospel allegeth his own example, saying:
column8: And even so christ in this gospel allegeth his own Exampl, saying:

column7: Who is greater, he that sitteth, or he that serueth?
column8: Who is greater, he that Sitteth, or he that serveth?

column7: Is not he that sitteth?
column8: Is not he that Sitteth?

column7: And I am among you, as he that serueth.
column8: And I am among you, as he that serveth.

column7: <NOTE> Heare you not howe Christ, although he was lorde, yet he meketh hym selfe and is made a seruaunt to vs?
column8: Hear you not how christ, although he was lord, yet he meketh him self and is made a servant to us?

column7: Euen so muste the apostels and all minysters of the woorde doo.
column8: Eve so must the Apostles and all Ministers of the word do.

column7: They maye beare rule, but yet so as CHRIST bare rule in this world, and as S.
column8: They may bear Rule, but yet so as CHRIST bore Rule in this world, and as S.

column7: Paule said: <NOTE> Let men so esteeme vs, as the ministers of Christe, and dispensers of the mysteries of God.
column8: Paul said: Let men so esteem us, as the Ministers of Christ, and dispensers of the Mysteres of God.

column7: Surely this gospel is a fearefull gospel to our Byshoppes and priestes.
column8: Surely this gospel is a fearful gospel to our Bishops and Priests.

column7: For it is to be feared, except they vse them selues otherwyse in expoundyng the worde of God then they haue done before tyme, this gospell wyll eternally condempne them.
column8: For it is to be feared, except they use them selves otherwise in expounding the word of God then they have done before time, this gospel will eternally condemn them.

column7: Thyrdly, there is in this gospel a notable and excellent promise, that Christ wyl ordain and appoint to his Apostles & all his electes a kyngdome, euen as his heauenly father hath appointed him, yt they may eat & drynke vpo his table in that kyngdom,
column8: Thirdly, there is in this gospel a notable and excellent promise, that christ will ordain and appoint to his Apostles & all his elects a Kingdom, even as his heavenly father hath appointed him, that they may eat & drink upon his table in that Kingdom,

column7: & furthermore syt vpon seates iudgyng the xii. tribes of Israel.
column8: & furthermore fit upon seats judging the xii. tribes of Israel.

column7: Who would not nowe gladly & with all his heart lay himselfe vnder this crosse, to suffre wt Christ in this worlde, seyng that by his passion wee shal entre into that great glory?
column8: Who would not now gladly & with all his heart lay himself under this cross, to suffer with christ in this world, sing that by his passion we shall enter into that great glory?

column7: Doubtles thei are fooles & without wyt, that more set by & esteme this temporal and smal ioye and voluptuous pleasures of this worlde, then that glorious kyngdome that Christ wyll geue to his after this life.
column8: Doubtless they Are Fools & without wit, that more Set by & esteem this temporal and small joy and voluptuous pleasures of this world, then that glorious Kingdom that christ will give to his After this life.

column7: Truth it is, ye Apostles fell in this thyng & desired this temporall glory.
column8: Truth it is, you Apostles fell in this thing & desired this temporal glory.

column7: But what do ye thynke by this, did not they after that their had receiued the holy ghost, cotemne and set not a strawe by this worldely glory?
column8: But what do you think by this, did not they After that their had received the holy ghost, cotemne and Set not a straw by this worldly glory?

column7: I long (sayd Paule) to be dissolued,
column8: I long (said Paul) to be dissolved,

column7: <NOTE> and to be with Christ.
column8: and to be with christ.

column7: Item Christ is life to me,
column8: Item christ is life to me,

column7: & death is aduantage. He sayd not, that he desired to be a Lord & beare rule, or to desire the worldly glory, or that the glorye of the worlde shuld be to him aduantage, but this wisheth he with most heartie desire, to be with Christ in his kyngdome.
column8: & death is advantage. He said not, that he desired to be a Lord & bear Rule, or to desire the worldly glory, or that the glory of the world should be to him advantage, but this wishes he with most hearty desire, to be with christ in his Kingdom.

column7: <NOTE> And here note, ye Christes kyngdome is spiritual, and though it standeth in this world & is begon by the word & spirit, yet shal it not be made perfecte and ende in this worlde, but in the worlde to come.
column8: And Here note, the Christ's Kingdom is spiritual, and though it Stands in this world & is begun by the word & Spirit, yet shall it not be made perfect and end in this world, but in the world to come.

column7: Nowe as this kyngdome is spiritual,
column8: Now as this Kingdom is spiritual,

column7: <NOTE> so to eate and drynke in it, is also spiritual.
column8: so to eat and drink in it, is also spiritual.

column7: And this is the meanyng of Christ:
column8: And this is the meaning of christ:

column7: In this worlde truely you shall haue smal ioye, for you are not of this worlde, therfore the worlde shall persecute & shall hate you, but be of a good comforte, for this persecucion shal ones haue an ende.
column8: In this world truly you shall have small joy, for you Are not of this world, Therefore the world shall persecute & shall hate you, but be of a good Comfort, for this persecution shall ones have an end.

column7: I wyll then receiue you into my kyngdome,
column8: I will then receive you into my Kingdom,

column7: In the whiche kyngdome ye shal enioy perpetual peace, ioye & aboundance of all spiritual riches.
column8: In the which Kingdom you shall enjoy perpetual peace, joy & abundance of all spiritual riches.

column7: And God shal wype al teares fro your eyes, and death shal be no more, nor lamentacion, nor criyng, nor sorowe shalbe any more, for they are gone before.
column8: And God shall wipe all tears from your eyes, and death shall be no more, nor lamentation, nor crying, nor sorrow shall any more, for they Are gone before.

column7: If ye haue sowed in teares, ye shall reape in gladnes.
column8: If you have sowed in tears, you shall reap in gladness.

column7: And in like maner must we speake of the thrones and iudgement.
column8: And in like manner must we speak of the thrones and judgement.

column7: For all these thynges are spiritual.
column8: For all these things Are spiritual.

column7: Those that beleue may iudge all thynges by the woorde, and they can bee iudged of no man.
column8: Those that believe may judge all things by the word, and they can be judged of no man.

column7: Furthermore at that daye they shalbe wytnesses to those that beleued their woordes, that they may bee saued, and against those yt beleued not their wordes to conuince theim, that they may be cast awaye and dampned for euer.
column8: Furthermore At that day they shall Witnesses to those that believed their words, that they may be saved, and against those that believed not their words to convince them, that they may be cast away and dampened for ever.

column7: In summe, Christ promiseth his Apostles, those that haue folowed him, despisyng ye pouertie of the worlde and the contempte & hatered of the Phariseys,
column8: In sum, christ promises his Apostles, those that have followed him, despising the poverty of the world and the contempt & hatered of the Pharisees,

column7: & do obay him, that thei shal haue his kyngdome, perpetual saluacion,
column8: & do obey him, that they shall have his Kingdom, perpetual salvation,

column7: & euerlastyng ioy, whiche promise is not to ye Apostles only, but to all that beleue in him, and cotinue vnto the ende in his fayth.
column8: & everlasting joy, which promise is not to you Apostles only, but to all that believe in him, and cotinue unto the end in his faith.

column7: Whiche God graut vs through his only sonne our Lord Iesus Christ.
column8: Which God Graut us through his only son our Lord jesus christ.

column7: Amen. The gospel on sainct Mathewes day the Apostle and Euangelistes day. Math. 9.
column8: Amen. The gospel on saint Matthew day the Apostle and Evangelists day. Math. 9.
