column8: This saying of christ what is it Else, but as he would say:

column7: I send you wholly wtout weapon among extreme and cruel enemyes?
column8: I send you wholly without weapon among extreme and cruel enemies?

column7: What peace, traquilitee, or comfort shall a ma loke for amonges suche enemies? <NOTE> Surely this saiyng was necessary to be spoken to the Apostles and disciples of Christ For when they should be sent of Christ to preache,
column8: What peace, traquilitee, or Comfort shall a ma look for among such enemies? Surely this saying was necessary to be spoken to the Apostles and Disciples of christ For when they should be sent of christ to preach,

column7: that the kyngdom of Messias was nere at hande & already come, they were put in remembrance of persecutions and afflictions that should happen vnto them, because they should not imagyne and dreame of a corporal kyngdom of Messias:
column8: that the Kingdom of Messias was never At hand & already come, they were put in remembrance of persecutions and afflictions that should happen unto them, Because they should not imagine and dream of a corporal Kingdom of Messias:

column7: and that they shuld perceiue also, that when ye Prophetes settyng furth the peaceable, ioyfull & happye kyngdome of Messias, they did not speake of the outward peace and tranquilitee of this worlde, but of the spiritual maiestie & perpetuall felicitee, then preached by the Gospell, and afterwarde to be manyfested vnto the whole worlde.
column8: and that they should perceive also, that when you prophets setting forth the peaceable, joyful & happy Kingdom of Messias, they did not speak of the outward peace and tranquillity of this world, but of the spiritual majesty & perpetual felicity, then preached by the Gospel, and afterward to be manifested unto the Whole world.

column7: For if the kyngdome of Christe were of this worlde,
column8: For if the Kingdom of Christ were of this world,

column7: Christ should not haue sent his Apostles as shepe among Wolues, but rather he would haue brought it to passe, that they shuld haue been had in great reputacion, and should haue been honourably entreated and receiued, as it had become suche a great kynges Ambassadors.
column8: christ should not have sent his Apostles as sheep among Wolves, but rather he would have brought it to pass, that they should have been had in great reputation, and should have been honourably entreated and received, as it had become such a great Kings ambassadors.

column7: But nowe he setteth theim furth into many daungers, saiyng:
column8: But now he sets them forth into many dangers, saying:

column7: They shall deliuer you vp (sayth he) to ye counsails,
column8: They shall deliver you up (say he) to the Counsels,

column7: <NOTE> and shall scourge you in their synagoges.
column8: and shall scourge you in their Synagogues.

column7: <NOTE> And ye shall be brought to the head rulers and kynges for my sake.
column8: And you shall be brought to the head Rulers and Kings for my sake.

column7: And in another place he sayth:
column8: And in Another place he say:

column7: <NOTE> They shall put you to trouble and shall kyll you, and ye shal be hated of all people for my names sake.
column8: They shall put you to trouble and shall kill you, and you shall be hated of all people for my names sake.

column7: Thesame that Christ preacheth here to his Apostles, partaineth to all other priuate persons, beleuyng the wordes of the Apostles.
column8: The same that christ Preacheth Here to his Apostles, partaineth to all other private Persons, believing the words of the Apostles.

column7: For euery manne in his owne vocacion is sent like a Lambe among Wolues.
column8: For every man in his own vocation is sent like a Lamb among Wolves.

column7: And necessarily wee must entre through many afflictio^s into the kyngdom of God.
column8: And necessarily we must enter through many afflictio^s into the Kingdom of God.

column7: For we must bee euer on the sufferyng syde.
column8: For we must be ever on the suffering side.

column7: The Lambe hurteth not, he spoyleth not, nor deuoureth.
column8: The Lamb hurteth not, he spoileth not, nor devoureth.

column7: But he is hurt, spoyled & deuoured.
column8: But he is hurt, spoiled & devoured.

column7: So likewyse the smal and weake flocke of Christ is of other iniured, spoyled, and troubled.
column8: So likewise the small and weak flock of christ is of other injured, spoiled, and troubled.

column7: We must (I say) by many tribulacions enter into the kyngdome of heauen.
column8: We must (I say) by many tribulations enter into the Kingdom of heaven.

column7: Also we are here commaunded not to be carefull, but euery man in folowing his vocacion muste bee diligent to execute the same, trusting and beleuing that god so wil prouide and care for vs, that we shal lacke nothinge. as it apeareth in his apostels and disciples whom he sente forthe without any wallet, scrip or shooes, yet thei did lack nothing, for whe he did ask the whether they had lacked ani thig or no, thei answered:
column8: Also we Are Here commanded not to be careful, but every man in following his vocation must be diligent to execute the same, trusting and believing that god so will provide and care for us, that we shall lack nothing. as it appeareth in his Apostles and Disciples whom he sent forth without any wallet, scrip or shoes, yet they did lack nothing, for when he did ask the whither they had lacked ani thig or no, they answered:

column7: No. Therefore let vs (as Christ comandeth vs) seke first the kingdom of god, and the righteousnes thereof, and all these thinges shal be ministred vnto vs.
column8: No. Therefore let us (as christ commandeth us) seek First the Kingdom of god, and the righteousness thereof, and all these things shall be ministered unto us

column7: Filftey, here is to be noted, that we must earnestly and diligently do that which we are bidden to do, and not to be withdrawen from it by no manner of wayes, nother vnder pretence of loue and friendeshippe, or visityng our friends, and saluting them, but (as the disciples were commaunded) to go forwards and not to be stayed or returned by any such meetings & communings by the way, so neglecting our offyce.
column8: Fifty, Here is to be noted, that we must earnestly and diligently do that which we Are bidden to do, and not to be withdrawn from it by no manner of ways, neither under pretence of love and friendeshippe, or visiting our Friends, and saluting them, but (as the Disciples were commanded) to go forward and not to be stayed or returned by any such meetings & communings by the Way, so neglecting our office.

column7: After this manner did Eliza the Prophete saye vnto his seruaunt:
column8: After this manner did Eliza the Prophet say unto his servant:

column7: If ye mete any man, salute him not:
column8: If you meet any man, salute him not:

column7: and if anye salute the, answere him not againe.
column8: and if any salute thee, answer him not again.

column7: Wherwith commaunding him, that he diligentlye and spedely shuld do and performe hys maisters busines and commaundement.
column8: Wherewith commanding him, that he diligently and speedily should do and perform his masters business and Commandment.

column7: Wherfore let euery man so apply and take heede in his vocation that god thereby may be glorified and praysed To whome with the sonne and holy, ghost be all honour, worlde without ende.
column8: Wherefore let every man so apply and take heed in his vocation that god thereby may be glorified and praised To whom with the son and holy, ghost be all honour, world without end.

column7: Amen.
column8: Amen.

column7: Certayne fautes which at the fyrst sight might stay the reader, are these:
column8: Certain Faults which At the fyrst sighed might stay the reader, Are these:

column7: The fyrst numbre, signifieth the lease of the queyre:
column8: The fyrst numbered, signifies the lease of the queyre:

column7: the seconde numbre, the syde.
column8: the seconde numbered, the side.

column7: b. 1. the second syde, for mothes, reade mouthes. b. 2. facie. 1. what shall signes, what signes shal. b. 3. fac. 1. doth loke his mayster, loke for his maister. c. 2 fac, 2. then so, then to. c. 5 fa. 1. folish folishnes, folio eodem, mystery, ministery. d. 2. 1. a mes, armes. d 3. 1 he aith, he saith. e. 1. did long, did not longe. e. 8. 1. inogh, ynough. f. 3. 2 our neceues, our necessaries. f. 4. 1. this is place, this place it is. f. 5. 1. and wag battail, and wage battail. eodem, shall say, shal heare. f. 6. 2. satisfaction, sanctificacion. g. 1. 2. so much, adde, so much to who it pleaseth him. g. 4. 1. faith by hearyng, faith cometh by heryng. h. 5. 1. laiyng, saying. h. 5. 2. wold worlde, k. 4. 1. doth he giue, doth he not giue.
column8: b. 1. the second side, for moths, read mouths. b. 2. fancy. 1. what shall Signs, what Signs shall. b. 3. fac. 1. does look his master, look for his master. c. 2 fac, 2. then so, then to. c. 5 fa. 1. foolish foolishness, folio Eodem, mystery, Ministry. worser. 2. 1. a mes, arms. worser 3. 1 he aith, he Says. e. 1. did long, did not long. e. 8. 1. inogh, enough. f. 3. 2 our neceues, our necessaries. f. 4. 1. this is place, this place it is. f. 5. 1. and wag battle, and wage battle. Eodem, shall say, shall hear. f. 6. 2. satisfaction, sanctification. g. 1. 2. so much, add, so much to who it Pleases him. g. 4. 1. faith by hearing, faith comes by hearing. h. 5. 1. laying, saying. h. 5. 2. wold world, k. 4. 1. does he give, does he not give.

column7: Where the gospell on Easter daye is appointed Mathew. 28. take for it Marc. 16. for the exposition is applyed to the same. o. 2. 1. whiche go, which would go, p. 2. 1. deseching, besechinge. s:
column8: Where the gospel on Easter day is appointed Matthew. 28. take for it Marc. 16. for the exposition is applied to the same. oh. 2. 1. which go, which would go, p. 2. 1. deseching, beseeching. s:

column8: 5. 2. mihtely, mightily. v. 2. 2 christ was,
